Entry Requirement: To be eligible for the BA (Hons) Accounting and Finance (Top-Up) degree, applicants must possess one of the following qualifications: an HND or Foundation Degree in Accounting or Finance (or an international equivalent); ACCA papers F1-F6 or ACCA F1-F5 and F7; a CIMA Advanced Diploma; an ABE Advanced Diploma in Business Administration; or an IBAM Advanced Diploma in Business Administration.  If English is not your first language, you'll need an IELTS score of at least 6.0, a TOEFL score of 550 (paper-based), 213 (computer-based), or 80 (internet-based), a Pearson Test of Academic English score of 51, a Cambridge Advanced Certificate pass, a London Test of English level 4, an International GCE O-level English Language grade C, or an International GCSE English/English as a Second Language grade C.  For Pakistani students, entry requirements will vary depending on previous qualifications. If studied at the A-levels or International Baccalaureate within Pakistan, direct entry to the first year is possible.  Those with degrees directly equivalent to UK second class honours degrees will be considered.
Overview: The University of Derby's online BA (Hons) Accounting and Finance (Top-Up) degree is designed for students who already hold a relevant qualification, allowing them to complete a full bachelor's degree.  The program provides a comprehensive understanding of accounting and business concepts, preparing graduates for careers in accounting, finance, and other related fields.  The curriculum combines core modules with optional subjects, allowing for some specialization within accounting and finance.  The course is taught by qualified professionals with both academic and industry experience, ensuring the curriculum is current and relevant to modern business practices.  Students benefit from a flexible online format, allowing professionals or those returning to work the option of a part-time study schedule.
Course Structure: The program requires a total of 120 credits.  Core modules account for 80 credits, while 40 credits are earned from two optional modules chosen from available concentrations.  Students can choose to study at an accelerated rate of two modules per term to complete the degree quicker. Although the list of optional modules is not provided, it can be assumed that the optional modules provide students a choice within the Accounting and Finance fields.  Assessment is exclusively based on coursework, which could include assignments such as essays, research reports, presentations, group work, and practical reports.  The university partnerships with organizations such as CISI (Chartered Institute for Securities and Investment) enhance the programme's credibility and career prospects, providing opportunities to take external exams.
Year 1: NA
Year 2: NA

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical UCAS points are 112.  A-Level requirements are BBC, BTEC is DMM, and a T Level Merit is required.  GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/Grade C (or above) or equivalent are needed. An Access to HE Diploma with 60 credits is also acceptable: 45 at Level 3 with a minimum of Distinction: 15, Merit: 24, Pass: 6.  Contextual offers may apply for students meeting specific criteria, including those who are care experienced, estranged from families, refugees, asylum seekers, or whose parents/carers are in the UK armed forces.  Students from Pakistan studying A-Levels or the IB from International Schools can enter the first year.  Postgraduate applicants from Pakistan need a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree, and a Master's degree if their Bachelor's was two or three years. A four-year Bachelor's with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 is also considered. PhD applicants require a Master's and Bachelor's degree in a relevant subject, along with a research proposal.
Annual Tuition Fee: UK: £9,535 per year; International: £16,900 per year
Overview: The University of Derby's Accounting and Finance BA (Hons) is a three-year undergraduate program designed to equip students with a comprehensive understanding of accounting and financial principles.  The course is accredited by the European Foundation for Management Development (EFMD) and offers exemptions from various professional accounting bodies like ACCA, CIMA, ICAEW, CPA Australia, and AIA.  Students benefit from industry partnerships, including a Mazars Accelerate Pathway (MAP) offering paid student placements and mentoring. The curriculum integrates practical experience through live consultancy projects, field trips, and the use of industry-standard software such as Sage and Bloomberg.  Assessment methods are varied, allowing students to choose between exam-based and non-exam-based options, and include computer-based assessments, essays, reports, presentations, and employer-negotiated briefs.  The program emphasizes personal academic tutoring and career development support, enabling students to build valuable skills and network with professionals.
Course Structure: The course structure involves a combination of formal lectures, tutorials, workshops, and industry projects.  The curriculum covers key accounting and financial principles, with students progressing to more independent learning and research in later years.  Modules likely include financial accounting, management accounting, auditing, taxation, and financial management, but specifics are not listed. The program incorporates practical experience through live consultancy assignments and collaborations with organizations like Hays.  A professional development module prepares students for internships and graduate roles. The final year includes an independent study module, allowing in-depth research into chosen areas, potentially involving live briefs for employers.
Year 1: The first year will likely focus on foundational concepts in accounting and finance.  Students will be introduced to fundamental accounting principles, financial reporting, and basic financial analysis techniques. The curriculum might introduce business-related subjects as context for accounting. Introductory modules might prepare students for upper-year specializations, such as auditing or taxation.  The year will incorporate workshops on basic software skills and preparation for professional accounting qualifications.
Year 2: Year two will delve into more advanced topics within accounting and finance.  Students will likely cover more in-depth financial accounting, management accounting, and auditing techniques.  Specific subjects explored may include cost accounting, budgeting, performance measurement, or financial statement analysis.  The professional development module would be undertaken in this year to better prepare the students for the workplace by giving them the necessary workplace-based skills.
Year 3: The third year allows for specialization and in-depth study.   Students would focus on advanced areas like international taxation, corporate finance, financial analysis, and financial modelling.  The independent study module enables deeper exploration of a chosen theme, potentially involving research and a project for an employer.  Students can take a placement year during the third year after successful application.

Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with 5.5 in each skills area
Entry Requirement: For the MSc, a good honours degree with an accounting background is usually required.  If English isn't your first language, IELTS 6.5 with at least 5.5 in each skill is needed.  To benefit from the dual learning, a good honours degree in Accounting with exemptions from the first 9 ACCA papers or having passed ACCA F1-F9 is required. ACCA registration is the student's responsibility.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognised university in Pakistan, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree is needed. Students with a two or three-year Bachelor's degree must also have a Master's degree. A Bachelor's degree with honours (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University is also acceptable.
Overview: The University of Derby's MSc Accounting and Finance is a challenging, intellectually stimulating program designed to prepare students for senior finance roles globally.  The curriculum blends technical and strategic learning, developing advanced financial techniques and knowledge.  Students enhance their employability through skill-building in critical thinking, communication, teamwork, and leadership.  The program offers a dual approach, allowing students with ACCA exemptions to work towards their professional level papers alongside their master's.  The course links academic content to real-life business scenarios through consultancy projects, guest lectures, mentoring, and internships, fostering practical experience and networking opportunities.  Taught by professionally qualified accountants with extensive experience, the program provides a dynamic and supportive learning environment, including a Financial Markets Lab for hands-on experience.
Course Structure: The MSc Accounting and Finance is composed of three stages: Postgraduate Certificate, Postgraduate Diploma, and MSc.  The Postgraduate Certificate includes modules like Strategic Business Leader, Market Analysis, and Corporate Reporting. The Postgraduate Diploma builds upon this with modules such as Advanced Financial Management, Advanced Performance Management (subject to availability), Advanced Taxation (subject to availability), Advanced Audit and Assurance, International Finance, and Mergers and Acquisitions. The MSc stage culminates in an Independent Study: Research Methods and an Independent Study: Dissertation.  Assessment methods vary, including case studies, assignments, reflective writing, research papers, presentations, and group work, also incorporating digital literacy assessments.
Year 1: The first year of the full-time MSc Accounting and Finance program covers the Postgraduate Certificate modules: Strategic Business Leader, focusing on professional judgment in accounting, governance, and risk management; Market Analysis, integrating strategic analysis and business decision-making; and Corporate Reporting, covering international accounting standards and ethical implications.  Students may also begin work on ACCA professional level papers if eligible.
Year 2: The second year (full-time) or first year (part-time) builds upon the foundation with Postgraduate Diploma modules.  These modules cover advanced topics in financial management, performance management (subject to availability), taxation (subject to availability), audit and assurance, international finance, and mergers and acquisitions. The program emphasis deepens, focusing on strategic financial decision-making and practical application.

Course Title: Undergraduate Accounting and Finance with Foundation Year BA (Hons)
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For entry in 2025, typical requirements include 72 UCAS points, A Levels (DDD), a T Level pass, BTEC (MMP), or a pass in an Access to HE Diploma. GCSEs in Maths and English are preferred, but if lacking, Level 2 Maths and English can be taken as part of the course.  International students need an IELTS score of 6.0 with a minimum of 5.5 in each skill area.  For Pakistani students, A-levels or International Baccalaureate from Pakistani international schools allow direct entry into the first year. For postgraduate entry in Pakistan, a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to at least a UK Upper Second Class (2:1) or Lower Second Class (2:2) is required.  Those with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees also need a Master's pass. A four-year honors Bachelor's degree with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university is also considered for Master's entry.
Duration: 4 years (5 years with optional placement year)
Overview: The University of Derby's BA (Hons) Accounting and Finance with Foundation Year is a four-year (or five-year with placement) undergraduate program designed to equip students with the necessary skills and knowledge for a successful career in accounting and finance.  The foundation year provides a strong base, particularly beneficial for career changers.  The curriculum emphasizes professional practice, incorporating live consultancy projects, field trips, and access to a Financial Markets Lab using industry-standard technology. Students receive instruction from professionally qualified staff with extensive industry experience.  The program offers flexibility – selecting modules to gain exemptions from professional bodies like ACCA, CIMA, ICAEW, and others, including an optional placement year between the second and third years.  The course culminates in advanced projects tackling complex real-world problems, fostering critical analysis and problem-solving skills. The inclusion of a Mazars Accelerate Programme provides opportunities for paid placements and potential graduate programs.  International opportunities, such as a Copenhagen trip focusing on forensic accounting, enhance students' global perspective.
Course Structure: The course structure is divided into stages, with the foundation year focusing on building fundamental skills and knowledge in accounting and finance. Further stages introduce advanced accounting techniques, specialist areas, and ethical considerations within a business framework. Independent study allows students to delve into chosen subject areas in the final year. A range of assessment methods are employed throughout, including coursework, exams, reports, and presentations. There's also an optional placement year for gaining practical experience and a 'Diploma on Professional Practice', and students can choose specialized areas in the final year aligning with their career ambitions.  The curriculum integrates teamwork, leadership, and project management skills training.
Year 1: The first year (foundation year) focuses primarily on building a solid foundation in core accounting principles, financial mathematics, basic business economics, and essential study skills.  Students will gain a general understanding of accounting concepts and business contexts.  Emphasis is placed on developing essential study skills and understanding the fundamentals of accountancy within a structured learning environment.  Assessment is largely coursework based, often in-class tests, setting the groundwork for higher level study.
Year 2: Year two delves into more advanced accounting techniques, covering intermediate financial accounting and management accounting. Students explore cost and management accounting concepts in detail and develop their analytical capabilities.  Modules likely include financial reporting, budgeting, forecasting, and financial statement analysis. Emphasis shifts towards more independent study and research, enabling development of critical thinking.
Year 3: The third year (following an optional placement year) could incorporate specialized studies in various accounting disciplines, such as auditing, taxation, or forensic accounting.  Students may undertake more complex projects with real-world applications, potentially involving external clients or industry partners. This year combines further theoretical knowledge with practical application, allowing specialization in areas of interest.
Year 4: The fourth year engages students in advanced studies in chosen accounting specializations.  Students will refine their skills in specific areas such as financial management, strategic accounting, or international accounting. It is expected to include a significant dissertation or independent project, where students apply their knowledge to solve complex problems or conduct in-depth research.

It provides a comprehensive education in accounting and finance principles, preparing students for careers in various sectors.  The curriculum includes modules covering key accounting concepts, financial principles, and practical applications. Students benefit from opportunities like a placement year, live consultancy projects, and field trips, enhancing their practical experience and career prospects.  The program also offers exemptions from several professional accounting bodies like ACCA, CIMA, ICAEW, CPA Australia, and AIA, accelerating students’ paths to professional qualifications.  The University boasts experienced faculty with industry connections and offers support through a Personal Academic Tutoring program.
Course Structure: The course structure involves a combination of lectures, tutorials, workshops, and industry projects.  The initial years focus on foundational accounting and finance concepts, progressing to more specialized modules in later years.  A placement year allows students to gain practical work experience. Assessment methods include computer-based assessments, examinations, essays, business reports, employer-negotiated briefs, videos, group presentations, and portfolio-based assessments. Year 1: The first year lays the foundation in accounting and finance, introducing core concepts and principles. The course includes a professional development component, preparing students for internships, placements, and future roles. Year 3: This is the placement year. Students gain practical, paid experience in a real-world environment, applying their knowledge and skills in an industry setting. The year culminates in final assessments, preparing students for graduation and careers.

Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with a minimum of 5.5 in all areas
Entry Requirement: Applicants should demonstrate evidence of continual professional development (CPD), successful completion of degree-level modules (40 credits plus), and around a minimum of 5 years post-registration experience.  A statement of entry or evidence of professional registration (NMC, HCPC, or GPC) is required.  Written confirmation of employer support, including clinical supervision with an identified clinical supervisor (and where possible, an education supervisor), and an employer reference are also needed. Evidence of a degree or professional qualification is necessary. International students residing in the UK with appropriate visas and employment with an NHS Trust or supporting organization are eligible, provided they meet the entry criteria and can attend once a week.  For apprenticeships, an up-to-date DBS check and evidence of English and Maths L2 qualifications (GCSE or equivalent) are also required.  Pakistani students must have completed a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised University in Pakistan, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree. Those with two or three-year Bachelor degrees also need a Master's degree pass. A four-year Bachelor's degree with honours (minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00) from a recognised Pakistani University is also acceptable.
Overview: The University of Derby's MSc Advanced Clinical Practice program is designed to equip healthcare professionals with advanced clinical and theoretical skills in managing individual patient care.  The course focuses on developing autonomous practitioners through a constructivist learning approach in partnership with employers.  Students gain expertise in history taking, examinations, investigations, prescribing, result interpretation, and appropriate referrals.  A key element of the program involves improving services through audit, research, and knowledge dissemination.  It's structured around the four pillars of advanced practice and is accredited by the Centre for Advancing Practice, increasing career prospects and workforce consistency.  The program is strongly focused on practical application and reflective learning, linking theory to real-world clinical practice.
Course Structure: The MSc Advanced Clinical Practice is structured in three stages: Postgraduate Certificate, Postgraduate Diploma, and MSc. Stage one covers clinical decision-making and management of investigations and referrals. Stage two includes non-medical prescribing (or alternative modules) and research. The final stage involves consolidating advanced practice with an option module (for non-apprentices) that offers choices such as advanced communication skills, symptom management, and therapeutics.  Assessment methods are varied and include case-based scenarios, OSCEs, presentations, examinations, clinical logs, and vivas.  The program continually reviews its content to enhance student experience and graduate outcomes.

Overview: This Level 7 course, "Advancing Communication Skills," focuses on enhancing communication abilities for healthcare professionals.  The curriculum emphasizes a needs analysis approach, allowing participants to address their specific communication skill gaps. It covers various communication strategies applicable in complex healthcare settings.  The course is designed to be relevant to the professional practice of a wide variety of health professionals, assisting them in developing and refining necessary communication tools for improved patient interaction and care delivery. The module evaluation will be based on a negotiated learning contract allowing customization to individual needs and professional contexts. Upon completion, participants will be equipped with effective and adaptable communication strategies for application in their daily work, enhancing their patient interactions and professional capabilities.

This analysis will then inform the selection of three specific areas of communication for further focused study, based on the individual's needs and chosen learning contract. Course Title: PG Cert Advancing Integrated Urgent Care Practice
Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with a minimum of 5.5 in all areas
Entry Requirement: Applicants should normally have a first degree. If you do not hold a first degree, you must have successfully undertaken a minimum of one level 6 (undergraduate) or level 7 (postgraduate) module within the past 5 years.  In addition to the academic requirements, you will need to be a qualified health professional with active registration as either a Pharmacist (on the General Pharmaceutical Council register), Nurse or Midwife (on the Nursing and Midwifery Register), or a professional on the Health and Care Professions Register. You will need to be actively practicing in a patient-facing role for a minimum of one day per week.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised University in Pakistan is required, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree. Students with a two or three-year Bachelor's degree must also have a pass in a Master’s degree. A Bachelor's degree with honors (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University will be considered for entry.
Overview: The Postgraduate Certificate in Advancing Integrated Urgent Care Practice is a one-year online program designed for healthcare professionals to enhance their skills in remote consultation and integrated urgent care.  The curriculum focuses on clinical decision-making, remote consultation techniques, and professional practice within the context of person-centered care.  It covers topics such as triage, clinical leadership, ethical considerations, and safeguarding. The program emphasizes practical application, enabling students to directly apply learned skills to their workplace. It also incorporates personal development planning (PDP) to help learners identify and address their developmental needs, improving their confidence and sense of purpose.  The program is suitable for professionals aiming for specialist or advanced practice roles in various healthcare settings.
Course Structure: The program consists of three core 20-credit modules, totaling 60 credits at level 7.  Each module is delivered entirely online through a virtual learning environment, providing access to learning materials, resources, and communication tools.  The modules cover consultation skills, legal and ethical considerations, clinical decision-making, challenges of remote consultation, and strategies to mitigate safeguarding risks. Teaching methods include online discussions, live sessions, and practice-based learning with opportunities for critical reflection and engagement with clinical supervision.  Personal Development Planning (PDP) is integrated throughout the program, encouraging self-assessment and development.
Year 1: The program is designed for completion within one year. Students engage in three core modules, each covering essential aspects of integrated urgent care practice, such as remote consultation, clinical decision-making, professional standards and ethical considerations. Students are expected to dedicate approximately 20 hours per week to each 20-credit module. Assessment methods will include practical assessments like OSCEs or presentations, and coursework like essays and critical reflections.  The program emphasizes applying learnings directly into workplace settings.

Course Title: BSc (Hons) Aerospace Software Engineering Degree Apprenticeship
Entry Requirement: Entry requirements include 5 GCSEs at Grade 4/C or above, including Maths and English.  Applicants must be employed by an aerospace software engineering company.  Qualifications of 3 A-levels at C or above (or equivalent) including a STEM subject and 2 others, or a BTEC Extended Level 3 at DDM or a T-Level at Distinction are also acceptable. BTECs and T-Levels should be in STEM subjects. Employers may have additional selection criteria.  The University considers all application information and applicant enthusiasm.  For Pakistani students, completing A-levels or the IB from Pakistani international schools allows entry to Year 1.  For postgraduate study, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognised Pakistani university (equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2) is needed. Two or three-year Bachelor's degree holders require a Master's degree pass. A four-year Bachelors with honours and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University qualifies for Masters entry.
Overview: The Aerospace Software Development Engineer Degree Apprenticeship is a four-year blended learning program combining academic study with on-the-job training.  It's designed to meet the needs of regional aerospace companies, providing a strong foundation in software engineering principles and practical skills relevant to the aerospace industry. The curriculum integrates theoretical knowledge with hands-on experience through a dedicated balance of classroom learning at the university campus and practical work experience.  Graduates will be prepared for a range of roles within the aerospace sector. The program emphasizes the development of key software engineering competencies, problem-solving abilities, and professional skills.
Course Structure: The four-year program integrates academic coursework with practical, on-the-job training. Students spend 20% of their time on off-the-job training, which includes lectures, workshops, simulations, online learning, shadowing, mentoring, and industry visits.  The program combines theoretical learning at the university with hands-on practical experience from the employer.  The apprenticeship combines modules covering various aspects of Software Engineering including programming, mathematics, embedded systems, software testing, team projects, real-time systems and data mining.  The apprenticeship also incorporates business management and professional development modules. The final year culminates in an end-point assessment, ensuring that the apprenticeship leads to a validated qualification that meets industrial standards.
Year 1: The first year introduces foundational concepts in programming, computational mathematics, and embedded systems. Students explore computer systems, data structures, data management, and the foundations of embedded networks, IIoT, and security.  Business management and regulations are also introduced to provide a holistic understanding of the aerospace industry. The modules are designed to build a solid foundation in computing principles and industry knowledge.
Year 2: Year two delves into programming language paradigms, software engineering principles, testing, validation, and integration methodologies.  Students engage in NVQ studies to complete apprenticeships standards, and build their understanding of corporate responsibility and professional development. This year focuses on gaining specific skills which are fundamental to employment in the aerospace software sector.
Year 3: The third year involves a significant work-based team project, providing practical experience and collaboration skills. Students explore model-based design, concurrency and communication, and real-time embedded systems. NVQ continuation and Gateway preparation modules improve understanding of the overall apprenticeship requirements and prepare learners for their final end-point assessment. Defining a project linked to KSB and Gateway helps further embed practical skill-building into the programme.
Year 4: The final year concentrates on data mining, foundations of AI, and an individual project.  It includes end-point assessment preparation and completion. This culminates in a final assessment that tests the learners understanding and application of knowledge learnt throughout the programme.

Course Title: Certificate of Continuing Professional Development in Anaesthetic Practice
Required IELTS Score: 7.0 (or equivalent) in all areas
Entry Requirement: Applicants must be a registered practitioner with current and unrestricted registration with a relevant professional regulatory body (e.g., HCPC or NMC). They must be employed in a UK-based perioperative environment for the course duration.  A degree or Diploma in Higher Education (or equivalent) relevant to their professional qualification is required. Evidence of recent study (within the last three years) or the ability to study at a degree level is necessary; if not available, a reflective piece of work related to perioperative experience will be considered. A current DBS is also required.  A completed Manager's Approval Form is needed, confirming employer support, suitable placement opportunities, access to continued learning, at least six months' experience as a registered nurse in the perioperative environment, a knowledgeable mentor, and the applicant's fitness for the course.  For non-native English speakers, an IELTS score of 7.0 (or equivalent) in all areas is required.  Pakistan-specific entry requirements are not detailed on the provided webpage.
Overview: This online Certificate of Continuing Professional Development in Anaesthetic Practice is designed for practicing anaesthetic practitioners in the UK perioperative environment.  The course focuses on enhancing knowledge and skills in various aspects of anaesthetic practice, emphasizing resilience and patient safety.  It covers advanced resuscitation techniques, risk management, service user monitoring, health and social policy implications, anaesthetic equipment usage, the care of diverse patient populations (including pediatrics, obstetrics, and those with mental health needs), regional anesthesia, pain management, and responding to emergencies. The program blends online academic study with supervised clinical practice in the workplace, facilitating skill development and competency enhancement relevant to the role of an anaesthetic practitioner.
Course Structure: The course spans two 10-week trimesters delivered entirely online, complemented by supervised clinical practice in the workplace. Each trimester involves approximately 20 hours of weekly study, covering units such as advanced resuscitation, risk management, patient monitoring, health and social policy, anaesthetic equipment, care of diverse patients, regional anaesthesia, pain management, managing complications, venepuncture, and emergency response.  The course includes virtual classrooms, with recordings made available for those unable to attend live sessions. Assessment includes a 3000-word written assignment and a clinical portfolio demonstrating practical competence.

Annual Tuition Fee: UK: £9,535 per year; International: £16,900 per year
Overview: The BA (Hons) Animation course at the University of Derby provides a comprehensive education in both traditional and digital animation techniques. Students will learn the principles of animation, experiment with various software and methods (2D and 3D), and develop their skills in storytelling, character development, sound design, and editing. The curriculum emphasizes practical project-based learning, including the creation of animated films and showreels.  Students benefit from access to professional-standard facilities and industry-standard software. Regular critiques, workshops, and industry guest speakers further enhance learning and career preparation. The course aims to nurture individual artistic vision and equip graduates for employment.  The University boasts impressive graduate employment rates, with a majority securing jobs or further studies within six months of their degree's completion.
Course Structure: The course integrates technical, analytical, intellectual and organisational aspects of professional practice through various teaching methods and practical projects, including workshops, demonstrations, group critiques, field studies, cultural visits, lectures, seminars, individual tutorials, work checks, reports, and assignments.  Students gradually take on more individual responsibilities.   Key subject areas encompass drawing, sequential image making, 2D and 3D computer animation, character development, narrative, timing, editing, sound design, and the historical and contemporary context of animation.  Students also explore animation applications across multiple mediums (storytelling, social commentary, documentary, music videos, etc).  The curriculum aims to equip students with both artistic and technical skills to produce high-quality animation.
Year 1: First-year students will gain foundational skills in drawing, sequential image making, and the basic principles of 2D and 3D animation. They will be introduced to different software packages and learn about the historical and theoretical context of animation.  Early projects emphasize developing fundamental artistic and technical skills, laying the groundwork for more complex work in subsequent years. Students will also begin to explore different animation styles and storytelling techniques.  The year culminates in the creation of several smaller animation projects using a range of techniques.
Year 2: Year two focuses on expanding technical skills and exploring more advanced animation techniques. Students will undertake larger and more complex animation projects, requiring them to integrate their artistic vision with technical proficiency. This involves further development in character development, narrative structure, sound design, and editing. They will experiment with more sophisticated software and workflows.  Collaboration and group project work will also be emphasised to simulate real-world professional environments.
Year 3: The final year of the course centers around the creation of a significant graduation film.  Students will refine their individual artistic style and apply skills to bring their vision to life.  Emphasis is placed on professional practice, including self-promotion, creating showreels, and building a portfolio. They will also receive guidance and feedback from industry professionals. The final project provides a substantial opportunity to showcase skills and creative potential to prospective employers.  Students may participate in exhibitions or competitions to further refine their work.

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical requirements include 72 UCAS points, A Levels (BCC), a T Level pass, a BTEC MMP, or a pass in an Access to HE Diploma. GCSEs in Maths and English are preferred but not mandatory.  A portfolio is recommended.  Contextual offers may be available for students who are care experienced, estranged from their families, refugees or asylum seekers, or whose parents/carers are in the UK armed forces.  International students will have individual requirements.  For Pakistani students, A-levels or IB from Pakistani international schools allow direct entry into Year 1. Postgraduate entry from Pakistan requires a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to at least a UK 2:1 or 2:2, potentially a Master's degree if the Bachelor's was a shorter program,  or a four-year honors Bachelor's with a minimum 2.4/4.0 GPA. PhD entry from Pakistan requires both a Master's and Bachelor’s degree in a relevant field, along with a research proposal.
Overview: The BA (Hons) Animation with Foundation Year is a four-year undergraduate program at the University of Derby, focusing on equipping students with the necessary skills and knowledge in both traditional and digital animation techniques.  Students will learn various animation methods, including hand-drawn, 2D and 3D digital animation, character development, storytelling, and post-production processes. The course emphasizes practical project work, integrating technical, analytical, and creative aspects of professional practice.  Students will benefit from access to state-of-the-art facilities, including a dedicated production studio, and will have opportunities to collaborate with industry professionals.
Course Structure: The curriculum is designed to provide a comprehensive understanding of animation production, spanning traditional and digital techniques.  Students will cover fundamental animation principles, character design, narrative structure, storyboarding, and the technical aspects of animation software.  Later years will incorporate advanced digital techniques, visual effects, and post-production workflows. The course also includes modules focusing on professional practice such as industry networking, portfolio building, and career planning.  Throughout the program, students will work on individual and collaborative projects to develop their skills and build a portfolio of work.
Year 1: The first year serves as a foundational year, introducing students to core concepts in art, design, and animation.  Students may build foundational skills in drawing, visual communication, basic animation principles in 2D, and an understanding of design software. This year focuses on building a skill set that prepares students for the higher-level courses. Students will build upon their skills from year to year.
Year 2: Year two will focus on building upon Year 1’s foundations with an introduction to more advanced drawing and design techniques and more complex animation principles.  Students will be introduced to digital techniques and software relevant to the field and may begin exploring different animation styles and techniques.  They may also start to develop their own individual style and develop their personal workflow and creative approaches.
Year 3: The curriculum in Year 3 increases in complexity, introducing advanced animation techniques, character animation, visual effects, and aspects of production pipelines.  Students will also improve their artistic and storytelling capabilities, working on more substantial projects to prepare for the final year’s culminating project. Students get feedback and guidance from professionals in the field, preparing them for the rigors of a professional career.
Year 4: The final year focuses on the creation of a graduation film, a substantial project that demonstrates the culmination of the skills and knowledge gained throughout the program.  Students will further refine their style, hone their technical abilities, and develop professional strategies for presenting their work. They may also get the chance to collaborate with professionals which may help inform their future careers.

Course Title: Level 7 An Introduction to Art Therapy Supervision
Required IELTS Score: NA
Entry Requirement: Ideally, applicants should have at least three years of post-qualification clinical experience and current professional registration or accreditation with HCPC, UKCP, BACP, or a similar organization. A reference from their clinical supervisor or employer is required.  Applicants must provide clinical supervision to less experienced art therapists or trainees throughout the module.  For Pakistani students,  a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognized university is needed, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree. Those with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees also require a Master's degree pass. A Bachelor's degree with honors (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university is considered for entry.
Overview: This Level 7 course provides a comprehensive introduction to art therapy supervision.  It's designed for qualified art therapists, psychotherapists, counselors, and mental health professionals who conduct or plan to conduct clinical supervision of art therapists or trainees. The program covers a wide range of theoretical supervision models, group dynamics, ethical considerations, and the integration of art-making and reflection into the supervisory process.  Students will gain practical experience supervising others, develop critical thinking skills, and achieve a deep understanding of both theory and practice in art therapy supervision. Upon successful completion, participants will be equipped to effectively manage a small supervision caseload, critically reflect on their supervisory practice, and evaluate relevant theories.
Course Structure: The course combines contact sessions (lectures, seminars, workshops, and small-group supervision) with self-directed learning. Contact sessions focus on theoretical frameworks of supervision, practical application, and reflective practice. The non-contact time involves providing supervision, self-assessment, reflection, and personal study. The curriculum includes content on the history and development of supervision, diverse models, the supervisory frame, group dynamics, unconscious processes, working with images, authority, ethics, diversity, assessment, and inter-professional collaboration.  Emphasis is placed on integrating theory and practice to cultivate critical thinking and reflection.
Year 1: NA
Year 2: NA

Course Title: Certificate in An Introduction to Emotional Resilience
Required IELTS Score: NA
Entry Requirement: There are no formal entry requirements for this short course.  Access to the internet and a valid email address are needed to register for the online learning environment.  Learners should have an understanding of the English language and the ability to study in English.  The course is open to anyone regardless of age, location, or educational background.  While there is no mention of specific Pakistani requirements, the general access requirements apply to all participants. For Pakistani students, no specific educational qualifications are stated beyond the English language comprehension requirement.
Overview: This online short course provides an introduction to emotional resilience, focusing on its development and application.  It explores the definition of emotional resilience and how it can be developed, covering various theoretical perspectives and models of reflection.  The course aims to equip participants with strategies to become more resilient, not only personally but also professionally, particularly for those working with others in challenging situations such as in health and social care or education.  Learners will engage with real-world examples and scenarios to enhance understanding and develop practical applications of the concepts discussed.
Course Structure: The course consists of four units, each requiring approximately five hours of study.  Unit 1 introduces the definition and importance of emotional resilience using popular culture examples, encouraging reflection. Unit 2 delves into theoretical perspectives on the development of emotional resilience, exploring individual traits and environmental influences. Unit 3 focuses on practical reflective frameworks and exercises to enhance reflective skills, using scenarios. Finally, Unit 4 introduces reflective supervision, providing learners with a role play activity to enrich understanding and application. The course uses interactive activities, scenarios, and discussions to make learning a more immersive and personal experience.
Year 1: NA
Year 2: NA

Entry Requirement: For UK students, an undergraduate degree in a science or relevant discipline is required.  Those without the Institute of Acoustics (IOA) Diploma in Acoustics must contact the programme leader. International students need an undergraduate degree or postgraduate qualification in a science or relevant discipline, or an equivalent.  IELTS 6.0 or above is needed if English isn't their first language. International students must study remotely and complete or be completing the IOA Diploma in Acoustics and Noise Control or equivalent.  The IOA diploma at the University of Derby is part-time on campus and unavailable to international students. For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised University in Pakistan is required, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree. Students with two or three-year Bachelor degrees also need a Master's degree pass.  A Bachelor's degree with honours (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University is also acceptable for Masters entry.
Annual Tuition Fee: £3,000 for 60 credit Independent Project (UK);£3,115 for 60 credit Independent Project (International)
Overview: The University of Derby's MSc in Applied Acoustics is a distance learning program designed for working professionals, particularly those with the IOA Diploma in Acoustics.  The course focuses on enhancing practical skills in noise assessment and control, using interdisciplinary approaches and real-world case studies.  Students undertake a research-based project tailored to their work or chosen area, supervised by an academic advisor.  The program emphasizes flexibility, allowing students to fit studies around existing commitments, and offers support and online resources.  Graduates are well-placed for career advancement in acoustics, consultancy, and research.
Course Structure: The course centers around a 60-credit Independent Scholarly Activity module. This module involves a substantial research project, either practical or a desktop review, undertaken on an acoustic topic of the student's choosing. This independent study is intensely supervised and supported by an experienced academic advisor. While there are no examinations, assessment is solely based on coursework assignments completed during the independent research project.
Year 1: The MSc in Applied Acoustics is a one-year program. Students focus their efforts on the 60-credit Independent Scholarly Activity module, leading to a research-based final project. This work involves selecting a topic related to applied acoustics, conducting the necessary research (either theoretically or practically), analyzing the results, and creating a comprehensive thesis or report.  Students receive regular guidance and support from an advisor throughout this process.
Year 2: NA

Entry Requirement: For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 112 UCAS points, A-Levels BBC, T Level Merit, BTEC DMM, or a Pass Access to HE Diploma.  GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or above are also needed. An interview and written test are required.  Applicants must demonstrate an understanding of UK social worker roles, relevant social care/work experience, and how this experience makes them suitable. Experience can be paid or unpaid, in various settings involving interaction with children and adults.  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or IB from international schools in Pakistan, entry into the first year is possible.  If not meeting entry requirements, the BA (Hons) Applied Social Work with Foundation Year may be considered.  Non-UK applicants need a minimum IELTS score of 7.0 overall (or equivalent).
Overview: The University of Derby's Applied Social Work BA (Hons) is a three-year undergraduate program designed to prepare students for careers as qualified social workers.  The course emphasizes practical skills and theoretical knowledge, equipping graduates to work with diverse populations and address complex social issues.  Students undertake substantial periods of work placement in various settings, including local authorities, hospitals, and voluntary organizations, applying theoretical knowledge to real-world situations.  The curriculum focuses on developing professional competencies, including assessment, intervention, and partnership building with individuals, families, and professionals. The program is approved by Social Work England, enabling graduates to register as qualified social workers upon completion. The curriculum is regularly reviewed and updated in response to national developments and employer needs, ensuring its continued relevance and timeliness.
Course Structure: The course curriculum is designed to provide a comprehensive understanding of social work theory and practice. Students will engage in a variety of learning activities, including lectures, seminars, workshops, group work, and individual study. A significant component of the program involves substantial work placements, allowing students to gain practical experience across 170 days in various social care settings.  Assessment methods include written assignments, presentations, exams, reports, placement portfolios, role-play, and professional discussions. The program incorporates inter-professional learning opportunities, fostering collaboration with students from other health and social care disciplines. Students undertake individual projects in their final years, exploring topics in-depth and developing their research skills. The curriculum covers a broad range of social work themes, including loss and grief, poverty, inequality, mental health, and disability.
Year 1: The first year focuses on building foundational knowledge and skills.  Key areas of study will likely include social work theory, values, and ethics; social policy and legislation; human behavior in the social environment; working with families, children, and adults; and introduction to social work practice methods.  Students will also undertake preparation for the required practice placements.
Year 2: Year two likely builds upon foundational knowledge and develops specific social work skills.  Students will delve deeper into specialized practice areas.  This year will continue to develop assessment and intervention skills while working with real-life case studies.  A significant portion of the year involves structured practice placements expanding the hands-on experience begun in the first year.
Year 3: The final year involves advanced social work practice and potentially specialized areas of study.  Students will focus on developing advanced assessment, therapeutic approaches, and intervention methodologies.  A further strengthened and expanded placement period emphasizes the application of this increased knowledge and sophistication in real-world situations.

Course Title: BA (Hons) Applied Social Work with Foundation Year
Required IELTS Score: 6.5 (with at least 6.0 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical UCAS points are 80.  A-Level requirements are CDD, BTEC is MMP, and a pass in T Level (C or above in the core) is needed.  An Access to HE Diploma with 60 credits (45 at Level 3) is also acceptable. GCSE Maths and English are preferred, but if lacking, they can be undertaken at Level 2 during the course.  An IELTS overall score of 6.5 (at least 6.0 in each band) or equivalent SELT at CEFR level B2 is required.  An interview is mandatory.  An Enhanced Disclosure & Barring Service certificate and an Occupational Health Assessment are required.  Applicants must have social care experience (paid or unpaid, personal care experience, or as a service user).  Contextual offers may apply to care experienced students, estranged students, refugees/asylum seekers, or students whose parents/carers are in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistan, if studying A-levels or IB in Pakistani international schools, direct entry to Year 1 is possible. For postgraduate, a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ is required. A Master's degree is needed if the Bachelor's degree is two or three years. A four-year Bachelor's degree with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 is considered for Master's entry. PhD applicants need a Master's and Bachelor's degree with a research proposal submission.
Overview: The BA (Hons) Applied Social Work with Foundation Year is a four-year undergraduate program designed to prepare students for careers as qualified social workers.  The program incorporates a foundation year, beneficial for students returning to education or needing a more gradual transition to university study.  It focuses on developing practical skills and theoretical knowledge through a combination of classroom learning, fieldwork, and real-world applications. The curriculum covers various social work aspects, relevant to working with diverse populations and tackling their problems.   The course aims to provide students with a robust foundation, supported by experienced academics and practical experience, allowing them to meet Social Work England's requirements for registration.
Course Structure: The course is structured across four years, beginning with a foundation year. The foundation year serves as an introduction to university study and social work concepts, building foundational skills.  The subsequent three years focus on the core aspects of applied social work.  Specific modules may vary but will generally cover social work theory, practice, ethics, legislation, and various practice areas such as child protection, mental health, disability, youth justice, and work with vulnerable populations. The course will involve both theoretical learning and practical placements to apply the learned skills in real-world settings.
Year 1: The foundation year provides a supportive introduction to higher education. Students develop essential academic skills while gradually building knowledge of social care principles, relevant subject areas and various practice areas. The assessment methods may include essays, assignments, presentations, and practical assessments. Direct entry into the foundation year only happens when students don't meet the grade criteria for the standard entry but show good potential.
Year 2: NA

Course Title: MSc Applied Sport and Exercise Science
Entry Requirement: For UK students, an upper second-class honours degree in a related subject is usually required.  EU/international students need an equivalent qualification. If English isn't your first language, IELTS 6.0 or above is necessary.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized university is needed, equivalent to at least a UK Upper Second Class (2:1) or Lower Second Class (2:2) degree.  Those with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees also require a Master's degree pass. A four-year Bachelor's with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.0 from a recognized Pakistani university is also an acceptable entry requirement.

Overview: The University of Derby's MSc Applied Sport and Exercise Science is a postgraduate program designed to equip students with the knowledge and practical skills needed for careers in the field.  The program caters to diverse career interests with options in psychology or performance analysis. Students will develop applied skills through 150 hours of placement, benefitting from partnerships with professional sports organizations.  The curriculum emphasizes a strong foundation in research methods, allowing students to conduct independent studies and build critical analysis skills. Cutting-edge facilities provide a unique learning environment with access to state-of-the-art equipment. Graduates are well-prepared for roles as applied sport scientists working with athletes, promoting healthy lifestyles, or pursuing further research opportunities.
Course Structure: The MSc Applied Sport and Exercise Science program blends core and optional modules.  Core modules build a strong foundation in research methods, advanced physiological processes, and practitioner development.  Optional modules allow specialization in areas like sport psychology, performance analysis, sports training principles, and biomechanical analysis. A key element is the “Practitioner Development in Applied Sport and Exercise Science” module, which includes a substantial work placement. Students can also pursue postgraduate certificates (PGCert) or diplomas (PGDip) depending on the number of credits earned.  Psychology and Performance Analysis pathways provide specialized module options.
Year 1: The first year (for full-time students) includes core modules like Practitioner Development in Applied Sport and Exercise Science (including a 150-hour placement) and Advanced Research Methods, laying the groundwork for the Independent Research project.  Students then choose from a selection of optional modules based on their chosen pathway (Psychology or Performance Analysis), which might include options like Applied Practice in Sport Psychology, Applied Performance Analysis, Advanced Sport & Exercise Physiology, or Strength and Conditioning Science. The year culminates in the Independent Research project.

An interview is part of the application process to assess suitability and practical experience. For non-native English speakers, an IELTS score of 6.0 or equivalent is needed.  A Disclosure and Barring Service (DBS) check is required upon acceptance.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognized university, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree, is necessary. A four-year Bachelor's degree with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university is also considered.

Overview: The MA Applied Theatre and Education is a postgraduate program designed to equip graduates with the skills and knowledge necessary to become successful educational practitioners using theatre and drama in various settings.  The program focuses on applied theatre practices in non-traditional settings, working with marginalized communities and addressing crucial social and cultural policy areas like public health, education, and social welfare. Students will deepen their theoretical understanding of applied theatre, gain practical experience through hands-on work and real-life projects conducted at Derby Theatre, a professional producing theatre.  The program emphasizes a strong link between theory and practice, allowing students to engage in practice-as-research, and preparing them for employability in the field of theatre education. The program is run in partnership with Derby Theatre, providing students with unique opportunities to learn and collaborate alongside professionals. The course structure consists of various modules focusing on theoretical underpinnings and practical application of applied theatre within educational contexts, leading to a final major project that allows for in-depth exploration and critical evaluation of a chosen applied theatre project.
Course Structure: The course involves modules such as Applied Theatre Context and Work-based Learning, exploring various drama methodologies and the historical context.  Students delve into crafting their master's study, developing personal and academic competencies.  Applied Educational Thinkers and Theorists are studied, examining the contributions of educational theory to practice.  The Performance and Practice as Research module involves the development of a practical performance piece in various settings which would enable students to engage practically with different environments and contexts.   Independent Study (Major Project) forms a significant part of the program, encouraging students to apply their knowledge through a substantial project in a community setting, with a strong emphasis on the reciprocal relationship between research and practice.   Optional Education modules allow interaction with students from other MA Education programs, facilitating cross-disciplinary discussions. Assessment methods include written assignments such as essay, portfolios and practical assessments comprising performances, workshops, and presentations.
Year 1: The first year of the full-time MA Applied Theatre and Education program will likely include modules covering applied theatre context and work-based learning, introducing key practitioners and philosophies. Students will develop their mastery study skills and engage in modules on applied educational thinkers and theorists and practical performance. The program also includes optional education modules, allowing for interdisciplinary collaboration and discussion.,This year would also include development of performance and facilitation skills under direction from the tutor. The module will prepare students for the major project of the course.
Year 2: NA

Overview: The BSc (Hons) Architectural Technology and Practice degree at the University of Derby is a comprehensive program focusing on the design, technology, and science of architecture, incorporating sustainability and construction principles.  The curriculum emphasizes practical application through live projects, design exercises utilizing CAD and BIM software, and field trips to construction sites. Students also benefit from industry placements, guest lectures from professionals, and opportunities to collaborate with major firms on real-world projects.  The program is accredited by the Chartered Institute of Architectural Technologists (CIAT), providing students with a recognized professional qualification.  Graduates have a strong job placement record, with nearly all finding employment or further education within six months of completion. In addition,  The course fosters a deep understanding of industry standards, including Building Information Modelling (BIM) technology and building simulation systems and environmental approach.
Course Structure: The course integrates design, technology, and the science of architecture with a focus on sustainable and practical applications.  Students engage in a range of projects and assessments, including coursework, live project work, assignments, competitions, exams, exhibitions, and oral presentations.  The program includes practical architectural design and technology projects, field trips, placements, and guest lectures from industry professionals.  Computer-aided design (CAD), Building Information Modelling (BIM), sketching, and model making are essential components. Modules cover management, procurement, contracts, and professional practice.  The program offers flexibility, allowing students of various backgrounds including HND or foundation degree holders to top-up their existing qualification to get a full bachelor's degree.
Year 1: The first year introduces foundational concepts in architectural technology and practice. Students will develop fundamental skills in design, drawing, computer-aided design (CAD), and model making, alongside an introduction to building materials, construction methods, and architectural design principles.  This year will also include a compulsory field trip within England, focusing on practical application and site visits.
Year 2: Year two builds upon the foundational knowledge established in the first year, delving deeper into advanced design techniques, BIM software, and sustainable building practices. Students will undertake more complex projects, potentially including an optional five-day trip abroad to expand their international perspective. This is also where students can undertake an optional placement to refine their skill.
Year 3: The final year focuses on project management, professional practice, and the development of a comprehensive portfolio showcasing the student's abilities. Students will also work on their final year projects, engaging with real industry collaboration, and potentially presenting their work at events like the Derby Property Summit. The curriculum also includes modules on advanced architectural technologies, and integrated environmental approaches.

Course Title: Undergraduate Architectural Technology and Practice with Foundation Year BSc (Hons)
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 72 UCAS points, A Levels (DDD), T Level (Pass), BTEC (MMP), GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or above, or a Pass in Access to HE Diploma.  International students need an IELTS score of 6.0 with at least 5.5 in each skill.  For Pakistan, A-levels or IB from recognized schools allow direct entry to Year 1 of a Bachelor's degree. Postgraduate entry requires a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK Upper or Lower Second Class Honours and might require a Master's degree for some two or three-year Bachelor's degrees. A four-year Bachelor’s degree with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani University is considered for Masters programs. PhD applicants from Pakistan must possess both a Master's and Bachelor's degree in relevant subjects along with a research proposal.
Overview: The University of Derby offers a BSc (Hons) in Architectural Technology and Practice, including an optional foundation year. This four-year (or five-year with placement) program combines design, technology, architectural science, sustainability, and construction. Students develop skills in design, Building Information Modelling (BIM), and sustainable building practices with  practical projects, field trips, and industry guest lectures. The course is accredited by the Chartered Institute of Architectural Technologists (CIAT) and boasts strong industry connections, leading to high employability, with 100% of graduates in professional or managerial roles within six months of graduating (2016).  The curriculum encompasses a balance of theoretical learning with extensive practical application and incorporates industry-standard software and techniques, making the graduates highly competitive within the architecture industry.
Course Structure: The course structure integrates design, technology, architectural science, and sustainability.  The curriculum includes practical projects, design studios, technical modules on building information modeling (BIM) and building simulation systems.  Students also engage in field trips, guest lectures by industry professionals, and potentially a placement year. Management, procurement, contracts, and professional practice are also addressed.  Assessment methods are diverse and include coursework, live projects, assignments, competitions, exams, exhibitions, portfolios, graphics, and oral presentations.  A personal academic tutoring program aids students throughout their degree. The exact module breakdown may vary; it's best to check the most current information available on the University's website.
Year 1: The first year focuses on foundational skills in architectural design and technology.  It introduces students to CAD software, sketching, model-making, and fundamental design principles.  The year also incorporates introductory modules covering building science, construction technology, and potentially materials with a mandatory 4-day residential field trip within England.  Students work on initial design projects using the University's workshops and resources.
Year 2: Building upon the foundation established in the first year, the second year delves deeper into architectural design processes and technical expertise.  Students engage in more complex design projects, perhaps incorporating BIM and sustainable design techniques. They might start to specialize in different branches of architectural technology as well as optional 5 day trip abroad.  The curriculum integrates modules on professional practice, project management and additional workshops.
Year 3: Year three typically includes an optional placement year in industry, allowing students to gain valuable real-world experience, working on live projects and gaining insights into professional practice.  Alternatively, students can continue with their studies on campus, expanding on their advanced design and technical skills by using advanced technology and software available at the university's workshops.
Year 4: This final year focuses on the development of a final major project—a comprehensive design and technical project that allows students to apply all accumulated skills and knowledge. It provides students with an excellent opportunity to showcase their talents while gaining valuable hands-on experience, incorporating the experience to prepare a strong portfolio as they graduate. Students might also begin exploring career options and preparing for job applications.

Course Title: BSc (Hons) Artificial Intelligence and Data Science
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 128 UCAS points, A-Levels ABB (with at least a B in Mathematics), a Merit in T Levels, DDM in BTECs, GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or above, or a Pass in an Access to HE Diploma with specific credit and grade requirements.  International students need an IELTS score of 6.0 with at least 5.5 in each skill.  For Pakistani Students:  If completing A-levels or IB from an International School in Pakistan, entry to Year 1 is possible. Contextual offers may be available for students who are care experienced, estranged from their families, refugees, asylum seekers, or whose parents/carers are in the UK armed forces.
Overview: The BSc (Hons) Artificial Intelligence and Data Science degree at the University of Derby provides a comprehensive education in the mathematical foundations of data analysis and AI, combined with practical application. Students learn to extract meaningful insights from data and construct AI systems and models.  The program emphasizes industry connections, offering opportunities for placements and collaborations with companies like Rolls-Royce and JCB.  Assessment is coursework-based, eliminating written exams.  The curriculum is flexible, allowing students to specialize in their chosen area in later years. The University provides strong support through personal academic tutoring.
Course Structure: The course is structured in a way that combines theoretical knowledge with practical skills. The first year builds a strong foundation in mathematical concepts and programming relevant to Data Science and AI. The second year involves more specialized modules focusing on further options and flexibility to explore your interest areas. The final year provides opportunities to tailor your studies through specialized modules and projects. There's also a placement year option available to gain industry experience which will help you progress in your career after graduation. The assessment involves a variety of methods like coursework, portfolios, assignments, and presentations, focusing on practical application.
Year 1: The first year focuses on building a foundation in core concepts. Overview: The Artificial Intelligence and Data Science BSc (Hons) with Foundation Year is a four-year undergraduate program designed to equip students with a strong foundation in both artificial intelligence and data science.  The curriculum combines theoretical knowledge with practical application, preparing graduates for a wide range of data-driven careers. Students will learn the mathematical foundations of data analysis and AI, mastering skills to extract meaningful insights from data and construct sophisticated AI systems and models.  The program emphasizes practical learning through coursework, projects, and potential work placements. The inclusion of a foundation year provides additional support and skill development for students before progressing to the honors degree. The university's industry connections also offer invaluable real-world experience.
Course Structure: The course is structured across four years. Year 1 will focus on fundamental concepts in mathematics, programming, and data science. Year 2 builds on these building blocks to introduce more advanced AI and data analysis techniques and allow students to begin specializing. Later years will offer more advanced modules and options that allow students to tailor their study to their interests. There will be assignments, coursework and projects but no written exams. The program incorporates a placement year to offer practical, paid industry experience between Year 2 and 3.  The modules are regularly reviewed and updated to reflect the latest industry developments and technological advancements.
Year 1: The first year, including the foundation year, focuses on developing a solid foundation in mathematics, programming, and core computing principles relevant to AI and data science.  Students will gain foundational skills to support their academic studies and potential career paths in data science.
Year 2: Year 2 (Year 1 after foundation year) introduces students to more advanced topics in artificial intelligence and data science.  Students will begin to specialize their learning, tailoring their coursework to their emerging interests within the field. Year 3: Year 3 is a placement year, giving students the chance to gain invaluable industry experience. Students work with a company relating to the course and apply their skills in a practical setting. The experience also helps students to develop their professional skills and find out more about the types of job they might want to do after graduation.
Year 4: The final year allows for advanced specialization in areas like machine learning, natural language processing, or data visualization.  Students undertake a significant individual project, applying their accumulated skills and knowledge to tackle a challenging problem, creating a portfolio piece for future job applications.

Overview: The Artificial Intelligence in Criminology BSc (Hons) at the University of Derby is a three-year undergraduate program exploring the ethical, opportunistic, and threatening aspects of artificial intelligence (AI) within the field of criminology.  Students will examine how machine learning and automated technologies impact crime prediction, criminal tracking, and sentencing. The curriculum delves into ethical dilemmas related to AI in legal contexts, such as AI-related crimes and culpability.  The program provides hands-on practical experience in modern facilities, including computer labs, a replica crown court, and a custody suite, in addition to leveraging connections with organizations such as the HM Prison Service and Rolls-Royce.  The course aims to prepare graduates for careers at the forefront of AI and criminology, equipping them with skills for addressing real-world justice system challenges.
Course Structure: The course is structured around a combination of lectures, seminars, practical sessions, and group work.  Assessment methods are diverse and include coursework, portfolios, presentations, examinations, case studies, team projects, and computer-based assessments. The program integrates mathematical foundations of AI, AI systems and models and disciplines like sociology, law, psychology, and philosophy. It fosters creative thinking, challenging established beliefs, and nurturing individual research interests. Students develop strong skills in investigation, management, communication and work within real-world settings.
Year 1: The first year would likely introduce foundational concepts in criminology,  including core theories, research methods, and the legal framework. It would also cover basic principles of artificial intelligence, such as machine learning algorithms and data analysis techniques.  This year would also begin to explore introductory ethical considerations of AI and its impact on society.  Practical elements might involve introductory programming and data visualization.
Year 2: The second year would likely delve deeper into specialized aspects of both criminology and AI.  Advanced criminological topics like victimology, criminal behavior, and crime prevention would be explored, alongside advanced AI modules covering natural language processing, computer vision, and AI security. The second year would intensify the ethical debates linked to AI, covering topics of bias, accountability, privacy, and social justice, in relation to the justice system. The second year will provide the students more in depth practical experience in specialized areas.
Year 3: The final year would focus on applied projects and research related to the intersection of AI and criminology.  Students would likely undertake a significant research project, potentially in collaboration with industry partners.  Advanced modules on AI system design, deployment and maintenance, policy making would complement advanced studies in specialized areas of criminal justice. This year brings together all the knowledge gained to complete a large scale project to apply the concepts learned.
