Overview: The BSc (Hons) Artificial Intelligence in Human Resources is a three-year undergraduate program designed to equip students with the skills to integrate artificial intelligence (AI) into human resource management (HRM).  The curriculum combines traditional HRM principles with cutting-edge AI technologies, preparing graduates for roles in a rapidly evolving field. Students will explore AI's applications in recruitment, performance analysis, employee engagement, and policy creation, while also considering the ethical implications.  The course emphasizes hands-on experience, industry connections, and real-world case studies to help students translate academic knowledge into practical solutions.  Graduates will be well-prepared for various careers in HRM and AI.
Course Structure: The course structure integrates traditional human resource management theory with the practical use of AI tools.  Students gain a foundational understanding of AI through mathematical and programming modules to enable the practical analysis of data generated by these specialized tools. The course then moves into more specialized human resource management topics such as recruitment, employee management and retention, diversity and equality in the workplace, the development of effective leadership skills, and contemporary issues in human resource management. Alongside this, there is an emphasis on project work, case studies and employer-led projects so that students can put theory into practice before they graduate.
Year 1: The first year will lay the groundwork for the program, building a strong foundation in both AI and HRM.  Students will embark on programming modules, and mathematics modules necessary to undertake the data analysis techniques required to work with AI tools. Introductory HRM modules will also be undertaken, providing a solid grounding in topics such as recruitment processes, pay and benefits, and employee relations.  The emphasis will be on building a comprehensive understanding of fundamental concepts, preparing students to tackle more specialized aspects of the field later in the curriculum.
Year 2: Year two intensifies the practical AI application, focusing on the data analysis tools students will need to successfully use AI at work.   Alongside this, the specialized HRM modules will build this understanding to more advanced HR topics such as employee development, talent management and change management.  The year includes more group project work and case studies in which students will have to interpret data findings and use this to formulate effective HR strategies. This year will develop the problem-solving, data analytical and critical thinking skills necessary for the modern HR professional.
Year 3: The final year provides students with deeper knowledge of advanced analytical techniques, and also allows for a focus on developing a specialized area of expertise in the field.  The final year involves a major project that challenges students to develop and present their own research into a specialization within the field of Artificial Intelligence and Human Resources.  This final year also focuses on consolidating all the theoretical and practical knowledge learned, ensuring students are ready to begin their career paths after completion of the course.

Overview: The University of Derby's MA Arts program offers pathways in Fine Art or Photography, providing students with a rigorous and challenging curriculum. The program emphasizes the development of individual creative practices through reflection, research, and experimentation.  Students benefit from access to exceptional facilities such as darkrooms, studios, and specialized software.  The program fosters a collaborative environment where students work across disciplines, participate in lively debates and showcase their work. It blends studio-based research with theoretical learning in contemporary practice, creating a multidisciplinary learning experience that prepares graduates for careers as independent artists or in related fields.
Course Structure: The MA Arts program is structured in stages leading to a Postgraduate Certificate, Diploma and finally the MA. The initial stage involves modules focusing on practice, theory, and curation in chosen pathways, incorporating visual and written analysis. The next stage enhances critical studies, negotiates viewing contexts for artwork, and refines key research skills. The final stage culminates in a major project, often a degree show exhibition, requiring independent scholarship, critical reflection, and theoretical and historical investigation or focuses on artistic research. Modules are regularly reviewed to enhance student experience and career prospects. The program also features taught modules alongside seminars, tutorials, workshops, and guest lecturers as well as trips to galleries and cultural institutions.
Year 1: Full-time students complete the program within one year, covering modules that integrate theory and practice.  They will engage with curatorial debates, undertake reflective self-critical practice, critically analyze their artistic or photographic practice within a contemporary international context, articulate the context of their work concerning audience engagement, and finally create a significant body of exhibition-quality work through individual scholarship and project development.
Year 2: Part-time students complete the program over two years, following a similar structure to the first year in the first year of study. The coursework will be completed at more leisurely pace over a period of two years.

Overview: The University of Derby's MA Art Therapy program is a two-year, full-time course designed to equip students with the skills and knowledge to become practicing art therapists.  The program integrates clinical practice with theoretical understanding, emphasizing the role of the image and imagination in therapeutic practice. Students will gain experience in individual and group art therapy, studio practice, and critical analysis of current theoretical ideas.  The course includes supervised clinical placements, personal therapy, and an independent scholarship project where students conduct arts-based research to develop their clinical reasoning and professional identity. Upon successful completion, graduates are eligible for professional registration with the Health and Care Professions Council (HCPC) and full membership of the British Association of Art Therapists (BAAT). The course is intellectually stimulating and provides students with the necessary skills to start their career in areas such as mental health, education, or the prison service. The emphasis is on real-world learning through multiple clinical placement opportunities.
Course Structure: The MA Art Therapy curriculum comprises several core modules.  The Postgraduate Certificate phase begins with modules covering Art Therapy Studio Practice, Art Therapies Theory and Research in Relation to Practice One, and Art Therapy Clinical Placement One.  The Postgraduate Diploma then builds upon this foundation with modules on Art Therapy Experiential Group, Art Therapies Theory and Research in Relation to Practice Two, and Art Therapy Clinical Placement Two.  Finally, the MA level culminates in a substantial Art Therapies Independent Scholarship: A Body of Work. This independent project allows students to integrate their learning and undertake arts-based research.  Assessment methods are diverse, involving written assignments, artwork production, oral presentations, and reports based on clinical performance.  The program integrates theory with practical, hands-on experience across various settings and therapies.
Year 1: The first year of the MA Art Therapy program introduces students to fundamental theoretical frameworks and practical techniques in art therapy.  Core modules such as Art Therapy Studio Practice and Art Therapies Theory and Research in Relation to Practice One provide a foundation in both practical skills and theoretical underpinnings of the field.  Students will gain valuable hands-on experience through the Art Therapy Clinical Placement One module, completing supervised clinical practice. This initial placement provides a valuable introduction to the challenges and rewards of working in real-world clinical settings.
Year 2: The second year builds on the foundation laid in the first year, focusing on deepening theoretical knowledge and developing advanced clinical skills. Modules like Art Therapy Experiential Group and Art Therapies Theory and Research in Relation to Practice Two provide a more in-depth analysis of different therapeutic approaches and research methodologies.  This year also involves a second clinical placement (Art Therapy Clinical Placement Two) offering a more extended and significant experience, which builds upon what was learned in the first year.  A substantial Independent Scholarship project (Art Therapies Independent Scholarship: A Body of Work) allows students to integrate their learning through an in-depth research project and culmination of their practical work.  The year completes with the showcase of all final pieces of work in an exhibition.

Overview: This Level 7 postgraduate module focuses on the assessment, prevention, and management of falls in older adults. It's designed for health and social care professionals who need to effectively identify fall risks and implement appropriate interventions.  The course covers the pathophysiology of falls, postural stability, risk factors and assessment tools, prevention strategies, and national guidelines. It will also examine the epidemiology of falls, considering the broader social, economic, and political impacts. Students will analyze current service provision and justify the requirements of a falls service, gaining a comprehensive understanding of best practices in fall management.
Course Structure: The module covers a range of topics within falls management.  It begins by establishing a foundational understanding of fall epidemiology, considering the social, economic, and personal consequences of falls and fall-related injuries.  Students will explore the physiology of falls, examining risk factors and utilizing risk assessment tools. A significant component involves learning and critically evaluating intervention strategies, and national guidance strategies for prevention and management.   Critical analysis of current service provision and justification of fall service requirements is also a key part of the learning experience. The module emphasizes practical application, enabling students to confidently assess, treat, and monitor individuals at risk of falls.

Overview: The Level 7 Assessment of the Hand and Upper Limb module is designed for occupational therapists and physiotherapists.  It focuses on standardized and non-standardized assessment techniques for hand and upper limb injuries and conditions. The program aims to improve the application of standardized assessments, address common knowledge gaps among hand therapists and meet NHS requirements for evaluating intervention effectiveness. Tutorials are available via telephone, email, or online.  The curriculum emphasizes critical reflection on professional practice and the use of assessment tools.  Overall, the module is intended to enhance participants' ability to make informed decisions about assessment and treatment evaluation in hand therapy.
Course Structure: The course is delivered entirely online via distance learning. Content is modular and may include self-directed learning materials, online lectures, practical activities and assignments. Assessment methods likely involve written assignments, projects, and possibly case study analysis, all aimed at evaluating the participants' understanding of hand and upper limb assessment procedures and critical thinking processes around the subject. The module focuses on both standardized and non-standardized approaches which will provide them with a comprehensive skillset in hand therapy.  Participants will learn to evaluate different methods, understand their benefits and drawbacks, and to critically reflect on how this improves clinical practice.

Course Title: Assessment Only Route to Qualified Teacher Status (QTS)
Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with a minimum of 5.5 in all areas
Entry Requirement: Applicants need a UK degree or equivalent, GCSE grade 4 or above in Maths and English (or equivalent), and a science GCSE (grade 4 or above) if teaching ages 3-11.  Key Skills and OCR Level 2 qualifications are unacceptable; only A Star Equivalency tests are accepted for equivalency.  Two years' teaching experience in two separate schools is required, demonstrating teaching across various backgrounds and approaches from diverse settings (state or international schools). For Pakistani students seeking postgraduate entry, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized university is required, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree, or a four-year Bachelor's degree with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00.  Those with a two or three-year Bachelor's degree need a Master's degree pass.
Annual Tuition Fee: £3325 per candidate for international students. UK Students: Up to 50 miles - £2500; 51-74 miles - £2500 + £60 extra per visit; 75-100 miles - £2500 + £120 extra per visit; 100+ miles - please contact askadmissions@derby.ac.uk to discuss
Overview: The University of Derby's Assessment Only Route to Qualified Teacher Status (QTS) is designed for experienced educators who already possess the necessary skills and knowledge to teach but lack formal QTS certification. This program provides a fast-track pathway to QTS, requiring around 12 weeks of assessment.  Candidates are observed teaching in their school settings, demonstrating competence across the Teachers' Standards.  The assessment process includes observations, portfolio development, a subject knowledge assessment, and a final interview. The program is ideal for those working as unqualified teachers, cover supervisors, HLTAs, supply teachers, experienced further education lecturers, or overseas-trained teachers who do not automatically qualify for QTS or have not gained QTS within four years. The program emphasizes reflective practice and demonstrating competency against the Teachers’ Standards.
Course Structure: The Assessment Only Route is a flexible, assessment-focused program. There's no formal training; instead, candidates demonstrate existing teaching skills and knowledge through a series of assessments.  These assessments involve classroom observations by both school staff and university assessors, the development of a teaching portfolio showcasing evidence against the Teachers' Standards, a subject knowledge assessment, and a final oral examination (viva voce).  Support is provided by a school-appointed mentor and a university assessor throughout the assessment period.  The structured approach ensures that the candidate's teaching skills and knowledge meet the required standards for QTS. Candidates are expected to actively develop professionally and enhance their subject knowledge and teaching skills throughout the assessment period, with ongoing mentoring and feedback.

Required IELTS Score: NA
Entry Requirement: Applicants must be employed for at least 30 hours per week, and their employer must cover apprenticeship costs.  Strong recommendations include Level 2 English and Maths qualifications (GCSE Grade 4-9, GCSE Grade A-C, Level 2 Functional Skills, Key Skills Level 2, or equivalents). For the Maternity Pathway, applicants need Level 2 Maths & English/GCSE Grade 4 (C) or equivalent.  Pakistan-specific entry requirements are not detailed on the provided webpage.  The university may set additional requirements.
Overview: The Assistant Practitioner Higher Apprenticeship is a two-year, online foundation degree designed for individuals entering assistant practitioner roles in healthcare and social care.  It equips students with skills beyond those of traditional healthcare support workers, aligning with current NHS and sector policies.  The curriculum includes core modules focused on communication, safe care practices, and a work-based project, complemented by specialized pathway modules (Nursing, Radiography, Theatres, Occupational Therapy, Maternity). The program prioritizes practical skills, assessment methods include poster presentations, exams, essays, assignments, and case-based discussions. The program is developed in close consultation with employers and offers strong career prospects.
Course Structure: The course is structured across two years, starting with core modules in communication, safe care, and a practice module.  Students choose two additional modules from a selection relevant to their chosen pathway: Nursing, Radiography, Theatres, Occupational Therapy or Maternity. Year two includes core modules on leadership, another practice module involving End-Point Assessment preparation, and further module choices. Pathways offer further specialization; for example, the Nursing pathway includes modules on essential clinical skills and medicines management and allows progression to the Nursing Degree Apprenticeship.  The Radiography pathway focuses on imaging modalities with progression to a related apprenticeship, and similar structured pathways exist for Theatres, Occupational Therapy and Maternity.
Year 1: Year one comprises core modules such as Communicating Health Promotion (40 credits), Developing Safe Care (30 credits), and a Practice Module (10 credits, pass/fail). Students also select two modules (20 credits total) from options including Mental Health Across the Lifespan, Occupation and Wellbeing, Work Based Project, Complex Health and Social Care Needs in Maternity Settings, Essential Clinical Skills, Maternity Care and Skills, Occupational Therapy modules, and modules focusing on Theatres and Radiography practices.  The year involves work placements organised by the employer.
Year 2: Year two builds upon the foundation year, starting with core modules focusing on Leadership and Learning (30 credits) and a Practice Module (10 credits, pass/fail), preparing for End-Point Assessment (EPA, 40 credits). Students select another two modules (20 credits total) from options such as Falls and Frailty, Independence, Dignity and Occupation, Listen Without Prejudice, Music and Care, Work Based Project, Medicines Management, Assisting at Births, Care of the Mother and Newborn in the Postnatal Period, Caring for People with Learning Disabilities, Human Anatomy and Physiology for Healthcare, and modules in Anaesthetic and Imaging Practices. Work placements continue through this year.

Entry Requirement: Entry requirements for this course include a foundation degree in radiographic practice, an IELTS score of 6.5 (or 7.0 at registration with the HCPC), GCSEs in Maths and English at grade C or above, current employment as an Assistant Practitioner in general radiography, a portfolio of radiographic skills evidence, completion of an occupational health screening form, UK residency (international applicants are not eligible), and a Disclosure and Barring Service (DBS) check.  Employers must also partner with the University, and placements outside Derby, Nottingham, or Leicester require College of Radiographers' approval.  For Pakistani students, specific entry requirements are not explicitly detailed on the provided webpage; however, general university requirements may apply.  Further information on Pakistani requirements for undergraduate, postgraduate, and PhD programs are listed separately on the University's website. This would need to be investigated separately for specific eligibility.
Overview: The Level 5 Assistant Practitioner to Radiographer course is a short, intensive program designed for assistant practitioners in general radiography seeking career advancement to Band 5.  The course combines academic study with clinical placements, enhancing practical skills and knowledge.  It focuses on key competencies and core knowledge in diagnostic radiography. Students benefit from high-quality teaching and opportunities to interact with other healthcare students. Upon successful completion, graduates may progress to the final year of a BSc (Hons) Diagnostic Radiography program (self-funded) to become a registered diagnostic radiographer. The program is currently limited to Level 5 qualified Assistant Practitioners in plain film radiography, but other qualified practitioners may be considered.
Course Structure: The course comprises a four-week intensive academic program followed by three short clinical placement blocks.  The academic program builds upon existing knowledge, while clinical placements expose students to various clinical environments.  Throughout the program, students receive extensive tutorial support, focused sessions on research, writing, and analytical skills, and complete multiple assessments.  These assessments include clinical competencies, reflective practice exercises, a professional discussion, a short case report, and an electronic poster/short critical narrative.

An Access to HE Diploma with 60 credits (45 at Level 3, 15 at Level 2) is also acceptable.  Crucially, this course is only open to applicants from ProChance Football or Litchfield Football Club.  Regarding Pakistan entry requirements, the provided text does not offer specific details for this FdA programme.  However, general university details mention that for undergraduate study in Pakistan, completing A-levels or the International Baccalaureate from Pakistani international schools allows entry to the first year of a Bachelor's degree.
Overview: The FdA Athlete Professional Development course at the University of Derby is a unique, flexible program designed for promising sportspeople and officials.  It allows students to balance full-time training and playing/officiating with their studies, providing a recognized qualification while pursuing their sporting careers. The course focuses on personal and professional development, helping students plan for life after sport.  It covers areas like personal values, future planning, and strategies for success both during and after a sporting career. The program uses a blend of on-campus and remote learning, incorporating practical application through work-based learning opportunities in various roles (coaching, teaching, administration, etc.) within the host organization. The aim is to provide students not only with a degree but also with the skills and confidence to transition seamlessly into the next phase of their careers, either advancing their current sporting trajectory or moving into related fields.
Course Structure: The course combines traditional academic study with practical application and work-based learning.  Assessment methods include written papers, presentations, portfolios, blogs, vlogs, and interviews—methods designed to reflect real-world work and prepare students for upcoming careers. The program includes modules focused on personal and professional development, positive communication, teamwork, leadership, ethical considerations in sports, and business skills for planning and implementing products and services. Students have opportunities for application via work-based learning during both years. Year one focuses on developing personal and professional skills, mental and physical well-being, and communication techniques. The second year culminates in an independent project centered on analysis of sporting communities and professional development using business skill sets.  The program also benefits from Personal Academic Tutoring, providing individual support and guidance.
Year 1: The first year of the Athlete Professional Development FdA explores personal and professional development, emphasizing physical and mental well-being.  Students develop skills in positive communication, including counseling techniques and learn the importance of teamwork to foster leadership confidence.  Practical application via work-based learning begins preparing students for future careers and roles within the sports sector.,
Year 2: In the second year, students complete an independent project reflecting on sporting communities and their place in their lives. They delve into ethics on both personal and societal levels, applying their knowledge to relevant events and issues. A key focus is on developing business skills through planning and implementing products or services, preparing students for the next step in their chosen careers.  Work-based learning continues providing practical experience and real-world application of their skills.

Entry Requirement: Applicants need an undergraduate degree (2:2 or above) in Engineering, Science, Music Technology, or an equivalent qualification.  If English isn't your first language, IELTS 6.0 or above is required. For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized university (equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2) is needed.  A Master's degree is also required if the Bachelor's degree was two or three years. A four-year Bachelor's degree with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university is acceptable.
Overview: The University of Derby's MSc Audio Engineering is a master's program designed to equip students with in-demand skills in the audio engineering field.  Developed with industry leaders, the curriculum covers advanced topics such as audio electronics, live sound reinforcement, surround sound systems, and software engineering. Students benefit from state-of-the-art facilities, including 3D multichannel sound rooms and a hemi-anechoic chamber. The program features guest lectures and masterclasses from industry professionals, and students have the opportunity to engage in cutting-edge research.  Graduates are prepared for high-level careers in various audio-related fields.  This is a suitable program for graduates of Electronic Engineering, Music Technology or related subjects seeking to advance within the audio sector and for professionals to further their skills and understanding.
Course Structure: The course is structured in three stages: Postgraduate Certificate, Postgraduate Diploma, and MSc.  The Postgraduate Certificate involves three modules, which could include topics like Audio Electronics, focusing on the electroacoustic signal chain; Audio Innovation, fostering innovative thinking and research; Live Sound System Design and Optimization, covering implementation and system design; Acoustics in Buildings, dealing with acoustic characteristics of enclosed spaces and sound insulation; Environmental Noise Assessment, focusing on diverse noise sources and control; Advanced Surround Sound Systems; Audio Software Engineering, covering music technology software; and a Negotiated Module. The Postgraduate Diploma requires three more modules from this list. The MSc culminates in an Independent Engineering Scholarship, where students develop specialist skills in an area of their choice.
Year 1: The first year (full-time) of the MSc in Audio Engineering comprehensively covers core principles and advanced techniques in audio engineering. Students delve into the design and implementation of audio electronics, exploring both analog and digital methodologies.  Furthermore, they study live sound system design and optimization, incorporating principles of acoustics and room modeling. Advanced surround sound systems are also explored, including various applications in cinema, broadcast, gaming, and personal audio. The curriculum also includes modules specializing in environmental noise assessment and acoustics in buildings, providing a well-rounded education in the field.  Students are also given the opportunity to participate in a research project.

The curriculum would likely cover topics like financial markets, investment strategies, risk management, and regulatory compliance. Course Title: MSc Behaviour Change (incorporating PG Dip/PG Cert)
Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with a minimum of 5.5 in all areas
Entry Requirement: For UK students, an undergraduate degree (lower second or above) or equivalent in a relevant subject or substantial professional experience is required.  The program is part-time only.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognized university is needed, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree. Those with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees require a Master's degree pass. A Bachelor's degree with honors (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university is also acceptable.
Overview: The MSc Behaviour Change program at the University of Derby is a part-time, three-year course designed to equip students with in-depth knowledge and practical skills in understanding and influencing human behavior.  The program covers various psychological theories and models, allowing students to develop interventions to promote positive behavior changes in diverse contexts like health, safety, and environmental sustainability.  It is suitable for both professionals seeking to enhance their skills and graduates wishing to specialize in behavior change. The flexible structure with on-campus study blocks and online learning caters to working professionals and offers a unique blend of theoretical and applied learning.
Course Structure: The MSc Behaviour Change program comprises three stages: Postgraduate Certificate (PG Cert), Postgraduate Diploma (PG Dip), and MSc. The PG Cert involves learning about psychology as a science, examining theories and models of behavior, and developing skills to design and evaluate interventions. The PG Dip expands on this by incorporating advanced research and evaluation skills focusing on quantitative and qualitative methods.  A key component is studying how to sustain behavior change in practical settings. The final MSc stage centers on a research project where students independently investigate a behavior change issue within their chosen area of expertise, applying contemporary psychological methodologies and data analysis techniques.
Year 1: The first year focuses on building a foundation in the psychology of behavior change.  Key modules include "Psychology for Behavior Change," which explores psychological approaches to learning, cognition, individual differences, and social factors in understanding behavior.  "Theories and Models of Behaviour" examines major models and theories of behavior change, incorporating individual, social, and environmental factors. The curriculum also includes "Applied Behaviour Change Interventions," which provides the skills and knowledge to design and evaluate evidence-based behavior change interventions.
Year 2: The second year builds upon the foundational knowledge by developing advanced research and evaluation techniques applicable to various settings.  Modules focus on quantitative and qualitative research methods, particularly relevant to evaluating interventions. Students delve into the complexities of "Sustaining Behaviour Change," drawing on systems thinking and relevant research to understand and impact areas like Positive Psychology, Environmental Sustainability, Health and Safety, and Organizational Culture.
Year 3: The final year is dedicated to the "Research Project in Behaviour Change."  Students undertake an independent study into a chosen aspect of behavior change, guided by a faculty member.   This involves identifying a problem, reviewing the literature, formulating research questions, applying ethical guidelines, and utilizing appropriate methodologies for data collection, analysis, and scientific reporting.

Entry Requirement: Applicants normally need an undergraduate degree (2:2 or above) or equivalent in science, technology, engineering, mathematics, or a related discipline with significant mathematical content.  If English isn't your first language, an IELTS score of 6.0 or equivalent is needed.  Those without these qualifications might be considered if they have relevant work experience in a management or supervisory position.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognized university is required, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree. Students with a two or three-year Bachelor's degree must also have a Master's degree. A Bachelor's degree with honors (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university is also acceptable.
Overview: The MSc Big Data Analytics program equips students with the technical expertise and industrial experience required for careers in big data analytics.  The curriculum covers business intelligence, data analytics, database technology, and the practical application of SAS software. Students work on real-world industry problems and conduct major research projects.  The program benefits from partnerships with global leaders in data analytics, ensuring up-to-date and relevant teaching. Graduates will be equipped to extract, analyze, manage, and visualize information from large datasets, and communicate results effectively. The program aims to develop both technical skills in data analysis and broader skills in communication, teamwork, and management. It is suitable for graduates from STEM fields and those with relevant professional experience.
Course Structure: The course is structured in three stages: Postgraduate Certificate, Postgraduate Diploma, and MSc. The Postgraduate Certificate covers foundational modules such as Studying at Masters Level and Research Methods, Statistical Techniques, and Processing Big Data. The Postgraduate Diploma includes modules like Business Analytics, Analytics: Ethics, Trust and Governance, and an optional module on Information Visualisation.  The MSc stage culminates in an Independent Scholarship module, a substantial research project allowing students to apply their learning to real-world problems and develop advanced research skills.
Year 1: The first year of the full-time MSc Big Data Analytics program would cover modules from the Postgraduate Certificate and Postgraduate Diploma stages, including foundational topics such as research methods, statistical techniques, processing big data, business analytics, ethics in analytics, and data visualization.  Students would develop a strong theoretical foundation and practical skills in data analysis and management using SAS software. There would also likely be introductory sessions and preparation for the Independent Scholarship project.
Year 2: The second year (part-time) or the extended component of the part-time program includes the remaining Postgraduate Diploma modules and the MSc level Independent Scholarship Project. This year focuses on advanced data analysis techniques, independent research, and the application of theoretical knowledge to a significant research project that showcases the student's analytical abilities and research prowess.

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical UCAS points are 104.  A-Level requirements are BCC, with at least a C in Biology.  A Merit in Science is needed for T Levels; DMM for BTECs. GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or above are required.  An Access to HE Diploma with 60 credits (45 at Level 3) is accepted, with a minimum of Distinction: 15, Merit: 24, and Pass: 6. Compulsory Level 3 subjects must be passed.  Contextual offers may be available for students from specific backgrounds.  For Pakistani students with A-levels or IB from international schools in Pakistan, entry may start in the first year.  For Postgraduate study in Pakistan a relevant bachelor's degree is required (equivalent to UK 2:1 or 2:2).  A Masters degree is needed for 2 or 3 year bachelor's degrees.  A 4 year bachelor's with a minimum 2.4/4.0 GPA also qualifies.  For PhD programs in Pakistan, a master's and bachelor's degree in relevant subjects, plus a research proposal, are required.
Overview: The University of Derby's BSc (Hons) Biology program is a three-year (full-time) or up to six-year (part-time) course accredited by the Royal Society of Biology.  It focuses on contemporary and future applications of biology in environmental and biotechnological fields. The curriculum is informed by leading researchers who actively contribute to the field, ensuring students learn cutting-edge developments in areas like coral reef diseases, animal ecology, and cell biology.  The program incorporates fieldwork, laboratory work, and opportunities for placements and internships to enhance practical skills and prepare students for careers in various scientific fields. The course integrates theoretical knowledge with hands-on experience, providing a robust foundation in biological principles and contemporary research methods, fostering adaptability and critical thinking for graduates to contribute to solving global challenges.
Course Structure: The Biology BSc (Hons) program integrates theoretical learning with extensive practical experience.  Students benefit from lectures, seminars, tutorials, e-learning, laboratory work, and fieldwork both within the UK and internationally.  The curriculum includes core modules that build a strong foundation in biological concepts and transferable skills.  Elective modules are included allowing for specialization within the larger field of Biology.  Students undertake a variety of assessments, including written assignments, practical write-ups, data analysis, presentations, and examinations, focusing on authentic assessment methodologies that promote learning through deep engagement. The program strongly emphasizes a blend of theoretical and applied learning. Students are supported through personal tutoring to facilitate professional development and meet individual career aspirations.
Year 1: First-year modules lay the foundation in core biological disciplines.  Students typically cover essential topics in cell biology, genetics, organismal biology, and ecology.  Introductory laboratory and fieldwork experience provides hands-on skill development. Early years also focus on developing fundamental scientific skills and the underlying methodologies for data analysis and interpretation. Students develop foundational knowledge in areas to support subsequent years of more directed study.
Year 2: The second year builds upon the foundational knowledge acquired in the first year.  Students delve deeper into specialized areas of biology, with modules often focusing on areas such as molecular biology, physiology, microbiology, and environmental biology.  More sophisticated experimental design, data analysis, and lab-based practices are introduced. Students might undertake more extensive fieldwork assignments, providing exposure to more advanced research techniques.
Year 3: The final year of the program allows for specialization and project-based learning.  Students typically undertake an independent research project, allowing them to apply their skills and knowledge to conduct original research under supervision.  There are often optional modules which allow for greater choice in areas such as conservation biology, biotechnology, or animal behavior.  The final year cultivates advanced research skills and the ability to critically evaluate scientific evidence.

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2024 entry, typical requirements include 72 UCAS points, A Levels (DDD), T Levels (Pass), BTEC (MMP), or an Access to HE Diploma. GCSEs in Maths and English are preferred but not mandatory.  International students require an IELTS score of 6.0 with at least 5.5 in each skill.  For students from Pakistan completing A-levels or the IB from international schools, entry to the first year is possible.  Students applying from Pakistani universities must hold a relevant Bachelor’s degree equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree; a Masters degree is additionally required for those with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees. Bachelors with honors (four-year) from recognised Pakistani universities with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 are considered for entry.
Overview: The BSc (Hons) Biology with Foundation Year is a four-year undergraduate program at the University of Derby, designed to provide a comprehensive education in biology and zoology. It's structured to equip students with a strong foundation in core biological principles, incorporating cutting-edge research and practical applications. Fieldwork and lab work are incorporated into the curriculum, allowing students to hone their skills in diverse environments and apply their knowledge practically.  The program includes placements and internships. Students will be taught by internationally renowned researchers. The program focuses on critical 21st-century challenges like climate change and biodiversity loss, aiming to prepare graduates to contribute meaningfully to addressing environmental issues.  It cultivates skills in scientific analysis, communication, and teamwork, vital for many biological careers and further education. The course incorporates extensive fieldwork at various locations like Twycross Zoo, Mallorca, and the Maldives(optional module).
Course Structure: The course integrates traditional and modern components of biology. It combines theoretical learning with extensive hands-on laboratory work using state-of-the-art equipment.  The program emphasizes field-based learning through various projects and studies in diverse locations. Students engage in a range of assignments, presentations, and examinations. This includes written assignments, practical work write-ups, data analysis, essays, computer-based assessments, poster presentations, seminar presentations, and traditional examinations.  The curriculum covers various specializations within biology, including ecology, entomology, biodiversity, cell biology, primate evolution, and soil microbiology, depending on students' interests and optional modules and projects.  Students have the option of an industrial placement year to enhance practical experience.
Year 1: The first year, the Foundation Year, aims to build skills, confidence, and knowledge for success in higher education. Students develop a solid foundation in fundamental biological principles, providing support and a steady transition to the undergraduate program.  The curriculum will include introductory modules covering different areas of biology, including basic chemistry, cell biology, genetics, and ecology; along with essential academic skills such as essay writing, critical thinking, and research methods.  This stage involves both theoretical study and practical experience. Students have access to University facilities and resources, ensuring they receive adequate support throughout the foundation year.
Year 2: Year 2 builds on the foundation year, covering more advanced concepts in biology. This stage introduces specialized modules like cell structure and function, genetics and molecular biology, and organismal biology. Students will deepen their understanding of genetics and molecular biology, exploring cellular processes and techniques in molecular biology labs.  Fieldwork opportunities begin at this stage, providing valuable hands-on experience with sampling techniques and data collection in natural environments.  Practical laboratory techniques are further strengthened with a focus on analysis and interpretation of complex scientific data.
Year 3: Year 3 moves into more specialized areas of biology, allowing students to tailor their learning according to their specific interests. Examples include advanced modules in ecology, animal behavior, conservation biology, or plant biology.  The year will likely involve independent research projects with a focus on experimental design, data collection and analysis, and scientific report writing.  Practical skills are further enhanced with laboratory work and extensive fieldwork opportunities across different habitats, including the possibility of international field trips.
Year 4: The final year (Year 4) allows for in-depth study in chosen biological areas.  This includes a substantial research project, allowing them to apply gained knowledge and skills through original research.  They refine their data analysis, research writing, and presentation skills. Advanced concepts within ecology, physiology, genetics, or conservation biology will be explored. Students often focus on a specific research topic under the supervision of experienced researchers, potentially leading to publication and adding to their professional portfolio. This year may include options for placements in relevant organizations.

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical requirements include 120 UCAS points.  A-Level students need BBB, with at least a grade C in a science subject (Biology, Human Biology, or Applied Science).  T Level requires a Merit in Science, while BTEC needs DDM. GCSE Maths and English at grade 4/C or equivalent are also necessary.  An Access to HE Diploma with 60 credits (45 at Level 3) is an alternative.  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or IB from International Schools in Pakistan, direct entry into Year 1 is possible.  Contextual offers may be provided to students who meet certain criteria such as care experience, being estranged from family, refugee/asylum seeker status, or having parents in the UK armed forces.
Overview: The University of Derby's BSc (Hons) Biomedical Science program is a comprehensive undergraduate course focusing on the practical application of science to human health and disease.  Students develop strong laboratory skills through hands-on experience starting in the first year.  The curriculum covers core subjects such as clinical chemistry, immunology, microbiology, histology, clinical genetics, molecular biology, pathology, and cancer biology.  The program integrates employability training, providing students with opportunities for work placements, internships, and participation in research projects.  The course is accredited by the Institute of Biomedical Science (IBMS), providing a pathway to registration as a Biomedical Scientist with the HCPC.  The program also includes sessions on research governance, ethics, and good scientific practice.  Graduates are well-prepared for careers in clinical and public health laboratories, industry, and research settings.
Course Structure: The Biomedical Science BSc (Hons) at the University of Derby is structured across three years (full time) or up to six years (part-time).  The curriculum combines theoretical study with extensive practical laboratory work.  Year one introduces fundamental concepts in biological and medical sciences, including laboratory techniques. Year two builds upon these foundations, exploring advanced topics in areas such as clinical chemistry, microbiology, and immunology alongside further development of professional skills. Year three culminates in a substantial research project, allowing students to apply their learning to a chosen area, often within a clinical or laboratory setting. Throughout the course, students benefit from a range of teaching methods and assessments, including lectures, tutorials, seminars, laboratory sessions, computer sessions, coursework, laboratory reports, essays, presentations, and examinations.
Year 1: The first year provides a foundational understanding of biomedical science.  Students learn core biological principles, essential laboratory techniques, and basic medical science concepts. Key subjects include introductory modules in human biology, chemistry, cell biology, and introductory laboratory skills.  This year focuses on building a solid base for the more specialized modules in subsequent years. Along with theoretical aspects, practical laboratory-based skills and data analysis receive significant attention.
Year 2: Building on the foundation from year one, year two delves into more specialized areas of biomedical science.  Students explore topics like clinical chemistry, immunology, microbiology, and histology.  Focus shifts towards developing advanced laboratory skills and scientific investigation techniques. The year often includes mandatory work experience placements to provide practical application of knowledge and develop professional experience. Assessment involves a combination of assignments, laboratory reports and exams.
Year 3: The final year provides opportunities for independent research and project development.  Students undertake an independent research project, applying previously acquired knowledge and skills to investigate a topic of their choice.  This usually involves a lab-based project or analysis of clinical data.  Modules likely include advanced subjects related to pathophysiology and research methodology, enabling them to develop sophisticated analytical skills and build on their understanding of experimental design.  Presentations and reports form a key part of the assessment.

Required IELTS Score: 6.5 (with no band score less than 6.0)
Entry Requirement: A 2.2 UK Honours degree or above in biomedical science or a related discipline with a high proportion of biomedical content, or an international equivalent. Evidence of competence in written and spoken English (GCSE grade C or equivalent) is required. An interview may be optional, depending on the applicant's status. Alternative entry qualifications, such as Recognition of Prior Experiential Learning (RPEL), are assessed on a case-by-case basis. Working experience in NHS laboratories is desirable.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised University in Pakistan is required, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree. Students with a two or three-year Bachelor's degree must also have a pass in a Master’s degree. A Bachelor's degree with honours (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University is also acceptable.
Overview: The University of Derby's MSc Biomedical Science program offers advanced knowledge of clinical disease concepts and their pathophysiology through laboratory investigations using cutting-edge methods.  Students develop critical reflection on biomedical theories and practice, problem-solving skills, and expertise in a chosen specialization: clinical immunology, advanced cellular pathology, or clinical hematology and transfusion science.  The program includes advanced research training, encompassing multi-omics approaches in disease diagnosis and drug development, conducted in university labs, NHS hospitals (subject to availability), or the student's workplace (with approval).  The curriculum bridges the gap between undergraduate study and a PhD or provides a stand-alone research qualification. Strong industry connections with NHS trusts enhance practical application and career prospects.
Course Structure: The MSc Biomedical Science curriculum comprises core modules such as 'Professional Skills in Biomedical Science', 'Applied Microbial Biotechnology', and 'Current Issues in Biomedical Science,' alongside 'Research Methods and Data Interpretation'.  A significant component is the 'Research Project', which develops research skills and culminates in a journal-style research article. Students also select one of three specialist options: 'Clinical Haematology and Transfusion Medicine', 'Applied Immunology', or 'Advanced Cellular Pathology'. Assessment methods are varied, including essays, lab reports, case studies, reflective portfolios, posters, and oral presentations, ensuring a comprehensive evaluation of acquired skills and knowledge. The program's structure emphasizes both theoretical understanding and practical application, preparing graduates for diverse roles in the biomedical field.
Year 1: The MSc Biomedical Science program is a one-year full-time course. The first and only year includes core modules covering professional skills in biomedical science, applied microbial biotechnology, current issues in the field, and research methods and data interpretation.  A significant portion of the year is dedicated to an independent research project, chosen from the three specialist options: clinical haematology and transfusion science, applied immunology, or advanced cellular pathology. This project emphasizes development of advanced laboratory and research skills, resulting in a journal-style research article.  Throughout the year, students benefit from state-of-the-art laboratory facilities, including the new FORM facility for omics research.

Course Title: Undergraduate Biomedical Science with Foundation Year BSc (Hons)
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 72 UCAS points, A Levels (DDD), T Level (Pass), BTEC (MMP), or a Pass in the Access to HE Diploma.  GCSEs in Maths and English are preferred but not mandatory; students lacking these can take Level 2 courses as part of their degree. International students need an IELTS score of 6.0 with at least 5.5 in each skill. For Pakistani students, A-levels or IB from Pakistani international schools allow direct entry into Year 1.  Those with a four-year Bachelor's degree with a minimum 2.4/4.0 GPA from a recognized Pakistani university are considered for entry.
Overview: The University of Derby's Biomedical Science with Foundation Year BSc (Hons) is a four-year undergraduate program designed to equip students with practical laboratory skills and a strong foundation in biomedical sciences.  The curriculum covers various core subjects, including clinical chemistry, immunology, microbiology, histology, clinical genetics, molecular biology, pathology, and cancer biology. Students will gain hands-on experience through laboratory research, starting from the first year, and participate in scientific investigations, culminating in an independent research project in the final year. The program includes employability and interpersonal skills modules with placements and internships. The course is accredited by the Institute of Biomedical Science (IBMS).
Course Structure: The course is structured to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of biomedical sciences, integrating theoretical knowledge with substantial practical laboratory experience.  The first year introduces fundamental concepts, providing a solid foundation in core areas like cell biology, chemistry, and human biology. As students progress through each subsequent year, they will explore more specialized areas, such as clinical biochemistry, immunology, microbiology, and genetics.  The curriculum includes lectures, tutorials, workshops, laboratory sessions, computer-based learning activities, and research projects.  A significant portion of the program is dedicated to developing practical laboratory skills, essential for future employment in various biomedical settings. Students will present their research at conferences and gain experience through work placements.
Year 1: The first year lays the groundwork for future studies by introducing fundamental concepts in biomedical sciences.  Students develop essential skills in laboratory techniques, data analysis, and scientific report writing. Key topics covered typically include fundamental concepts in chemistry, biology, cell biology, human anatomy, and physiology.  The focus is on establishing a robust understanding of the biological processes and building fundamental laboratory skills.
Year 2: The second year builds upon the foundation established in the first year, introducing more advanced concepts and techniques in several core areas of biomedical sciences.  Students delve deeper into subjects like microbiology, immunology, genetics, and molecular biology.  Practical laboratory work becomes more sophisticated and includes more focused experiments. Students normally complete at least 30 hours of work experience during their second year to enhance their employability profile and to apply learned concepts to real world setting.
Year 3: The third year provides specialization within biomedical science, allowing students to delve deeper into particular areas of interest.  Students enhance their independent research skills by working on an individual research project or by participating in research project associated with the university's research initiatives.   Modules focus on advanced topics within the core subjects, combined with further enhancement of laboratory skills.  An optional year-long placement in industry or research setting is possible during this period.
Year 4: The final year culminates in an independent research project, furthering research capabilities. Students conduct in-depth investigations within their chosen area of interest, applying advanced knowledge and techniques learned throughout the program.  Students present their research findings at conferences and/or through final year dissertation .  This year builds upon the earlier years and allows for more self-directed learning and refined professional skills.

Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with a minimum of 5.5 in all areas
Entry Requirement: Applicants typically need a first degree or equivalent healthcare qualification and registration with a relevant professional body, along with appropriate post-registration experience.  They must be working as a physician, radiographer, technologist, or nurse in a bone densitometry service, with support from the service's clinically responsible clinician who will sign off the reflective portfolio.  Completion of appropriate IRMER training and the NOS National Training Scheme for Bone Densitometry, or the Postgraduate Certificate in Osteoporosis and Falls Management, or equivalent osteoporosis service experience is required. For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised University in Pakistan equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree is needed. Those with two or three-year Bachelor degrees require a Master’s degree pass.  A four-year Bachelor's degree with honours and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University is also considered.
Overview: The Postgraduate Certificate in Bone Densitometry Reporting is a part-time course designed to enhance knowledge and skills in osteoporosis diagnosis, fracture prevention, and DXA (dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry) reporting.  The program focuses on developing a systematic approach to research appraisal and bone mineral density result reporting.  Students learn to critically evaluate evidence, improve patient management skills, and identify areas for practice improvement.  The curriculum includes modules on DXA reporting and an additional module from the MSc Leadership in Health and Social Care, allowing for personalized learning and professional development.  The course incorporates the University Certificate Continuing Professional Development in DXA Reporting for Clinicians.  Learning is supported by healthcare professionals with experience in fracture risk management. Students benefit from a multi-professional learning environment, enhancing understanding across various healthcare settings and the program closely aligns with current health and social care sector standards and national guidance.
Course Structure: The course consists of modules focusing on DXA reporting for clinicians and one additional 20-credit module chosen from the MSc Leadership in Health and Social Care program.  This elective module can be related to bone densitometry reporting or a more general area of interest.  Examples of available modules include Advancing Practice, Assessment, Prevention and Management of Falls (Theory), Principles of Service Improvement in the Workplace, and Theoretical Considerations in the Diagnosis and Management of Osteoporosis. A work-based negotiated module is also included. Assessment involves creating a portfolio of reports and extended case studies with an audit comparing reports to those of a trained practitioner, along with a written examination and assignment on Vertebral Fracture Assessment (VFA).

Required IELTS Score: NA
Entry Requirement: The Bridge to GeoEnergy course has no formal entry requirements.  It is open to all, regardless of age, location, or educational background. However, basic requirements include internet access and a valid email address to register for the online learning environment.  Proficiency in English is necessary to fully participate.  For those seeking to pursue postgraduate studies in GeoEnergy at the University of Derby, this short course is particularly beneficial for providing the foundational geoscience knowledge necessary for a Master's degree.  Specific entry requirements for the MSc GeoEnergy at University of Derby, for Pakistani students, include completion of a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized university, equivalent to at least a UK Upper Second Class (2:1) or Lower Second Class (2:2) degree.  Those holding a two- or three-year Bachelor's degree might need a Master's degree pass.  A four-year Bachelor's degree with honors (minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00) is acceptable for Master's entry.
Overview: The Bridge to GeoEnergy online short course provides a foundational understanding of geoscience principles crucial for a successful transition to the GeoEnergy sector.  It is designed for those lacking the technical skills needed to pursue a Master's in GeoEnergy, professionals seeking a career shift toward non-carbon geo-energy, those returning to geoscience after a career break, and individuals addressing energy poverty challenges. The course covers fundamentals of geology, and sedimentary rocks and basins, porosity, permeability, and fluid flow. It also delves into the challenges of the Net Zero Carbon transition and explores relevant GeoEnergy solutions.  The self-guided learning is highly flexible and accommodates personal and professional commitments.  Successful completion results in an e-certificate and recognition of 48 CPD hours.
Course Structure: The course consists of six units, each requiring approximately eight hours of self-directed study. Unit 1 introduces fundamental geological concepts, while Unit 2 focuses on sediments and sedimentary rocks. Unit 3 examines interpreting sedimentary environments, followed by sequence stratigraphic concepts in Unit 4.  Unit 5 covers porosity and permeability, and the final unit investigates the transition to Net Zero Carbon and GeoEnergy solutions, including areas like geothermal, hydrogen, carbon capture and storage, and hydrocarbons. There is no graded assessment; however, learners receive a badge for each completed unit and an e-certificate upon course completion.

Required IELTS Score: NA
Entry Requirement: This free online course has no formal entry requirements.  It is open to anyone interested in learning more about dementia, including carers, healthcare professionals, and individuals with a general interest in the subject. There are no specific standardized test scores like IELTS, TOEFL, or PTE required for admission.  The course is accessible regardless of age, location, or prior educational background. For Pakistani students, there are no special entry requirements beyond an interest in the course subject matter.  The course does not offer university credits and is not comparable to undergraduate or postgraduate qualifications.
Overview: The "Bridging the Dementia Divide" course offers a comprehensive understanding of dementia, its global impact, and effective care strategies.  The course emphasizes compassionate communication and collaborative care approaches, challenging stereotypes and promoting sensitivity towards individuals living with dementia and their families.  It explores various aspects of dementia care, including communication techniques, ethical considerations, maintaining independence and dignity, and end-of-life care.  Participants engage in interactive activities like forum discussions and group work to learn best practices in dementia care, and the impact of cultural differences on healthcare responses. The flexible, self-paced online format fits various schedules. It aims to equip learners with the knowledge and skills to provide better care and improve the quality of life for people with dementia.
Course Structure: The course consists of five units, each requiring about three hours of study per week for a total duration of five weeks. Unit 1 introduces dementia, covering types, causes, stages, and available treatments. Unit 2 focuses on compassionate communication and effective interaction strategies for dementia care. Unit 3 examines independence, dignity, quality of life, consent, and capacity issues in dementia care.  Unit 4 explores the global impact of dementia, including cultural variations in healthcare responses and the importance of integrated care. Unit 5 integrates previous learning, discussing dementia progression, challenges during later stages, and palliative care considerations for both patients and families.  The course uses a variety of learning methods, including videos, forum discussions, and group activities, making it both educational and interactive.

Course Title: MSc Building Information Modelling and Project Collaboration
Entry Requirement: A minimum of a 2:2 undergraduate degree in architectural, construction or other built environment, or a professional qualification of equal standing, or significant practical or professional experience that would support your application is required. If English is not your first language, you will need to demonstrate proficiency in English (IELTS 6.0 or equivalent).  Applicants from non-traditional backgrounds are welcome and will be accepted subject to successful interview and relevant work experience. For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised University in Pakistan, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree, is needed. Students with a two or three-year Bachelor's degree must also have a pass in a Master’s degree. A Bachelor's degree with honours (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University is also acceptable.
Overview: The MSc Building Information Modelling (BIM) and Project Collaboration course is designed for professionals in architecture, architectural technology, design and project management, civil/structural engineering, and surveying.  The program focuses on BIM as an industry-standard approach to building lifecycle management, integrating design management, sustainable design analysis, advanced modeling, customization, and visualization.  Students learn through real-world project simulations, collaborative learning, and cutting-edge technology.  The curriculum is informed by the latest research and industrial practices, emphasizing efficient design integration and project collaboration. The course is accredited by RICS, CIAT, and CIOB, offering a pathway to chartership and enhanced career prospects.
Course Structure: The course comprises three stages: Postgraduate Certificate, Postgraduate Diploma, and MSc. The Postgraduate Certificate covers modules such as BIM and Integrated Project Collaboration, nD BIM – Costing, Project Planning and Design Management, and Environmental Risk and Responsibility. The Postgraduate Diploma includes modules like Advanced Parametric Design and Specification, Sustainable Design Analysis and Simulation, and electives such as Project Planning, Value Engineering and Risk Management, Construction Contracts and Dispute Resolution, and Sustainable Architecture and Low Energy Design. The MSc culminates in an Independent Scholarship module.  Assessment methods are varied, including coursework, live projects, assignments, presentations, and an Autodesk Certification exam.
Year 1: The first year of the full-time MSc program covers fundamental BIM principles, integrated project collaboration, and nD BIM applications in costing, project planning, and design management.  Environmental risk and responsibility are also addressed. Students delve into advanced parametric design, sustainable design analysis and simulation, and may choose electives like project planning, value engineering, risk management, construction contracts, dispute resolution, or sustainable architecture and low energy design.
Year 2: The second year, for part-time students, builds upon the first year's foundation.  It focuses on more advanced applications of BIM, further exploration of sustainable design, and potentially includes a substantial independent research project, culminating in a final dissertation or project submission. Students will also have the opportunity to apply their knowledge through practical project work.

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For entry in 2025, typical requirements include 112 UCAS points, A-Levels BBC, T Level Merit, BTEC DMM, GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or above, or an Access to HE Diploma (60 credits, 45 at Level 3, minimum Distinction: 15, Merit: 24, Pass: 6).  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or IB from international schools, entry into the first year of a Bachelor's degree is possible. Contextual offers may be available for students meeting specific criteria, such as being care experienced, estranged from their families, refugees, asylum seekers, or having parents/carers in the UK armed forces.  Students need to declare these criteria on their application.
Overview: The BA (Hons) Business Accounting and Finance degree at the University of Derby provides a comprehensive education in accounting and finance principles, blending them with business strategy, leadership, and governance.  The program equips students with the versatility and flexibility to excel in diverse business settings globally. Students develop strong analytical and problem-solving skills through real-world projects for various organizations.  Graduates gain eligibility for exemptions from professional accounting bodies like CIMA, ACCA, and ICAEW, accelerating their career progression.  The curriculum combines theoretical knowledge with hands-on experience using professional software and data services like Bloomberg, enhancing practical skills.  The program emphasizes real-world application, including consultancy projects with local employers, visits to organizations, and interactions with industry professionals.
Course Structure: The course structure combines core accounting and finance modules with broader business-related subjects.  Year 1 likely features introductory accounting, financial mathematics, and business foundations.  Year 2 builds upon this with more advanced accounting topics, potentially including management accounting, financial reporting, and business analysis techniques. Year 3 will likely focus on specialized accounting areas and encompass a major project or consultancy work with external organizations, solidifying practical application and professional skills.  The curriculum also includes workshops, guest lectures, and field trips, ensuring practical experience and industry insights.  Assessment methods vary, including computer-based assessments, essays, reports, projects, presentations, and examinations.
Year 1: The first year establishes a strong foundation in accounting principles, financial mathematics, and introductory business subjects. Students learn basic accounting concepts such as financial statements, budgeting, and cost accounting.  Introduction to business environments and operations, possibly including elements of law or management, are also included. The foundation year would involve developing business and accounting literacy in preparation for the main degree programme.
Year 2: Building on the first year, the second year delves into more advanced accounting methodologies. The modules might include management accounting techniques, financial reporting standards, financial statement analysis, and auditing concepts.  Students also learn about areas like business strategy, focusing on accounting's role in decision making.  The year continues developing analytical and problem-solving skills, preparing students for more complex scenarios.
Year 3: Year three focuses on more specialized accounting and finance topics with a greater emphasis on practical application. This year may include modules on consultancy projects, where students work on real-life business problems for external clients or organizations.  Advanced financial modeling, corporate finance, and possibly other specialized areas, such as taxation or forensic accounting, are possibly included.  The culminations could include a major dissertation or final-year project.

Overview: The University of Derby's Business Accounting and Finance BA (Hons) with Placement Year is a four-year undergraduate program designed to equip students with a comprehensive understanding of accounting and finance principles, combined with essential business skills.  The curriculum blends theoretical knowledge with practical application, preparing graduates for diverse roles within the accounting and finance industry.  Students develop strong financial and management accounting skills while gaining expertise in business strategy, leadership, and governance. The program includes a placement year, allowing students to build real-world experience, network with industry professionals, and apply their classroom learning in a professional setting.  Graduates will obtain significant exemptions from professional accountancy bodies like CIMA, ACCA, and ICAEW, accelerating their career progression. The program integrates hands-on learning through projects for real organizations, use of professional data services, and field trips, enriching the educational experience and enhancing practical skill building.
Course Structure: The course structure integrates core accounting and finance modules with business-related subjects. Year one introduces fundamental accounting principles, financial reporting, and business economics. Year two covers financial management, management accounting, and broader business contexts.  The placement year provides extensive practical experience, with student support available throughout.  Year three builds on prior learning, incorporating advanced accounting techniques, business strategy, and ethical considerations.  In each year there is likely a mix of lectures, seminars, coursework, and assessments, including computer-based assessments, essays, reports, projects, and examinations. Year 1: The first year lays a solid foundation in accounting principles, including financial accounting, bookkeeping, and introductory managerial accounting.  Students are also introduced to foundational business concepts such as economics, business law, and business communication.  The year’s curriculum develops numeracy skills and exposes students to the various sectors and roles within accounting and finance.
Year 2: The second year builds upon the first, consolidating accounting knowledge and introducing more advanced concepts. Students delve into financial management, exploring topics like investment appraisal, working capital management, and risk management.  Management accounting techniques are developed further, and students gain insights into cost accounting, performance measurement, and budgeting and forecasting.  The year concludes with foundational knowledge and practical work that prepare the students for the placement year.
Year 3: The third year is the placement year, providing invaluable practical experience and professional development.  Students undertake a full-time placement within an organization relevant to accounting and finance, gaining hands-on skills. The placement exposes students to the professional environment, enabling them to network and gain practical knowledge of an accounting role, applying classroom concepts in a practical situation.  Guidance is commonly provided by academics and career services during this year. Following this year, the accounting modules and assessments become more business-focused using some of the skills demonstrated during the placement.
Year 4: The final year brings together the knowledge and skills acquired throughout the program.  Students will engage in advanced topics in financial and management accounting, focusing on strategic decision-making and leadership perspectives. The focus is on preparing students for professional roles within diverse organizations and industries, further building upon placement learning.

Entry Requirement: To be eligible for the BSc (Hons) Business and Management Top-Up, you need a HND, foundation degree, or equivalent qualification in a business-related field or 240 credits from a business-related qualification.  Other professional business qualifications like BTEC level 5, CMI level 5, Edexcel level 5, and CIMA may also be considered. If you have completed a relevant ABE Level 6 Diploma in Business Management, an ABE Level 6 Diploma in Business Management and Marketing, ATHE Level 6 Diploma in Business and Administrative Management, or the ATHE Level 6 Extended Diploma in Management, you may be eligible for module exemptions. If English isn't your first language, you'll need an IELTS 6.0, TOEFL 550 (paper-based), 213 (computer-based), or 80 (internet-based), Pearson Test of Academic English: 51, Cambridge Advanced Certificate: Pass, London Tests of English (level 4), International GCE O-level English Language (Grade C), or International GCSE English/English as a Second Language (Grade C). Postgraduate students need a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to at least a UK 'Upper Second Class (2:1)' or 'Lower Second Class (2:2)' degree. Students with a two or three-year Bachelor's degree must also have a pass in a Master's degree. A four-year Bachelor's degree with honours and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University is also acceptable for Masters.

The curriculum focuses on strengthening leadership and management capabilities, developing specialist knowledge through optional modules, building transferable skills (digital literacy, innovation, cross-cultural understanding), and conducting in-depth research.  It covers strategic management, resource management, stakeholder needs, ethical considerations, and innovation. The course blends theory with practice, using real-world case studies and diverse student experiences.  It offers a global perspective and includes guest lectures from industry professionals and CMI representatives.  Graduates receive a BSc (Hons) degree and a CMI Level 5 Diploma or Certificate in Management and Leadership.

Key modules include Leadership and Management, an Independent Research Project, and a choice between Project Management or Strategic Marketing to fulfill the optional credits. The curriculum is regularly updated to reflect current trends and business challenges. Students have flexibility to study one or two modules per trimester depending on their preferred pace, which impacts the overall course duration.
