Overview: The Postgraduate Certificate in Civil Engineering and Construction Management is designed for built environment professionals. It aims to equip them with essential skills to address current and future technological and environmental challenges in the civil engineering and construction sectors. The program delves into the interplay between legislation, the environment, and technical advancements to promote sustainable urban and rural development.  The curriculum balances core and optional modules, allowing for personalized study paths. Modules cover crucial topics such as flood risk management, sustainable development, and environmental performance management, fostering expertise in achieving and maintaining sustainable built environments. This certificate serves as a stepping-stone to the MSc in Civil Engineering and Construction Management, providing 60 credits (level 7) towards that degree.
Course Structure: The PG Cert requires successful completion of one core 20-credit module and two optional 20-credit modules, totaling 60 credits. Students study alongside the MSc programme cohort.  Modules address key areas within civil engineering and construction management, such as project planning, value engineering, risk management, transport and infrastructure engineering, sustainable design, and geotechnical engineering. Some modules incorporate a three to five-day residential in Derbyshire, offering hands-on experience using state-of-the-art equipment.   The program emphasizes practical application through live lectures, tutorials, seminars, and assessments such as project design work, design briefs, project reviews, portfolios, assignments, case studies, presentations, teamwork projects, and examinations. Two optional modules, 'Geomatic Monitoring and Asset Engineering' and 'Advanced Geotechnical Engineering', involve a residential component.
Year 1: The Postgraduate Certificate in Civil Engineering and Construction Management is a one-year program.  The first year comprises at least three modules. A core module and optional modules covering various aspects of civil engineering and construction management. Depending on modules selected, students may participate in a short residential program in Derbyshire, focusing on practical application of theoretical knowledge.  Assessment methods include online exams, project work, presentations and more.

Overview: The University of Derby's BEng (Hons) Civil Engineering program is a four-year undergraduate course (including a compulsory placement year) designed to equip students with advanced knowledge and practical skills in various civil engineering domains.  The curriculum covers structures and infrastructure design, technical design processes, management, and key skills in structures, fluids, geology, soil mechanics, surveying, and materials. Students engage in real-life projects, case studies, site visits, and fieldwork to bridge theoretical learning with practical application.  The course is accredited by leading professional bodies, partially meeting the academic requirements for Chartered Engineer registration.  The university provides extensive support, including personal academic tutoring and industry placement opportunities to enhance students' career prospects. The program integrates hands-on experience using state-of-the-art equipment at the university's STEM Centre. The program aims to make students work ready by giving them opportunities like internships, placements and graduate roles.
Course Structure: The course structure combines lectures, seminars, tutorials, laboratory work (both on and off-campus), site work, and company visits.  Assessment methods include workshop labs, fieldwork, group projects, individual assignments, and design-based exams.  The curriculum covers a broad range of civil engineering topics, including but not limited to structural analysis and design, geotechnical engineering, transportation engineering, hydraulics and hydrology, and construction management. The specific module breakdown may change from year to year. The course includes a compulsory placement year between the second and final year of study, providing students with valuable real-world work experience.
Year 1: First-year modules likely introduce fundamental concepts in mathematics, engineering mechanics, introductory surveying, introduction to civil engineering materials, and engineering drawing.  Students would also begin to develop their understanding of fundamental principles in areas such as structural analysis, fluid mechanics, and soil mechanics, along with an introduction to construction techniques and management.  Laboratory and practical sessions would be integrated to support the theoretical learning.
Year 2: The second year builds upon the foundations established in the first year.  It would likely delve deeper into subjects like structural analysis, geotechnical engineering, and hydraulics, including more advanced calculations and design principles.  Students may encounter modules on transportation engineering, environmental engineering, and construction planning and management.  Further development of practical skills through laboratory and fieldwork exercises is expected.
Year 3: The third year typically involves a placement year in industry, where students gain real-world experience working on civil engineering projects under professional supervision.  This can provide students with exposure to specific areas within the industry, shaping their career goals.  The internship allows students to put their theoretical knowledge to practical use, develop their interpersonal skills, and build a professional network.
Year 4: The final year would involve advanced modules which may cover specialized areas within civil engineering, such as structural design, geotechnical design, hydrological modelling, transportation planning, or construction management. Design projects, typically involving a significant level of autonomy, are included to test students' abilities.  Students will also complete a significant final year project showcasing the skills and knowledge acquired throughout the course.

An Access to HE Diploma with 60 credits (45 at Level 3, minimum Distinction: 15, Merit: 24, Pass: 6) is also acceptable. Those with a relevant HND or equivalent may enter later stages of the course.

Overview: The University of Derby's BSc (Hons) Civil Engineering program is a three-year, full-time course designed to equip students with the knowledge and skills necessary for a successful career in civil engineering.  The curriculum covers a wide range of topics, including structures, fluids, geology, soil mechanics, surveying, and materials. The program integrates theoretical learning with practical experience through real-life projects, case studies, site visits, and field trips. Students work on projects like sustainable building designs in collaboration with organizations such as Down to Earth Derby and Eden Project.  The program includes a personal academic tutoring program to support individual student progress and goals. Graduates will meet the academic requirements to register as an Incorporated Engineer (IEng), opening various career avenues.
Course Structure: The course integrates theory and practice through a combination of lectures, seminars, tutorials, laboratory work, and site visits.  Students gain hands-on experience through workshop laboratories, surveying fieldwork, group projects, and individual assignments.  The program is accredited by leading professional institutions, ensuring graduates meet the requirements for professional registration.  Modules likely cover core civil engineering subjects such as structural analysis and design, geotechnical engineering, hydrology and hydraulics, transportation engineering, and construction management.  Specific module details may change and should be checked on the University's website.
Year 1: The first year will likely introduce foundational concepts in mathematics, science, and engineering principles relevant to civil engineering.  Introductory modules covering topics such as statics and dynamics, materials science, surveying, and introductory design might be included.  Students will be introduced to the core areas of the discipline and develop fundamental skills in problem-solving and analytical thinking.  This year would include essential laboratory sessions for fundamental engineering practices.
Year 2: The second year deepens knowledge in core areas and introduces more specialized subjects.  Students will likely take modules such as structural analysis, geotechnical engineering, fluid mechanics, transportation engineering, and construction materials.  More advanced design projects and laboratory experiments would enhance their practical understanding.  Field trips and site visits will provide real-world context to their learning.
Year 3: The third year involves advanced coursework and significant project work.  Students may specialize in areas like structural engineering, geotechnical engineering, or transportation engineering, undertaking substantial design projects and potentially involving industrial collaborations.  Students will further develop their skills in project management, report writing, and professional presentation.  A final-year project allows them to demonstrate independent research and problem-solving abilities.

Entry Requirement: Minimum 96 UCAS points at A-level or equivalent, including Mathematics and one STEM subject (Physics, ICT, Computing, Electronics). Alternatively, a Level 3 Civil Engineering Technician Apprenticeship and five GCSEs (A*-C) including Mathematics, English Language, and Double Science.  Employers set their own criteria.  For Pakistani students with A-levels or IB from International Schools, direct entry to Year 1 is possible.  Postgraduate entry requires a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized Pakistani university, equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2. A Master's degree is needed if the Bachelor's is two or three years. A four-year Bachelor's with a minimum 2.4/4.0 GPA is also acceptable.  PhD applicants need a Master's and Bachelor's in relevant subjects plus a research proposal.
Overview: The BEng (Hons) Civil Engineering (Apprenticeship) is a part-time degree designed for apprentices working in the civil engineering sector.  The program combines on-the-job training with university-based learning, providing a practical and theoretical grounding in the field.  Students will develop skills in areas such as structural engineering, geotechnics, hydraulics, surveying, and construction management, using state-of-the-art facilities. The program is accredited by the Joint Board of Moderators and the Institution of Civil Engineers, leading to Incorporated Engineer (IEng) status.
Course Structure: The four-year program is divided into levels. Level 4 covers introductory topics in applied mathematics, construction materials, CAD, surveying, and construction health and safety. Level 5 delves deeper into applied mathematics, geology, structural design, infrastructure surveying and asset management, fluids and drainage, and infrastructure design. Level 6 culminates in a final year project focusing on independent study and professional development, alongside further advanced study in geotechnical, structural, hydraulic, and construction management aspects of civil engineering.
Year 1: Level 4 modules introduce fundamental concepts in civil engineering, including applied mathematics, construction materials and technology, and the basics of structural engineering. Students also gain experience with CAD, surveying techniques, and construction health and safety practices.  The focus is on developing a foundation in core principles, alongside professional skills.
Year 2: Level 5 builds upon the foundational knowledge from Year 1. More advanced topics in applied mathematics, geotechnical engineering (geology and soil mechanics), structural design, and surveying are covered in detail. This year introduces more specialized topics in fluids and drainage engineering, and further development on  infrastructure design and material selection.
Year 3: Level 6 modules challenge students with advanced technical topics. The focus shifts toward project-based learning, culminating in a significant final year project that encourages independent investigation and professional development in a chosen area of civil engineering. Also covered are more advanced studies in geotechnical, structural, and hydraulic engineering, plus construction management.
Year 4: The final year integrates theoretical knowledge with practical applications. Through advanced modules and the final-year project, students demonstrate their ability to apply theoretical knowledge to real-world civil engineering challenges. The final year project can be structured around the student’s area of interest within the field and allow them to tailor the final piece of academic work according to the needs and skills learned during the apprenticeship.

Overview: The BEng (Hons) Civil Engineering with Foundation Year is a four-year (or five-year with an optional placement year) undergraduate program offered by the University of Derby. This course provides a strong foundation in civil engineering principles and practices, preparing students for professional roles in design, construction, maintenance, and asset management. The integrated foundation year offers extra support to students who need it, before proceeding to the main degree.  Students develop a comprehensive understanding of structural and infrastructure design, technical design and management processes, and key skills such as surveying, soil mechanics, structural design, fluids, geology and material science. The program includes hands-on learning experiences through real-life projects, case studies, site visits, and field trips, conducted within the new STEM Centre.
Course Structure: The course combines theoretical knowledge with practical applications.  The curriculum covers fundamental civil engineering principles, including structural analysis, geotechnical engineering, hydraulics, transportation engineering, and construction management.  Students apply this knowledge using sophisticated computer aided-software and are provided with real-life projects and case studies and supported by civil engineering experts.  Students have the choice of including a year in industry and will use dedicated Civil Engineering laboratories in the new STEM Centre on campus. Assessment involves a combination of coursework, lab work, field surveys, group projects, individual assignments, and design-based exams. Furthermore, students benefit from a Personal Academic Tutor (PAT) program, providing individualized support and guidance.
Year 1: The foundation year focuses on building a strong foundation in mathematics, science, and engineering principles. It provides essential knowledge and skills needed for success in the subsequent years of the degree program. This year helps students who haven't studied many of these subjects before, to gain confidence and expertise before beginning the main degree.  It includes introductory modules in engineering concepts, mathematics, and fundamental science topics to ensure a solid educational base for further study.
Year 2: Year two of the BEng (Hons) Civil Engineering program delves into core civil engineering subjects, introducing students to structural analysis, geotechnical engineering, and fluid mechanics. Students begin to apply the theoretical knowledge they gained in the foundation year to practical problem solving. The curriculum also helps students develop their skills in engineering design and technical drawings.
Year 3: The third year builds upon the foundation established in the previous years, exploring advanced concepts in structural design, transportation engineering, and construction management.  The year increases the student's practical skills and design proficiency. Students engage in project-based learning, tackling complex engineering challenges that simulate real-world situations. There is also the opportunity to spend a year in industry for students completing the 5 year course option.
Year 4: The final year of study focuses on advanced specialisation within civil engineering, allowing students to choose electives that align with their areas of interest.  They develop their proficiency in advanced analysis techniques, as well as their independent research and problem solving capabilities. As well as further refining and developing knowledge in core subjects, the focus shifts towards professional practice, preparing the student for their future career.
Year 5: This year (optional) is a placement year spent working in industry. Students gain practical experience and make important professional contacts. Placements provide valuable professional experience in a real-world context, strengthening their skills and preparing for careers in the industry.  This year of industry experience enhances their resumes and demonstrates knowledge and experience to future employers.

Course Title: Undergraduate Civil Engineering with Foundation Year BSc (Hons)
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical requirements include 72 UCAS points, A Levels (DDD), T Level (Pass), BTEC (MMP), or an Access to HE Diploma.  GCSEs in Maths and English at Grade 4/C or above are also needed.  International students require an IELTS score of 6.0 with at least 5.5 in each skill area. Contextual offers may be available for students from particular backgrounds, including care experienced students, estranged students, refugees or asylum seekers, and those whose parents/carers are in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or the IB from Pakistani international schools, direct entry into Year 1 is possible. Students with a four-year Bachelor's degree (BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university will be considered for entry.
Annual Tuition Fee: UK: £9,250 per year; International: £16,900 per year
Overview: The University of Derby's BSc (Hons) Civil Engineering with Foundation Year is a four-year undergraduate program designed to equip students with the skills and knowledge sought after by employers in the civil engineering sector. The course balances theoretical learning with practical application through real-life projects, case studies, site visits, and field trips. Students will develop expertise in areas such as structures, fluids, geology, soil mechanics, surveying, and materials.  The program is accredited by leading professional institutions, enabling graduates to meet the academic requirements for Incorporated Engineer (IEng) status. The foundation year provides additional support and skill development for students before progressing to the main degree program.  The University boasts excellent facilities, including a new STEM Centre, to support student learning.  The program also includes opportunities for students to work on projects such as sustainable community garden development with organizations like the Eden Project.
Course Structure: The course integrates lectures, seminars, tutorials, and extensive laboratory and fieldwork, including on and off-campus site visits and company visits. Assessment methods vary depending on the module and might incorporate workshop laboratories, surveying fieldwork, group work, and individual assignments. Traditional design tests and exams might also be used. The course is structured to build student confidence and skills through hands-on experience, preparing them for professional practice.  The foundation year focuses on developing essential skills and knowledge before entering the core civil engineering curriculum.  Students receive support via a Personal Academic Tutoring programme, aiding their academic and personal development.
Year 1: The foundation year focuses on building a strong academic base and developing essential skills in mathematics, science, and engineering principles.  This could involve introductory modules in areas relevant to civil engineering, such as basic structural concepts, introductory surveying, and an overview of engineering materials and geology.  Students receive comprehensive support from the university staff to smoothly transition to university study and the demands of the degree program. The aim of the foundation year is to provide students with a solid understanding of engineering concepts, and bolster their ability to confidently progress into the second year and beyond.
Year 2: Year 2 delves into more specialized areas of civil engineering, including further concepts in structural analysis and design, fluid mechanics, and geotechnical engineering principles.  Students may undertake coursework focusing on structural analysis techniques, hydraulic systems, soil behavior, and foundation design aspects, with laboratory components and computational aspects.  Building upon the foundation year, students tackle more complex problems and apply their developing skillset as they move into more advanced coursework.
Year 3: In Year 3, students study specialized modules such as transportation engineering, materials science, and construction management.  Students are expected to build mastery of their subject matter, through both theory and substantial practical components such as project work and site visits.  This stage of the program involves many real-world case studies and independent assessments.  Students have opportunities to focus their learning towards specific areas of civil engineering, developing more specialized competencies.
Year 4: The final year integrates advanced concepts and allows the student to work on a significant individual project.  Modules include further advanced specialist modules, selected according to areas of interest. The final-year project may be a substantial design project, a more detailed analysis of existing infrastructure, or research-oriented analysis. Through this stage, students work independently to demonstrate full mastery of the subject and deliver an output worthy of the honors degree.

Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with a minimum of 5.5 in all areas
Entry Requirement: Academically, applicants should typically hold a first degree or, in its absence, have completed at least one Level 6 or Level 7 module within the past five years.  For the prescribing module specifically, a completed 20-credit Level 7 module is required. Professionally, applicants must be a registered health professional (Pharmacist, Nurse, Midwife, Physiotherapist, Podiatrist, or Paramedic) actively practicing in a patient-facing role at least one day per week.  Each profession has specific entry requirements detailed in the program handbook and on the university website.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized university, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree is needed.  A Master's degree is required if the Bachelor's degree is two or three-year long. A four-year Bachelor's degree with honours and minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 is also acceptable.
Location/Campus: St Helena, Chesterfield; Kedleston Road, Derby Campus
Overview: The Postgraduate Certificate in Clinically Enhanced Prescribing is a one-year blended learning program designed to equip healthcare professionals with the skills and knowledge for independent prescribing. The curriculum focuses on clinical decision-making, enhancing professional autonomy, and promoting collaborative practice.  It covers diagnostic reasoning, clinical assessment, and the management of various health conditions. The program is specifically tailored for pharmacists, nurses, midwives, physiotherapists, podiatrists and paramedics, preparing them to meet the standards set by their respective regulatory bodies.  Students will develop critical thinking skills, refine their decision-making processes, and learn to identify developmental needs to advance their practice and support colleagues. The program emphasizes a practical approach, incorporating coursework, exams, OSCEs, and clinical sign-off to ensure a well-rounded and comprehensive educational experience.
Course Structure: The program consists of two core modules: a 40-credit module on Non-medical Prescribing and a 20-credit module on Diagnostic Reasoning in Clinical Practice.  Students can choose to start with the Diagnostic Reasoning module in May or with the Prescribing module in September or January.  Assessment methods include practical OSCEs, written examinations (including a pharmacology exam for prescribers), and coursework involving evidence-based posters and case studies. For prescribing qualifications, 90 hours of clinical practice sign-off is mandatory.  Successful completion of the non-medical prescribing module awards an interim Postgraduate Practice Certificate.
Year 1: The first year of this postgraduate certificate involves completing two core modules: "Non-medical Prescribing" (40 credits) and "Diagnostic Reasoning in Clinical Practice" (20 credits).  The "Non-medical Prescribing" module provides the necessary skills and knowledge for practicing as an independent prescriber, adhering to  professional regulatory standards.  The "Diagnostic Reasoning in Clinical Practice" module equips learners with skills in clinical assessment, diagnostic decision-making, and managing patients with diverse health conditions. Assessment methods include OSCEs, written examinations (including a pharmacology exam and a calculations test for some students), and academic coursework such as essays, case studies and evidence-based poster presentations.  The year concludes with a clinical practice sign-off (90 hours).
Year 2: NA

Required IELTS Score: NA
Entry Requirement: Usually five years post-qualification experience.  For those accessing the module as a CPD option, support from employers to provide a clinical supervisor is required for the completion of the Practice Document log assessment.  Specific entry requirements for Pakistani students are not detailed on this page, but general postgraduate requirements for Pakistanis include a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised University in Pakistan equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree. Students with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees also need a Master's degree pass. A Bachelor's degree with honours (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University may also be considered.
Overview: This Level 7 Clinical Decision Making module provides health professionals, particularly those in advanced practice, with a comprehensive understanding of clinical decision-making processes.  The course covers pathophysiological processes of common diseases, utilizing a systems approach and theories related to etiology, pathogenesis, and clinical manifestations.  Students will develop skills in health history taking and clinical examination.  Emphasis is placed on correlating physical findings with underlying pathophysiology and formulating clinical diagnoses based on scientific rationale and evidence. The program also incorporates training in effective communication with colleagues and patients, covering discussions about health history, physical assessments, diagnoses, and personal health plans. The course includes a six month on-campus component and requires access to practice opportunities negotiated via a learning contract with a mentor, essential for the summative assessment.
Course Structure: The course is structured around the key concepts of clinical decision making.  It begins with an overview of pathophysiological processes common in various diseases, using a systematic approach.  Students learn how to connect the etiology, pathogenesis, and clinical presentation of diseases.  Significant time is dedicated to hands-on skills in health history taking and clinical examination.  The curriculum further emphasizes the integration of scientific rationale and evidence-based practices in formulating diagnoses.  A crucial part involves training on effective communication with patients and colleagues, covering various aspects from health history discussions to explaining diagnoses and treatment plans. Finally, the course includes a practicum component, requiring students to secure practice opportunities and complete a practice document log assessment, with employer support often needed.
Year 1: NA
Year 2: NA

Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with no lower than 6.0 in each category
Entry Requirement: Applicants need a 2.1 or higher relevant undergraduate science degree covering content related to the MSc modules.  International applicants need an equivalent qualification and must meet English language requirements (IELTS 6.5 with at least 6.0 in each section).  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized university, equivalent to a UK Upper Second Class (2:1) or Lower Second Class (2:2) degree, is required. Students with two or three-year Bachelor degrees need a Master's degree pass. A four-year Bachelor's degree with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.0 from a recognized Pakistani university is also acceptable for Master's entry.
Overview: The MSc Clinical Exercise Science program at the University of Derby is designed to equip students with the knowledge and skills needed to excel as clinical exercise scientists.  This intensive one-year (full-time) or two-year (part-time) program blends theoretical learning with practical experience. Students will explore three key areas: rehabilitation and training, physical activity and health, and clinical exercise physiology.  The curriculum features a significant placement component (150 hours) in clinical settings providing real-world experience alongside the course theoretical learning. The course involves  research-based learning, including an independent research project.  Graduates are uniquely positioned for careers in clinical rehabilitation, clinical exercise physiology, and health and wellbeing sectors. The program is taught by leading experts at the University who are actively involved in research in the field.
Course Structure: The MSc Clinical Exercise Science program comprises a series of core modules designed to provide a comprehensive understanding of the field.  Modules cover advanced research methods, independent research in sport and exercise science, advanced clinical exercise physiology, clinical exercise and rehabilitation training, global physical activity and public health, and professional practice in clinical exercise science.  The curriculum also includes real-world learning components such as  placements (150 hours)  based on partnerships with local hospitals and community health organizations providing invaluable experience, mentorship combined with  practical laboratory sessions, field-based studies and independent study time. Assessment methods include written essays, reports, case studies, oral presentations, and viva-voce examinations, focusing on practical skills application and critical analysis.
Year 1: The first year of the full-time MSc Clinical Exercise Science program is intensive and combines modules focusing on theory, research design, and practical application in the area of exercise science. Advanced Research Methods teaches rigorous research design and reporting skills, followed by Independent Research in Sport and Exercise, allowing in-depth exploration of a chosen subject.  Advanced Clinical Exercise Physiology deepens understanding of various clinical conditions and supports clinical decision-making.  Clinical Exercise and Rehabilitation Training introduces rehabilitation stages, screening techniques, and intervention design. Global Physical Activity and Public Health explores the role of physical activity in enhancing public health, while Professional Practice explores clinical research training and practical experience through placements.
Year 2: NA
Career Opportunity 4: Researcher in Biomedical and Clinical Sciences

Course Title: Level 7 Clinical Management Investigations and Referral for the Advanced Practitioner
Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with a minimum of 5.5 in all areas
Entry Requirement: Applicants usually require five years of post-professional-qualification experience.  For Pakistani students, the requirements are as follows:  For postgraduate programs, students must have completed a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised University in Pakistan, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree. Students with two or three-year Bachelor degrees also need a Master's degree. A four-year Bachelor's degree with honours (minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00) from a recognised Pakistani University is also acceptable.
Overview: This postgraduate module focuses on enhancing the skills of advanced practitioners in clinical management, investigations, and referrals.  The course aims to equip participants with the ability to initiate investigative treatments, interpret results, and create appropriate treatment plans.  It emphasizes understanding investigative procedures, results interpretation, referral pathways, and the interdependence of body systems. The module uses an on-campus teaching approach, running over three months. The emphasis is on practical application and clinical decision-making based on investigative data. Students will critically analyze therapeutics and health promotion strategies, considering socioeconomic and political factors alongside referral pathways. They will learn competent assessment, interpretation, treatment planning, communication, education, referral, and discharge procedures for complex patients. The course integrates prior learning in pathophysiology, health assessment, and pharmacotherapeutics.
Course Structure: The module's structure is not explicitly detailed, but it focuses on developing practical skills in clinical management investigations and referral processes.  The curriculum includes topics such as interpreting investigative results, developing appropriate treatment plans, understanding referral pathways, and considering the broader social, economic, and political factors that impact healthcare decisions.  The course actively integrates prior knowledge of pathophysiology, health assessment, and pharmacotherapeutics, building upon existing expertise to enhance advanced practice skills.  The emphasis is on hands-on application of theoretical knowledge to real-world clinical scenarios.
Year 1: NA
Year 2: NA

Course Title: PG Cert Clinical Supervision Postgraduate Certificate
Entry Requirement: Applicants must be professionally qualified with a minimum of 12 months post-qualification experience in counselling, psychotherapy, or healthcare.  Evidence of learning at level 6 or equivalent is required.  Those with equivalent learning may claim credits for prior learning, but a maximum of one module.  English language qualifications are needed if English is not your first language, including IELTS 7.0, TOEFL 550 (paper-based), 213 (computer-based), or 80 (internet-based), Pearson Test of English 66, Cambridge Advanced Certificate, London Tests of English level 5, International GCE O Level English Language Grade C, or International GCSE English/ESL Grade C.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised University in Pakistan equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree is required.  Those with two or three-year Bachelor degrees need a Master’s degree pass. A four-year Bachelor's degree with honours from a recognised Pakistani University and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 is also acceptable.
Overview: This online postgraduate certificate in Clinical Supervision is designed for practicing professionals aiming to provide clinical supervision to various health professionals, including counselors, psychotherapists, nurses, and occupational therapists. The program focuses on developing advanced supervisory skills, analyzing supervisory models and educational theories, and understanding supervisory structures and processes.  Students will critically evaluate clinical supervision assessment methods, manage influencing factors like organizational, ethical, professional, and legal considerations, and reflect upon and improve their supervision skills through experiential learning and feedback. The entirely online format allows for flexible learning, fitting around existing professional commitments.  The program emphasizes self-awareness and networking with a diverse range of professionals.
Course Structure: The course is structured around modules delivered online.  Assessment is 100% coursework, including essays, research reports, presentations, group work, and practical reports. The program covers advanced supervisory skills development, analysis of various supervisory models and educational theories, understanding supervisory structures and processes, critical evaluation of clinical supervision assessment, effective management of influencing factors (organizational, ethical, professional, legal), and self-reflective development of supervision skills.  Experiential learning and feedback on practice are integral components.
Year 1: The program is one year long, and content covers the development of advanced supervisory skills encompassing building and maintaining effective supervisory relationships.  Students will analyze various supervisory models and educational theories to build a comprehensive understanding of supervisory frameworks.   The curriculum further delves into the critical assessment and evaluation of clinical supervision practices, including ethical, professional, and legal ramifications. Students refine their systematic approach to supervision amidst organizational constraints.
Year 2: NA

Course Title: MSc Cognitive Behavioural Psychotherapy (BABCP accredited) (incorporating PG Cert/PG Dip)
Required IELTS Score: Overall: 6.5 with at least 6.0 in each skill area
Entry Requirement: Entry requirements typically include an undergraduate degree in a health and social care-related field, along with relevant experience.  Individuals with mental health nursing, occupational therapy, social work, psychiatry, psychology, or counseling backgrounds need at least two years of post-qualification mental health experience.  Those without a core profession may be considered with a Knowledge, Skills, and Attitude (KSA) portfolio and at least two years of experience.  Applicants with existing CBT qualifications or substantial supervised practice may qualify through Recognition of Prior Learning (RPL).  For non-native English speakers, an IELTS score of at least 6.5 (with a minimum of 6.0 in each section) is required. A Disclosure and Barring Service (DBS) check is also necessary.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized university, equivalent to at least a UK Upper Second Class (2:1) or Lower Second Class (2:2) degree, is required.  Two- or three-year Bachelor's degree holders need a Master's degree pass.  A four-year Bachelor's degree with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university is also acceptable.
Overview: The University of Derby's MSc in Cognitive Behavioural Psychotherapy (CBT) is a BABCP-accredited program designed to train skilled, independent CBT practitioners.  The course emphasizes evidence-based practice, ethical considerations, and reflective practice, equipping students with the theoretical knowledge and practical skills necessary for working in diverse settings. The curriculum covers core CBT principles, advanced techniques, and professional requirements, along with opportunities for supervised clinical practice and interprofessional learning.  Graduates will possess a critical understanding of CBT's theoretical underpinnings and ethical implications and apply this knowledge to real-world clinical scenarios.
Course Structure: The course is structured in three stages: Postgraduate Certificate, Postgraduate Diploma, and MSc. The Postgraduate Certificate involves foundational modules in CBT, including specialist practice and professional requirements.  The Postgraduate Diploma builds upon this foundation with modules on ethics, law, research, and advanced CBT practice. The MSc culminates in an Independent Scholarship module, demonstrating advanced research and critical analysis.  Throughout the program, students engage in clinical placements, supervised practice, receive clinical supervision and complete various assessments. These assessments will include: critical case studies, observed exams, video recordings of clinical practice with critical analysis, and a reflective portfolio demonstrating research and problem-solving abilities.
Year 1: The first year focuses on building a solid foundation in Cognitive Behavioural Psychotherapy. Students will delve into the fundamentals of CBT, covering core principles, assessment methods, and intervention techniques for adults.  The emphasis is on building a strong theoretical understanding and acquiring practical skills through case studies and simulated clinical experiences.  This year also incorporates an introduction to the ethical and legal considerations integral to practicing as a therapist.
Year 2: In the second year, students build upon their knowledge and skills from the first year. They will undertake advanced clinical practice and professional requirements.  The curriculum introduces students to more advanced CBT theories and techniques.  Students will carry out more advanced sessions to improve their skills. This year also includes a focus on research methodology, enabling students to critically evaluate existing research and potentially conduct their own small-scale research projects related to CBT. The development of skills in supervision and consultation are also provided.

Course Title: Certificate of Credit in Cognitive Ergonomics and Psychology
Required IELTS Score: 6.5 (minimum of 6.5 in each module)
Entry Requirement: Applicants need a UK undergraduate degree or equivalent international qualification, or a relevant professional qualification.  Applicants with substantial relevant practical experience and work-based training will also be considered.  For those whose first language isn't English, or whose highest qualification wasn't completed in English, an English language qualification is required (IELTS 6.5 with a minimum of 6.5 in each module; TOEFL 550 paper-based, 213 computer-based, or 80 internet-based; Cambridge Advanced Certificate pass; London Test of English level 5; International GCE O Level English Language Grade C; International GCSE English/English as a Second Language Grade C; or ASE Proficiency pass).  For Pakistan, students must have completed a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised University in Pakistan, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree. Students with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees need a Master's degree pass. A Bachelor's degree with honours (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) with at least a 2.4/4.00 GPA from a recognised Pakistani University is acceptable.
Overview: This 10-week online Certificate of Credit in Cognitive Ergonomics and Psychology provides a framework of key cognitive, psychosocial factors, and individual differences, exploring how psychological influences affect human performance, health, and well-being.  It delves into the intersection of psychology and ergonomics/human factors, exploring human performance and behavior in various situations. Students will critically discuss and integrate psychological knowledge relevant to ergonomics, demonstrate in-depth knowledge of research, and critically position task performance within a psychological context.  The program benefits from the University of Derby's 20+ years' experience in online ergonomics courses, supported by experienced academics and online learning advisors. The course is CIEHF Accredited.
Course Structure: The course is delivered entirely online over 10 weeks, utilizing interactive learning materials including some live classroom sessions.  Interaction with tutors and fellow students is facilitated through live virtual classroom sessions and online discussion forums.  Students will also learn alongside those enrolled in the Ergonomics and Human Factors MSc, enriching their understanding of cognitive ergonomics and psychology. Assessments are 100% coursework based, encompassing a variety of methods including essays, research reports, presentations, group work, and practical reports. The program recommends about 20 hours of weekly study.
Year 1: NA
Year 2: NA

Required IELTS Score: NA
Entry Requirement: For this short course, a qualification in occupational therapy is required.  There is no mention of specific requirements for standardized tests like IELTS, TOEFL, or PTE.  Regarding Pakistan-specific entry requirements, the University of Derby website does not provide details for short courses.  General entry requirements for undergraduate and postgraduate programs at the university are available, but they are not applicable to this short course.  The requirements for undergraduate programs from Pakistan include A-levels or IB from international schools, while postgraduate programs require a relevant bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2, possibly with a master's degree if the bachelor's degree is only two or three years.  PhD programs require a master's and bachelor's degree in a relevant subject area, along with a research proposal.
Overview: This Level 7 Community Focused Occupational Therapy module is a 3-month distance-learning course designed for occupational therapists.  It delves into the essence of community practice and occupational therapy's role within it.  The curriculum covers management perspectives, multi-agency collaboration, relevant legislation, practice interfaces, and occupational justice.  The course is delivered entirely online, with tutor support available via email, phone, and Skype.  The overall aim is to enhance the participants' understanding of community-based occupational therapy practices and their effective application within the broader healthcare system.
Course Structure: The module focuses intensively on community practice and the role occupational therapists play.  Key areas include understanding management perspectives and strategies within community settings to maximize efficiency and effectiveness.   The interaction and collaboration with various healthcare professionals and agencies is a critical subject to ensure holistic treatment for people, which promotes partnership working and interdisciplinary perspectives.  The course examines relevant legislation and policies for healthcare practices within the community.  The course also includes a deep perspective into the topic of occupational justice that encompasses the fairness and equity in access to healthcare therapies for everyone.  Participants are provided with a supportive environment for critical analysis and evaluation to apply the concepts in real-life settings.
Year 1: NA
Year 2: NA

Course Title: Level 6 and 7 Community Practitioner Nurse Prescribing
Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with a minimum of 5.5 in all areas
Entry Requirement: To undertake this module, you must be an NMC registered nurse intending to practice in an area of clinical need where prescribing from the Community Practitioner Formulary will improve patient/client care and service delivery. You must also hold a professional qualification (Diploma, Degree, or equivalent), have current NMC registration, and have at least two years of relevant clinical experience as a registered nurse.  Appropriate background knowledge and experience are also needed, alongside the ability to study at academic level 6 (degree level). Approval and support from your employer/sponsor are required, confirming that you will have appropriate supervised practice. An approved Mentor or Practice Teacher, recognized by the employing/Health Service commissioning organization as having relevant experience and training in supervision, support, and assessment of trainees, is also necessary.  You must be professionally practicing in a post relevant for community prescribing. For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognized University in Pakistan, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree, is required. Those with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees need a Master's degree pass. A Bachelor's degree with honors (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani University is also considered for entry to a Master's degree.
Overview: This postgraduate course focuses on equipping NMC-registered nurses with the necessary knowledge and skills to become competent nurse prescribers. The curriculum covers a wide range of essential topics, including pharmacology, legal and ethical considerations in prescribing, patient assessment and consultation techniques, evidence-based prescribing practices, and the roles and relationships involved in the medication process.  Students gain practical skills to prescribe safely and cost-effectively, operating within a framework of professional accountability.  The program blends theoretical learning with supervised practice in a clinical setting, ensuring that nurses develop both the knowledge and the competency to prescribe in community practice settings.
Course Structure: The course follows a structured curriculum that builds on existing nursing knowledge to equip registered nurses with the skills and understanding required for safe and effective nurse prescribing. The curriculum integrates theoretical learning with practical application using realistic case studies and guided practical experiences in the community setting.  The program includes modules that cover relevant legislation, pharmacology, consultation techniques, patient assessment, ethical and legal considerations of prescribing and practical experience under supervision.  The course culminates in a supervised practice period that provides hands-on clinical experience to ensure the proper skills are developed and refined.
Year 1: NA
Year 2: NA

Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with a minimum of 5.5 in all areas
Entry Requirement: Applicants must be registered on part one of the Nursing and Midwifery Council register and have a first degree at 1:1 or 2:1 with 120 credits at degree level or equivalent.  At least one year of post-registration experience is required (three years for V300 Non-medical prescribing).  A student District Nurse or General Practice Nursing position from a seconding/sponsoring organisation is necessary.  The student must have applied for a clinical secondment/sponsorship with a local Care Provider/employer before applying. The employer is responsible for DBS and health checks. For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised University in Pakistan equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree is required.  Students with a two or three-year Bachelor's degree need a Master's degree pass. A four-year Bachelor's degree with honours and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani university is also acceptable.
Annual Tuition Fee: £712 per 20 credits (part-time) /  £6,408 for the full course* (full-time)
Overview: The MSc Community Specialist Practice (District Nursing) is a postgraduate program designed for registered nurses seeking to enhance their skills and knowledge in community healthcare.  The course provides extensive clinical placement experience, complementing theoretical learning. Students develop advanced assessment, leadership, and management skills while focusing on integrated, high-quality health and social care.  The curriculum is closely aligned with current healthcare practices and incorporates modules covering public health, research methodologies, and clinical practice improvement. The program prepares nurses for independent practice and contributes to advanced clinical scholarship.
Course Structure: The course integrates theoretical learning with significant practical experience through clinical placements.  Modules cover a broad range of topics, including Principles of Clinical Practice and Assessment, Innovation, Leadership and Team Development, Public Health and Educating Communities, Research, Management and Consolidating Clinical Practice and Non-medical prescribing.  Assessment methods are diverse, encompassing assignments, exams, presentations, and a practice portfolio, with additional assessment during placements. The MSc stage involves an extended research project or practice-based project focusing on specialist nursing.
Year 1: Year one of the full-time program covers the core modules of the Postgraduate Diploma, which include Principles of Clinical Practice and Assessment, Innovation, Leadership and Team Development, Public Health and Educating Communities, Research, Management and Consolidating Clinical Practice, and Fundamentals of Long-term Condition Management (Non-medical Prescribing). Students will spend half of their time on placement to gain practical experience and integrate theoretical knowledge.  Assessment includes assignments, exams, and presentations.
Year 2: NA

Entry Requirement: Applicants require 120 credits at Diploma level, a current nursing or midwifery qualification with NMC registration, a student Health Visitor/Occupational Health Nurse/School Nurse position from a sponsoring organisation, and at least one year of post-registration experience (two years if taking the V300 non-medical prescribing qualification).  An Enhanced Disclosure & Barring Service certificate is also needed.  For Pakistani students, if studying A-Levels or the IB from an International School in Pakistan, entry to the first year is possible.  Those with a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised Pakistani University (equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2) are eligible.  A Master's degree pass might be required for two or three-year Bachelor degrees.  A Bachelor's degree with honours (four-year) and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University is also considered for entry.
Overview: The BSc (Hons) Community Specialist Practice is a one-year undergraduate program designed for registered nurses seeking professional qualification in district or general practice nursing.  It's suitable for those with diplomas or advanced diplomas in nursing, allowing them to upgrade to a degree, or for those already holding a nursing degree to progress to an MSc. The program emphasizes bringing care closer to patients' homes, focusing on the evolving role of nurses in primary care.  Students will develop specialist assessment, leadership, and management skills, alongside critical understanding of clinical practice, care management, and clinical practice development.  The curriculum includes modules like prescribing, palliative care, long-term condition management and tissue viability, equipping graduates to provide effective patient care.  The program incorporates significant practical experience through placements, mentored by clinical practitioners.
Course Structure: The course combines theoretical learning with extensive practical experience. Students spend approximately half their time on clinical placements in primary care settings, working within a District Nursing Team.  The curriculum is regularly reviewed to align with current health and social care practices and future strategic developments in community health. Teaching methods include lectures, workshops, seminars, and group discussions. Assessment is multifaceted, incorporating assignments, exams, presentations, and a practice portfolio, also assessed within placements by practice teachers.  A key component is the V100 Community Nurse Prescribing qualification leading to independent prescribing abilities. Overall, it is a practice-based project and a balance of theoretical and practical application ensures relevancy to real world scenarios.
Year 1: The first year of the BSc (Hons) Community Specialist Practice program is immersive, combining classroom learning with extensive hands-on experience in primary care settings.  Students will cover modules such as Principles of Practice Assessment, Public Health and Health Promotion, Evidence Based Project, Leading for Quality, Applied V100 Prescribing, Symptom Management in Palliative Care, Principles of Long Term Conditions management, Palliative Care, End of Life Care, Educating Health and Social Care, and Tissue Viability.  The curriculum integrates theoretical knowledge with practical application through regular assessments, including assignments, examinations, presentations, and performance evaluation during placements.  The V100 prescribing qualification provides a solid foundation for independent practice. The emphasis is on developing effective clinical and leadership skills.

Overview: The BA (Hons) Computer Games Modelling and Animation degree at the University of Derby is a three-year (or four-year with placement) program focused on equipping students with the skills and knowledge to succeed in the computer games industry.  The curriculum blends theoretical learning with extensive practical experience using industry-standard software and hardware. Students will learn to create 3D art and animations, develop game environments, collaborate on projects, and showcase their work publicly.  The focus is on real-time environments and technologies, preparing graduates for roles in developing games across various genres. The program benefits from the University's extensive facilities as well as its location in Derby, a city deeply rooted in games development history.  Career support and industry connections are integral, increasing graduate employability.
Course Structure: The course is structured around modules studied across semesters, combining lectures, tutorials, and extensive hands-on practice using industry-standard software such as Maya, Unreal Engine, ZBrush, Houdini, 3Ds Max, and more. Students have access to state-of-the-art facilities including computer games labs, an XR lab dedicated to mixed-reality game development, a CAVE lab for data visualization, and a makerspace.  Assessment is entirely coursework-based, comprising a mix of group and individual assignments, culminating in a significant personal project in the final year.  A placement year option adds valuable industry experience.  The final year involves collaboration with computer games programming students to develop a game that is displayed at the public Games Expo.
Year 1: First-year modules will introduce foundational concepts in 3D modeling, animation, texturing, and the principles of game design.  Students will gain proficiency in core software applications like Maya, 3Ds Max, and ZBrush, learning essential workflows within the chosen software and working on various projects to develop practical experience. Additionally, there will likely be introductory modules on game design principles and the fundamentals of animation processes.
Year 2: The second year builds upon the foundational skills; students delve deeper into specialized areas such as character animation, environment design, advanced modeling techniques, and rigging.   Students continue to improve technical expertise through hands-on work across varied projects while learning advanced skills in different software such as Houdini, Unreal Engine, and Substance Painter. Collaboration and project management skills are also emphasized through group assignments.
Year 3: In the final year, the focus shifts to a capstone project where students combine and build on all their knowledge to craft a complete game.  Students work in teams collaborating with computer game programming students.  The curriculum includes advanced specialized software skills, refining previous modeling,texturing and animation techniques learned on the course.  The independent project allows extensive development of a portfolio piece, showcasing their mastery of the skills needed for professional practice. The culmination of the year features presentation the game at the University's Games Expo.
Year 4: The optional placement year (between years 2 and 3) provides students with real-world experience in the games industry. Students work in professional settings, gaining practical skills, building their network, and deepening their understanding of industry practices.

Entry Requirement: To be eligible for this top-up BSc (Hons) degree, applicants need one of the following: an HND or foundation degree in Computing from a UK university or a recognized international equivalent; an Edexcel BTEC Level 5 HND Diploma in Computing and Systems Development (2010 QCF); a British Computer Society (BCS) Diploma in IT (level 5), including the professional project; an HNC in Computing plus at least 3 years of relevant work experience; or evidence of significant work and life experience equivalent to traditional qualifications. Overview: The Level 6 Computing Technologies in Society short course offers a broad, transdisciplinary introduction to the evolution and application of advanced digital technologies.  It examines the societal, individual, and environmental impacts of these technologies, covering past, present, and future innovations.  Students will develop crucial skills for computing professionals through a research-infused curriculum, active participation in online discussions, and a research-informed case study or practical exercise. The course emphasizes ethical considerations in technology development and application, exploring topics such as digital systems and genocide, environmental sustainability in computing, data archiving, privacy concerns, and the responsible use of technologies like drones and AI.
Course Structure: The course is structured around a 10-week online curriculum with approximately 20 hours of study per week.  Assessment is 100% coursework, including essays, research reports, presentations, group work, and practical reports. There are 1 or 2 virtual classrooms. Indicative topics include digital systems and genocide, the environmental impact of the technology life cycle, long-term data archiving, server farms and sustainability, digital shadows and privacy, automation, predictive modeling, surveillance systems, drones, RFID, technology failures, animatronics, and ethical and professional responsibilities in computing.  The course also covers ethical responsibilities in various contexts, including multicultural settings and online interactions, linking technology to human factors, and professional codes of conduct.

Course Title: Level 4 Diploma in Advanced Hospitality Management

Overview: The CTH (IOH) Level 4 Diploma in Advanced Hospitality Management is an online course designed for hospitality professionals seeking career advancement.  It focuses on developing business management skills within the hospitality context.  The curriculum covers strategic business management, service marketing and communication, customer-focused organization management, financial planning and control, leadership and HR management, legal compliance, and professional development.  The program emphasizes practical application, preparing students for senior roles in the industry. The program is supported by the Institute of Hospitality, enhancing its value and credibility for career progression.
Course Structure: The course consists of seven units, each requiring approximately 80 hours of study. Units cover Strategic Business Management in Hospitality; Services Marketing and Communication for Hospitality; Managing a Customer Focused Organisation in Hospitality; Financial Planning, Business Performance and Control in Hospitality; Leadership and HR Management in Hospitality; Managing Changes to Business and HR Legislation in Hospitality; and Professional Development and Project Management for Hospitality.  Each unit includes online learning materials (texts, videos, interactive diagrams, self-assessment activities) and culminates in a multiple-choice online test. A final online coursework assessment is required upon completion of all units to receive the diploma. The course can be completed at your own pace within 3 to 18 months, with a recommended completion time of 6-7 months.

A four-year Bachelor's degree with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university is also acceptable for Master's entry.
Overview: The MSc Conservation Biology program at the University of Derby addresses the urgent need for skilled conservation biologists.  It combines theoretical knowledge with practical fieldwork and laboratory experience. Students explore the causes of species endangerment and develop skills in wildlife and environmental management, finding practical solutions to environmental problems. The curriculum includes modules covering core conservation principles, analytical methods for ecologists, habitat management, and ecological surveying.  A significant component is an independent research project, allowing students to specialize in their areas of interest.  Students also benefit from a potential placement opportunity within a relevant organization.
Course Structure: The course comprises three stages: Postgraduate Certificate, Postgraduate Diploma, and MSc.  The Postgraduate Certificate includes modules on Conservation Biology in Principle and Practice, Species Identification for Conservation, and Tropical Conservation Biology (including a field trip to Costa Rica). The Postgraduate Diploma involves Analytical Methods for Ecologists and two chosen modules from Environmental Impact Assessment, International Environmental Policy and Law, Habitat Management, and Ecological Surveying.  The MSc involves an independent scholarly activity, a major research project, allowing students to pursue their own research interests.
Year 1: The first year (for full-time students) covers fundamental concepts in conservation biology, including its theoretical underpinnings and practical applications. Students will develop skills in species identification, ecological surveying techniques, data analysis using statistical software (like R), and environmental impact assessment. The highlight of the year is the field trip to Costa Rica, focusing on tropical conservation issues. A training-based placement may also be undertaken.
Year 2: NA

The course involves individually negotiated modules tailored to the needs of practitioners, emphasizing advanced clinical decision-making, assessment, and examination skills.  The program also helps in consolidating learning within the field and supports the development of crucial skills such as reflective practice, critical analysis of clinical cases, evidence synthesis, and advanced clinical skills, all while addressing issues of clinical governance, competence, and safe practice.
Course Structure: The module is individually negotiated to meet the needs of the advanced practitioners. Learning is achieved through a combination of reflective practice, analyzing clinical case-based discussions (CBD), and the application of evidence-based practice.  The curriculum emphasizes the development of advanced clinical skills in decision making, assessment, and examination. It addresses theoretical and professional issues relating to clinical governance, clinical competence, and safe practice. The learning is supported and critiqued by experts to achieve the full potential of the course in advanced clinical practice.

GCSEs in Maths and English at Grade 4/C or above are also needed.  International students require an IELTS score of 6.0 with at least 5.5 in each skill. Overview: The University of Derby's BSc (Hons) Construction Management is a three-year (full-time) or five-year (part-time) program designed to equip students with the skills and knowledge needed for successful careers in the construction industry.  The course is accredited by the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS), the Chartered Institute of Building (CIOB), and the Chartered Institution of Civil Engineering Surveyors (CICES), signifying its high standards and industry relevance. Students gain practical experience through hands-on projects, site visits, and an optional placement year.  The curriculum blends theoretical learning with practical application, fostering problem-solving and decision-making abilities. Emphasis is placed on developing essential skills such as data interpretation, professional practice, and communication.  The program also provides opportunities for networking through student memberships with professional bodies and study trips.  Career prospects include roles in construction management, project management, site management, and manufacturing.  Graduates are well-prepared for roles with major construction and civil engineering contractors, teaching positions, or further postgraduate studies.
Course Structure: The Construction Management program integrates hands-on learning with theoretical studies. Year one introduces fundamental concepts in construction technologies, data analysis, and construction management theories. Students develop practical skills. The program introduces interdisciplinary professional practice and independent study. An optional placement year can enhance practical skills. An optional year abroad allows gaining global perspectives. Students are assessed through varied methods like assignments, exams, presentations, tests, and portfolios, fostering critical thinking and communication skill development.  Students can work on local projects. It also includes professional accreditation.
Year 1: The first year introduces fundamental construction technologies, data interpretation techniques, and the theoretical underpinnings of construction management.  Students develop practical skills and a solid base for further study.  A compulsory field trip based within England is included, offering hands-on experiences and insights into real-world construction practices during coursework and field visits.
Year 2: The second year builds on the foundational knowledge from the first year, delving deeper into the principles and practices of construction management.  Students begin to apply these theories through larger-scale projects and case studies. More emphasis is focused on independent learning and data interpretation projects related to cost estimating and value engineering.
Year 3: The third year culminates in a major independent study, allowing students to demonstrate their accumulated knowledge and skills on a substantial project.  Students may opt for an industrial placement between years two and three, gaining practical experience and improving their career prospects. The final year assessment is based on an independent study module, which culminates in a dissertation.

Overview: The University of Derby's BSc (Hons) Construction Management with Foundation Year is a four-year program designed to equip students with practical skills and theoretical knowledge in construction management.  The foundation year provides a supportive environment to build essential skills and knowledge before progressing to the main degree. The course is accredited by RICS, CIOB, and CICES, offering a pathway to chartered status and enhanced career prospects.  It incorporates hands-on experience, problem-solving activities, optional industry placements, and study trips.  The program emphasizes a practical approach, encouraging students to challenge existing ideas and analyze competing theories. Students benefit from personal academic tutoring and access to high-quality facilities.
Course Structure: The course combines practical and theoretical learning. The foundation year covers design and construction science and essential scholarship skills for technologists. The subsequent years introduce students to construction technology, data interpretation, and theories of construction management.  Later stages delve deeper into construction management through interdisciplinary professional practice and independent study, with an optional placement year available to enhance career prospects.  Modules are subject to change, reflecting efforts to improve student experience and graduate prospects. Assessment methods are varied, encouraging development of presentation and communication skills which are essential for professional practice.
Year 1: The first year, which includes the foundation year, focuses on building a strong base in design and construction science and developing key scholarship skills.  Students are introduced to fundamental concepts, preparing them for the more specialized modules in the subsequent years of the degree.
Year 2: Year two of the degree introduces students to practical skills in construction technology.  It develops their ability to interpret data and provides a solid understanding of the theories of construction management. This year is a crucial step to integrate practical skills and understanding in order to progress to more advanced studies.
Year 3: The third year of the program sees students gain a deeper knowledge of construction management principles through modules focusing on Interdisciplinary Professional Practice and Independent Study. These modules serve to bridge theory and practice, preparing the students for professional work.

Course Title: Certificate of Credit Contemporary Issues in Ergonomics and Human Factors
Required IELTS Score: 6.5 (minimum of 6.5 in each module)
Entry Requirement: Applicants need a UK undergraduate degree or equivalent international qualification, or a relevant professional qualification.  Relevant practical experience and work-based training may also be considered.  For non-native English speakers, acceptable English language qualifications include IELTS 6.5 (minimum 6.5 in each module), TOEFL 550 (paper), 213 (computer), or 80 (internet), Cambridge Advanced Certificate, London Tests of English level 5, International GCE O Level English Language Grade C, International GCSE English/ESL Grade C, and ASE Proficiency.  Regarding Pakistan entry requirements, students need a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognized Pakistani university equivalent to at least a UK Upper Second Class (2:1) or Lower Second Class (2:2) degree.  Those with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees also need a Master's degree pass. A Bachelor's degree with honors (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university is also acceptable.
Overview: This 10-week online Certificate of Credit in Contemporary Issues in Ergonomics and Human Factors provides 20 credits at level 7.  It critically examines the theoretical basis and practical application of ergonomics and human factors approaches. The course explores various contemporary issues such as the impact of an aging population on product and space design, the aging workforce, inclusivity challenges in autonomous vehicles and public transport, medical device usability and error prevention, the Internet of Things, behavior change, sustainability, and green ergonomics. Successful completion demonstrates a deep understanding of emerging ergonomics/human factors issues across various sectors and the ability to critically evaluate their applications and communicate their importance to diverse stakeholders. The course is CIEHF accredited.
Course Structure: The course is delivered 100% online using interactive learning materials and live classroom sessions.  Interaction with tutors and fellow students occurs through virtual classroom sessions and online discussion forums.  The curriculum covers emerging issues in ergonomics and human factors across various sectors, critically evaluating the application and communication of these principles to diverse stakeholders.  Specific topics explored include the effects of an aging population, inclusivity in design, autonomous vehicles, public transport, medical device usability, error prevention, the Internet of Things, behavior change, and sustainability. Assessment is 100% coursework encompassing essays, research reports, presentations, group work, and practical reports.

Overview: The MSc Control and Instrumentation program at the University of Derby is designed to equip students with advanced knowledge and skills in the design and implementation of measurement and control systems.  The curriculum integrates theoretical concepts with hands-on practical projects, providing students with a comprehensive understanding of modern control systems and instrumentation techniques. The course is accredited by the Institute of Measurement and Control, and is specifically designed to satisfy the educational requirements for Chartered Engineer (CEng) status. Students gain essential experience through industrial visits to leading companies and participation in projects based on cutting-edge research.  The program offers flexibility, with options for online and workplace learning, creating a dynamic and relevant learning environment.  Graduates are equipped for senior roles in various sectors, including automotive, aerospace, and manufacturing.
Course Structure: The MSc Control and Instrumentation consists of three stages: Postgraduate Certificate, Postgraduate Diploma, and MSc.  The Postgraduate Certificate includes modules such as Research Methods, Intelligent Instrumentation Systems, Embedded System Design, and Environmental Risk and Responsibility. The Postgraduate Diploma builds upon this foundation with modules like CPD and Strategic Management, Modern Control System Design, and elective choices such as Industrial Electronics or a Negotiated Technical Module. The final MSc stage involves a module such as Independent Engineering Scholarship, allowing students to specialize in a chosen area.  Assessment methods vary and include written work, presentations, online discussions, CAD work, laboratory assessments, interviews, and exams. The program is enriched by visits to major companies and the opportunity to engage with influential research conducted by the teaching team.
Year 1: The first year, or full-time program, encompasses a comprehensive exploration of core control and instrumentation principles, incorporating practical projects and applications.  Students delve into advanced control system design using various analytical techniques and computer tools.  Key modules cover research methods, intelligent instrumentation systems, embedded system design, environmental risk, and strategic management. Students are also introduced to modern control system design, optimal control techniques, and industrial applications of electronics. Practical projects and industrial visits allow for hands-on learning and industry exposure.
