Overview: The BSc (Hons) Counselling and Psychotherapy (Humanistic Approaches) is a three-year (full-time) undergraduate program focused on humanistic theories and practices in counselling and psychotherapy.  Students develop core academic skills in critical analysis and reflection, alongside practical clinical counselling skills through a 100-hour placement. The course emphasizes personal development, professional and ethical development, and research, aiming to prepare students for professional registration and employment in various settings.  It includes interactive teaching, workshops, and personal development groups, supported by experienced lecturers and practitioners.  The curriculum integrates theory with practical experience, fostering self-awareness and strong interpersonal skills.
Course Structure: The course structure is built upon five pillars: Theory and Development; Clinical Skills & Reflective Practice; Personal Development; Professional & Ethical Development; and Research.  These pillars are mapped against professional standards (BACP, QAA, SCoPEd) and are integrated throughout the three years of study.  The curriculum integrates theoretical knowledge with practical application through assignments (essays, posters, presentations, reports), clinical placements, and guest lectures from various therapeutic fields.
Year 1: The first year likely establishes a foundational understanding of humanistic counselling theories and core counselling skills. Students will engage with fundamental concepts, ethical considerations, and the practical application of therapeutic techniques.  Introductory modules may cover the history and theory of humanistic approaches, models of person-centred therapy, and ethical framework practices.  Personal and professional development will also be a focus to prepare students for the requirements of the field.
Year 2: The second year builds on the foundational year. The focus shifts toward developing advanced clinical skills through application in a supervised setting. Modules will likely include experiential learning through role play, case studies, and further exploration of humanistic therapy models, along with advanced concepts in therapeutic communication, relationship building, crisis intervention, or specific populations.  The placement begins this year, giving students supervised practical experience.
Year 3: The final year includes a significant clinical placement (100 hours) which provides students with a chance to apply their knowledge and skills in a real-world setting.  Students will be placed in various settings, including healthcare, educational, or community organizations, dependent upon available placement sites and individual needs.   In the classroom, the course likely will cover topics such as professional development, research methods, and writing a dissertation or equivalent research project. This year may also involve further exploration of special interests through electives or advanced specialization topics.

Overview: The University of Derby's BSc (Hons) Counselling and Psychotherapy (Humanistic Approaches) with Foundation Year is a four-year undergraduate program focusing on humanistic approaches to counselling and psychotherapy.  It equips students with a strong theoretical foundation, practical counselling skills, and personal development.  The program includes a 100-hour clinical placement, allowing students to gain valuable experience and potentially register with regulatory bodies like the BACP. The humanistic approach emphasizes personal growth and self-awareness, which are beneficial both professionally and personally.  The course is designed to transform students academically, professionally, and personally in the context of societal need for mental health services, The foundational year helps students strengthen their skills and knowledge before beginning the honors degree.
Course Structure: The program combines theoretical learning with practical application. Students will engage in interactive teaching sessions like lectures, seminars, skills workshops, and personal development groups.   Assessment is primarily through assignments, including essays, posters, presentations, and reports. The program utilizes blended learning, including the University of Derby Online (UDO) portal for access to resources.  A personal academic tutor supports students throughout their academic journey. The curriculum is subject to change but focuses on humanistic theories, critical analysis, reflection, and the development of professional counseling skills.
Year 1: The foundation year focuses on strengthening academic skills and knowledge.  It offers support to students in strengthening skills, knowledge and confidence, before entering the main part of the degree. Content may include introductory modules in psychology, counselling theory, and communication skills, along with academic skills development workshops. This year is designed to prepare students for the demands of the subsequent years and to provide an excellent base of knowledge for study in later years.
Year 2: The second year delves deeper into counselling theories and practices within a humanistic framework. Students will learn various therapeutic approaches, client communication skills, ethical considerations, and the legal aspects of counselling. The practical application of these theoretical concepts begins through role-playing exercises and simulated client sessions. This year introduces students to the concepts of the professional practice of counselling alongside theory.
Year 3: Year three involves direct practical experience through clinical placement and further development of practical counselling approach. Students refine their therapeutic skills under professional supervision.  Emphasis is placed on ethical dilemmas, supervision techniques and personal development alongside developing and implementing a professional counseling practice.  Students can engage on a clinical placement and will learn about ethical, legal and professional practices that are important in the counselling field.
Year 4: The final year focuses on integrating knowledge and skills.  Students may have additional clinical placements, and they will engage in more independent learning and advanced study.  The emphasis shifts to professional development, refining skills and integrating knowledge gained, through further counselling practice, personal development and exploration of different models and approaches.  This will provide an excellent foundation for the eventual transition to the professional field and is a vital component of all counselling degrees.

Required IELTS Score: Overall: 6.5, minimum 5.5 in each test category
Entry Requirement: A 2:1 undergraduate degree or relevant experience and a strong interest in creative arts is recommended. Overview: The MA Creative and Cultural Industries is a postgraduate program designed to equip graduates with the skills for a successful career in the creative and cultural industries. It integrates expertise in creative thinking, business, art, heritage, media, and journalism. Students develop knowledge and skills for leading future cultural and creative institutions, benefiting from partnerships with Midlands organizations in cultural heritage, festivals, and advertising.  The program offers specializations such as curation, film production, publishing, freelancing, and audience studies, allowing for in-depth exploration of specific areas within the creative industries.  Graduates will possess practical and intellectual skills, strong decision-making abilities, and a firm understanding of ethical considerations.
Course Structure: The program includes core modules like CCI Management, Creative Collaborative Project, and Project Modelling and Methods. Optional modules provide flexibility to specialize, including Practical Content Production, Curation and Conservation in the Digital Age, Audiences and Audience Development, Freelancing, Digital Skills, Heritage Management, Funding and Marketing, Marketing Sales Modern Publishing, and Magazine Publishing.  A range of teaching methods is used, including lectures, seminars, tutorials, debates, workshops, and collaborative work with industry professionals.  Assessment methods vary depending on the module and may include essays, reports, presentations, and practical content creation.
Year 1: The first year of the full-time MA Creative and Cultural Industries program covers core modules such as CCI Management, Creative Collaborative Project, and Project Modelling and Methods. Students also select optional modules from a range of specializations, including practical content production, curation, audience studies, freelancing, and digital skills. Overview: The FdA Creative Art and Design Practice course offers a balanced curriculum that blends creative practical work with theoretical studies. The course prepares students for further art education or immediate entry into the creative industries.

Course Title: BA (Hons) Creative Expressive Arts, Health and Wellbeing
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 104 UCAS points, A-Levels BCC, T Level Merit, BTEC DMM, GCSE English Grade 4/C or equivalent, or a Pass Access to HE Diploma.  A portfolio is recommended. An Enhanced Disclosure & Barring Service certificate is required.  Contextual offers may apply to care experienced students, those estranged from their families, refugees or asylum seekers, and those whose parents/carers are in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or IB from International Schools in Pakistan, entry to the first year is possible.  If a portfolio is submitted, unconditional offers may be made.
Location/Campus: Kedleston Road and Britannia Mill, Derby Campus
Overview: The BA (Hons) Creative Expressive Arts, Health and Wellbeing program at the University of Derby is designed to equip students with the skills to use the arts therapeutically in diverse settings.  The program integrates practical experience with theoretical learning, emphasizing the application of art, dance, drama, and music in health and wellbeing contexts. Students develop professional skills and confidence in working with communities and individuals, building strong practical experiences through work-based learning and placements with organizations including arts groups, hospitals, schools, and charities. Assessment methods combine creative outputs with reflective writing, developing portfolio work that demonstrates career readiness.  The course fosters groupwork, leadership, and communication skills, building essential competencies for multi-disciplinary collaborations.  Students will be involved in community project work and will benefit from the university's facilities and professional guest lectures.
Course Structure: The three-year (full-time) or up to six years' (part-time) course is structured across three stages, each focusing on the student's development as a practitioner.  Stage one establishes the grounding of the therapeutic principles, developing skills in creative group work, cultural awareness and personal reflection regarding creative identity. Stage two develops practitioner skills, looking at arts practices within health and wellbeing, using research methods to guide practice, with additional practice in working with diverse populations. The Final Year emphasizes the professional identity of the student, developing their final body of work that can either consist of a dissertation and exploration of theory or a creative performance/exhibition, and incorporates an extended placement within the community to contextualise their learning. Throughout the program, a variety of assessment methods are used, ensuring that students develop a wide range of skills, including practical skills and reflective writing. Throughout the course, students have access to personal tutors and additional academic skills support.
Year 1: Year one focuses on building a foundation in therapeutic arts practice. Key modules include "The Healthy Practitioner", exploring the role and responsibilities of the practitioner, "Human Development and Play", examining human development through the lens of playing, "Working Creatively with Groups", introducing group work methodologies,  "Arts, Culture and Wellbeing", covering cultural contexts within arts practices," and "The Creative Self", a module encouraging student self-reflection on their creative practices.
Year 2: The second year deepens students’ understanding of therapeutic approaches and research methods.  Modules such as "The Developing Practitioner" further examines theoretical grounding, "Concept of Self" allows for deeper exploration of self and identity, "Arts for Health Research Methods" equips students with appropriate research methods,  "Arts for Health" looks into professional application for wellbeing, and "Group Work for Diverse Population" hones skills in working within complex group situations. This year includes an emphasis on experiential learning and reflection, consolidating skills developed earlier.
Year 3: The final year integrates theory with substantial practical application, culminating in an individual project.  "The Emerging Practitioner" module explores the student's own final professional identity as an artist, "The Professional Self" builds on professional preparation, "Group Work in Community" enhances real world collaborative experiences, and "Independent Scholarship" supports the development of the independent project, which may be a theory-based dissertation or a practice-led project such as a performance or exhibition.

Overview: The BA (Hons) Creative Expressive Arts, Health, and Wellbeing with Foundation Year is a four-year undergraduate program designed to equip students with the skills and knowledge to utilize creative arts therapeutically.  The program begins with a foundation year, ideal for those returning to education, changing careers, or needing a gradual introduction to university-level study.  Students will gain practical experience through placements with partner organizations and develop transferable skills applicable to various settings.  The course balances theoretical learning with practical studio, performance, and exhibition work.  Highly experienced academics, including practicing arts therapists and artists, provide instruction and support.  Upon completion, graduates can pursue careers in community arts, healthcare, education, or establish their own businesses.
Course Structure: The course consists of a foundation year and three subsequent years of study.  The foundation year focuses on building fundamental skills such as study skills, communication, and anti-discriminatory practice, alongside an introduction to health, wellbeing, and the recovery model for mental health.  Subsequent years delve into more specialized areas. Year one might include modules on the healthy practitioner, human development and play, working creatively with groups, and exploring the creative self. Year two might cover art for health research methods, group work for diverse populations, and exploring the concept of self. By year three, students undertake placements, independent scholarship, and explore their professional self. The modules are subject to change to improve student experience and graduate prospects.
Year 1: The first year focuses on building a strong foundation in the therapeutic arts.  Students will learn about the healthy practitioner, human development, and the importance of play in therapeutic settings. They engage in learning methods of creative expression within group settings.  Other important topics may include the intersection between arts, culture, and overall wellbeing, and also explore their own creative self and personal expression.
Year 2: The second year builds upon the foundation, focusing on the developing practitioner. Students will explore the concept of self in relation to therapeutic practice and further their understanding of research methods tailored for arts and health studies. An important area of focus might be the usage of arts for health interventions with diverse populations and the use of group dynamics for positive change.
Year 3: The third year provides students with significant practical experiences. Students will transition into the role of an emerging practitioner and refine their professional self within this setting, enhancing group work skills within community settings through extended placement opportunities. This stage would also strongly emphasize the significance of independent scholarship and research.

Students from Pakistan with a relevant four-year Bachelor's degree and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised university are considered for entry.
Location/Campus: Kedleston Road and Britannia Mill, Derby Campus
Overview: The MArts (Hons) Creative Expressive Arts and Health Practice is a four-year (full-time) or seven-year (part-time) undergraduate program designed to equip students with the skills to use the arts therapeutically in various settings.  The course integrates practical experience through work-based learning and placements with community partners, building professional and personal skills for careers in arts, health, social care, and education. Students develop expertise in multiple art forms and therapeutic principles, applying their creative abilities to promote physical and emotional wellbeing within diverse populations. Through a balance of theoretical learning and hands-on studio work, students develop self-awareness and reflective practice skills, collaborating on projects and gaining experience in leadership and coaching.  The program culminates in an independent study focusing on students' area of interest.  The course equips graduates with the necessary skills  for a career in arts therapy and related fields.
Course Structure: The course combines classroom-based theory with practical sessions in art, dance, drama, and music studios.  Students engage in studio, performance, and exhibition work.  The curriculum emphasizes transferable skills development and critical consideration of relevant theories. The program incorporates real-world experience through community placements and projects, providing opportunities to work in diverse settings including hospitals, schools, and charities.  Learning activities are tailored to foster self-awareness, reflection, and professional development.  Assessment methods include essays, performances, exhibitions, reflective journals, and projects reflecting real-world practice.  The program also includes guest lectures by industry professionals and environmental workshops.
Year 1: The first year introduces foundational concepts of the healthy practitioner, human development and play, creative group work, the relationship between arts, culture, and well-being, and exploration of the creative self.  Students start to develop their foundational knowledge and skills in creative arts practice within a health and well-being framework.
Year 2: Building on the foundation established in Year 1, the second year focuses on the developing practitioner, concepts of self, exploring arts-based approaches within health and well-being contexts, research methods, group work with diverse populations. Students deepen their understanding of therapeutic frameworks and their application.
Year 3: The third year is centered around groupwork in a community placement setting, allowing students to apply their knowledge practically.  The focus extends to developing the professional self, mentoring and reflective practice, research, monitoring, and evaluating practice to prepare students for professional practice.
Year 4: Year four advances students' understanding of applied arts and health practice.  Focus areas include the professional practitioner role, extensive scholarship focused on a specialization in the field, and the development of robust research and evaluation skills. This final year also includes the completion of a significant independent scholarship project.

Required IELTS Score: 7.0 (with at least 6.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical requirements include 128 UCAS points.  A-Level applicants need ABB grades with at least a C in English or a related subject.  T Level applicants require a Merit, while BTEC requires DDM. GCSEs require grade 4/C or above in Maths and English. An Access to HE Diploma needs a pass with 60 credits, including 45 at Level 3 and at least a Distinction in 30 credits, Merit in 15, and Pass in 0.  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or IB from international schools within Pakistan, direct entry into the first year of a Bachelor's degree is possible.Contextual offers may apply to students from disadvantaged backgrounds, including those who are care experienced, estranged from their families, refugees or asylum seekers, or whose parents/carers are in the UK armed forces. Students must declare this criteria on application.
Overview: The University of Derby's BA (Hons) Creative Writing and Publishing course offers a comprehensive education in both the creative and commercial aspects of writing and publishing. Students develop skills in fiction and non-fiction writing, covering various forms like books, magazines, and digital content.  The program integrates practical writing workshops with a strong understanding of the publishing industry's structure and processes. Students learn about editorial work, design, production, sales, marketing, and publicity, preparing them for diverse careers in the literary world.  The course is flexible, allowing students to specialize in areas like writing for specific genres, content design, self-publishing, or business skills.  Industry guest speakers and work-based projects enhance practical learning and career preparation.
Course Structure: The three-year (full-time) or 4-6 year (part-time) course blends creative writing with publishing knowledge. Year one covers fundamental skills and knowledge through core modules. Years two and three offer optional modules tailored to student interests. Optional modules cover various aspects of writing, editing, design, production, marketing, publishing, self-publishing and more. This structure ensures practical application of theory, fostering industry relevance.
Year 1: Year one introduces students to the core aspects of creative writing and publishing.  Modules such as "Introduction to Creative Writing and Publishing," "Markets, Media and Audiences," "The Workshop," "Editorial," "Writing and Publishing: Fiction," and "The Story" lay the groundwork for future study. These modules provide a broad foundation in writing techniques, industry practices, and publishing markets.
Year 2: Year two builds upon the foundation established in year one. Core modules include "Copy-editing for Writers and Editors" and "Writing and Publishing: Children and Young Adults." Optional modules allow for specialization, including areas such as non-fiction writing, design & production, the study of language and poetry, short fiction, gaming, and more. Students begin honing their chosen niche within the publishing world.
Year 3: The final year integrates independent study with professional development. Core modules, "Independent Study in Writing and Publishing" and "Professional Development," prepare students for their careers. Optional modules provide further specialization opportunities, including advanced development, the written world in the 21st Century, genre studies, self-publishing, and academic/professional publishing. Students complete a major publishing project to showcase their skills.

Course Title: BA (Hons) Creative Writing and Publishing with Foundation Year
Required IELTS Score: 7.0 (with at least 6.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical entry requirements include 72 UCAS points, A Levels (DDD), T Level (Pass), BTEC (MMP), or an Access to HE Diploma. GCSEs in Maths and English are preferred but not mandatory.  International students require an IELTS score of 7.0 with a minimum of 6.5 in each skill. For students from Pakistan who have completed A-levels or the IB from International Schools in Pakistan, direct entry into the first year of the Bachelor's degree is possible.  Those with a Bachelor's degree with honors (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university will be considered for entry.
Annual Tuition Fee: UK: £9,250 per year; International: £16,900 per year
Overview: This four-year BA (Hons) Creative Writing and Publishing course with a foundation year provides a comprehensive education in both the creative and commercial aspects of writing and publishing. Students will gain the art and craft of writing fiction and non-fiction for various platforms, including books, magazines, and digital content.  The curriculum covers the publishing industry's workings, equipping students with the skills to navigate the market, whether by self-publishing or traditional means. The program balances creativity with commercial awareness, preparing students for careers as writers or publishing professionals.  The course includes workshops, work-based projects, guest lectures from industry leaders, and opportunities for industry experience like internships and placements. Students can tailor their degree with optional modules focusing on various writing genres, publishing specializations, and business skills.
Course Structure: The course begins with a foundation year designed to prepare students for university-level study. The subsequent three years are divided into core and optional modules.  Year one introduces fundamental skills in creative writing, publishing, editorial practices, and understanding markets and audiences. Year two and three offer a wider range of optional modules allowing students to specialize in areas like non-fiction writing, children's literature, gaming writing, design and production, self-publishing, and aspects of the publishing business. The course culminates in an independent study project showcasing the students’ developed skills and knowledge.
Year 1: The first year lays the groundwork for the degree. Core modules include "Introduction to Creative Writing and Publishing," examining the fundamentals of writing across different genres. "Markets, Media and Audiences" helps students understand the publishing landscape. "The Workshop" provides practical writing skills development.  "Editorial" focuses on the skills of editing and publishing fiction.  "The Story" delves into narrative development and construction through in-depth exploration.
Year 2: Students build upon the foundation year, taking core modules like "Copy-editing for Writers and Editors."  "Writing and Publishing: Children and Young Adults" explores this specific market demands and techniques, with optional modules allowing for specialization. Options may include: "Writing and Publishing: Non-fiction," "Design and Production," "Language and the Poetic,"  "Short Fiction Development," and "Writing and Publishing: Gaming."
Year 3: The final year focuses on independent study and professional development. Core modules include "Independent Study in Writing and Publishing," where students undertake a significant independent project demonstrating their learned skills. "Professional Development" focuses on career skills and job search practices. It also offers more specialized optional modules, such as "Development II," "The Written World in the Twenty-first Century," "Genre," "Self-publishing," and "Language and the Poetic II."

Required IELTS Score: Overall: 6.5, including a minimum score of 5.5 in each test category
Entry Requirement: A good honours degree (1st or 2:1) in any subject, or its international equivalent, is required.  Applications from those with a 2:2 honours degree may be considered if significant creative writing experience or related industry experience/aptitude is demonstrated. A writing sample (maximum 1000 words) is needed with the application. An interview may be required. If English is not your first language, IELTS 6.5 is required (minimum 5.5 in each category). For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognized university is needed, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree. Those with a two or three-year Bachelor's degree must also have a Master's degree. A Bachelor's degree with honors (four-year) and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university is also acceptable.
Overview: The University of Derby's MA Creative Writing program is a postgraduate course designed to enhance students' creative writing skills across various genres, including prose, poetry, life writing, creative non-fiction and scriptwriting.  The program offers two pathways: Creative Writing for Gaming, which focuses on script and narrative design for games; and Creative Writing with Publishing, allowing students to take modules from the MA in Publishing. The curriculum blends creative and critical approaches, incorporating workshops, individual supervision, and collaboration with peers. Employability is a strong focus, with opportunities to pitch work to a literary agent, receive industry advice and gain work experience. Guest speakers, writing retreats, and opportunities to collaborate on projects like the Writer’s Conference with Writing East Midlands enrich the learning experience.
Course Structure: The MA Creative Writing program is structured across three trimesters.  The core modules in the autumn trimester include Writing Workshop, Working as a Writer, and Editorial and Editing. The spring trimester features Writing Apprenticeship and Writing Commission, plus pathway-specific modules: What is the Imagination For? (MA Creative Writing), Writing for Games (Gaming pathway), or Magazine Publishing (Publishing pathway). The summer trimester culminates in an Independent Project (dissertation). The program promotes flexibility, allowing students to explore multiple genres and gradually specialize.
Year 1: The first year of the full-time MA Creative Writing program comprises three trimesters. The autumn trimester focuses on foundational skills with modules like Writing Workshop, Working as a Writer, and Editorial and Editing.  The spring trimester provides specialized training through modules like Writing Apprenticeship and Writing Commission, in addition to the chosen pathway module. The final summer trimester involves the completion of a substantial Independent Project (dissertation) which allows students to fully demonstrate their skills and learning.
Year 2: This applies only to part-time students. The second year mirrors the structure of the first year, with the core modules and pathway-specific modules in the appropriate trimesters, leading to the final independent project and completion of the degree.

Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with 5.5 in each skill area
Entry Requirement: A 2:2 undergraduate degree or equivalent is required.  Applicants whose first degree isn't in Social Sciences or related fields (criminology, criminal justice, policing, sociology, psychology, economics) should contact the Programme Leader.  Those whose first language isn't English need to prove English proficiency (IELTS 6.5 with 5.5 in each skill).  Applicants without an undergraduate degree but with substantial relevant professional experience are also considered.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized university, equivalent to a UK Upper Second Class (2:1) or Lower Second Class (2:2) is needed.  A Master's degree is also necessary if the Bachelor's degree is two or three years.  A four-year Bachelor's degree with honors (minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00) from a recognized Pakistani university qualifies for entry.
Location/Campus: One Friar Gate Square, Derby Campus
Annual Tuition Fee: £16,900 for the full course (full-time);£1,080 per 20 credits (part-time)
Overview: The MSc Criminal Investigation program at the University of Derby offers a rigorous academic and practical education in investigative techniques. It aims to develop high-caliber investigative professionals, suitable for law enforcement, finance, health and safety, and social services. The program aligns with the Professionalising Investigation Programme (PIP) occupational standards, providing students with skills in conducting complex investigations from initial information gathering to evidence preparation for prosecution.  The curriculum emphasizes ethical considerations, critical thinking, and professional practice while incorporating theoretical underpinnings and real-world case studies. The course attracts both graduates from traditional academic backgrounds and serving investigation professionals, benefiting from a teaching team with extensive professional investigative experience.
Course Structure: The course consists of three stages: a Postgraduate Certificate, a Postgraduate Diploma, and the MSc.  The Postgraduate Certificate covers core modules such as 'Criminal Investigation 1: Principles of Investigation' and 'Criminal Investigation 2: Victims and Witnesses', and 'Applied Research'.  The Postgraduate Diploma builds upon this foundation with 'Criminal Investigation 3: Suspects' and either two optional modules (e.g., Fundamentals of Financial and Digital Investigation, Financial Intelligence, Digital Intelligence) or a specialist pathway (Investigating Domestic Abuse or Investigating Child Sexual Exploitation Offences). The MSc culminates in an independent study project, leading to a dissertation.  The program employs a blend of lectures, seminars, group work, and e-learning, allowing students flexibility in their learning approach. Assessment methods include various assignments, presentations, and a dissertation for the MSc stage.
Year 1: The first year of the full-time MSc Criminal Investigation program covers core modules focusing on the principles of investigation, encompassing the use of intelligence and evidence gathering. It examines interactions with victims and witnesses, including identifying vulnerabilities, handling interviews, and preparing for trials.  Students will also develop applied research skills through modules covering both quantitative and qualitative methodologies. For part-time students, this content is delivered over two years.
Year 2: In the second year (or the final year for part-time students), the curriculum delves into questioning suspects to obtain reliable accounts. Optional modules allow for specialization in areas such as financial investigation, digital intelligence, and selected pathways. Finally, the students undertake an independent study, involving an extensive research project that culminates in a dissertation, showcasing their skills and knowledge.

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 with 6.0 in each skill area
Entry Requirement: An undergraduate degree (2:2 or above) in criminology or a related subject is required.  Applicants with substantial and relevant professional experience but lacking a degree are also considered.  For those whose first language is not English, an IELTS score of 6.0 with at least 6.0 in each skill area is mandatory.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized university, equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2, is needed.  A Master's degree is also required if the Bachelor's degree was two or three years. A four-year Bachelor's degree with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university is acceptable.
Location/Campus: One Friar Gate Square, Derby Campus
Overview: The MSc Criminal Justice and Criminology is a postgraduate program designed for graduates and professionals alike, focusing on the intricacies of the criminal justice system.  It delves into various aspects of criminology, including criminal behavior, penology, victimology, crime prevention, and the impact of media on crime.  The program emphasizes both theoretical understanding and practical applications, incorporating current policy debates and challenges.  Students will develop critical analysis skills, research capabilities, and policy formulation skills through a range of teaching methods, including lectures, tutorials, and independent study. The curriculum is structured around wide-ranging criminological debates, including criminal behavior; comparative criminology; victimology; penology; crime prevention; crime, media and popular culture; civil liberties and human rights; gender; and race and ethnicity.  Emphasis is placed on real-world learning with links to criminal justice organizations and guest lectures from leading practitioners.
Course Structure: The MSc program begins with an introduction to crime and contemporary criminal justice policy, examining the police, courts, prisons, probation, media, and private security. Key policy issues like rising incarceration rates and changing probation delivery are highlighted. Core modules include Criminological Frameworks, Independent Studies (Criminal Justice and Criminology), Criminal Justice: Theory and Practice, Global Criminology and Criminal Justice Systems, and Applied Research in Criminal Justice Systems. Optional modules may include Concepts of Global Terrorism, Criminal Justice: Practice and Management, and The Criminal Justice Context of Forensic Psychology. The program utilizes diverse learning approaches: lectures, tutorials, online forums, project work, group work, and guided independent study.  Assessment relies heavily on continuous assessment and written assignments, with some modules incorporating presentations and group projects.
Year 1: The first year of the full-time MSc Criminal Justice and Criminology program covers core modules such as Criminological Frameworks, providing a foundational understanding of criminological theories and their application to real-world issues.  Students explore Criminal Justice: Theory and Practice, examining the workings of the criminal justice system and its various agencies. Global Criminology and Criminal Justice Systems provide a comparative perspective, analyzing different approaches to criminal justice across the globe.  The year also includes Applied Research in Criminal Justice Systems, developing students' research skills and data analysis capabilities. Finally, students undertake an Independent Studies project, allowing them to specialize in an area of personal interest within the field of criminal justice and criminology.
Year 2: NA

For Pakistani students completing A-levels or the IB from international schools in Pakistan, entry to the first year is possible.

Overview: The BA (Hons) Criminology and Sociology degree at the University of Derby offers a comprehensive exploration of the intersection between crime and society.  Students develop a deep understanding of criminal behavior, its underlying social factors (inequality, prejudice, substance abuse), and its impact on communities. The program emphasizes practical application through real-life projects with local and national organizations, field trips to courts, prisons, and other relevant settings, and engagement with guest speakers from various criminal justice professions.  The curriculum integrates global perspectives on criminal justice and social issues, fostering critical thinking and analytical skills.  The University provides strong academic support, including a personal tutor system to assist students in achieving their academic and career goals.
Course Structure: The course combines lectures, tutorials, group work, and independent learning. Assessment methods include coursework, portfolios, individual and group projects/presentations, and examinations.  While the specific module details are subject to change, the curriculum covers various aspects of criminology and sociology, exploring the connections between crime, society, and social justice.  Students engage in research projects on contemporary topics such as drug use, hate crime, extremism, and organized crime, gaining valuable research and analytical skills. The program also includes study visits and field trips to enhance practical learning.
Year 1: Year 1 likely introduces foundational concepts in criminology and sociology, covering theoretical frameworks, research methodologies, and core sociological perspectives.  Students might delve into the history of criminological thought, exploring classic and contemporary theories of crime causation and criminal behavior.  Introductory modules in sociological theory, social research methods, and the relationship between crime and social structures might be included.  These foundational modules will provide a strong base for further study in later years.
Year 2: Year 2 builds upon the foundational knowledge of Year 1, delving deeper into specific areas within criminology and sociology. Students may have more specialized options that focus on particular types of crime (organized crime, white-collar crime, cybercrime), explore the role of institutions in the criminal justice system, or examine specific societal issues affecting crime rates like poverty, inequality and social disorganization.  Modules might include advanced research methods, victimology, criminal justice policy, and comparative criminal justice systems.
Year 3: Year 3 focuses on advanced study and applied research, allowing students to specialize in certain fields of criminology and sociology.  This could include independent research projects or dissertations, requiring students to design, conduct, and analyze data within their chosen specialization.  Students likely delve deeper into topics like criminal investigation, forensic science, restorative justice, or community justice programs. A possible study trip abroad to organizations like the International Criminal Court might be an integral part of this final year.

Overview: The Criminology and Sociology with Foundation Year BA (Hons) is a four-year undergraduate program at the University of Derby.  It explores the complex relationship between crime and society, aiming to equip students with the knowledge and skills to address real-world issues. Students will develop research and analytical skills to understand and evaluate criminal behaviour and responses. The course combines criminology and sociology perspectives, providing a comprehensive understanding of the factors contributing to crime, including social inequality, prejudice, and substance abuse.  Real-world application is emphasized through collaborations with community organizations, study visits to courts, prisons, and police forces, and potential study trips to places such as the International Criminal Court.  The program incorporates global perspectives on criminal justice and social issues.  Students will benefit from expert teaching by active researchers, police officers, sociologists and criminologists.
Course Structure: The course is structured across four years, beginning with a foundation year designed to provide students with a strong base in the subject matter.The curriculum involves a mix of lectures, tutorials, group work, and independent study.  Assessment methods are diverse and include coursework, portfolios, individual and group projects/presentations, and examinations.   Module specifics are not explicitly detailed but would cover core criminological and sociological theories, research methodology, and application to real-world contexts, while accommodating specialized interests in areas like hate crime, drug use, and gang culture within the subject areas. Year 1: The foundation year focuses on building a strong academic foundation in social sciences.  Students will develop essential skills in research, writing, critical thinking and numerical reasoning methods, alongside introductory modules in pertinent concepts and perspectives of Criminology and Sociology. The key goal is to prepare students for  undergraduate-level study, bridging any gaps in prior education, boosting confidence, and strengthening core academic skills. The year also integrates essential support and guidance,  helping students make the transition to university-level learning.
Year 2: The second year dives deeper into core criminological and sociological theories and concepts. Students will study various theoretical frameworks explaining criminal behavior and social problems. Modules will explore the interplay between social structures, individual agency, and deviance.  Methodology courses focusing on research design and data analysis are also included and students will be exposed to various forms of qualitative and quantitative research methods. Students will analyse several case studies of criminal behaviours and social problems.
Year 3: The third year involves more specialized study in criminology and sociology, allowing students to tailor their learning to their interests. There will likely be advanced modules on topics such as victimology, criminal justice systems, penology, and social policy.  There may be opportunities to undertake research projects or engage in fieldwork with community organizations.  This year also includes a module dedicated to global perspectives within the Criminology and Sociology fields, focusing on similarities and differences through research and application.
Year 4: The final year of study culminates in a major independent research project, allowing students to delve into a topic of their choice within Criminology and Sociology and showcase their acquired research, analytical, and writing abilities.  Advanced modules may incorporate areas like contemporary crime and social issues, investigative techniques, and criminal policy. The program may conclude with a focus on career development and employability skills, preparing students for professional and academic opportunities.

Overview: The University of Derby's BSc (Hons) Criminology is a three-year undergraduate program exploring the causes and consequences of crime, its measurement and definition, and criminal management and control.  Students will delve into the challenges facing criminal justice professionals across various sectors, including policing, courts, prisons, probation, youth offending, and victim support. The course emphasizes hands-on learning through partnerships with criminal justice agencies, offering opportunities for practical application of knowledge.  It fosters critical thinking, challenges established beliefs, and encourages development of research interests.  International perspectives are integrated, enriching learning and enhancing career prospects.  Students develop investigative, management, and communication skills via various activities like interviews, negotiations, and research projects. The program is taught by an award-winning team of experts actively engaged in practice, ensuring contemporary relevance.
Course Structure: The curriculum is structured across three years and may be subject to change.  The course covers a range of topics in criminology, combining theoretical knowledge with practical application.  Specific subjects may include theoretical criminology, criminal justice systems, victimology, criminal psychology, and research methodologies.  The final year offers complete flexibility to tailor modules to suit individual career aims and passions. This involves various teaching methods like lectures, tutorials, group work, and independent study. Assessment is diverse, utilizing coursework, portfolios, individual and group projects, and examinations.
Year 1: The first year provides a foundational understanding of key criminological theories and concepts. Students are introduced to the history and development of criminology, different theoretical approaches to understanding crime, and the social context of crime.  They may also explore topics such as deviance, social control, and the criminal justice system’s organisation.  Practical experience is incorporated through visits to relevant institutions like the National Justice Museum, offering a historical context to the academic learning.
Year 2: Building upon the foundation established in the first year, Year 2 delves deeper into specialized areas within criminology. Students may explore subjects like criminological research methods, facilitating the development of their research skills in criminological contexts.  Focus areas could involve more specific types of crime, such as white-collar crime or cybercrime, the criminal justice processes, and investigation techniques. Practical elements continue, potentially including participation in projects such as mock murder hunts or investigations into miscarriages of justice.
Year 3: The final year allows for specialization based on individual career interests.  Students can tailor their module choices according to their professional aspirations.  This might include advanced criminological theories, research projects on chosen topics, and potentially placement in a criminal justice setting, thereby enabling real-world experience. Projects undertaken during the final year of the course could lead to publications or presentations at conferences, thereby providing students with career-enhancing activities.

Overview: The University of Derby's BSc (Hons) Cyber Security degree is designed to equip students with the technical and analytical skills necessary to thrive in the rapidly growing field of cybersecurity.  The program covers a broad range of topics, including security policies, legal and regulatory requirements, risk and vulnerability assessment, security architecture and development, information assurance methodologies, ethical hacking, and incident management.  Students will develop expertise in critically analyzing and evaluating responses to security incidents and building secure physical infrastructure and software. The course also incorporates employability skills and offers an optional placement year to enhance career prospects.  The curriculum is assessed through coursework, portfolios, assignments, case studies, and presentations, eliminating written examinations.
Course Structure: The course structure involves a foundational first year shared with other Computing students, allowing for flexibility to transfer to other Computing specializations if desired.  Following the first year, the curriculum focuses on cybersecurity specialization, with opportunities for tailored study in the final year. The modules cover a range of cybersecurity topics, including security principles, networking security, ethical hacking, cryptography, incident management, risk analysis, and legal and regulatory compliance. Students will also gain practical experience using industry-standard software and tools in state-of-the-art laboratories. An optional placement year can provide valuable real-world work experience.
Year 1: The first year provides a foundation in computing, shared with students from other Computing degrees.  This includes fundamental programming concepts, data structures, algorithms, and an introduction to computer networks.  It also sets the groundwork for cybersecurity learning by introducing core security principles and concepts.
Year 2: Year two deepens the study of various aspects of Cybersecurity. Students will undertake more focused modules which explore areas like network security, cryptography, risk management and security architecture. The course will introduce more advanced concepts with more practical work and potentially the start of a placement year.
Year 3: The third year focuses on specialist areas within cybersecurity, allowing students to tailor their studies to their interests and career goals.  This year may include modules on advanced topics such as ethical hacking, incident response, digital forensics, security auditing, and cloud security.  The practical skills gained during years 1 and 2 will be expanded upon.
Year 4: In the optional fourth year, students participate in a placement year. This can significantly improve a student's resume and allow them to apply the knowledge they learned in years 1-3 at an established company and gain professional contacts within the Cyber Security field.

Entry Requirement: For UK/International students, an honors degree (at least a 2.2) or equivalent qualifications/experience in a computing discipline is required. If English is not your first language, proof of English proficiency (IELTS 6.0 or equivalent) is necessary.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognized university is required, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree. Students with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees need a Master's degree pass. A Bachelor's degree with honors (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university is also acceptable for Master's entry.
Overview: The University of Derby's MSc Cyber Security program is designed to equip students with both managerial and technical expertise in information security.  The curriculum is informed by industry needs and covers a range of topics, including advanced security protocols, enterprise security management, network security, ethical hacking, risk management, compliance, and legal and human aspects of cybersecurity.  The program emphasizes a holistic approach to protecting organizational systems, preparing graduates for management roles and addressing the current shortage of cybersecurity professionals.  Students benefit from a dedicated cybersecurity lab, blended learning methods, and industry collaborations. The program is accredited by the Chartered Institute of Information Security (CIISec).
Course Structure: The MSc Cyber Security is structured in three stages: Postgraduate Certificate, Postgraduate Diploma, and MSc. The Postgraduate Certificate requires three modules from a selection including Advanced Security Protocols, Enterprise Security Management, Studying Masters Level and Research Methods, Security: Attacks and Countermeasures, Securing Networks, and Human and Legal Aspects of Cyber Security. The Postgraduate Diploma requires all six modules.  The MSc involves an independent scholarship, a significant research project culminating in a master's-level dissertation, which usually involves real-world applications in partnership with industry collaborators.
Year 1: The first year of the MSc Cyber Security program involves completing the Postgraduate Certificate and Postgraduate Diploma modules. This intensive year covers fundamental and advanced topics in cybersecurity. Students will learn about managing security processes in businesses, analyzing complex security protocols, securing networks, understanding and mitigating attacks, and the legal and ethical considerations of cybersecurity. The curriculum uses a blended learning approach, using lectures, seminars, and hands-on practical sessions in a dedicated cybersecurity lab.

Overview: The University of Derby's BSc (Hons) Cyber Security with Foundation Year is a four-year undergraduate program designed to equip students with the technical and analytical skills needed for a successful career in cybersecurity.  The curriculum covers a wide range of topics including security policies, legal and regulatory requirements, risk and vulnerability assessment, security architecture and development, information assurance methodologies, ethical hacking, and incident management. Students will learn to critically analyze security incidents and develop the skills to build robust and secure IT infrastructure.  The course includes a foundation year to help students strengthen their skills and knowledge, and an optional placement year to gain practical experience and enhance their professional network.  The program is assessed through coursework, portfolios, assignments, and presentations, eliminating written exams.  The university boasts industry-standard laboratories, and its partnership with the Chartered Institute of Information Security (CIISec) enhances the program's industry relevance.
Course Structure: The course is structured across four years, starting with a foundation year focused on building a solid base in computing knowledge. The subsequent years delve into specialist modules in cybersecurity, which includes, among many other topics such as Security Policies, Legal and Regulatory requirements, Risk and Vulnerability assessment,  Security architecture and development, Information assurance methodologies, Ethical Hacking and Incident Management, and  assess students through a mix of coursework, projects, and presentations. There is an optional industrial placement year, allowing for practical, real-world experience. Students will be equipped to evaluate and respond to security incidents, and develop skills in physical and software infrastructure to create robust and secure solutions.
Year 1: The foundation year focuses on building a strong base in computing principles. It provides fundamental knowledge in computing alongside students from other computing degrees, preparing them for the specialized subjects of the next three years and providing an opportunity to further their computing knowledge before specializing in Cyber Security. It is a supportive year that helps build confidence and academic skills. Students who successfully complete the foundation year will directly progress to the first year of the degree without reapplication.
Year 2: Year two of the BSc (Hons) Cyber Security program builds upon the foundational knowledge of the first year. The specific modules will vary, providing flexibility for students to later choose their area of expertise and specialization. Students will begin to delve into more specialized cybersecurity modules, developing their technical skills and critical analysis capabilities.
Year 3: The third year of the program allows for an optional placement year, where students can gain hands-on experience in the industry. If they choose to do industrial placement, students will have the opportunity to network, grow their industry skills and learn from real-world professionals in their chosen field. If the student opts not to do the placement year, this year will focus more on the deeper and more specialized aspects of the course, giving them more in-depth knowledge of the field.
Year 4: The final year of the program focuses on advanced cybersecurity topics as well as honing essential skills such as critical analysis and evaluation of security response, risk and vulnerability management and incident response capabilities.  Students will further refine their technical skills in building and managing secure systems. The program culminates in a final project that allows students to showcase their expertise and apply integrated knowledge and skills.

Overview: The University of Derby offers an advanced cycling assessment short course designed to optimize cycling performance for athletes of all levels.  This comprehensive assessment goes beyond a basic evaluation, incorporating detailed measurements of cycling efficiency, including fat max, critical power, and anaerobic work capacity – metrics commonly used by professional cycling teams.  The assessment involves a series of tests, including body composition analysis, resting blood analysis (hematocrit and hemoglobin), blood lactate assessment (to determine LT1 and LT2), and an assessment of cycling efficiency using advanced gas analysis to calculate gross efficiency and fat max.  The course concludes with advanced analysis of results, enabling the creation of personalized training zones and performance models, as well as identification of areas for improvement and strength maximization.
Course Structure: The course consists of a battery of tests designed to provide a comprehensive assessment of cycling performance.  These tests include body composition assessment, resting blood analysis measuring hematocrit and hemoglobin levels, and a blood lactate assessment using a step protocol to determine lactate thresholds (LT1 and LT2).  A crucial component is the assessment of cycling efficiency, which involves calculating gross efficiency and fat max using advanced gas analysis.  Finally, critical power and anaerobic work capacity are determined via a 3-minute all-out maximal test, also yielding max power and VO2 max/peak values. The course also includes an in-depth analysis of the test results, with detailed reporting, personalized training zone recommendations and individualized training plans for performance optimization.

Overview: The University of Derby offers a short course called "Cycling Assessment - Experience," designed to provide cyclists with comprehensive physiological data to optimize their training and performance.  The assessment includes body composition analysis, resting blood analysis (hematocrit and hemoglobin), and VO2 max and blood lactate assessment using a step and ramp protocol. Participants receive detailed results, interpretations, and personalized training recommendations, comparing their performance to elite cyclists.  This intensive assessment helps cyclists better understand their strengths, weaknesses, and identify areas for training improvement. Ultimately, the course aims to facilitate the development of targeted training regimes to help cyclists excel. The course provides insight into the physiological demands of cycling at an elite level.
Course Structure: The course involves a battery of tests designed to provide a comprehensive physiological assessment of the cyclist's capabilities.  These tests include body composition analysis using bioelectrical impedance, assessing body fat and lean muscle mass. Resting blood analysis involving the measurement of hematocrit and hemoglobin, key indicators of blood health and oxygen-carrying capacity,  is also included. The core assessment is the VO2 max and blood lactate assessment conducted using a two-stage protocol.  First, a step protocol gradually increases power output to identify lactate thresholds (LT1 and LT2). Second, a ramp protocol gradually increases power output until exhaustion to determine VO2 max, peak heart rate, and maximal aerobic power. This data allows for individualized training based on the athletes current performance.

Overview: The MA Dance and Choreography program at the University of Derby is a postgraduate course designed for dance artists seeking to enhance their skills and push creative boundaries.  It focuses on developing choreographic abilities and provides opportunities for creating innovative work. The course fosters collaboration and networking, both regionally and internationally, giving students access to exceptional resources and infrastructure. Key areas of study include narrative development, audience engagement, creating work for various contexts (indoor/outdoor), funding strategies, developing partnerships, securing commissions, and health and safety in dance practice.  Students will create and present work in professional studio spaces, gaining valuable experience and industry connections, ultimately preparing them for a professional dance career.
Course Structure: The MA consists of modules structured across postgraduate certificate and diploma stages, culminating in a major project. The Postgraduate Certificate includes 'Choreography 1' (40 credits) and 'Advanced Research Methods' (20 credits). The Postgraduate Diploma adds 'Choreography 2' (40 credits) and 'Artist as Entrepreneur' (20 credits). Finally, the MA requires a 'Major Project: Dissertation OR Performance Piece' (60 credits). Modules are subject to change to enhance student experience and graduate prospects.  Assessment methods are diverse, employing papers, practical demonstrations, performances, and viva voce (oral examination).
Year 1: The first year is focused on intensive dance and choreography training, encompassing both theoretical and practical components.  Students will engage in creative lab sessions, experimenting with new ideas and collaborating with peers.  The year covers modules such as Choreography 1 (exploring fundamental aspects of choreography and creative processes), Advanced Research Methods (developing research skills applicable to dance practice), Choreography 2 (developing advanced skills in choreography through further creative work).  Artist as Entrepreneur focuses on practical business skills for dance professionals. The year concludes with a major project, either a dissertation or performance piece, which serves as a capstone to the program.

Course Title: BA (Hons) Dance and Movement for Wellbeing
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical requirements include 112 UCAS points, A Levels BBC, BTEC DMM, GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or equivalent.  A portfolio is recommended.  Contextual offers may apply to care experienced students, those estranged from their families, refugees, asylum seekers, or those whose parents/carers are in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or the IB from international schools in Pakistan, entry to year one is possible. Students with a four-year Bachelor's degree with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani university may be considered.
Overview: The BA (Hons) Dance and Movement for Wellbeing is a three-year undergraduate program designed for students passionate about dance and its impact on wellbeing.  The course provides a strong foundation in dance technique across various styles, alongside theoretical knowledge of the relationship between dance and mental/physical health. Students will develop practical skills in teaching and facilitating dance for diverse populations, including children, the elderly, and community groups.  The curriculum emphasizes applied learning, research-informed teaching, and integrates theory with practical experience through workshops, placements, and individual projects.  The program aims to equip graduates with the skills and understanding needed to pursue fulfilling and impactful careers in the field.
Course Structure: The course is structured across three years, with a range of modules focusing on dance technique, improvisation, choreography, and therapeutic applications. Year 1 introduces fundamental dance techniques, exploring movement styles and their application to mental health and community settings. Year 2 builds on these foundations, delving into specialized areas such as dance for the elderly and early years, and includes a placement in an applied dance setting.  Year 3 culminates in independent study, focusing on a specific area of interest within dance and wellbeing, and explores creative ballet practice alongside broader arts for wellbeing. Throughout the program, students are assessed via practical classes, performances, essays, presentations, and journals.
Year 1: Year 1 modules include Dynamic Movement 1 focusing on contemporary, ballet, yoga, and Skinner Release techniques and improvisation; Dance for Mental Health exploring the impact of dance on wellbeing; Exploring Current Dance Practice for Wellbeing analyzing trends in 21st-century dance; and Community Dance, which explores leading and inspiring through movement in various community settings.
Year 2: Year 2 continues with Dynamic Movement 2, building on Year 1's skills; Dance for the Elderly, focusing on movement for older adults and falls prevention; Community Engagement and Applied Dance Placement, encompassing theory and practice with a placement; and Dance for Early Years, exploring facilitating dance experiences for young children and their parents.
Year 3: Year 3 features Dynamic Movement 3, involving the design and delivery of dance sessions; Independent Study in Dance and Movement for Wellbeing, allowing for individual research; Creative Ballet Practice, examining ballet within social and political contexts; and Arts for Wellbeing, exploring the therapeutic potential of various art forms.

Required IELTS Score: 7.0 with 6.5 in each skills area

Overview: The MA Dance Movement Psychotherapy program at the University of Derby is a two-year, full-time course designed to equip students with the necessary skills and knowledge to become registered dance movement psychotherapists. The program integrates theoretical understanding with practical application, emphasizing the body-mind connection and creative self-expression through dance and movement.  Students will explore various therapeutic approaches, develop clinical skills, and engage in personal therapy as part of professional development and registration. The program emphasizes current research, critical reflection, and ethical practice within diverse healthcare settings such as health, education, and community environments. Graduates will be well-prepared for careers as registered Dance Movement Psychotherapists, potentially progressing to roles including supervision, lecturing, and research within the field. The program benefits from strong links with the healthcare and education sectors, ensuring its curriculum remains current and relevant.
Course Structure: The course comprises several modules, including those focused on the body-mind relationship, movement observation and analysis, clinical placement and supervision, experiential group skills, research and theory in dance movement psychotherapy, advanced clinical practice and supervision. Assessment methods vary and include presentations, video production, written critiques, and case studies. Students also participate in 80 hours of personal therapy which is mandatory for professional registration. Guest speakers, varied teaching methods and interaction with professional placement managers support learning.  International, national and global viewpoints are incorporated. Students are encouraged to establish professional employer relationships and develop projects and networks while on placement. There is the opportunity to present ideas at conferences and develop research projects.
Year 1: The first year focuses on foundational knowledge and skills in dance movement psychotherapy. Modules cover the core principles of psyche-soma, movement observation and analysis within studio settings, and practical experience through clinical placement and supervision. Students develop fundamental therapeutic skills and begin to apply their knowledge in practice under supervision, receiving feedback and guidance on their approach. Emphasis is placed on both theoretical frameworks and experiential learning, building a strong base for the more advanced study in the second year.
Year 2: Year two deepens the student's understanding of dance movement psychotherapy through advanced modules. Experiential group skills are developed along with an in-depth exploration of research, theory, and advanced practical applications in clinical supervision. Students undertake an extensive supervised clinical placement, expanding on their clinical practice skills and allowing them to build a portfolio of experience.  The final major project allows the student to integrate their learning, providing a significant contribution to the theoretical body of knowledge in dance movement psychotherapy.

Overview: The University of Derby's MA/MDes Design is a future-focused program designed for experimental and curious designers.  It emphasizes collaborative work across design disciplines to tackle societal challenges. Students develop personalized curricula, participate in live projects with industry and community partners, and utilize innovative technology in a blended studio environment.  The program fosters creative disruption, risk-taking, and critical thinking, integrating theory, research, and practice.  Students can choose to graduate with either an MA Design or an MDes in a specific specialism (Graphic Design, Illustration, Fashion, Textile Design, Interior and Spatial Design, or Product Design). The program includes professional development seminars, critiques, and concept panels, culminating in an integrated design project and thesis.
Course Structure: The program consists of several core and optional modules.  It starts with 'Design Propositions,' a diagnostic module to re-evaluate skills and set a learning direction.  Students undertake 'Design Lab' modules focusing on themes like 'experiencing the past' or 'creative futures,' engaging in live design projects with external stakeholders.  They can choose the optional 'Creative Entrepreneurial Business' module. The final stage involves 'Design Synthesis,' an independent study module integrating previous learning into a major project and thesis.  Students choose a specialization path within Design Synthesis, aligning with either the broader MA Design or a specialized MDes.
Year 1: The first year (full-time) or the first two years (part-time) of the MA/MDes Design program includes the foundational module 'Design Propositions', allowing students to assess their existing skills and establish a direction for their studies. Students will then choose a selection of Design Lab modules, focusing on themes relevant to their chosen specialism, participating in live design projects alongside external stakeholders. There will be regular professional development seminars, critiques, and concept panels to provide feedback.
Year 2: In the second year (part-time) students continue to undertake 'Design Lab' modules to further develop their skillset. They will select optional subjects from several modules. The modules undertaken in the first year will continue to be developed, with greater focus on advanced skills, leading into the final Design Synthesis module.

Overview: This Level 7 short course, "Developing as an Evidence-Based Practitioner," focuses on equipping health and social care professionals with the skills and knowledge to critically appraise research and apply evidence-based practices.  The course will cover the importance of evidence-based practice, literature searching techniques, and foundational research methodology.  Participants learn to critically evaluate research, improving their practice based on robust and relevant evidence.  The objective is to improve practical skills and build proficiency in academic skills valuable for postgraduate studies such as critical reading, writing, and thinking. The course is primarily geared towards already established health and social care professionals including nurses, paramedics, occupational therapists, pharmacists, and sonographers. Students will have online access to the course support and will be assisted by a module tutor via phone, email, or Skype.
Course Structure: The course is structured into modules that cover the foundational aspects of evidence-based practice.  It covers how to conduct a systematic literature search to find appropriate evidence, the essential features of research methodology, and the vital ability to critically analyze research within their field. Then, the main study modules cover the critical application of the theories and practices for effective evidence-based practice.  The course culminates in a final assessment designed to measure the comprehensive understanding and ability to apply the learned concepts and practical skills.   The course includes online learning resources, with support provided via phone, Skype, and email, to facilitate both the theoretical understanding and the application of evidence-based practice.
Year 1: NA
Year 2: NA

Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with a minimum of 5.5 in all areas
Entry Requirement: Applicants need a science or healthcare-related degree with at least a 2:1 classification.  Degrees older than five years require evidence of successful level 6 study within the past two years.  Five GCSEs at grade C or above are needed, including Maths and English Language. If the first degree isn't in a pure science (biology, chemistry, or physics), or a pure science A-level at grade B or above is lacking, at least one pure science GCSE at grade C or above is required. Recent work experience in a Radiography department is also mandatory.  The University considers all application information and interview performance, looking for enthusiasm and motivation to become a Radiographer. For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognised university, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree, is required. Those with two or three-year Bachelor degrees need a Master’s degree pass. A Bachelor's degree with honours (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University also qualifies for admission.
Overview: The University of Derby's MSc Diagnostic Radiography (Pre-Registration) is a two-year, full-time program designed to prepare students for careers as Diagnostic Radiographers.  The course is HCPC-accredited, ensuring graduates are eligible for registration upon completion.  The curriculum blends theoretical knowledge with extensive practical experience through clinical placements in various settings, from large teaching hospitals to smaller community hospitals. Students will develop skills in various imaging modalities (X-rays, CT, ultrasound) and learn to work effectively within a multidisciplinary team.  The program emphasizes critical thinking, research skills, and professional development, providing students with a strong foundation for a successful career in medical imaging.
Course Structure: The program consists of a structured curriculum delivered over two years  The first year focuses on foundational knowledge and skills in radiographic principles, professional practice, and clinical practice.  The second year builds upon this foundation, integrating advanced clinical placements, a scientific project, and additional modules focusing on advanced imaging practices and the role of the graduate practitioner. A robust professional development program runs throughout the two years, culminating in a comprehensive portfolio demonstrating skills and attributes required for clinical practice. Modules include Research Skills for Practice, Principles of Professional Practice, Clinical Practice for Radiography 1 and 2, Imaging Practice 1, 2, and 3, and The Graduate Practitioner.
Year 1: The first year lays the groundwork for clinical practice. Students cover fundamental principles of professional practice, research skills relevant to the field, and foundational clinical practices in radiography.  They are introduced to various imaging modalities through dedicated modules on imaging practice.  A key component is hands-on training and simulation to develop essential patient positioning and imaging techniques. The year concludes with a foundation of core radiological knowledge and practical skills, preparing students for the advanced learning and clinical experience of year two.
Year 2: The second year intensifies clinical experience with longer placement blocks, particularly during the summer months. Students undertake a scientific project allowing for in-depth study in a chosen area of diagnostic radiography.  Advanced imaging techniques and practices are explored in more detail.   Professional development continues with a focus on developing the skills and attributes of a graduate practitioner, including critical thinking and problem-solving skills in realistic clinical scenarios. Students complete a professional development portfolio. The year culminates in preparedness for professional registration and employment as a Diagnostic Radiographer.
