Required IELTS Score: Overall: 6.5, no less than 6 in any category
Entry Requirement: This program is designed for assistant practitioners holding a foundation degree (FdSc) in a projection (plain film) imaging pathway, typically completed within the previous 5 years.  Applicants with FdSc in a modality-only pathway require additional qualifications to meet entry requirements.  Those whose foundation degree was completed more than 5 years ago may need to provide evidence of ongoing CPD. Overseas applicants require an IELTS score of 6.5 with no less than 6 in each category, or an equivalent English qualification.  Essential qualifications include Level 2 English and Maths (GCSE Grade 4-9, A-C, or equivalent). The Healthcare Assistant Practitioner Apprenticeship Standard Reference: ST0215 is acceptable if modules in skeletal imaging (including appendicular imaging), radiographic anatomy, and radiation physics were completed.  Applicants must be working in a diagnostic imaging environment and have access to a full range of clinical experience to meet HCPC standards.  Manager support and named assessors with specific training are also required.  Pakistan Entry Requirements are not specified for this course.
Overview: The BSc (Hons) Diagnostic Radiography Degree Apprenticeship is a flexible, predominantly online program designed to upskill assistant practitioners to become registered diagnostic radiographers. It bridges the gap between the assistant practitioner role (band 4) and the requirements for registration as a diagnostic radiographer. The program incorporates two optional face-to-face on-campus schools and utilizes the University of Derby's online platform with regular synchronous tutor support.  The curriculum focuses on building upon existing assistant practitioner competencies, emphasizing both theoretical knowledge and practical clinical skills.  The program is accredited by the HCPC and validated by the University of Derby, approved by the College of Radiographers, prioritizing a patient-focused approach and evidence-based practice.
Course Structure: The program is structured across three trimesters: January-April, May-August, and September-December.  It comprises modules at levels 5 and 6, all core modules.  Level 5 includes: Developing projection radiography, Developing imaging practice, and Professional skills in clinical practice.  Level 6 modules are: Advancing projection radiography, Advancing imaging practice, Advancing professional skills, Independent scholarship, and Transition to practice. The program uses a blended learning approach.  Assessment includes various practice-based assessments linked to HCPC standards, clinical assessments forming part of a clinical portfolio (using Pebblepad), and regular tripartite reviews to track progress. Workplace mentors are involved in assessment, and training and support are provided.
Year 1: NA
Year 2: NA

Required IELTS Score: 6.5 (with at least 6.0 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical requirements include 128 UCAS points.  A-Level students need ABB, with at least a B in Biology, Physics, or Chemistry.  T Level requires a Distinction, while BTEC needs DDM (excluding Health & Social Care).  GCSEs in Maths, English, and Double Science at grade 4/C or above are mandatory.  An Access to Science course is preferred but an Access to Higher Education Diploma with specific criteria is also accepted.  An interview is required.  An Enhanced Disclosure & Barring Service certificate and an Occupational Health Assessment are also needed.  For Pakistani students holding A-levels or IB from International schools in Pakistan can enter directly into the first year. Students with other qualifications should refer to the university’s Pakistani entry requirements on the website for Undergraduate, Postgraduate and PhD programs.
Annual Tuition Fee: UK: £9,535 per year; International: £16,900 per year
Overview: The University of Derby offers a Diagnostic Radiography BSc (Hons) program designed to equip students with the necessary skills and experience for a career as a diagnostic radiographer. This three-year, full-time course integrates theoretical learning with significant clinical placements, making up approximately 50% of the program. The curriculum covers imaging techniques like x-rays, CT scans, and ultrasound, alongside professional skills development and preparation for registration with the Health and Care Professions Council (HCPC).  The program utilizes state-of-the-art facilities, including a diagnostic imaging suite and an immersive simulation environment. Emphasis is placed on the development of technical skills, interpersonal capabilities, and leadership qualities to suit a variety of career pathways within the field.
Course Structure: The Diagnostic Radiography BSc (Hons) program is structured across three years, with a strong emphasis on practical, hands-on learning alongside theoretical modules. Year 1 establishes foundational knowledge in radiographic principles and techniques, alongside the development of essential clinical skills.  Year 2 delves deeper into advanced imaging modalities and procedures. Students continue to improve their clinical competence through  placements. Year 3 involves specialized modules, a longer clinical placement, and an elective placement allowing students to broaden the horizons of their practical skills. The program also integrates extensive clinical placements throughout to ensure practical experience.  The program is designed to meet the demands of the healthcare sector, with modules regularly reviewed and updated to reflect current industry practices. Students will participate regularly in group activities, lectures, practical work, seminars and simulated enviroments. Regular assessment methods will include exams, assignments, presentations, and performance evaluations during placements .
Year 1: The first year focuses on establishing fundamental knowledge of radiographic principles and techniques.  Students develop basic skills in image acquisition, processing, and interpretation, covering various imaging modalities.  This year incorporates introductory modules in anatomy, physiology, radiation protection, and patient care.  Early clinical placements provides early exposure to the healthcare environment and practical experience with imaging equipment in different locations. Emphasis will be on the development of fundamental clinical skills and preparation for future modules.
Year 2: Building upon the foundation established in the first year, the second year introduces more advanced imaging modalities and techniques, such as CT scanning and ultrasound. Students will engage in more complex clinical scenarios, enhancing their diagnostic abilities and decision-making skills.  There will also be modules covering radiation biology, medical law, ethics, and professional practice. This year also involves longer clinical placements across a wider variety of healthcare settings, thereby improving students hands-on experience and clinical competence. The assessment for this year could include practicals, exams and assignments based on theoretical and practical skills obtained during the duration.
Year 3: The final year focuses on specialization, consolidating theoretical knowledge with extensive clinical practice.  Students undertake a substantial clinical placement, allowing for in-depth experience in diverse areas of diagnostic radiography. This could involve a longer placement involving specialised areas like Interventional Radiography or MRI. This year also entails a shorter three-week elective placement, giving students an opportunity to explore further specialisms or gain international experience. Advanced modules include image analysis, quality assurance, and management aspects in radiography. The assessment will be based on a variety of methods which may include  projects, examinations, and presentations that assess clinical competence and advanced skill mastery .

Course Title: Undergraduate Diagnostic Radiography with Foundation Year BSc (Hons)
Required IELTS Score: 6.5 (with at least 6.0 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical requirements include 80 UCAS points.  A-Level: CDD; T Level: Pass (C or above in the core); BTEC: MMP; GCSE: Maths, English and double Science grade 4/C (or above) or equivalent; Access to HE: Pass Access to HE Diploma with 60 credits (45 at Level 3, minimum Distinction: 0, Merit: 30, Pass: 15). An interview is required, along with an Enhanced Disclosure & Barring Service certificate and an Occupational Health Assessment and Clearance.  Contextual offers may apply to care experienced students, those estranged from their families, refugees or asylum seekers, or those whose parents/carers are in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or the IB from international schools in Pakistan, entry to the first year is possible.
Overview: The University of Derby offers a four-year Diagnostic Radiography BSc (Hons) with a Foundation Year. This program is designed for students who possess the aptitude for higher education but lack the formal qualifications for direct entry into the honors degree. The foundation year strengthens skills and knowledge, introducing students to the subject.  The subsequent three years comprise the accredited Diagnostic Radiography degree, preparing graduates for registration with the Health and Care Professions Council (HCPC) as diagnostic radiographers upon meeting HCPC requirements. The program features innovative teaching methods delivered by qualified health professionals with extensive clinical and community experience. Students benefit from personal tutoring support  to maximize academic success. A career in healthcare is emphasized, offering the opportunity to positively affect people's lives daily.
Course Structure: The four-year course begins with a foundation year designed to provide a strong academic base.   Following the foundation year, the program focuses on core diagnostic radiography concepts and practical training. Students undergo extensive clinical placements in real-world healthcare settings to gain practical experience and expertise. The curriculum includes modules covering anatomical knowledge, imaging techniques, radiation protection, patient care, professional ethics, and aspects of clinical practice, emphasizing hands-on training and professional development throughout.
Year 1: The foundation year focuses on developing essential academic skills and knowledge needed for the subsequent Diagnostic Radiography degree. Students receive foundational instruction across relevant scientific disciplines and may engage with introductory modules covering core study skills, healthcare systems, basic human anatomy and physiology, and introduction to radiographic imaging principles. The goal is to ensure students are well-prepared for the higher-level material in subsequent years. This year provides intensive support to bridge any academic gaps and build confidence.
Year 2: Year two delves deeper into the scientific principles of diagnostic radiology, building on the foundational year's coursework. Students explore more advanced topics in human anatomy and physiology, integrating theoretical knowledge with practical skills training.  They receive further instruction in radiographic techniques, including plain film, fluoroscopy, computed tomography (CT), and possibly magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).  They may also undertake introductory modules related to patient care and communication, radiation physics and protection, and ethical practice in healthcare. Clinical placement opportunities could commence.
Year 3: The third year intensifies practical training. Students undertake a significant clinical placement in a hospital or healthcare setting, gaining practical expertise in various aspects of diagnostic radiography.  They further develop technical skills in various imaging modalities and gain experience in interacting with patients, applying the ethical considerations and practical skills developed in previous years. Advanced modules could cover specialized imaging techniques (like CT or MRI) and further aspects of radiological physics, image analysis and reporting.
Year 4: The final year focuses on advanced clinical skills, and professional practice. Students continue to refine their diagnostic abilities and extend their knowledge base through specialized modules and potentially elective options, depending on the program's structure.  They complete a comprehensive clinical placement to fully integrate learned skills and knowledge.  Emphasis is placed on professional development, preparing students for the workplace through modules covering career planning, professional conduct, and potentially advanced imaging techniques.

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 112 UCAS points, A Levels (BBC), T Level (Merit), BTEC (DMM), or an Access to HE Diploma.  GCSEs in Maths and English at Grade 4/C or above are also needed. International students require an IELTS score of 6.0 with at least 5.5 in each skill.  Contextual offers may be available for students from particular backgrounds, including care-experienced students, estranged students, refugees, asylum seekers, and students whose parents/carers are in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or the IB from international schools in Pakistan, entry to the first year is possible.
Overview: The BSc (Hons) Digital Marketing degree at the University of Derby provides a comprehensive education in the rapidly evolving field of digital marketing.  Students gain hands-on experience using various digital media, including social media, viral marketing, multi-channel campaigns, content management, online advertising, search engine optimization, and mobile marketing strategies. The curriculum emphasizes practical application, incorporating real-world projects and potential internships with marketing agencies.  The program also covers foundational marketing principles, business, and brand management, ensuring graduates possess a robust skillset.  The course is accredited by the Chartered Institute of Marketing (CIM), providing exemptions towards the CIM Diploma in Professional Marketing.  The university also features a strong personal academic tutoring program aimed at fostering student success throughout their academic journey.
Course Structure: The course structure is not explicitly detailed, but the program covers a wide range of digital marketing topics. Students will engage in practical projects and assessments such as developing social media business profiles, creating infographics, building presentations, and writing reports. The curriculum includes modules focusing on social media engagement, viral marketing, multi-channel campaign strategies, content management systems, online advertising techniques, search engine optimization (SEO) practices, mobile marketing approaches, and digital analytics.  The program integrates theoretical knowledge with practical application, including the utilization of relevant technologies and tools. Guest speakers from marketing agencies and businesses contribute to the learning experience, offering real-world insights and perspectives.
Year 1: The first year likely lays the foundation in core marketing principles alongside introductory modules on digital marketing technologies and practices. Students gain an understanding of marketing fundamentals including brand management and research methods. An introduction to social media marketing, content creation, and basic SEO would also be expected.  The focus in the first year is on developing a comprehensive understanding of the digital landscape and building essential skills.
Year 2: The second year deepens students' knowledge of digital marketing theory and techniques.  Modules may include advanced social media marketing, analytics, and paid advertising strategies, with a focus on hands-on projects and the application of learned concepts. Students start to specialize in specific areas and refine their skills in areas like SEO optimization, content strategy, and campaign management.  This year would also likely include work on project management and client interaction skills.
Year 3: The final year focuses on advanced digital marketing strategies and culminates in a major project which provides students with an opportunity to apply their skills to a significant project. Students further specialize, perhaps undertaking a module focused on specific data analytical techniques, consumer behavior, or developing a dedicated marketing campaign.  Students will enhance their professional skills through strategic planning, in-depth data analysis, and client interaction simulation.  Modules dedicated to career readiness and professional development are commonly featured in the final year.

Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with 5.5 in each skills area
Entry Requirement: A minimum of a 2:2 undergraduate degree or equivalent is required.  For non-native English speakers, IELTS 6.5 with at least 5.5 in each skill is mandatory.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized university equivalent to at least a UK Upper Second Class (2:1) or Lower Second Class (2:2) is needed.  Those with a two or three-year Bachelor's degree must also have a Master's degree. A four-year Bachelor's degree with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university is also acceptable.
Overview: The University of Derby's MSc Digital Marketing program provides a comprehensive education in digital marketing strategies and techniques within a responsible and ethical framework.  Students develop leadership skills and expertise in areas such as digital transformation, balancing innovation with responsible practices, AI in digital marketing, and data-driven strategies. The curriculum integrates practical experience through industry projects and live briefs, enhancing employability.  The program balances theoretical knowledge with analytical skills, preparing students for the challenges and opportunities of modern digital marketing.
Course Structure: The MSc Digital Marketing program combines theoretical study with practical application. Modules cover various aspects of digital marketing, including innovation and change management, contemporary marketing challenges, digital marketing strategy, strategic brand management, digital marketing campaigns and analytics, and marketing metrics.  Students also undertake independent study projects, including research methods and a dissertation.  Assessment typically includes coursework such as reflective portfolios, reports, case study analysis, and presentations.  The program integrates live projects, guest lectures by experts, and various learning methods including simulations and AI-based learning.
Year 1: The first year of the full-time MSc Digital Marketing program covers core modules such as Digital Innovation and Change Management, Contemporary Marketing Challenges, Digital Marketing Strategy, Strategic Brand Management, Digital Marketing Campaigns & Analytics, and Marketing Metrics. Students are expected to complete independent study projects focusing on research methods. Emphasis is placed on applying theoretical knowledge to practical situations via business improvement projects, and live industry briefs.
Year 2: NA

Course Title: BSc (Hons) Digital Marketing with Placement Year
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 112 UCAS points, A-Levels BBC, T Level Merit, BTEC DMM, GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or equivalent, or a Pass Access to HE Diploma.  International students need IELTS 6.0 with at least 5.5 in each skill.  For Pakistani students, A-levels or IB from Pakistani international schools allow direct entry to Year 1.  Postgraduate entry requires a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK Upper or Lower Second Class Honours, with a Master's degree required if the Bachelor's was two or three years. A four-year Bachelor's with a minimum 2.4/4.0 GPA is considered for Masters entry. PhD applicants need a Master's and Bachelor's in a relevant subject, along with a research proposal.
Overview: The BSc (Hons) Digital Marketing with Placement Year is a four-year undergraduate program accredited by the Chartered Institute of Marketing (CIM).  It focuses on the practical application of digital marketing techniques, covering social media, viral marketing, multi-channel campaigns, content management, online advertising, SEO, mobile marketing, and digital analytics.  The curriculum combines theoretical learning with hands-on experience, including a placement year in a real-world marketing environment. Students learn to use various technologies and techniques, keeping abreast of the latest trends.  The program integrates fundamental marketing principles with digital expertise, fostering strong business and brand management skills.  The CIM accreditation offers exemptions toward the CIM Diploma in Professional Marketing.  The course aims to prepare graduates for immediate entry into various digital marketing roles.
Course Structure: The course integrates theoretical knowledge in marketing, business, and brand management with hands-on practical application of digital marketing techniques.  Students will develop skills in social media engagement, viral marketing, multi-channel campaigns, content management, online advertising, search engine optimisation (SEO), mobile marketing strategies, and digital analytics.  The curriculum includes projects, assessments requiring creation of business profiles, infographics, presentations, and reports. A placement year provides real-world experience, enhancing employability. Guest speakers from marketing agencies and businesses provide industry insights. The program's structure ensures students gain both academic rigor and practical experience sought after by employers.
Year 1: The first year likely provides a foundation in marketing principles, business fundamentals, and introductory modules to digital marketing concepts.  Students are introduced to the core concepts of marketing management, consumer behavior, market research, branding, and potentially some basic digital tools and platforms. It also lays the groundwork for more specialized digital marketing topics in subsequent years.
Year 2: In the second year, students delve deeper into specific digital marketing channels and strategies.  This may include social media marketing, search engine optimization (SEO), content marketing, email marketing, and online advertising.  Students will likely start to develop their skills in using relevant software and tools.  The year may also include modules focused on data analytics and the measurement of digital marketing campaigns.
Year 3: The third year involves a placement year in a real-world marketing setting. This allows students to apply their learned knowledge and skills, gain practical experience, and build their professional network. Students work under supervision of a company thus gaining experience.
Year 4: The final year integrates advanced digital marketing concepts, focusing on strategic planning, campaign management, and data-driven decision-making.  Students may specialize in areas like social media management, digital analytics, or content strategy. This year could feature a significant final project or dissertation showcasing their expertise in digital marketing.

Required IELTS Score: 6.5 (with no less than 5.5 in each component)
Entry Requirement: The Doctorate in Business Administration (DBA) program at the University of Derby requires a master's degree in a relevant field, or a good first degree may be considered as an alternative.  At least three years of professional experience is necessary.  Applicants whose first language is not English must meet the minimum English language proficiency requirement of IELTS 6.5 (with no less than 5.5 in each component).  Those with degrees from the UK or other English-speaking countries may be exempt. All applicants will be interviewed, and admission decisions are based on the application, prior education, interview, professional experience, and research proposal.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized university in Pakistan equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree is required. Students with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees must also hold a Master's degree. A four-year Bachelor's degree with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 may be sufficient.  A research proposal is mandatory for all applicants.
Overview: The Doctorate in Business Administration (DBA) program at the University of Derby is designed for business professionals, managers, and practitioners seeking to advance their careers and contribute to their field. This executive doctoral research degree combines academic rigor with a practical approach, allowing students to conduct impactful research directly relevant to their professional experience. The program focuses on developing high-level research and analysis skills, enabling graduates to critically evaluate, apply existing knowledge, and drive innovative problem-solving within their organizations.  The program emphasizes flexibility to accommodate professional commitments, incorporating short study blocks and work-integrated learning opportunities. The program also provides comprehensive support from academic supervisors and fosters a collaborative research community through peer learning and networking opportunities.
Course Structure: The DBA program is structured in stages.  It begins with a 'Theory for Practice' stage, which involves five core modules including a negotiated applied research project tailored to the student's interest. This stage emphasizes argument construction, critical evaluation, and reflection, enhancing research methodologies and skills.  An optional module allows for an MSc Business and Management Research qualification. The subsequent 'Independent Research Stage' focuses on a practitioner project (PhD thesis) requiring 50,000-60,000 words. This aligns with doctoral progression milestones and culminates in a final viva voce examination. The program involves seminars, practical activities, supervision, tutorials, and work-based learning, enabling participants to engage with advanced critical analysis and refine their problem-solving abilities.
Year 1: The first year of the DBA program focuses on the foundational aspects of research, including module such as 'Introduction to Research' and 'Designing Research Projects'. Students begin building their core research skills, learn argumentative writing, critical evaluation, and refine their analytical abilities. The focus is on developing a solid theoretical base for the research undertaken in later years and laying groundwork for their independent research project.  Students also start familiarizing themselves with different research methodologies and approaches via seminars and practical assignments.  Furthermore, the initial work on their negotiated module builds upon the core research skills and begins to establish their area of expertise.
Year 2: The second year builds upon Year 1, building research skills and delving deeper into the chosen area of practical expertise.  It covers modules such as 'Developing the Professional Self' and 'Communicating your Research'. These modules enhance the knowledge and abilities acquired in the first year, focusing on self-reflection and communication of research findings.  Students continue work on their chosen project and receive guidance from their supervisor. At the end of the second year, students prepare a research progress review which serves as an assessment of their trajectory and helps guide their continued development.
Year 3: Year 3 marks the commencement of the substantial independent research project. Students dedicate a significant portion of their time to the practitioner project (thesis), focusing on a key challenge within their organization or professional domain. Students will receive ongoing support and guidance from their supervisors.  They will design and carry out their research plan, analyze data, interpret findings, and progress towards writing up their thesis. Regular presentations to peers during this stage are encouraged to enable feedback and exchange of ideas within the research community.
Year 4: Year 4 is largely dedicated to finalizing the practitioner project (thesis). Students will complete the writing of their thesis, refine the research arguments, and ensure that it meets the standards for a doctoral-level dissertation. This stage involves extensive literature review, analysis of findings, and writing up a well-structured and well-supported dissertation.  This stage also includes work on practicing the thesis presentation in preparation for the final viva voce examination.

Course Title: PhD Doctorate in Health and Social Care Practice
Entry Requirement: Applicants need a master's or postgraduate degree (or equivalent) in a relevant field and must be a registered or accredited health professional with a relevant regulatory organization.  An IELTS score of at least 6.5 is required if English is not the first language. A research proposal is also necessary, including title page, aims and objectives, background, research problem definition, methods and data analysis outline, potential outcomes, timeline, resources, references, and appendices.  For Pakistani students, a relevant bachelor's degree from a recognized university (equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2) is needed. Those with two- or three-year bachelor's degrees must also have a master's degree. A four-year bachelor's degree with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university is also acceptable.
Overview: The Doctorate in Health and Social Care Practice is a part-time online program designed for health professionals, academics, and leaders in health and social care.  It equips students with advanced research skills and project management expertise to lead practice and service development. The program allows for specialization in various areas such as nursing, occupational therapy, and psychotherapy.  Students will contribute original research to their field, enhancing their professional standing and career prospects. The curriculum is closely aligned with industry needs, ensuring relevance and responsiveness to changes in policy and practice.
Course Structure: The program comprises a postgraduate taught (PGT) phase and a postgraduate research (PGR) phase. The PGT phase involves two 60-credit modules completed over the first two years.  The PGR phase, spanning the remaining two years, focuses on an Independent Scholarship (420 credits), where students conduct original research under the guidance of a director of studies and a supervisor.  Students are encouraged to engage in research groups to foster collaboration and networking within their field. Assessment methods include written assignments, project reports, research dissemination, a thesis, and a viva voce examination.
Year 1: Year one involves the completion of the first of two 60-credit modules in the postgraduate taught (PGT) phase. Students will be introduced to core research methodologies, learn to formulate research questions, and will begin developing fundamental research and analytical skills.  The modules are delivered online through a virtual learning environment with a mix of synchronous sessions (webinars) and asynchronous learning.
Year 2: The second year involves completing the second 60-credit module from the postgraduate taught phase. Building on the foundation laid in year one, this year will focus on advanced skills and knowledge specifically within their chosen research area.  Students continue to engage with online course materials, participate in webinars, and collaborate within their respective specialism groups.
Year 3: Year three marks the start of the postgraduate research (PGR) phase, comprising the 420-credit Independent Scholarship.  Students dedicate this year to refining their research proposal, conducting literature review, data collection and analysis.  Regular meetings with their director of studies and supervisor provide ongoing guidance and support throughout the research process.
Year 4: The final year focuses on completing the Independent Scholarship. Students concentrate on writing and refinement of their thesis, responding to feedback from their supervisors.  The year culminates with the viva voce examination, a discussion of their research and its findings with their examiners.

Course Title: Professional Doctorate in Sport and Exercise
Entry Requirement: Applicants typically need a master's degree in a sport and exercise-related field, along with two to three years of relevant professional experience.  They must demonstrate how the program aligns with their professional and personal goals.  English language proficiency is required; IELTS 7.5 or equivalent is needed if English isn't the applicant's first language.  For Pakistani students, a relevant bachelor's degree from a recognized university (equivalent to a UK Upper or Lower Second Class degree) is necessary.  Those with two or three-year bachelor's degrees also need a master's degree.  A four-year bachelor's degree with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university is considered for entry. A research proposal is a mandatory part of the application for all students.
Overview: The Doctorate in Professional Practice (Sport and Exercise) is an online program designed to enhance professional practice through applied research.  It caters to sport and exercise practitioners seeking to improve their skills and understanding of their field.  The course focuses on developing advanced research methodologies, including ethnography, action research, and case studies, to explore and critique professional practices. Students will refine their research questions and design, addressing ethical considerations. The program culminates in a doctoral thesis, contributing original knowledge to the field. The program emphasizes professional development, with support from an experienced teaching team and access to online learning resources allowing practitioners to combine cohort-based learning with independent research.
Course Structure: The program consists of a postgraduate taught (PGT) phase and a postgraduate research (PGR) phase. The PGT phase involves two 60-credit modules focusing on developing research skills and refining research questions.  The first module explores relevant literature, while the second module delves into research design, methods, and ethical considerations.  The PGR phase involves an independent 420-credit research project, guided by a supervisory team, leading to the submission of a doctoral thesis and viva voce examination.  The program utilizes online learning, including virtual learning environments, webinars, tutorials, and online discussion forums to foster learning and provide support using a coaching-based approach and utilizing communities of practice.
Year 1: Year one of the Doctorate in Professional Practice program involves the first 60-credit module. This module focuses on developing essential research skills and beginning the process of selecting a research area appropriate for a PhD. The module combines self-study with interactive engagement in a virtual learning environment. Students begin to explore the existing literature in their chosen discipline and refine their research ideas. Students will be encouraged to reflect upon their progression and their evolving understanding of the subject and of the methodology and techniques involved.
Year 2: The second year covers the second 60-credit module and additional work on the research project. The second 60-credit module involves refining the research question and design, critically considering methodology, methods, and the ethics surrounding the research topic.  Students will also be encouraged to reflect on the researcher-practitioner identity which develops as they progress through the research process.  In the second year, students will likely begin collecting data for their research project.
Year 3: Year three is mostly focused on the research for the doctoral thesis, a major component of the PhD, comprising 420 credits in total. Students work independently under the guidance of their doctoral supervisory team, conducting research, collecting and analyzing data, and drafting the thesis.  The year also includes continued engagement in the online cohort and Communities of Practice (COPs).
Year 4: Year four involves completing the 420-credit research thesis. Students continue meeting with their supervisors, revising the thesis based on feedback, and preparing for the viva voce (oral examination). Support continues to be available through the communities of practice and the postgraduate research development program offered by the university.  The thesis is submitted, and the viva voce examination is undertaken, concluding the doctoral study if successful.  Years five and six may be available to extend the research if necessary.

Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with a minimum of 5.5 in all areas
Entry Requirement: A master's degree in a relevant field and at least two years of professional experience are typically required.  High English language proficiency is necessary, often demonstrated with an IELTS score of 6.5.  A comprehensive research proposal is a crucial part of the application, outlining the research question, methodology, ethical considerations, and expected contributions to knowledge. The proposal should clearly identify a gap in existing research.  Pakistan-specific requirements are not explicitly detailed on the provided webpage but generally include a relevant bachelor's degree (equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2) and may require a master's degree for those with shorter bachelor's degrees.  A minimum GPA of 2.4/4.0 from a recognized Pakistani university may also be considered.
Overview: The Doctor of Education (EdD) program is designed for professionals in various sectors, including education, public service, and industry, seeking to enhance their research skills and make significant contributions to their fields. This part-time, online program focuses on developing a substantial research project directly relevant to the student's professional practice. Students will gain expertise in research methodologies and critical thinking, leading to improved professional practice and career advancement.  The program is highly flexible, accommodating personal commitments with a minimum registration period of four years and a maximum of eight.
Course Structure: The EdD program is structured into a taught phase and an independent research phase.  The first two years focus on building skills and confidence in doctoral-level study and research through modules and interactive learning. This includes an analysis of practitioner research and a reflective literature review. The extended essay covers research methodology, ethics, and contemporary philosophical debates. Years three and four involve a significant independent research project resulting in a professionally researched thesis which concludes with a viva voce examination.  The program is delivered entirely online, blending self-study with asynchronous interactions and live tutorials.
Year 1: The first year of the EdD program at the University of Derby focuses on building foundational skills needed for more advanced doctoral research. While no specific modules were cited by name, you should expect an introduction and foundational preparation related to the research process, this would include learning styles, academic rigor, writing styles and the research proposal process.
Year 2: Year two continues the structured teaching and development of research-related skills. Students will expand on their research process while developing and strengthening specific research skills to prepare for the thesis in the following years.  The focus here would be further development and honing of skills obtained throughout the first year's introduction.
Year 3: Year three marks the commencement of the independent research phase.  Students will begin fully working on their Professional Research for Practice module and conducting their research projects. The student's individual research will require the dedicated time and effort of a full year's work. Consistent consultation with advisors is part of this stage and this year is largely independent study.
Year 4: The final year of the program culminates in the completion of the student's thesis. This year requires the student to produce a full-length thesis that will be reviewed and defended for graduation by a committee of advisors and experts in the student's field.

Entry Requirement: Applicants usually need a master's degree in a relevant field and at least two years of professional experience.  High English proficiency is required (IELTS 6.5). A detailed research proposal is mandatory, including a working title, research questions, aims, literature review demonstrating a gap in existing research, proposed methodology, data collection and analysis methods, ethical considerations, and the benefits the research will bring.  The application process is competitive, and all suitable applicants are interviewed. For Pakistani students, a relevant bachelor's degree from a recognized university (equivalent to a UK Upper or Lower Second Class degree), or a four-year bachelor's degree with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00, is required.  Those with two or three year bachelor's degrees also need a Master's degree. A research proposal must be submitted.
Overview: The University of Derby's online Doctor of Education (EdD) program is designed for professionals in various sectors, including education, public service, and industry.  It focuses on developing high-caliber research skills through independent study, allowing participants to generate new insights relevant to their professional roles and the broader education community. The program emphasizes a structured approach to doctoral-level study, combining self-study with online interactions, such as discussions and tutorials.  The course balances academic rigor with practical application, allowing students to conduct research directly relevant to their workplace, improving practices and fostering career advancement. The program is taught by research-active tutors, ensuring students are exposed to cutting-edge educational research and developments.
Course Structure: The EdD program is a part-time online course structured over four to six years with a maximum registration period of eight years. It comprises a taught phase in the first two years, followed by an independent research phase to complete a thesis.  The taught phase involves completing two 60-credit modules per year. The final two years consist of an independent research project (420 credits).  Assessment methods vary beyond standard essays to encompass tasks that enable students to articulate their expertise, including analysis of practitioner research, a literature review, an extended essay justifying the chosen research methodology, and a viva voce examination of the thesis. The academic year includes three ten-week trimesters requiring approximately 20 hours of weekly study for each 20-credit trimester.
Year 1: Year one of the EdD program focuses on building foundational skills for doctoral-level study and research. Students complete two 60-credit modules that equip them with the necessary knowledge and competencies to engage with academic literature and conduct preliminary research in their chosen area. This might involve exploring research methodologies, reviewing relevant literature, and developing research plans. The modules are delivered entirely online, and students benefit from instructor-led tutorials and peer interaction facilitated via online forums. This initial year sets the stage for more advanced research and writing pursuits in subsequent years.
Year 2: The second year continues to build upon the skills and knowledge acquired in the first year. Students undertake two further 60-credit modules. They further refine their chosen research area, potentially delving deeper into specific methodologies, theoretical frameworks, or practical application approaches.  The curriculum further supports development in critical thinking and research design, encouraging students to refine their thinking and analysis skills. The interactive elements, such as online seminars and one-on-one tutoring, remain integral for providing consistent feedback and facilitating collaborative learning.
Year 3: Year three marks the transition to the major independent research project. Students dedicate this year to focusing on their research, building upon their skills in reviewing literature, conducting research using appropriate methods, and analyzing data collected from their study. They will work closely with their allocated supervisor to develop an understanding of critical analysis, to refine their research questions, data collection and analysis methods to ensure strong results in the completion of the thesis.  Individual tutorials offer essential direction in progressing the thesis as well as thought-provoking group seminars enhancing the experience.
Year 4: The final year, which can extend up to eight years in total, involves completing the thesis and undergoing a viva voce examination.  This year requires significant dedication to data analysis, interpretation, and the final written submission of the thesis.  Students will work closely with their supervisors for guidance and receive ongoing feedback about their progression.  The viva voce examination provides important feedback and highlights areas of understanding and improvement.   Upon successful completion, students have made a substantial, demonstrable contribution to their field.

Required IELTS Score: 7.0 with 6.5 in each individual skill area
Entry Requirement: Applicants need a relevant undergraduate degree (e.g., BA (Hons) Drama, Theatre Arts, Creative Expressive Arts, Health and Wellbeing) or a degree/training in psychology, occupational therapy, social work, or nursing with evidence of theatre experience.  One year of full-time (or equivalent) relevant work experience in a health and social care environment is usually required (paid or voluntary).  Sufficient life experience and emotional maturity are essential. If English isn't your first language, you'll need to meet HCPC's English language standards (IELTS 7.0 with 6.5 in each skill or equivalent). A Disclosure and Barring Service (DBS) check is required upon acceptance.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized university, equivalent to a UK Upper Second Class (2:1) or Lower Second Class (2:2), is needed.  A Master's degree is also required if the Bachelor's degree is two or three years. A four-year Bachelor's degree with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university will also be considered.
Overview: The MA Dramatherapy program at the University of Derby is a two-year, full-time course designed to equip students with the theoretical knowledge and practical skills needed to become registered dramatherapists.  The curriculum integrates theoretical understanding of psychological processes with the practical application of dramatherapy techniques.  Students engage in clinical placements, personal therapy, research, and reflective practice to develop comprehensive competency and self-awareness in the field. The program is approved by the Health and Care Professions Council (HCPC), allowing graduates to apply for registration upon successful completion, provided they fulfill additional HCPC requirements.  The curriculum emphasizes the use of improvisation and adaptation of interventions to individual and group therapeutic needs. The course integrates work with various client populations, and students are supported with supervision and group learning, thereby fostering both professional and personal development.
Course Structure: The MA Dramatherapy program comprises several modules, beginning with a Postgraduate Certificate and then proceeding to a Postgraduate Diploma and finally the Master's level.  The Postgraduate Certificate includes modules on Dramatherapy Studio Practice, Art Therapies Theory and Research in Relation to Practice One, and Dramatherapy Clinical Placement One. The Postgraduate Diploma builds upon this foundation with modules on Dramatherapy Experiential Group, Art Therapies Theory and Research in Relation to Practice Two, and Dramatherapy Clinical Placement Two. Finally, the MA level culminates in a significant piece of independent arts-based research (Arts Therapies Independent Scholarship: A Body of Work), presented through a solo performance, written critique, and viva voce examination.  Throughout the program, students undertake clinical placements and engage in a minimum of 72 sessions of personal therapy.  The program also includes guest lectures, workshops and coursework in the form of written reflections, case studies, presentations, and literature reviews.
Year 1: The first year of the MA Dramatherapy program focuses on foundational knowledge and skills in dramatherapy. This foundation includes theoretical frameworks, research methodologies relevant to art therapies, and clinical practice. Students will practice dramatherapy in both studio and placement settings. The first year concludes with a theoretical underpinning developed and a range of techniques learned in practical placement settings.
Year 2: The second year of the program builds upon the groundwork established in the first year. Students engage in more advanced theoretical study and clinical practice, focusing on specialized areas of dramatherapy and expanding their understanding of art therapies.  A major component of the second year is the completion of the Independent Scholarship, an original arts-based research project involving a solo performance, written critique, and a viva voce examination. This showcases students' skills in research, creative expression, and critical analysis within dramatherapy.

Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with a minimum of 5.5 in all areas
Entry Requirement: A first degree or equivalent with academic and/or clinical competencies to work at a master's level is required.  Applicants must also be professionally registered, working as a healthcare professional (radiographer, technologist, nurse, or doctor) in a bone densitometry service, with a mentor's support to sign off the portfolio.  Completion of appropriate IRMER training and the ROS (previously NOS) National Training Scheme for Bone Densitometry, or the Postgraduate Certificate in Osteoporosis and Falls Management, or an equivalent qualification, is mandatory. A reference confirming suitability for master's-level study and written confirmation of mentor support are also needed.  The mentor must be currently reporting DXA scans, including treatment recommendations.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognised university equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree is necessary.  Those with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees need a Master's degree pass. A Bachelor's degree with honours (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University is also acceptable for entry into a Master's degree.
Overview: The Level 7 DXA Reporting for Clinicians course is designed for experienced healthcare professionals working in osteoporosis or DXA services who are currently reporting on or about to commence reporting on DXA scans.  The course aims to equip participants with the skills and knowledge to consistently and independently report on DXA scans, adhering to national and local clinical governance procedures.  The curriculum covers a wide range of topics, including normal and osteoporotic appearances on DXA images; clinical risk factors affecting BMD; artefacts and confounding factors; vertebral fracture assessment; treatment thresholds and protocols; interpreting changes in DXA results over time; quantitative and semi-quantitative vertebral fracture assessment; common pitfalls in interpreting DXA scan results; and radiation protection and IRMER.  The course emphasizes a systematic approach to reporting BMD and VFA results, improving patient management in line with national guidance.  Participants will develop a reflective portfolio and undergo an assessment including an examination and assignment.
Course Structure: The course consists of a minimum of two study days on campus and three online study evenings. These sessions will include keynote lectures, case study discussions, and viewing of scan sessions.  Participants will develop a reflective portfolio independently reporting on BMD results, commenting on normal variants, artefacts, and image appearances, along with treatment recommendations aligned with local protocols.  A crucial component is an audit comparing participants' reports with those of a trained practitioner. The portfolio also requires detailed reflective practice and sign off by a mentor.  Finally, participants will also sit an examination and submit an assignment focusing on Vertebral Fracture Assessment.  This module forms part of the Bone Densitometry Reporting PGCert.
Year 1: NA
Year 2: NA
Career Opportunity 5: Healthcare Professional in Bone Densitometry Service

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: Applicants require a foundation degree passed with grades above 50% and 240 credits.  At least five GCSEs (or equivalent) including Maths and English at grade 4/C or above are also needed.  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or the International Baccalaureate from International Schools in Pakistan, entry into the first year is possible.  The University of Derby also guarantees an interview for its PGCE Primary course upon completion of this degree provided entry requirements for the PGCE are met.
Overview: The BA (Hons) Early Childhood Studies (Top-Up) at the University of Derby is a one-year (full-time) or two-year (part-time) program designed to equip students with the skills and knowledge for rewarding careers working with young children. The curriculum explores child development from birth to eight years, focusing on meeting children's holistic needs.  Students benefit from practical placements, expert teaching, access to excellent facilities, and a supportive learning environment.   The course emphasizes professional development and includes opportunities for students to participate in research initiatives.  Graduates are well-prepared for various roles in health, education, and social care settings.
Course Structure: The course structure emphasizes practical experience alongside theoretical understanding of early childhood development.  Students engage in lectures, seminars, tutorials, and group work. Assessment methods include case studies, essays, independent research, online tests, posters, presentations, and reports. There are no exams.  A significant portion of the program involves a placement, providing students with hands-on experience working with young children. The modules are regularly reviewed to ensure their relevance and to enhance graduate employability. The curriculum integrates several key areas, including child development, educational practices, social care, professional skills development and practice, and theoretical frameworks for understanding childhood.
Year 1: The first year of the BA (Hons) Early Childhood Studies (Top-Up) focuses on building a strong foundation in early childhood development theory and practice. Students delve into the various stages of child development, examining physical, cognitive, social, emotional, and moral growth. Key topics will include the theories and principles of early childhood education, understanding and implementing inclusive practices, and building effective relationships with families and communities. The year also includes an introduction to professional practice, with students gaining practical skills through hands-on experiences, placements, and case studies.
Year 2: NA

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with 5.5 in each skills test)
Entry Requirement: Applicants need either a HND or Foundation Degree in a relevant subject (equivalent to 240 credits). Significant work and life experience may be considered, requiring at least 60 credits at levels 4 and 5 in a relevant subject.  Exemptions are possible based on prior academic study, professional qualifications, or experience.  Recognition of Prior Learning (RPL) allows for credit transfer.  If English isn't your first language, you'll need an IELTS score of 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skill) or equivalent qualifications such as Cambridge English Scale: B2,  International GCE O-Level English Language: Grade C,  International GCSE English/English as a Second Language: Grade C, Functional Skills Level 2 English, or 12 English Language credits at Level 2 from a pre-2014 Access to HE Diploma. For Pakistani students,  A-levels or the International Baccalaureate (IB) from International Schools in Pakistan allow entry.  Those with a relevant Bachelor’s degree equivalent to a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree may be eligible.  Two or three-year Bachelor's degree holders may need a Master's degree pass. A four-year Bachelor's degree with honours (minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00) from a recognised Pakistani university may also suffice.
Overview: The University of Derby's online BA (Hons) Early Childhood Studies (Top-Up) is designed for those with a Level 5 qualification working in early childhood settings.  The program deepens knowledge of early childhood studies to meet the needs of integrated care and education for children from birth to eight years. It's structured for flexibility, suitable for individuals juggling work and family.  Taught by expert academics, the curriculum integrates theory and practice, focusing on child development, learning, and critical reflection. Students benefit from collaborative online learning, enhancing professional development planning (PDP). The course prepares students for leadership roles in diverse settings, including social care, health, and education.
Course Structure: The course consists of five core modules: Child protection; Contesting childhood; Leadership in early childhood education and care; The critically reflective practitioner; and Independent study.  The curriculum is designed to provide a cohesive understanding of early childhood studies from a multi-disciplinary perspective, combining theory and practical application. Modules are regularly reviewed and updated to ensure relevance and high professional standards.  Assessment is 100% coursework-based, employing diverse methods like essays, reports, presentations, group work, and practical reports.
Year 1: NA
Year 2: NA

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical UCAS points are 104, equivalent to BCC at A-Level, Merit in T Level, DMM in BTEC, or a Pass in Access to HE Diploma with 60 credits (45 at Level 3).  GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or above are also required. An Enhanced Disclosure & Barring Service (DBS) check is mandatory.  For students from Pakistan who have completed A-Levels or the International Baccalaureate from International Schools in Pakistan, entry into the first year is possible. Students with other qualifications should contact the university.
Overview: The University of Derby's BA (Hons) Early Childhood Studies is a three-year (full-time) undergraduate program designed to prepare students for rewarding careers in health, education, and social care.  The curriculum focuses on holistic child development from birth to eight years, exploring theories of learning, child development milestones, and the needs of children across diverse backgrounds and contexts. Students will combine theoretical learning with significant practical experience through placements in various settings. The program emphasizes critical reflection, inclusion, and advocacy for children's rights.  Graduates will gain employable skills and potentially further qualifications like a Paediatric First Aid Certificate. The course aims to cultivate forward-thinking, reflective practitioners who are well-prepared for entry into this dynamic field.  There are options for students to choose a route with practitioner status.
Course Structure: The BA (Hons) Early Childhood Studies program is structured across three years, with various modules focusing on child development, the theory and practice of early childhood education, and related fields of social care and health.  The curriculum incorporates theoretical learning with extensive practical experience through placements in educational, social care, and health settings. There is flexibility to tailor the curriculum to personal interests by selecting optional modules. This structure promotes a strong foundation in early childhood theory, development, and practice, ultimately enabling graduates to meet the Early Childhood Graduate Practitioner Competencies.
Year 1: The first year introduces foundational knowledge in early childhood development, encompassing such areas as child psychology, pedagogy, and the policies and regulatory frameworks governing early years education and care.  Students will begin developing practical skills and understanding through introductory placement experiences, building a basis for future specialization and advanced study.  The emphasis is on building a solid understanding of theoretical concepts and early applications of those concepts
Year 2: The second year delves more deeply into specialist areas within early childhood studies. Students will further develop their understanding of curriculum planning, assessment, and implementation within diverse settings. Building on prior experience, they'll expand their practical skills through extended placement experiences, allowing them to apply theory and practice while working directly with children and families. Modules might include specific themes aligned with personal career aspirations
Year 3: The final year focuses on advanced study and specialization within the field of early childhood studies. Students will have opportunities to complete a significant research project, which can contribute greatly to their professional portfolio. Advanced placement experiences provide the opportunity for students to gain practical experience and assess professional skills to further develop their professional profiles. The emphasis shifts towards independent study and critical reflection

Course Title: BA (Hons) Early Childhood Studies with Foundation Year
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For entry in 2025, typical requirements include 72 UCAS points, DDD at A-Level, a pass in T Level or BTEC MMP, and a pass in the Access to HE Diploma with specific credit and grade requirements. GCSEs in Maths and English are preferred but not mandatory; if lacking, Level 2 Maths and English can be undertaken alongside the course.  An Enhanced Disclosure & Barring Service (DBS) check is required.  For Pakistani students, those completing A-Levels or the IB from International Schools in Pakistan can begin directly in Year 1.
Overview: The BA (Hons) Early Childhood Studies with Foundation Year is a four-year undergraduate program designed to prepare students for careers working with young children.  The program offers a comprehensive understanding of child development, learning, and thinking from birth to eight years old, covering holistic needs and challenges faced by early years professionals. Students will develop professional skills and knowledge through coursework, and a significant amount of hands-on, practical experience from placement in various settings such as nurseries and children's centers. The program also integrates opportunities for extra qualifications and international experiences to boost employability. The foundation year provides support for students who may not meet the standard entry requirements for the full honors degree.
Course Structure:
The course incorporates a foundation year followed by three years of the honours degree program.  The curriculum includes lectures, seminars, tutorials, and practical work placements, which occupy one or two days per week starting from the first year. Learning is enhanced through field trips to museums and potential overseas placements.  Assessment methods vary from coursework in the foundation year and other year to case studies, essays, independent research, online tests, posters, presentations, and reports with no exams.
Students can tailor their studies through optional modules covering diverse topics such as children's literature, family dynamics, health and inequality, child protection, and children across the world. Specific modules are subject to change but can include topics like professional and personal development, creativity for early years professionals, and social constructions of childhood. Students have opportunities to participate in research initiatives, potentially even contributing to published works.
Year 1: The first year, which is the foundation year, provides a solid grounding in essential skills and knowledge. Students who may have lack of formal qualifications are supported to gain sufficient academic and professional skills while building confidence. Assessments are primarily coursework-based, along with some in-class tests.
Year 2: Year two begins the main BA (Hons) Early Childhood Studies program. Students start their work placement learning in practical settings for one or two days a week while undertaking relevant modules.  Along with theoretical study, students develop observation and reflective skills. The specific modules covered will depend on the optional choices made by students.
Year 3: Year three further develops core skills and knowledge in early childhood studies. Students are expected to continue and possibly increase the hours at their placements. With a wider variety of module choices, students can specialise according to their interests. Students build upon skills learned in previous years, deepening understanding of child development through practical experience and in-depth study.
Year 4: The final year of the program focuses on developing specialist knowledge and skills, culminating in a final project or dissertation. Students complete more complex assignments, expanding their capabilities in independent research and analysis. Placements continue and may involve different placements while students can broaden their skills and qualifications, through participation in relevant workshops and training.

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement:
For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 120 UCAS points.  A-Level students need BBB grades, with at least a C in Geology, Geography, or Environmental Science; other sciences and maths are considered.  T Level students need a Merit in Science; BTEC students need DDM; and Access to HE Diploma requires a pass with 60 credits (45 at Level 3, minimum Distinction: 15, Merit: 24, Pass: 6) including passes in compulsory Level 3 subjects. GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or equivalent are needed.  Contextual offers may apply to care experienced students, those estranged from families, refugees, asylum seekers, or those whose parents/carers are in the UK armed forces.  

For Pakistani students, A-levels or IB from Pakistani international schools allow entry into Year 1. Postgraduate entry requires a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK Upper or Lower Second Class Honours degree. Two or three-year Bachelor's degrees necessitate a Master's pass. A four-year Bachelor's with a minimum 2.4/4.0 GPA from a recognised Pakistani university is considered for Master's entry. PhD applicants need Master's and Bachelor's degrees in relevant subjects and a research proposal.
Overview: The University of Derby's BSc (Hons) Earth Sciences program provides a comprehensive understanding of Earth processes, encompassing geology, geography, climatology, hydrology, and related sciences.  Students develop practical skills through fieldwork, laboratory work, and the use of cutting-edge technology, preparing them for careers in a growing Earth Science job sector.  The curriculum emphasizes sustainability, incorporating the UN's Sustainable Development Goals and addressing challenges like climate change and resource management.  Graduates possess strong analytical, problem-solving, and communication skills, applicable across diverse careers. The course integrates research-led learning, exposing students to cutting-edge knowledge and skills. Practical activities and industry engagement play a crucial role, ensuring graduates are work-ready and equipped to tackle real-world challenges.
Course Structure: The Earth Sciences BSc (Hons) curriculum is structured to provide a broad foundation in geoscience principles and specialization in areas such as volcanology, hydrogeology, geophysics, paleontology, climatology, and more.  It is a three-year full-time program with modules spread across three years.  Students learn through lectures, laboratory practicals, tutorials, computer classes using industry software, and field trips across the Peak District and further afield.  Extensive fieldwork is an integral part, training students in essential practices like mapping, surveying, coring and water quality analysis.  Specific module names may vary, but an applied and holistic approach to learning is maintained across the program.  Assessment methods are diverse, including presentations, report writing, data recording, computer modelling, and mapping, to prepare students for the real world of work.
Year 1: The first year likely establishes a foundation in fundamental Earth science principles covering topics like physical geology, mineralogy, stratigraphy, structural geology, geomorphology, introductory hydrology, and fundamental geochemistry or environmental chemistry. Introductory, skills-based sessions on mapping, data analysis, and presentation may also be covered. Students are introduced to a variety of fieldwork techniques through day and local field trips, which can incorporate aspects of geology mapping, basic geophysics and hydrology. These early practical elements help build a strong foundation for more advanced coursework.
Year 2: The second year builds on this foundation by building a more detailed understanding of Earth processes through specific modules.  This is where students are likely to undertake more detailed fieldwork, allowing them to combine analytical data, and field experiences. Examples might include modules on sedimentary geology, igneous and metamorphic petrology, geochronology, geophysics, further detailed Hydrology such as groundwater modeling, and advanced mapping techniques. Advanced practical skills are also typically built in second year modules, including the use of several industry-standard software packages.
Year 3: The final year is dedicated to specialized modules and significant research projects. Students would typically focus on topics reflecting their chosen area of expertise, this can include modules on global environmental change impacting climate, water resources and natural hazards. In parallel, advanced analytical and modelling skills will be taught and may be applied within a final-year research project.  Students are given the opportunity to undertake a significant field study, usually a residential fieldwork course lasting several days. These projects allow students to integrate the knowledge and skills learned throughout the course. This year commonly culminates in a dissertation or final year project.

Course Title: Undergraduate Earth Sciences with Foundation Year BSc (Hons)
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 80 UCAS points.  A-Level students need DDD, with at least one in Geology, Geography, or Environmental Science (other sciences and mathematics considered).  T Level requires a pass in Science, BTEC needs MMP, and Access to HE Diploma needs 60 credits (45 at Level 3, minimum Distinction: 0, Merit: 24, Pass: 21). GCSE Maths and English are preferred.  Students from Pakistan studying A-levels or IB from international schools can start in Year 1; those with a relevant 4-year Bachelor's degree (BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) and a minimum 2.4/4.0 GPA are considered for entry.  Postgraduate applicants need a recognised Bachelor's degree equivalent to at least a UK 2:1 or 2:2; those with 2 or 3 year degrees need a Master's degree pass.  PhD applicants need a Master's and Bachelor's in relevant subjects, plus a research proposal.
Overview: The Earth Sciences with Foundation Year BSc (Hons) is a four-year undergraduate program focusing on the Earth's systems and their relation to societal challenges.  Students will gain a multidisciplinary understanding of geology, geography, chemistry, biology, and physics, applying this knowledge to issues like climate change, natural resource management, and sustainable development. The course involves practical fieldwork, laboratory work, data analysis, and theoretical learning, preparing graduates for careers in various geoscience sectors.  The foundation year provides extra support and strengthens skills before the main degree program.
Course Structure: The course integrates practical fieldwork, laboratory sessions, data analysis and interpretation, and theoretical learning. Students will explore subjects such as mineralogy, petrology, structural geology, geochemistry, geophysics, sedimentology, paleontology, and environmental geology. They'll also study the applications of earth science knowledge for sustainable development, environmental management, hazard mitigation, and resource exploration; topics include climate science, critical mineral exploration, carbon sequestration, and green energy technologies. The program includes both theoretical learning and practical application through day and residential field trips. Students develop essential field skills such as mapping and data interpretation.
Year 1: The first year, a foundation year, focuses on building a solid base in relevant scientific and mathematical principles,  developing core skills and knowledge that will be beneficial throughout the degree program. It offers extra support if students are changing career paths.  Study might include introductory modules in mathematics, physics, chemistry, and earth system processes, along with practical skills workshops and laboratory work.
Year 2: Second-year modules build upon the foundation year, delving deeper into earth science concepts. Students typically take more advanced courses in geology, geochemistry, geophysics, and environmental sciences. They will learn and apply techniques of data analysis, interpretation, and visualization, possibly focusing in areas such as mineralogy and volcanic processes or sedimentary geology.  Field trips and practical laboratory work remain central aspects of learning.
Year 3: The third year provides students with more specialized knowledge and advanced field and laboratory techniques.  There's greater freedom in module selection, permitting specialization based on career interest. Subjects might include specific aspects of geophysics, structural geology, hydrogeology, or environmental change. This year will involve longer field trips and potentially an industry-relevant project.
Year 4: The final year offers opportunities for independent research projects in their own area of specialism and development of professional skills. Module choices can include more advanced topics like plate tectonics, geochronology, ore deposits, petroleum geology, or a dissertation-type final project in partnership with a relevant industry.  There is a strong focus on integrating knowledge and producing a final piece that reflects the acquired skills.

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 120 UCAS points, A Levels (BBB), T Levels (Merit), BTECs (DDM), or an Access to HE Diploma.  GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or equivalent are also needed.  International students require an IELTS score of 6.0 with at least 5.5 in each skill area.  Contextual offers may be available for students from disadvantaged backgrounds, including care leavers, estranged students, refugees, asylum seekers, or those whose parents are in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or IB from international schools in Pakistan, direct entry into the first year is possible. Overview: The University of Derby's BSc (Hons) Economics and Finance is a practical, applied degree accredited by the Chartered Institution for Securities and Investment (CISI). Students gain hands-on experience through live consultancy projects, research with businesses, and work in the Financial Markets Lab, which utilizes Bloomberg data. Course Structure: The course structure is modular, with assessments varying across the three years. Year 1 may include introductory modules covering economic principles, financial markets and mathematics. Year 2 likely involves more specialized courses incorporating quantitative analysis, econometrics, and further advanced modules building upon Year 1 knowledge. Year 3 focuses on research and consultancy skills, culminating in an applied economics project involving a live business project.  While specific modules change regularly, the overall emphasis remains in developing practical analytic abilities in economics and finance, in parallel with professional certification preparations.
Year 1: The first year introduces fundamental concepts in economics and finance.  Students will likely develop foundational knowledge in microeconomics, macroeconomics, introductory statistics, and possibly financial accounting.  Quantitative skills are developed through introductory mathematical and statistical methods.  The curriculum also introduces students to financial markets and essential concepts concerning company finance, giving a wide-ranging overview of the main topics related to the field.
Year 2: Building on foundational understanding from the first year, the second year explores more specialised topics.  Students deepen their quantitative skills using econometric methods, advancing their programming and data analysis skills to analyze real economic data.
