Overview: The online MA Education (Leadership and Management) is designed for those in education settings seeking to enhance leadership and management skills.  It explores key theories, policies, and practices shaping modern education, allowing students to tailor their studies to their interests. The program does not lead to Qualified Teacher Status (QTS) but equips graduates with skills for more senior roles and enhanced professional practice. Students analyze their leadership practices, critically assess existing literature, and improve their understanding of leadership in various contexts.  The program uses a flexible online format and offers support resources for balance in studying while working.
Course Structure: The MA requires six 20-credit modules and a 60-credit independent study, totaling 180 credits.  Core modules include: Designing Social Research, Leadership and Management Strategies, and Developing Leadership Capacity. Three additional optional 20-credit modules are chosen to complete the program. The Independent Study module is a major research project or academic paper. Modules are delivered online through a virtual learning environment, incorporating virtual classrooms, tutorials, guest lectures, and online discussion forums. The program includes study skills resources to support students in postgraduate-level study.  Assessment is entirely through coursework: formative and summative assessments (written assignments, project reports, presentations, and portfolios).

Students can choose to study specific pathways such as Early Childhood, TESOL, Leadership and Management, or Inclusion and Special Educational Needs and Disability. Optional modules cater to various areas of education, including comparative education, curriculum challenges, educational policy, and leadership strategies, allowing for customization based on organizational needs and student interests.  Assessment methods vary, including essays, presentations, and portfolios, directly relevant to learners' educational practice and personal development.
Year 1: NA

Required TOEFL Score: 87 (minimum 20 in Speaking and 19 in all other elements)
Entry Requirement: A good undergraduate degree (2.2 or above) or an equivalent level 6 qualification is usually required.  Overseas qualifications will be verified by NARIC.  A CV/resume detailing academic and work experience is also necessary.  An interview may be conducted to assess the relevance of work and life experiences.  If English is not your first language, an English language qualification is needed, such as an IELTS score of 6.5 or equivalent, TOEFL 87, Pearson Test of Academic English 71, Cambridge English 184, or equivalent qualifications.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized university in Pakistan is required, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree.  A Masters degree may be required in addition to a two or three-year Bachelor's degree.  A Bachelor’s degree with honors (four year) with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani University is acceptable for entry to a Masters degree.
Overview: The University of Derby's online MA Education is designed for professionals in education seeking to enhance their expertise or advance their careers.  It's not a teaching qualification but helps refine professional practice. Students can choose a broad-based master's or specialize in leadership and management, or teaching English to speakers of other languages. The program explores key theories, policies, and practices shaping modern education, allowing students to tailor their studies to their interests.  Assessments primarily consist of coursework, including a substantial independent study project focusing on a chosen professional practice theme. Strong emphasis is placed on applying theoretical knowledge to practical scenarios.  The program prioritizes flexibility for working professionals.
Course Structure: The MA Education comprises six 20-credit modules and a 60-credit independent study, totaling 180 credits.  Two compulsory modules are: Designing Social Research and Independent Study.  Five optional 20-credit modules selected from various specializations are also required. While a full master's degree is encouraged, it is possible to complete a Postgraduate Certificate in Education Studies (60 credits) within one year if unable to commit to the full course.  Modules change regularly to enhance student experience and graduate prospects.

Overview: The BA (Hons) Education Studies (Top-Up) is a one-to-two-year program designed for those holding foundation degrees who aim to complete a full honors degree.  It provides a broad understanding of education from early years to lifelong learning, preparing students for careers in teaching or wider educational roles. The course emphasizes social equality and features international learning opportunities and specialist pathways.  Students benefit from a focus on educational equality, integrating perspectives from history, psychology, sociology, and philosophy. It explores the role of education in society, analyzing current policies and practices through an intellectually stimulating curriculum.   Teaching is by leading researchers and published authors, covering inclusion, diversity, social equality, online learning, and pastoral care.
Course Structure: The curriculum builds on prior knowledge and skills from foundation-degree level study and work experience.  It analyzes various elements of the modern education world, including early years education and lifelong learning.  Specific module details are subject to change, with regular content review to improve learning and graduate prospects. The program includes opportunities for outdoor learning, applying education principles in outdoor settings to improve children's skills.  A mandatory placement module (Level 5) is included, with further pathway options such as TESOL and SEND. The course culminates in an end-of-year symposium where students present future plans and career aspirations.
Year 1: The first year of study covers foundational concepts in education, drawing upon the student's existing foundation-degree background.  Key topics would likely include educational theories, child development, curriculum design, assessment strategies, inclusive teaching methodologies, and understanding educational psychology and sociology within the context of diverse learners.  The focus is on developing a broad understanding of the educational landscape, with an introduction to relevant research methodologies.

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with 5.5 in each skills test)
Entry Requirement: Applicants need an HND or Foundation Degree in a relevant subject (equivalent to 240 credits).  Alternatively, 120 credits at level 5 and evidence of significant work and life experience may be considered.  International students, or those whose first language isn't English, require an IELTS score of 6.0 with at least 5.5 in each skill, or equivalent qualifications like a Cambridge English Scale B2, or 12 English Language credits at Level 2 from a pre-2014 Access to HE Diploma.  For Pakistani students, entry requirements are not explicitly stated on the provided webpage, but generally, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized university is expected for undergraduate courses.
Overview: The University of Derby offers an online BA (Hons) Education Studies Top-Up degree, designed for students holding 240 credits (120 at level 4 and 120 at level 5) in a relevant field.  This two-year program provides a comprehensive education in the field of education, exploring its historical, sociological, philosophical, and psychological aspects.  Students develop a strong understanding of current education policies and practices. The course includes a research project allowing in-depth investigation of students' chosen area of interest. This flexible online format is suitable for those balancing work and family commitments. The program is taught by experienced academics and uses a user-friendly online learning environment.
Course Structure: The course consists of five modules totaling 100 credits: four 20-credit modules and one 40-credit module. The specific modules and order are determined upon enrollment. The program is 100% coursework-based using various assessment techniques including academic posters, essays, a literature-based project, and pre-recorded presentations. The university regularly reviews and updates modules to maintain high standards and relevance.
Year 1: The first year of the top-up BA (Hons) in Education Studies involves approximately four 20-credit modules.  These modules would likely cover foundational areas of education studies – such as historical influences on education, sociological perspectives on different educational groups, philosophical underpinnings of educational methodologies, and core psychological concepts as they relate to learning and teaching.  Specific titles of each module aren’t given and will vary.  The course also likely introduces research methodologies, providing preparation for the major research project.
Year 2: The second year focuses on building upon the foundation from year one. In addition to further specialized modules, students would undertake a larger 40-credit module which is a substantial research project.This allows for detailed investigation into an area of education that personally interests the student.  This research project may involve significant literature review, data analysis (depending on the research design selected), and the production of a substantial written thesis or equivalent report. The coursework element in this year enhances critical thinking abilities and deepens understanding of specialized educational concepts.

Course Title: Undergraduate Criminology and Education Studies BA/BSc (Hons)
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement:
For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 112 UCAS points, A Levels BBC, T Level Merit, BTEC DMM, GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or equivalent, or a Pass Access to HE Diploma with specific credit requirements.  International students need an IELTS score of 6.0 with at least 5.5 in each skill area. For Pakistan, A-Levels or IB from International Schools allow entry to Year 1, while postgraduate entry requires a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2, a Masters degree if a Bachelor's was 2 or 3 years, or a 4-year honours Bachelor's with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00.
PhD entry from Pakistan requires a Master's and Bachelor's degree in a relevant subject and a research proposal.
Overview: The Criminology and Education Studies BA/BSc (Hons) Joint Honours degree at the University of Derby combines the study of human behavior and criminal justice with a multidisciplinary social science approach to education. Students explore crime, deviance, and victimisation, examining their relationships to social divisions.  The education studies component analyzes education through sociology, history, psychology, and philosophy.  The program includes practical elements such as interviewing, negotiation, research, and problem-based learning.  Students may choose to study both subjects equally, or major in one subject, starting with an equal split in the first year and choosing their path afterward.  The program incorporates real-world experiences through work placements, field trips, study abroad opportunities, and links with courts, prisons, and youth offender training centers.
Course Structure: The course structure allows students to choose whether to study both subjects equally or to specialize in one. The first year involves equal study of both Criminology and Education Studies. Subsequent years allow for specialization, where students may either equally continue the study of Criminology and Education Studies, or major in criminology or major in Education Studies while minoring in criminology. Criminology modules utilize lectures, tutorials, group work, and independent learning, assessed through coursework, portfolios, presentations, and exams. Education Studies modules employ directed study, lectures, seminars, tutorials, are assessed through essays, presentations, portfolios, reports, and case study analyses. There are a range of modules that students can expect to encounter, while the actual modules may vary. To discover the specific modules offered under these programs students are encouraged to contact jhs@derby.ac.uk
Year 1: The first year provides an equal introduction to both Criminology and Education Studies.  Criminology modules will cover foundational concepts of crime, deviance, and social justice, potentially including topics like criminological theory, criminal behavior, and the criminal justice system.   Education Studies modules will introduce core concepts in education, possibly including sociology of education, history of education, educational psychology, and philosophy of education, providing a broad understanding of the field.
Year 2: In year two, students will have started the major/minor subjects. Therefore, they will take core modules specific to their chosen major (Criminology or Education Studies), delving deeper into specialized topics within their chosen field.  They will also continue to take modules from their chosen minor subject to provide a well-rounded education.   A student choosing to equally continue the study of both subjects will engage with more advanced modules in both fields.
Year 3: The final year focuses on advanced studies within the chosen major and minor, allowing students to develop their expertise.  For criminology majors, this might involve specialized areas like victimology, youth justice, or forensic psychology. For Education students, further specialism may be taken within the subjects encountered at different stages.  Students may also undertake independent research projects, dissertations, or internships to extend their knowledge and practical experience.

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For entry in 2025, typical requirements include 112 UCAS points, A-levels BBC, a Merit in T Levels, DMM in BTECs, and GCSE Maths and English at Grade 4/C or above.  An Access to HE Diploma with 60 credits (45 at Level 3, with a minimum of 15 Distinction, 24 Merit, and 6 Pass) is also acceptable.  Contextual offers may be available for students from care, estranged families, refugee or asylum-seeker, or UK armed forces backgrounds.  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or the IB from international schools in Pakistan, entry to Year 1 is possible. For postgraduate study, a relevant Bachelor’s degree equivalent to a UK Upper or Lower Second Class degree is needed; those with 2 or 3-year Bachelor's degrees also require a Master's pass. A Bachelor's degree with honors (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani University is considered for Master's entry.
Overview: The BA (Hons) Economics and Education Studies is a joint honors degree program offered by the University of Derby. It allows students to explore the interplay between economic principles and educational practices, providing a multidisciplinary approach to understanding education within societal and economic contexts.  The curriculum integrates economic theory with educational perspectives from history, sociology, philosophy, and psychology, exploring different educational approaches. Students gain practical experience through real-world projects, placements, and internships, enhancing their employability skills.  The program encourages independent learning but provides ample support through academic tutoring.  Students can choose to major in either Economics or Education Studies or study both equally. This flexible structure caters to students' diverse interests and career aspirations combining the theoretical aspects of both subjects with practical application. Students develop skills in analytical thinking, research, and data analysis through coursework and assessments, preparing them for a diverse range of career paths.
Course Structure: The course combines modules from both Economics and Education Studies. Year one involves equal study across both subjects, with students making a decision on their major or minor specialism at the end of the first year.  Economics modules focus on developing an understanding of key economic concepts and theory through the application of live research projects and the utilization of current economic data.  Education Studies modules explore the subject through historical, sociological, philosophical, and psychological lenses. The program emphasizes research-informed teaching, involving staff with expertise in their fields and exposure to real-world situations. Students are assessed through a mixture of coursework, presentations, projects, and computer-based assessments, reflecting both sectors' requirements.
Year 1: The first year provides a foundational understanding of both Economics and Education Studies. In Economics, students are introduced to core principles, macroeconomic and microeconomic theories, and basic econometrics.  Education Studies introduces students to educational philosophies and their historical development, exploring the sociological, psychological, and philosophical perspectives on teaching and learning.  Students will equally cover modules from both subjects, providing a solid background before specializing.
Year 2: Year two allows students to deepen their knowledge and specialization in their chosen major or minor subject.  Economics modules may include more advanced topics, such as international economics and financial markets. Education Studies may delve into areas such as curriculum development, educational policy, or inclusive education, depending on the specialization chosen.  Students engage with more advanced methods and projects to enhance their analytical and practical skills.
Year 3: The final year focuses on independent research and advanced concepts within the chosen specializations.  Economics modules could explore areas such as behavioral economics or development economics and practical research and analytical project work using tools like Bloomberg, Excel and SPSS. Education Studies modules might involve a dissertation or a significant research project on an area of interest, allowing for more in-depth study and focused reflection. Students consolidate their skills and knowledge preparing for their future careers.

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)

Overview: The BA (Hons) English and Education Studies is a joint honours degree program offered at the University of Derby.  This three-year, full-time course allows students to explore both English literature and the field of education. The program combines critical analysis of literature with an understanding of the context of its production and reception, including intellectual and cultural history, film, philosophy, linguistics, sociology, and contemporary cultural politics. The curriculum also provides a thorough grounding in education policy, practice, equality, history, psychology, sociology, and philosophy.  Students can choose to major in one subject or balance both equally, deciding after the first year. The program incorporates practical elements, including work-based learning, visits to cultural and heritage institutions, guest lectures, and real-world learning projects.
Course Structure: The course structure is flexible, allowing students to specialize in either English or Education Studies or to maintain an equal balance. Year 1 involves an equal study of both subjects. After the first year, students choose to major in one, minor in one, or continue with an equal balance.  Modules range from literary analysis and creative writing to education policy, social inequalities in education, and practical approaches to teaching and learning.  Assessment methods are varied, emphasizing coursework over exams. English modules employ seminar debates, presentations, and research projects, while education studies modules utilize essays, presentations, portfolios, reports, and case studies. The university offers Personal Academic Tutoring for guidance and support.
Year 1: The first year provides a foundation in both English and Education Studies, ensuring students gain a solid grounding in both disciplines. Students explore key literary texts and critical theories alongside fundamental concepts in educational theory and practice.   They develop skills in close reading, analysis, and creative writing, complemented by research methods and an introduction to educational research methodologies. This balanced approach lets students make an informed decision regarding their subject focus in subsequent years.
Year 2: In the second year, students continue their studies in English and Education Studies, building upon the knowledge and skills gained in the first year.   Those who choose to major in English delve deeper into critical theory, historical contexts, and literary movements.  They would further refine their research and writing abilities. Students focusing on Education Studies will engage in more specialized modules including pedagogical approaches, curriculum design, and educational psychology alongside additional research techniques relevant to the field. Students who opt to maintain equitable focus will continue to balance modules in both disciplines.
Year 3: The third year allows for specialization and the application of the knowledge and skills students acquired during their degree.  Students majoring in English can undertake indepedent research, engaging in advanced critical analysis and literary studies, perhaps focusing on a particular author, period, or genre. Major in education would focus on applying theory through practice, perhaps through a placement in a school or educational setting. Students with a balanced approach will further integrate both subjects. This year may also include a dissertation or major research project, depending on program specifics.

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical requirements include 72 UCAS points, A Levels (DDD), a T Level pass, BTEC (MMP), or a pass in the Access to HE Diploma. GCSE Maths and English are preferred but not mandatory.  International students will need an IELTS score of 6.0 with at least 5.5 in each skill.  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or the IB from International Schools in Pakistan, entry to the first year is possible.  The university employs contextual offers, potentially reducing grade requirements for students who are care experienced, estranged from their families, refugees, asylum seekers, or whose parents/carers are in the UK armed forces.  Students need to declare these circumstances in their application.  A DBS check might be required before placement.
Overview: The BA (Hons) Education Studies with Foundation Year is a four-year undergraduate program designed to provide a comprehensive understanding of education, from early years to lifelong learning.  It offers two specialist pathways: Special Educational Needs and Disability (SEND) and Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages (TESOL).  The program integrates theoretical knowledge with practical experience, including a 12-day work placement and potential international field trips. Students will explore various aspects of education, including its role in society, moral and social issues in learning, and educational equality, drawing from history, psychology, sociology, and philosophy. The foundation year aims to build students' knowledge, skills, and confidence before progressing to the honors degree.
Course Structure: The course is structured into four years, beginning with a foundation year that gives students a solid base in educational theory and practice. Afterwards it moves to three years of study. The curriculum includes modules covering educational psychology, sociology of education, history of education, educational policy, and research methods. Students will choose a specialization between SEND or TESOL.  Depending upon the chosen pathway, students undertake a work placement in an educational setting. The program also includes opportunities for international field trips and guest workshops. Assessment methods are diverse and include essays, presentations, and portfolio work.
Year 1: The foundation year focuses on developing fundamental skills and knowledge in education.  Students will gain a broad understanding of educational contexts, theories, and practices while building confidence and academic skills. The curriculum may include introductory modules in educational psychology, sociology, and the history of education alongside academic skills development components.
Year 2: Year two builds upon the foundation year, delving deeper into core educational concepts. Students develop skills needed within an educational setting. Students will begin to work towards selected pathways, focusing on aspects of inclusive teaching, curriculum development, educational policy, and assessment.  A 12-day work placement is also undertaken.
Year 3: In the third year, students intensify their chosen pathway (SEND or TESOL).  SEND students will focus on special educational needs, disability, and inclusion. TESOL students will concentrate on language acquisition, teaching methodologies, and language assessment for ESL learners.  The focus is on the application of theoretical knowledge to practical settings.
Year 4: The final year involves advanced studies reflecting the chosen pathway's focus, along with a significant project or dissertation. This could involve further exploration of special educational needs and inclusion for SEND pathways and developing teaching portfolios for TESOL pathways. The focus is on developing advanced analytical and research skills in line with individual pathways.
Career Opportunity 5: Teacher of English to Speakers of Other Languages (ESOL)

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical requirements include 104 UCAS points, A Levels BCC, T Level Merit, BTEC DMM, GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or equivalent, or a Pass Access to HE Diploma with 60 credits (45 at Level 3). Overview: The BA (Hons) Education Studies is a comprehensive undergraduate program exploring education's role in society and its interplay with moral and social issues.  It integrates perspectives from history, psychology, sociology, and philosophy to provide a solid understanding of education and educational equality. Students can specialize in Special Educational Needs and Disability (SEND) or Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages (TESOL). The curriculum includes practical work placements and international learning opportunities, enhancing both theoretical knowledge and practical skills.  The course emphasizes social equality, inclusion, and diversity, preparing graduates for various career paths in education and related sectors.
Course Structure: The course structure includes a range of teaching methods such as lectures, seminars, and tutorials.  Students can choose to specialize in SEND focusing on working with learners with special needs or TESOL focusing on English language teaching across various contexts.  Regardless of pathway choice, a work placement is included, and assessment is primarily coursework-based. The curriculum incorporates topics like inclusion, diversity, social equality, online learning, and pastoral care. Students also learn practical application of education in outdoor settings, exploring nature's role in skills development.   The curriculum is regularly reviewed, and some modules might change to improve the student experience and enhance graduate prospects.
Year 1: Year 1 of the program lays a foundation in education theory and practice, exploring the historical, sociological, and philosophical underpinnings of education. The curriculum likely covers core topics such as educational psychology, curriculum development, and teaching methodologies. It also familiarizes students with different educational settings across various contexts. Students would likely gain basic understanding of inclusive education principles and diverse learning needs.  The year might include introductory modules in related disciplines along with foundational teaching methodologies.
Year 2: The second year builds upon the foundational knowledge acquired in the first year.  Students delve deeper into specialized areas, particularly if they have chosen a pathway, such as SEND or TESOL.  If a student is in the SEND pathway the curriculum might cover special educational needs legislation, assessment strategies for students with diverse abilities, and inclusive teaching practices. The TESOL pathway could focus on communicative language teaching, English language acquisition theories, and practical ESL curriculum design. A 12-day work placement might be included in the year.
Year 3: The third year focuses on advanced study and practical application of knowledge. Students undertake a significant work placement (if not done before), giving them real-world experience and enhancing their employability. The final year builds upon the knowledge developed in previous years with specialized modules related to chosen pathway. Students might have to work on major projects and dissertations/thesis.
Career Opportunity 5: Teacher specializing in English as a Foreign Language

Course Title: Integrated Masters in Education (MEdu) with Qualified Teacher Status
Required IELTS Score: 7.0 (with at least 6.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical requirements include 120 UCAS points, A Levels (BBC), T Levels (Merit), BTECs (DMM), or an Access to HE Diploma.  GCSEs (or equivalents) in Maths, English Language, and a Science at Grade 4/C or above are also needed. A reference from a professional email address (school/college/employer) is required, along with certified qualifications and photographic ID (Passport/Driving License). A personal statement detailing reasons for pursuing the course is mandatory.  An Enhanced Disclosure & Barring Service certificate and an Occupational Health Assessment are required.  For Pakistani students, those completing A-levels or the International Baccalaureate from international schools in Pakistan can enter the first year.  Those with a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognised Pakistani University equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree are eligible. Students with a two or three-year Bachelor's degree need a Master's degree pass. A four-year Bachelor's degree with honours and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani university qualifies for Master's entry.
Overview: The University of Derby's Integrated Masters in Education (MEdu) with Qualified Teacher Status is a four-year program designed to prepare students for primary school teaching.  It combines undergraduate and master's level study, allowing students to develop advanced research skills and gain Qualified Teacher Status (QTS). The curriculum emphasizes practical experience through varied school placements across different year groups and settings, including special educational needs environments. The course aims to develop outstanding teachers who are resilient, critical, reflective, and equipped with advanced teaching and academic skills. Students will focus on developing a personal educational philosophy, exploring innovative classroom practices, and understanding curriculum leadership and management.  The program fosters collaboration, community engagement, and research skills through a personalized dissertation. The university's reputation for excellent teacher training, as evidenced by its 'Outstanding' Ofsted rating, further enhances the program's value.
Course Structure: The four-year MEdu program integrates undergraduate and master's level study.  The first three years focus on foundational teaching skills, practical experience in various school placements, and subject-specific knowledge. In the third and fourth years, students take master's level modules developing critical thinking and problem-solving abilities.  Students can choose a curriculum enhancement in areas such as English, Mathematics, Science, or the Arts, specializing in a particular subject. A significant component involves extensive school placements, which allow for a diverse range of teaching experience. The final year includes a master's-level dissertation on a chosen research area and a module focused on curriculum leadership and management, building on the chosen enhancement subject.
Year 1: The first year provides a foundation in educational theory and practice. Students will begin their school placements, gaining practical experience in a primary school setting. Key areas covered may include child development, classroom management, assessment strategies, and foundational subject knowledge.  The curriculum balances theoretical learning with initial observation and teaching opportunities, enabling students to build a strong base for subsequent years.
Year 2: Building upon the foundation year, Year 2 continues to develop practical teaching skills and subject knowledge.  Students will experience different placements across primary year groups and placements will include an experience in a special educational needs (SEN) school and an alternative setting placement.  Curriculum focus will evolve to include more specialized teaching methodologies, differentiated instruction, and inclusive teaching practices. The increased responsibility in school placements will challenge students to apply the learning from the first year.
Year 3: The third year bridges undergraduate and postgraduate study. Students will engage in advanced modules focusing on critical thinking, educational research, and complex issues in education.  They will also select a curriculum enhancement, specializing in a subject area of interest, and begin fieldwork and research for their dissertation.  The program deepens students' understanding of leadership qualities in education, including effective collaboration among professionals within schools.
Year 4: The final year is dedicated primarily to the master's level. Students complete their dissertation, undertaking independent research within their chosen curriculum enhancement. The Curriculum Leadership and Management module builds on the specialization, focusing on leading and managing a curriculum in a specialized area.  Students continue to refine their teaching skills during a placement focusing on leadership and building upon research, and prepare for their roles as newly qualified teachers.

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 112 UCAS points.  A-Level students need BBC grades (at least a C in Maths, Physics, or a related subject).  T Level requires a Merit in relevant engineering specialisations. BTEC needs DMM in Engineering or Physics, with a Merit in Maths. GCSE Maths and English need Grade 4/C or above.  Access to HE Diploma requires a Pass with 60 credits at Level 3, including distinctions in compulsory subjects.  Contextual offers may adjust requirements based on individual circumstances like care experience, being estranged, refugee status, or having parents in the armed forces.  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or IB from international schools within Pakistan, direct entry to Year 1 is possible.  Postgraduate entry from a recognized Pakistani university requires a degree equivalent to at least a UK Upper Second Class (2:1) or Lower Second Class (2:2), with a Master's degree needed if the Bachelor's is only two or three years. A four-year Bachelor's degree with honours and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 is considered for entry to a Masters program. PhD applicants need a Master's and Bachelor's degree in a relevant subject plus a research proposal.
Overview: The BEng (Hons) Electrical and Electronic Engineering degree provides a comprehensive education in the field, preparing students for diverse careers in areas such as avionics, medical electronics, automotive systems, power generation, and entertainment.  The curriculum blends theoretical knowledge with extensive hands-on laboratory work and project-based learning, utilizing state-of-the-art facilities including a STEM Centre, various specialized labs (Electronics Principles, Electrical Power, Electronics Project Developments, Multipurpose Labs, and Multi-Channel Sound Lab), and a Makerspace equipped with tools such as a laser cutter and 3D printers. The first year provides a broad overview of engineering disciplines, allowing students to explore different areas before specializing.  Students can also choose to include an optional industry placement year, which enhances career prospects.  The program focuses on practical learning using a mix of lectures, tutorials, mini-projects, and laboratory experiments. The University's Careers and Employment Service provides support in developing job-seeking skills and career paths.
Course Structure: The course integrates classroom learning with extensive practical laboratory sessions and projects. Year one includes a foundational study of engineering principles, providing a broad base.  The second year offers the option to switch to Motorsport or Mechanical Engineering, while those continuing in Electrical and Electronic Engineering will advance in their specialized studies. Years three and four (or three if no placement), students advance further into specialized areas of Electrical and Electronic Engineering and undertake a range of projects, developing hands-on skills and expertise aligned with industrial needs.  A placement year is optional, enhancing the practical experiences and improving employability upon graduation.  Assessment includes a range of methods, like assignments, projects, computer-related tasks, laboratory work, written work, analysis and examinations.
Year 1: The first year provides a broad foundation in engineering principles, covering core concepts across various engineering disciplines. Students gain a foundational understanding of electrical and electronic systems, mathematics, computing, and general engineering methodologies.  The curriculum is designed to allow students to explore different specializations before making a choice for further years of study. The focus is on foundational knowledge and preparing students for more advanced courses in subsequent years.  Alongside lectures and tutorials, students engage in practical lab work that helps to solidify their comprehension of core engineering concepts and provide a foundation for future coursework.
Year 2: In the second year, students specializing in Electrical and Electronic Engineering continue more in-depth study of relevant subjects. The choice offered to switch to Motorsport or Mechanical Engineering if they had other interest during the first year is given here. Continued specialization in electrical and electronic engineering areas will also take place this year. Students will undertake more advanced projects, often in group settings, further developing their problem-solving skills and teamwork competencies. The emphasis is on applying the foundational knowledge from the first year to progressively more complex projects and theoretical studies.  There may be a transition to more specialized modules reflecting the career pathways most electrical and electronic engineers follow.
Year 3: The third year involves advanced studies in electrical and electronic engineering, integrating both theoretical knowledge and practical application. Students undertake independent projects, applying the knowledge they’ve accumulated to solve real-world problems. Advanced coursework covers specialized areas like power systems, control systems, digital signal processing, or embedded systems.  Focus would be on developing their depth of knowledge in these areas, enhancing their understanding of practical applications. There is also an independent investigation or a group research project in this year that the students can engage in.  Students expand on their problem-solving skills and research methodologies that many electrical engineers employ on a day-to-day basis.
Year 4: The fourth year (for students taking the placement year option) is dedicated to a year-long placement in industry. Students gain valuable practical experience and network with professionals. This placement year provides practical insights and professional skills, such as teamwork and communication which are highly regarded in industry. This also develops connections that can help provide a smooth transition into their professional careers in Electrical and Electronic Engineering. Upon completion of the placement year, students will return to the university in the final year of their course. With this valuable experience, students can leverage their learnings and network to find employment or further educational opportunities.

Course Title: BEng (Hons) Electrical and Electronic Engineering with Foundation Year
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical requirements include 72 UCAS points, A Levels (DDD), a T Level pass, BTEC (MMP), GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or above, or a pass in an Access to HE Diploma.  International students need an IELTS score of 6.0 with at least 5.5 in each skill area.  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or the IB from international schools in Pakistan, direct entry to Year 1 is possible.  Postgraduate entry from Pakistan requires a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK Upper or Lower Second Class degree (a Master's degree is also needed if the Bachelor's degree is two or three years). A four-year Bachelor's degree with honours and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani university is also acceptable for Master's entry. PhD applicants from Pakistan need a Master's and Bachelor's degree in a relevant subject, along with a research proposal.
Overview: The BEng (Hons) Electrical and Electronic Engineering with Foundation Year is a four-year undergraduate program designed to equip students with a comprehensive understanding of electrical and electronic engineering principles. The course covers a wide range of topics, from fundamental electronic circuit behavior to advanced concepts in renewable energy and power systems.  The integrated foundation year provides extra support for students needing to build essential skills and strengthens knowledge before embarking on their chosen field of study. Students will engage in laboratory work, projects, and industry placements, enhancing their practical experience. This practical approach, coupled with expert teaching staff, positions graduates for successful careers in diverse sectors. The curriculum is regularly reviewed to ensure students graduate with skills that meet the demands of the modern engineering industry with a focus on sustainability and industrial needs, making this degree a valuable asset in a competitive job market.
Course Structure: The course structure involves a blend of lectures, tutorials, laboratory sessions, and mini-projects.  The first year provides a multidisciplinary foundation in engineering, allowing students to explore different branches and decide which area best suits their strengths. Students can switch to Motorsport or Mechanical Engineering at the end of year one or remain in Electrical and Electronic Engineering.  Years 2 and 3 build on this foundation with more specialized modules.  A placement year is optional and can provide invaluable real-world experience. The final year involves a substantial project to create a functioning product within the discipline.  Students regularly use specialist laboratories for hands-on learning involving electronic principles, electrical power, sustainable energies, electronics projects and audio and immersive audio applications.
Year 1: The first year offers a broad foundation in engineering, covering all key aspects and providing students with a solid understanding of fundamental principles across various specialisations.  This common first year allows students to fully explore different engineering disciplines before committing to a major in years 2 and subsequent years. This includes core modules across electrical and electronic engineering to provide a grounding before choosing if they want to remain studying this degree or branching out to other disciplines within the university.
Year 2: Year two builds upon the foundational knowledge of year one allowing for a deeper exploration into specific areas within electrical and electronic engineering. Students complete core modules while having the option to change their degree major to either BEng (Hons) Motorsport Engineering or BEng (Hons) Mechanical Engineering or remaining in their current choice of study Electrical and Electronic Engineering. Students could also choose to take an optional placement year at year two, allowing for vital, practical experience within their field of study and improve their job prospects.
Year 3: The third year of the BEng (Hons) Electrical and Electronic Engineering allows students continue to specialise within their chosen area. Module choice opens up wider possibilities within the field of electrical and electronic engineering. If the student has taken a placement year at year 2, this would be the start of their final year and focus would then transition into a major project.
Year 4: The final year focuses on developing advanced skills and undertaking a significant project to consolidate their learning. This is a practical element that demonstrates skills to potential employers.  The final year of study focuses on a major project and allows the opportunity to consolidate theoretical learning to apply practical skills.  This year involves modules in specialised areas with the degree culminating in the completion of a substantial project with a focus on innovation and application of knowledge.

Required IELTS Score: 6.5 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)

Overview: The BEng (Hons) Engineering Management (Top-Up) is a one-year full-time or two-year part-time program designed for students who already hold an HND or foundation degree in a relevant engineering discipline.  The course aims to equip graduates with the necessary multi-disciplinary skills for management roles in the engineering industry.  It blends technical expertise with business skills, covering areas such as operations and supply chain management, continuous improvement, project management, and sustainable development.  The curriculum balances theoretical concepts with practical work, techniques, and principles relevant to successful engineering management careers. The program is accredited by the Institution of Mechanical Engineers (IMechE).
Course Structure: The course structure integrates lectures, tutorials, case study discussions, work-related learning activities, research-based learning, and computer lab sessions.  Students gain hands-on experience with software and benefit from industrial visits and guest lectures. Modules may vary from time to time and a full module list is often unavailable online. Assessments involve coursework assignments, exams, and presentations.  Personal Academic Tutoring provides tailored support to help students reach their goals. The course content appears to cover a broad range of engineering management subjects, reflecting the needs of employers across manufacturing and service sectors. The exact modules and their content are subject to change.
Year 1: The first year (or the only year for full-time students) likely focuses on core engineering management principles such as operations management, supply chain management, project management, and sustainable development.  Students will likely engage in practical work, case studies, and computer-based learning exercises to reinforce their understanding of these concepts. The year will also include the application of theoretical concepts to real-world scenarios through case studies, guest lectures, and potentially some form of industry project. Modules are subject to change and availability depends on the student's prior qualifications.
Year 2: This applies only to part-time students. The second year of study for part-time students will likely build upon the foundation established in the first year. It might delve deeper into specialized areas within engineering management or explore business-related subjects needed to further skill sets and career advancement.  The modules and activities would involve a combination of lectures, workshops, projects, and assessments aimed at equipping students with advanced skills. Exact module details aren't available widely, but it would be focused on management specific elements of the degree.

Course Title: BA (Hons) English and Creative and Professional Writing
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement:
For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 112-120 UCAS points.  A-Level students need BBB-BBC grades, with at least a C in English or a related subject.  T Level students require a Merit, while BTEC students need DDM-DMM. GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or above are also required.  Access to HE Diploma requires a pass with 60 credits (45 at Level 3 with Distinction, Merit, and Pass requirements).  International students should refer to specific IELTS requirements.  

For Pakistani students, A-Levels or IB from Pakistani international schools allow direct entry into Year 1. Postgraduate applicants need a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2, a Master's degree if having a two or three-year Bachelor's degree, or a four-year Bachelor's degree with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 for consideration. For PhD, a Master's and Bachelor's degree in a relevant subject, along with a research proposal, are required.
Overview: The BA (Hons) English and Creative and Professional Writing is a three-year undergraduate program at the University of Derby. This joint honors degree allows students to combine their passion for English literature with the practical skills of creative and professional writing. The curriculum blends literary analysis with the realities of the publishing industry, covering fiction and non-fiction writing, publishing processes, and marketing strategies.  Students explore a range of literary genres and theories, including fantasy, crime fiction, historical and political contexts, and critical theory. The course aims to produce well-rounded graduates equipped for careers in various creative fields.
Course Structure:
The course structure is designed to allow students to explore literature through critical analysis and the application of writing processes.The  first year introduces both the literary study of English and Creative writing and is then followed by the option to either major or minor in one of the subjects in years 2 and 3.
Modules will vary depending on the choice to major or minor thus creating options depending on career trajectory. Students will be assessed through a variety of methods such as essays, presentations, and creative writing samples which depends on the subject.  The program places considerable emphasis on developing research and communication skills, crucial for success in any career.
Year 1: The initial year provides a balanced foundation in both English and Creative and Professional Writing. Students will be introduced to key literary theories and genres within English, while simultaneously learning fundamental writing techniques and styles in Creative and Professional Writing.  Expect modules that cover core literary texts, writing exercises, and workshops focusing on various writing forms – for instance, fiction, poetry, and journalism.
Year 2: The second year builds upon the foundation laid in the first year, allowing students to delve deeper into their chosen major subject whilst maintaining a minor subject. In English, students  might undertake advanced literary analysis, exploring critical frameworks or researching specific periods or authors. Within Creative and Professional Writing, students may specialize in a chosen field such as screenwriting, publishing or digital media.
Year 3: The final year provides students with an opportunity to specialize within their chosen degree by allowing them to complete a final year long project, an opportunity to put to practice the knowledge and experience gained throughout the degree program.  Expect specialized modules within English and Creative writing that allows specialization in preferred area whether it is historical analysis, creative writing, or journalism.

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical requirements include 112 UCAS points.  A-Level students need BBC grades (with at least a C in English or a related subject), while BTEC students need DMM.  A Merit in T Levels is required, and Access to HE Diploma needs 60 credits (45 at Level 3, with a minimum of 15 Distinction, 24 Merit, and 6 Pass). GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or higher are also needed.  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or IB from International Schools in Pakistan, entry to the first year is possible.  Those with a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized Pakistani university, equivalent to at least a UK Upper Second Class (2:1) or Lower Second Class (2:2), are also considered.  A master's degree is necessary for students with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees.  A four-year Bachelor's degree with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized university in Pakistan may qualify applicants for a Master's degree.
Location/Campus: Kedleston Road and One Friar Gate Square, Derby Campus
Overview: The University of Derby's BA (Hons) English and Law is a three-year, full-time joint honors degree program.  It uniquely combines the study of literature, culture, and legal theory, equipping students with advanced analytical, research, and creative skills.  The program offers students the flexibility to choose subjects based on their career goals, allowing them to tailor each year's studies based on their needs.  Students are exposed to modules covering literary theory and analysis of various literary works, exploring themes and genres across cultures and historical periods.  The legal component develops advocacy, negotiation, and drafting skills through mock court cases, legal research, and potentially through work with the Student Legal Advice Centre. The program emphasizes practical application, with opportunities for internships, mentoring, and real-world legal experience.  Graduates gain skills applicable in various sectors.
Course Structure: The program structure allows students to explore English and Law subjects equally in the first year, before deciding between majoring in one subject or continuing with an equal split in their second and third years.  The law modules are prescribed, while students may customize their English modules to align with career goals.  The Law modules might cover various subfields of law based on the curriculum, providing knowledge and practice exercises. The English modules emphasize close textual analysis, critical theory, and historical context.  Assessments vary and include essays, presentations, research projects, group work, moot court experiences, and potentially papers for publication in the Derby Law School Journal.  The program provides continuous support via Personal Academic Tutors.
Year 1: The first year involves an equal balance between English and Law modules.  English modules introduce core literary theories, historical contexts, literary analysis, and a range of literary genres and writing styles from various cultures.  Law modules introduce fundamental legal principles, legal reasoning, and methodologies.  Students start building core skills in legal and literary argumentation, research and presentation, and legal and literary analysis.
Year 2: In the second year, students can maintain the balance between English and Law modules or opt for specialization. Those who choose to specialize might have more in-depth modules in English that dive deeper into specific periods, genres, authors or critical theories. Law students may cover more advanced legal topics through modules relating to business law, criminal law or international law, enhancing practical skills and theoretical knowledge.  Students will further hone skills in legal and literary research and writing, while developing greater confidence in presenting their ideas and arguments.
Year 3: The final year, similar to the second year, allows students to deepen their knowledge and expertise based upon their subject choice of focus. English studies may include advanced research projects, literary criticism, and potentially specialized elective courses. Law modules could address topics such as corporate law, family law, human rights law, or criminal justice based on subject pathway selection. Students are expected to demonstrate sophisticated analysis and critical thinking by compiling a final project, potentially through dissertation or a major research assignment.

Course Title: BA (Hons) English, Creative Writing and Publishing
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical UCAS points are 104.  A-Level requirements are BCC, with at least a grade C in English or a related subject (or equivalent).  T Level requires a Merit, BTEC needs DMM, and GCSE needs Grade 4/C or above in Maths and English (or equivalent). An Access to HE Diploma is acceptable with 60 credits (45 at Level 3, including 15 Distinction, 24 Merit, 6 Pass).  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or IB from International Schools in Pakistan, direct entry into the first year is possible.  Contextual offers may be available for care experienced students, those estranged from their families, refugees, asylum seekers, or those with parents/carers in the UK armed forces.
Overview: The University of Derby's BA (Hons) English, Creative Writing, and Publishing degree offers a comprehensive and challenging program exploring English literature, language, and culture.  Students delve into literary analysis, critical theory, and cultural contexts, studying diverse works from across the globe.  The curriculum incorporates modules in linguistics, sociolinguistics, psycholinguistics, and the intersection of language and identity. Students develop strong analytical, research, and communication skills through essays, seminar participation, and independent projects. The course is designed to equip graduates for careers in teaching, journalism, publishing, arts administration, and various other fields. The supportive and engaging teaching environment, along with opportunities for work-based learning, study visits, and guest lectures, enhances the learning experience. The course also offers a chance to study abroad at a partner university in America.
Course Structure: The course structure is split into three years of study for full-time students and up to six years for part-time students. The curriculum is focused on a strong core of English Literature, combined with options in English Language.  Year One will likely build a foundation in literary and critical theory, key literary movements, and fundamental concepts in Linguistics. Year Two and Three will involve more specialized modules allowing for  specialization in areas like literary movements, critical theory, and linguistics. The program features a combination of lectures, seminars, tutorials and independent study, alongside assessment methods including essays, presentations, seminar participation, and research projects, with no final exam.  Students have opportunities for work-based learning, placements, and study visits to cultural institutions. A personal academic tutor provides individual support and career guidance.
Year 1: The first year establishes a strong foundation in English literature and language. Students will be introduced to core literary movements, critical theories, and fundamental concepts in linguistics.  Modules might cover introductions to literary criticism, historical contexts of literature, and basic linguistic concepts, along with foundational writing and research skills workshops. A focus will be placed on developing strong analytical skills and understanding different interpretive approaches to literary texts.
Year 2: The second year allows for increased specialization.  Students will likely explore modules in specific literary periods, genres, or theoretical approaches in more depth. The course might include modules in creative writing and publishing, allowing students to gain practical experience. Independent research projects and conference papers will form a key part of assessment. Research methodologies will be developed, while focusing student skills on building their own academic expertise.
Year 3: The third year focuses on advanced study in a chosen area of specialization. Students will undertake a substantial research project and potentially present their findings at a conference. The teaching will increase the research capabilities and independent learning. Assessment methods incorporate the more advanced research and argumentation skills, demonstrating a deeper critical understanding. Students also refine professional skills through additional practical and applied modules.

Course Title: MA English, Creative Writing and Publishing
Required IELTS Score: Overall: 7.0, minimum 6.5 in each category
Entry Requirement: A good honours degree (first or upper second class) in any subject, or its international equivalent, is required.  Applicants with a lower second class honours degree and/or significant relevant professional experience may also be considered.  An informal interview may be conducted to assess applicants' aspirations and expectations. Non-standard applicants are encouraged to apply.  International students must have equivalent qualifications to UK students.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognised university is needed, equivalent to at least a UK Upper Second Class (2:1) or Lower Second Class (2:2) degree. Those with two or three-year Bachelor degrees must also have a Master's degree. Overview: The MA English, Creative Writing and Publishing course at the University of Derby provides a comprehensive study of literature, encompassing theoretical approaches, cultural contexts, and advanced research methodologies. Students explore diverse literary texts from various nations and periods, critically reflecting on how narratives shape our world. The program develops advanced analytical and communication skills, equipping graduates for careers in various sectors.  The course blends traditional literary study (exploring themes like landscape representation and censorship) with cutting edge critical approaches including decolonization.  The program culminates in a substantial independent research project, preparing students for doctoral studies or professional roles.
Course Structure: The course is structured around thematic modules instead of historical periods, fostering connections between texts across various times and places.  Students learn through lectures, seminars, workshops and will develop advanced research skills. Modules include: Wilderness and the Imagination, Laughter and the Carnivalesque, Theory, Culture and Criticism, Taking and Making Offence, Global Literature:Travel Writing, and the culminating Independent Study (dissertation). Assessments are varied, including essays, literature reviews, case studies, seminar presentations, and reflective pieces, gradually building skills and expertise. A strong emphasis is placed on self-directed study, independent learning and developing intellectual curiosity.
Year 1: The first year of the full-time MA program fully immerses students in literary theory. Students participate in seminars and workshops covering various modules such as Wilderness and The Imagination, Laughter and the Carnivalesque, Theory, Culture and Criticism, Taking and Making Offence: Blasphemy, Obscenity and Censorship from Milton to Rushdie, Global Literatures: Travel Writing. These modules delve into diverse themes, exploring theoretical frameworks, critical analyses, and research methodologies.  Students progressively develop their writing and research capabilities through a series of assessments, building a strong foundation for their independent study in the final term. Students work one-to-one with their tutors, and the course incorporates interactive teaching styles to amplify understanding and communication.

Overview: The University of Derby's English with Foundation Year BA (Hons) is a four-year undergraduate program. It offers a strong foundation in English Literature, encompassing literary, critical, and cultural theory. Students explore diverse aspects of English language and literature, including fantasy, crime representation, the legacy of Empire, and various literary movements and periods. The course combines literature modules with linguistics, focusing on sociolinguistics, psycholinguistics, and language's relation to identity.  The program fosters critical thinking, analyzing literature within the context of identity, desire, and cultural politics. It aims to equip students with skills relevant to fields such as teaching, journalism, publishing, and arts administration. The assessment is coursework-based, emphasizing research, seminar participation, and independent projects, without any exams.  Students benefit from various opportunities like study abroad in the US, work-based learning, and interactions with guest speakers and industry professionals.  The flexible structure allows students to specialize in their literary interests during the later years.
Course Structure: The course is structured across four years including a foundation year. The foundation year strengthens skills and knowledge needed for the main degree. The program comprises a core of modules in English Literature and Language, allowing for option choices in later years that let students focus on their specific interests. Alongside modules focused on literary movements and periods, further modules in Linguistics such as sociolinguistics and psycholinguistics are included.  A key element is the development of research skills throughout the program. Assessment primarily involves coursework including essays, seminar participation and presentation, independent projects, and conference papers. There are no exams.
Year 1: The foundation year focuses on building a strong base in English literature and language. Students develop essential academic and research skills through coursework and in-class tests. Year 2: The second year delves deeper into literary analysis, critical theory, and selected areas of English language. Year 3: During year 3 students continue their specialized learning within the broader field of English Literature and Language. The emphasis on independent research projects and conference papers would increase. Students would also be expected to take increased responsibility in seminar discussions.
Year 4: The final year builds upon previous learning by allowing the students to do advanced research relating to their own specific interests.  The program culminates in a major research project, possibly presented at a conference and/or prepared for publication.  There is also assessment related to seminar leadership and participation.

Course Title: Level 6 and 7 Enhanced Clinical Practice (ECP) Apprenticeship
Required IELTS Score: NA
Entry Requirement: Employment Requirements:  Applicants must work at least 30 hours per week in a suitable role and have employer support.  Employers must provide clinical governance, supervise clinical skill development, and collaborate with the University.  Registration with a professional body like the Health and Care Professions Council, Nursing and Midwifery Council, or Social Work England, or an accredited voluntary register is also required.  Academic Requirements (Level 6):  Applicants need a minimum of a DipHE, FDSc, or equivalent qualification; a level 2 qualification in English and Maths (IfATE recognised); and access to apprenticeship funding.  Academic Requirements (Level 7):  Applicants require a minimum of a Bachelor's degree in a health-related subject (or equivalent) alongside the other requirements listed above.  Pakistan Specific Requirements are not explicitly stated on the course page.
Overview: The Enhanced Clinical Practice (ECP) Apprenticeship is a 21-month program designed to train qualified health and social care professionals to a higher level of practice.  It combines online university education with practical, work-based learning, focusing on complex clinical care within a specialty.  The curriculum covers advanced clinical assessments, diagnostics, interventions, and the use of clinical equipment, emphasizing critical analysis and evidence-based decision-making.  Students will develop strong communication and interdisciplinary teamwork abilities.  The program includes a significant work-based component for practical application and skills development, overseen by both university staff and practice supervisors.
Course Structure: The program structure is designed to allow apprentices to undertake the Level 6 apprenticeship standard, along with either a Level 6 or Level 7 academic program determined based on the candidate's prior qualifications and discussion with employers and academic representatives.  It's comprised of four terms of core Enhanced Clinical Practice modules (40 credits), one optional 20-credit module that can be chosen from a range of available subjects, followed by end-point assessment.  The optional modules cover a breadth of health specialities and perspectives allowing students to specialize in their areas of interest.  Summative assessments across all modules focus on demonstrating theoretical knowledge and its practical application which is supported by  report writing, presentations, reflections, and practice assessments.

Overview: The BA (Hons) Creative and Professional Writing and Entrepreneurship is a three-year undergraduate program offered at the University of Derby.  This joint honors course uniquely blends creative writing skills with entrepreneurial principles, equipping students for success in the writing industry and beyond. Students will develop their writing, editing, and publishing skills across various genres, including poetry, fiction, journalism, and non-fiction. Simultaneously, they'll explore business, enterprise, and entrepreneurship, gaining the skills to start their own ventures or add innovation to established businesses. The program incorporates hands-on experience through work placements, volunteering, and community engagement, fostering a strong connection to the city's literary scene. Students can choose to major in Creative and Professional Writing or maintain an equal balance between both subjects.
Course Structure: The course combines creative writing and entrepreneurship modules. In the first year, students study both equally, then choose to major in Creative and Professional Writing or continue studying both equally. Creative writing modules cover various genres and writing techniques, including poetry, prose, journalism, and non-fiction writing; also included are workshops and projects.  Entrepreneurship modules introduce students to business concepts, including business start-up, innovation, and how to operate effectively within different business structures.  Students will use various learning approaches like collaborative projects, case studies, and real-world business engagements. The program culminates in a final project where students synthesize skills and knowledge obtained throughout the course.
Year 1: The first year provides a foundation in both Creative and Professional Writing and Entrepreneurship.  Creative writing modules introduce core writing skills and genres. Students are exposed to various creative writing techniques through workshops and projects. Simultaneously, foundational entrepreneurship concepts, such as  basic business models, ideation, and market research, are introduced.  Students gain an understanding of the fundamental aspects of both subject areas, establishing a robust platform for further specialization.
Year 2: In the second year, students can choose to major in Creative and Professional Writing or maintain a balanced approach to both subjects.  Those specializing will delve deeper into their chosen field. Students specializing in creative writing might undertake advanced creative projects such as writing a more substantial piece of fiction or a series of non fiction articles. Those pursuing to study both subjects equally will receive more modules from both creative writing and entrepreneurial departments, giving them a very balanced approach.
Year 3: The final year allows students to hone their expertise and apply their skills through larger-scale projects and potentially collaborative projects. Advanced aspects of both creative writing and entrepreneurship are studied. Students focusing on creative writing might prepare a portfolio for submission or design and execute a plan on how best to publish their creative work. Students more keen on the business side may engage in creating a business plan, working with an established company, or potentially attempting to set up their own company.

Overview: The Early Childhood Studies and Entrepreneurship BA (Hons) is a joint honours degree program that combines the study of early childhood development with the principles of entrepreneurship. Entrepreneurship modules cover various aspects of business creation and management, equipping students with practical skills. Assessment methods vary across subjects. Early Childhood modules typically involve assessments like case studies, essays, research projects, and presentations; while Entrepreneurship relies on business reports, consultancy projects, presentations, and the development of digital materials.  The program includes opportunities for placement within the early childhood sector or an entrepreneurship-based placement year.
Year 1: The first year provides a foundational understanding of both Early Childhood Studies and Entrepreneurship. This year serves as an introduction to both disciplines and allows students to explore their interests and preferences before making major/minor decisions for subsequent years.
