Year 2: Depending on the chosen pathway (equal study, Early Childhood Studies major, or Entrepreneurship major), year two will either continue the balanced approach or focus more heavily on the chosen area of expertise. The continued exploration of Early Childhood will involve advanced study of relevant developmental theories, assessment methods, and practical application in diverse settings.  If following the entrepreneurship pathway, there will be increasing specialized study within particular business functions, such as marketing, finance, or HR management within entrepreneurial ventures.
Year 3: In the final year, students specialize further in their major subject. Those majoring in Early Childhood Studies may apply knowledge to research projects, complete an assessed placement and deepen understanding of professional practice.  Students prioritizing entrepreneurship might develop detailed business plans, participate in simulation exercises, or work on real-world consulting projects with Derby partners.

Course Title: BA (Hons) Human Resource Management and Entrepreneurship
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2024 entry, typical requirements include 112 UCAS points, A Levels BBC, T Level Merit, BTEC DMM, GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or equivalent.  Access to HE requires a pass with 60 credits including at least 45 at Level 3 (minimum Distinction: 15; Merit: 24; Pass: 6). Contextual offers may be available for care experienced students, those estranged from their families, refugees or asylum seekers, and students whose parents/carers are in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or IB from International Schools in Pakistan, entry to Year 1 is possible.  Postgraduate entry from Pakistan requires a relevant Bachelor’s degree equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree; two or three-year Bachelor's degree holders need a Master's pass; and a four-year Bachelor's degree with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University is also considered. PhD applicants need a Master's and Bachelor's degree in relevant subjects, plus a research proposal.
Overview: The BA (Hons) Human Resource Management and Entrepreneurship is a three-year undergraduate joint honors degree program offered by the University of Derby.  It combines the study of human resource management principles with entrepreneurial skills and knowledge, providing a comprehensive education in both fields. Students gain a solid understanding of HR policies, practices within international and strategic contexts, and sustainable business operations.  The curriculum also equips students with the skills needed to start their own businesses, work freelance, or thrive in entrepreneurial roles within various business environments. The program emphasizes real-world application through case studies and partnerships with the business community, including the Derby Network of Entrepreneurs. Students have the option of completing a placement year to enhance employability. The course allows students to equally pursue both subjects during the first year, and then choose to major in Human Resource Management or continue to study both subjects equally.
Course Structure: The course integrates both Human Resource Management and Entrepreneurship modules.  The first year involves a balanced study of both disciplines.  Subsequently students can choose to either major in HRM or continue an even split of the two subjects and this choice impacts the modules studied in years two and three.  Specific module titles are not provided in the available information, but assessment methods range from traditional essays and reports to group projects, research activities, presentations, and digital material design.  A personal academic tutor program is available further personalized support to the students.  The course includes optional placement and or internship opportunities.
Year 1: The first year provides a balanced introduction to both Human Resource Management and Entrepreneurship. Students will gain foundational knowledge of HR principles, policies, and practices, alongside the key concepts of entrepreneurship, business planning, and market analysis.  They will learn to integrate these concepts, applying theoretical frameworks to real-world business scenarios.  The year will likely involve introductory modules in both disciplines to build a robust understanding and establish the foundation needed for specialization in later years.
Year 2: The second year allows students to specialize or continue with a balanced focus.  Those choosing to major in HRM will delve deeper into areas such as strategic HR, talent management, performance management, and employment law. Students maintaining an equal split will build upon both HRM and Entrepreneurship foundations with more advanced topics to further their competencies in both subject-areas. Specific modules are not listed, but it will be a blend of coursework and potentially more practical applications of the skills learned in year one.
Year 3: The third year provides opportunities for advanced specialization and practical application of knowledge.   For HRM majors, this could include modules on international HR, change management, organizational behavior or other advanced topics in HRM.   Regardless of a student's chosen pathway after year one, year three will focus on project work, independent study, possibly a dissertation or extensive report, to test the practical skills and industry application of both concepts.

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2024 entry, typical requirements include 112 UCAS points, A-Levels BBC, T-Level Merit, BTEC DMM, GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or equivalent, or a Pass Access to HE Diploma.  International students need an IELTS score of 6.0 with at least 5.5 in each skill.  Contextual offers may be available for students from disadvantaged backgrounds (care experienced, estranged families, refugees, asylum seekers, or parents/carers in the UK armed forces).  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or IB in Pakistani International schools, direct entry into Year 1 is possible. For postgraduate study, a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2 is needed;  a Master's is required if the Bachelor's is 2 or 3 years. A four-year Bachelor's with a minimum 2.4/4.0 GPA from a recognised Pakistani university will be considered for Masters entry. For PhD, a Master's and Bachelor's in the relevant subject, alongside a research proposal, are required.
Annual Tuition Fee: UK: £9,535 per year; International: £16,900 per year
Overview: The University of Derby's BA (Hons) Law and Entrepreneurship is a three-year joint honors degree program designed to equip students with a comprehensive understanding of both English legal systems and the principles of entrepreneurship.  Students gain practical experience through mock court cases, real-world business projects, and potential placements or internships.  The program blends theoretical knowledge with practical application, preparing graduates for careers in diverse sectors.  The curriculum covers key areas such as constitutional law, human rights, business enterprise, and theoretical business concepts, encouraging the development of both legal and entrepreneurial skills. Students can choose to major in either law or entrepreneurship or study both equally. This tailored approach allows students to craft a degree path that aligns with personal interests and career aspirations.
Course Structure: The course combines modules from both law and entrepreneurship. In the first year, students study both subjects equally before selecting a major or minor specialization or continuing equal study.  Law modules focus on core legal concepts, practical legal skills, and case study analysis.  Entrepreneurship modules cover business planning, market analysis, financial management, and practical projects involving real businesses. The program integrates lectures, seminars, tutorials, group work, presentations, individual and group assignments, and real-world projects throughout its duration.
Year 1: The first year provides a foundation in both law and entrepreneurship. Law modules introduce core legal concepts such as constitutional law and human rights, along with an introduction to the English legal system.  Entrepreneurship modules cover fundamental business principles, including market research, business planning, and financial management.   Students engage in a combination of lectures, seminars, and practical exercises to gain an understanding of both disciplines.
Year 2: Year two builds upon the foundation established in the first year. Students continue with modules in both law and entrepreneurship. The law modules delve deeper into specific areas of the law depending on the path selected by the student, while entrepreneurship modules explore more advanced concepts, such as innovation and marketing. This year also incorporates opportunities for placements or summer internships, providing practical experience. Assessments incorporate a variety of methods, including examinations, coursework, and presentations.
Year 3: The final year allows students to specialize. The depth and breadth of chosen modules will depend on the subject major/minor/equal weighting undertaken by the student. If the student chooses an equal weighting, both the law and entrepreneurship modules will cover advanced topics. There is usually a significant project or dissertation alongside module coursework. It also provides opportunities for students to further develop professional skills and apply their knowledge to complex business and legal challenges.

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2024 entry, typical requirements include 112 UCAS points, A Levels BBC, T Level Merit, BTEC DMM, GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or equivalent.  An Access to HE Diploma with 60 credits (45 at Level 3) is also acceptable. Contextual offers may be available for care experienced students, estranged students, refugees, asylum seekers, or those whose parents/carers are in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or the IB from international schools in Pakistan, entry to Year 1 is possible.  Postgraduate entry from Pakistan requires a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to at least a UK 2:1 or 2:2, potentially with a Master's degree if the Bachelor's is 2 or 3 years. A four-year honors Bachelor's with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 is also considered.
Overview: The BA (Hons) Marketing and Entrepreneurship is a three-year undergraduate program offered by the University of Derby.  This joint honors degree allows students to develop expertise in both marketing and entrepreneurship, preparing them for a range of careers.  The curriculum blends theoretical knowledge with practical application, featuring industry projects and real-world challenges. Students can opt for a placement year or internships to enhance their experience and CV.  The program offers flexibility, allowing students to choose whether they major in marketing or study both subjects equally after the first year.
Course Structure: The course is structured across three years, with a balanced approach between marketing and entrepreneurship in the first year. Students then choose to either major in marketing or continue studying both subjects equally throughout the remaining two years.  The curriculum covers a wide range of topics, including theoretical business models, enterprise concepts, digital marketing, advertising, public relations, social media, and strategic analysis.  Learning methods include lectures, seminars, tutorials, workshops and individual and group assignments, working with real businesses to tackle live projects. Assessment includes coursework, presentations, creative outputs, reports, and online assessments.  The program is enhanced by links with industries that provide real-world experience for students before graduation.
Year 1: The first year of the course provides a balanced introduction to both marketing and entrepreneurship.  Students will be introduced to fundamental concepts in both areas, including theoretical aspects of business and enterprise, basic marketing principles, introductory concepts of branding and advertising, the fundamentals of digital marketing, public relations strategies, and exploring social media in enterprise and business.  Through lectures, seminars, tutorials, and practical case studies this year lays the groundwork for specialization in the following years.
Year 2: In the second year, students can choose to either continue with an equal balance of the two subjects or select a major in one of the subjects. The curriculum builds upon the year one fundamentals.  Those choosing to major in marketing will delve deeper into promotional strategies, market research techniques, consumer behavior, digital marketing practices, and branding initiatives.  Those pursuing the balanced approach will address advanced aspects of both entrepreneurship and marketing and get involved in further modules focusing on marketing and enterprise projects and business planning.
Year 3: The third year provides several opportunities in specialized areas. Students get involved in in-depth analysis of chosen subjects based on their decision of the major. Students are also required to focus on project work, case studies and individual reports to demonstrate their understanding of the core concepts studied.  Those focused on marketing may refine their expertise in specific areas like digital marketing, advertising campaigns,  marketing strategy and market research. Those opting for balanced study will complete comprehensive strategies, business models and project reports to address their skill development in both arenas.

Course Title: Undergraduate Popular Music and Entrepreneurship BA (Hons)
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For entry in 2025, typical requirements include 112 UCAS points, A-Levels BBC, T Level Merit, BTEC DMM, GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or equivalent, or a Pass Access to HE Diploma.  International students need IELTS 6.0 with at least 5.5 in each skill. Contextual offers may be available for care experienced students, those estranged from their families, refugees, asylum seekers, or those whose parents are in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or IB from International schools in Pakistan, direct entry into Year 1 is possible. Students with a 4-year Bachelor's degree (BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani university will be considered for entry.
Annual Tuition Fee: £16,900 per year (2025/26) for international students.  Full-time only.
Overview: The Popular Music and Entrepreneurship BA (Hons) is a joint honours undergraduate program that combines the creative and performance aspects of popular music with a cutting-edge entrepreneurship curriculum. Students develop musical skills in state-of-the-art facilities while gaining business acumen relevant to the modern music industry.  The curriculum emphasizes agility, innovation, and resilience in a rapidly changing global business environment.  Students learn to be self-directed, collaborative, and adaptable, vital for various careers. The program facilitates networking with local business leaders and entrepreneurs.
Course Structure: The course blends popular music and entrepreneurship studies throughout the three years, allowing students to choose a major in popular music or continue with an equal split between both subjects starting from the second year. Popular Music modules are taught through lectures, composition exercises, tutorials, workshops, and group discussions. Entrepreneurship modules utilize lectures, seminars, tutorials, real-world projects, and self-directed study. Assessment for popular music typically includes coursework, portfolios, assignments, presentations, and examinations, while entrepreneurship assessments are predominantly practical coursework assignments mirroring workplace tasks.
Year 1: The first year introduces both popular music and entrepreneurship equally. Popular music modules cover foundational music theory, performance techniques, and introductory music technology.  Entrepreneurship modules focus on foundational business principles, market analysis, and basic business planning. Students engage in introductory projects, presentations, and group work across both subjects, gaining a broad understanding of both fields before making a major decision for further years.
Year 2: Students choose to either continue studying popular music and entrepreneurship equally or to specialize in Popular Music with Entrepreneurship as a minor subject.  The emphasis on either subject will increase depending on the path selected.Regardless of the path, this year will push students to create, design, and develop. Students may engage in internships, projects, and collaborations, further developing their specialized skills.
Year 3: The final year deepens the specialization chosen in Year 2. Students refine their creative and professional skills in their chosen area. For those majoring in popular music, this may involve advanced music production, composition projects, or research. For those following the joint honours path, the focus will maintain a balanced approach with advanced projects bridging music and business.  A major project or thesis is often required in the final year and students have the potential to network into the business world.

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical requirements include 112 UCAS points.  A-Level students need BBC grades (with at least a C in English or a related subject), while T Level requires a Merit, and BTEC needs DMM.  A GCSE grade 4/C or higher in Maths and English is also necessary.  Access to HE Diploma needs a pass with 60 credits, 45 at Level 3 (minimum Distinction: 15, Merit: 24, Pass: 6), including passes in compulsory Level 3 subjects.  Contextual offers may apply to care-experienced students, those estranged from their families, refugees, asylum seekers, or those whose parents/carers are in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or IB from International Schools in Pakistan, direct entry into Year 1 is possible.
Overview: The University of Derby's BA (Hons) Publishing and Entrepreneurship is a joint honours degree that blends creative and commercial aspects of publishing with key business themes.  Students explore the publishing process from manuscript to publication, developing problem-solving skills relevant to writing, book publishing, and magazine publishing.  The course also emphasizes entrepreneurship, providing skills for starting or innovating within businesses.  Real-world learning includes live briefs, industry projects, and the option of a placement year. The program fosters strong industry links with publishers, magazines, and literary organizations. Students choose between equally weighting both subjects or majoring in publishing after the first year.
Course Structure: The program integrates publishing and entrepreneurship modules.  First-year students study both subjects equally, choosing to major in publishing or continue with equal weighting after the year. The curriculum includes lectures, seminars, tutorials, workshops, project work, technology-enhanced learning, and peer reviews. Publishing modules use a variety of assessment methods, including projects, presentations, and research, while entrepreneurship modules use methods like essays, reports, group projects, presentations, posters, and digital material design, as well as some in-class test and computer assessments. A Personal Academic Tutor supports student academic and personal growth.
Year 1: The first year involves an equal balance of publishing and entrepreneurship modules.  Students will gain foundational knowledge in the publishing process, including aspects like manuscript preparation, editing, and marketing. Simultaneously, they'll learn fundamental business concepts, entrepreneurship principles, and basic business analysis techniques. This year serves as an introduction to both subjects before students choose their preferred emphasis for the subsequent years.
Year 2: In Year 2, students continue to build upon their first-year foundation, focusing either equally on both disciplines or deepening their expertise in publishing, depending on the pathway chosen after the first year. For the publishing track, the curriculum might delve deeper into specific publishing niches such as book publishing or magazine publishing and will focus on more advanced publishing techniques.  In both specialization students will continue improving their business acumen and entrepreneurship skills through relevant projects and case studies. Students are expected to start more independent projects in preparation for graduation.
Year 3: The final year is designed for students to apply their knowledge to major projects. This may include a significant research project, an extended business plan or a major contribution to a live publishing project for graduating students focusing on publications. The independent nature of the project provides students with opportunities to showcase their developed expertise across the publishing and/or entrepreneurship specializations. Students are also expected to further develop advanced skills needed in the workforce. Students benefit from opportunities to present their work to potential employers.

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For entry in 2025, typical requirements include 112 UCAS points, A Levels BBC, T Level Merit, BTEC DMM, GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or equivalent, or a Pass Access to HE Diploma.  International students will need to meet the IELTS requirement. For Pakistani students completing A-levels or the IB from International Schools in Pakistan, direct entry into Year 1 is possible.  Postgraduate entry from Pakistan requires a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2, or a 4-year Bachelor's with Honours and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00. Students with 2 or 3 year Bachelor's degrees need a Master's degree pass. PhD applicants require a Master's and Bachelor's degree in a relevant field, plus a research proposal.
Overview: The BA (Hons) Theatre Arts and Entrepreneurship is a joint honours degree program offered at the University of Derby.  The course uniquely combines practical theatre arts training with a strong foundation in entrepreneurship, equipping graduates with skills for both creative and business careers. Students learn theatre production, direction, stage management, and performance alongside business planning, marketing, finance, and project management.  The program is highly practical, emphasizing real-world learning through collaborations, work placements within Derby Theatre (a professional venue the university owns and operates), and potential entrepreneurship-based placements. This blended approach allows graduates to launch their own ventures or work innovatively within established organizations.
Course Structure: The course blends practical studio work and theoretical learning. The first year involves an equal split between Theatre Arts and Entrepreneurship modules. Subsequent years allow students to explore specific subject areas with more specialized modules within Theater Arts (covering areas such as acting, directing, stage management, technical theatre) and  Entrepreneurship (covering areas such as business finance, marketing, and strategic planning).  Assessment methods are diverse, encompassing written assignments, presentations, creative portfolios, practical workshops, performances, and business reports.  A personal academic tutoring system supports individual student needs.
Year 1: The first year provides a balanced introduction to both Theatre Arts and Entrepreneurship. In Theatre Arts, students gain foundational skills in acting, directing, stagecraft, and theatre history.  Entrepreneurial concepts are also introduced. This year includes workshops focusing on collaborative work, devising projects, and introducing core business principles.   Students develop essential communication, teamwork, and problem-solving skills applicable to both professional theatre and entrepreneurial contexts.
Year 2: Year two allows for further specialization, building on the foundational knowledge gained in year one.  Theatre students engage with more advanced techniques in acting, directing, and design.  Possible specializations include stage management or technical theatre. The Entrepreneurship modules become more focused; students start building a business plan and study specific aspects such as marketing and sales, finance and accounting. The year may also include a work placement for either area of study.
Year 3: The third year fosters significant independent study and application of skills.  Students may further specialize in their chosen aspects of theater arts or entrepreneurship, culminating in a major project in each area that incorporates many skills learned across the course.  The year might involve advanced production work, developing an original play, or an entrepreneurship project involving business start-up or innovation within an existing organization. The combination of practical and theoretical work creates a showcase for potential employers.

Entry Requirement: For UK students, a second-class honours degree in a related scientific subject or equivalent experience is usually required.  EU/international students need the same or an equivalent qualification. If English isn't your first language, IELTS 6.0 or higher is necessary.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized university is needed, equivalent to at least a UK Upper Second Class (2:1) or Lower Second Class (2:2) degree. Students with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees must also have a Master's degree. A four-year Bachelor's degree with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university is also acceptable for Master's entry.
Overview: The MSc Environmental Assessment and Control is a postgraduate program focusing on preventing and controlling land and freshwater contamination. It emphasizes applying scientific knowledge to real-world problems and offers specialization in a crucial environmental field.  The course is accredited by the Institution of Environmental Sciences and prepares graduates for careers in government, local authorities, consultancies, and industry.  Students gain in-depth understanding of policies and strategies for assessing, preventing, managing, and controlling contamination.  Practical experience is a core component, with work placements offering hands-on training and practitioner-based learning.  The curriculum integrates expertise from various disciplines, including conservation, biology, environmental health, and ecosystems, and links theory to real-world case studies.
Course Structure: The course structure includes core modules like Contaminated Land and Remediation, and Freshwater Management.  Students also undertake an Independent Scholarly Activity, conducting original research on a chosen topic. Optional modules provide further specialization and practical experience via a placement. These options include Practical Training-Based Placement, Ecological Surveying, Analytical Methods for Ecologists, Climate Change, Environmental Impact Assessment, International Environmental Policy and Law, Flood Risk Engineering Management, and Global Energy Challenges.  Assessment methods combine coursework (essays, practical reports, presentations) and project work.
Year 1: The first year of the full-time MSc Environmental Assessment and Control program covers core modules like Contaminated Land and Remediation, focusing on contaminant sources, effects, and management strategies for sustainable environmental practices.  Freshwater Management explores water quality in different freshwater environments and its management.  An Independent Scholarly Activity module allows students to conduct original research on environmental contamination and remediation. Depending on the student's choice, one or more optional modules, such as Practical Training-Based Placement (offering real-world experience), Ecological Surveying, Analytical Methods for Ecologists, Climate Change, or other subjects, may also be included.
Year 2: NA

Entry Requirement: A UK undergraduate degree (at least a 2:2) with honours in a pure applied science (or combination) from a UK university, the CNAA or an overseas equivalent is normally required.  Alternatively, equivalent qualifications and experience will be considered, subject to assessment and interview by the Programme Leader.  Exceptional admission may be granted without these qualifications if the applicant demonstrates the potential to meet the curriculum's aims and outcomes, and has equivalent experience to a 2.2 honours degree.  Assessment will include consideration of current qualifications, experience in environmental health, decision-making level in previous roles, and motivation for the programme. An interview, employer reference, and a critical written report may be requested. If English is not your first language, you will need to meet the English language requirements. For Pakistan, students must have completed a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised University in Pakistan, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree. Those with a two or three-year Bachelor's degree need a Master's degree pass. A Bachelors degree with honours (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University is also acceptable.
Overview: The University of Derby's online MSc in Environmental Health is a CIEH-accredited program designed to equip students with the knowledge and skills needed to become environmental health professionals. The course covers a wide range of topics, including public health, food safety, occupational safety, and environmental protection.  Students will learn to assess environmental health risks, understand their impact on public health, and develop critical thinking and analytical skills to address real-world challenges. The program uses case studies and features a team of experienced practitioners as instructors.  It's suitable for those aiming to improve public health and wellbeing in various settings, from workplaces to residential areas.
Course Structure: The course consists of six core 20-credit modules and an independent study project worth 60 credits. Modules are delivered online through a user-friendly portal, enabling interaction with tutors and peers via virtual classrooms, forums, and collaborative tools.  The curriculum integrates real-life case studies to provide practical experience.  Students benefit from access to online library resources, ebooks, journals, and databases.  Advanced study skills resources are also available to support students. Assessments are 100% coursework-based and include essays, reports, presentations, group work, and case studies.
Year 1: NA
Year 2: NA

Course Title: Certificate of Credit in Environmental Impact Assessment
Entry Requirement: A good first degree in a related subject is normally required.  Applicants with professional qualifications or relevant experience may also apply.  If English is not your first language, you'll need an IELTS 6.0, TOEFL 550 (paper), 213 (computer), or 80 (internet), Pearson Test of Academic English 51, Cambridge Advanced Certificate pass, or equivalent.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised University in Pakistan equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree is needed. Those with two or three-year Bachelor degrees require a Master’s degree pass. A four-year Bachelor's degree with honours (minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00) from a recognised Pakistani University is also acceptable.
Overview: The University of Derby's online Certificate of Credit in Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) is a 20-credit module designed for environmental management professionals.  It provides a comprehensive understanding of EIA principles, techniques, and international perspectives, including strategic environmental assessment (SEA). The course covers changes in EIA regulation and guidelines, equipping students with the critical understanding of international environmental assessment practice and its potential for delivering sustainable development. The program is accredited by CIWEM, offering free student membership with access to resources, networking opportunities, and career enhancement programs.
Course Structure: The course is delivered 100% online over 10 weeks, utilizing interactive learning materials and live classroom sessions.  Students engage with tutors and peers through virtual classrooms and online forums.  The curriculum integrates elements from the Sustainability and Environmental Management MSc, giving broader exposure to sustainability practices. Assessment is based on 100% coursework, including essays, research reports, presentations, group work, and practical reports. The learning pace is designed for an approximate 20 hours of study per week.
Year 1: NA
Year 2: NA

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2025 entry, typical UCAS points are 104.  A Levels require BCC (including a C in Science or Geography), a Merit in Science for T Levels, DMM in BTECs, and a GCSE grade 4/C or above in Maths and English.  An Access to HE Diploma requires 60 credits (45 at Level 3) with a minimum of 15 distinctions, 24 merits, and 6 passes.  Contextual offers may be available for care experienced students, estranged students, refugees/asylum seekers, or those with parents/carers in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or IB from International Schools in Pakistan, entry to Year 1 is possible.  Postgraduate entry from Pakistan requires a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK Upper or Lower Second Class Honours, while a Masters degree is needed for 2 or 3-year Bachelor's degree holders. A four-year Bachelor's degree with a minimum 2.4/4.0 GPA is also considered. PhD Entry from Pakistan requires a Master's and Bachelor's degree, along with a research proposal.
Overview: The BSc (Hons) Environmental Sustainability program at the University of Derby equips students with applied skills to address current and emerging environmental challenges.  It's an interdisciplinary course allowing specialization or a broad knowledge base.  The curriculum aligns with UN Sustainable Development Goals, the UN Biodiversity Framework, and the IUCN 30-Year Plan for Biodiversity. Students learn from active researchers, gaining practical experience through placements and field trips. The final year includes an Independent Study or Industrial Project. The course emphasizes problem-solving, sustainable business awareness, data analysis, and project management, preparing graduates for a range of careers in environmental sustainability. The curriculum addresses climate change, biodiversity loss, sustainable living, environmental degradation, sustainable governance, and more.
Course Structure: The course blends theoretical learning with extensive practical experience. It integrates modules around UN Sustainable Development Goals, the Convention on Biological Diversity, and national agendas like the UK's 25 Year Environment Plan and Industrial Strategy.  Core modules cover climate change, biodiversity loss, sustainable living, environmental degradation, and sustainable governance. An interdisciplinary approach allows students to specialize or combine topics. A ‘Student Initiated Module’ enables personalized study in the final year. Students can choose to complete either an Independent Study (dissertation) or an Industrial Project involving a live industry brief.  A placement year is also an option to enhance employability and practical application of learning. Students will have access to industry-standard equipment and software, including drone technology, field spectrometers, and a Scanning Electron Microscope. Fieldwork will involve local and residential trips to explore diverse environments and witness sustainability initiatives in action.
Year 1: The first year will likely introduce fundamental concepts in environmental science, covering topics such as ecological principles, environmental chemistry, and sustainability studies. It might include introductory modules on data analysis and scientific writing, building a foundation for later specialized studies.  Students might begin laboratory work and introductory fieldwork, enhancing their practical skills.  The focus will be on establishing a broad understanding of environmental systems and building essential scientific skills.
Year 2: The second year will likely involve more specialized modules focusing on key environmental challenges. Specific topics such as climate change, biodiversity loss, pollution control, and sustainable resource management may be introduced in greater depth.  This year could incorporate a substantial work placement experience, applying theoretical knowledge to real-world scenarios and enhancing employability. This year also seems to include a module focused on Environmental and Ethics Legislation.
Year 3: The third year offers options for specialization or continued broad-based study, depending on student preferences.  Students will likely undertake independent research projects or work on applied problems within businesses during an industrial placement.  Modules such as Business and Sustainability, incorporating field trips to observe sustainability initiatives, may be a key feature of this year.  A final dissertation or major project is generally required, integrating learning from across the entire degree program. The third year will also include the 'Student Initiated Module'.

Course Title: Undergraduate Environmental Sustainability with Foundation Year BSc (Hons)
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 72 UCAS points, A Levels (DDD), T Level (Pass), BTEC (MMP), or an Access to HE Diploma. GCSE Maths and English are preferred but not mandatory.  International students need an IELTS score of 6.0 with at least 5.5 in each section.  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or the International Baccalaureate from International Schools in Pakistan, direct entry into Year 1 is possible.  Students with a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized Pakistani university (equivalent to a UK Upper or Lower Second Class degree) are eligible for postgraduate study. A four-year Bachelor's degree with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university is considered for Master's entry.  Postgraduate research (PhD) requires a Master's and Bachelor's degree in a relevant field, along with a research proposal.
Overview: The Environmental Sustainability with Foundation Year BSc (Hons) is a four-year undergraduate program designed to equip students with the skills to address current and emerging environmental challenges.  The interdisciplinary curriculum integrates theory and practical experience, incorporating the UN Sustainable Development Goals, UN Biodiversity Framework, and IUCN's 30-Year Plan for Biodiversity. Students learn from active researchers, exploring topics such as climate change, biodiversity loss, and sustainable urban environments.  The program includes fieldwork, a placement year option, and a final-year independent study or industrial project.  The curriculum directly addresses issues of sustainable governance and the role of policy in environmental protection.  Graduates develop problem-solving and critical-thinking skills, along with a solution-focused approach to environmental sustainability.
Course Structure: The course blends theoretical knowledge with extensive practical experience.  The first year provides foundational knowledge of environmental science. Subsequent years build upon this foundation, covering modules such as 'Environmental and Ethics Legislation' (including a significant work placement component), 'Business and Sustainability' (with a field trip), and a student-initiated module allowing for specialization. The final year offers a choice between an independent study or an industrial project.  The curriculum integrates key initiatives like UN Sustainable Development Goals, UN Framework Convention on Climate Change, and Convention on Biological Diversity, alongside UK national environmental plans and strategies.  Throughout the course, students utilize cutting-edge technology and software, conducting fieldwork at locations like Cuckoos Tor in the Peak District National Park, and benefitting from access to modern laboratories and research facilities.
Year 1: Year 1 establishes a strong foundation in environmental science. Students gain fundamental understanding of ecological concepts, environmental chemistry, and geological processes.  They delve into the interdisciplinary nature of environmental challenges and learn basic research methods and data analysis techniques. The focus is on building a robust foundation for advanced study in the subsequent years.
Year 2: Building on the foundational knowledge from Year 1, Year 2 modules delve deeper into key areas of environmental sustainability. Students study environmental legislation and ethics, completing substantial work placements in the process. They may explore topics such as environmental impact assessment, pollution control technologies, and environmental management systems. Data analysis and research skills continue to be developed.
Year 3: Year 3 allows for more specialization. Students can choose modules to reflect their career interests while strengthening their understanding of core environmental issues.  'Business and Sustainability' becomes relevant here, with an experiential field trip to observe sustainable initiatives in various sectors.  The focus shifts towards tackling real-world environmental problems and developing solution-oriented skills.
Year 4: The final year sees students undertake either an independent study (dissertation) or an industrial project. This provides a practical application of knowledge gained and develops professional skills such as research design, data analysis, report writing, and project management.  The student-led project further facilitates advanced subject matter study, allowing students to further tailor their capabilities and employable skill base.

Course Title: Certificate of Credit in Ergonomics and Human Factors (Behaviour Change)
Required IELTS Score: 6.5 (minimum of 6.5 in each module)
Entry Requirement: Applicants need a UK undergraduate degree or an equivalent international qualification.  Equivalent professional qualifications in a relevant discipline are also considered.  The university will also review applications demonstrating relevant practical experience and work-based training.  For applicants whose first language isn't English, or who didn't complete their highest qualification in English, an English language qualification is needed.  Acceptable qualifications include IELTS 6.5 (minimum 6.5 in each module), TOEFL 550 (paper-based), 213 (computer-based), or 80 (internet-based), Cambridge Advanced Certificate (Pass), London Tests of English (level 5 for postgraduate courses), International GCE O Level English Language (Grade C), International GCSE English/English as a Second Language (Grade C), and ASE Proficiency (Pass).  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized university (equivalent to a UK Upper Second Class (2:1) or Lower Second Class (2:2) degree)  is required.  Those with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees need a Master's degree pass. A Bachelor's degree with honors (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university is also considered.
Overview: This online Certificate of Credit in Ergonomics and Human Factors (Behaviour Change) is a 10-week, part-time course focusing on the psychological aspects of behavior change within the ergonomics and human factors field.  It examines how attitudes, values, and norms influence behavior, differentiating between behavior models and change theories.  Students learn to define behavioral problems, use a theory-driven approach to behavior change using appropriate techniques, and effectively communicate ergonomic/human factors issues to stakeholders. The course is CIEHF accredited and delivered by experienced academics with over 20 years of experience in online ergonomics courses.  It provides a structured learning experience with regular contact, feedback, and support from academic staff and online learning advisors.
Course Structure: The course is delivered 100% online over 10 weeks.  It utilizes a variety of interactive learning materials, including live classroom sessions (with recordings available if missed), online discussion forums, which facilitate the interaction between students and tutors. Students engage in coursework assessments, such as essays, research reports, presentations, group work, and practical reports.  The suggested study time is about 20 hours per week. The course includes approximately 1/2 virtual classroom sessions during the trimester.

Course Title: Certificate of Credit in Ergonomics and Human Factors (Healthcare)
Required IELTS Score: 6.5 (minimum of 6.5 in each module)
Entry Requirement: Applicants should possess a UK undergraduate degree or an equivalent international qualification.  Equivalent professional qualifications in a relevant discipline are also acceptable.  The university will consider applications demonstrating relevant practical experience and work-based training.  If English is not your first language, you'll need an IELTS score of 6.5 (minimum 6.5 in each module), a TOEFL score of 550 (paper-based), 213 (computer-based), or 80 (internet-based), a Cambridge Advanced Certificate pass, or an equivalent qualification. For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized university in Pakistan, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree is required.  Students with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees need a Master's degree pass.  A four-year Bachelor's degree with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 may also suffice.
Overview: The Ergonomics and Human Factors (Healthcare) Certificate of Credit is a 10-week online course focusing on applying ergonomic and human factors principles within healthcare.  It examines the impact of illness cognitions, health behaviors, health promotion, and long-term condition management.  The course covers medical device usability, medical errors, healthcare communication, and the implications of the 'internet of medical things'.  It also addresses clinical regime adherence and effective patient-professional communication. A key theme is shifting from biomedical to biopsychosocial health perspectives.  The course awards 20 credits at level 7 and can be part of an online MSc Ergonomics and Human Factors program or completed independently.
Course Structure: The course is delivered entirely online using interactive learning materials and live classroom sessions.  It incorporates discussions and interactions with tutors and fellow students through virtual classrooms and online forums.  Students learn alongside those in the Ergonomics and Human Factors MSc program, providing a broader perspective.  The program includes a range of assessment methods such as essays, research reports, presentations, group work, and practical reports.  The curriculum emphasizes critical evaluation of psychological theory's role in understanding human behavior and health,  understanding ergonomics/human factors contributions to patient safety, and effectively communicating ergonomics/human factors issues to stakeholders.

Required IELTS Score: 6.5 (minimum of 6.5 in each module)
Entry Requirement: Applicants need a UK undergraduate degree or equivalent international qualification, or a relevant professional qualification.  Relevant key practical experience and work-based training will also be considered.  For those whose first language isn't English, or who didn't complete their highest qualification in English, an English language qualification is required (IELTS 6.5 with a minimum of 6.5 in each module; TOEFL 550 paper-based, 213 computer-based, or 80 internet-based; Cambridge Advanced Certificate; London Tests of English level 5; International GCE O Level English Language Grade C; International GCSE English/English as a Second Language Grade C; ASE Proficiency).  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized university, equivalent to at least a UK Upper Second Class (2:1) or Lower Second Class (2:2), is needed. Overview: The University of Derby's online MSc in Ergonomics and Human Factors is a comprehensive program designed for professionals worldwide from various disciplines such as design, health and safety, healthcare, computing, engineering, and architecture.  The curriculum is developed by experts aligned with the Chartered Institute of Ergonomics and Human Factors (CIEHF) curriculum, equipping students with skills for the profession.  The program balances theoretical knowledge, research, and practical application, integrating classroom learning with independent study, group projects, and real-world case studies. Students engage in discussions, assessments, and presentations applying knowledge to their workplaces. This master's degree qualifies graduates for Graduate Membership of the CIEHF, a stepping stone towards Chartered status.  The program emphasizes human-centered design with a systems approach, helping graduates optimize usability and user experience in product and service design.  Students gain a strong understanding of human-technology-system interactions.
Course Structure: The MSc comprises three stages: Postgraduate Certificate (PG Cert), Postgraduate Diploma (PG Dip), and Master of Science (MSc).  The MSc requires six 20-credit modules (five core and one optional) and a 60-credit research project. Three optional modules lead to specialized awards: MSc Ergonomics and Human Factors, MSc Ergonomics and Human Factors (Healthcare), or MSc Ergonomics and Human Factors (Behaviour Change). Modules can be studied individually for professional development (CPD).  The curriculum integrates theory, research evidence, and practical application through a mix of group and independent study, interactive activities, readings, reflections, and assessments.  Assessments are entirely coursework-based, including reports, case studies, oral and poster presentations, and research proposals. The program is structured across three 10-week terms, requiring approximately 20 hours of study per week per module.

It's the first step towards a Master's degree in the same field, and modules can also be taken individually for professional development.  Taught by industry experts, the curriculum aligns with the Chartered Institute of Ergonomics and Human Factors (CIEHF) standards, providing students with practical skills and a strong career foundation.
Course Structure: The PG Cert comprises three core 20-credit modules (totaling 60 credits at level 7).  The modules provide a comprehensive introduction to ergonomics and human factors, covering both theoretical knowledge and practical applications. Students utilize a variety of learning materials, including online resources, interactive activities, and group work. Assessment is entirely coursework-based, incorporating academic reports, case studies, online oral presentations, and poster presentations.
Year 1: The first year of the Postgraduate Certificate covers three core modules: an introduction to human factors/ergonomics and their theoretical frameworks; a module focusing on psychological ergonomic principles; and a module dedicated to the physical aspects of ergonomics and their application in various work settings. Each module will include a mix of learning activities and assessments, designed to ensure comprehensive understanding and practical skill development.

Overview: The Postgraduate Diploma in Ergonomics and Human Factors is a two-year online program designed to advance knowledge and understanding of human-centered design.  It focuses on a systems approach to design, encompassing human-technology interactions, and offers specializations in Healthcare and Behavior Change.  The curriculum, developed by industry experts and aligned with CIEHF standards, blends theory, research, and practical application. Students engage in a mix of group work and independent study, with assessments including reports, case studies, presentations, and research proposals.  The program provides a pathway to an MSc in Ergonomics and Human Factors.
Course Structure: The PG Dip comprises six 20-credit modules (120 credits total).  Five are core modules covering foundational ergonomics and human factors principles. The final module is an optional elective allowing students to specialize in either Healthcare or Behavior Change. This specialization is reflected in the awarded degree title (e.g., PG Dip Ergonomics and Human Factors (Healthcare)).  Modules are delivered in ten-week trimesters, with approximately 20 hours of study per week recommended. Assessments are entirely coursework-based, with a mix of formative and summative evaluations.
Year 1: The first year will likely cover core modules introducing fundamental ergonomic and human factors principles.  Students might explore topics in human-computer interaction, workplace design, human error, and various research methodologies, along with foundational theory and its application in design processes.  Specific module titles in the first year are not explicitly detailed but will likely cover the foundations of the field.
Year 2: Year 2 builds upon the first-year foundations, with further specialization. Students will focus intently on the chosen pathway (Healthcare or Behavior Change). This involves more advanced modules and likely includes tackling specific complex case studies in the areas of healthcare ergonomics or behavioral change through design interventions.  Assessment will likely include in-depth analysis and applied projects in the chosen specialization.

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2024 entry, typical requirements include 104-120 UCAS points, A Levels (BCC-BBB), a Merit in T Levels, BTEC (DMM), GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or above, or a Pass Access to HE Diploma.  For 2025 entry, requirements are 112 UCAS points, A Levels (BBC), a Pass in T Levels, BTEC (DMM), GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or above, or a Pass Access to HE Diploma.  IELTS 6.0 with at least 5.5 in each skill area is required. Contextual offers may apply to students who are care experienced, estranged from their families, refugees, asylum seekers, or whose parents/carers are in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistan, students completing A-levels or IB from international schools can enter directly into Year 1. A master's degree may also be required for those with shorter bachelor's degrees.
Overview: The BA (Hons) Event Management degree at the University of Derby equips students with the management and operational skills needed to thrive in the events industry.  The curriculum emphasizes business management, entrepreneurship, sustainability, creativity, and design thinking.  Students learn to stage events, understand the visitor economy (including tourism and hospitality), and consider the social and environmental impacts of events. The program includes practical projects, real-world event experiences, and opportunities for study abroad and work placements.  Students develop skills in areas such as financial planning, marketing, HR, risk assessment, crowd management, and event safety. The program is designed to cultivate adaptable and creative thinkers who are confident in leading change within the industry. The University maintains strong relationships with local event venues and operators, providing several networking opportunities.
Course Structure: The course covers the full range of modern event management and business management skills. It explores events from diverse perspectives, considering the economic, socio-cultural, and political roles of events in society.  Students will learn how events can address civic needs and contribute to community cohesion, as well as the use of events in tourism and destination development.  Key learning areas include event planning, management, and evaluation; data analysis and presentation; business creation and finance management; team leadership; event safety and risk assessment; and project management. This is interwoven with relevant modules in finance, marketing and HR and teaching these subjects relevantly within the course.  Practical projects, including the planning and execution of both virtual and physical events, forms an integral part of the learning process.  Students will gain experience in using relevant technologies, developing proposals, working with clients, and evaluating event outcomes, through working with a range of real-world event venues.
Year 1: The first year of the BA (Hons) Event Management program lays the foundation for students' understanding of events management and business principles. It focuses on introductory concepts in event management, marketing, finance and operations, introducing core event business models. Students would get basic knowledge in the relevant subjects which would be developed in later years through more relevant modules. Students are introduced to various event types and the processes involved in successful event planning and implementation. This year would include introductory modules in areas like event marketing, event logistics, financial management for events, and risk assessment, and basic modules of business processes and principles. This year also introduces students to the basics of leading teams and building relationships with clients, stakeholders and sponsors.
Year 2: The second year builds upon the foundational knowledge of year one, introducing more specialized skills and advanced techniques in event management.  Students delve deeper into areas like event marketing and promotion, more advanced finance and cost management, and sustainable event practices.  They will also begin to work on more complex event projects, potentially involving collaborations with real-world clients or organizations. The study abroad opportunity is incorporated during this year. This is where students are expected to apply the knowledge they acquired the year before within modules, thus allowing for practical experience to gain a foothold in their careers.
Year 3: The final year of the program focuses on advanced event management strategies and specialization.  Students may choose to undertake further relevant modules based on their individual interests.  Additional advanced practical projects are undertaken, which would include complete real-world event planning and execution, requiring collaboration and stakeholder management. This year emphasizes in-depth understanding of  event concepts within different contexts, such as community-oriented events or tourism events.  Students would also finalize their event management skillset to complete their final year project, which requires them to build a more complete understanding of the subject areas in addition to the experience learned, allowing them to start developing their careers.

Overview: The University of Derby's Event Management with Foundation Year BA (Hons) is a four-year undergraduate program designed to equip students with the skills and knowledge necessary to succeed in the event management industry.  The program integrates business management, entrepreneurship, sustainability, creativity, and design thinking. Students learn practical skills by planning and managing virtual, in-person, and hybrid events, using the latest technology while working on real-world projects with local event venues. A key feature is the integration of event management with tourism and hospitality, broadening career options.  The curriculum also emphasizes sustainability, aligning with the UN's Sustainable Development Goals. The program includes opportunities for study abroad in Year 2 and a placement year between Years 2 and 3, enhancing both practical experience and global perspective. Personalized academic tutoring and career support ensure students are well-prepared for their careers after graduation.
Course Structure: The course covers a wide range of topics relevant to modern event management and business. Students learn about planning and managing various types of events (virtual, in-person, and hybrid), utilizing event technologies. Along with event management operational and financial aspects, there is also coverage of business management, entrepreneurship, marketing and sales, human resource management, risk assessment, event safety, and legal requirements. Emphasis is given to teamwork, problem-solving, adaptability, and creativity as important attributes for  success in this dynamic sector. Sustainability and its implications for event planning are integrated across various aspects of this program. The course structure is designed to provide both theoretical knowledge and practical experience through a variety of assessments, including coursework, case studies, practical projects, presentations, and potentially some online exams.
Year 1: The foundation year strengthens skills, knowledge, and confidence through comprehensive support.  It covers foundational business skills, introduces broad concepts of event management, helps students develop self-awareness as well as their abilities to work with others. Students receive mentorship and guidance to help grow their skills and abilities. The foundation year prepares students for their degree studies by helping create a solid foundation in both theory and practice.
Year 2: Year two focuses on core event management principles, including event planning, design, budgeting, marketing, and risk assessment. Students are introduced to sustainable event practices and gain experience working on hands-on projects.  This year also includes the possibility of studying abroad for a semester, providing opportunities for cultural enrichment and broadening skillsets.
Year 3: Year Three includes an optional placement year where students gain hands-on experience working in event management related organizations. Students consolidate and further develop their leadership skills as well as their understanding and ability to work within a wider team enviornment.
Year 4: The final year of the program combines specializations with business leadership and entrepreneurial skills. Students work on major projects, allowing them to plan and execute events and further refine their management skills.  Modules focus on advanced event management techniques, strategic planning, and innovative approaches to event delivery.  The final year culminates in a larger project that allows students to showcase their abilities and create their own original event concepts.

Year 1: The first year lays the groundwork for event management, covering fundamental concepts in planning, event logistics, marketing, and basic business principles. Students gain an understanding of the wider visitor economy, learning how events intersect with tourism and hospitality. This foundational year provides a strong base for more specialized study in subsequent years. It also includes introductory modules in finance and risk management.
Year 2: Building on the foundational knowledge of year one, the second year delves into more specialized areas. This year may include modules on event technology, sustainable event management, event marketing and promotion and international event practices. With the opportunity to study abroad, students gain both academic and cultural enrichment.  The year also helps students develop their leadership skills.

This hands-on experience is essential for career development, leading to improved employability post-graduation. The university offers support throughout this year.
Year 4: The final year focuses on advanced management techniques, strategic project planning, and event evaluation. Overview: The BA (Hons) Fashion Design and Marketing degree at the University of Derby blends creative fashion design skills with a robust understanding of the business side of the industry.  Students develop their design talents through practical projects and learn about branding, market trends, and commercial strategies. The course incorporates work placements, offering valuable industry experience and professional development.  Graduates will be well-prepared for careers in fashion marketing, design, and related fields, equipped with both creative and strategic skills. This integrated program incorporates elements of the university's BA (Hons) Fashion Design program. The course incorporates national and international competitions, enhancing students' practical experience and market exposure.
Course Structure: The course covers a range of modules across the three years. First and second years introduce fundamental design practices, market sensing for ready-to-wear, branding, and influencing. The focus shifts toward the commercial world in the second year. The final year enables students to pursue self-managed projects and extended essays on subjects of personal interest. The program also incorporates a work placement in industry, leading to a Diploma in Professional Practice, which helps students transition to suitable job roles.
Year 1: Year one provides a foundation in fashion design methods and market research, primarily focusing on the ready-to-wear market.  Students explore design fundamentals, learning about the industry's creative and commercial aspects. Foundational skills in market research, consumer analytics, and basic design principles are taught, building a pathway for future specialization.
Year 2: The second year deepens students' commercial understanding in the fashion industry, emphasizing branding strategy, and influencing techniques.  Students develop advanced design skills and engage in national and international competitions. Work placement opportunities within the fashion industry are a key offering of the second-year curriculum, providing students with opportunities to enhance their resume and industry connections.
Year 3: The third year provides opportunities for specialized learning and self-directed creative exploration. Students can advance their thinking and practice through independent projects and an extended essay. Modules focusing on business and entrepreneurship prepare graduates for roles in fashion management, marketing, and brand development. This culminates in student participation in the fashion show and showcasing their collections.

Course Title: Undergraduate Fashion Design and Marketing with Foundation Year BA (Hons)
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)

Overview: The Fashion Design and Marketing with Foundation Year BA (Hons) course at the University of Derby blends creative fashion design skills with a solid understanding of the business side of the industry.  Students develop design expertise while learning about branding, marketing, and the commercial aspects of fashion. The program integrates practical studio work with theoretical modules, allowing students to create and market their designs.  It caters to those interested in both creative design and strategic business marketing, offering a blend of practical and theoretical knowledge.  The course also emphasizes industry collaborations, work placements and competitions to enhance students' experience and marketability.
Course Structure: The course structure covers design fundamentals, including practical production and market sensing in the first year.  The second year introduces branding and influencing, encouraging participation in competitions. The third year is dedicated to self-managed projects, with modules in business and entrepreneurship. Industry placements are encouraged in the second year, leading to a Diploma in Professional Practice. Students have the opportunity to exhibit their final collections and portfolios at the Graduate Fashion Show and participate in competitions.  The course is heavily influenced by practice-based learning, encouraging students to explore their creativity within a commercial framework.
Year 1: Year one introduces the foundation of fashion design and market sensing for the ready-to-wear market.  Students gain fundamental design skills, learn about fashion trends, and develop an understanding of consumer needs and market analysis. This foundational year establishes the basic skills crucial for progressing to more advanced design and marketing concepts in subsequent years. Students will also likely receive introductions to design software and basic design principles.
Year 2: In the second year, the focus shifts towards the commercial aspects of fashion. Students delve deeper into branding, marketing strategies, and influencing techniques within the fashion industry. This includes learning how to utilize social media and design effective marketing campaigns.  Students are encouraged to participate in national and international competitions to gain valuable industry experience and showcase their talent.  A work placement is also encouraged in second year, providing hands-on professional experience.
Year 3: The third year provides an opportunity for independent, self-managed projects that allow students to advance their creative and strategic design techniques.  Students undertake risk-taking and experimentation that are supported by specific modules dedicated to business and entrepreneurship, grounding creative endeavors in practical commercial context.  The curriculum's innovative design enables students to utilize their accumulated skills from previous years to build a professional portfolio.
Year 4: The fourth year of this degree program culminates in a final collection and portfolio presentation. Students may write an extended essay on a chosen subject and work on self-negotiated and independent creative projects.  They are expected to build their professional network via engagement with relevant industry partners. This is a vital time for students to showcase the culmination of their skills from previous years of study and prepare themselves for professional work environment.

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical entry requirements include 104 UCAS points, A Levels BCC, T Level Merit, BTEC DMM, GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or above, or a Pass Access to HE Diploma.  A portfolio is recommended but not mandatory, and a strong portfolio may secure an unconditional offer.  Contextual offers may be made to students from disadvantaged backgrounds, including those who are care experienced, estranged from their families, refugees, asylum seekers, or whose parents are in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or the IB from International Schools in Pakistan, direct entry into the first year is possible.  Students should declare any of these criteria on their application.
Overview: The BA (Hons) Fashion Design course at the University of Derby is a three-year, full-time program focused on developing students' skills and knowledge in fashion design for the ready-to-wear market.  The curriculum covers fundamental design practices, commercial aspects of the industry, and independent creative projects allowing for experimentation and self-directed learning. Students will benefit from access to industry-standard equipment and facilities, including studios and workshops and they will also gain experience through work placements, enhancing their professional portfolios. The program includes contextual studies and continuous professional development, preparing students for a variety of career paths in the fashion industry.  Strong industry links provide valuable connections and placement opportunities with notable companies improving students' readiness for their career choices. The course culminates in a Graduate Fashion Show, giving students a valuable opportunity to exhibit their final collections and network within the industry.
Course Structure: The course is structured across three years, with a focus on foundational skills in year one, progressing to more commercial applications in year two, and culminating in independent study and major project development in year three. Year one introduces fundamental fashion design practices for the ready-to-wear market.  Year two increases the emphasis on commercial considerations and industry practices.  Year three offers independent study, facilitating experimentation and risk-taking to advance design thinking and creativity. Contextual studies and continuous professional development (CPD) are integrated throughout the program.  The program utilizes a variety of teaching methods like problem-solving, portfolio building, group work, critiques, and presentations.  Assessment is entirely coursework-based, including practical work, oral presentations, and written assignments.  Industry guest lectures, field trips, and work placements are incorporated to enhance learning and networking opportunities.
Year 1: The first year introduces the fundamentals of fashion design practice for the ready-to-wear market. Students will learn basic design principles, pattern cutting, draping, illustration, and construction techniques, laying the ground work for more advanced skills later in the course.  Students will have introductory work with various fabrics, understand their characteristics, and be introduced to basic garment construction methods.  Elements of sustainable practice and design considerations are incorporated to equip graduates with a responsible approach to fashion design.
Year 2: The second year builds upon the foundational skills learned in year one, placing more emphasis on the commercial aspects of fashion design. Students will work on projects that involve market research, trend forecasting, brand development, and collection design specifically to practice putting theory into practice.  Students refine technical skills, learning more complex construction methods, material selection, and finishing techniques.  They will have the opportunity to participate in work placements to gain practical experience and build industry connections.
Year 3: The third year allows for independent study and the creation of a final major project, which can be a self-driven collection or a fashion-related research project. Students will gain in-depth experience in working independently building a portfolio that showcases their skills and creativity for their potential employers.  They will hone their skills in presentation and communication, learning to articulate and defend their design choices while working through potential challenges.  Industry collaboration is encouraged, furthering students' network and providing access to mentorship and support.

Course Title: Undergraduate Fashion Design with Foundation Year BA (Hons)
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical UCAS points are 72, equivalent to A Levels (DDD), T Level (Pass), BTEC (MMP), or an Access to HE Diploma. GCSE Maths and English are preferred but not mandatory.  A portfolio is recommended. Contextual offers may be available for students from specific backgrounds, including care experienced, estranged families, refugees, asylum seekers, or those with parents in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistan, students completing A-levels or IB from international schools can enter Year 1. Postgraduate entry requires a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2, and a Master's degree if the Bachelor's is two or three years.  A four-year Bachelor's Honours degree with a minimum 2.4/4.0 GPA may be sufficient for a Master's.
Overview: The University of Derby's BA (Hons) Fashion Design with Foundation Year is a four-year undergraduate program focused on equipping students with the skills and knowledge needed for a successful career in the fashion industry. The curriculum blends practical studio work with theoretical learning, providing a holistic approach to fashion design. Students gain a thorough understanding of design fundamentals, commercial aspects of the industry, and professional practices. Through work placements and collaboration with industry professionals, students gain real-world experience and connections, enhancing their career prospects.  The program emphasises individual creativity while fostering professional development through portfolio building and critique sessions. Students showcase their work through fashion shows and competitions, gaining valuable exposure within the industry.
Course Structure: The course integrates studio-based practical work, design theory, and professional development modules.  Year 1 introduces the fundamentals of fashion design for ready-to-wear. Year 2 focuses on commercial aspects. Year 3 encourages independent study, experimentation, and risk-taking.  Contextual studies and professional development are ongoing throughout each year. The course includes field trips, guest lectures from industry professionals, and opportunities to participate in graduate shows and competitions.  Work placements are encouraged, allowing students to gain practical experience and industry-standard qualification. The University of Derby boasts purpose-built facilities with specialized equipment to further enhance the learning environment.
Year 1: Year one of the program lays the groundwork in the fundamentals of fashion design for the ready-to-wear market. It introduces core design principles, materials, and techniques. Students build their portfolios and participate in initial critiques, focusing on developing practical skills and understanding basic industry operations. Introductory modules in textiles, design history, and fashion business will support the hands-on studio practice. Students start to experiment with innovative ideas and conceptual thinking while developing problem-solving skills based on industry best practices.
Year 2: The second year builds upon the foundational skills developed and increases emphasis on the commercial application of fashion design knowledge. Students delve deeper into design strategy and processes while developing technical proficiency.  There will be a higher degree of project-based learning with a focus on the creative workflow process, working with professionals in the industry.  Additional modules in sketching, pattern cutting, and garment construction will further refine capabilities. This year also lays a base for the year three independent study project.
