Year 3: Year three offers a unique opportunity for individual development through a self-managed project. Students expand their independent thinking and creative practice through self-negotiated ideas, experimentation, and the resolution of complex design challenges.  Students have the chance to focus on a niche area they wish to specialize in while continuously developing design and presentation skills. This year offers additional modules in design for sustainability, design criticism, and digital media applications, further enriching skill sets. It also involves a greater emphasis on professional portfolio building, preparing students for a collaborative, real-world working environment.
Year 4: The final year is dedicated to the culmination of learned skills. This includes a major design project through which students present a series of cohesive collections and the opportunity to fully demonstrate their ability to be creative while meeting industry challenges. Students produce a reflective portfolio and are encouraged to enter design competitions. Additional modules focus on graduate employability skills, professional networking and career development strategies, including presentations and interviews.

Entry Requirement: This Foundation Degree is designed for those already employed within the sector, or recently new to the sector who have a requirement to further develop their skills and knowledge, and progress their career. Learners are employed or have affiliation with an employer and will have been nominated to attend following a review/discussion with their line manager and/or recruitment manager. Learners will have been identified by the organisation as being able to succeed on the programme.  The selection of participants is consistent with the University’s equal opportunities policies and sensitive to legal obligations to avoid discrimination on the basis of gender, race or disability. Learners can demonstrate English language capability to that of GCSE English Language, IELTS 6.0 or its equivalent as a prerequisite of enrolment on the programme. Learners will complete an application form as provided by the University of Derby and meet the above requirements. Learners must be at, or over the age of 18 upon the commencement date of their programme.  For Pakistani students, specific entry requirements are not explicitly stated on the provided webpage, but general University guidelines for undergraduate programs suggest that A-levels or the International Baccalaureate from Pakistani international schools would be acceptable.
Overview: The FdSc Asphalt and Pavement Technology program is a flexible, blended learning course designed to meet the needs of working professionals in the mineral products industry.  The program emphasizes practical application of knowledge, with assessment strategies that directly relate to workplace scenarios. It offers a strategic, holistic, and integrated perspective on the operations, finance, and commercial management within the sector, equipping learners with the skills needed for operational effectiveness in management positions and leadership roles. The curriculum addresses a range of topics necessary for successful work in the industry, including engineering principles, construction materials, business management, asphalt technology, pavement solutions, and contractual management.  The program aims to develop not only technical expertise but also leadership, sustainability, and innovative problem-solving skills vital to success in today’s evolving industry environment. The program is open to those employed in or new to the mineral products sector, seeking career advancement.
Course Structure: The program is structured in three years (part-time), covering a span of both theoretical knowledge and practical skills in the mineral products industry. Year 1 introduces engineering and mathematical fundamentals, the mineral products industry's economic and geological aspects, environmental considerations, and crucial learning and thinking skills for higher education. Year 2 delves into more advanced subjects including engineering principles, construction products technology, business and operational management, and asphalt technology.  Year 3 focuses on production facility engineering, more advanced pavement solutions and innovations, contract management, and a work-based project where students apply what they've learned to a real-world problem within the mineral products industry. The program utilizes a blended learning approach which employs a variety of techniques such as face-to-face sessions, online materials, action learning sets, and individual reflection on the learning process.
Year 1: The first year provides fundamental knowledge in engineering and mathematics, introducing essential principles of mechanics, electricity, and basic electrical circuits which are required in the mineral products sector. Students acquire an understanding of the mineral products industry, its economic importance, geological roots, and health and safety regulations.  Environmental sustainability and corporate social responsibility are discussed, with an emphasis on climate change, net-zero goals, and biodiversity. Finally, essential learning, thinking, and study skills for success in higher education are developed alongside an introduction to leadership and employability skills.
Year 2: Year 2 builds on the foundational knowledge, advancing into more specialized aspects of the industry.  Students learn about the engineering principles and theories pertinent to the operational aspects of static and mobile plant and equipment. Construction products technology provides knowledge of materials such as aggregates, bituminous mixtures, cement, concrete, and bricks. Building on this, business and operational management introduces students to the financial and human resource aspects of managing a mineral products facility. The year culminates with an in-depth study of asphalt technology, encompassing the design, testing, production, and related health and safety considerations.
Year 3: The third and final year specializes in Production Facility Engineering including aspects like lubrication, bearings, hydraulic systems, and mechanical power transmission systems. It then covers Pavement Solutions & Innovation with a focus on sustainable practices and innovations in asphalt technology, including the environmental impact, life-cycle assessment, and recycling strategies. Finally, it covers Contracts Management, exploring legal and contractual issues within the construction industry, and concludes with a Mineral Products Workbased Project, offering the students an opportunity to apply their accumulated knowledge to a real-world industry challenge and develop a coherent argument based on the issues identified and relevant academic and professional literature.

Entry Requirement: This Foundation Degree is designed for those employed in or new to the mineral products sector who need to enhance skills and progress careers.  Applicants must be nominated by their employer after a review with their line manager or recruitment manager and be deemed capable of program success by the organization. The University's equal opportunities policies guide participant selection.  Prospective students must demonstrate English language proficiency equivalent to a GCSE English Language, IELTS 6.0, or equivalent. Completing a University of Derby application form and meeting age requirements (18 or older at program commencement) are also necessary. While the University holds final acceptance responsibility, employers typically nominate students. Prior experience is significant to program design; employers, potential learners, professional bodies, and stakeholders were consulted during development.  Specifically for Pakistan, if you're completing A-levels or the IB from an International School in Pakistan, you can start in Year 1.  For Postgraduate study, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized Pakistani University (equivalent to a UK Upper Second Class (2:1) or Lower Second Class (2:2) is required. Two or three year Bachelor's degree holders need a Master's pass. A four-year Bachelor's with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani University is also acceptable for Masters entry.
Overview: The FdSc Cement Technology program is a flexible, blended distance learning course designed to meet the needs of professionals in the mineral products industry. It offers a strategic, holistic, and integrated perspective of the sector's operations, finance, and commercial management. The curriculum covers a wide range of topics, equipping learners with the theoretical knowledge, practical skills, and leadership qualities necessary for success in management positions.  The blend of online learning and face-to-face sessions allows for flexible study arrangements suitable for those working in often-remote locations.  Assessments directly apply learned knowledge to real-world workplaces, emphasizing a practical and contemporary approach to cement production and technology.
Course Structure: The course's structure incorporates a combination of subjects relevant to the mineral production industry, including fundamental engineering principles, technologies associated with manufacturing cement products, the business and operational aspect of managing a plant, and the various processes involved in the production of cement clinker. Specialized modules are incorporated in later years to enable comprehensive learning aligned with professional standards and to enhance the knowledge and understanding of learners.  The program employs varied and applied assessment methods, using practical projects, reports, presentations, portfolios, e-assessments, and problem-solving tasks to evaluate attained knowledge, skills, and competence. This course blends work-based and academic learning, utilizing face-to-face modules, workplace-based learning opportunities, action learning sets, and technology-enhanced learning.
Year 1: Year one introduces foundational knowledge in engineering and mathematics, covering basic mechanics, electricity, electrical circuits, and mathematical principles applicable to engineering and mineral products.  The "Industry Introduction" module provides an overview of the Mineral Products Industry, including its economic importance, its roots in geosciences, health and safety regulations, and emergency planning.  "Industry & the Environment" explores geology relevant to safe mineral extraction, workplace health and safety, sustainability, corporate social responsibility, climate change, and biodiversity.  "Learning, Thinking & Study Skills in Higher Education" focuses on personal development planning, learning and thinking skills, and academic study skills.
Year 2: The second year delves into "Engineering Principles & Theory," developing a deeper understanding of mechanics, heat and fuels, engineering materials, and AC electricity applications.  "Construction Products Technology" explores the technology, standards, and testing methods for construction materials like aggregates, cement, and concrete. "Business & Operational Management" covers operational, business, and financial management, human resources, communication, asset management, and sustainable business practices, also including  the fundamentals of cyber security. "Cement Raw Materials Processing" reviews the processes involved in preparing kiln feed materials.
Year 3: Year three features "Production Facility Engineering," covering lubrication, hydraulic systems, mechanical power transmission, and electrical systems.  "Cement Process Engineering" examines fuels used in cement production, including waste streams and energy optimization. "Cement Clinker Processing" focuses on grinding, blending, and cement types, including composite cements.  The "Mineral Products Workbased Project" integrates industry knowledge and requires learners to analyze a problematic area of their workplace within the context of academic and professional literature.

Entry Requirement: This Foundation Degree is designed for those employed within the mineral products sector or new to the sector who need to develop their skills and knowledge. Learners must be nominated by their employer after a review/discussion with their line manager and/or recruitment manager.  The organization must identify the learner as someone who can succeed in the program. Selection is consistent with the University’s equal opportunities policies, avoiding discrimination. Learners must demonstrate English language capability equivalent to GCSE English Language, IELTS 6.0, or equivalent.  They complete a University of Derby application form and meet the age requirement of 18 or older upon program commencement.  Prior experience is a key factor; employers, potential learners, professional bodies, and stakeholders were consulted during program development.  For Pakistani students, specific entry requirements depend on their prior education.  Those with A-levels or IB from Pakistani international schools can enter directly. Students with a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized Pakistani university (equivalent to a UK Upper or Lower Second Class degree) are eligible.  A two or three-year Bachelor's degree requires a passing Master's degree.   A four-year Bachelor's degree with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university is acceptable.
Overview: The FdSc Clay Technology program is a flexible, blended learning course designed for those working in or entering the mineral products industry. It addresses the geographical dispersion of the industry and the diverse needs of its workforce by using online learning materials supported with face-to-face sessions at the University of Derby's Enterprise Centre.  The program develops a strategic understanding of the mineral products sector, encompassing operational, financial, and commercial management aspects. Assessment methods allow for direct application of learned knowledge to workplace situations while preparing individuals for management roles. The curriculum incorporates sustainability, corporate social responsibility, and an understanding of global and environmental influences on the industry.
Course Structure: The course is structured across three years of part-time study, combining online learning, face-to-face sessions, and workplace-based learning. Year one introduces fundamental engineering, mathematics, and industry knowledge including health, safety, environmental awareness and sustainability. The second year delves further into engineering principles and theory, construction product technology, operational and business management, and clay evaluation. The third year focuses on production facility engineering, clay winning, preparation, forming, drying, and firing. A final work-based project allows learners to apply to their workplace and integrate academic learning and professional practice. Teaching methods are varied, including face-to-face modules, workplace learning, group work, and independent reflection.
Year 1: The first year covers foundational topics in engineering and mathematics, essential for understanding mineral products processing and plant operation. Learners will gain an understanding of the mineral products industry, its economic significance, and its role in society.  This includes an exploration of geology, chemistry, health and safety regulations, emergency procedures, safe machinery operation, environmental awareness, first aid, and mental health best practices. The foundational module on learning skills helps learners manage their studies effectively.
Year 2: The second year builds on foundational knowledge.  It includes advanced engineering concepts, focusing on the theory and principles of mechanics as applied to the mineral products sector, including heat, fuels, engineering materials, AC electricity, and power transmission systems.  The curriculum also includes construction products technology, encompassing industry standards, material testing methods, quality management, and customer specifications. Business and operational management concepts will be presented as well as practical techniques for clay evaluation and site investigation, including various site assessment methods.
Year 3: The third year provides specialized knowledge in clay technology. It focuses on production facility engineering, covering hydraulic systems, mechanical power transmission, gas behavior, and  electrical systems. The curriculum also includes clay winning, preparation, and forming, detailing techniques and practical applications. This is followed by the study of clay drying and firing processes, including quality control, standards, and environmental aspects. The final module is a work-based project that requires diagnosis of an organizational issue and creating a presentation of their findings.

Entry Requirement: This Foundation Degree is designed for those employed in the sector or new to it who need to develop their skills and knowledge.  Applicants must have affiliation with an employer and be nominated after a discussion with their line manager. The organization must identify them as able to succeed in the program. The selection process complies with the University’s equal opportunities policies.  Learners must demonstrate English language proficiency equivalent to a GCSE English Language, IELTS 6.0, or equivalent. They must complete a University of Derby application form and meet the age requirement of 18 or older at the program's start date.  Regarding Pakistan, the provided text does not offer specific entry requirements beyond the general English language proficiency requirement. For Pakistani students, the University's general admission requirements must be satisfied, and any additional requirements are determined by the applicant's previous education.
Overview: The FdSc Concrete Technology program is a flexible, blended learning course designed to meet the needs of professionals in the mineral products industry.  It provides a comprehensive understanding of concrete technology, from the properties of its constituents and production processes to its application in construction and the management of concrete structures' durability. The program is characterized by its agile delivery model, incorporating both online learning materials and face-to-face sessions at a corporate environment. A strategic and holistic perspective on operations, finance, and commercial management within the sector is developed. Assessment strategies are designed for direct application of knowledge in real-world workplace settings. The course equips learners to address shortcomings in industry development, strengthening their theoretical basis and practical skills relevant to modern business practices, making them responsive to change and fostering lifelong learning. It also develops leadership skills and encourages responsible professional practice, aligning with QAA Qualification Framework standards.
Course Structure: The course is structured across three years (part-time) and covers different aspects of concrete technology and the mineral products industry.  Year one introduces foundational engineering, mathematics, the mineral products industry, environmental considerations, and essential study skills.  Year two delves into advanced engineering principles, construction product technology, business and operational management, and concrete constituents and types. Finally, year three focuses on production facility engineering, concrete construction, the durability of concrete structures and a work-based project that integrates the knowledge acquired throughout the program.  The teaching methodology includes face-to-face modules, workplace-based learning, action learning sets, and technology-enhanced learning through a virtual learning environment. Assessments include practical projects, reports, presentations, portfolios, e-assessments, problem-solving tasks, and oral assessments.
Year 1: The first year focuses on establishing foundational knowledge.  Modules include Engineering & Mathematics (covering mechanics, electricity, and mathematical principles), Industry Introduction (exploring the economic significance of the mineral products industry, its geological underpinnings, health and safety, environmental awareness, and emergency procedures), Industry & the Environment (covering geological hazards, workplace health and safety, sustainability, corporate social responsibility, and climate change), and Learning, Thinking & Study Skills in Higher Education (developing personal learning skills, academic study skills, and workplace application skills).
Year 2: The second year builds upon the foundational knowledge by focusing on core engineering concepts and business practices. Modules cover Engineering Principles & Theory (mechanics, heat and fuels, engineering materials, and AC electricity), Construction Products Technology (aggregate and concrete testing, product specifications and quality management), Business & Operational Management (operational management, finance, communication, asset management, sustainable business practices, and cybersecurity), and Concrete Constituents & Types (influence of aggregates, cementitious materials, admixtures on concrete characteristics and health and safety aspects).
Year 3: The third year culminates in a comprehensive work-based project that allows integration of the knowledge and skills gained during the program.  Modules include Production Facility Engineering (lubrication, hydraulic systems, mechanical power transmission, process control, and electrical systems), Concrete in Construction (reinforced and prestressed concrete, specialist concrete types, and formwork), Durable Concrete Structures (long-term durability, crack analysis, and repair methods). The Mineral Products Workbased Project involves investigation and analysis of a problem in the industry, drawing from literature and personal experience.

Entry Requirement: This Foundation Degree is designed for those employed within the mineral extractives sector or new to the sector who need to develop skills and knowledge.  Applicants must be nominated by their employer after a review with their line manager and/or recruitment manager. The organization must believe the applicant can succeed in the program. Selection follows the University’s equal opportunities policies.  Applicants must demonstrate English language proficiency equivalent to a GCSE English Language, IELTS 6.0, or equivalent.  They must complete a University of Derby application form and meet the age requirement of 18 or older upon the program start date.  Prior experience is a key factor, and employers, potential learners, and stakeholders were consulted during program development.  For Pakistani students, specific entry requirements are not detailed on the provided course page, but general university standards may apply.  Contacting the university for details on the Pakistan admission requirements is necessary.
Annual Tuition Fee: £3,910 for UK/EU students and £4,880 for International students (2023-2024 fees)
Overview: The FdSc Mineral Extractives Technology program is designed to provide flexible, blended learning for professionals in the mineral products industry.  It addresses the geographically dispersed nature of the industry and the diverse needs of its workforce. The curriculum combines online learning materials with face-to-face sessions at the University of Derby's Enterprise Centre, fostering a corporate learning environment. The program develops a strategic, holistic, and integrated understanding of operations, finance, and commercial management in the sector.  It equips learners with the knowledge and skills needed to succeed in operational management positions, promoting adaptability to change and fostering independent learning. The program is accredited by the Joint Board of Moderators (JBM), meeting the academic requirements for Engineering Technician (EngTech) registration and partially for Incorporated Engineer (IEng) registration.
Course Structure: The program is structured across three years (part-time), incorporating modules focusing on subjects like engineering and mathematics, industry introduction, environmental impact, and various aspects of mineral extraction, processing, and transportation.  The curriculum progresses from foundational concepts to more advanced studies, allowing for a practical, workplace integration.  Each year builds upon the previous year's knowledge and skills. The program includes practical projects focused on workplaces, management and technical reports, presentations, portfolios, e-assessments, problem-solving, and oral assessments to foster deep learning.
Year 1: Year One introduces fundamental engineering and mathematics, along with an introduction to the mineral products industry including its economic importance, geoscience underpinnings, health, safety, and environmental awareness, and emergency planning.  Students also develop their learning, thinking, and study skills in higher education, focusing on personal development planning and workplace application.
Year 2: Year Two delves into engineering principles and theory, as applied to the mineral products sector, including mechanics, heat and fuels, and AC electricity. Learners develop expertise in construction products technology, covering EN standards, testing, and quality management, coupled with operational and business management skills, including human resources and sustainability.  Finally, the year covers the exploration, development and risks associated with mineral extraction and transportation.
Year 3: Year Three covers production facility engineering, encompassing hydraulic systems, mechanical power transmission, asset maintenance, and electrical safety.  It also focuses on minerals management and processing, exploring sustainable development, waste management, environmental law and blasting operations.  Finally, students complete a Mineral Products Workbased Project that identifies a problematic area and its practical application.

Course Title: BA (Hons) Film and High-end Television Production
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For entry in 2025, typical requirements include 120 UCAS points, A Levels (BBB), T Levels (Merit), BTECs (DDM), and GCSEs in Maths and English (Grade 4/C or above).  An Access to HE Diploma with 60 credits (45 at Level 3, minimum Distinction: 21, Merit: 24, Pass: 0) is also acceptable.  A portfolio is recommended.  Contextual offers may be available for students from certain backgrounds, including care experienced, estranged families, refugees/asylum seekers, or those with parents/carers in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or IB from international schools in Pakistan, direct entry into the first year is possible.  For postgraduate study in Pakistan, a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2 is required.  A Master's degree may be needed with a 2 or 3-year Bachelor's degree. A four-year Bachelor's degree with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university is considered for Master's entry.
Overview: The BA (Hons) Film and High-end Television Production course at the University of Derby is a three-year program designed to equip students with the creative, technical, and theoretical expertise needed for success in the film and television industry.  Focusing on both big-screen and streaming platform productions, the curriculum covers screenwriting, directing, cinematography, sound, editing, production, film history, theory, and research skills. Students gain practical experience using industry-standard equipment, including RED and ARRI cameras and traditional 35mm film. The course emphasizes real-world application through various projects, a potential six-month placement with the Malta Production Hub, and opportunities to showcase their work at industry competitions and festivals. The program also cultivates artistic development, encouraging students to push creative boundaries and develop their unique voices.  Graduates are prepared for various roles within the moving image sector and the wider creative industries.
Course Structure: The course structure blends practical projects with theoretical learning.  Key areas covered include screenwriting and directing, cinematography, sound, and editing. Students learn production techniques, including first assistant directing, and gain foundational knowledge in film history, theory, research, and employability skills.  The program features progressively challenging productions throughout the three years, allowing students to build a portfolio and industry experience.  The final year culminates in a film premiere event at QUAD, Derby's arts center, offering valuable networking opportunities.  The course is updated to reflect industry trends, encompassing modern digital media such as apps, web videos, and podcasts, alongside traditional filmmaking techniques.  Instruction uses diverse methods like practical work, lectures, seminars, tutorials, studio practice, screenings, and presentations. Student assessment is entirely coursework-based, involving film production, reflective essays and journals, portfolio maintenance and presentations.
Year 1: The first year establishes a foundation in filmmaking techniques and theory.  Students will learn basic screenwriting principles, fundamental cinematography, core sound recording practices, and the basics of film editing. They'll also begin developing their production skills through small-scale projects, focusing on teamwork and collaboration.  Introduction to film history and theory provides context to their practical work.  The year concludes with a portfolio showcasing their initial accomplishments and the foundational skills they've acquired.
Year 2: The second year builds upon the foundational skills developed in the first.  Students undertake more complex productions, practicing various roles on filmmaking teams.  More advanced techniques in cinematography, sound design & editing are taught, as well as aspects of production management.  The focus shifts towards exploring diverse genres and developing a personal filmmaking style.  Students will receive detailed instruction on developing a creative vision and translating that into a practical and workable project. They are introduced to the concept of developing and executing a commercial brief.
Year 3: The final year is dedicated to large-scale film production and portfolio development.  Students lead their own projects or collaborate on ambitious productions, often requiring more advanced planning, logistics, and budget management skills.  They refine their writing, directing, and production abilities while also mastering advanced editing techniques and mastering post-production workflows.  Students will also focus more on industry standards and professionalism and preparing themselves for a professional work environment.  The year culminates in the presentation of their final projects at the prestigious film premiere.

Course Title: BA (Hons) Film and High-End Television Production with Foundation Year
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical requirements include 72 UCAS points, A Levels (DDD), T Level (Pass), BTEC (MMP), or a Pass in an Access to HE Diploma. GCSEs in Maths and English are preferred but not mandatory.  A portfolio is recommended and may lead to an unconditional offer.  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or the International Baccalaureate from International Schools in Pakistan, entry to the first year is possible.
Annual Tuition Fee: UK: £9,250 per year; International: £16,900 per year
Overview: The BA (Hons) Film and High-End Television Production with Foundation Year is a four-year undergraduate program designed to equip students with the creative, technical, and theoretical skills needed for success in the film and television industry.  The curriculum covers screenwriting, directing, cinematography, sound, editing, production, film history, theory, and research. Students work on various film and TV productions, increasing in complexity throughout the program.  The course emphasizes practical experience, offering opportunities to work on real film sets, participate in industry competitions, and potentially secure a six-month placement with a production company in Malta.  The program aims to foster artistic development and encourages experimentation, pushing creative boundaries and preparing students for the multiplatform nature of the modern media industry.  Graduates will be well-prepared for careers in various areas of film and television, including production, directing, cinematography, and other related roles.
Course Structure: The course comprises a variety of modules covering practical filmmaking skills and theoretical understanding.  Practical modules focus on different aspects of film production, such as screenwriting, directing, cinematography, sound design, and editing.   Students work collaboratively on various production projects throughout their study.  Theoretical components cover film history, theory, and industry practices.  Employability skills are highlighted, preparing students for professional environments and networking opportunities. The curriculum progresses in complexity, with increasingly challenging productions undertaken each year.  The final year culminates in a portfolio presentation and the opportunity to screen work at a prestigious film premiere. Year 1 introduces fundamental film production skills; Year 2 deepens these skills and starts introducing specializations; Year 3 introduces more advanced techniques and collaborative filmmaking, with an increasing emphasis on professional practice; and Year 4 culminates in a major production project and further professional placement experience.
Year 1: The first year lays the foundation for the course, focusing on core filmmaking principles and skills.  Students learn about the technical aspects of filmmaking, including camera operation, lighting, and sound recording.  They also develop their scriptwriting and directing abilities.  Further, introductory modules might include film history, theory, and basic editing techniques.  Practical exercises and group projects might provide experience working in film crews and understanding different production roles.
Year 2: Building on the base acquired in Year 1, second-year modules delve deeper into specialized areas of film production.  Students might receive specialized training in cinematography, sound design, or editing.  The emphasis shifts toward collaborative projects, allowing students to work on more complex productions and take on various roles, from director to cinematographer.  The focus might also be on developing more advanced technical skills and understanding the intricacies of professional production workflows.  This year might include the first chance for some students to take a study trip abroad.
Year 3: The third year places a strong emphasis on pre-production and post-production processes.  More advanced production management and budgeting techniques might be taught, giving students a deeper understanding of production logistics.  Practical projects might involve larger-scale productions with larger team involvement.  It is in this year that students might have the opportunity to undergo a six-month placement, working at the Malta Film Hub and collaborating with industry professionals on live projects.  Further industry theory and study trips are also common.
Year 4: In the final year, students undertake a major production project that involves all the skills and knowledge gained throughout the course.  They may also focus on the development of their portfolios, preparing for future career opportunities and postgraduate study.  The year might include further specialization and may culminate in a screening and networking event at an established art center. The course concludes with a major independent film project representing their culmination of acquired knowledge and skills.

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For UK and EU students, a relevant Film/Writing first degree (minimum 2:2 or above), a professional qualification of equal standing, or significant practical/professional experience is usually required.  International students need equivalent qualifications.  If English isn't your first language, an IELTS score of 6.0 (with 5.5 in each skills area) is needed.  Depending on qualifications and portfolio, an interview may be required.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized university (equivalent to at least a UK 2:1 or 2:2) is necessary. A Master's degree might be required if the Bachelor's degree is two or three years. A four-year Bachelor's degree with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university will also be considered.
Annual Tuition Fee: £16,900 for the full course, N/A for part-time
Overview: The University of Derby's MA Film and Screen Production is a one-year, full-time program designed to equip students with the practical and theoretical skills needed to succeed in the film and screen industries. Students can specialize in filmmaking, documentary making, or scriptwriting.  The course emphasizes hands-on experience, using high-spec equipment and providing opportunities to work on individual and collaborative projects, culminating in a short film, documentary, or full-length script.  Students will benefit from mentorship by industry professionals, masterclasses, and networking opportunities. The program also covers commercial awareness, pitching techniques, and ethical considerations in content production. The curriculum includes modules on research methods, practical content production, and a final creative or advanced research project.  The program aims to nurture original voices and particularly encourages applications from historically under-represented communities.
Course Structure: The MA Film and Screen Production curriculum is structured across three stages. The Postgraduate Certificate stage introduces research methods and practical content production skills, encompassing screenwriting, directing, cinematography, editing, and sound. The Postgraduate Diploma stage builds upon this foundation with a more advanced module focused on research by practice where students refine their chosen specialisation. Students further develop their chosen creative practice at an advanced level, designing and undertaking a personal research project, and considering their next steps in terms of employability and entrepreneurship.  The final MA stage comprises a choice between  a creative project (in film, documentary, or scriptwriting) or an advanced research project. The creative project involves working through the stages of professional filmmaking or scriptwriting to produce a short film, documentary, or full-length script. The advanced research project allows students to engage in an in-depth critical review of the theoretical and historical dimensions of their practice.
Year 1: The first year of the MA Film and Screen Production program covers the Postgraduate Certificate and Postgraduate Diploma modules.  The Postgraduate Certificate modules focus on establishing a strong theoretical and practical base in film production through modules in ‘Research Methods’ and ‘Practical Content Production’. The ‘Practical Content Production’ module provides hands-on experience in various aspects of filmmaking, including screenwriting, directing, cinematography, editing, and sound.  The Postgraduate Diploma stage delves deeper into ‘Research by Practice’ enabling students to develop a personal research project that aligns with their professional ambitions, incorporating critical reflection and contextualization within relevant industry frameworks.
Year 2: NA

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical requirements include 120 UCAS points, A Levels (BBB), a Merit in T Levels, a DDM in BTECs, and GCSEs in Maths and English with a Grade 4/Grade C or above.  Contextual offers may be available for care experienced students, estranged students, refugees or asylum seekers, and those with parents/carers in the UK armed forces. International students need to meet specific English language requirements.  For Pakistan, students completing A-levels or the IB from International Schools in Pakistan can enter Year 1. Postgraduate entry requires a relevant Bachelor’s degree equivalent to at least a UK Upper Second Class (2:1) or Lower Second Class (2:2); those with two or three-year Bachelor degrees also need a Master’s degree; a 4-year Bachelor’s degree with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 is considered for Master's entry. PhD entry needs a Master's and Bachelor's degree plus a research proposal.
Overview: The BSc (Hons) Finance and Technology degree at the University of Derby bridges classical financial theories with real-world applications, equipping graduates with the technological skills needed in the FinTech sector.  The program explores the impact of technology on finance, including innovations in business, financial transactions, and investment management. Students develop skills in financial and economic analysis using programming languages like Python and software such as Stata, SPSS, and Microsoft Azure.  The curriculum includes topics like cryptocurrencies, blockchain, big data, and AI. The program utilizes a specialist Financial Lab featuring industry-standard software and real-world financial data. The course aims to prepare students for careers at the forefront of this growing industry, contributing to the UK economy’s FinTech growth.
Course Structure: The three-year (full-time) program offers a structured curriculum that balances foundational economic and financial principles with the application of advanced technologies. First-year covers introductory micro and macroeconomics, quantitative analysis, programming, finance and fintech introduction.  Second-year focuses on developing data expertise, explores financial markets and corporate finance, combines applied macroeconomics studies, delves into big data and artificial intelligence, and offers dedicated programming for finance.  Students may also have an optional placement year. The final year integrates a FinTech research project and includes econometrics, financial risk management, corporate governance, and portfolio management. The curriculum is subject to change and is designed to improve the student experience and employment opportunities.
Year 1: The first year introduces foundational concepts in microeconomics and macroeconomics. Students develop quantitative skills through introductory quantitative analysis modules. A crucial introduction to programming lays the groundwork for future data analysis and FinTech applications, incorporating an introduction to finance and FinTech and studying the impact of finance on business performance. This foundational year prepares students for advanced work in the coming years.
Year 2: Building upon the first year, the second year deepens students' data analysis capabilities.  This includes focused study in financial markets and instruments and an exploration of corporate finance principles. Students engage with applied intermediate macroeconomics, exploring big data and artificial intelligence, gaining practical finance-focused programming skills.  An optional placement year is also available.
Year 3: The third year culminates in a FinTech research project, demonstrating students’ ability to investigate and solve problems within the field. Students gain knowledge in econometrics, learning to interpret and analyze financial data.  They also study financial risk management, exploring best practices in mitigating financial risks and understand corporate governance, crucial to ethical professional conduct. The year culminates in portfolio management, equipping them for real-world investment strategies.

Course Title: MSc Financial Investigation and Digital Intelligence
Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with 5.5 in each skill area
Entry Requirement: At least a 2:2 from your first degree, or the equivalent. If your first degree is not in the social sciences or related subjects such as criminology, criminal justice, policing, sociology, psychology and economics, please contact the Programme Leader. If your first language is not English, you will need to evidence a proficiency in English (IELTS 6.5 with 5.5 in each skill area). Applicants without an undergraduate degree but with substantial and relevant professional experience are also welcome.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised University in Pakistan is required, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree. Students with a two or three-year Bachelor's degree need a pass in a Master’s degree.  A Bachelor's degree with honours (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University is also acceptable.
Annual Tuition Fee: £16,900 per year of study (International Full-time), £1,080 per 20 credits (UK Part-time)
Overview: The MSc Financial Investigation and Digital Intelligence is a postgraduate program designed for graduates, practitioners, and investigators interested in cybercrime, fraud, organized crime, money laundering, and terrorist finance.  The course emphasizes practical investigative skills using financial and digital techniques, applying criminological and victimological insights to policy and practice. It integrates theoretical concepts with real-world applications, focusing on UK legislation and policy while providing international perspectives. Students develop skills in financial and digital intelligence, research methodologies, and critical assessment of investigative practices.  The program is practitioner-focused, offering flexible full-time and part-time options.
Course Structure: The course consists of three stages: Postgraduate Certificate, Postgraduate Diploma, and MSc. The Postgraduate Certificate involves modules on Fundamentals of Financial and Digital Investigation and Financial and Digital Intelligence. The Postgraduate Diploma adds modules on Applied Research in Criminal Justice Systems, Financial Investigation, and Digital Investigation.  The MSc culminates in an independent study project (dissertation) allowing students to delve deeper into a chosen area of investigation under expert supervision. The curriculum is regularly reviewed and updated to align with industry needs.
Year 1: Year 1 (for full-time students) covers the Postgraduate Certificate modules: Fundamentals of Financial and Digital Investigation, providing a foundation in systematically assessing criminality and identifying opportunities for integrated investigative approaches; and Financial Intelligence and Digital Intelligence, focusing on developing standardized tools for information gathering, analysis, and ethical sharing in both financial and cyber contexts. Part-time students will complete these modules over the first two years.
Year 2: Year 2 (for full-time students) includes the Postgraduate Diploma modules: Applied Research in Criminal Justice Systems, developing advanced research skills in qualitative and quantitative methods; Financial Investigation, focusing on professional practice in identifying and remediating the proceeds of crime; and Digital Investigation, applying criminological theory to digital investigation and the use of digital evidence. Part-time students complete their Postgraduate Diploma modules this year.
Year 3: Year 3 (for full-time students) is dedicated to the MSc Independent Study, where students undertake a significant research project culminating in a masters-level dissertation. Part-time students will complete their dissertation in the third year of the program. This involves rigorous inquiry into selected topics relevant to the field of investigation under the supervision of specialist researchers.

Entry Requirement: Applicants need one of the following: HND or Foundation Degree in Accounting or Finance or international equivalent; ACCA (Association of Chartered Certified Accountants) F1-F6 or ACCA F1-F5 and F7; CIMA (Chartered Institute of Management Accountants) Advanced Diploma; ABE (Association of Business Executives) Advanced Diploma in Business Administration; IBAM (Institute of Business Administration and Management) Advanced Diploma in Business Administration.  If English is not your first language, you'll need an IELTS 6.0, TOEFL 550 (paper), 213 (computer), 80 (internet), Pearson Test of Academic English 51, Cambridge Advanced Certificate (pass), London Tests of English (level 4), or International GCE O-level/GCSE English Language (grade C).  For Pakistani students, the requirements depend on their prior qualifications.  If you have completed A-levels or the International Baccalaureate from an international school in Pakistan, you may begin the first year of the Bachelor's degree. For postgraduate study, you must have a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized Pakistani university (equivalent to a UK Upper or Lower Second Class degree) or a four-year bachelor's degree with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00.
Overview: This course provides advanced training in financial strategy, focusing on investment decisions (capital budgeting) and capital structure adjustments to maximize shareholder value. It explores the interrelationship between investment, financing, and dividend decisions in developing a comprehensive financial strategy. The program goes beyond decision-making by emphasizing the analysis of implications based on organizational objectives and broader strategic issues. It covers relevant theories, models, and practical financial tools through case studies and real-world examples, and also stresses the importance of clear, effective communication of financial decisions. The learning outcomes include critical analysis of business situations from a financial perspective, applying accounting tools to support strategic decisions, and assessing various courses of action.
Course Structure: The course covers advanced capital budgeting, incorporating real-life considerations like tax, limited capital, and inflation, with practical applications through mini-case studies.  It explores capital structure by considering theoretical models and empirical evidence and analyzing the effect of various funding sources on a company's performance.  The curriculum explores dividend policy, considering theoretical models, empirical evidence and its impact on shareholder wealth and the capital budgeting and capital structure decisions.  The course also equips students to confidently communicate the rationale and implications of their decisions. The assessment comprises 100% coursework, including essays, research reports, presentations, group work, and practical reports, with 1-2 virtual classrooms over the 10-week period.
Year 1: NA
Year 2: NA

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical entry requirements include 128 UCAS points, A-Levels ABB, T Level Merit, BTEC DDM, or a Pass in the Access to HE Diploma with specific credit requirements.  GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/Grade C (or above) or equivalent is also needed.  A portfolio is recommended. Contextual offers may apply to students who meet specific criteria such as being care experienced, estranged from their families, refugees, asylum seekers, or having parents/carers in the UK armed forces.  International students have different English language requirements as outlined.  For students from Pakistan completing A-levels or IB from international schools, entry into the first year is possible.  Postgraduate applicants from Pakistan need a relevant Bachelor’s degree equivalent to at least UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’, and possibly a Master's degree depending upon the level.  A minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University would be acceptable for admission.
Overview: The University of Derby's BA (Hons) Fine Art program is a three-year (full-time) or six-year (part-time) course designed to nurture students' artistic potential and equip them with the skills necessary for a career as a practicing artist.  It emphasizes experimentation with various media, materials, and ideas, guided by leading artists and educators.  Students benefit from dedicated studio spaces, access to state-of-the-art facilities, and opportunities for exhibitions and competitions.  The program develops both artistic skills and professional competencies, allowing students to consider diverse career paths within the creative economy, from curatorship to community arts and teaching. The program prides itself on its small cohort size, ensuring individualized attention and mentorship.
Course Structure: The curriculum is structured to progressively develop students' artistic skills and understanding. It involves studio workshops, individual and group tutorials, seminars, lectures, and visits to cultural centers in Europe and the USA, as well as national galleries and museums.  Students engage in a wide range of artistic disciplines, experimenting with painting, printmaking, sculpture, photography, installation, film, video, and digital media.  Learning is enhanced by access to cutting-edge facilities, including an Apple Mac suite, printmaking studios, darkrooms and workshops equipped for work in ceramics, wood, and metal. Regular critiques, individual and group projects, exhibitions and theoretical module contributions support the development of an individual practice. The course culminates in a major public exhibition showcasing the work of students.
Year 1: The first year introduces fundamental artistic skills and concepts, along with introductory workshops in various media (painting, printmaking, sculpture etc). Students will develop foundational drawing skills, begin exploring different art theories, and focus on personal development within the studio setting. Introduction to different cultural and art contexts will take place through visits to galleries, museums or other cultural locations.
Year 2: In their second year, students consolidate their technical skills and begin to develop a more defined artistic practice.  They will explore various artistic approaches and build upon the foundation in year 1. The programme will build upon their existing knowledge and allow for a more individualised approach to practice. Further cultural contexts will also be explored through study and visits
Year 3: The final year is dedicated to developing a major individual project, culminating in a public exhibition. Students refine their personal artistic vision, and continue to develop their practice, technical skills and wider art historical and theoretical understanding. The project allows for consolidation of previous learning and allows students to explore a specific area of their individual artistic practice.  Students also contribute to workshops, group critiques and seminars.

Course Title: BA (Hons) Fine Art with Foundation Year
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical requirements include 72 UCAS points, A Levels (DDD), T Level (Pass), BTEC (MMP), or a Pass in an Access to HE Diploma. GCSEs in Maths and English are preferred but not mandatory.  A portfolio is recommended.  Contextual offers may be available for care experienced students, estranged students, refugees, asylum seekers, or those whose parents are in the UK armed forces.  Students from Pakistan who have completed A-levels or the IB from international schools can start in Year 1.  Those with a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognised Pakistani university (equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2) are eligible for postgraduate study, with further requirements for those holding two- or three-year Bachelor degrees.
Overview: The University of Derby's BA (Hons) Fine Art with Foundation Year is a four-year undergraduate program designed to cultivate artistic potential and expertise in contemporary fine art practices.  The curriculum emphasizes hands-on studio work, experimentation with diverse media, and the development of individual artistic voices. Students benefit from small class sizes, personalized instruction from internationally renowned artists and educators, and access to state-of-the-art studios and resources, including printmaking, photography, digital media, and sculpture facilities.  The program culminates in a major public exhibition, showcasing students' work to industry professionals and the public. The university also provides personalized academic tutoring, supporting students' academic and professional growth.  The course attracts students from a variety of educational backgrounds and offers career progression opportunities within the various creative arts industries.
Course Structure: The Fine Art program combines studio-based learning with theoretical study. Students engage in a series of workshops and individual tutorials, allowing for exploration of various artistic techniques including painting, printmaking, photography, sculpture, and installation art. The core curriculum develops students' conceptual understanding of art through seminars, lectures, and individual projects.  Students have the chance to further explore a variety of paths in their artistic practice, utilising resources such as the Art and Design Library, print bureau and a digital media equipment centre. Assessment consists of studio work, presentations, and written assignments.
Year 1: The first year introduces fundamental art practices and concepts. Students engage in foundational technical skills workshops across various media, including drawing, painting, printmaking, and sculpture.  They begin to explore personal artistic expression and develop individual studio practice through guided experimentation with materials and techniques.  Introductory modules focus on developing practical and theoretical skills, building a solid foundation for future years of study.
Year 2: Year two builds upon the foundational skills established in the first year through further exploration of individual artistic expression.  In-depth workshops and tutorials allow students to continue experimentation across a wider range of media and techniques. Students refine their technical skills, begin developing individual artistic voices, and refine their conceptual approaches to art-making.  An initial UK field trip broadens perspectives and provides opportunities for engaging with art outside of the academic context.
Year 3: The third year of the course involves more advanced exploration of personal artistic expression and the development of an independent studio practice. Students further refine their technical skills and enhance their understanding of art theory through advanced modules and workshops. The curriculum includes significant studio-based project work, allowing students to develop larger-scale projects and experiment with new combinations of media. A substantial portion of the year involves developing the work leading up to the final year show.
Year 4: The final year focuses on the culmination of students' artistic development and preparation for a professional career. Students undertake a major project resulting in a substantial body of work for their final exhibition. Emphasis is placed on developing professional presentation skills, creating a coherent portfolio, and networking with professionals in the art world.  Students receive individual guidance and support to prepare for post-graduation opportunities.

Required IELTS Score: NA
Entry Requirement: This free online course is open to anyone regardless of age, location, or educational status.  There are no specific academic entry requirements.  For higher education practitioners, such as Programme Leaders or Module Leaders, working in any of the 279 QAA member institutions this course can be beneficial. Strategic Managers within Higher Education will also benefit from this exploration of digital learning.  The course is particularly relevant to those facing challenges in flexible module and programme design in the higher education sector.  Pakistan-specific entry requirements are not mentioned as this is a free, non-credit-bearing course.
Overview: The Flexible Learning Toolkit is a free online course designed to address challenges in flexible module and programme design within higher education, particularly those highlighted during the Covid-19 pandemic.  The course focuses on creating flexible learning experiences that address issues like inconsistent staff contact, poorly structured digital modules, student engagement challenges, and content overload. It uses a practical approach, providing participants with tools and strategies to enhance their teaching methods. The course is self-paced and consists of five units, each with reading, viewing, and interactive activities.  The course draws upon research and experiences from various learning modes (online, work-based, and campus-based) and offers solutions based on enhancing the overall student experience irrespective of mode of learning.  The course does not require extra reading; all necessary resources are incorporated into the learning materials.  The main outcome is the development of practical strategies for creating flexible and engaging learning environments.
Course Structure: The Flexible Learning Toolkit course comprises five units, each focusing on a different aspect of flexible module design.  Unit 1 explores the relationship between pedagogies and digital tools and technologies. Unit 2 examines learning communities across different learning modes and student/staff interactions. Unit 3 focuses on personalizing learning journeys by addressing issues such as media overload and pacing. Unit 4 tackles the creation of a sense of institutional belonging through effective communication strategies. Finally, Unit 5 integrates all previous themes and focuses on orientating students to effective digital spaces. Each unit includes reading, watching, and doing sections, allowing a more practical learning experience, and incorporates reflections from student and educator experiences. A summary section concludes each unit, providing recommendations for module design enhancement. There is also no intention for you to undertake additional reading as part of this course.
Year 1: NA
Year 2: NA

Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with a minimum of 5.5 in all areas
Entry Requirement: For this module, you must be studying or have completed the Principles of Medical Ultrasound module (or an equivalent qualification).  Access to supervised training sessions is required throughout the module, with the number of scanning hours varying based on individual needs.  A Clinical Mentor with the necessary skills and experience to assess final competence in your specialist area is also essential.  Entry is subject to discussion with the module leader and completion of a practice-based agreement.  For Pakistani students, those with a four-year Bachelor's degree (BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized university will be considered.  Students with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees need a Master's degree pass.
Overview: This Level 7 module provides initial training in a single, focused ultrasound application.  Students work closely with a service-based mentor and an academic supervisor, defining their learning needs and building a portfolio demonstrating ultrasound experience and competence. The 20-credit module involves 200 learning hours, combining self-directed learning, tutorial support, and supervised scanning practice.  Students are encouraged to attend themed study days, multi-disciplinary team meetings, and in-house training events.  The module focuses on developing skills in planning and performing focused ultrasound examinations, interpreting findings, and reporting results to contribute effectively within a multi-disciplinary healthcare team. Students will critically reflect on the development of focused specialist ultrasound services and their own role within their clinical setting. The course is designed for a variety of health professionals in diverse areas such as emergency medicine, critical care, and more.
Course Structure: The course involves 200 total learning hours, tailored to individual learning needs, and agreed upon with each student. This includes self-directed learning, tutorial support, and supervised scanning practice. Students will also have the opportunity to attend relevant themed study days offered at the University, multi-disciplinary team meetings, and in-house training events.  A significant portion will involve supervised scanning practice, the amount of which varies according to the student's specific learning needs and progress.  The course will cover practical application of focused ultrasound, interpretation of results, reporting techniques, and integration into multi-disciplinary teams.  Critical reflection on service development and personal role expansion are central components.
Year 1: NA
Year 2: NA

Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with a minimum of 5.5 in all areas
Entry Requirement: To enroll in this module, you must be studying or have completed the Principles of Medical Ultrasound and FSUP 1 modules (or an equivalent qualification). You will be expected to have access to supervised training sessions throughout the module. The total number of scanning hours will vary according to your specific learning needs. You must have access to a Clinical Mentor with the necessary skills and experience to assess final competence in your specialist area. Your Mentor will typically be based within your own Trust. Entry is subject to discussion with the module leader and completion of a practice-based agreement.  For Pakistani students, those with a four-year Bachelor's degree (BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university will be considered. Students with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees must also have a Master's degree.
Overview: This Level 7 module builds upon existing focused ultrasound experience, enabling participants to enhance their specialist skills in providing ultrasound services.  Students work closely with a service-based mentor and an academic supervisor to identify learning needs and develop a portfolio showcasing a rationale for expanding ultrasound use in their workplace.  The impact on clinical practice for service users and practitioners is assessed.  An individual learning strategy is tailored to each student, comprising self-directed learning, tutorials, and supervised scanning practice.  Attendance at university study days, multi-disciplinary team meetings, and in-house training is encouraged.  The module can be completed entirely through distance learning and requires access to supervised training sessions and a clinical mentor.  Successful completion will result in enhanced ultrasound skills within a clinical specialty.
Course Structure: The course consists of self-directed learning, tutorial support, and supervised scanning practice. The number of scanning hours is dependent on individual learning needs. The program involves creating a portfolio demonstrating a rationale for expanding ultrasound provision within the student's workplace and the impact on clinical practice. The curriculum includes participation in themed study days, multi-disciplinary team meetings, and in-house training events. Successful completion necessitates a practice-based agreement and review of utilization of ultrasound within the student's specialty.
Year 1: NA
Year 2: NA

Required IELTS Score: 7.0 (with at least 6.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 112 UCAS points, A Levels BBC, T Level Merit, BTEC DMM, GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or equivalent.  An Access to HE Diploma with 60 credits (45 at Level 3) is also acceptable.  A portfolio is recommended and may lead to an unconditional offer.  For Pakistani students completing A-Levels or IB from International Schools in Pakistan, entry into the first year is possible.  The University may offer contextual offers based on individual circumstances, such as being care experienced or estranged from family.
Overview: The BA (Hons) Football Journalism degree at the University of Derby is designed to equip students with the skills and knowledge needed to thrive in the dynamic world of football media.  The curriculum covers traditional journalistic practices such as interviewing, newswriting, and media law, while also emphasizing modern skills like video production, social media management, podcasting, and data analysis.  The course incorporates practical experience through opportunities to work with football clubs and media organizations, and includes guest lectures by industry professionals.  Students will develop a strong portfolio of work, enhancing their marketability to prospective employers. The course emphasizes the evolving nature of the sports media landscape, specifically addressing the growing demand for content across various platforms and the increasing importance of clubs managing their own narratives.
Course Structure: The three-year (full-time) or 4-6 years (part-time) course is structured to provide a comprehensive education in football journalism. Year one establishes a foundation in core journalistic principles and media practices. Year two and three allow for specialization, enabling students to choose modules in areas such as writing, podcasting, radio, TV, social media, or communications. Assessment involves producing journalistic content, including news articles, social media content, podcasts, and videos. Alongside practical assessments, students undertake essays, case studies, and presentations.
Year 1: The first year lays the groundwork for the following years with modules covering fundamental journalistic principles such as news writing, interviewing techniques, and digital media basics. It also introduces students to the legal and ethical dimensions of journalism. Additionally, students may start to develop skills in a specialized area.
Year 2: Building upon the foundational knowledge from Year 1, the second year allows for greater specialization. Students choose modules that align with their interests and career aspirations. Modules can include feature writing, social media strategies, broadcast journalism (radio and TV), and data journalism. Practical assignments and projects enable students to hone their chosen specializations.
Year 3: The final year provides an opportunity to further refine skills in chosen areas and to undertake substantive projects that showcase the learned skills.   Students engage in advanced modules, often related to their chosen specialization or broader media contexts. This culminates in a major project, often an in-depth report, documentary, or other media product reflecting their expertise.

Course Title: Undergraduate Football Journalism with Foundation Year BA (Hons)
Required IELTS Score: 7.0 (with at least 6.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement:
For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 72 UCAS points, A-Levels (DDD), T-Levels (Pass), BTECs (MMP), or an Access to HE Diploma. GCSEs in Maths and English are preferred but not mandatory.  A portfolio is recommended. International students will need to meet specific English language requirements (IELTS 7.0 with at least 6.5 in each skill).  

Pakistan Specific Requirements:
Undergraduate: A-levels or IB from Pakistani international schools allow entry to Year 1.
Postgraduate: A relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised Pakistani university (equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2),  with a Master’s degree required for 2 or 3-year Bachelor’s degrees.  A 4-year Bachelor’s degree with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 is sufficient.
PhD: A Master’s and Bachelor’s degree in a relevant field plus a research proposal are needed.
Overview: The University of Derby's Football Journalism BA (Hons) with Foundation Year is a four-year (or five-year with placement) undergraduate program designed to equip students with the skills and knowledge necessary for success in the dynamic field of football journalism. The curriculum covers traditional journalism skills like interviewing and newswriting, alongside contemporary aspects such as social media management, podcasting, video production, and data analysis.  Students benefit from industry-experienced tutors, practical workshops, real-world projects, and guest lectures from prominent figures in sports broadcasting. The program also emphasizes building a professional portfolio to give graduates a competitive edge in the job market. The foundation year provides additional support for students to build their academic skills and confidence before starting their degree, and it’s a benefit for those changing career paths.
Course Structure: The course is structured to integrate theory with practice. The first year focuses on foundational journalism skills, media law, and the industry landscape. From Year 2, students select modules tailoring their studies towards specific areas of interest such as writing, podcasting, or broadcasting.  The curriculum regularly updates to reflect industry trends, incorporating modules on esports, commentary and punditry, data analysis, social media strategies, and video journalism. Students might also undertake work placements to strengthen hands-on experience. The assessments are largely based on practical assignments: producing social media content, podcasts, videos, features, and news articles.  Essays, case studies, and presentations form part of the assessments in some modules.
Year 1: The first year focuses on foundational journalism skills, including introductory modules in reporting, writing news articles, understanding media law, and ethical considerations. Students gain hands-on experience by practicing various aspects of journalism including interviewing and scriptwriting.  Additionally, they will study the historical context of journalism and its different forms.  The foundation year is designed to give students a crucial head start in their academic and professional lives, strengthening skills and confidence with support from staff.
Year 2: In the second year, students begin to specialize. Modules covering more advanced aspects of writing, such as feature writing and sports reporting might be selected. The option to focus on specific areas within football journalism becomes available. Students can select modules that cater to their interests such as podcasting, radio, TV, social media, or communications. The course content includes practical exercises to develop their chosen areas of expertise, and they will begin to build a strong practical portfolio.
Year 3: Year 3 continues to focus on specialization, with optional modules that permit deeper exploration of chosen aspects within journalism. Students might develop a high level of proficiency in video editing and social media management, or take on additional in-depth writing modules. Students use up-to-date industry-standard technology. They may have the opportunity to participate in field trips and cover live sports events for real-world experience.  Academic assignments continue to refine their reporting and analytical skills
Year 4: The final year of the program concentrates on final projects involving extensive practical experience. Students may create a portfolio of high-quality work covering a range of journalistic mediums.  The year also integrates career preparation modules. This year may incorporate a relevant professional placement where students gain experience in a relevant field such as working for a club or broadcasting company. The course also involves presentations and potentially an extended independent research project.

Required IELTS Score: 6.5 (with at least 6.0 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 120 UCAS points, A Levels (BBB), T Level (Merit), BTEC (DDM), or an Access to HE Diploma.
