Overview: The University of Derby's MSc Health Psychology program is a research-led course that equips students with the theoretical and practical skills needed for careers in health psychology within the NHS, public, private, and charity sectors. Taught by research-active psychologists, the curriculum covers a broad range of topics, including the psychology of health and wellbeing, health promotion, and behavior change, as well as the psychology of illness and living with long-term conditions. Students develop advanced research methods skills, and undertake their own empirical research project under supervision. The program is accredited by the British Psychological Society (BPS), providing Stage One training for those holding Graduate Basis for Chartered membership (GBC), making graduates eligible for Chartered Psychologist status and Health and Care Professions Council (HCPC) registration.
Course Structure: The MSc Health Psychology curriculum integrates research-led teaching with applied assessments.  Core modules provide a foundational understanding of health psychology principles, exploring the psychological factors impacting health, illness, and wellbeing across the lifespan. Students delve into health promotion and behavior change strategies, learn advanced research methods, and critically analyze existing literature through systematic reviews and other applied assessments.  A key feature is an independent research project, allowing students to specialize in an area of interest and develop their research skills.  The course emphasizes professional development, including modules that focus on clinical and professional skills relevant to the field.  Assessments are diverse, and include oral presentations, intervention reports, and reflective portfolios.
Year 1: Full-time students complete the MSc Health Psychology program within one year.The first year encompasses core modules such as Psychology of Health and Wellbeing, exploring the historical, social, and political contexts of health psychology. Health Promotion and Behaviour Change investigates factors influencing health behavior and psychological interventions. Psychology of Illness examines the interplay between psychological and physiological factors in illness and symptom response, and their implications for healthcare utilization. Living with Long Term Conditions explores psychological aspects of managing long-term health conditions and their impact on individuals and social networks.  Students develop advanced research methods in Advanced Psychological Research Methods in Context, build clinical and professional skills, and undertake an Empirical Research Project, leading to a substantial independent research study.
Year 2: Part-time students complete the program over two years.  The second year would mirror the remaining modules from the first year depending on the student's learning pathway and module choices.  The focus is on deepening the understanding and application of core health psychology principles. For example students are provided opportunities to strengthen their research skills, refine their clinical and professional skills, and complete their individual research project.

Entry Requirement: Normally, a 2:1 Honours Degree in Psychology recognised by the British Psychological Society for Graduate Basis for Chartership (GBC) is required.  A 2:2 Honours Degree in Psychology with GBC may be accepted with a satisfactory interview. Related disciplines (mental health, public health, joint honours with psychology) with a minimum 2:1 Honours may be considered with relevant work experience or evidence of Level 7 study.  Applicants from overseas with non-BPS accredited degrees should apply to the BPS for recognition.  For Pakistan, students need a relevant Bachelor’s degree equivalent to a UK Upper or Lower Second Class degree. A Master's degree is also needed if the Bachelor's was a two or three-year program. A four-year Bachelor's degree with honours (minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00) from a recognized Pakistani university will also be considered.
Duration: 2-3 years (2 years with accelerated pace of study)
Overview: The University of Derby's online MSc in Health Psychology is a comprehensive postgraduate program designed to equip students with the theoretical knowledge and practical skills needed to excel in the field.  The curriculum is research-informed and covers a wide range of topics within health psychology, including the theoretical underpinnings, professional issues, and contemporary challenges. Students learn through a combination of live online sessions, pre-recorded videos, interactive online spaces, guest lectures, and independent study. This course is accredited by the British Psychological Society (BPS), providing Stage One Health Psychology professional training, a vital prerequisite for Stage Two training and registration as a health psychologist with the Health and Care Professions Council (HCPC). The program focuses on applying psychological principles to promote health, prevent illness, and support individuals coping with physical health conditions. Graduates are prepared for diverse career opportunities within the NHS, public, private, and charity sectors.
Course Structure: The MSc Health Psychology comprises six core 20-credit modules and a 60-credit Empirical Research Project, totaling 180 credits. Module order depends on the intake (September or January). The curriculum covers core elements of relevant and structured content, a variety of learning activities, and feedback. Students engage with weekly study materials, attend live online webinars, and complete assessments such as essays, presentations, developing health promotion resources, intervention reports, and research project reports.  The program also incorporates Personal Development Planning (PDP) to help students reflect on their learning and career development.  The program includes support for students, whether new to online learning or returning to study.
Year 1: Year 1 (for the 3-year part time option) involves completing one 20-credit module per trimester.  Students study core concepts in health psychology, exploring theoretical frameworks and applying them to real-world scenarios.  The exact modules vary based on the course structure and intake (September or January).  Students will develop foundational research skills and begin to engage with a range of assessment methodologies.
Year 2: Year 2 (for the 3-year part-time option) also involves completing one 20-credit module per trimester.  This builds on the foundation from Year 1, delving into more specialized areas of health psychology.  The focus will increasingly involve applied aspects of health psychology, potentially with work placements or projects related to specific health settings and populations. If following the accelerated study, students may cover two modules per trimester, accelerating their progress towards the final stage of the course.
Year 3: Year 3 (for both 3-year part-time and accelerated options) involves completing the 60-credit empirical research project. Students undertake a significant research project, allowing them to apply their acquired knowledge and skills to a chosen area of interest within health psychology. This project typically involves literature review, data collection, and analysis, culminating in a substantial written thesis or dissertation.  This year is crucial for developing advanced research skills and demonstrating competency in the field.

Overview: The BA (Hons) History and Business Management is a joint honours degree that allows students to explore both disciplines equally in the first year before choosing a major or minor in one subject. The program combines historical analysis of the early modern and modern periods with a practical approach to business and management principles.  Students will learn how businesses operate, exploring the practical application of business through real-world learning opportunities like live briefs and projects set by industry partners.  The course boasts Chartered Management Institute accreditation, enhancing graduate prospects. The unique structure allows for tailored learning, catering to students' interests and career goals.
Course Structure: The course structure involves a combination of mandatory and optional modules across history and business management.  Students start by exploring both subjects equally in the first year. History modules might cover topics like the Enlightenment, material culture, and global history, employing varied assessments to develop key historical and transferable skills. Business management modules focus on practical application, using industry links for real-world learning. Assessments might include reports, digital material design, in-class tests, and portfolio work. The optional module choices provide flexibility for specialization in history or business management, allowing students to align their degree with their career aspirations.  A placement year is optional, boosting employment prospects.
Year 1: The first year provides a balanced introduction to both history and business management.  Students will engage with fundamental concepts in both fields, laying a foundation for further specialization.  History modules may cover introductory aspects of historical analysis, key historical periods, and research methodologies.  Business management modules will address core business principles, including fundamental accounting, marketing and management theories. The assessment methods will incorporate a variety of techniques to evaluate both historical analytical skills and business managerial abilities.
Year 2: In the second year, students will delve deeper into their chosen specializations, either continuing an equal balance of history and business management or specializing in one area.  History modules will explore more specialized areas of interest in greater depth,potentially including advanced research methodologies and historiography within their specialization. Business management modules will focus on more advanced topics relevant to the selected areas of specialization or the chosen pathway, giving opportunities for greater business understanding and practical application.
Year 3: The final year allows further refinement of specialized knowledge.  Students engage in advanced modules, strengthening their chosen focus in either history or business management.  A capstone project or dissertation might be a major component,culminating in a substantial piece of independent work that demonstrates deep understanding and advanced skills.  This final year helps the graduates develop advanced skills and prepare them for entry into the workforce or further studies.

Overview: The University of Derby's History and Criminology joint honors degree program offers a unique blend of historical analysis and criminological theory and practice. Students explore the intersection of crime as an individual and social phenomenon, examining various aspects of the criminal justice system, including imprisonment, probation, policing, and youth justice. The historical component delves into the rich history of Derby and Derbyshire, examining key themes and ideas from the 16th century to the present day, with a focus on England's social, economic and cultural aspects. The program fosters critical thinking, research skills, and practical experience.
Course Structure: The program begins with equal study in both History and Criminology in the first year.  Students choose in the second year if they wish to major or minor in either subject or continue with an equal split.  Modules vary based on the chosen pathway (History and Criminology equally, History with Criminology, or Criminology with History).  Learning involves a variety of methods including lectures, seminars, tutorials, group work, independent study, workshops, study visits, and co-curricular learning, with assessments including coursework, portfolios, projects/presentations, and possibly examinations, depending on the moduless.  The History assessments emphasize key historical skills, research, public history, and global contexts. The Criminology assessments use interviewing, negotiation and problem-based learning.  There is a Personal Academic Tutoring program offering support.
Year 1: The first year involves equal study of both History and Criminology. Students are introduced to foundational concepts in both disciplines. In Criminology, this might include introductory criminological theories, the study of crime and deviance, and an understanding of the criminal justice system.  In History, this could cover periods such as the Enlightenment or the broader social structure of British society. The year aims to provide a solid base in both subjects, allowing students to make an informed decision about their preferred emphasis in later years.
Year 2: In the second year, students can select to either major in one subject or maintain an equal split in both History and Criminology. The modules available would differ based on the chosen specialization. If majoring in Criminology, this could involve deeper thematic study, such as forensic psychology, victimology, or rehabilitation. If majoring in History, students continue to examine historical concepts and events, perhaps learning marketing & writing history, global mobility, or specific periods in greater detail. Those students maintaining an equal course load continue to take modules in both fields to sustain their education in both subjects.
Year 3: The final year will build upon the knowledge and skills acquired in previous years. Students will likely focus on their chosen major and have more specialization or advanced modules. If they chose to major in Criminology, modules could explore topics such as crime prevention or criminal justice policy. Students majoring in History might delve into specialized areas such as digital humanities, historical methodology, or a broader thematic study across selected periods. Those who maintain an equal course load will have a final year divided between the subjects in a relevant fashion.

Overview: The BA (Hons) History and Education Studies is a joint honours degree offered by the University of Derby, allowing students to explore both history and education in depth.  Students begin by studying both subjects equally in the first year, then can choose to major or minor in one subject or continue with an equal split.  The course blends theoretical learning with practical elements including fieldwork at historical sites, collaborations with heritage organizations, and work placements, enhancing employability.  The curriculum explores British, European, and global history, while the education studies component examines education's societal role, moral and social issues, and equality.  Assessment is non-exam based, focusing on developing research, presentation, and teamwork skills.
Course Structure: The program consists of modules covering both history and education studies.  In the first year, students study both subjects equally; in subsequent years, they can choose a major or minor or maintain the 50/50 split. Modules may include aspects of British, European and global history from Renaissance times to the 21st century. The education modules cover topics such as early years education, lifelong learning, education within society, social equality, educational psychology and philosophy and the practical applications of teaching and education.  Students will be assessed through various means such as essays, research projects, seminar debates, presentations, and conference papers.  The program emphasizes developing research and analytical skills through individual and group projects.
Year 1: The first year involves an equal study of both History and Education Studies. Introductory modules in both subjects would provide a solid foundation. In History, this may include the study of major periods and themes.  Education Studies would introduce fundamental concepts that shape learning and education, potentially including early childhood education principles.
Year 2: In year two, students choose their major or minor discipline. Those equally studying history and education will deepen knowledge in both fields and may take advanced modules in subjects such as 18th and 19th century British History, which might include analysis of gender history alongside modules focused on aspects of modern education such as pedagogic approaches, ethics, and diversity.   This year may also include the practical component of work experience or placements.
Year 3: The final year allows students to specialize further in their chosen major or continue to study history and education equally.  This might involve significant independent research projects, focusing on specific historical periods or educational theories that they can present at a conference, alongside modules that bring together different perspectives from history, psychology, sociology, and philosophy for the major subject.

The program develops critical thinking, analytical, and research skills applicable to a wide range of careers.  The History component explores key themes and ideas within a global context, while the Sociology component focuses on contemporary social issues, inequalities, and power dynamics. Course Structure: The course structure comprises modules spanning across three academic years. Postgraduate entry from Pakistan requires a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2, and a Master's pass if the Bachelor's is 2 or 3 years. A 4-year honors Bachelor's degree with a minimum 2.4/4.0 GPA also qualifies for Masters admission.
Overview: The University of Derby's History with Foundation Year BA (Hons) is a four-year undergraduate program designed to equip students with a strong understanding of historical analysis and research skills.  The foundation year provides extra support and skill-building for students before progressing to the main BA (Hons) degree. The course emphasizes both British and global history, from the Renaissance to the 20th century, covering a diverse range of topics, such as the Enlightenment, Totalitarianism, and the history of non-European societies, including China and India. Students benefit from fieldwork at historical sites, practical experience through public history projects, and dedicated support from renowned faculty experts.  The program combines coursework assessments with opportunities to engage with the wider community through research and conference organization.
Course Structure: The course is structured across four years, beginning with a foundation year designed to bolster students' skills and confidence before starting the BA (Hons) program.  The remaining three years focus on core areas of historical study, covering both British, European and global history. Modules cover a wide range of historical topics and periods, including, but not limited to the Enlightenment, Totalitarianism, the history of the body, British Country Houses and non-European history such as the history of China and India. The program employs a 100% coursework assessment system, with a variety of assessment types including essays, document analysis, material culture examination, projects, presentations, and conference organization.  There are no exams.
Year 1: The foundation year focuses on developing essential academic skills and providing a broad introduction to History. Students receive extensive support to build their knowledge and confidence in historical analysis and research methods.  This includes foundational modules, such as those in historical theory that will serve as building blocks as they progress to subsequent years.
Year 2: Year two marks the beginning of the undergraduate coursework in History. Students will be introduced to a range of subjects across the broad spectrum of British, European and World History. Specific subjects vary but students can expect to encounter module topics concerning British, European and Global themes and will begin to explore more specialized modules depending on elective choices.
Year 3: The third year builds on the knowledge gained in earlier years, with a greater emphasis on independent research and specialized modules.  Students will have the opportunity to specialize in particular historical areas or periods of greater interest to them, developing their research skills with larger projects and perhaps preparing for conference or exhibition work.  The program emphasizes engagement with primary sources and refining research methodologies.
Year 4: The final year focuses on dissertation work, enabling students to conduct in-depth research on a chosen topic of specialization. This year allows students to showcase their historical analysis capabilities, research skills, and creative interpretation of historical events.  It also represents a chance to refine skills in presentation and public engagement, perhaps through conference organization and public presentation of their work.

Course Title: University Diploma in Hospitality Business Management
Entry Requirement: Applicants need one of the following: a Level 4 qualification (e.g., HE Certificate) in hospitality or a relevant subject (tourism, business, or management) plus at least one year of relevant industry experience; a Level 5 qualification in a non-relevant subject area with two or more years of hospitality experience; or a Level 3 qualification with over two years of hospitality experience.  Those not meeting these criteria may be considered based on relevant professional experience.  Regarding Pakistan,  students completing A-levels or the International Baccalaureate from Pakistani international schools can start the first year of a Bachelor's degree. For postgraduate studies, a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2 degree is needed;  students with two- or three-year Bachelor's degrees also need a Master's degree pass; and a four-year Bachelor's degree with honors (minimum 2.4/4.00 GPA) is required for Master's admission.
Overview: The University Diploma in Hospitality Business Management is a 12-month online program designed for working hospitality professionals aiming for senior management roles.  It enhances analytical, digital literacy, and communication skills applicable to the workplace. The course builds confidence, deepens understanding of the hospitality sector, and contributes to continued professional development (CPD).  Students benefit from flexible online learning and can use real-world experiences through assignments.Successful completion allows progression to a BA (Hons) International Hospitality Business Management (Top-Up) degree.
Course Structure: The program consists of three 20-credit modules, each lasting 10 weeks and requiring approximately 20 hours of weekly study. Modules cover various aspects of hospitality business management, incorporating a range of assessment methods, including essays, research reports, presentations, group work, and practical reports.  The specific order and content of the modules will depend on student's start date (September, January, or May) and are subject to change to enhance student experience and career prospects.  The modules provide students with the skills and knowledge to advance in the hospitality industry.
Year 1: The first year of this program comprises three modules covering essential aspects of hospitality business management.  Topics will vary slightly depending on when the student commences the modules, but likely will include core management principles, strategic thinking relevant to the hospitality sector, operational procedures and advanced digital skills necessary for the modern hospitality environment. The modules are designed to be practical and relevant to the workplace, and assessment will reflect this, with a variety of coursework to build upon and demonstrate the theoretical and practical learning.  There will be opportunities to use real-world workplace examples in assignments.
Year 2: NA

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For entry in 2025, typical requirements include 104 UCAS points.  A-Level students need BCC, with at least a C in Biology, Human Biology, or Chemistry.  T Level students require a Merit in Science, while BTEC students need DMM.  GCSE Maths and English grades of 4/C or above are necessary.  Access to HE Diploma requires a pass with 60 credits at Level 3, including distinctions. International students might need an IELTS score of 6.0 with at least 5.5 in each skill.  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or IB from international schools in Pakistan, direct entry into the first year is possible.  Contextual offers may be given to students from disadvantaged backgrounds such as care experienced students, estranged students, refugees, or those with parents in the UK armed forces. Students must declare this on their application.
Overview: The University of Derby's BSc (Hons) Human Biology course provides a comprehensive foundation in human biology, focusing on improving health and well-being.  Students gain expertise in human physiology, anatomy, biochemistry, genetics, and medical microbiology, exploring disease causes, diagnosis, and treatment.  The curriculum delves into lifestyle factors affecting health, such as physical activity, smoking, and infectious diseases.  Students can tailor their studies with specialist modules in bioscience, psychology, and sports science and benefit from placement opportunities at organizations like the Leukaemia Research Foundation. The program emphasizes employability skills, with opportunities for internships, live projects, and research participation.  Lecturers are research-active, bringing current theories to the classroom. The course is accredited by the Royal Society of Biology, leading to Associate Membership upon graduation. The course also features state-of-the-art facilities including the Facility for Omics Research in Metabolism (FORM).
Course Structure: The course combines lectures, seminars, tutorials, and e-learning with hands-on laboratory practicals. Assessment involves written assignments (data analysis, portfolios, practical reports), computer-based assessments, essays, experimental reports, case studies, and presentations.  The final year includes an in-depth research project on a human health theme.  Students can choose optional modules in areas like bioscience, sports science, and psychology, aligning their studies with career aspirations.  Guest speakers and a Human Biology Society enhance the learning experience. The program also includes a Personal Academic Tutoring system aimed at supporting students' academic and personal growth.
Year 1: First-year modules will likely cover fundamental aspects of human biology, including introductory anatomy and physiology, basic biochemistry principles, basic genetics and cell biology, and an introduction to microbiology.  The curriculum also builds a foundation in medical terminology and research methods, providing the building blocks for more specialized topics in later years.  Students will also gain experience in the lab through practical assignments and experiments.
Year 2: The second year builds on the foundation of year one, moving into more specialized areas within human biology.  Students can expect modules covering advanced physiology, focusing on specific organ systems and their functions, alongside more advanced modules on molecular biology techniques.  The curriculum often includes modules on microbiology, immunology, or genetics and may delve into specific areas such as disease pathways and mechanisms.  Students may have opportunities to partake in research projects or work placements to gain practical experience.
Year 3: The final year allows for greater specialization and independence. Students will typically undertake an extensive research project, applying their acquired knowledge to a specific area of interest in human biology; areas of focus might include infectious disease, genetic disorders, or environmental influences on health.  Modules will allow students to delve into more depth into advanced topics selected to suit their interests and career goals. The final year project involves substantial research, data analysis, and presentation of findings, preparing students for professional settings.

Course Title: Undergraduate Human Biology with Foundation Year BSc (Hons)
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For entry in 2025, typical requirements include 72 UCAS points, A Levels (DDD), a T Level pass, BTEC (MMP), or a pass in an Access to HE Diploma. GCSEs in Maths and English are preferred, but if not available, Level 2 Maths and English can be completed as part of the course.  International students need an IELTS score of 6.0 with at least 5.5 in each skill area.  For Pakistani students, A-levels or IB from Pakistani international schools allow direct entry into Year 1. For postgraduate study, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized Pakistani university is needed, equivalent to at least a UK 2:1 or 2:2. A Master's degree is needed if the Bachelor's lasted 2-3 years.  A four-year Bachelor's with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 is acceptable. PhD applicants require a Master's and Bachelor's degree in the relevant subjects, and a research proposal is necessary.
Annual Tuition Fee: UK: £9,250 per year; International: £16,900 per year
Overview: The Human Biology with Foundation Year BSc (Hons) is a four-year undergraduate program designed to equip students with a strong foundation in bioscience and prepare them for careers in healthcare, medical research, and related fields.  The course focuses on human physiology, anatomy, biochemistry, genetics, and medical microbiology, providing insights into the causes, effects, and treatments of human diseases.  Students develop practical skills in laboratory settings, including work with advanced equipment such as scanning electron microscopes and high-performance liquid chromatography. The program includes a foundation year to strengthen skills and knowledge, and opportunities for work placements and research projects. Students benefit from expert, industry-relevant teaching and close academic support through a personal academic tutor program.  The program is accredited by the Royal Society of Biology, enhancing graduate employment prospects.
Course Structure: The course comprises a foundation year followed by three years of honours degree study. The foundation year builds a solid base in biology and related areas. The honours years cover core modules in human physiology, anatomy, biochemistry, genetics, and medical microbiology.  Specialized, optional modules in bioscience, sports science, and psychology allow students to tailor their studies toward particular interests and career paths. A significant component is the final year's in-depth research project focusing on a health-related theme.  Throughout, students benefit from hands-on laboratory work, guest lectures from professionals, and potential research assistantships.
Year 1: The foundation year focuses on providing a firm grounding in fundamental biological principles and study skills.  It helps students develop the necessary knowledge and confidence to transition into the more advanced stages of the degree.  The curriculum would incorporate introductory modules to core biological subjects but at a pace which allows for development of confidence and successful transition into year two. Specific module names are not available, but expect foundational biology, chemistry, and possibly mathematics content.
Year 2: Year 2 delves into core human biology subjects, building on the foundation year.  Expect modules covering human anatomy, physiology, and biochemistry in more depth.  Introductory modules on genetics and microbiology are also likely to be covered and serve as precursors for later advanced modules in these subjects. Students may start exploring optional modules aligned with their individual interests, and they might also begin applying for work placement opportunities.
Year 3: During year 3, students continue expanding their knowledge in human biology.  More sophisticated modules in genetics and medical microbiology would be introduced, and a deeper understanding of the pathophysiology of various diseases would be expected.  Students would likely have more opportunity to choose optional modules suitable for career ambitions, and they might begin planning their final-year research project.
Year 4: The final year culminates in a substantial research project allowing students to apply their acquired knowledge and practical skills to an independent scientific investigation.  They continue studying specialized modules chosen in previous years and may complete a work placement.

Course Title: PG Dip Human Resource Management (CIPD accredited)
Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with a minimum of 5.5 in all areas
Entry Requirement: Applicants usually need a minimum of a 2:2 undergraduate degree or equivalent.  Relevant work experience is also required. For those whose first language isn't English, an IELTS score of 6.5 is necessary.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized university, equivalent to at least a UK Upper Second Class (2:1) or Lower Second Class (2:2) degree is needed. Students with a two or three-year Bachelor's degree must also have a Master's degree.  A four-year Bachelor's degree with honors (minimum GPA 2.4/4.00) from a recognized Pakistani university is also acceptable.
Overview: The postgraduate diploma in Human Resource Management is a CIPD-accredited program designed for HR professionals and general managers seeking to enhance their skillset.  The course focuses on developing HRM strategies, policies, and procedures within a dynamic business context, emphasizing practical problem-solving and adding competitive advantage. Students gain a deep understanding of organizations, management, and external challenges, utilizing current research, and case studies with an international perspective.  The program facilitates networking opportunities with HR professionals and provides a pathway to Chartered Membership of the CIPD, boosting professional profile and career prospects.   The curriculum integrates real-world scenarios, workplace experiences, and projects relevant to students' roles, enabling them to contribute immediately to their organizations.  The course emphasizes career development planning, including a personal tutor to assist in skill development.
Course Structure: The Postgraduate Diploma comprises two stages: a Postgraduate Certificate and a Postgraduate Diploma. The Postgraduate Certificate introduces core HR concepts, including professional practice (leadership, critical thinking, financial management), international HR contexts, and leading, managing, and developing people. The Postgraduate Diploma builds upon this foundation with modules on international resourcing and talent development (talent management strategies, learning and development), advanced diversity and inclusion (strategic workplace diversity and inclusion, legal compliance), and strategic employment relations (employment relations perspectives, power and authority).  Assessment is entirely coursework-based, reflecting real-world scenarios.
Year 1: Year 1 (Postgraduate Certificate) focuses on foundational HRM concepts. Students develop analytical tools and techniques for enhancing professional development and adding business value.  Core modules examine human resource management in international contexts, exploring organizational structures and global influences on HR practices.  Leadership, ethical considerations, change management approaches, engagement strategies, and teamwork are also significant elements in this year.
Year 2: Year 2 (Postgraduate Diploma) delves into advanced HRM topics.  Students explore various talent management strategies for attracting, developing, and retaining high-potential employees.  This involves understanding learning and development interventions and evaluating impact.  The curriculum also covers advanced diversity and inclusion initiatives, analyzing workplace behavior, legislation, and promoting a fair work culture.  Strategic employment relations are covered, exploring different perspectives, power dynamics, conflicts, institutional roles, and collaborations with trade unions.

Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with 5.5 in each skill area
Entry Requirement: A minimum of a 2:2 undergraduate degree or equivalent is required. Relevant work experience is also expected. For those whose first language is not English, an IELTS score of 6.5 with at least 5.5 in each skill is mandatory.  For students from Pakistan, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized university, equivalent to at least a UK 'Upper Second Class (2:1)' or 'Lower Second Class (2:2)' degree, is needed.  Those with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees must also have a Master's degree. A Bachelor's degree with honors (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university is acceptable for Master's entry.
Overview: The University of Derby's MSc in Human Resource Management is a postgraduate program designed for both specialist HR practitioners and general managers seeking to enhance their HRM skills.  The course emphasizes the impact of HR strategies on organizational performance across various sectors.  It integrates HRM within the broader context of business, management, and corporate strategy, incorporating current research, case studies, and international perspectives.  Students will develop skills in strategic HRM, policy development, change management, and talent development. A key feature is the application of learning to real-world workplace scenarios, maximizing the impact of the qualification. The program provides a pathway towards Chartered Membership of the CIPD, enhancing career prospects.
Course Structure: The MSc Human Resource Management is structured in three stages: Postgraduate Certificate, Postgraduate Diploma, and MSc. The Postgraduate Certificate introduces core HR concepts and professional development skills, covering topics like leadership, financial management, and international HRM perspectives. The Postgraduate Diploma builds upon this foundation with modules on international resourcing, diversity and inclusion, and strategic employment relations. Finally, the MSc stage involves completing independent study including a research project relevant to the student's workplace or area of interest.  Assessment methods include coursework, scenario-based assignments, and a dissertation.
Year 1: The first year of the full-time MSc HRM program covers foundation modules introducing core HR principles and professional development. Subjects include developing professional practice, focusing on enhancing analytical tools and techniques to improve work effectiveness; human resource management in an international context, exploring the influence of globalization on HRM; and leading, managing and developing people, a critical analysis of contemporary talent management trends.  Students begin to apply their knowledge to work-based scenarios.
Year 2: The second year (part-time) focuses on advanced HRM concepts and specializations.  Modules include international resourcing and talent development, focusing on attracting, developing and engaging high-potential employees. This will also include advanced diversity and inclusion strategy and policy development and implementation, and the employment relation strategies. The year concludes with the dissertation which can focus on a range of issues.

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical entry requirements include 96 UCAS points.  Equivalent qualifications are accepted, such as CCC at A-Level, a pass (C and above) at T-Level, MMM at BTEC, and a pass in the Access to HE Diploma with specific credit distributions. GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/Grade C (or above) are also required.  A portfolio is recommended. Contextual offers may apply to students who are care experienced, estranged from their families, refugees or asylum seekers, or whose parents/carers are in the UK armed forces.  Students from Pakistan studying A-levels or the IB from international schools can enter directly into the first year of a bachelor's degree.  Students should declare if they meet any contextual criteria on their application.
Overview: The University of Derby's BA (Hons) Illustration course provides a comprehensive education in the field of illustration. Students will develop a strong foundation in traditional and digital techniques, working across various mediums such as drawing, printmaking, and digital illustration software.  The program focuses on practical project work, including live projects and industry collaborations, allowing students to build a professional portfolio while gaining real-world experience.  The curriculum incorporates theoretical modules, cultural field trips, and opportunities to showcase work in competitions and exhibitions. Individualized tutoring and support ensure students reach their full potential. Graduates will be prepared to enter the professional illustration field with a distinctive skillset and creative voice.
Course Structure: The BA(Hons) Illustration course combines practical studio work with theoretical studies.  Students will engage in a wide range of hands-on projects, utilising traditional and digital techniques including drawing, painting, printmaking (screen printing, lino, mono-printing, drypoint, risograph, solar etching),  photography, 3D modeling, multimedia collage, and digital image making software such as Photoshop, Illustrator, InDesign, and After Effects.  Theoretical modules will enhance intellectual development, explore the history and theory of illustration, and develop crucial graduate skills. The program includes live briefs from employers, workshops with design companies, and commissions for art organizations, preparing students for professional practice.  Regular critiques, seminars, and individual tutorials provide valuable feedback and mentorship from experienced lecturers.
Year 1: First-year students will build a foundation in core illustration techniques.  This includes intensive drawing workshops focusing on experimental and observational drawing skills, introduction to various printmaking methods, fundamental digital illustration software skills using Adobe Creative Suite, and exploration of different illustration styles and approaches.  Students will also begin to develop their individual style while working on smaller projects to build confidence and familiarity with different tools and techniques.
Year 2: The second year will see a deeper exploration of specializations within illustration. Students will undertake more challenging projects focusing on areas such as character design, sequential image-making, editorial illustration, and visual narrative.  The curriculum will also incorporate modules on illustration history and theory, developing critical thinking and contextual understanding.  Students will have more opportunities for collaborative projects and external briefs, allowing them to work with professional clients and build their networks.
Year 3: The final year focuses on developing a professional portfolio and preparing for a career in illustration. Students will work on major independent projects, often involving extended live briefs from industry partners,  and potentially participate in high-profile competitions or exhibitions like New Designers.  Additional emphasis is placed on self-promotion and business skills, enabling graduates to confidently enter the freelance market.  Students can further refine their chosen specialisation and begin developing a clear professional identity and visual language.

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)

GCSE Maths and English are preferred but not mandatory.  A portfolio is recommended.  Contextual offers may be available for care experienced students, those estranged from their families, refugees or asylum seekers, or students whose parents/carers are in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or the International Baccalaureate from international schools in Pakistan, entry into the first year is possible.

Overview: The BA (Hons) Illustration with Foundation Year at the University of Derby is a four-year program designed to cultivate innovative and distinctive illustrators.  Students engage in a range of projects and activities, fostering self-motivation and confidence to push creative boundaries. The curriculum blends traditional and contemporary techniques, encompassing drawing, printmaking, digital art, and multimedia approaches.  Students benefit from a dedicated illustration studio, access to high-profile competitions, and networking opportunities within the industry.  The program integrates practical project work with theoretical modules to enhance intellectual development and industry readiness.  Graduates develop a professional portfolio and business skills to launch successful careers.
Course Structure: The course integrates practical project work with theoretical modules, enhancing intellectual development and industry readiness.  Students will learn and develop skills in drawing, printmaking techniques (screen printing, lino, mono-printing, drypoint, risograph, solar etching), photography, digital image-making, 3D model making, painting and multimedia collage. They learn through project work, workshops, lectures, demonstrations, seminars, group critiques, individual tutorials and assignments, including live briefs from employers.  Trips to galleries, museums and book fairs complement studio-based learning. Students have the opportunity to partake in prestigious competitions and exhibitions, such as New Designers in London. Students gain a subscription to LinkedIn Learning and Adobe Creative Cloud.
Year 1: The first year likely focuses on foundational art and design skills, building a strong base in drawing, visual communication, and fundamental design principles as well as introduction to Illustration. Students develop basic skills in a variety of media, including traditional and digital techniques.The foundation year will also include introductory modules in art history and theory to provide an overview of relevant contexts.
Year 2: Year two would likely expand upon foundational skills, introducing more advanced techniques in illustration, likely exploring different styles and genres of illustration. Students might focus on developing their personal artistic style through exploration of drawing, painting, and printmaking techniques, while also learning about different illustrative markets and applications This year also introduces more complex projects involving client briefs and professional practices.
Year 3: The third year allows for increased specialization within illustration. Students could delve into specific areas of interest such as editorial illustration, children’s book illustration, or graphic novels.  Advanced technical skills might be emphasized, along with a focus on portfolio development and professional practice. Students undertake a significant independent project that showcases their chosen area of expertise.
Year 4: The final year culminates in a major self-directed project, allowing students to refine their work and build a strong professional portfolio.  This might be linked to an industry placement or involve a collaboration with a professional organisation.  Students might also develop their entrepreneurial skills and refine their understanding of the illustration industry which will involve business and professional practice elements. The year concludes with a final exhibition.

Entry Requirement: Applicants typically need a 2:1 or equivalent science or health-related degree, IELTS 7, two years of post-registration experience, and current HCPC or NMC registration.  Candidates with suitable diplomas and experience may also be considered.  Sufficient study capacity and a qualified clinical mentor are also required. For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ is needed.  Those with two- or three-year Bachelor's degrees also require a Master's degree. Four-year Bachelor's degree holders with a minimum 2.4/4.0 GPA are considered.
Overview: The Postgraduate Certificate in Image Reporting is a part-time, one-year program designed to enhance image interpretation skills and prepare students for independent reporting roles.  The curriculum emphasizes the four pillars of advanced practice: Expert Clinical Practice, Education, Research, and Leadership and Management.  Students will refine critical thinking and research skills using state-of-the-art facilities, including a diagnostic imaging suite with PACS. This program addresses the need for faster reporting turnaround times and improved patient care.  The course involves lectures, seminars, and real-world assessments, providing a solid educational foundation for advanced practice roles.  Students will choose a specific reporting area (Appendicular, Axial, or Chest) and receive feedback on teaching and leadership skills.
Course Structure: The program includes a core module, 'Fundamental Principles of Image Reporting,' covering terminology, ethical and legal implications, quality improvement, teaching theory, leadership principles, and radiation safety. Students also complete a 40-credit specialized module focusing on their chosen reporting area (Appendicular, Axial, or Chest).  This module examines relevant anatomy, physiology, pathology, report writing, patient pathways, teaching skills, and audit processes.  Assessment methods include posters, presentations, a portfolio of reporting activity and case reviews, and an Objective Structured Exam (OSE).
Year 1: The first year comprises a core module focusing on the fundamental principles of image reporting, encompassing ethical considerations, legal implications, quality improvement methods, and teaching and leadership theories. It also includes a specialized module concentrating on a selected area of reporting (Appendicular, Axial, or Chest), delving into anatomy, physiology, pathology, report writing, and patient pathways, along with hands-on practice and feedback on teaching and audit skills. The year culminates in a portfolio submission and an OSE exam.
Year 2: NA

It focuses on advancing theoretical knowledge, refining clinical skills, and fostering independent scholarship. Students will undertake independent study, using research to develop their therapeutic approach and creating an evidence-based review of contemporary theory or a small-scale research project. The goal is to produce independent, evidence-based practitioners while emphasizing anti-discriminatory, reflective, and ethical practice.

Students will engage in intensive individual study, utilizing research to refine therapeutic practices and create either an evidence-based review of contemporary theories or a small-scale research project. This necessitates an advanced understanding of research methodologies, critical analysis of theoretical arguments, and the skills required to produce high-quality scholarly work. The curriculum incorporates ethical considerations and anti-discriminatory principles throughout the learning process and project development.
Year 1: The first and only year of the course focuses on developing independent scholarly work within a specific area of the student's choosing. This involves enhancing theoretical understanding, acquiring advanced clinical skills, and conducting a significant research project.  The emphasis is on the synthesis of theory, personal insight, and reflective practice to address contemporary challenges in mental health, while adhering to professional standards and ethical principles. The year culminates in the completion of a dissertation, work-based project, or a small-scale research study, demonstrating a strong grasp of research methodology and scholarly writing conventions.
