Overview: The University of Derby's International Business Management with Foundation Year BSc (Hons) is a four-year undergraduate program designed to equip students with a comprehensive understanding of international business, economics, and finance.  The integrated foundation year helps build a solid base for students before they progress to the honors degree.  The program offers specializations in Economics, Finance, Supply Chain and Logistics, and Business Technology. Students can study abroad for a semester during year two, gaining valuable international experience. The course combines theoretical knowledge with practical skills development utilizing a Financial Markets Lab with real-world data and analyses.  Graduates are well-prepared for diverse career paths in international business, finance, consulting, and related fields.  The program is accredited by CIMA and CMI, adding value to graduates' qualifications.
Course Structure: The four-year program begins with a foundation year designed to strengthen skills and knowledge. The first year covers core aspects of international business management, including micro and macro-economics, quantitative analysis, global business and sustainability, human resources, finance, and business performance.  In the second year students can select one of the specialist pathways (Economics, Finance, Supply Chain and Logistics, or Business Technology) or opt for the general international business management pathway. The third year for selected pathways will incorporate specific modules related to chosen specializations.  Across all pathways, in the second and third years, approximately one-third of modules are dedicated to the specialized area, maintaining a solid base. Optional modules are available in the final two years for all pathways to allow students to explore diverse areas of international business management.
Year 1: The first year lays the groundwork for the entire program. Students delve into core areas of international business management. This includes modules on micro and macroeconomics, providing the foundational economic principles students require. Then, quantitative analysis equips them with data interpretation and analysis skills necessary for strategic decision making.  Furthermore, the study of global business and sustainability addresses ethical and environmental factors in the global business environment.  Principles of finance and business performance are also introduced, along with human resource management practices.  All of this integrates to give students a firm understanding of core business functions and their interactions in an international setting.
Year 2: The second year is pivotal as students choose their specialization or stick with the core International Business Management pathway. Those selecting specializations will begin taking modules specific to their choice: economics, finance, supply chain, or technology.  Those remaining on the core pathway will maintain studies in broader international business but will have more opportunity to select optional modules from across the specializations. Regardless of the chosen pathway, all students continue to develop crucial skills in economic analysis, data management, and strategic decision-making. Students may also participate in a semester abroad, enriching their academic understanding with cultural and international business experience.
Year 3: The third year further intensifies specialization for students who chose a particular focus in the previous year.  Students will complete additional modules relevant to their choice of specialisation. Whether studying economics, finance, supply chain, or technology, this year deepens knowledge and skills specific to the chosen area. Those remaining on the general route will continue with a selection of modules from other specializations.  All students in their third year will continue refining their analytical capabilities, applying their knowledge to real-world business challenges, and strengthening project management and strategic thinking.
Year 4: The final year involves in-depth exploration of chosen specializations or advanced course work related to general international business management for those not selecting a specific area of focus.  Students develop advanced skills in their chosen area or refine business strategy and decision making. Students will also engage with real-world case studies and potentially professional development.  The culmination of their studies depends on their chosen pathway, often involving a capstone project or significant research element. This final year aims at the integration of skills, knowledge, and experience for readiness to enter the professional world.

Course Title: BSc (Hons) International Business Management with Placement Year
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical entry requirements include 112 UCAS points, A Levels (BBC), T Level (Merit), BTEC (DMM), or an Access to HE Diploma. GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or equivalent are also needed.  IELTS 6.0 with at least 5.5 in each skill is required for international students. For students from Pakistan who have completed A-Levels or the IB from international schools in Pakistan, direct entry into the first year is possible. Students with a four-year Bachelor's degree with honours and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani university will be considered for entry.
Overview: The BSc (Hons) International Business Management with Placement Year is a four-year undergraduate program designed to equip students with a comprehensive understanding of international business from a cross-cultural perspective.  The curriculum covers various subjects, including business management, economics, accounting and finance, marketing, human resource management, logistics, enterprise, IT and technology. A key feature is a placement year between the second and third year, providing practical experience in a real-world business setting. The program is accredited by CIMA and CMI, adding value to graduates' qualifications. Students can choose from specialized pathways in Economics, Finance, Supply Chain and Logistics, or Business Technology, in addition to the general International Business Management pathway. The program culminates in a well-rounded skill set preparing graduates for various career paths.
Course Structure: The program's structure is designed around core subject areas with an option to specialize later. Year one focuses on foundational aspects of international business management, such as micro and macroeconomics, quantitative analysis, global business and sustainability, human resources, finance and business performance.  Years two and three offer more focused options by selected pathway: core International Business Management, Economics, Finance, Supply Chain and Logistics, or Business Technology. A placement year is strategically positioned between year two and three followed by the final year, which varies slightly based on the selected pathway. A wide range of assessment methods is implemented to enhance learning and ensure graduates acquire the skills expected in the workplace.
Year 1: The first year provides a broad foundation in international business management. Core modules cover fundamental concepts in micro and macroeconomics, quantitative analysis techniques essential for business decision-making, global business environments and sustainability considerations, human resource management principles, financial management basics, and key performance indicators for business evaluation.
Year 2: In the second year, students build upon their foundational knowledge.  They can choose to study abroad for a semester, gaining international exposure.  Core modules continue to develop their understanding of international business, and students also begin to specialize with options depending on their pathways, exploring topics more deeply.
Year 3: The third year involves a placement year in industry, allowing students to apply their learned skills in a real-world setting to strengthen their CV and networks.  Students find placements themselves or with support from the university. This practical experience is a significant part of the learning. Upon successful completion of this year, they move into their final academic year.
Year 4: The fourth and final year focuses on advanced topics related to the chosen pathway. Students consolidate and deepen their knowledge in specialized areas within international business management.  Modules may include advanced financial modeling, supply chain optimization techniques, advanced business technology solutions, or in-depth economic analysis, depending on the student’s choice.  The year concludes with final assessments and graduation.

Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with 5.5 in each skills area
Entry Requirement: A second-class or higher undergraduate degree in a relevant area (business, economics, marketing, management, accounting, or finance) is typically required.  Other degrees with sufficient relevant business experience may be considered.  For non-business related degrees, the MSc Management program might be a better fit.  For those whose first language isn't English, an IELTS score of 6.5 with at least 5.5 in each skill is needed.  Specific requirements for Pakistani students include: completion of a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized Pakistani university (equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2); students with two or three-year bachelor's degrees require a Master's degree pass; a four-year Bachelor's with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university qualifies for Master's entry.
Annual Tuition Fee: £9,720 for the full course* (UK full-time), £16,900 for the full course (International full-time), £1,080 per 20 credits (UK part-time)
Overview: The University of Derby's MSc International Business program is designed to equip students with a comprehensive understanding of international business operations.  The curriculum covers various aspects of economics, strategy, law, finance, marketing, and human resources, all with a global perspective. Students benefit from interactions with industry experts through guest lectures, consultancy projects, case studies, and mentoring.  The program emphasizes applied analysis using real-world data, such as Bloomberg, and fosters practical skills development through projects and competitions.  The culmination of the program is an independent study focusing on students' chosen international business interests. A unique Futures Award in Leadership in International Business is also available, enhancing students' leadership and consultancy skills. The program prepares graduates for diverse careers in international business and related fields.
Course Structure: The MSc International Business is a three-stage program consisting of a Postgraduate Certificate, Postgraduate Diploma, and the MSc itself.  The Postgraduate Certificate modules include International Economics for Business and Finance, Market Analysis, Strategic and Financial Performance Management, HRM in an International Context, and Customer Behaviour and Decision Making. The Postgraduate Diploma then covers modules including International Business Theory and Strategy, National and International Sale of Goods, Mergers and Acquisitions, International Finance, and Advanced Diversity and Inclusion.  The final MSc stage comprises an Independent Study: Research Methods (20 credits) and an Independent Study: Dissertation (40 credits).  The course uses a variety of teaching methods, including lectures, group work, case studies, and practical analysis, with assessments ranging from essays and reports to presentations and projects.
Year 1: The first year of the full-time MSc International Business program covers foundational modules such as International Economics for Business and Finance to establish a comprehensive understanding of macroeconomic principles within an international context. Students delve into market analysis, learning how to analyze markets at both the market and consumer levels based on quantitative and qualitative data.  Students also begin to understand Strategic and Financial Performance Management, HRM in an International Context to develop business and managerial perspectives on organizations, and develop a thorough understanding of Customer Behaviour and Decision Making. This year lays the base for more specialized topics.
Year 2: NA

Course Title: Certificate of Credit in International Environmental Policy and Law
Entry Requirement: A good first degree in a related subject is required.  Applicants with professional qualifications or relevant experience may also apply.  If English is not your first language, you'll need an IELTS 6.0, TOEFL 550 (paper), 213 (computer), or 80 (internet), Pearson Test of Academic English 51, Cambridge Advanced Certificate Pass, or equivalent.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized university, equivalent to at least a UK Upper Second Class (2:1) or Lower Second Class (2:2) degree, is needed.  Those with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees must also have a Master's degree. A Bachelor's degree with honors (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university is also acceptable.
Overview: This postgraduate Certificate of Credit in International Environmental Policy and Law provides a critical understanding of international environmental policy and law principles.  The course adopts an international perspective, examining key topics such as the history and sources of international environmental law and policy. It uses a comparative approach, analyzing UK legislation alongside other national laws and focusing on environmental compliance mechanisms within organizations through interactive case studies.  The curriculum is developed with input from the Institute of Environmental Management and Assessment (IEMA) and is suitable for professionals seeking to enhance their knowledge and understanding or improve compliance within their organizations.  The course is accredited by CIWEM, offering free student membership with access to resources and networking opportunities.  Upon completion, students gain a deeper comprehension of how policy and legislation address environmental issues and achieve organizational compliance, becoming eligible for CIWEM graduate membership.
Course Structure: The program involves completing a single 20-credit module that comprehensively covers environmental policy and law. The module is delivered 100% online across 10 weeks, employing diverse interactive learning materials and live classroom sessions.  Students can interact with tutors and peers through virtual classroom sessions and online discussion forums. The assessment is entirely coursework-based, using a variety of methods like essays, research reports, presentations, group work and practical reports.  The pace of study is recommended at approximately 20 hours per week. Accelerated options for completing two modules in one trimester are available but are advised only after completing one module at the standard rate due to the increased study work load..
Year 1: NA
Year 2: NA

Required IELTS Score: 4.5 (with at least 4.0 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: The entry requirements include the equivalent of GCSE English language (grade A-C or 9-4) and GCSE maths (grade A-C or 9-4).  A personal statement demonstrating commitment and ability to study at this level is also required.  For progression onto a degree programme, you must meet the minimum entry requirements for that specific program.  English language requirements are an IELTS score of 4.5 with a minimum of 4.0 in each skill area.  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or the International Baccalaureate from international schools in Pakistan, direct entry into the first year of a Bachelor's degree may be possible.  However, specific entry requirements vary depending on the chosen undergraduate degree program.
Overview: The International Foundation Programme at the University of Derby is designed to prepare international students for undergraduate study in the UK.  It focuses on developing essential academic and English language skills, bridging the gap between secondary education and university-level coursework.  The program includes modules to enhance academic writing, reading, listening, speaking, referencing, research methods, and presentation skills, all tailored to support international students' transitions to the UK higher education system.  Students also study specialized subject modules related to various degree pathways, thus creating a smooth transition to their chosen undergraduate program.
Course Structure: The International Foundation Programme is a full-time course (15+ hours) spanning two semesters.  All students take two core modules: Academic English (60 credits), aiming to improve English language skills to an IELTS 6.0 equivalent, and Academic Skills (20 credits), focusing on essential academic skills.  Additionally, students choose subject-based modules from various disciplines like Business, Engineering, Design, Law, and more. The range of options includes modules in Construction Science, Design, Environmental Science, Psychology, Sociology, Electrical Engineering, Mathematics, and Creative Studies, among others. The choice of subject module is designed to align with the student's chosen undergraduate degree path but if the desired option is not available, alternative modules are recommended. The successful completion of the course requires 120 credits.
Year 1: The first year of the International Foundation Programme covers two core modules. The first is  Academic English, which aims to enhance students' English language proficiency to the level of an IELTS 6.0 across all areas. The second core module focuses on developing essential academic skills required for university-level study including critical reading, writing, referencing, research, and presentation methods. In addition to these, students select subject-specific modules based on their intended undergraduate degree, providing introductory knowledge and practical experience within their chosen field.  These specialist modules can range from subjects such as Business, Engineering, Design, or Science.
Year 2: NA

Course Title: MSc International Hospitality and Tourism Management
Required IELTS Score: Overall: 6.5 or equivalent
Entry Requirement: A UK 2.2 (or above) bachelor’s degree or equivalent from a recognised British or overseas institution listed on ENIC-TI. All subjects are considered, but possession of degrees or relevant experience in related subjects will be advantageous. Applicants with other qualifications e.g. not BA (Hons) and/or relevant work experience will be accepted on a case-by-case basis. An interview will be part of the process to assess your capacity for critical awareness, self-reflection, communication skills and the motivation required to successfully complete the programme.  International applicants will need to be able to show they have a good standard of English. If you are taking the placement route for this course you will also need to consider the following items: Students will be required to find their own placements and will need to arrange and attend an interview in the second semester with a prospective industry organisation. To comply with UKVI requirements, international students wishing to undertake their optional placement in the UK will have to state their intentions of which route they want to study at the point of application so that they can work with the registry and admission teams to obtain the correct visa documentation and CAS in advance of entry. International students will need to comply with the CAS requirements and return to campus to complete their studies to qualify for future visa routes into the UK. For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised University in Pakistan is required, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree. Students with a two or three-year Bachelor's degree must also have a pass in a Master’s degree. A Bachelor's degree with honours (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University is also considered.
Annual Tuition Fee: £16,900 for the full course (2025/26) N/A for Part-time
Overview: The MSc International Hospitality and Tourism Management is a postgraduate program designed to equip students with the knowledge and skills to manage organizations in the international hospitality and tourism sectors. The curriculum emphasizes sustainable practices, ethical considerations, and responsible tourism. Students will explore topics such as responsible tourism, sustainable hospitality solutions, and building better businesses through sustainable practices.  The program integrates theoretical learning with practical experience, offering an optional work placement to enhance employability.  Graduates will be prepared for managerial roles in various settings.
Course Structure: The program covers a range of modules focusing on responsible and regenerative tourism destinations, sustainable hospitality and food solutions, ethical business management, research methods, hospitality and tourism experience design and innovation, sustainable and ethical business operations and marketing, and a dissertation. The curriculum is designed to provide real-world experiences and industry insights through authentic assessments and investigations co-designed with industry professionals.  An interdisciplinary approach draws on expertise from the College of Business, Law, and Social Sciences, offering a comprehensive understanding of responsible tourism and hospitality.
Year 1: The first year of the MSc International Hospitality and Tourism Management program encompasses core modules covering responsible and regenerative tourism destinations, exploring sustainable practices and their impact on communities and the environment. Students will delve into sustainable hospitality and food solutions, examining ethical sourcing, supply chains, and waste management.  The curriculum includes modules on ethical business management, focusing on corporate social responsibility and sustainable business operations.  Students will also develop their research skills through modules on research methods and experience design and innovation within the hospitality and tourism sectors. This year culminates in the commencement of the dissertation project.
Year 2: NA

Entry Requirement: To be eligible for this top-up BA (Hons) degree, applicants must possess both an HND or Foundation degree in a relevant subject and a minimum of six months' full-time work experience in the hospitality industry.  Those with extensive supervisory or management experience but lacking the required academic qualifications may still be considered.  Applicants must provide a transcript of previously completed modules to ensure compatibility with the course.  If applying based on professional experience, a detailed CV is necessary.  For those who have completed the Confederation of Tourism and Hospitality (CTH) Level 6 Diploma in Tourism and Hospitality Management, exemptions from up to three modules may be granted based on completed units.  English language requirements apply to those whose first language is not English or whose highest level of qualification was not completed in English.  Acceptable qualifications include IELTS 6.0, TOEFL 550 (paper-based), 213 (computer-based), or 80 (internet-based), Pearson Test of Academic English 51, Cambridge Advanced Certificate (pass), London Tests of English (level 4), International GCE O-level English Language (Grade C), and International GCSE English/English as a Second Language (Grade C).  Specific Pakistani entry requirements are not explicitly detailed on the provided webpage.
Overview: The University of Derby's online BA (Hons) International Hospitality Business Management (Top-Up) program is designed to equip students with the skills and knowledge needed to excel in the global hospitality sector. This top-up degree builds upon existing HND or Foundation degrees, providing a comprehensive understanding of international hospitality business management. The curriculum focuses on developing critical thinking skills, evaluating the role of core management functions, and creating strategic plans adaptable to the ever-changing demands of the international hospitality environment. The program's flexible online format allows students to study at their own pace, combining online learning materials with virtual classrooms to facilitate interaction and personalized support.  The course is fully accredited by the Institute of Hospitality, offering access to exclusive resources and networking opportunities.  Graduates will be well-prepared for a wide array of careers in the dynamic and expanding hospitality industry.
Course Structure: The top-up degree requires completion of 120 credits, comprising four 20-credit core modules and two 20-credit optional modules chosen from students preferred areas. The modules are subject to change to improve student experience and graduate prospects. The pace of study is flexible; students can choose the standard study rate of one 20-credit module per 10-week trimester or an accelerated rate of two modules per 10-week trimester.  Assessment is 100% coursework-based, employing methods such as essays, research reports, presentations, group work, and practical reports. The course is supported by online learning materials, virtual classrooms, and a dedicated team providing support and guidance. Students have access to various university resources, including the library, health and wellbeing center, careers and employability service, IT support, student union, and Develop@Derby.
Year 1: NA
Year 2: NA

Course Title: University Advanced Diploma in International Hospitality Business Management
Entry Requirement: Applicants need an HND or Foundation degree in a relevant subject and at least 6 months of full-time hospitality industry experience.  Those with extensive industry experience at supervisory or management levels but lacking the academic qualifications may also be considered.  A transcript of previously studied modules or a detailed CV is required during application.  If English is not your first language, you'll need an IELTS 6.0, TOEFL 550 (paper-based), 213 (computer-based), or 80 (internet-based), Pearson Test of Academic English 51, Cambridge Advanced Certificate (Pass), London Tests of English (Level 4), International GCE O-level English Language (Grade C), or International GCSE English/English as a Second Language (Grade C).  For Pakistani students, those completing A-levels or the International Baccalaureate from international schools within Pakistan can begin the first year of a Bachelor's degree.  For postgraduate studies in Pakistan, a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree is needed; two or three-year Bachelor degree holders must have a pass in a Master’s degree; or a Bachelors degree with honours (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University.
Overview: The University Advanced Diploma in International Hospitality Business Management is a 1-year online program designed to equip students with the skills and knowledge necessary for success in the international hospitality industry.  The curriculum focuses on the critical aspects of hospitality management, including the forces influencing the industry's development and the application of core management functions to enhance quality and performance. The program is accredited by the Institute of Hospitality and developed in consultation with industry professionals, ensuring direct applicability to real-world roles. Flexible online learning allows students to study at their own pace and incorporate their work experiences into assignments.  The course includes access to the Institute of Hospitality's Educational Membership Scheme and provides comprehensive student support through personal tutors, online advisors and various university services.  It is particularly suitable for professionals seeking continued professional development and career advancement.
Course Structure: The program comprises three 20-credit modules, though the specific content is subject to change.  A course taster gives insight into the learning style, learning materials and assessment methods.  Assessment is 100% coursework-based, using methods such as essays, research reports, presentations, group work, and practical reports. Students should aim to dedicate approximately 20 hours of study per week for a 20-credit module, spread over a 10-week trimester.  Virtual classrooms are offered throughout the course, and recordings of the sessions are made available for review.
Year 1: The course is completed within one year.  Students complete three 20-credit modules focused on key aspects of international hospitality business management.  Modules may include topics like strategic management within the hospitality industry, operational management, and marketing and sales in the hospitality sector. The modules' specific content is subject to change.  Assessment is entirely coursework-based, including diverse methods such as essays, research projects, presentations, and practical reports.
Year 2: NA

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2024 entry, typical entry requirements include 104-120 UCAS points, A Levels (BCC-BBB), a Merit in T Levels, DMM in BTECs, and GCSE Maths and English at Grade 4/C or above.  For 2025 entry, 112 UCAS points are required, along with A Levels (BBC), a Merit in T Levels, DMM in BTECs, and GCSE Maths and English at Grade 4/C or above.  An Access to HE Diploma with 60 credits (45 at Level 3) is also acceptable. Contextual offers may be available for students meeting specific criteria (care experienced, estranged from family, refugees/asylum seekers, or parents/carers in the UK armed forces).  For Pakistani students, A-levels or IB from International Schools in Pakistan allow direct entry into the first year. Postgraduate entry requires a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2, a Master's degree if the Bachelor's is two or three years, or a four-year honors Bachelor's with a minimum 2.4/4.0 GPA.
Overview: The BA (Hons) International Hospitality Management degree at the University of Derby equips students with the managerial and operational skills needed for success in the modern hospitality industry.  The curriculum emphasizes business management, new technologies, entrepreneurship, and sustainability, fostering adaptable and creative thinking. Students learn about the wider visitor economy, encompassing hospitality, tourism, and events, benefiting from shared modules with related programs.  A study abroad semester in year two and an optional placement year are key features. The program aligns with the UN's Sustainable Development Goals, promoting responsible and sustainable hospitality practices.  Real-world learning is integrated through case studies, industry partnerships, and practical projects.
Course Structure: The course covers a broad range of modern hospitality and business management skills. It combines lectures, seminars, tutorials, practical projects, case studies, research, and independent study. Students engage in industry days, conferences, and competitions and benefit from field trips across the UK and internationally. Placements and internships, as well as networking and mentoring opportunities, enhance practical experience. Assessment methods are varied, creative, and challenge students using digital technology as much as possible.
Year 1: The first year introduces fundamental concepts in hospitality management, including operations management, the hotel industry, and basic business principles such as finance and marketing. Students will start building their understanding of the visitor economy and its various components. Practical projects and assignments allow students to apply their learning and gain practical experience.
Year 2: Year two involves a study abroad opportunity in countries like the Netherlands, Germany, Thailand, Bali, or South Africa, providing exposure to global hospitality practices and diverse cultures.  Students continue to develop their hospitality management skills through dedicated modules and will develop core business skills, particularly in finance and marketing, through practical application.
Year 3: The final year focuses on advanced hospitality management, strategic planning, business development, and specialized modules like hotel data analytics or menu design, depending on student choice.  Students complete significant projects, potentially with industry partners, and further refine their leadership, problem-solving, and business acumen. An optional placement year can be taken between year 2 and 3.
Year 4: If taken, the optional placement year provides valuable hands-on experience in various hospitality settings, both in the UK and internationally.  Students will gain practical experience in different roles, enhance their professional network, and build their resume for future career prospects. This year provides a valuable opportunity for students to enhance their career prospects.

Course Title: BA (Hons) International Hospitality Management with Foundation Year
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2024 entry, typical requirements include 72 UCAS points, DDD at A-Level, a pass in T Level or BTEC MMP, and preferred GCSEs in Maths and English (Level 2 Maths and English can be undertaken as part of the course if not initially held).  Access to HE Diploma with 60 credits (45 at Level 3, minimum Distinction:0, Merit:24, Pass:21) is also accepted.  For 2025 entry, requirements remain largely similar, except for Access to HE Diploma which requires a minimum of Distinction:0, Merit:30, Pass:15.  Contextual offers may be applied to students from care, estranged families, refugee/ asylum seeker backgrounds,  or those with parents/carers in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistan,  A-Levels or IB from Pakistani International Schools allow direct entry to Year 1. Postgraduate entry from Pakistan requires a relevant Bachelor’s degree equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2 (or a Master’s degree if the Bachelor’s is shorter), or a 4-year honours Bachelor’s with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00.  PhD entry needs a Master's and Bachelor's degree in relevant subjects, plus a research proposal.
Overview: The BA (Hons) International Hospitality Management with Foundation Year is a four-year undergraduate program designed to equip students with the management and operational skills needed to thrive in the modern hospitality industry.  The curriculum integrates business management, technology, entrepreneurship, and sustainability, fostering adaptable and creative thinkers. Students explore the interconnectedness of hospitality, tourism, and events within the visitor economy, gaining a broad skillset.  The program includes opportunities for studying abroad, work placements, and internships with major international and UK employers, enhancing career prospects.  The course is part of an internationally accredited Centre for Contemporary Hospitality and Tourism, aligning with UN Sustainable Development Goals.
Course Structure: The course covers a complete range of modern hospitality and business management skills. Students learn problem-solving, adaptation to change, innovative concept creation, and sustainable practices.  The program integrates finance, marketing, HR, and other business disciplines into relevant modules, applying knowledge practically.  Topics include hotel industry management (luxury hotels, revenue strategies), emerging technologies (simulation, self-service, AR/VR), sustainable practices, and optional modules in areas such as hotel data analytics, menu design, talent management, and consumer behavior.  Students complete practical projects, work placements, internships, and potentially study abroad in stage two.
Year 1: The foundation year aims to strengthen students' skills, knowledge, and confidence before progressing to the degree.  The focus is on strengthening academic and professional skills and providing support to prepare students for higher education level learning.
Year 2: Year two includes the opportunity for a semester studying abroad in countries such as the Netherlands, Germany, Thailand, Bali, or South Africa.  Students also complete at least 30 hours of work experience;  The curriculum builds on the foundation year, introducing core hospitality management concepts and business principles. Specific modules focus on the integration of business across the hospitality sector. It is also includes modules covering operations management, hotel industry trends, financial management for hospitality businesses and developing leadership skills.
Year 3: Year three might include an optional placement year or summer internship, providing practical experience and networking opportunities with employers. Depending on placement opportunities, students might undertake work activities and projects that develop their skills within specific hospitality settings. The program will cover more advanced hospitality and business modules relevant to workplace activities.
Year 4: The final year focuses on advanced hospitality management and strategic planning. Students will consolidate their knowledge and skills by completing a capstone project, which allows them to apply their learning to a real-world business challenge. The curriculum will explore leadership, change management, and the development of strategic business plans. Modules will cover more contemporary themes, innovation and technology within the hospitality sector.

Course Title: Undergraduate BA (Hons) International Hospitality Management with Placement Year
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical UCAS points are 112.  A Levels BBC, T Level Merit, BTEC DMM, or a Pass Access to HE Diploma with specific credit requirements are acceptable.  GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/Grade C or above are also needed.  Contextual offers may be available for students who meet specific criteria, such as being care experienced, estranged from their families, refugees or asylum seekers, or having parents/carers in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistan, students from International schools completing A-Levels or IB can enter Year 1.  Those with a relevant four-year Bachelor's degree with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University will also be considered.
Annual Tuition Fee: UK: £9,535 per year; International: £16,900 per year
Overview: The BA (Hons) International Hospitality Management with Placement Year is a four-year undergraduate program designed to equip students with the management and operational skills for success in the modern hospitality industry.  The curriculum emphasizes business management, new technology, entrepreneurship, and sustainability, encouraging creative and adaptable thinking.  Students learn about various aspects of the hospitality industry, such as hotel management, revenue management, and operations, while also developing transferable skills like research, data analysis, and project management.  The program includes a placement year to provide real-world experience, and students have the opportunity to study abroad for a semester.
Course Structure: The course integrates business management subjects throughout the program, applying them to relevant areas like financial knowledge in business plan creation and leadership skills in organizational transformation. Students will cover a wide range of modern hospitality management, problem-solving, creating innovative customer experiences while considering sustainability, and project evaluation and management.  The curriculum aligns with UN Sustainable Development Goals. There are optional modules in areas such as hotel data analytics, menu design, and talent management. Assessments utilize various creative methods, including digital technology, analysis, research, report writing, teamwork, and presentations.  The program includes a placement year and study abroad opportunities.
Year 1: The first year likely introduces foundational concepts in hospitality management, business fundamentals, and relevant soft skills. Students would gain an introduction to the hospitality and wider visitor economy, learning about various segments within the industry. Basic business and management principles would be covered, along with an introduction to key technologies used within the hospitality sectors.  Initial modules would give a broad overview of the industry and would build the fundamental knowledge needed in following years.
Year 2: The second year allows students to study a semester abroad in countries like the Netherlands, Germany, Thailand, Bali or South Africa.  Further specialist hospitality knowledge would be added to what was learned in the first year. Core business management skills continue to develop, with more focus on practical application.  Perhaps some specialization will be introduced, allowing for elective choices.
Year 3: Year three is a placement year, allowing students to gain practical experience in a real-world hospitality setting.  Students would apply the knowledge and skills to a professional environment, strengthening their CV and building industry networks. This year is a period of professional development and growth.
Year 4: The final year focuses on consolidating and enhancing the skills acquired in previous years and completing a final project.  The focus is on more advanced hospitality management theories and practices, strategic planning, specialized areas within hospitality (such as revenue management or hotel operations), along with more advanced marketing, finance, and leadership content.  Students will be prepared for the job market and their future roles.

Course Title: PG Cert International Postgraduate Certificate of Education (iPGCE)
Required IELTS Score: 6.5 (a minimum score of 6 in one area may be acceptable)
Entry Requirement: Applicants need an undergraduate degree (at least a 2:2) with Honours or equivalent.  They must be currently employed educators in a classroom setting, teaching and assessing children aged 3-18 for a minimum of 15 hours weekly.  English language proficiency is required if English isn't their first language, with acceptable tests including IELTS 6.5 (with a minimum of 6 in one area), TOEFL (580 paper-based, 237 computer-based, or 92 internet-based), Pearson Test of Academic English (51), Cambridge Advanced Certificate (pass), London Tests of English (level 5), International GCE O-level English Language (grade C), or International GCSE English/English as a Second Language (grade C). For the 2024/25 academic year, the Duolingo English Test (DET) with a minimum score of 120 overall and 120 in each area (a minimum score of 105 may be acceptable in one area) is also accepted.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized university, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree, is required. Those with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees also need a Master's degree pass. A four-year Bachelor's degree with honours and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university is also acceptable.
Overview: The International Postgraduate Certificate of Education (iPGCE) is a part-time, online program designed for educators working outside the UK. It's a level 7 qualification (Master's level) focusing on practical teaching skills and critical awareness of education in global contexts. The program covers contemporary pedagogy and provides opportunities for established professionals to enhance their skills and knowledge. The curriculum is structured to be manageable alongside full-time employment and accommodates flexible learning schedules. The course aims to build valuable knowledge applicable to various subjects and curricula. Upon completion, students may progress to a full Master's award, with credits from the iPGCE transferring.
Course Structure: The iPGCE requires completing 60 credits through three 20-credit modules.  The modules are subject to change, with regular reviews to enhance the learning experience and graduate prospects. The assessment is 100% coursework-based, utilizing various methods such as essays, research reports, presentations, group work, and practical reports. The program includes virtual classrooms, and recordings are available if students miss a session.  The university provides many support services for online students like Personal Tutors, Online Learner Advisors, library access, health services, career guidance, IT support, student union, and further skills development programs.
Year 1: NA
Year 2: NA

Required IELTS Score: 6.5 or equivalent and no lower than 6.5 in any area
Entry Requirement: Applicants require an undergraduate degree (at least a 2:2) with Honours or equivalent; Grade 4 in GCSE English Language, Mathematics, and Science, or equivalent.  Those without these must take an equivalency test.  Non-native English speakers need an IELTS score of 6.5 or equivalent with no band score below 6.5. Non-UK qualifications require a Statement of Comparability from UK ENIC. A Prohibition List check is conducted after acceptance.  Good health is required, evidenced by a health questionnaire.  A successful interview is mandatory.  Pakistan-specific requirements are not detailed on the provided course page, but  generally, a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised University in Pakistan equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree is needed for postgraduate study.  A two or three-year Bachelor's degree requires a passing Master's degree. A four-year Bachelor's degree with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 might suffice.
Overview: The University of Derby's online International Qualified Teacher Status (iQTS) program is a one-year, part-time postgraduate course designed to prepare outstanding primary school teachers (ages 3-11) for international settings.  The curriculum focuses on developing "thinking professionals" capable of critical thinking and educational leadership.  It emphasizes inclusive practices and high aspirations for all learners.  The course combines online learning with school-based placements (minimum 140 days, including 20 days of Intensive Training and Practice).  Students must source their own placements and secure a mentor. The qualification is UK government-backed and equivalent to English Qualified Teacher Status (QTS), enhancing global career prospects.
Course Structure: The iQTS program comprises three level 6 professional practice modules. The specific module order and availability are communicated upon enrollment.  The course integrates online learning (live sessions, virtual forums, case studies, workshops, and seminars) with practical school placements. Placements are divided between two age groups (3-7 years or 5-11 years), with at least one placement spanning consecutive age groups.  Assessment is through placement-based assessments and includes formative and summative tasks (presentations, seminars, written work, and practical activities). Ongoing feedback is provided by tutors, mentors, and peers.
Year 1: The iQTS program is a one-year course. The first year involves three professional practice modules, online learning encompassing live sessions, virtual discussions, case studies, workshops and independent study. Practical placements are a vital part, requiring 140 days in schools, including the 20-day Intensive Training and Practice. Placements follow a structured approach, with students selecting either the 3-7 or 5-11 age group. Assessment integrates formative and summative evaluations, and includes presentations, seminars, discussions and written and practical activities.
Year 2: NA

Course Title: BA (Hons) International Relations and Business Management
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 112 UCAS points, A-Levels BBC, BTEC DMM, or a pass in the Access to HE Diploma.  Specific GCSE requirements are not listed.  International students should refer to the university's guidelines for their particular countries. For Pakistani students completing A-levels or the IB from International Schools in Pakistan, direct entry into Year 1 is possible. For postgraduate study from a recognised Pakistani university, a UK equivalent of at least a 2:1 or 2:2 degree is needed.  A Masters degree is also required for those with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees. A four-year Bachelor's degree with a minimum 2.4/4.0 GPA may be considered for Master's entry.  PhD applicants from Pakistan need a Master's and Bachelor's degree in related fields, plus a research proposal.
Annual Tuition Fee: UK: £9,535 per year; International: £16,900 per year
Overview: The BA (Hons) International Relations and Business Management is a joint honours degree offered by the University of Derby.  It provides a transdisciplinary approach to global affairs, combining the study of international relations with the practical application of business management.  Students develop solutions to real-world problems, present ideas to external audiences, and engage in work experience modules.  The curriculum includes theoretical frameworks complemented by practical, real-world learning experiences through industry projects and collaborations. The course is professionally accredited by the Chartered Management Institute (CMI), demonstrating its high quality. Students can choose to major in one subject or study both equally throughout the three-year program.
Course Structure: The course structure allows for flexibility, with students equally studying both subjects in their first year, followed by a choice of a major or minor subject in later years. While the exact modules vary depending on the chosen pathway (either studying both International Relations and Business Management equally, majoring in International Relations or Business Management, or minoring in each), a range of assessment methods is used. These include lectures, seminars, tutorials, work experience projects, and self-directed study. Assessment varies by module and includes coursework such as essays, research reports, presentations, and group projects, as well as individual assignments like business reports and digital material design.
Year 1: The first year involves an equal study of both International Relations and Business Management.  Students are introduced to foundational concepts in both fields, gaining a broad understanding of international affairs and business principles.  Assessment is likely to include introductory modules covering topics such as global politics, international organizations, and basic business concepts, potentially accompanied by preparatory assignments for group work and individual research to lay the foundation for future modules.
Year 2: In the second year, students continue to develop and specialize their studies based on the pathway chosen. The year may include modules focusing on advanced aspects of International Relations, such as conflict resolution or international law.  Business Management students will advance in areas such as strategic management, operations management, or marketing. Students participate in a mandatory work experience module, collaborating on projects with organizations in real-world business contexts.  The focus is likely on applying acquired knowledge and refining professional skills in practical settings.
Year 3: The final year sees students engage in more specialized modules in their major or both subjects equally, depending on pathway selections. Projects and assessments focus on independent research, advanced problem-solving, and the development of advanced practical skills in specific areas, including independent research projects, advanced presentations, and problem-solving tasks reflecting the work experience and knowledge acquired in previous semesters.  This year aims to equip students with the skills and knowledge necessary for their chosen career path.

A four-year Bachelor's with a minimum 2.4/4.0 GPA may suffice for Master's entry.

Overview: The BA (Hons) International Relations and Economics is a three-year undergraduate program at the University of Derby's Kedleston Road campus. It offers a joint honors approach, allowing students to study both International Relations and Economics equally in the first year, before selecting a major or minor in either subject or continuing with an equal balance for the remainder of the course.  The curriculum integrates theoretical knowledge with practical application, utilizing resources like the Financial Markets Lab, providing hands-on experience with financial software and data analysis. The program emphasizes a transdisciplinary approach to International Relations, examining significant global issues and their impact, while  Economics focuses on applying theoretical frameworks to solve problems across various sectors.  The program aims to cultivate critical thinking, problem-solving, communication, and cultural awareness, attributes highly valued in the job market.
Course Structure: The program commences with an equal exploration of both International Relations and Economics in the first year.  Students will develop foundational knowledge in economic theory, models, and analysis, as well as an understanding of various global issues, including political, economic, and social aspects.  In subsequent years, students can choose to major in either subject, taking advanced courses in International Relations or Economics, while still engaging in some modules from the other subject. The choice of a major or continued balanced split depends on student preference and career path. The course structure includes a mix of lectures, seminars, group work, case studies, computer lab sessions, and individual research projects enabling students to build their skills and knowledge through diverse learning approaches.
Year 1: The first year offers a balanced introduction to both International Relations and Economics. In International Relations, introductory modules cover global political systems, key concepts in global politics, and introductory aspects of the global economy. Economics modules build a foundation in microeconomics, macroeconomics, and econometrics.  Students  will be introduced to economic concepts, models, and methods of analysis and possibly engage in introductory case studies and problem-solving activities.
Year 2: The second year allows students to deepen their specialization. Students choosing to major in International Relations will take modules on international political economy, specific regional studies (such as those focusing on China, India, Eastern Europe), and perhaps environmental politics. Those majoring in Economics might delve into advanced econometrics, behavioral economics, and specialized areas like financial markets or public policy. Students continuing with an equal focus will get more in-depth modules in their favorite areas in both IR and Economics.
Year 3: The third year involves advanced study in the chosen major, alongside potentially a capstone project or dissertation that allows for in-depth research on a real-world problem.  International Relations majors may focus on specific international relations theories, foreign policy, or global governance challenges. Economics majors may engage in specialized research projects, advanced statistical modeling, or business analysis applications.  Students maintaining an equal focus will continue expanding on their knowledge in both areas with more advanced level modules.

Overview: The University of Derby's BA (Hons) International Relations and Law is a three-year, full-time joint honours degree designed for students interested in global issues and their legal implications.  The program offers a balanced study of both subjects, allowing students to eventually specialize in one or maintain equal focus. It integrates different disciplines such as politics, international affairs, cultural studies, economics, data science, sociology, geography, history, and international development, providing students with a broad understanding of global issues and the legal frameworks that govern them.  The program enhances employability by equipping students with highly sought-after skills like negotiation, conflict resolution, objective analysis, communication, problem-solving, and more.   The course utilizes various teaching methods, from lectures and seminars to practical activities like mooting (mock court cases) and real-world engagement opportunities, ensuring a diverse and enriching learning experience.
Course Structure: The course begins with an equal distribution of International Relations and Law modules in the first year. Students then choose to major or minor in one subject or continue with an equal balance in years two and three.  The curriculum incorporates a variety of assessment methods including coursework across different formats, presentations, debates, examinations, and group projects, in addition to providing unique opportunities such as a student involvement in a Student Legal Advice Centre and working in a mock court case environment.  The program ensures a strong foundation in both subjects, combined with the development of essential practical and theoretical skills that are applicable in various career paths.  The courses cover a range of topics relevant to current and future global issues, making students adaptable to various contexts and challenges.
Year 1: The first year introduces fundamental concepts in both International Relations and Law. Students are exposed to core theories and principles in each discipline.  International Relations modules may introduce topics like global politics, international organizations, and contemporary international issues.  Law modules might cover legal systems, constitutional law, and basic legal principles. Assessment includes a mix of essays, presentations, and examinations, laying a strong foundation for more specialized study in subsequent years.
Year 2: In the second year, students can opt to either continue studying both subjects equally, or to major in one field and minor in the other.  Those continuing with an equal focus will delve deeper into specialized areas within International Relations and Law. If choosing to major, they would concentrate on advanced modules within their chosen area, while minoring in the other will still involve core subjects but at a less intensive level. Assessment methods continue to be varied, aligning more closely to the chosen specialisation, if selected.
Year 3: The final year offers a high degree of specialization, solidifying the chosen path. Students who decide to specialize in law will engage more with legal studies while keeping up with a lighter but still required International Relation subject matter.  Those focused on International Relations will work more on subjects relevant to their primary choice of study. Assessments emphasize independent and collaborative work, reflecting the professional responsibilities of future careers.  The opportunity is granted for some high quality work to be published in the Derby Law School Journal.

Overview: The BA (Hons) International Relations and Sociology is a three-year undergraduate joint honours degree offered by the University of Derby.  Students explore global affairs, societal issues, and their interconnectedness. The program emphasizes hands-on learning, including real-world projects and work experience, enabling students to apply their knowledge to solve contemporary problems. The curriculum blends theoretical understanding with practical application through various assessment methods, such as essays, case studies, group projects, and presentations.  Students develop critical thinking, research, and analytical skills, preparing them for a diversity of careers.
Course Structure: The course begins with equal study of International Relations and Sociology in the first year. Students then choose to major in one subject or continue studying both equally in years two and three.  International Relations modules involve problem-solving and presenting solutions to external audiences, incorporating work experience opportunities.  Sociology modules cover diverse societal aspects like media, culture, inequality, globalization, youth justice, and political sociology.  The program integrates a strong research component, including data collection, statistical analysis and an independent research project, enhancing the students’ abilities to analyze information and support their opinions.
Year 1: The first year provides an equal introduction to both International Relations and Sociology.  Students will explore fundamental concepts in both fields, and develop foundational understanding of research methodologies and data analysis. The year aims to provide a broad base of knowledge and prepare the student to choose a major or continue to study both subjects equally in the following years.
Year 2: In the second year, students can either continue a balanced study of both subjects or choose to major in either International Relations or Sociology.  The curriculum includes a work experience module where students collaborate on a project with external organizations or companies to implement or recommend change, enhancing practical skills and workplace exposure. Sociology students will delve further into chosen topics, developing independent study and deeper analytical skills.
Year 3: The final year allows for specialization based on students’ choice of major or continued balanced study. Students will tackle complex societal and international issues through advanced projects and an extended research piece showcasing their expertise. There is an emphasis on applying research findings to practical applications, fostering independent problem-solving abilities.

Overview: The BA (Hons) International Tourism Management degree equips students with the management and operational skills necessary for success in the modern tourism industry.  The curriculum emphasizes business management, entrepreneurship, and sustainability, fostering adaptable and creative thinking. Students gain a broad understanding of the visitor economy, encompassing tourism, events, and hospitality, and have opportunities for study abroad, overseas field trips, and a placement year.  The program incorporates practical projects, allowing students to apply their knowledge and gain hands-on experience, and includes professional training from ABTA.  Strong emphasis is placed on sustainable tourism practices and the integration of technology.
Course Structure: The course covers all aspects of modern tourism management and business management.  Students learn to solve problems, adapt to changing environments, create successful tourism experiences while considering sustainability, and manage projects effectively.   Key topics include sustainable tourism and e-tourism, alongside niche areas such as food, nature-based, and adventure tourism.  Students develop research, analytical, and presentation skills, business planning abilities, financial management skills, and team leadership competencies. The curriculum integrates business concepts like finance, marketing, and HR throughout the course rather than teaching them as separate modules.
Year 1: Year 1 likely introduces foundational tourism concepts, management principles, and introductory business modules.  Students engage with practical projects, possibly designing tourism experiences or promotional materials, and begin building research skills.  A residential field trip is included, providing first-hand experience of the industry and location-specific learning.
Year 2: Year 2 builds on the foundational knowledge, delving deeper into specialized areas of tourism management.  Students would likely develop more advanced business and marketing skills. A study abroad opportunity is available, offering a broader cultural perspective.  A minimum of 30 hours of work experience is also compulsory, providing practical skills and industry insight.
Year 3: Year 3 focuses on more specialized and advanced aspects of tourism management.  Students may engage in industry-focused projects, such as consulting assignments, and develop advanced skills in areas like business development, sustainable tourism, and technology applications. The optional placement year between Years 2 and 3 provides intensive hands-on experience.
Year 4: Year 4 (optional placement year) focuses on practical experience in the tourism industry, which could be based either in the UK or abroad.  Students apply the skills learned in preceding years while working in a professional setting, gaining valuable experience and networking opportunities.  This placement significantly enhances students’ employability, providing practical skills and industry-specific insights.

Overview: The BA (Hons) International Tourism Management with Foundation Year is a four-year undergraduate program designed to equip students with the management and operational skills needed for success in the tourism industry.  It emphasizes practical application through projects simulating real-world scenarios, including designing tourism experiences, creating marketing campaigns, and developing business proposals. A strong focus is placed on sustainability, technology's role in tourism, and emerging niche markets like food and adventure tourism. Students will also gain exposure to the wider visitor economy, encompassing events and hospitality. The program includes opportunities for work placements and study abroad, enhancing employability and providing valuable real-world experience. The curriculum is updated to reflect the modern tourism landscape, addressing aspects such as business management, entrepreneurship, and sustainability.
Course Structure: The course integrates business management, entrepreneurship, and sustainability throughout its four years.  Instead of separate modules for finance, marketing, and HR, these subjects are woven into relevant sections of the curriculum. For example, financial knowledge is developed through the creation of business plans, while HR and leadership skills are acquired through organizational change management projects. The program includes modules on areas such as sustainable tourism, e-tourism, niche tourism, business planning, marketing, finance, data analysis and presentation, along with management consulting projects. Students also have optional modules in event management and hospitality modules available.  The course is part of an International Centre of Excellence (ICE) in Tourism and Hospitality, aligning with UN Sustainable Development Goals.
Year 1: The foundation year strengthens skills, knowledge, and confidence. Students receive support from expert staff before progressing to the honors degree.  It incorporates introductory modules covering foundational aspects of tourism, business, and management; developing essential skills for academic and professional success. The curriculum includes basic business and management principles with an introduction to the tourism industry sector.
Year 2: Year two introduces core tourism management concepts and principles, building upon the foundation year. It combines theoretical knowledge building with practical assignments. The year includes a mandatory fieldwork experience of at least 30 hours, and fieldwork trips. Students have the opportunity to study abroad for a semester.
Year 3: Year three offers specialization in tourism management, consolidating skills learned in previous years. Students will undertake a range of projects focusing on specific aspects like destination management, tourism marketing, and sustainable tourism practices. This may also include an optional placement year or summer internship, either in the UK or abroad, giving students valuable professional experience.
Year 4: The final year focuses on independent project work and developing advanced skills applicable to the modern tourism setting. Students may undertake a substantial independent final year project, putting their accumulated skills and knowledge into practice. They are also provided industry insight opportunities and further professional training, for example through ABTA.

The curriculum focuses on management, operational skills, business management, entrepreneurship, and sustainability. Students will learn to manage and promote destinations, develop tourism strategies, and understand the interplay between tourism, events, and hospitality.  The program includes opportunities for study abroad, overseas field trips, and a placement year in the UK or internationally.  Students will also gain exposure to professional training from ABTA, the UK's largest travel association, and work on practical projects such as designing tourism experiences and developing business proposals. Subjects such as finance, marketing, and human resources are integrated throughout the course, applied in relevant contexts like business planning and organizational transformation.  Students will explore sustainable tourism, e-tourism, niche tourism (food, nature-based, adventure), and learn data analysis, business launch strategies, financial management, and team leadership. Overview: The BSc (Hons) Internet of Things is a three-year (full-time) or six-year (part-time) undergraduate program designed to equip students with the skills needed to develop and utilize Internet of Things (IoT) and Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) devices and applications.  The curriculum covers computing, data science, and electronics, preparing graduates for in-demand global roles.  Students will learn how IoT systems impact various sectors, from smart home appliances to industrial applications, by focusing on aspects like sensors, actuators, software, connectivity, and data science. Through industry collaborations and practical projects, students gain experience applying their knowledge to real-world scenarios, thereby enhancing their employability.
Course Structure: The course involves a mix of lectures, practical sessions, seminars, and tutorials to enhance skills in equipment, small system creation, and evaluation.  Teamwork is emphasized to develop interpersonal skills. Technology-enhanced learning is utilized through suitable virtual environments. Assessment varies across modules with coursework, portfolios, assignments, case studies, presentations, teamwork, and computer testing.  Modules may vary, and the university regularly reviews and improves its content. The program includes industry briefs, case studies, and projects from companies like Rolls Royce, Toyota, CERN, and more.  The focus is on preparing graduates for a workforce relying on data interpretation from sensors and devices within industries like logistics, manufacturing, medicine, and transport.
Year 1: The first year will cover the fundamental aspects of IoT, likely including introductory computing, programming fundamentals, electronics basics, and introductory data analysis.  Students might engage in introductory projects focusing on basic IoT system design and setup.  The curriculum will integrate theoretical concepts with practical applications, laying the groundwork for advanced studies in subsequent years.
Year 2: Year two focuses on more advanced concepts with detailed studies of specific technical aspects of the Internet of Things.  This may involve more sophisticated programming, networking, and data science modules.  Students likely work on larger projects, integrating multiple components and challenging them to apply knowledge practically.  Modules possibly include specialized areas within IoT, such as security or embedded systems.
Year 3: In the final year, students undertake advanced projects and modules that integrate all aspects learned throughout the course.  The curriculum might contain modules on specialized IoT applications like AI-enhanced systems or large-scale industrial IoT.  Students likely pursue larger-scale projects, possibly involving collaboration with industry partners, to gain real-world experience and prepare for the job market.  The final year emphasizes professional development skills, including teamwork and communication.
