Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 72 UCAS points, A Levels (DDD), a T Level pass in STEM, a BTEC MMP, GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or above, or a relevant Access to HE Diploma.  International students will need to meet specific English language requirements, such as an IELTS score of 6.0 with at least 5.5 in each skill.  For Pakistani students completing A-Levels or IB in Pakistani International Schools, direct entry into Year 1 is possible.  Those with a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized Pakistani university (equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2) can apply for postgraduate studies.  A 4-year Bachelor's degree with at least a 2.4/4.0 GPA from a recognized Pakistani university is considered for Master's entry. Students with 2 or 3-year Bachelor's degrees need a Master's pass for postgraduate entry. PhD applicants require a Master's and Bachelor's degree in a relevant field and a research proposal.
Annual Tuition Fee: UK: £9,250 per year; International: £16,900 per year
Overview: The Internet of Things with Foundation Year BSc (Hons) at the University of Derby is a four-year undergraduate program designed to equip students with the skills and knowledge to design, develop, and deploy IoT and IIoT systems.  The curriculum blends computing, data science, and electronics, preparing graduates for in-demand roles globally.  Students will work on real-world projects with industry partners like Rolls Royce and Toyota, gaining practical experience and understanding ethical considerations.  The program emphasizes a strong theoretical foundation alongside practical application, fostering problem-solving, research, and communication skills, crucial for success in the rapidly evolving IoT field.
Course Structure: The course integrates theoretical knowledge and practical application through lectures, interactive sessions, and hands-on labs. Students will develop skills in computing, data science, and electronics, learning to design and develop IoT/IIoT devices and applications.  The curriculum covers sensors, actuators, software, connectivity, data analysis, and AI, while also addressing ethical, economic, social, and environmental contexts of IoT applications.  Students undertake industry-based projects, case studies, and teamwork assignments, enhancing their practical and interpersonal skills.  Regular assessments, including coursework, portfolios, presentations, and projects ensure continuous evaluation of learning.  The program also includes a personal academic tutoring system to support students' academic and personal growth.
Year 1: The first year focuses on building a foundational understanding of core computing principles.  It includes introductory programming, fundamental computing concepts, basic electronics and circuit design, and an introduction to data science and mathematical foundations. Students will also get familiar with the various aspects of IoT in an introductory course. This year provides a strong base for subsequent years’ specialized coursework in IoT and associated technologies.
Year 2: The second year delves deeper into programming, software development, and data science.  Students will learn more advanced programming techniques and explore data analysis, database management and data visualization, and network technologies relevant to IoT systems.  Students may  also take specialized modules focused on specific applications of IoT in different fields, such as smart mobility or smart homes.
Year 3: The third year focuses on the design, development, and implementation of IoT systems.  Students engage in advanced courses on IoT architectures, embedded systems, and cloud computing. They will develop more complex IoT applications, focusing on security, scalability, and real-time data processing.  This year usually includes a significant industry project that enhances practical skills and professional experience.
Year 4: The final year involves a major project, often industry-sponsored, focusing on a complex IoT problem.  Students refine their analytical and problem-solving abilities with a focus on design, implementation, testing, presentation and communication skills.  There is further specialized knowledge acquisition in relevant computing, data, or electronics fields to fulfill any remaining course requirements. An optional placement year or a practical research module may be included.

Required IELTS Score: NA
Entry Requirement: This short course is open to anyone regardless of age, location, or educational background. However, basic requirements include internet access via PC, tablet, mobile, or other electronic devices and a valid email address for registration on the online learning platform.  Proficiency in English is also necessary.  For those from Pakistan, there are no specific entry requirements mentioned for this particular short course; the general Pakistan entry requirements for undergraduate, postgraduate, or PhD programs are detailed separately.  Those requirements would not apply to this short course, which is not at degree level.
Duration: 20 CPD hours (4 units, 5 hours of study per unit)
Overview: This online short course provides an introduction to innovative 21st-century teaching methods.  It focuses on the three 'C's: Curiosity, Curation, and Community, emphasizing practical applications of technology in education.  Participants explore various digital tools and technologies, including MOOCs and social media, and how these can enhance learning experiences inside and outside of traditional educational settings.  The course aims to build confidence and competence in using digital technologies for teaching and learning, relevant to various professionals including aspiring teaching assistants, trainee teachers, and educational leaders.
Course Structure: The course consists of four units, each requiring approximately five hours of study.  Unit 1 introduces the concept of 21st-century teaching and inspires curiosity. Unit 2 examines the increasing use of MOOCs and OERs in learning. Unit 3 focuses on case studies of social media in education and explores its potential classroom applications.  Unit 4 explores emerging technologies and their potential in education and training, incorporating insights from thought leaders.
Year 1: NA
Year 2: NA

Entry Requirement: Applicants need A-levels or equivalent qualifications like BTEC certificates or diplomas, International Baccalaureate, OU credits, Access to HE diplomas, Scottish Highers, or Irish Leaving Certificates.  Relevant experience will also be considered.  If English isn't your first language, you'll need an IELTS 6.0, TOEFL 550 (paper-based), 213 (computer-based), or 80 (internet-based), Pearson Test of Academic English 51, Cambridge Advanced Certificate pass, London Tests of English level 4, International GCE O-level English Language Grade C, or International GCSE English/English as a Second Language Grade C.  For Pakistani students,  entry requirements depend on their previous qualifications.  If studying A-levels or the International Baccalaureate from an international school in Pakistan, direct entry to the first year of a Bachelor's degree may be possible.  Postgraduate entry requires a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized Pakistani university, equivalent to at least a UK Upper Second Class (2:1) or Lower Second Class (2:2). Two or three-year Bachelor's degree holders also need a Master's degree pass. A four-year Bachelor's degree with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani University is also acceptable for Masters entry.
Overview: The University of Derby's Introduction to Marketing is a 10-week online short course providing a foundation in marketing principles and concepts.  It covers marketing planning, analysis, decision-making, and the tools and techniques businesses need to thrive in competitive markets. Students explore current marketing trends, consumer behavior, and strategies for maintaining customer focus and competitiveness. The course emphasizes the practical application of marketing tools and plans within a business setting, examining the role and function of marketing within organizations.  The course aims to equip students with a comprehensive understanding of marketing fundamentals and their practical application.  It's designed to build the necessary skills for success within the marketing industry and related fields.
Course Structure: The course covers a range of key marketing areas including an introduction to modern marketing concepts, analysis of the marketing environment, market segmentation, targeting and positioning, marketing orientations and strategies, service marketing, the marketing mix and extended mix, marketing plan evaluation, and marketing ethics.  Assessments are 100% coursework-based, encompassing various methods such as essays, research reports, presentations, group work, and practical reports, submitted at the end of the 10-week trimester.  There will be one or two virtual classroom sessions during the course.
Year 1: NA
Year 2: NA

Course Title: Certificate of Credit in Investigation and Analysis
Required IELTS Score: 6.5 (minimum of 6.5 in each module)
Entry Requirement: Applicants need a UK undergraduate degree or equivalent international qualification, or a relevant professional qualification.  The university will also consider applications from individuals with relevant practical experience and work-based training.  For those whose first language isn't English, or whose highest qualification wasn't earned in English, an English language qualification is required (IELTS 6.5 with minimum 6.5 in each module, TOEFL 550/213/80, Cambridge Advanced Certificate Pass, others listed on site).  For Pakistan, students must have a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised University equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree.  Those with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees need a Master's degree pass. A Bachelor's degree with honours (four-year) and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University is also acceptable.
Overview: This 10-week online Certificate of Credit in Investigation and Analysis focuses on research design, ethical research practices, and qualitative and quantitative research methods.  Students will learn to design, conduct, and report ethically sound quantitative research studies exploring human behavior, and critically evaluate qualitative research designs and findings. The course covers philosophical underpinnings of empirical research, hypothesis generation, and exploring qualitative and quantitative approaches (descriptive tests, inferential analyses, testing for differences and relationships, effect sizes, power analysis). Upon completion, students will be able to develop methodologically sound empirical research studies, analyze and interpret findings, and critically appraise qualitative research papers.  The course is CIEHF accredited and taught by experienced academics with over 20 years of experience in online ergonomics courses.
Course Structure: The course is delivered 100% online and uses various interactive learning materials and some live classroom sessions.  Students interact with tutors and peers through virtual classrooms and online discussion forums.  The curriculum covers philosophical background to empirical research, generating and exploring hypotheses, qualitative approaches (assumptions, epistemology, differences between methods, validity and reliability), and quantitative approaches (assumptions, descriptive tests, inferential analyses, testing for differences and relationships, effect sizes, power analysis). Assessment is 100% coursework, including essays, research reports, presentations, group work, and practical reports.
Year 1: NA
Year 2: NA

Required IELTS Score: 7.0 (with at least 6.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 112 UCAS points, A-Levels BBC, T Level Merit, BTEC DMM, GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or above, or an Access to HE Diploma.  A portfolio is recommended. Contextual offers may apply to care experienced students, those estranged from families, refugees, asylum seekers, or those whose parents are in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or the IB from international schools in Pakistan, direct entry into Year 1 is possible.  Postgraduate entry requires a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK Upper or Lower Second Class Honours degree.  Those with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees also need a Master's degree, while a four-year Bachelor's with a minimum 2.4/4.0 GPA from recognized Pakistani Universities is considered for Master's entry.
Overview: The University of Derby's BA (Hons) Journalism program is a three-year (full-time) or four to six-year (part-time) course designed to equip students with the skills and knowledge needed for a successful career in journalism. The curriculum emphasizes practical experience, including coursework, placements and real-world projects, allowing students to produce stories across various platforms (online, print, broadcast). Students benefit from industry-experienced tutors and guest speakers, networking opportunities (including visits to organisations such as the BBC), access to state-of-the-art facilities, and the chance to publish their work through the university's StoryHub website and Twitter feed. The course fosters a global perspective on journalism, incorporating modules focusing on its role in global affairs, politics, and international relations. The curriculum is structured to allow students to specialise from year two.  The program is designed to produce well-rounded journalists equipped with the skills and experience to excel in the dynamic media landscape.
Course Structure: The course blends theoretical and practical learning, using a mixture of lectures, seminars, workshops, news days, real projects, field trips, and technical visits.  Year one focuses on foundational skills such as news writing, reporting, online content production, SEO, audio/video recording and editing, media law and interview techniques. Subsequent years allow for greater specialisation through optional modules and assignments, focusing on areas such as PR, social media, politics, live radio and podcasting, or data journalism. Students also have the opportunity to work on real projects for employers and gain work experience, including covering local events.
Year 1: The first year establishes a solid foundation in journalism fundamentals. Students develop core skills in news writing and reporting, producing content for online, print, and broadcast platforms.  They learn interview techniques, develop skills in audio and video recording and editing, gain an understanding of media law and ethical considerations, and begin to understand the principles of search engine optimization (SEO). The year culminates in assessing the student's ability across several key areas.
Year 2: Year two builds upon the foundational skills acquired in the first year and introduces more specialized modules. Students delve into areas such as the newsroom environment, future trends in journalism (smart device journalism), and may choose optional modules reflecting their interests, allowing them to explore specific areas of journalism in more depth. The year involves greater practical application of learned skills, providing opportunities to cover both local and national events and work collaboratively, preparing students for the challenges of real-world journalism.
Year 3: The final year offers students opportunities to specialize further.  Students choose many of their modules, potentially including an option such as Live Radio and Podcasting.  They work on more complex projects, applying their skills to a wider range of journalistic assignments.  The year also emphasizes professional development, with a focus on building connections and preparing for entry into the job market. This is reinforced through guest speakers and career advice.  The final year also allows the student to create their portfolio and to further develop their skills.

Required IELTS Score: Overall: 6.5, minimum 5.5 in each test category
Entry Requirement: A 2:1 undergraduate degree or relevant experience is required.  For those whose first language is not English, an IELTS score of 6.5 with a minimum of 5.5 in each category is necessary.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized university is needed, equivalent to at least a UK Upper Second Class (2:1) or Lower Second Class (2:2) degree.  Those with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees must also have a Master's degree.  A Bachelor's degree with honors (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university is also acceptable.
Overview: The University of Derby's MA Journalism is a flexible program designed to equip students with the skills and knowledge needed for a successful career in journalism.  The course emphasizes critical thinking, research skills, and the ability to analyze and synthesize information from various sources.  It also allows for specialization in areas of interest, with a choice between a thesis or practice-based project allowing for diverse engagement and focus. Students are provided with hands-on experience in state-of-the-art facilities, including studios, editing suites, and a newsroom. The program boasts strong industry links, enabling students to secure work experience and projects with numerous media organizations. Through a blend of traditional and modern approaches, the course aims to cultivate well-rounded journalists equipped for the dynamic media landscape.
Course Structure: The MA Journalism curriculum encompasses both core and optional modules. Core modules cover global challenges in journalism, project modeling and methods, a major journalism project, and the development of the Master's Thesis or a related significant project.  Optional modules cater to individual interests and might include data journalism, investigative journalism and politics, audience studies, and freelance journalism.  The teaching methodology includes lectures, seminars, tutorials, workshops, and guest speakers from the media industry. There's a strong emphasis on self-directed study, supported by online learning resources. Assessment methods are diverse, including essays, presentations, reports, and reflective pieces.
Year 1: The first year of the full-time MA Journalism program is intensive, covering core modules such as Global Challenges in Journalism, which explores the role of journalism in democracies and its societal impact. The Project Modelling and Methods module builds research and analytical capabilities. Students also work on a Major Journalism Project, applying their learning in a practical setting. The culmination of the year is the Master's Thesis or practice-based project, where students will focus on a chosen area of interest.
Year 2: NA

Course Title: Undergraduate Journalism with Foundation Year BA (Hons)
Required IELTS Score: 7.0 (with at least 6.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 72 UCAS points, A Levels (DDD), T Level (Pass), BTEC (MMP), or a Pass in an Access to HE Diploma. GCSE Maths and English are preferred.  A portfolio is recommended.  Contextual offers may apply to students who are care experienced, estranged from their families, refugees, asylum seekers, or whose parents/carers are in the UK armed forces.  Students from Pakistan studying A-Levels or the IB from International Schools in Pakistan can enter the first year. For postgraduate study, a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised Pakistani University is required, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree.  Those with two- or three-year Bachelor's degrees need a Master's degree pass. A four-year Bachelor's with a minimum 2.4/4.00 GPA from a recognised Pakistani university is considered for entry to a Masters degree. For PhD programs, a Master's and Bachelor's degree are needed, along with a research proposal.
Overview: The University of Derby's Journalism with Foundation Year BA (Hons) is a four-year undergraduate program designed to equip students with the skills and knowledge needed to thrive in modern journalism. The program covers various aspects of journalism, including print, audio, video, and online reporting. Students gain practical experience through newsgathering, reporting, and work placements with media organizations in the UK or abroad. The curriculum emphasizes multimedia skills and the development of a multi-platform mindset to prepare graduates for diverse opportunities. The foundation year strengthens skills and knowledge before progressing to the main degree. It aims to foster creative and versatile journalists competent across various production methods, also encouraging specialization in areas of personal interest.
Course Structure: The course integrates theoretical knowledge with practical skills.  The foundation year is dedicated to providing a solid base in journalism principles and techniques, including reporting, research, and writing. The subsequent years build upon this foundation, covering media law, ethics, public administration, and advanced reporting and production skills.  Students gain hands-on experience in producing various media formats, such as articles, audio and video reports, blogs, podcasts, and social media content. There is also an opportunity to study abroad in either Europe or America.  Students complete work placements, building professional experience and networking contacts.
Year 1: The foundation year focuses on building a strong base in journalism's core principles and practices, including research methods, storytelling techniques, news writing, and media ethics. The curriculum may also include introductory modules on print, audio, and video production, preparing students for more advanced coursework in subsequent years.
Year 2: Building upon the foundation year, the second year delves into more specialized areas of journalism. Students will likely advance their reporting and writing skills, exploring various genres, including feature writing, investigative journalism, and news reporting for different media platforms.  The year may also include modules on media law, regulations, and ethics, along with practical assignments and group projects that simulate real-world experiences.
Year 3: The third year typically involves a practical placement with a media organization, giving students hands-on experience in a professional setting.   Academically, this year may offer more specialized module options, allowing students to focus on specific areas of interest, such as broadcast journalism, online journalism, or multimedia production. The focus will shift toward project work, culminating in a substantial piece of portfolio work.
Year 4: The final year focuses on advanced skill development, project work, and final-year projects leading to a significant journalistic output. Students refine their specialized skills and build a professional portfolio, enhancing their job prospects.  Modules might delve into specialized areas such as data journalism, visual storytelling, or social media strategy, strengthening their readiness for the job market.

Course Title: Short Course Lattice Climbing - Performance Assessment
Required IELTS Score: NA
Entry Requirement: The Lattice assessment at the University of Derby is best suited for climbers operating at a minimum of F6c and V3. If you climb below this grade, or are unsure, please get in contact before booking your assessment.  For Pakistan, specific entry requirements are not listed for this short course.  General entry requirements for undergraduate, postgraduate, and PhD programs at the University of Derby are specified separately and would not apply to this short course.  These include IELTS, TOEFL, and PTE scores for English language proficiency, and vary depending on the program level and whether the applicant has completed A-levels or the IB from an international school in Pakistan or a relevant bachelor's degree from a recognized Pakistani university.
Start Date: Appointments available until the end of 2020
Overview: This short course provides a comprehensive performance assessment for climbers using the Lattice system.  The assessment involves a series of tests evaluating finger strength, aerobic and anaerobic performance, climbing-specific muscle strength and conditioning, movement patterns, pacing, and efficiency.  Data collected is analyzed to identify areas for improvement and compare performance to other climbers of similar skill levels. The analysis is done using Lattice's proprietary software, providing objective data-driven feedback that helps climbers improve their training to reach their climbing goals.  The assessment helps climbers identify their current potential grade and optimize their training approaches based on objective data and professional insight from a Lattice-accredited coach.
Course Structure: The Lattice Climbing Performance Assessment is a 1.5-hour session involving several tests.  These tests cover a range of climbing-relevant physical abilities: finger strength, aerobic and anaerobic capacities, strength and conditioning within  climbing-specific muscle groups, as well as movement analysis.  Following the tests, the data is processed by Lattice's software. A coach then integrates this data with their own assessment to formulate a highly personalized feedback report tailored to optimize the individual climber's performance.
Year 1: NA
Year 2: NA

Overview: The University of Derby's BA (Hons) Law and Accounting is a three-year, full-time joint honours program designed to provide a comprehensive understanding of both legal and accounting principles.  Students explore the English legal system, its operation, and methodology, alongside core accounting areas like financial and management accounting. The program integrates practical application through specialized facilities like a replica Crown Court and a Financial Markets Lab, offering hands-on experience with financial data analysis and simulated legal practice.  The curriculum includes a range of teaching methods, including lectures, seminars, workshops, and practical exercises like mooting and case preparation, enhancing employability.  A placement year is also optional between years two and three, boosting career prospects.
Course Structure: The course structure is divided into three years.  The first year provides a balanced foundation in both law and accounting, introducing key concepts and principles in each field. Year two and three allow for optional module choices within law and accounting specializations. Assessment methods vary depending on the module and subject, including written coursework, examinations, oral presentations, group work, business reports, research projects, case preparation, and mooting (in law modules). A personal academic tutoring program offers personalized support throughout the degree.
Year 1: The first year provides a foundational understanding of both law and accounting principles.  In law, students will be introduced to the English legal system, its structure, processes, and fundamental legal concepts.  Simultaneously, accounting fundamentals will be introduced, focusing on concepts like financial and management accounting, covering basic accounting principles, bookkeeping, and financial statements. Students will also receive career development training and will possibly start working on internships.
Year 2: In the second year, students build upon previously learned concepts. Students will explore various specialized areas of law, such as contract law, tort law, or criminal law or accounting, like auditing or tax depending on their path choices. Students further develop legal skills through more advanced case studies and simulations. Accounting students will focus on applying accounting principles to practice and will be involved in business projects alongside their studies.
Year 3: The final year focuses on advanced study and specialization.  Law students might specialize in areas such as corporate law, international law, or human rights law.  Similarly, accounting students could specialize in areas like forensic accounting, management accounting or financial planning depending on their specializations.  The program concludes with a significant piece of research demonstrating the student’s comprehension of core principles and ability to apply them to complex scenarios.

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 112 UCAS points, A Levels BBC, T Level Merit, BTEC DMM, GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or equivalent, or a Pass Access to HE Diploma with specific credit requirements.  International students may need to meet additional English language requirements, such as an IELTS score of 6.0 with at least 5.5 in each skill area.  Contextual offers may be available for students who meet certain criteria, such as being care experienced, estranged from their families, refugees, asylum seekers, or having parents/carers in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistani students, those completing A-levels or IB from international schools in Pakistan can enter the first year.  Those with a relevant four-year Bachelor's degree with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.0 from a recognized Pakistani university will be considered for entry.
Overview: The University of Derby's BA (Hons) Law and Economics is a three-year, full-time joint honours degree program.  Students explore the English legal system, legal research, and the application of economic theories to real-world business issues.  The curriculum blends legal and economic principles, allowing students to develop a strong foundational understanding of both fields.  Students can choose to major in either Law or Economics, or to study both equally.  The program includes a variety of teaching methods, such as lectures, seminars, workshops, and practical exercises like mooting and simulated legal practice.  Students have access to specialist facilities, including a replica Crown Court and a Financial Markets Lab.  A placement year is available, enhancing employability prospects.
Course Structure: The course is divided into three years. Students initially study Law and Economics equally in the first year. By the end of the first year, they choose whether to major in one subject or study both equally throughout the duration of their degree program. The program includes a range of assessments designed to evaluate students' understanding of legal and economic concepts and their ability to apply these to solve problems. Assessment methods include exams, essays, presentations, and projects in both areas of study. The curriculum is designed to be both theoretical and practical, giving students the skills and knowledge needed to succeed in a variety of careers.
Year 1: The first year provides a foundational understanding of both Law and Economics. Students explore core legal principles and concepts within the English legal system, alongside introductory economic principles, including microeconomics and macroeconomics.  They will develop fundamental skills in legal research, economic analysis, and critical thinking.  The equal weighting of both subjects allows students to assess their interests and preferences before deciding on a major or specialisation for subsequent years.  Assessment methods likely include a mix of coursework and exams covering both subjects.
Year 2: In the second year, building upon the foundation created in the first year, students will delve deeper into specialized areas within Law and Economics based on their chosen pathway (Law with Economics, Economics with Law, or Law and Economics equally).  For example, they may explore specific legal fields like contract law or tort law, while economics modules may focus on econometrics, financial economics, or behavioral economics.  The program will include in-depth case studies, research projects, possibly a placement option, and assessments aligned with the chosen specialization.
Year 3: The final year offers advanced modules that allow students to further specialize their knowledge and skills within the chosen subject path.  They may pursue advanced modules within chosen fields of Law or Economics, or undertake an independent research project.  The final year will also build on essential skills developed throughout the program, such as legal writing, economic modeling and analysis,  presentations, and professional communication.  The emphasis will be on preparing students for their future careers.

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 120 UCAS points, A Levels (BBB), T Levels (Merit), BTECs (DDM), and GCSEs in Maths and English (Grade 4/C or above).  An Access to HE Diploma with 60 credits (45 at Level 3) is also accepted.  Contextual offers may be available for students from care, estranged families, refugee/asylum-seeker backgrounds, or with parents/carers in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or IB in Pakistani International Schools, entry to Year 1 is possible. Postgraduate entry for Pakistani students requires a relevant Bachelor’s degree equivalent to a UK Upper or Lower Second Class degree. A Master’s degree is needed if the Bachelor’s is a two or three-year program. Students with a four-year Bachelor’s degree with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 are also considered.
Location/Campus: One Friar Gate Square, Derby Campus
Overview: The University of Derby's LLB (Hons) Law degree is a comprehensive undergraduate program designed to equip students with the skills and experience needed for a successful legal career.  The curriculum blends core legal knowledge with practical skills development through mooting competitions, mock trials, contract drafting, and internships. Students develop skills in advocacy, negotiation, and legal research, enhanced by modules in legal technology, commercial awareness, and entrepreneurship.  The program offers specialist pathways in Company and Commercial Law, International and Comparative Law, International Business Law, and Social and Public Policy, allowing students to tailor their studies to their interests.  The program emphasizes hands-on learning through the Student Legal Advice Centre, providing real-world experience in assisting clients under the supervision of qualified solicitors.  Strong links with the legal profession provide opportunities for mentoring, networking, and internships, enhancing graduate prospects.
Course Structure: The LLB (Hons) Law program is structured across three years of full-time study.  The first year provides foundational knowledge in core legal areas, including contract law, criminal law, and tort law. Subsequent years build upon this foundation, incorporating more specialized modules related to chosen pathways.  Students engage in practical learning through workshops, simulations, and real-world legal projects. Optional field trips to courts and international legal institutions provide additional learning opportunities. Assessment comprises various methods, including group work, presentations, written assignments, and examinations.  A dedicated Personal Academic Tutoring program offers individualized guidance and support throughout the degree.
Year 1: The first year focuses on foundational legal principles.  Core subjects typically include contract law, exploring the formation, validity, and enforcement of contracts.  Criminal law introduces students to criminal offences, procedures, and defenses.  Tort law covers civil wrongs and the legal remedies available to victims.  Legal method and research skills are also developed, providing a basis for academic work and future legal practice.
Year 2: Building upon Year 1, the second year delves deeper into specialist areas.  Students explore advanced topics within areas like contract and criminal law, while also broadening their knowledge with subjects such as land law, focusing on property ownership and rights.  Constitutional law examines governmental structures and powers, while equity and trusts introduce principles of fairness and fiduciary relationships. Students continue honing practical skills through workshops and simulated legal exercises.
Year 3: The final year offers increased specialization through optional modules aligned with chosen pathways.  Students select specialized electives within areas like company law, intellectual property, or international law to focus on their chosen field. The year culminates projects, potentially including dissertations or significant research assessments. Legal skills development continues through simulations, presentations, and participation in mooting competitions. This year offers many opportunities to network with the legal community.

Course Title: Postgraduate Certificate in Leadership and Management in Health and Social Care
Entry Requirement: A bachelor's degree or equivalent in a relevant subject is required, along with work experience in a health or social care setting following the bachelor's degree. Current employment in a relevant field (voluntary, public, private, community, or acute health and social care) is also necessary to achieve the module learning outcomes. International qualifications must be mapped to the UK equivalent registration with at least 120 academic credits at level 6.  English language requirements apply if your first language is not English.  For Pakistan, a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognized University is needed, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree.  Those with two or three-year Bachelor degrees also require a Master’s degree pass. A Bachelor's degree with honours (four-year) and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani University also qualifies for entry
Overview: This Postgraduate Certificate in Leadership and Management in Health and Social Care is designed for health and social care professionals seeking to enhance their leadership and management skills.  The program equips students with advanced understanding of leadership and management theories applicable to diverse health and social care settings.  The curriculum focuses on developing practical, forward-thinking managerial skills and strategic involvement within the expanding health and social care sector.  Students will learn to implement new skills and improve quality and service delivery while developing a better understanding of their leadership styles through critical analysis and leadership theories. The program is ideal for professionals aiming for career progression and improvement of care provided to patients or service users.  The program meets the needs of those in current managerial roles seeking skill development.
Course Structure: The program consists of three core 20-credit modules at level 7, totaling 60 credits, studied one per trimester over one year.  Assessment is 100% coursework including essays, research reports, presentations, group work, and practical reports. The program offers flexibility, allowing students to integrate learning with their work.  Specific module titles aren't directly available, but the overall focus is on practical application of leadership and management theories in health and social care environments, addressing inter-professional issues, policy, and change implementation.

Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with a minimum of 5.5 in each component

If English is not their first language, they need an IELTS score of 6.5 (with no less than 5.5 in each component) or a University of Derby equivalent. Overview: The MRes Leadership and Management program is designed for working professionals seeking to enhance their research skills and understanding of complex management challenges.  It offers specializations in areas such as Human Resource Management, International Relations, and Sustainable Strategic Development.  The program combines theoretical knowledge with practical research skills, culminating in a substantial independent research project and thesis.  The aim is to equip students with the research methodologies, critical thinking, and analytical capabilities needed for advanced roles in management and potential doctoral studies.  Strong links with the business community provide real-world opportunities.
Course Structure: The MRes program consists of several modules followed by an independent research project.  Initial modules focus on research philosophy, methods (including a selection of masterclasses covering diverse techniques, like survey research and qualitative data analysis), and professional development for researchers (covering communication, research management, finance, and funding). Students then undertake a substantial work-based research project (at their workplace, a university cluster, or external organization), followed by the Independent Research Project that culminates in a 20,000-word thesis.   The coursework balances structured learning with hands-on, real-world research. Learning methods encompass interactive lectures, seminars, workshops, and masterclasses both on campus and online.
Year 1: The first year of the full-time MRes comprises modules in Research Philosophy and Methods, providing a basis in theoretical approaches and research construction.  Advanced Research Methods expands these foundations with specialized techniques via masterclasses.  Professional Development for Researchers enhances skills in research communication, management, finance, and impact. The significant portion of the year consists of a work-based research project (40 credits) and the independent research project (80 credits), involving a literature review, original research, a 20,000-word thesis, and a presentation at an annual conference.

Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with a minimum of 5.5 in all areas
Entry Requirement: Applicants usually need a degree or equivalent qualification and must be working in a healthcare environment.  For those applying from Pakistan, a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognized university is required, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree. Overview: The Postgraduate Certificate in Leadership for Healthcare Improvement equips healthcare practitioners with advanced leadership and management skills focused on quality and service improvement.  The program uses current research and improvement techniques to support ongoing improvement projects.  It's designed for professionals involved in high-level decision-making and problem-solving, helping them enhance their knowledge, innovation, and practice.  Students will learn to systematically apply improvement theory to a project within their clinical role, critically evaluate evidence, and understand the complexities of implementing change.  The course culminates in the completion of an improvement cycle in the workplace, fostering reflection on future service improvements.  The course is flexible, delivered fully online, and suitable for those actively working in healthcare.
Course Structure: The program consists of two modules: 'Quality Improvement- Principles and Preparation' (20 credits) and 'Quality Improvement- Implementing' (40 credits). The second module guides students as they execute their project, critically appraising the challenges in clinical practice.  Both modules emphasize reflection on personal and professional development throughout the project leadership and management process.

The curriculum covers theoretical frameworks, practical applications, and methodological approaches to planning, execution, and assessing the effectiveness of quality improvement initiatives in a healthcare setting. The module provides groundwork for the implementation phase while offering a framework for critical analysis of project success and failure. The second module, 'Quality Improvement- Implementing', immediately follows and provides structured support during the execution of the quality improvement project.

Course Title: PG Cert Leading Interprofessional Practice Education
Required IELTS Score: 7.0 (6.5 in Writing, 7.0 in other sections)
Entry Requirement: Applicants typically need a degree in a health or social care-related subject, a teaching role within the health or social care setting, employer support (financial and time for study), and a qualified mentor (preferably with a PGCE and Advance HE Fellowship).  Those with level 6 study (minimum 20 credits) and relevant work experience may also be considered. A master's degree might be needed if the bachelor's degree was two or three years. A four-year bachelor's degree with honors (minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00) may also be accepted.
Overview: This online postgraduate certificate focuses on developing leadership and educational skills for registered health and social care professionals involved in higher education learning, teaching, and assessment.  The program emphasizes interprofessional learning, providing a supportive environment for participants to enhance their teaching practices. Students will explore theories of teaching, learning, and assessment, focusing on curriculum design and quality while improving service user outcomes.  The course includes online learning, live sessions, and practical application in the workplace, guided by a practice education facilitator. Successful completion can lead to Associate Fellowship or Fellowship of Advance HE.
Course Structure: The program comprises two core modules: 'Innovating learning, teaching and assessment toward enhanced professional practice' (20 credits) and 'Leading and Evaluating the Curriculum' (40 credits). The first module introduces teaching, learning, assessment theories, and the educator's role in various health and social care learning environments. The second module delves into curriculum design, quality mechanisms, and interprofessional education to enhance service user outcomes.  Assessment involves coursework such as essays, presentations, a professional practice portfolio, and practical teaching observation reports.
Year 1: In the first year (or first trimester for 1-year completion), students complete the 20-credit module, 'Innovating learning, teaching and assessment toward enhanced professional practice.' This module covers teaching, learning, and assessment theories. Students will also explore their values and roles in supporting higher education students across various health and social care environments.  Assessment within the caring professions is a key focus, emphasizing the protection of patients.
Year 2: The second year (or remaining trimesters if the course is completed in one year) involves the 40-credit module, 'Leading and Evaluating the Curriculum.'  This module covers curriculum design, quality assurance, and maintaining currency and credibility within the educational landscape. It integrates interprofessional education to improve service user outcomes. Students apply learned concepts within their practice. This includes activities such as peer assessment, workplace observation and feedback, and feedback from the Practice Education Facilitator.

Entry Requirement: Admission to the LLM in Legal Practice (SQE) is open to those holding an undergraduate degree in any subject area with a 2:2 or above classification.  Students aiming for a Master's qualification without completing all three stages must provide evidence of suitable recognised prior learning (RPL), assessed individually by the Programme Leader.  Applicants whose first language is not English need to demonstrate English proficiency (IELTS 7.0 with 6.5 in each skills area). For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised University in Pakistan is required, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree.  Those with a two or three-year Bachelor's degree need a passing Master's degree.  A Bachelor's degree with honours (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University is also acceptable.
Location/Campus: One Friar Gate Square, Derby Campus
Overview: The University of Derby's LLM in Legal Practice (SQE) prepares students for the Solicitors Qualifying Examination (SQE).  It combines online learning with face-to-face workshops led by legal practitioners, offering practical experience through client scenarios. The program emphasizes ethical considerations within commercial practice, aligning with UN Sustainable Development Goals.  Students develop crucial legal skills, including advocacy, legal research, and drafting, alongside commercial awareness, and ethical considerations, building a strong foundation for a successful legal career. The program is structured in three stages, focusing on the SQE 1 and SQE 2 assessments and culminating in independent research. The program also provides access to support through learning coaches and a personal academic tutor system.
Course Structure: The LLM is structured across three stages. Stage one covers the Functioning Legal Knowledge (FLK) 1 and 2, preparing students for the SQE 1 exams. Stage two focuses on legal and professional skills for SQE 2 and professional practice.  The final stage involves an independent study module where students conduct specialized legal research. Learning takes place through various methods including online BARBRI lectures and activities, face-to-face teaching, one-on-one sessions, and workshops. Assessments include oral and written exercises, simulated client case studies, a learning development record, reflections, and written assessments.
Year 1: The first year (full-time) or first two years (part-time) of the LLM program covers the foundational legal knowledge and skills required for both SQE1 and SQE2. This includes modules focusing on Business Law and Practice, Dispute Resolution, Tort, Contract, Legal Systems in England and Wales, Administrative and Constitutional Law, EU Law and Legal Services, Property Practice, Wills and the Administration of Estates, Solicitor Accounts, Land Law, Trusts, Criminal Law and Practice, Advocacy, Interviewing, Attendance Note and legal analysis and Case and matter analysis.
Year 2: The second year (for part-time students) of the LLM program focuses on more advanced legal and professional skills for SQE2 preparation and  developing expertise within chosen areas. It includes modules delving into case and matter analysis, legal research, legal writing, and legal drafting. The independent study module allows for in-depth research and critical analysis of a specialized area of law, furthering academic and professional development. This culminates in a final independent research project.

Required IELTS Score: Overall: 7.0, no element below 6.5
Entry Requirement: 5 GCSEs (or equivalent) at grades A-C or 4-9, including Mathematics and English.  English and Maths L2 are required, or Entry Level 3 for those with an education, health & care plan or legacy statement. Evidence of recent study, a current DBS check, and the ability to meet the occupational health requirements are also necessary.  If English is a second language, an overall IELTS score of at least 7.0 with no element below 6.5 is required.  Apprentices must be employed in a Prosthetic or Orthotic Department with managerial support to complete the program. For Pakistani students, specific entry requirements were not listed on this course page but general entry requirements for undergraduate, postgraduate and PhD programs in Pakistan are available on the University's website.  These may include specific GPA requirements and degree equivalencies.
Overview: The Level 3 Prosthetic/Orthotic Technician Apprenticeship is designed to train skilled technicians who work alongside prosthetists and orthotists.  The program emphasizes evidence-based practice, covering clinical support, technical design, and fabrication of prosthetic and orthotic devices.  It incorporates on-the-job learning, complemented by academic study delivered through blended learning (face-to-face and online).  The curriculum is aligned with industry standards and developed in collaboration with key organizations like Health Education England (HEE) and Skills for Health.   The apprenticeship aims to equip learners with the necessary skills and knowledge to provide compassionate and skilled care, ensuring optimal patient outcomes. The program focuses on providing the knowledge and skills for prosthetic and orthotic manufacturing as well as in a real-world environment.
Course Structure: The 18-month apprenticeship combines on-the-job training with academic study. The academic component, constituting 20% of the course, utilizes blended learning. Face-to-face sessions are conducted in blocks, supplemented by online learning resources such as webinars, independent activities, and reading materials.  The on-the-job learning involves practical experience in a prosthetics and orthotics department, with evidence collected and uploaded to an e-portfolio.  The curriculum covers a range of topics related to prosthetic and orthotic design, fabrication, and application. The program is mapped to the Institute for Apprenticeships and Technical Education standards, ensuring industry relevance and work-based learning integration.

The program is flexible and can be tailored to specific industry sectors.

Overview: The University of Derby's LLB (Hons) with Criminology is a three-year undergraduate law degree that combines core legal studies with a strong focus on criminology.  The program aims to equip students with the essential skills for legal careers, including drafting, advocacy, interviewing, and negotiation, while also fostering entrepreneurship, problem-solving, and business acumen.  Students will explore various aspects of crime, its measurement, reduction, and the challenges of prosecuting offenders. The program includes field trips, internships, mentoring, and practical experience through the Student Legal Advice Centre, offering opportunities to engage with the community and provide legal assistance. The curriculum covers all areas of legal services and integrates practical experiences, including mooting competitions, mock trials, and contract drafting.  Students can specialize in various legal fields, such as company law, commercial law, family law, and international human rights, alongside focused study in criminology, exploring crime causation, sentencing, and the impact of crime on society.  The program is recognized by the Bar Standards Board and Solicitors Regulation Authority, providing a pathway to becoming a solicitor or barrister.
Course Structure: The LLB (Hons) with Criminology curriculum covers core legal subjects, foundational criminology and then allows for some specialization in optional modules.  Core modules likely include subjects such as contract law, criminal law, tort law, constitutional law, and legal methods alongside criminological theory, research methods and possibly victimology. Students gain practical skills through activities like case preparation, mooting, interviewing, and negotiation. Specialist modules might include company law, commercial and consumer law, family law, international human rights law, child protection, cybercrime, and legal ethics. The final-year modules facilitate specialisation in areas such as murder, psychopathy, cybercrime, miscarriages of justice or others.  In-depth study of criminology will also explore topics around rehabilitation, punishment, and the criminal justice system, in relation to current societal issues. The program also incorporates hands-on learning, including the Student Legal Advice Centre,  providing opportunities for pro bono work. Real-world learning is emphasized through mock trials, contract drafting, internships, and work placement opportunities.
Year 1: The first year will likely focus on foundational legal principles and introduction to criminology.  Core subjects might include contract law, criminal law, tort law, and constitutional law.  Students also begin to develop essential legal skills such as legal research, case analysis, and legal writing.  An introduction to criminological theory, key concepts, and research methods will be explored, possibly including topics such as crime statistics, sociological theories of crime, and different models of criminal justice.  Field trips may be incorporated to enhance the practical understanding of the legal system.
Year 2: Year two will build upon the first year's foundation, delving deeper into specialized areas of law and criminology. Core legal subjects may include property law, equity and trusts, and administrative law. Students further develop legal skills through sessions such as mooting competitions and workshops and engagement with the Student Legal Advice Centre.  More advanced criminological topics may be included, including aspects of victimology, specific types of crime, and the impact of crime on individuals and communities.  Opportunities for internships and mentoring might start toward the end of the year.
Year 3: The final year allows for specialisation and advanced studies in both law and criminology. Students choose from a range of optional modules in specialist areas of law or criminology. This could include options like company law, family law, human rights law, cybercrime, psychopathy, or other areas of criminal justice practice. The final year also includes a significant project or dissertation, which gives students the opportunity to undertake in-depth research in an area of special interest.  Professional development activities, such as the Legal Skills Triathlon, networking events, and careers workshops would also be prominent in this year.

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical requirements include 72 UCAS points.  A Levels: DDD; T Levels: Pass; BTEC: MMP; Access to HE: Pass with 60 credits (45 at Level 3, minimum Distinction: 0, Merit: 30, Pass: 15). GCSE Maths and English are preferred but not mandatory.  Contextual offers may apply.  For Pakistani students with A-levels or IB from Pakistani international schools, entry to Year 1 is possible.  Postgraduate entry from a recognised Pakistani university requires a Bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2; those with two or three-year Bachelor degrees need a Master's degree pass; A four-year Bachelor's degree with a minimum 2.4/4.00 GPA is considered for Master's entry. PhD applicants from Pakistan need a Bachelor's and Master's degree and a research proposal.
Location/Campus: One Friar Gate Square, Derby Campus
Overview: The University of Derby offers a four-year LLB (Hons) with Foundation Year, designed to equip students with the skills and knowledge needed for a successful legal career.  The program includes a foundation year to strengthen skills and confidence before proceeding to the LLB.  Students can choose a generic LLB or specialize in Company and Commercial Law, International and Comparative Law, International Business Law, or Social and Public Policy.  The course emphasizes practical experience through mooting competitions, mock trials, contract drafting, and work internships.  Students gain practical experience at the Student Legal Advice Centre, offering free legal aid.  The program also includes study visits, networking events, and mentoring opportunities with legal professionals.  The LLB meets the criteria of the Bar Standards Board and Solicitors Regulation Authority, offering exemptions for aspiring solicitors and barristers.
Course Structure: The course integrates academic learning with practical application. The foundation year focuses on building essential academic and professional skills. The LLB program combines core legal subjects with specialized modules in chosen pathways. This includes modules covering case preparation, mooting, interviewing techniques, negotiation strategies, legal research, and problem-solving.  Students participate in various practical assessments like group work, oral presentations, written coursework, and examinations.  The curriculum also includes elements of entrepreneurship, creative thinking, and legal technology. Professional development is a strong focus, with networking events, mentoring, and internships integrated in the curriculum. These combined aspects provide a holistic learning experience that prepares graduates for the realities of legal practice and diverse careers.
Year 1: The first year, a foundation year, focuses on developing essential academic skills and knowledge, providing students with a solid base before starting their LLB studies in Year 2. It covers fundamental academic skills, study methods and potentially introductory aspects relevant to studying law.  Support from expert staff ensures sufficient preparation.

Required IELTS Score: 7.0 with 6.5 in each skills area
Entry Requirement: For admission to the LLM program, an honors degree (minimum 2.2 classification) in any subject is required.  Relevant work experience may also be considered.  If English is not your first language, you'll need an IELTS score of 7.0 with at least 6.5 in each skill (reading, writing, listening, and speaking).  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized university in Pakistan is required, equivalent to at least a UK Upper Second Class (2:1) or Lower Second Class (2:2) degree. Students with a two or three-year Bachelor's degree must also have a Master's degree. A four-year Bachelor's degree with honours and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university will also be considered.
Location/Campus: One Friar Gate Square, Derby Campus
Overview: The University of Derby offers a comprehensive LLM program, including specialized pathways in Commercial Law, Corporate and Financial Law, Intellectual Property and Information Technology Law, and International Protection of Human Rights and Personal Freedom.  The program combines academic theory with practical application, providing students with a strong foundation in legal scholarship and research. It emphasizes the interaction of law and policy on an international level, preparing graduates for roles in diverse sectors. The curriculum is flexible, allowing students to tailor their studies to their interests and career goals, whether they are recent graduates or working professionals seeking to enhance their skills and expertise. The LLM program is taught by experienced lecturers and practitioners, and students benefit from modern teaching methods, dedicated support, and access to superior facilities, including a mock courtroom.
Course Structure: The LLM program offers both a general LLM pathway and specialized pathways. The general LLM requires core modules in Legal Scholarship and Independent Studies, along with five additional optional modules from a diverse range.  Specialized pathways include core modules specific to each area and three optional modules. Core modules vary by pathway.  Commercial Law covers commercial theories and sales of goods. Corporate and Financial Law explores company law and international finance.  International Protection of Human Rights focuses on investigating human rights violations and public international law. Intellectual Property and IT Law examines international intellectual property rights and information and communication technology law. Optional modules include Commercial Theories, Company Law, Information and Communication Technology Law, International Protection of Intellectual Property Rights, Intellectual Property in the Digital Age, International Banking and Finance Law, National and International Sale of Goods, Public International Law, The Law and Investigation of Human Rights Violations, International Criminal Law, Transnational Organised Crime, International Economic Law & Development, and International Human Rights Law Clinic.
Year 1: The first year of the full-time LLM program covers core modules such as Legal Scholarship, which focuses on developing research, communication, and independent study skills, and Independent Studies, allowing in-depth exploration of a chosen legal topic. Students also complete modules based on their chosen pathway (general or specialist), which may include Commercial Theories, Company Law, International Banking and Finance Law, The Law and Investigation of Human Rights Violations, or International Protection of Intellectual Property Rights, and at least three optional modules depending on the pathway.
Year 2: NA

Overseas students need a minimum IELTS score of 7.5 overall with at least 6.5 in each skill. For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognized university equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree is needed. Overview: The University of Derby's LLM Legal Practice Course (LLM LPC) is a postgraduate program designed to prepare students for a training contract and ultimately, a career as a solicitor.  The course is highly practical, focusing on both knowledge and skills development. It's divided into three stages: Stage one covers core subjects like business law, litigation, property law, professional conduct, and essential legal skills. Stage two involves three work-based electives allowing students to specialize in areas aligning with their career goals. Stage three consists of independent study, culminating in a dissertation or practice-oriented report.  The program features small group workshops with feedback sessions, role-playing exercises to practice legal skills, and an e-learning system for self-assessment.  The faculty comprises experienced solicitors, many of whom are still active in practice.  The course is designed to equip students with not only the requisite legal knowledge but also the professional skills, work ethic, and commercial awareness needed for success in the legal field.
Course Structure: The LLM LPC is structured in three stages. Stage one focuses on foundational legal subjects and core skills, including business law and practice, civil and criminal litigation, property law and practice, professional conduct, and skills like legal research, interviewing, and advocacy.  Stage two offers a range of elective subjects chosen by the student, allowing for specialization in areas such as criminal litigation, mergers and acquisitions, clinical negligence, commercial law, employment law, and family law.  Stage three centers on independent study, where students undertake a dissertation or practice-oriented report under the supervision of an experienced legal professional. This independent research project allows students to delve deeper into a chosen area of law and to hone their research and employability skills. The assessment methods mainly involve written assessments, but skills-based assessments are also included, as determined by the Solicitors Regulation Authority (SRA).
Year 1: The first year of the full-time LLM LPC program covers core subjects such as business law and practice, civil and criminal litigation, property law and practice, and professional conduct and regulation. Students also develop crucial legal skills through workshops and exercises focusing on legal writing, research, interviewing, advising, and advocacy.  Taxation is integrated into some core subjects.  Students also begin to prepare for their independent study project in the final stage of the program.
Year 2: NA

Course Title: Level 7 Management for an Integrative Health and Social Care Workforce
Entry Requirement: Applicants typically require a bachelor's degree or equivalent in a relevant field, along with work experience in health, social care, or a related sector.  Current employment in a relevant setting is also necessary.  For non-native English speakers, proof of English language proficiency is needed, with options including IELTS 7.0, TOEFL scores (various versions), Pearson Test of Academic English (66), Cambridge Advanced Certificate (Pass), London Tests of English (Level 4), International GCE O Level English Language (Grade C), or International GCSE English/English as a Second Language (Grade C).  Regarding Pakistan specific entry requirements, the University does not directly address this on the provided webpage. However, based on general postgraduate requirements, a relevant bachelor's degree from a recognized Pakistani university (equivalent to a UK Upper or Lower Second Class degree) would likely be sufficient. A master's degree might be required if the bachelor's degree is shorter.  A four-year bachelor's degree with honors (minimum GPA 2.4/4.00) may also qualify.
Overview: This online short course is designed for individuals in managerial roles or aspiring managers within health and social care, encompassing the voluntary and independent sectors. The course teaches essential management skills for improving the quality and services of integrative health and social care.  It addresses the challenges faced in contemporary management roles on both a national and international scale.  Students gain practical skills in strategic management, professional judgment, problem-solving, and effective leadership for quality and service enhancements. Participants also develop skills in  people management, process management, strategic business and service planning, and financial management to navigate the complexities of integrative health and social care settings.
Course Structure: The course covers a wide range of management topics relevant to integrative health and social care.  These include people management (including power dynamics and conflict resolution), process management, project management (commissioning, procurement, and contracting for care services), technology management, information management, organizational structure, and financial management (budget monitoring and decision-making).  Further topics encompass change management, management theory, innovative problem-solving, networking, professional judgment, audit and evaluation, legal, ethical, and policy awareness, quality and service improvement (including complaints management and root cause analysis), social networking for influence, return on investment, and training needs analysis. The course utilizes a blended approach, incorporating online learning and virtual classrooms.

Overview: The Postgraduate Certificate in Management of Long-Term Conditions equips healthcare professionals with advanced skills in managing long-term conditions.  The program focuses on developing critical thinking, analysis, and appraisal skills to inform evidence-based practice.  Students enhance their understanding of interprofessional collaboration and leadership, becoming autonomous practitioners capable of sustaining and advancing specialist knowledge. The curriculum includes modules on the principles of long-term condition management, strategic and clinical management, and an optional module allowing for specialization in an area of personal interest. This prepares graduates for case management roles, such as community matron, nurse practitioner, or district nurse, at both individual and strategic levels. The program aligns closely with the current health agenda, ensuring relevance and currency.
Course Structure: The program consists of 60 credits distributed across three modules:  'Principles of Long-Term Conditions Management' (20 credits), 'Strategic and Clinical Management of Long-Term Conditions' (20 credits), and an 'Option Module' (20 credits).  The option module allows students to tailor their studies to a specific area of interest, in consultation with the Programme Leader. Assessment methods include presentations and assignments. Entry Requirement: For this apprenticeship, you must be employed for at least 30 hours weekly, with your employer covering apprenticeship costs.  Employers generally set their own selection criteria; however, typical academic requirements include Level 3 qualifications such as A-levels (grade C or above in mathematics and a STEM subject) or 90+ credits in an Engineering Level 3 BTEC.  Level 2 qualifications, including 5 GCSEs at grade C or above (Mathematics, English, and a STEM subject), are also usually expected.  For Pakistani students, completing A-levels or the IB from International Schools in Pakistan allows direct entry into the first year. For postgraduate studies, a relevant bachelor's degree from a recognized Pakistani university (equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2) is needed; a master's degree might be required for two or three-year bachelor's degree holders. A four-year bachelor's degree with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university is considered for master's entry.
Overview: This four-year degree apprenticeship program focuses on advanced manufacturing techniques and project management skills needed for successful product launches. Students gain practical experience through 80% on-the-job training and 20% blended learning (face-to-face and online).  The program offers three specializations: Manufacturing Engineering, Manufacturing Engineering with Mechanical Design, and Manufacturing Engineering with Electronics. The first year is largely the same across specializations, with specialized modules introduced later.  The curriculum covers mathematics and science for engineers, materials and manufacturing, CAD/CAE, project management, engineering operations, business management, and product improvement. The program emphasizes practical application and professional development, culminating in a BEng (Hons) degree.
Course Structure: The apprenticeship is structured over a minimum of four years, combining on-the-job learning with academic study. On-the-job learning involves completing tasks and uploading evidence to an e-portfolio.  Academic study accounts for 20% of the course and is delivered through blended learning, with face-to-face sessions in blocks and online activities.  The curriculum varies slightly depending on the chosen specialization, but all share common foundational modules in core engineering principles. Year one introduces fundamental engineering concepts, while subsequent years delve into specialized areas like advanced manufacturing technologies, design, and management. Project work, independent study, and professional development are integral components throughout.
Year 1: The first year provides a foundational engineering experience. Core modules include Applied Scientific Methods 1, Electrical Principles and Analysis, Practical Skills and Business Context, Materials and Manufacturing Processes, and Computer Aided Design. These modules build a strong base of relevant engineering knowledge and practical skills, preparing apprentices for more advanced study in the subsequent years.
Year 2: The second year introduces more specialized modules depending on the chosen pathway. For Manufacturing Engineering and Manufacturing Engineering with Electronics, modules may include Advanced Applied Analytical Methods, Computer Integrated Manufacturing, Industrial Control Systems, Corporate Responsibility and Professional Development, and Analog and Digital Electronics. For Manufacturing Engineering with Mechanical Design, modules may include Advanced Applied Analytical Methods, Thermo Fluids, Control and Instrumentation Systems, and Corporate Responsibility and Professional Development.
Year 3: In year three, students continue to specialize.  Manufacturing Engineering focuses on Engineering Design Modelling, Design for Manufacture and Materials Optimisation, Manufacturing Automation and Control, and Advanced Manufacturing Technology and Systems.  Manufacturing Engineering with Mechanical Design covers Engineering Design Modelling, Computer Integrated Manufacturing, Applied Thermodynamics, and Advanced Mechanical Design and Materials.  Manufacturing Engineering with Electronics includes Electronic Systems (Mode B), Control and Instrumentation Technology, Embedded Systems Technology, and Advanced Manufacturing Technology and Systems.
Year 4: The final year builds upon the previous three, specializing further, integrating knowledge, and focusing on project work and professional development.  Manufacturing Engineering may include Advanced Operations Management, Systems Simulation and Project Management or Advanced Engineering Materials and Applications, and Independent Study and Professional Development.   Manufacturing Engineering with Mechanical Design covers Embedded Systems, Advanced Engineering Design Modelling, and Independent Study and Professional Development.  Manufacturing Engineering with Electronics includes Advanced Operations Management, Systems Simulation and Project Management, and Independent Study and Professional Development.
