Developed in collaboration with the Institute of Quarrying, it aims to equip leaders and managers with advanced skills and knowledge.  The program balances online learning with optional workshops, allowing flexibility for working professionals. The curriculum covers a range of crucial topics such as leadership, operational and project management, financial and commercial management, marketing, extractives management, lean structures, quality management, and health, safety, and environmental management. A significant component is a work-based project, where students apply their learning to a real-world problem within their workplace.  The program is taught by experienced industry professionals and university faculty.
Course Structure: The course structure consists of five modules delivered over two years.  Students will cover Advanced Extractives Technology, Commercial & Financial Management, Operational Management, and Resource Management.  A substantial portion of the program is dedicated to a Work Based Project, allowing students to apply their knowledge to their professional context.  Assessment is comprised of a mix of exams and continuous assessment throughout the modules. Optional workshops enhance the learning experience, offering face-to-face interaction with academics and fellow students. Online access to learning materials, library resources, and video lectures supplement in-person interactions.
Year 1: The first year of the BSc (Hons) Minerals Management (Top-Up) includes modules on Advanced Extractives Technology, focusing on applying advanced-level theory to practice within the mineral products sector. Students learn about the required standards, ethical responsibilities, and technical operations within the mineral products industry.  Commercial and Financial Management in the first year provides an understanding of key issues for middle and senior managers in the industry, encompassing business environments and investment appraisal techniques. Students gain knowledge of legal frameworks governing project contracts.
Year 2: The second year of the BSc (Hons) Minerals Management (Top-Up) involves modules such as Operations Management, which examines key operations issues from a strategic and practical perspective, relating theory to challenges in a globalized business environment.  Students develop critical understanding of operations management in the mineral products sector. The Resource Management module examines both material and human resources, covering aspects of the employment process, workforce participation, procurement, and supply chain management.  A significant portion of the second year is dedicated to the Work Based Project, where students work on a project related to their own workplace, applying their learned skills and knowledge to address a specific issue or challenge.

Course Title: Level 5 Mineral Products Technician Higher Apprenticeship
Required IELTS Score: NA
Entry Requirement: This program is open to anyone employed within the Mineral Products Sector, but it's recommended that new employees (younger learners from tertiary/6th Form College or those with less experience) are the most suitable recruits.  A level 2 qualification in English and Maths is desirable; those without it need to achieve this level before the End-Point Assessment.  For those with an education, health and care plan or a legacy statement, the minimum requirement is Entry Level 3. A British Sign Language (BSL) qualification can replace the English qualification for BSL primary speakers.  Applicants must demonstrate English language capability equivalent to GCSE English Language, IELTS 6.0, or its equivalent. They must be 18 or older upon commencement. A Commitment Statement outlining the apprenticeship's details, expectations from the employer, higher education provider, and the apprentice is required.  For Pakistan, students must meet the general entry requirements mentioned in the text.  Specifically for undergraduate programs, completing A-levels or the International Baccalaureate from Pakistani International Schools is sufficient. Postgraduate students from Pakistan require a relevant Bachelor's degree.  A Bachelor's degree with honors (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani University would be sufficient for consideration.  PhD applicants need a master's and bachelor's degree, plus a research proposal.
Overview: The Mineral Products Technician Higher Apprenticeship is a 26-month program designed to equip new and existing employees in the mineral products sector with the knowledge, skills, and behaviors necessary for supervisory and senior management roles.  It blends on-campus and workplace learning, emphasizing practical application and industry relevance. The curriculum covers various aspects of the industry, including operational management, health and safety, environmental considerations, and specific pathway-focused modules (Mineral Extractives, Asphalt, Concrete, Cement, Clay).  The program aims to improve recruitment and retention, address sector challenges, and enhance the employability of apprentices.  The program incorporates blended learning that combines face-to-face teaching sessions with online learning via a virtual learning environment.  Students can expect project work, reports, presentations, and portfolio development.
Course Structure: The apprenticeship comprises various modules, beginning with a common first year focusing on introduction to the industry, environmental considerations, and study skills.  In the second year, apprentices choose one of five pathways (Mineral Extractives, Asphalt, Concrete, Cement, Clay). Each pathway focuses on several modules related to that specific area. The program concludes with an independent End Point Assessment (EPA), containing a professional discussion supported by a portfolio of evidence and a project focused on a technical health and safety report along with a presentation and questioning.
Year 1: The first year involves three core modules: Industry Introduction (providing an overview of the Mineral Products Industry, its economic significance, health and safety, and environmental awareness), Industry and the Environment (covering geology, workplace health and safety, sustainability, and corporate responsibility), and Learning, Thinking and Study Skills in Higher Education (focusing on personal development planning, study skills and e-portfolio creation).
Year 2: The second year begins with two further core modules: Business and Operational Management (covering running a business, communication, asset management and sustainable business concepts) and Production Facility Engineering (covering principles of hydraulic systems, mechanical power transmission, asset prioritisation and plant maintenance, and electrical safety).  After these students specialize, choosing modules from one of the five pathways; Mineral Extractives (Mineral Extraction & Transportation, Minerals Management & Processing, Blasting Operations); Asphalt & Pavements (Asphalt Technology, Pavement Solutions & Innovation, Contracts Management); Concrete (Concrete Constituents & Types, Concrete in Construction, Durable Concrete Structures); Clay (Clay Evaluation & Investigation, Clay Winning, Preparation & Forming, Clay Drying & Firing); Cement (Cement Raw Materials Processing, Cement Process Engineering & Cement Clinker Processing).

Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with a minimum of 5.5 in all areas
Entry Requirement: Applicants need an undergraduate degree (typically a 2:1 or higher; a 2:2 may be considered) in biology, human biology, biomedical health, or a related field.  Relevant professional experience in human health may also be considered. International students must have an equivalent qualification. If English isn't your first language, IELTS 6.5 is required.  Selected candidates will submit a one-page research project proposal.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized university (equivalent to a UK Upper Second Class (2:1) or Lower Second Class (2:2) is needed. Those with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees require a Master's degree pass. A four-year Bachelor's with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.0 from a recognized Pakistani university is also acceptable.
Overview: The MRes Molecular Medicine program at the University of Derby equips students with essential research skills for a career in research.  The curriculum focuses on developing confident, independent researchers capable of planning, executing, and evaluating biological research projects. Students undertake a substantial research project under expert supervision, benefiting from specialized laboratory facilities including molecular labs, an imaging suite, and a new Omics facility.  The program fosters strong industry connections with Royal Derby Hospital and other healthcare providers, enabling collaborations and networking opportunities.  The program is suitable for those seeking a stand-alone research qualification or a stepping stone to a PhD.
Course Structure: The MRes Molecular Medicine program comprises core and optional modules.  Core modules include Independent Research (80 credits) or Independent Study (20 credits for the Postgraduate Diploma), Professional Skills in Biomedical Science (40 credits), and Research Methods in Data Interpretation (20 credits). Optional modules cover diverse areas like Applied Microbial Biotechnology, Clinical Haematology and Transfusion Medicine, Applied Immunology, and Advanced Cellular Pathology.  Assessment methods are varied, encompassing essays, portfolios, dissertations, blogs, presentations, and viva voce examinations.  Students choose from various research project themes, including investigations in HPV, cardiac rehabilitation, angiogenesis, nanoparticle effects and apelin analogues, allowing for specialization within molecular medicine.
Year 1: The first year of the full-time MRes Molecular Medicine program involves a rigorous schedule combining core modules in research methods, professional skills applicable to biomedical science and data interpretation. Students will dedicate a significant portion of their time to their independent research project, carrying out experiments, analyzing data and writing up their findings.  This will be supported by regular supervision from academic staff and they may also be involved in some optional modules based on particular interests, as mentioned above in the 'Course Structure'
Year 2: NA

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical requirements include 120 UCAS points.  A-Level students need BBB, with at least a B in Mathematics or Physics.  T-Level students require a Merit in Maintenance, Installation and Repair for Engineering and Manufacturing, Design and Development for Engineering and Manufacturing, or Engineering, Manufacturing, Processing and Control. BTEC students need DMM in Engineering, Motorsport, or Physics, including a Merit in Maths. GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or above are also required.  An Access to HE Diploma with 60 credits (45 at Level 3, minimum Distinction: 15, Merit: 24, Pass: 6) is acceptable.  International students may need to meet additional English language requirements.  For Pakistani students, A-levels or IB from Pakistani international schools allow direct entry to Year 1. Postgraduate entry from Pakistan requires a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2,  a Master's degree if the Bachelor's was two or three years, or a four-year Bachelor's with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.0.
Overview: The BEng (Hons) Motorsport Engineering degree at the University of Derby is a comprehensive program designed to equip students with the skills and knowledge needed for success in the international motorsport industry.  The curriculum covers a wide range of topics, including advanced powertrain engineering, motorsport chassis design, and computational fluid dynamics.  Students gain hands-on experience in state-of-the-art facilities, such as a dedicated motorsport workshop, computer labs with industry-standard software, and a mechanical workshop. Extracurricular activities, like Formula Student and the Radical SR1 Cup Championship, offer valuable real-world experience. The course emphasizes practical and technical skills, with assessments involving coursework, examinations, and presentations.  Graduates are prepared for roles with top teams and manufacturers, as evidenced by the success of past graduates in Formula 1 and other racing environments. The program also includes opportunities for optional work placements and support from personal academic tutors.
Course Structure: The course combines theoretical learning with extensive practical work.  Year 1 provides a broad engineering foundation, allowing students to explore different specializations before choosing to continue with Motorsport Engineering, or switching to Electrical and Electronic or Mechanical Engineering in Year 2.  The program features modules covering topics such as vehicle dynamics, computational fluid dynamics (CFD), advanced power train engineering, and motorsport chassis design. Practical work is a key part of the curriculum, involving hands-on experience in the workshop using race vehicles, engines, and gearboxes, as well as working with the computer labs and specialist facilities, including a wind tunnel, a dedicated makerspace and industry-standard software. Assessment methods combine coursework assignments, examinations, and formal presentations. The final year project allow for specialized focus and real-world application of acquired skills.
Year 1: The first year focuses on building a strong foundation in engineering principles. Students will be exposed to core engineering concepts across multiple disciplines, including mathematics, physics, materials science, and fundamental engineering design. There will be an introduction to vehicle systems, electronics, and mechanical elements, providing a broad base before students specialize.  Students also undertake practical laboratory work to reinforce theoretical knowledge.
Year 2: Year two allows students to specialize in Motorsport Engineering or switch to Mechanical or Electrical Engineering.  The focus shifts to more specialized subjects relevant to the chosen area. For Motorsport Engineering, this involves in-depth study of vehicle dynamics, chassis design, powertrain systems, and aerodynamics.  Students will work hands-on with the Radical SR1 race car, enhancing their practical skills through testing and simulation exercises. This year also includes opportunities to participate in track testing and possibly racing events.
Year 3: The final year builds on the knowledge and skills developed in the previous years.  Students undertake an extensive final-year project. It's an opportunity to showcase their abilities, applying the learned skills to a real-world engineering challenge. Advanced topics in various areas of expertise are covered in depth, pushing students to the limit of their knowledge. The focus is on developing advanced skills for professional practice, such as team work, project management, and professional report writing.  Students may also participate in industrial visits and guest lectures to enhance their professional networking.

Course Title: BEng (Hons) Motorsport Engineering with Foundation Year
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 72 UCAS points, A Levels (DDD), a T Level Pass, BTEC (MMP), GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or above, or a Pass in an Access to HE Diploma.  International students need an IELTS score of 6.0 with at least 5.5 in each skill.  For Pakistani students, A-levels or IB from Pakistani international schools allow entry to Year 1.  Postgraduate entry from Pakistan requires a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2, or a 4-year Bachelor's with Honours and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.0.  A Master's degree is needed if the Bachelor's is 2 or 3 years. PhD applicants from Pakistan need a Master's and Bachelor's degree in a relevant subject, along with a research proposal.
Overview: The BEng (Hons) Motorsport Engineering with Foundation Year is a four-year undergraduate program designed to equip students with the technical and digital skills needed for success in the global motorsport industry.  The foundation year strengthens skills and knowledge, providing support before progressing to the honours degree.  The program combines theoretical learning with extensive practical experience in state-of-the-art facilities, including workshops, computer labs, wind tunnel, and makerspace.  Students work with various vehicles and systems, using industry-standard software.  Extracurricular activities such as Formula Student and Radical SR1 Cup enhance practical skills.  The curriculum aims to fulfill multi-disciplinary industry requirements, offering students the chance to switch to Mechanical or Electrical Engineering in the second year.  The program is accredited by the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, leading to potential Chartered Engineer status with further study.
Course Structure: The course integrates theoretical knowledge with extensive hands-on experience.  The first year provides a broad foundation in engineering, allowing students to explore different areas before specializing. The curriculum progresses through the core principles of motorsport such as chassis design, engine technology, vehicle dynamics, aerodynamics and material science. Students gain practical skills in workshops, utilize industry standard software for simulations and design, and are encouraged to participate in team projects like Formula Student; providing valuable team work and project management exposure.  Throughout the program, students have access to state-of-the-art facilities to conduct practical projects, design simulations, and advance their understanding of motorsport engineering.  The course incorporates industry visits, guest lectures, and participation in motorsport competitions such as the Radical SR1 Cup.
Year 1: Year one serves as the foundation year, strengthening skills and knowledge in various engineering disciplines.  Students gain a broad understanding of engineering principles, providing time to explore areas before specializing. The curriculum covers fundamental engineering concepts, mathematics, and science, building a solid base for later years.  The foundation year also supports students requiring additional time to adjust to university-level studies and aims at developing their confidence before advancing to the main degree program. The specific modules may vary, so checking the latest curriculum is advised.
Year 2: The second year introduces core motorsport engineering concepts, building on the foundation year's skills. Students delve into vehicle dynamics, chassis design, and powertrain engineering; alongside modules that include computational fluid dynamics, materials selection and manufacturing processes are key components of the second year. Students also participate in projects using the Radical SR1 race car, gaining hands-on experience in race car engineering through practical and simulation work, alongside potential track testing and race participation opportunities. Students can optionally transfer into mechanical engineering or electrical engineering degrees at the end of this year.
Year 3: The third year deepens students' knowledge in specialized areas of motorsport engineering.  Advanced modules expand on previous year's foundations, covering topics like aerodynamics, advanced powertrain engineering, and computational fluid dynamics. More independent project work is integrated in the third year; where you will collaborate on group projects, further enhancing your practical skills and experience in collaboration and project management. Students might also participate in more advanced industry-relevant activities, such as visits to leading motorsport facilities or participation in major motorsport events.
Year 4: The final year focuses on a significant individual project, allowing students to apply and integrate their knowledge from previous years, often mimicking a real-world industry setting. The final year project usually involves a substantial design or research component; enhancing critical thinking, problem-solving, and practical skills. Advanced topics might include the latest technologies in motorsport technologies; offering insight into future career paths while allowing students to further develop their specialization.  Additionally, students may have opportunities to enhance their professional networks through internships and industry placements.

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical entry requirements include 112 UCAS points, A-Levels BBC, T Level Merit, BTEC DMM, GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or equivalent.  An Access to HE Diploma with 60 credits (45 at Level 3) is also accepted.  A portfolio is recommended. Contextual offers may apply to care experienced students, estranged students, refugees, asylum seekers, or students whose parents/carers are in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or IB in Pakistan, direct entry into Year 1 is possible. For postgraduate study, a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2 is needed; two or three-year Bachelor's degree holders require a Master's pass.  A four-year Bachelor's with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University is considered for Masters entry. PhD applicants need a Master's and Bachelor's degree in a relevant subject and a research proposal.
Overview: The University of Derby's BSc (Hons) Music Production is a three-year, full-time undergraduate program focusing on practical studio skills and industry knowledge. Students learn sound recording and production techniques, design and build sound-making tools, and create commercial recordings.  The course emphasizes hands-on experience in state-of-the-art recording studios and collaborations with industry professionals through strong employer links.  Students gain an understanding of studio technology, post-production, acoustics and the commercial aspects of the music business, preparing them for diverse careers in the music industry. The program integrates practical work and theoretical knowledge while providing access to industry-standard equipment and facilities.
Course Structure: The course is structured around modules covering all aspects of music production, from recording to the final, commercially viable product. This includes theoretical learning, especially in acoustics, and practical time in studios. Students will work on their own projects, building skills in sound engineering, mixing, mastering and creating content ready for release. The coursework uses a variety of assessment methods to prepare students for the demands placed upon graduates in this sector. Practical sessions, lab work, investigations and exams help students gain a complete understanding of the aspects of a role in music production.  Throughout their studies, students will have the opportunity to use professional recording studios, software and equipment, helping to build up a strong portfolio of work.
Year 1: The first year introduces foundational concepts in music production, including sound recording techniques, studio acoustics, and basic digital audio workstations (DAWs).  Students will develop fundamental skills in audio editing, mixing, and mastering. Practical sessions allow them to gain confidence using various recording equipment and studio technologies.  Introductory modules on music theory and music business may also be part of the curriculum. The year culminates in individual and collaborative projects, honing their studio skills and creative abilities. The emphasis is a foundation in technical and creative aspects of production.
Year 2: Building upon the first year, this level explores advanced studio techniques, including more complex audio editing, mixing, and mastering, using high-end studio equipment and software. Students will delve deeper into music theory, sound design, and studio acoustics to improve their ability to deliver a polished product.  Students may specialize in certain areas of music production, such as sound for film or video games, developing their skills accordingly, and gaining expertise in their chosen area. The year includes advanced collaborative projects and the development of a substantial portfolio of work.
Year 3: The final year focuses on professional practice and career development. Students undertake a major project, often involving creating a complete recording, designing audio for video game projects, or work related to a similar situation. This project would be assessed, with the emphasis given to the successful delivery of a product to a professional standard. During this final level, students may have the opportunity to undertake work experience, and gain industry experience before starting their career, making their portfolio and experience more competitive during their search for work.  Modules on music business, marketing, and intellectual property rights prepare students for the realities of the changing sector. The year concludes with a final assessment and presentation of work.

Entry Requirement: An undergraduate degree (at least second class) in a relevant subject, or equivalent is required.  Applicants must submit a digital portfolio and a written statement describing their practice and ambitions. A meeting with the programme leader to discuss the portfolio may also be required. For students whose first language is not English, an IELTS score of 6.0 or equivalent is necessary.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognized University in Pakistan, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree, is required. Students with a two or three-year Bachelor's degree must have a Master's degree pass. A Bachelor's degree with honors (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani University is considered for entry.
Annual Tuition Fee: £9,720 (Full-time) / £1,080 per 20 credits (Part-time) UK students; £16,900 (Full-time) International Students
Overview: The University of Derby's MA Music Production is a postgraduate program designed to equip students with the academic knowledge and practical skills needed for success in the music and media production industries.  The course focuses on developing professional judgment, technical and creative abilities, and a strong understanding of the field. Students work individually and in groups, simulating real-world collaborative environments. The program is accredited by JAMES, ensuring its alignment with industry standards.  Students gain practical experience through collaborations with Dubrek, a local recording studio and music venue, providing valuable work experience opportunities throughout their studies.  The curriculum includes modules covering research methods, perceptual technologies, music production systems, studio production, digital signal processing, and sound design, with a significant independent project component.
Course Structure: The MA Music Production program is structured into modules, which include both practical and theoretical components. The postgraduate certificate includes modules in Research Methods: Application and Evaluation, Perceptual Technologies, and Music Production Systems. The postgraduate diploma adds CPD and Strategic Management, and Studio Production. Students can choose an optional module, such as Digital Signal Processing and Sound Design or a negotiated module. The final MA stage involves a significant Independent Scholarship (Technology) project which allows for significant independent creative work to develop and showcase a final project.
Year 1: The first year of the full-time MA Music Production program covers fundamental aspects of music production and research. Students will complete modules on Research Methods: Application and Evaluation;  Perceptual Technologies, which explores the technical and creative aspects of audio; and Music Production Systems, covering studio environments and the technical aspects of recording and mixing. The optional module, covering aspects of digital signal processing and/or sound design, allows for focused study in a specific area of music production. The year concludes with projects relevant to these modules.
Year 2: The second year, for part-time students, continues to develop practical skills and theoretical understanding through modules focusing on CPD and strategic management, essential for career advancement in the creative industries. Studio Production provides in-depth training in studio techniques and workflow.  The year culminates in the substantial Independent Scholarship (Technology) project, where students use their creative and technical skills to develop a significant piece of work. This project is a major part of the degree, demonstrating research and production capacity.

Course Title: BSc (Hons) Music Production with Foundation Year
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical requirements include 72 UCAS points, A Levels (DDD), a T Level pass, BTEC (MMP), or a pass in an Access to HE Diploma. GCSEs in Maths and English are preferred but not mandatory.  A portfolio is recommended.  International students will need to meet the IELTS requirement.  For Pakistani students completing A-Levels or the IB from international schools in Pakistan, entry into the first year is possible. Students from Pakistan holding a four-year Bachelor's degree with honours and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized university may be considered.
Annual Tuition Fee: UK: £9,250 per year; International: £16,900 per year
Overview: The BSc (Hons) Music Production with Foundation Year is a four-year undergraduate program at the University of Derby, focusing on practical music production skills within a commercial context.  Students learn various aspects of recording, from preparation and recording to processing and editing, developing a portfolio of commercial recordings.  The course blends technical skills training with an understanding of the music industry and how to promote music.  It's accredited by JAMES, ensuring it meets industry standards.  The program utilizes top-tier recording studios and other facilities, plus strong industry connections for work experience opportunities.
Course Structure: The course covers all aspects of the music production process, from initial recording through to the creation of a finished commercial product. Students gain practical experience in state-of-the-art recording studios, develop their skills using a wide range of equipment, and explore subjects such as studio acoustics and electronics.  The curriculum integrates practical work with theoretical knowledge and industry insights, including collaborations with professional companies. Assessment methods are varied, including coursework, portfolios, assignments, presentations, group projects, and exams, offering a balanced approach to learning and assessment.
Year 1: The foundation year likely involves introductory modules covering fundamental music theory, aural skills, music technology basics, and introductory studio techniques. Students might begin developing their foundational skills in using Digital Audio Workstations (DAWs) and basic recording workflows. This year may also include elements of music history, performance, and fundamental music industry context.
Year 2: Year two builds on the foundation year, deepening students' skills in audio engineering, music production techniques, and studio workflows. It is likely students refine their DAW skills and explore specific genres. This year will likely continue to build their knowledge base in music technology and industry practices. Students may begin smaller-scale project work to develop portfolio pieces.
Year 3: In the third year, students further develop their expertise in advanced music production techniques, potentially focusing on specialized areas like mixing, mastering, or specific recording styles.  They may undertake larger, more complex projects with a greater emphasis on commercial viability and professional standards.  Industry-related modules or work experience will be integral to refining practical skills. Students likely begin exploring their specialization paths.
Year 4: The final year is likely focused on a significant capstone project, possibly a portfolio of professional-level recordings, a large-scale project, or collaborative work showcasing their advanced skills and abilities.  Students develop their business acumen through management and marketing modules and will work on more realistic professional scenarios.  This prepares them for career opportunities after graduation.

Required IELTS Score: 7.0 with 6.5 in each skills area
Entry Requirement: Applicants need a first degree (2:2 or above) in a relevant subject or significant relevant experience/equivalent qualifications.  They must demonstrate experience working with individuals experiencing emotional/mental distress, learning needs, or developmental difficulties.  Appropriate musical ability and musicianship are essential, along with emotional robustness and intellectual capacity. All applicants meeting basic criteria attend a selection day.  If English isn't your first language, you'll need an IELTS of at least 7.0 with 6.5 in each skills area, or equivalent.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised University in Pakistan equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree is required.  Those with two or three-year Bachelor degrees also need a Master's degree pass.  A Bachelor's degree with honours (four-year) and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University is considered for entry.
Location/Campus: Kedleston Road and Britannia Mill, Derby Campus
Annual Tuition Fee: £16,900 for the full course£0 for part time
Overview: The University of Derby's MA Music Therapy is a two-year, full-time program designed to train aspiring music therapists. The course emphasizes an integrative approach, combining music and musicianship with theoretical knowledge and practical experience. It provides extensive clinical placements in various health, social care, and community settings. Students gain hands-on experience working with diverse clients under the guidance of experienced supervisors. The curriculum integrates theoretical concepts with practical application, including music performance, improvisation, and experiential group work. In addition to academics, students are expected to attend personal therapy sessions throughout the course and build a portfolio to showcase their abilities. The program aligns with Health and Care Professions Council (HCPC) standards, allowing graduates to register and practice as music therapists in the UK.
Course Structure: The MA Music Therapy program is structured into modules covering various aspects of music therapy practice.  The curriculum includes core modules focusing on music and musicianship in practice, arts therapies theory, research, and clinical placements.   Students participate in experiential learning groups, which help develop their therapeutic skills and teamwork ability.  They also undertake an independent study project on musicianship-related topics. Theoretical components are taught through lectures, seminars, and personal tutorials supplemented with online learning. The integration of theory and practice is a central element of the course structure, with significant time allocated to supervised clinical placements, allowing students to implement their theoretical learning in real-world settings.   Modules build progressively in complexity and depth, providing a comprehensive foundation for effective practice.
Year 1: The first year of the MA Music Therapy program lays the foundation for music therapy practice.  Key modules include "Music and Musicianship in Practice," which builds on students' musical skills and knowledge.  "Arts Therapies Theory and Research in Relation to Practice 1" introduces students to theoretical frameworks relevant to music therapy, building upon concepts of therapeutic communication and relationship building.  Practical skills are developed and honed through the first clinical placement, providing valuable experience in a supervised clinical environment. These early modules offer a blend of musical skill development and theoretical learning, ensuring a well-rounded foundational experience upon which subsequent learning can confidently be built.
Year 2: The second year of the course allows students to deepen their acquired skills and knowledge. The "Music Therapy Experiential Group 1 and 2 " modules provide opportunities for self-reflection, and collaborative learning.  In addition, students engage in a second clinical placement, expanding their experience with a broader range of clients and settings.  The year culminates in the major independent scholarship project, allowing students to demonstrate their acquired knowledge and skills in research and writing. The project allows for independent investigation into a topic of personal interest and relevance, bringing coherence to the theoretical and practical elements of the program and demonstrating their readiness for professional practice.

For those seeking LBR (Learning Beyond Registration) funding, direct application to the university is required. For self-funded students, contact with admissions is necessary. Overview: The University of Derby's Negotiated Module in Health, Psychology, and Social Care is a flexible, undergraduate-level course designed for health professionals.  This 20-credit module allows students to propose a tailored study plan focusing on an area relevant to their professional interests or those of their employer.  The curriculum is not pre-set; rather, it's designed through negotiation with a supervisor, ensuring the subject matter directly addresses specific learning needs. Students will collaborate to define learning outcomes and assessment methods, leading to a customized learning experience.  The module offers a chance to explore niche topics within the health and social care fields that might not be covered in standard curricula, or to enhance existing knowledge in a practical way. This allows professionals to deepen their expertise and boost their career prospects in a highly individualized learning setting.
Course Structure: The course structure is highly individualized and determined through a negotiation process between the student and their supervisor. The student proposes a focus area within health, psychology, or social care, and a detailed study plan is developed collaboratively. The plan includes clearly defined learning objectives, methodologies, and a robust assessment strategy aligned with university standards.  The supervisor ensures the proposed project is feasible, meets the necessary academic rigor, and adheres to ethical guidelines. Once the plan is approved (learning contract), the student works to complete the project, utilizing appropriate research, analysis, and presentation techniques. A significant component will be independent study, with scheduled supervision meetings to discuss progress, address challenges, and guide the overall work.
Year 1: NA
Year 2: NA

Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with a minimum of 5.5 in all areas
Entry Requirement: For this postgraduate course, students must have completed a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised University.  This should be equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree. Students with a two or three-year Bachelor's degree must also have a Master's degree. A Bachelor's degree with honours (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University is considered for entry.  The course requires access to a suitable clinical placement in line with CASE requirements, and a workplace mentor to assess final competence.
Overview: This postgraduate module focuses on equipping healthcare professionals with the knowledge and skills for musculoskeletal ultrasound examinations.  Building upon existing expertise, the course allows participants to expand their specialist skills to offer high-quality musculoskeletal ultrasound services in their clinical settings. The module involves a negotiated learning contract, allowing students to tailor their learning to areas like shoulder, hand, wrist, elbow, foot, ankle, hip, knee, rheumatology, neonatal hips, lumps, bumps, hernias, and ultrasound-guided injections.  Students work closely with a workplace mentor, academic supervisor, and expert advisor, creating a portfolio demonstrating competence.  The curriculum covers relevant legislation, anatomy, physiology, pathology, scan protocols, patient care, reporting, and clinical governance.  A personalized learning strategy balances self-directed learning, tutorial support, and supervised scanning practice. Successful completion requires demonstrating competency rather than a specific number of scans.
Course Structure: The module uses a negotiated learning contract, allowing students to choose at least two areas of musculoskeletal ultrasound practice.  Regardless of the chosen focus, all students must demonstrate competency in: rationale for developing musculoskeletal ultrasound service; relevant legislation, policy, and guidelines; anatomy, physiology, and pathology; vetting ultrasound requests; scan indications, contraindications, and limitations; patient assessment and consent; dynamic ultrasound assessment; imaging and reporting protocols; comparison with other tests; relevance of ultrasound findings; clinical governance, self-audit; and professional conduct.  The learning approach comprises self-directed study, tutorial sessions, and supervised practice in a clinical placement setting.  The total scanning hours vary according to individual learning needs.
Year 1: NA
Year 2: NA

Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with a minimum of 5.5 in all areas
Entry Requirement: For this postgraduate course, students must have completed a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised University.  In Pakistan, this should be equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree. Students with two or three-year Bachelor degrees need a pass in a Master’s degree. A Bachelor's degree with honours (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University is also considered.  The course requires existing musculoskeletal ultrasound experience.  All students need access to a workplace mentor with relevant skills and experience to assess final competence.
Overview: This postgraduate module builds upon existing musculoskeletal ultrasound skills, enabling participants to enhance their ultrasound services within their clinical settings.  Through a negotiated learning contract with a workplace mentor, academic supervisor, and expert advisor, learners define their learning objectives and create a portfolio demonstrating competence in an expanded practice area. This involves choosing at least two areas (e.g., shoulder, hip and knee, ultrasound-guided injections) and covers aspects such as relevant legislation, anatomy, physiology, ultrasound protocols, image interpretation and integration with other diagnostic tools. The course combines distance learning with supervised clinical practice and intensive study days.  Successful completion requires demonstrating competency in dynamic ultrasound assessment, image interpretation, reporting, and critically reviewing the use of ultrasound within one's specialty. Students must also justify the expansion of ultrasound provision in their workplace and assess its impact on clinical practice.
Course Structure: The course is structured around a negotiated learning contract, allowing for personalized learning pathways tailored to the individual student's needs and existing skill set. The learning contract will consist of at least two areas of musculoskeletal ultrasound practice. This ensures the course appropriately matches student needs and allows the study to address competency gaps and build on pre-existing knowledge and skills. Modules to be covered include review of relevant legislation and policy, anatomy, physiology and pathology, patient presentation, ultrasound assessment, imaging and reporting, protocols, comparison of diagnostic tests, and clinical governance.  Clinical placement is required to meet CASE criteria and obtain the required supervised practice hours, the total number of which varies depending on the learner's needs and identified competency goals.  Assessment is through a portfolio of evidence demonstrating competence in the chosen specialty areas.

Entry Requirement: For this degree apprenticeship, employment for at least 30 hours per week is mandatory, with the employer covering apprenticeship costs.  Employers generally set their selection criteria, but typically require Level 3 qualifications (e.g., in numerical, scientific, or engineering-related subjects).  Five GCSEs at grade C or above are needed, including Maths, English, and Science. Direct entry at Level 5 is possible with RPL equivalent to Level 4 (from 2023).  For Pakistani students, those completing A-levels or the IB from international schools in Pakistan can enter the first year. Postgraduate entry requires a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognised Pakistani university (equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2), possibly requiring a Master's degree if the Bachelor's was two or three years. A four-year Bachelor's with honours and a minimum 2.4/4.00 GPA from a recognised Pakistani university is also acceptable.
Overview: The BEng(Hons) Nuclear Engineering Degree Apprenticeship is a work-based program developed in collaboration with Rolls-Royce plc.  It aims to equip apprentices with the necessary skills and knowledge for a career in nuclear manufacturing.  The program blends on-the-job training at Rolls-Royce with off-the-job learning at the University of Derby's Nuclear Skills Academy.  Apprentices will gain experience in various aspects of nuclear engineering, from design and manufacturing to testing and maintenance. The curriculum focuses on practical application and real-world learning, complemented by expert mentors and lecturers from the industry. The integrated End Point Assessment (EPA) is completed in the final year.
Course Structure: The four-year apprenticeship is divided into semesters. The curriculum covers a broad range of subjects in nuclear science and engineering, including fundamental engineering principles, manufacturing processes, and nuclear-specific topics.  The program integrates on-the-job training with classroom learning to develop both theoretical understanding and practical skills.  Modules cover areas such as electrical and mechanical engineering, materials science, thermodynamics, systems engineering, and project management.  The final year culminates in a synoptic project and a competence interview as part of the EPA.
Year 1: The first year introduces fundamental concepts in nuclear science and the nuclear industry.  Students gain a solid foundation in electrical and mechanical engineering principles, mathematical tools, engineering materials and manufacturing processes.  An introduction to business management provides a broader perspective on the industry context. Specialized courses may also be introduced, which can include specific topics in nuclear science and technologies.
Year 2: The second year builds on the foundational knowledge with more specialized nuclear engineering modules.  Topics include fluids and thermodynamics as applied to nuclear systems, advanced engineering mathematics, lifecycle management and maintenance of nuclear facilities, digital manufacturing and corporate and professional responsibilities within the nuclear industries.  Furthermore, students will embark on a deeper understanding of nuclear-specific subjects enhancing their understanding of both the theoretical and applied components of the industry.
Year 3: The third year focuses on advanced topics in nuclear engineering, including systems engineering and management, technical responsibility and leadership skills,  sustainability, ethics, innovation in design and manufacture, and advanced manufacturing technologies and systems. The knowledge of computational mechanics and performance is further developed, along with sensor and embedded systems within nuclear applications.  The curriculum prepares students for advanced roles within the field.
Year 4: The final year culminates in the End Point Assessment, which includes a synoptic project and a competence interview.  This assessment integrates the knowledge and skills gained throughout the program and evaluates students' readiness for professional practice. Preparing for and completing the EPA provides a validation of the skills and expertise accumulated over the duration of the program.

Required IELTS Score: 6.5 (with at least 6.0 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 128 UCAS points, A-Level ABB, T Level Merit, BTEC DDM, GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or above, or a Pass Access to HE Diploma with specific credit requirements.  Health or care experience is desirable. An interview is required, along with an Enhanced Disclosure & Barring Service certificate and an Occupational Health Assessment.  International students must meet English language requirements.  For Pakistani students with A-levels or IB from International Schools in Pakistan, entry into the first year is possible. Students with a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised Pakistani University (equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2) are considered for entry.  A two or three-year Bachelor's degree may require a Master's pass, or a four-year honors degree with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised university.
Overview: The MSci Nursing (Adult) and Leadership program is a four-year, full-time course designed to prepare students for registration as a nurse with the Nursing and Midwifery Council (NMC).  The curriculum integrates theoretical knowledge with extensive practical experience through placements in various healthcare settings, totalling 2300 hours. Students develop fundamental nursing skills and in-depth understanding of adult nursing, leadership principles, and emotional resilience. The course uses diverse teaching methods, including classroom-based learning, skills laboratories, and online resources, and ensures alignment with NMC standards. Graduates are equipped to work with diverse patient populations across various healthcare environments.
Course Structure: The course comprises a structured series of modules across four years, designed to meet NMC standards. Year 1 establishes the foundation, Years 2 and 3 build upon this foundation with specialized modules, clinical practice, and simulated learning activities. Year 4 focuses on  leadership development to prepare students for advanced practice and career progression. Assessments are diverse, incorporating theoretical examinations, practical assessments, and evaluations of clinical practice, all aligned with NMC standards. Students receive regular feedback to ensure fitness for practice and professional development.
Year 1: The first year provides a foundational understanding of nursing science, anatomy, physiology, and basic nursing skills. Students learn the ethical and legal principles of nursing practice, fundamentals of care, communication, and teamwork within a multi-professional healthcare context.  The curriculum also includes introductory modules on adult health and illness, incorporating practical skills training in simulated and real-world settings.
Year 2: Building on the foundational skills of Year 1, Year 2 delves into more specialized areas of adult nursing.  Students gain in-depth knowledge of various health conditions and the care management of adult patients, further developing clinical skills, critical thinking, and problem-solving abilities through simulation and practice placements. The year emphasises evidence-based practice and the application of theoretical knowledge in real-life scenarios.
Year 3: Year 3 further specializes students' knowledge and experience in adult nursing. Students engage in complex clinical assessments, intervention planning, and comprehensive care delivery. The year provides exposure to diverse patient groups, advanced clinical skills, leadership, and management concepts within their chosen field.  Modules focus on the integration of evidence-based practice, research, and advanced technologies used in modern healthcare.
Year 4: The final year of study consolidates and extends students' competence in adult nursing, while incorporating advanced leadership and management skills. Modules include strategic leadership, policy, research, and service improvement.  Students further develop skills in advanced clinical practice, reflecting on their experiences, and honing critical thinking and decision-making under pressure through diverse assessments.

For 2025 entry, requirements are 112 UCAS points, A-levels BBC, BTEC DMM, and GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or above. Overview: The University of Derby's BSc (Hons) Adult Nursing program is a three-year, full-time course designed to equip students with the knowledge and skills necessary for a successful career as a registered nurse.  The curriculum focuses on developing practical abilities through clinical placements in diverse healthcare settings, coupled with theoretical learning through lectures, tutorials, and simulated exercises. Students benefit from state-of-the-art facilities, including clinical skills suites and immersive simulated environments. The program emphasizes the development of compassionate professionalism and emotional resilience, aligning with the NMC's Future Nurse standards.  Graduates are eligible to register with the Nursing and Midwifery Council upon completion, opening doors to various career pathways within the NHS and beyond.
Course Structure: The course integrates classroom-based activities, laboratory practice, and online learning resources such as Clinical Skills Net and WhileyPLUS to support anatomy and physiology studies. Assessment methods are diverse, using authentic assessments to ensure professional development and NMC registration compliance. The program utilizes a Practice Assessment Document (MYEPAD) for evaluating practical learning and involves continuous feedback and support from academic and clinical staff. The curriculum is regularly updated to reflect current healthcare practices and to enhance employability prospects.
Year 1: The first year of the adult nursing program lays the foundation for the course. Modules generally cover fundamental nursing concepts, principles of patient care, and the introduction of clinical skills through laboratory practice and simulations. Students develop an understanding of human anatomy, physiology, and disease processes to build a solid base for future learning and application in practice. The year is strategically designed to provide a comprehensive orientation to the nursing profession.
Year 2: The second year of the BSc (Hons) Adult Nursing program builds on the foundational knowledge gained in the first year. Students will engage in more advanced clinical skills and scenarios, both in simulated and real-world settings.  Focus areas will include a deeper dive into adult health and illness, specific health conditions, and appropriate nursing interventions. Students will develop decision-making skills and improve their practical competence in providing holistic care.
Year 3: The final year focuses on consolidating knowledge and skills, developing expertise in specialization areas, and preparing for the challenges of professional practice. This year expands on advanced clinical skills, involves extensive clinical placements, and incorporates modules that critically evaluate the delivery of care to adult patients.  Students further develop their leadership potential, teamwork skills, and reflection practices, ensuring they are prepared for a successful career. Final-year assessments critically explore the application of both theoretical underpinning and practical experience to underpin fitness for practice.

A Foundation Degree and current NMC registration as a Nursing Associate (or equivalent) are also mandatory.  Applicants must undergo an occupational health assessment and Enhanced Disclosure and Barring Service (DBS) check.  An interview is required, and supplementary evidence using a Recognition of Prior Learning template must be submitted, showcasing relevant qualifications, NMC registration, completed theory and practice hours, and practice experience.  A reference detailing how the applicant meets the program's professional requirements is also needed. The curriculum integrates classroom-based learning, skills labs, and online resources, ensuring students meet NMC standards for registration. Desirable requirements include paid employment and recent education or study.  Applicants must complete an occupational health assessment and Enhanced DBS check. Overview: The University of Derby's MSc Nursing (Adult) is a two-year, full-time program designed to prepare graduates for registration as Adult nurses with the NMC.  The program emphasizes a holistic learning experience, fostering emotional resilience and developing compassionate professionalism. Students gain in-depth knowledge in adult nursing practice, exploring diverse acute and long-term conditions.  The curriculum is structured around theory and extensive practice learning (50% of the program) across different healthcare settings, supported by high-quality facilities like clinical skills and immersive suites.  The course incorporates simulated learning activities, linking theory and practice, and provides opportunities for interprofessional collaboration. The program is mapped against NMC standards, ensuring up-to-date and relevant learning that adapts to national changes.
Course Structure: The program is delivered over two years with practice learning assessed in three equal parts.  It includes modules covering professional nursing practice, evidence-based nursing, complex care, leadership, innovation in nursing practice (adult), and transition to autonomous practice (adult). The modules aim to develop fundamental knowledge and skills for safe and effective nursing practice, prioritizing the interests of service users.  Assessment methods vary and align with module learning outcomes.  Practical abilities are reinforced through lectures, tutorials, workshops, and simulated practice, complemented by online resources and technology.  The curriculum also incorporates real-world experience through placements involving 24-hour care. Assessment of practice learning is tracked through the MYEPAD (Practice Assessment Document), aligning with NMC standards.
Year 1: The first year lays the groundwork for professional nursing practice.  Students develop core competencies in  professional nursing practice, evidence-based approaches to nursing, and complex care management. This year focuses heavily on foundational knowledge and skill development, preparing students for increasingly demanding clinical settings.  The curriculum emphasizes the practical application of learned concepts, laying the groundwork for advancing studies in subsequent years.
Year 2: Year two builds upon the foundation established in Year 1.  Students delve into Leadership for Nursing Practice (Adult), focusing on effective leadership strategies in adult care settings. The year also includes Innovation and Improvement in Nursing Practice (Adult), exploring current trends and evidence-based improvements that can be implemented in practical clinical situations.  Finally, the Transition to Autonomous Practice (Adult) module prepares students for independent practice and the challenges associated with decision-making and responsibility for their patients.

Course Title: Undergraduate Nursing (Adult) with Foundation Year BSc (Hons)
Required IELTS Score: 6.5 (with at least 6.0 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For entry in 2024 and 2025, 80 UCAS points are required.  A-levels (CDD), T-levels (Pass with C or above in the core), BTECs (MMP), or an Access to HE Diploma (60 credits, 45 at Level 3 with a minimum of Distinction: 0, Merit: 30, Pass: 15) are acceptable. GCSEs in Maths and English are preferred but not mandatory; if lacking, students can undertake Level 2 Maths and English as part of the course.  An interview is necessary.  An Enhanced Disclosure & Barring Service certificate and an Occupational Health Assessment and Clearance are also required.  Contextual offers may be available for care-experienced students, estranged students, refugees or asylum seekers, and students whose parents/carers are in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistani students, A-levels or IB from Pakistani international schools allow direct entry to Year 1.
Overview: The University of Derby offers a four-year BSc (Hons) Adult Nursing program with a foundation year for students lacking the necessary qualifications for direct entry into the honours degree.  The course is accredited by the Nursing and Midwifery Council (NMC), ensuring graduates' eligibility to register and practice as nurses upon completion, given fulfillment of NMC requirements. The curriculum integrates theory and practice, with a diverse range of assessments designed to prepare students for real-world nursing roles. The program emphasizes compassionate care, professional development, and the application of theoretical nursing knowledge in clinical settings. Students receive hands-on experience through placements and gain support from experienced teaching staff and practicing healthcare professionals who contribute to the teaching. The university also offers personal academic tutoring to help students succeed. The program ensures students meet NMC standards and emphasizes the importance of clinical skills and ethical practice.
Course Structure: The course unfolds over four years. The first year is a foundation year designed to provide students with a solid academic base. The remaining three years focus on the core curriculum of adult nursing, combining theory and practice. The curriculum may include modules covering various aspects of nursing care for adult patients. This includes anatomy, physiology, pharmacology, health assessment techniques, nursing interventions, care planning, and communication skills. Clinical placements in numerous settings (hospitals, community care) will be a key part of the program, allowing students to practice their skills under the supervision of experienced nurses. Students will work and develop in real-world healthcare settings.  Throughout the course, numerous assessments ensure students' grasp of concepts and skill development.  These are designed to not only check a student's knowledge but also develop their professional and academic skillset.
Year 1: The foundation year focuses on building a strong academic foundation, equipping students with essential skills and knowledge to progress to the main degree program. Students may be taught key academic skills, such as research, essay writing, and time management.  They will also be introduced to introductory healthcare concepts, preparing them for future studies. This year is crucial for students to develop confidence and a solid base in academic and nursing-related subjects.
Year 2: The second year is a deeper dive into nursing practice. Modules in this year cover the foundational elements of nursing science and practice. Students refine their assessment and physical examination abilities. They learn to create individualised care plans and effectively communicate with patients, families and healthcare professionals. Early clinical placements begin. Students also be introduced to legal and ethical implications of nursing practices.
Year 3: Year three focuses further on specialised nursing skills.  Students refine their ability in advanced clinical examinations and become adept at managing complex patient conditions and critically analyzing patient data.  Students develop skills in healthcare informatics, management and research.  There is a strong emphasis on leadership and teamwork.  Students' clinical experience expands, allowing them to consolidate their learned skills in a wide variety of workplace settings.
Year 4: The final year of study integrates all previous modules into a comprehensive approach to nursing practice. Students engage in extensive practice placements, further refining their clinical skills.  Modules focus on nursing management, leadership, policy and advocacy.   Students will manage complex scenarios in multiple settings.  At the end of Year 4, students will be ready to undertake their final assessments and graduate ready to embark on their nursing careers.

Overview: The MSci Nursing (Child) and Leadership program is a 4-year, full-time undergraduate course leading to a Master of Science degree and registration with the Nursing and Midwifery Council (NMC).  It provides comprehensive training in child nursing and leadership skills. The curriculum integrates theoretical knowledge with substantial practical experience through various placements in healthcare and community settings. Students develop fundamental nursing knowledge, skills for safe and effective practice, and advanced understanding of child nursing. The program utilizes a blended learning approach, incorporating classroom teaching, skills laboratories, online learning resources, and simulated learning environments.
Course Structure: The course integrates theory and practice, meeting NMC standards.  Students undertake modules covering fundamental nursing skills, child nursing specialization, and leadership development.  Assessment methods are diverse and authentic, supporting professional development and NMC registration requirements.  Practical placement learning comprises 50% of the program, spanning 2,300 hours across diverse settings.  The curriculum uses technology, including the university's Virtual Learning Environment (VLE), Panopto, Clinical Skills Net, and Wiley PLUS.  Students benefit from personal academic tutoring, access to state-of-the-art facilities, and collaboration with students from other disciplines.
Year 1: The first year will lay the foundation for nursing practice by introducing fundamental nursing concepts. Students will learn the basics of nursing care, patient assessment, communication, and teamwork, alongside a general introduction to the field of nursing. Likely subjects covered will include anatomy, physiology, pharmacology, health assessment, and foundational nursing skills such as wound care and medication administration. Alongside this, introductory modules in child development and care may be included.
Year 2: The second year builds upon the foundational knowledge of the first year, integrating theoretical concepts with practical experience in clinical placements. Studies deepen in child care specific areas, such as anatomy and physiology of children, paediatric disease processes, and developmental milestones, incorporating specialized care and treatment of children. Students will put their learning into practice, developing skills in administering interventions while under supervision.  They will begin understanding appropriate levels of independence according to their progress and ability.
Year 3: During the third year, the course focuses on refining specialized knowledge and skills in child nursing. Students will encounter a wider range of clinical settings specializing in child care, applying the theoretical knowledge from previous years to real-world scenarios. A range of illnesses and conditions specific to this age group will be studied, alongside the relevant treatments. Students will work on communication skills to effectively interact with children, families, and healthcare professionals, improving their professionalism and leadership abilities.
Year 4: Year 4 combines advanced child nursing practice with leadership and management skills development. Students will gain even greater autonomy in clinical settings, taking on increasing levels of responsibility in patient care.  This year focusses on leadership theories, ethical decision-making, leading teams, quality management and service improvement within childcare.  Students will also be integrating all previous knowledge to produce a final project or dissertation.

Year 2: Year 2 will introduce more advanced nursing concepts and practices specific to children's healthcare.  Students begin to apply their knowledge gained in the Foundation Year through practical application in a simulated environment.  This year will involve more specialized topics related to child health, development stages, and the management of childhood illnesses.  The emphasis remains on developing professional skills and ethical considerations related to the profession.
Year 3: Year 3 deepens the students' understanding and expertise in various aspects of children's nursing.  Building on previously acquired knowledge and skills, students progress to more complex scenarios. The curriculum includes expanded clinical placements, providing hands-on experience in diverse healthcare settings, including hospitals and community-based services, allowing them to develop valuable skills in practice.  This year often includes additional elective options.
Year 4: The final year provides the opportunity to further specialize in aspects of children's nursing, consolidating skills, knowledge, and experience gained throughout the programme.  Advanced concepts are taught, and students are further evaluated as they near the end of their journey in becoming professionals. There is more time spent in clinical settings, fine-tuning skills, and developing competence and independence as a practicing nurse. As the course nears completion, there is further focus on the ethics of children's nursing and the importance of professional growth.

Health or care experience is desirable.  An interview is required, along with an Enhanced Disclosure & Barring Service certificate and an Occupational Health Assessment.  Applicants whose first language isn't English need IELTS 6.5 overall with no less than 6.0 in each element. For Pakistani students, those completing A-levels or IB from international schools in Pakistan can enter the first year. Overview: The MSci Nursing (Learning Disabilities) and Leadership is a four-year, full-time undergraduate program leading to a Master of Science degree and eligibility for registration with the Nursing and Midwifery Council (NMC).  The program emphasizes a holistic approach to learning, focusing on developing fundamental nursing knowledge and skills, in-depth understanding of learning disabilities, and leadership capabilities.  Practical experience is gained through extensive placements in diverse healthcare settings.  Students are supported by experienced NMC-registered professionals and benefit from excellent facilities.  The curriculum is designed to meet NMC standards, preparing graduates for a rewarding career as registered nurses.
Course Structure: The four-year program integrates classroom learning, skills laboratories and online resources; 50% of the program involves practical placement learning, totaling a minimum of 2300 hours, ensuring the application of theoretical knowledge.  The curriculum includes modules focused on fundamental nursing skills, in-depth knowledge of learning disabilities, and leadership development.   Assessments are diverse, integrating professional practice and NMC standards, with timely feedback provided.   The unique structure allows students without prior degrees to achieve a Master's level award and NMC registration.
Year 1: Year 1 focuses on foundational nursing knowledge and skills, including fundamental care, anatomy and physiology, communication, and basic patient assessment. Students are introduced to the principles of nursing across all fields and across the lifespan.  Emphasis is placed on developing the professional values and behaviors associated with healthcare. Early clinical placements provide valuable experience in diverse settings. Students begin to apply theory to practices through case studies and simulated real-world scenarios.
Year 2: Building on year one, year two delves into specialized areas relating to learning disabilities, exploring complex care needs, communication strategies, ethical considerations, and collaborative practice. An increased number of clinical hours provide experience in managing challenging scenarios and developing proficiency in various nursing skills. Assessment involves a mix of theoretical examination, practical demonstrations, and reflective writing, providing holistic feedback for development.
Year 3: In the third year, students further develop their understanding of learning disability nursing and expand their clinical experience to encompass a more complex range of settings. The curriculum incorporates advanced skills training, such as medication management, wound care, and advanced assessment techniques. Modules focus on person-centered care,  managing challenging behaviors, family support, and service user advocacy. Advanced simulated scenarios are used alongside clinical placement to develop management skills.
Year 4: The final year is dedicated to consolidating nursing skills and developing leadership qualities required for future career progression. Students will focus on research, leadership theories, and quality improvement methodologies to be able to improve the quality of nursing care provided. An extensive final placement opportunity further enhances professional application of acquired skills.  Study concludes with a major piece of work and preparation for NMC registration.

Overview: The University of Derby's BSc (Hons) Nursing (Learning Disabilities) is a three-year, full-time program designed to prepare students for registration with the Nursing and Midwifery Council (NMC) as Learning Disabilities nurses.  The curriculum focuses on providing specialist healthcare and support to individuals with learning disabilities, their families, and care teams.  Students gain practical experience through placements in various healthcare settings, incorporating simulated learning activities to bridge theory and practice.  The program is structured around evidence-based care, emphasizing compassionate professionalism and emotional resilience.  Graduates will be equipped with advanced nursing skills and knowledge to provide high-quality patient care. The program emphasizes NMC standards and integrates opportunities to learn collaboratively with students from other healthcare disciplines.
Course Structure: The BSc (Hons) Nursing (Learning Disabilities) program combines theoretical learning with extensive practical experience. Students will engage in a series of modules covering fundamental nursing skills, learning disability-specific care, health assessment, medication management, communication skills, and ethical considerations.  Placements constitute 50% of the program, providing hands-on experience in various settings such as hospitals, community centers, and residential care facilities.  The curriculum is regularly reviewed to align with NMC standards and adapt to changes in the healthcare landscape.  Modules will employ various teaching methods, including lectures, tutorials, workshops, simulations, and online learning resources. Assessment will involve a mix of practical assessments, written assignments, presentations, and case studies, designed to align with NMC standards and promote reflective practice.
Year 1: The first year lays the foundation for nursing practice, introducing fundamental concepts in anatomy, physiology, pharmacology, and psychology.  Students will learn basic nursing skills such as wound care, medication administration, and communication techniques.  Initial placements provide introductory exposure to care settings and professional practice.  An emphasis on person-centered care and understanding the needs of diverse populations are incorporated. Students begin developing their ability to assess patients and create care plans.
Year 2: Building upon the foundation of year one, year two delves deeper into learning disability-specific care. Students will learn about various types of learning disabilities, their impact on health and well-being, and effective communication strategies.  Advanced clinical skills in areas such as mental health, physical health, and end-of-life care are included. Placements provide an opportunity for students to practice newly acquired skills in real-world settings, under the guidance and supervision of professionals.
Year 3: The final year focuses on consolidating learning and preparing students for independent practice.  Modules will cover advanced topics such as leadership, management, research methodologies, and professional development. Students will undertake a significant placement in a learning disability setting where they lead and manage their own caseload, demonstrating advanced clinical skills while integrating theory with clinical practice.  Students are encouraged to reflect upon their learning throughout, building emotional resilience, leading to competent professional practice.

Applicants need to declare this on their application.  A GCSE grade 4/C or above in Maths and English is required.  Applicants must be a registered Nursing Associate with the NMC and hold an FdSc in Nursing or equivalent. Applicants must submit supplementary evidence using the Recognition of Prior Learning template, including qualifications, NMC registration, theory and practice hours, practice experience, and an academic reference. Applicants must be currently registered with NMC
