Overview: The Nursing Associate Apprenticeship bridges the gap between health and care assistants and registered nurses.  The program provides a comprehensive education and practical training, allowing students to learn while earning a salary.  It covers all four fields of nursing: adult, child, mental health, and learning disabilities, allowing students to identify their passions and specializations. The course combines on-the-job learning with one day a week at the university for lectures, tutorials, and workshops.  Placements in various health and social care settings (hospitals, care homes, etc.) are mandatory, totaling 460 hours.  Upon completion, and successful End Point Assessment, students can progress to a Registered Nurse Degree Apprenticeship or full-time nursing degree. The program is well-established, led by experienced health professionals.
Course Structure: The course consists of modules covering professionalism and the role of a Nursing Associate, person-centered care, health promotion, managing complex health conditions, using evidence in care, and transition to registered practice.  Assessment includes practical work evaluations, academic assignments (posters, essays, exams), and a final End-Point Assessment (EPA).  The program balances on-the-job training under the guidance of employers with structured academic learning at the university, including placement opportunities in various healthcare settings.  Throughout the program, students have regular meetings with academic and practice assessors who monitor their progress.
Year 1: Stage one modules cover Professionalism and the role of the Nursing Associate, providing and monitoring person-centered care, holistic health promotion, and initial practical assessments. Students will begin on-the-job training, learning practical skills in their workplace while also attending one day per week at the university, partaking in lectures and tutorials based on the modules covered, as well as gaining practical knowledge through workshops.  The balance between practical experience and formal instruction enables development of diverse skills and knowledge.
Year 2: In Year two, students will cover modules on managing the complexities of health conditions, utilizing evidence for quality care, transition into Registered Nursing Associate practice, and further practical assessments.  They will continue to build on the skills gained in their first year, increasing responsibility and autonomy within their chosen placements. The blend of on-the-job experience and further university-based learning continues, creating a strong foundation for future progression either within the Nursing Associate role or into Registered Nurse training.

Required IELTS Score: 6.5 (with at least 6.0 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2024 entry, typical requirements include 80 UCAS points, A-Levels (CDD), T-Levels (Pass with C or above in the core), BTECs (MMP), GCSEs in Maths and English (Grade 4/C or above), or a Pass Access to HE Diploma.  The Senior Healthcare Support Worker Apprenticeship is accepted in lieu of UCAS points or Level 3 qualifications. An interview is required, along with an Enhanced Disclosure & Barring Service certificate and an Occupational Health Assessment.  For Pakistani students,  entry depends on qualifications obtained within Pakistan.  If A-Levels or the International Baccalaureate are completed from Pakistani international schools, entry to the first year of the Bachelor's degree is possible.
Location/Campus: Kedleston Road, Derby Campus; St Helena, Chesterfield
Overview: The University of Derby's Foundation Degree in Nursing Associate (FdSc) is a two-year, full-time program designed to train students for a career as a Registered Nursing Associate.  The curriculum bridges the gap between healthcare assistants and registered nurses, providing a comprehensive understanding of nursing practices across various settings, including hospitals, care homes, and GP practices. Students gain practical experience through 50% placement time in diverse healthcare environments and develop clinical skills aligned with the Nursing and Midwifery Council Standards. The program emphasizes teamwork and collaboration, preparing graduates to work effectively within multi-professional healthcare teams.  Graduates are eligible to become Registered Nursing Associates and can progress to further nursing degrees.
Course Structure: The FdSc Nursing Associate program integrates theoretical learning with extensive hands-on experience.  The curriculum covers all four fields of nursing, enabling students to explore their interests and talents.  Theoretical modules at the university are balanced with significant clinical placements in diverse settings such as hospitals, GP surgeries, care homes, and community health teams.   Learning methods include lectures, scenario-based learning, tutorials, seminars, debates, and workshops. Assessments are varied, covering practical skills, presentations, essays, assignments, and case discussions. The program is designed to ensure graduates possess the necessary skills and knowledge to provide safe, effective, and patient-centered care.
Year 1: Year one of the Nursing Associate FdSc program focuses on building a strong foundation in fundamental nursing principles, concepts, and practices. Students undertake theoretical modules covering anatomy, physiology, pharmacology, fundamental nursing skills, communication, and patient care.  A significant portion of the year is dedicated to clinical placements, allowing students to apply theoretical knowledge practice in real-world healthcare settings. The first-year placements introduce students to a range of healthcare environments and expose them to the variety of tasks and responsibilities involved in nursing associate roles. Feedback and support are provided by both university tutors and placement supervisors.
Year 2: Year two of the FdSc Nursing Associate program builds upon the foundational knowledge and skills acquired in the first year. It focuses on advanced nursing skills, specialized care pathways in particular areas, leadership, and professional development. Students continue to have extensive practical placement experiences, allowing for deeper application of learned theoretical concepts. These placements may involve more complex patient care situations and greater responsibility.  The curriculum also includes modules covering ethics, law, and professional accountability in nursing practice, preparing students for the professional responsibilities of a registered nursing associate. Assessment methods are diversified, involving practical demonstrations, written assignments, case studies, and presentations.

Course Title: MSci Nursing Dual Award (Adult and Child)
Required IELTS Score: 6.5 (with at least 6.0 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical requirements include 128 UCAS points, A Levels ABB, T Level Merit, BTEC DDM, GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or above, or a Pass Access to HE Diploma.  Health or care experience is desirable.  An interview is required, along with an Enhanced Disclosure & Barring Service certificate and an Occupational Health Assessment.  Applicants whose first language is not English must demonstrate IELTS 6.5 overall with no less than 6.0 in any element. For Pakistani students, if studying A-levels or the IB from an International School in Pakistan, they can enter the first year. For postgraduate entry, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognised Pakistani university equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ is needed. A two or three-year Bachelor's degree requires a Master's pass. A four-year Bachelors with honours and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani university may qualify for a Master's degree.
Annual Tuition Fee: £16,900 per year for International students (2025/26) Full-time, N/A for Part-time
Overview: The MSci Nursing Dual Award (Adult and Child) is a four-year, full-time undergraduate program leading to a Master of Science degree and eligibility for dual registration with the Nursing and Midwifery Council (NMC).  It provides a comprehensive education in adult and child nursing, encompassing theoretical knowledge and extensive practical experience through placements. Students develop fundamental nursing skills, knowledge of diverse healthcare settings,  emotional resilience, and teamwork skills. The curriculum incorporates a blend of classroom learning, simulations, and online resources. The program is aligned with NMC standards, ensuring its relevance to current nursing practices. Graduates are prepared to work with patients across various healthcare environments and client groups, managing diverse and complex health conditions. The program emphasizes holistic learning, preparing students to become Registered Nurses.
Course Structure: The course integrates theoretical modules with substantial practical placements, comprising approximately 50% of the four-year program. The curriculum covers adult and child nursing theory and practice. Year one lays the groundwork in fundamental nursing skills and knowledge, building upon this foundation in subsequent years. As students progress, they specialize in their two chosen fields. The final year includes focused modules to solidify and expand skills in both adult and child nursing, alongside enhancing emotional resilience and leadership attributes. Assessment methods are diverse, encompassing authentic professional practices and feedback mechanisms for ongoing development.  Practical placement experience is an essential component, equipping students with real-world experience and guidance from Practice Assessors and Supervisors.
Year 1: Year one focuses on building a robust foundation in fundamental nursing principles, practices, anatomy and physiology, and basic clinical skills.  Students will begin to explore nursing perspectives relevant to both adult and child care settings, gaining an understanding of health and illness across the lifespan. Emphasis is given to develop safe, effective and person-centred nursing practices.  Modules likely include introductory nursing science, communication and care, foundational anatomy and physiology with application to nursing, and patient assessment and care.
Year 2: In the second year, students delve deeper into the theoretical and practical aspects of care relevant to both the adult and child populations.  They will further develop clinical skills, refine their decision-making and problem-solving abilities, hone their communication skills and their understanding of patient needs, and apply nursing theories in real-world situations.  Modules can include more specific aspects of assessment, medication management, management of acutely unwell patients both adult and child, and expanding their understanding of the social, cultural, and psychological contexts in which patients find themselves.
Year 3: The third year expands upon the foundations developed in prior years, often featuring more specialized modules related to adult and child care.  Students perform more complex clinical situations in simulated environments and increase patient contact hours in placement settings. This year provides a deeper dive into their dual award, allowing for further development of skills and knowledge specific to each area. Modules may include advanced clinical skills for adults, specific long-term condition management, pediatric advanced clinical skills, or child developmental differences with appropriate care strategies.
Year 4: The final year consolidates and builds upon the knowledge and skills gained throughout the program. Students undertake additional modules to solidify their competencies in both adult and child health. Critical thinking, leadership abilities, and research principles are emphasized.  The year culminates in preparation for registration and the start of a professional nursing career.  Modules might focus on leadership and management in nursing, research methods in nursing, preparing for NMC registration, and consolidating applied clinical skills across both specialisations.

Course Title: MSci Nursing Dual Award (Adult and Mental Health)
Required IELTS Score: 6.5 (with at least 6.0 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For entry in 2025, typical requirements include 128 UCAS points, A Levels ABB, T Level Merit, BTEC DDM, GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or above, or an Access to HE Diploma.  Health or care experience is desirable.  An interview is required, along with an Enhanced Disclosure & Barring Service certificate and an Occupational Health Assessment.  International students must meet English language requirements. Contextual offers may be available for students meeting specific criteria such as being care experienced, estranged from their families, refugees, asylum seekers, or having parents/carers in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistani students, A-levels or IB from Pakistani international schools allow direct entry.  A relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognised Pakistani university (equivalent to at least a UK 2:1 or 2:2) is needed for postgraduate entry; a Master's degree is also required for those with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees. A four-year Bachelor's degree with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 is considered for Master's entry.
Annual Tuition Fee: UK: £9,535 per year; International: £16,900 per year
Overview: This four-year, full-time MSci Nursing Dual Award (Adult and Mental Health) program prepares students for registration as a dual-award registered nurse with the Nursing and Midwifery Council (NMC).  The curriculum blends theoretical knowledge with extensive practical experience through placements in various healthcare settings. This holistic learning experience emphasizes emotional resilience and the development of transformational nursing skills.  The program's rigorous curriculum is aligned with NMC standards to ensure up-to-date and relevant learning.  Students gain clinical experience, working with diverse patient populations and developing adaptability. The program includes modules focusing on fundamental nursing, advanced practice (Adult and Mental Health), and career progression skills.  Teaching methods include classroom training, interactive skills laboratories and simulations, electronic learning using the VLE and technology-driven instruction. Assessments are multi-faceted and designed to foster  professional development and competency in line with NMC standards.
Course Structure: The course integrates theoretical learning with significant practical experience acquired through placements.  The program includes a variety of modules covering fundamental nursing skills and knowledge, Adult Nursing, Mental Health Nursing, and additional modules during the fourth year to consolidate and advance expertise in a second field.  Instructional methods involve lectures, tutorials, workshops, simulated practice activities, and  technology-enhanced learning via a dedicated Virtual Learning Environment (VLE). Students participate in simulated learning activities that bridge theory and practice, preparing them for the demands of the clinical environment.
Year 1: The first year lays the foundation for nursing practice.  Students will learn fundamental theoretical knowledge alongside the application of fundamental nursing skills in theoretical scenarios and simulated learning environments.  It will consist of foundational modules covering essential areas like anatomy, physiology, and basic nursing skills, introducing ethical considerations and the professional values associated with patient care, professional behaviours, communication, health assessments, safe care practices, and the fundamentals of person centred care.  This year also integrates early practical experience, allowing students to begin to establish and build important relationships within multiprofessional healthcare teams.
Year 2: The second year delves deeper into fundamental nursing practice and builds on the foundational skills and knowledge established during the first year.  Students will become proficient in the assessment and management of patient needs and issues. The focus continues on person-centred care and students will develop enhanced abilities to deliver safe and effective nursing care to patients with diverse and complex needs. Building on theoretical development and expanding the application of skills to real-world situations, modules in this year may include  advanced clinical skills, patient assessment, care planning, different treatments, management of patient-related problems, health promotion, and disease prevention, introduction to mental health, and relevant legislation.  Placement hours will increase during this year.
Year 3: The third year intensifies practical applications of theory and clinical skills, focusing on more specific areas of practice. The curriculum will increasingly align with specialisms of Adult Nursing and Mental Health Nursing.  Students will refine hands on clinical skills, managing patients with acute or long-term health conditions and those dealing with various aspects of mental health issues.  Modules might cover areas such as advanced nursing practice, leadership, care in specific settings, and management of chronic diseases.  Placement opportunities are further enhanced to give students opportunities to develop and expand upon their practice in these areas.
Year 4: The fourth year concentrates on consolidating and extending skills in a second field of practice, alongside additional modules to support a Masters Level award. This year builds on the knowledge from the previous years' modules, providing opportunities for specialisation. Students refine their skills in both Adult Nursing and Mental Health Nursing, achieving a broader and more comprehensive understanding.  Modules may include advanced care planning, leadership in acute and specialist settings, management of long-term conditions, evidence-based care, and research skills.  Significant placement hours are required within the second area of practice.

Course Title: MSci Nursing Dual Award (Learning Disabilities and Child)
Required IELTS Score: 6.5 (with at least 6.0 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical requirements include 128 UCAS points, A-Level ABB, T Level Merit, BTEC DDM, GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or above, or a Pass Access to HE Diploma.  Health or care experience is desirable. An interview is required, along with an Enhanced Disclosure & Barring Service check and Occupational Health Assessment.  Applicants whose first language isn't English need IELTS 6.5 overall with at least 6.0 in each skill. Contextual offers may be considered for students who are care experienced, estranged from their families, refugees/asylum seekers, or whose parents/carers are in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistani students, entry depends on their qualifications.  A-levels or IB from Pakistani international schools allow direct entry to Year 1. Postgraduate qualifications depend on  a relevant bachelor’s degree equivalent to at least a UK 2:1 or 2:2; students with two or three-year bachelor's degrees need a master's pass; a four-year bachelor’s with a minimum 2.4/4.0 GPA is considered for master's entry.
Overview: This four-year Master of Science (MSci) program offers dual registration as a registered nurse specializing in learning disabilities and child nursing.  It combines theoretical knowledge with extensive practical experience through placements in various healthcare and community settings.  The curriculum covers fundamental nursing skills, in-depth knowledge of the chosen fields, and the principles of nursing across the lifespan. Students learn via lectures, tutorials, workshops, simulated practice and online resources, and gain crucial experience in 24-hour care settings. The program is mapped against Nursing and Midwifery Council (NMC) standards and includes personal academic tutoring and a variety of assessments aimed at developing professional competence. Upon completion, graduates are eligible to apply for dual NMC registration.
Course Structure: The MSci Nursing Dual Award (Learning Disabilities and Child) is a four-year program structured to meet NMC standards for registered nurses. The first three years focus on building a solid foundation in basic nursing theory and practice.  Fourth year involves additional modules focusing specifically on the second field of practice, leading to dual registration.  Students participate in practice learning, amounting to 50% of the program, through diverse placements in hospitals, community services, and other healthcare environments. This includes at least 2300 hours of general practice learning and an additional 800 hours in the secondary field of practice.  In addition to in-person learning, the program incorporates online learning materials, such as Clinical Skills Net and Wiley PLUS, to enhance students' understanding of clinical skills and patient anatomy/physiology. The curriculum regularly updates to reflect the latest advancements in the field and government policies, ensuring graduates meet the highest industry standards. Assessments are diverse, authentic, and designed to support students' professional development, including the use of MYEPAD for recording practice learning.
Year 1: The first year establishes a foundation in fundamental nursing skills, principles, and knowledge. Students will study essential subjects such as anatomy and physiology, basic life support, introduction to mental health, ethical perspectives, communication and interpersonal effectiveness, the impact of biology on nursing, and introductory clinical practice. A combination of classroom learning and initial hospital or healthcare setting placements introduce students to the practical aspects of patient care.
Year 2: Building upon the foundational knowledge of year one, the second year delves more deeply into diverse clinical fields. There is likely to include further practice in the primary specialization (Learning Disability Nursing), along with subjects like advanced clinical skills, pharmacology, mental health nursing, and leadership and management within an acute care setting.  Students will continue to develop their practical skills in simulated and real-world environments, building confidence and expertise in direct patient care. Increased responsibilities and advanced assessment techniques are introduced to prepare students for future roles.
Year 3: The third year of the program integrates more advanced theoretical topics with increasingly complex clinical placements.  Specialized and advanced skills for both Learning Disabilities and Child Nursing will be the primary focus. Potential topics include pediatric nursing, specific clinical conditions within both learning disability and child populations, leadership, management and teamwork skills, and further professional development. Longer placements give students the opportunity to work autonomously and take on increased levels of responsibility, replicating the demands of working as a qualified nurse.
Year 4: The final year builds upon previous learning and includes specialization in the second area while integrating theoretical and practical learning acquired over the previous 3 years. Modules will consolidate and refine knowledge and expertise in both fields to prepare the students for dual registration and successful transition into professional practice. The year might include advanced research methods, integrating evidence-based practice into daily nursing, and preparation for postgraduate study or further specialized training.  The final placement consolidates the combined skills and knowledge of both disciplines. There would also likely be extensive preparation for registering with the NMC.

Overview: This 4-year full-time MSci program provides dual awards in Mental Health and Learning Disabilities nursing, preparing students for registration with the Nursing and Midwifery Council (NMC).  The curriculum emphasizes comprehensive theoretical knowledge and extensive practical experience, including approximately 2300 hours of practice learning and 800 hours specialized in the second field of practice. It combines classroom-based learning, simulated activities, and online resources to build skills and expertise across diverse settings. The program integrates the NMC's Future Nurse standards, ensuring graduates are equipped with current and relevant practice standards, emotionally resilience, and ready to work with individuals across different age groups and health conditions. The University offers robust support systems, including personal academic tutoring, to help students achieve their goals.  The rigorous assessment process includes diverse methods to support student development. Graduates gain eligibility for dual registration with the NMC, opening various career paths.
Course Structure: The course is structured to meet NMC standards and integrate theory with practice. It involves a blended approach combining classroom-based learning, intensive simulated learning experiences within specialized clinical skills suites and the use of technology-delivered instruction. The program is divided into modules that build upon one another across four years.  The final year includes additional modules focusing on the second field of practice, strengthening skills for career advancement.  The curriculum incorporates varied assessment methods such as traditional paper based assessments, hands-on skills labs and reflective portfolios. The program’s structure uses assessment for enhanced learning and improvement. Students receive timely feedback on their performance which helps students improve their performance. Practice assessments are recorded for all practical learning, students are consistently supported through reflective practice, feedback and development plans.
Year 1: The first year lays the foundation for nursing practice. It covers fundamental concepts and skills including anatomy & physiology, basic nursing skills, communication and interpersonal skills, and introduction to Mental Health and Learning Disabilities nursing. Students begin to develop their understanding of person-centred care and principles of safeguarding. There will also be an introduction to practice placements where students gain foundational experience in care settings.
Year 2: Year 2 builds on the first year introducing students to a range of health and social care settings. Students refine their foundational nursing skills through further practical learning, working in different healthcare environments. Students expand their knowledge base by tackling advanced concepts in physiology, pharmacology, and health assessment.  They continue to develop their clinical reasoning and decision-making skills, learning to work more independently, while maintaining the person-centred approach. Modules include further specialized learning within Mental Health and Learning Disabilities.
Year 3: The third year further enhances specialized knowledge and skill development in Mental Health and Learning Disabilities nursing through challenging module content.  Students develop advanced clinical skills, decision-making ability, and leadership qualities.  The clinical placement expands to include diverse settings such as hospital wards and community services. The year encourages and challenges students to improve their clinical assessments, and provide evidence-based practice. Students also learn about the complex factors impacting people receiving care.
Year 4: The final year focuses on consolidating and enhancing skills in the second field of practice.  Students will complete further advanced modules in this area, deepening their ability in their specialist field.  There is also an emphasis on leadership, management, and professional development. This year includes further specialized practice placements, and final assessments. Students will prepare for their role as a Registered Nurse post qualification.

A four-year bachelor's degree with honours and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 may also be acceptable.
Overview: The University of Derby's online BSc (Hons) Nursing Studies (Top-Up) is a part-time program designed for registered nurses with a Diploma or Advanced Diploma in Nursing who want to upgrade their qualifications to a Bachelor's degree.  The program is 100% online and flexible, allowing students to manage their studies alongside their work.  It offers a choice of optional modules in various nursing specialities, fostering clinical and professional skill development. The curriculum is internationally focused, research-informed, and designed to prepare nurses for the evolving healthcare landscape.  Emphasis is placed on person-centered care, evidence-based practice, and the development of critical thinking and clinical reasoning skills.  The program includes innovative assessments and robust student support, including online tutoring and access to university resources.
Course Structure: The course structure depends on the student's prior qualifications.  Students with a Diploma in Nursing Studies will need to choose four optional modules and an Independent Study module. Those with an Advanced Diploma will select one optional module and the Independent Study module. Module choices include clinically focused options like respiratory diseases, palliative care, diabetes, and infection control, and professional modules such as leadership, management, and research.  The curriculum is regularly updated to reflect current healthcare practice and policy. Assessment is 100% coursework based using methods like essays, reports, presentations, group work, and practical reports.  There is also a focus on interprofessional learning, allowing students to interact with peers from a variety of healthcare backgrounds.

The course is designed for sonographers, midwives, or obstetricians looking to enhance their skills in providing a comprehensive range of obstetric ultrasound services. The module emphasizes practical application, critical analysis of ultrasound findings, and effective communication within a multidisciplinary healthcare team.
Course Structure: The course is structured around developing advanced skills in obstetric ultrasound. A significant component of the course involves practical, supervised scanning experience in a clinical placement setting for a recommended minimum of 14 hours (two days) per week. This hands-on training allows students to enhance their proficiency in various obstetric ultrasound examinations.  The module also includes comprehensive study material and learning resources covering the theoretical knowledge alongside the practical application and interpretation.  Regular assessment is also assumed throughout the program. The program is accredited by CASE.

Overview: The University of Derby's MSc Occupational Therapy (Pre-registration) is a two-year, full-time program designed to equip students with the necessary skills and knowledge to become qualified occupational therapists.  The curriculum blends theoretical learning with extensive practice-based learning, including three placements in diverse settings. Students will develop a strong foundation in the science, philosophy, and theory of occupational therapy, learn assessment and intervention techniques, and explore contemporary practices. The course emphasizes professional reasoning, identity development, and collaboration within multi-professional teams.  Students gain hands-on experience in state-of-the-art facilities and benefit from a supportive learning environment with experienced, registered occupational therapists as educators. The program is accredited by the Royal College of Occupational Therapists and approved by the World Federation of Occupational Therapists and the Health and Care Professions Council (HCPC), ensuring graduates meet professional standards for registration.
Course Structure: The MSc Occupational Therapy (Pre-registration) program is structured across two stages with an emphasis on practice-based learning. Stage one covers fundamental sciences, philosophies, and theories of Occupational Therapy, applied through real-life situations and placements. Modules include: Evidence-Based Practice, Research, and Quality; Foundations for Professional Practice; Occupational Beings and Occupational Performance; Mandatory Training and Practical Skills for Practice; and Assessments and Interventions. This is complemented by practical sessions and inter-professional learning. Stage two focuses on contemporary occupational therapy practice. Modules include Placement 3, Public, Global and Community Health, Professional Reasoning and Professional Identity and Independent Scholarship, allowing students to explore areas of specific interest. The curriculum is regularly reviewed to align with employer needs and national changes in healthcare policy.  Assessment includes written assignments, reports, oral presentations, practice-based learning, and reflections.
Year 1: Year one of the MSc Occupational Therapy (Pre-registration) program establishes a strong foundation in occupational therapy principles.  Students delve into the underpinning sciences, philosophies, and theories, applying them to practical scenarios.  They learn about evidence-based practice, research methods, and quality improvement.  Key modules cover professional practice fundamentals, occupational performance analysis, essential practical skills, assessment techniques, and intervention strategies.  The year also includes the first two practice-based learning placements, providing valuable practical experience in real-world healthcare settings. Through these placements students integrate theoretical knowledge gained into professional practice. Inter-professional collaboration is incorporated into the learning experience.
Year 2: The second year deepens the exploration of contemporary occupational therapy practice. Students participate in a final 12-week practice placement, building on skills gained in earlier placements.  The curriculum introduces public, global, and community health perspectives on occupational therapy, expanding their understanding of patient care within broader societal contexts.  Students refine their professional reasoning and identity, focusing on ethical considerations and self-reflection.  An Independent Scholarship module allows for focused study in an area of personal interest, fostering in-depth knowledge and research skills. This year culminates in preparation for registration with the HCPC, ensuring graduates are fully equipped for a successful career.

Required IELTS Score: 6.5 (with at least 6.0 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 128 UCAS points, A Levels ABB, T Level Distinction, BTEC DDM, GCSE Maths and English Grade 4 or above, or an Access to HE Diploma with specific credit requirements.  For 2024 entry, UCAS points range from 112-128, with A Levels BBC-ABB, T Level Merit, BTEC DMM-DDM.  All applicants need a satisfactory reference, should demonstrate commitment and enthusiasm for occupational therapy, and be familiar with at least two areas of the field. An interview is required.  An Enhanced Disclosure & Barring Service certificate and Occupational Health Assessment are also necessary.  Students from Pakistan who have completed A-levels or the International Baccalaureate from International Schools in Pakistan can directly enter the first year.  Students with a four year Bachelor's degree with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 will be considered for entry.
Annual Tuition Fee: UK: £9,535 per year; International: £16,900 per year
Overview: The University of Derby's Occupational Therapy BSc (Hons) is a three-year, full-time undergraduate program designed to prepare students for a career as a registered occupational therapist.  The course is accredited by the Royal College of Occupational Therapists and approved by the World Federation of Occupational Therapists, ensuring graduates meet professional standards. The curriculum integrates theory and practice through experiential learning, including three periods of practice-based learning in real-world settings such as NHS facilities, social services, and private/voluntary sectors.  Students learn from experienced occupational therapists and gain hands-on skills in state-of-the-art facilities, including a rehabilitation kitchen and immersive simulation suite.  The program emphasizes developing practical, theoretical, and interpersonal abilities to help individuals overcome barriers to independence.  Graduates are eligible to apply for registration with the Health and Care Professions Council (HCPC).
Course Structure: The course blends theoretical learning with extensive practical experience.  Teaching methods include lectures, seminars, tutorials, workshops, group activities, and online learning.  A significant portion of the program involves placements allowing students to hone their skills in diverse settings and age groups. Three practice-based learning modules are integrated, usually undertaken full-time during separate weeks of each academic year. These placements are carefully arranged to provide exposure to various Occupational Therapy settings in the East Midlands region including NHS facilities, private and voluntary organizations.  Assessment includes assignments, case studies, written/practical exams, and presentations, with feedback on at least one assessment to enhance ongoing learning.  The program includes inter-professional learning opportunities to collaborate with students from other healthcare disciplines.
Year 1: The first-year curriculum introduces fundamental occupational therapy principles and theories, building a strong foundation in areas such as human anatomy, physiology and psychology.  Students also start developing practical skills through introductory workshops and laboratory-style sessions focusing on basic assessment and intervention techniques. There is an introduction to various areas of Occupational Therapy practice with sessions covering diverse applications like working with children or the elderly and understanding holistic patient care.  Early experience working in healthcare settings may already begin in this year.
Year 2: Building upon the foundational knowledge, the second year delves into more specialized aspects of occupational therapy, introducing specific conditions, patient populations, and treatment approaches.  Students participate in sessions and practical work focusing on assessment and treatment of conditions covering different parts of the body (e.g., hand therapy). Students will spend more time in healthcare settings developing clinical skills and starting to take on more independent responsibilities.  There may also be introductory sessions covering inter-professional work and multi-professional teamwork ethics.
Year 3: The final year focuses on advanced clinical skills and professional development for the transition to becoming a registered practitioner.  It includes the bulk of practice based learning, with students handling more complex caseloads and developing expertise in specific areas.  Modules cover leadership skills and preparation for the transition into professional life and employment, covering topics such as job searching and interviewing techniques. The final year also includes significant focused placement time and independent assessments.

Course Title: Undergraduate Occupational Therapy with Foundation Year BSc (Hons)
Required IELTS Score: 6.5 (with at least 6.0 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical requirements include 80 UCAS points.  A-levels (CDD), T Levels (Pass with C or above in the core), BTECs (MMP), or an Access to HE Diploma (60 credits; 45 at Level 3 with a minimum of Distinction: 0, Merit: 30, Pass: 15) are acceptable. GCSE Maths and English are preferred but not mandatory.  An interview is required.  An Enhanced Disclosure & Barring Service certificate and an Occupational Health Assessment and Clearance are also needed.  Contextual offers may be available for care-experienced students, those estranged from their families, refugees or asylum seekers, or students whose parents/carers are in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistani students, if completing A-levels or IB from international schools in Pakistan, direct entry into Year 1 is possible.  Information for postgraduate entry from Pakistan is not provided for this undergraduate program.
Overview: The University of Derby's Occupational Therapy with Foundation Year BSc (Hons) is a four-year undergraduate program designed to equip students with the knowledge and practical skills needed to become registered occupational therapists.  The program includes a foundation year for students who lack the necessary qualifications for direct entry into the honors degree. The curriculum blends theoretical learning with hands-on experience in state-of-the-art facilities, from a rehabilitation kitchen to a simulation suite.  Students will learn from registered occupational therapists and other professionals, benefiting from a robust, supportive learning environment.  Upon graduation, students are eligible to apply for registration with the Health and Care Professions Council (HCPC).  The course focuses on helping individuals overcome obstacles to independence, addressing a wide range of physical and mental health challenges.
Course Structure: The course combines theoretical knowledge with practical skills development. The curriculum will cover a range of topics including, but not limited to, anatomy and physiology, psychology, sociology, and medical conditions affecting functional ability. Students will receive substantial practical training through placements and simulated experiences in various settings, possibly including healthcare facilities such as hospitals, schools, care homes, and community settings. The course aims to develop students' professional competence, fostering their clinical reasoning, critical analysis and communication skills. It also emphasizes ethical practice and working within a multidisciplinary team, preparing students for the complexities of the profession.
Year 1: The Foundation year focuses on building the necessary academic skills and providing a foundational knowledge base for occupational therapy. This may include modules in areas like biology, psychology, sociology, communication skills, and introduction to health and social care system. Students will also develop fundamental academic study skills, which will support them to successfully proceed to the main degree programme.
Year 2: NA

Required IELTS Score: Overall: 7.0, no band below 6.5
Entry Requirement: 5 GCSEs (or equivalent) at grades A-C or 4-9, including Mathematics and English or equivalent level 2; 112 UCAS points or Level 3 qualification; Valid DBS check on starting the program; Evidence of recent study; Ability to meet the occupational health requirements of the program. For applicants for whom English is a second language, an overall IELTS score of at least 7.0 with no elements below 6.5 is required.  For Pakistani students: If studying and completing A-levels or the International Baccalaureate (IB) from Pakistani International Schools, entry to the first year of a Bachelor's degree is possible.  Specific entry requirements for Pakistani applicants to postgraduate programs involve a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised University in Pakistan, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree. Those with two or three-year Bachelor degrees also need a Master’s degree pass. A four-year Bachelor's degree with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University is considered for Master's entry.
Location/Campus: Online; University of Derby for annual residential week
Overview: The BSc (Hons) in Operating Department Practice is a three-year accelerated apprenticeship designed to equip students with the skills and knowledge to become competent Operating Department Practitioners (ODPs).  The program covers the perioperative journey, encompassing anesthesia, surgery, and recovery.  Students learn professional practice, values, standards, leadership, management, and communication skills.  The curriculum integrates online learning with annual residential weeks at the University of Derby, providing hands-on experience in a state-of-the-art clinical skills suite.  Upon completion, graduates are eligible for HCPC registration.
Course Structure: The three-year program is structured around online modules delivered through Collaborate sessions, webinars, and unit activities.  Assessment methods include coursework, competencies, presentations, online exams, and oral exams (VIVAS).  Students receive personalized academic tutoring and regular tripartite reviews with their tutors and workplace mentors. The curriculum is divided into three years, each comprising several modules focusing on various aspects of operating department practice, including practical skills in scrubbing and circulating, anaesthetic practice, post-anaesthetic care, leadership and management, complex perioperative care, and a work-based dissertation.
Year 1: Year one introduces fundamental concepts in operating department practice, including working and learning within the profession; principles of scrub and circulating practice; principles of anaesthetic practice; science and pharmacology for operating department practice; anatomy and physiology for operating department practice 1; and patient care concepts.  These modules build a foundational understanding of the ODP role and relevant scientific knowledge.
Year 2: Year two expands upon the foundational knowledge established in Year 1, building practical skills and theoretical understanding. Key modules include developing anaesthetic practice; evidence-based practice; anatomy and physiology for operating department practice 2; practice in post-anaesthetic care; developing scrub and circulating practice; and exploring leadership and management in operating department practice. These modules develop advanced clinical competency and management skills.
Year 3: The final year focuses on complex perioperative care, including management of medication and facilitation of learning and assessment.  Students work on a dissertation through work-based study, gaining valuable research and practical application experience.  The module on transition to practice beyond registration helps prepare students for successful integration into the ODP profession after graduation.

Course Title: Organisational Culture and Person-Centred Approaches to Care
Required IELTS Score: NA
Entry Requirement: This free online course has no formal entry requirements.  It is open to anyone regardless of age, location, or educational background.  However, access to the internet and a valid email address are necessary for registration and participation.  The course materials are designed to be accessible to a wide audience, including qualified health and social care professionals, carers, those in leadership roles, students, trainees, and volunteers.  Specific requirements under the Pakistan Entry requirements heading were not found. The course is particularly beneficial for those in health and social care who may be preparing for revalidation with the Nursing and Midwifery Council (NMC) or the Health and Care Professions Council (HCPC).
Overview: This free online course, "Organisational Culture and Person-Centred Approaches to Care," focuses on developing an organizational culture that supports excellent person-centered care. The course explores key areas such as communication, customer service, workplace culture, productivity, leadership styles, and change management. Participants will gain a comprehensive understanding of person-centered care (PCC) and how cultural changes and person-centered approaches positively impact PCC.  The course will equip learners with practical tools and models to use in quality improvement activities. The course is suitable for a range of professionals and students across the health and social care sector, particularly beneficial for those preparing for professional revalidation. The course was initially developed for a specific integrated care system and funded by Health Education England.
Course Structure: The course comprises eight units. Unit 1 introduces person-centered care (PCC). Unit 2 focuses on good communication in healthcare. Unit 3 explores creating a customer service culture centered on PCC. Unit 4 discusses a positive workplace culture and its connection to PCC. Unit 5 examines workforce productivity and its link to PCC. Unit 6 centers on leadership styles that support PCC. Unit 7 addresses change management within healthcare to support PCC. Unit 8 explores the Model for Improvement and the PDSA cycle and how this relates to PCC.  Each unit includes interactive elements and activities designed for self-guided online learning.
Year 1: NA
Year 2: NA

Course Title: Level 7 Organisation Wide Approaches to Quality
Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with a minimum of 5.5 in all areas
Entry Requirement: To undertake this module at Level 7, you must demonstrate the ability to study at academic level 7 (post-graduate level).  For postgraduate study,  students must have completed a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised University. This should be equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree. Students with a two or three-year Bachelor's degree must also have a pass in a Master’s degree. A Bachelor's degree with honours (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University is considered for entry to a Masters degree.  Pakistan Entry Requirements for Postgraduate: Students must have completed a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised University in Pakistan.
Overview: This postgraduate module, "Organisation Wide Approaches to Quality," focuses on clinical and corporate governance within healthcare and social care settings.  It emphasizes the connection between individual practice and broader organizational contexts. The course aims to equip participants with the knowledge and skills to contribute effectively to quality improvement initiatives, incorporating current policy and real-world situations in their analysis.  Students will analyze theoretical approaches to organizational quality, patient safety, and the quality assurance cycle.  The curriculum includes clinical and corporate governance, commissioning for quality, the impact of quality failures, critical incidents, root cause analysis, and case study analysis.  The module prepares healthcare professionals to proactively improve their work environments benefiting themselves, patients, and their organizations.
Course Structure: The course structure explores several key areas within organizational quality improvement.  It begins with an examination of clinical and corporate governance principles, emphasizing how these relate to day-to-day professional practices.  Participants will delve into the quality assurance cycle, learning how to identify opportunities for improvement and implement effective changes.  The module also covers patient safety, focusing on the identification and mitigation of risks.  A substantial component of the course involves analysis of case studies, allowing students to apply theoretical knowledge to realistic scenarios.  In addition to this, examination of national and local policies, which influence quality, and learning to carry out root cause analysis will also feature. The curriculum emphasizes critical analysis, allowing students to form their own informed opinions about current debates within the field.
Year 1: NA
Year 2: NA

Course Title: PG Cert Osteoporosis and Falls Management
Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with a minimum of 5.5 in all areas
Entry Requirement: Applicants for the Postgraduate Certificate in Osteoporosis & Falls Management are expected to hold a professional qualification (degree or equivalent) in healthcare.  Other qualifications or experience demonstrating appropriate knowledge and skills may be acceptable due to the course's multi-professional nature.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized university in Pakistan, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree, is required. Students with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees need a Master's degree pass.  A four-year Bachelor's degree with honors (minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00) from a recognized Pakistani university may also be considered for entry.
Location/Campus:
Distance learning
Kedleston Road, Derby Campus
Overview: The Postgraduate Certificate in Osteoporosis and Falls Management provides healthcare professionals with advanced knowledge and skills in managing osteoporosis and falls.  It focuses on improving patient care through enhanced diagnostic and management techniques. The program emphasizes critical evaluation of work-based environments and problem-solving skills. Students will develop a deeper understanding of the theoretical framework underpinning osteoporosis and falls management and its application to clinical practice. The curriculum is closely aligned with the health and social care sector, ensuring relevance and currency.  The course is designed to be flexible and allows students to study at their own pace, enabling them to enhance their clinical practice while balancing their professional commitments.  It’s possible to continue to an MSc upon completion.
Course Structure: The program consists of three modules: two core modules – 'Theoretical Considerations in the Diagnosis and Management of Osteoporosis' and 'Assessment, Prevention and Management of Falls' – and one optional module chosen from a list, including  'Clinical Considerations in the Diagnosis and Management of Osteoporosis and Falls', 'Health Promotion: Improving Bone Health', or 'Developing as an Evidence Based Practitioner'. The optional module can even be selected from the MSc Leadership in Health and Social Care program, broadening the student's knowledge base.  Assessment methods include written assignments, case histories, log books, or poster presentations. The curriculum is regularly reviewed and updated to reflect changes in national policy and best practice, ensuring relevance to current practice.

Required IELTS Score: NA
Entry Requirement: For the Paediatric Imaging study evening, applicants should be a plain film radiographer with an interest in pediatrics or a diagnostic radiography student.  The provided text does not specify entry requirements beyond this for the short course.  There is further information provided for Undergraduate, Postgraduate and PhD programs at the university but this short course does not appear to require the same entry standards.  For undergraduate programs at the University of Derby, those completing A-levels or the International Baccalaureate from international schools in Pakistan may enter directly into the first year. Postgraduate programs require a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognised Pakistani university, equivalent to a UK Upper Second Class (2:1) or Lower Second Class (2:2) degree. A Master's degree is also needed for those with two- or three-year Bachelor degrees.  A four-year Bachelor's degree with honours (minimum GPA 2.4/4.00) qualifies students for a Master's program.  PhD applicants need a Master's and Bachelor's degree in a related field, along with a research proposal.
Overview: This short course, titled "Paediatric Imaging study evening," focuses on enhancing the skills of radiographers who work with children. The course provides training in the interpretation of pediatric skeletal images using plain film radiography.  Participants will improve their ability to identify abnormalities in pediatric skeletal systems and learn effective distraction and immobilization techniques for young patients.  It also emphasizes the proper communication of crucial information to other health professionals involved in patient care, promoting professional autonomy among participants. This short course offers a condensed program designed to specifically address knowledge gaps and improve practical skills in pediatric imaging.
Course Structure:
The course is a single evening session and the curriculum is not structured year by year or in modules.  The focus of the study evening are:

*Developing image interpretation skills of the paediatric skeleton
*Learning to identify abnormalities in paediatric skeletal images
*Practicing distraction and immobilisation techniques
*Mastering methods of conveying important information to inform the patient pathway
*Developing professional autonomy among attendees

Course Title: BSc (Hons) Performance Analysis and Coaching Science
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 112 UCAS points.  A-Level students need BBC grades (including at least a C in a science subject like Biology, Chemistry, Physics, Physical Education, or Psychology).  T Levels in Science are also accepted, as are BTEC DMM grades. GCSE Maths and English at grade 4/C or above are necessary. An Access to HE Diploma with 60 credits (45 at Level 3, with a minimum of 15 Distinction, 24 Merit, and 6 Pass credits) is an alternative.  International students need an IELTS score of 6.0 with at least 5.5 in each skill.  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or the IB from international schools in Pakistan, direct entry to Year 1 is possible.  Postgraduate entry from Pakistani Universities requires a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK Upper or Lower Second Class Honours degree.
Overview: The BSc (Hons) Performance Analysis and Coaching Science degree at the University of Derby provides a comprehensive education in the theoretical and practical aspects of performance analysis and coaching in elite sports.  Students gain hands-on experience using cutting-edge technology, including Hudl Sportscode, WyScout, iCoda, Hudl Replay, VICON 3D, and Quintic, within a state-of-the-art performance analysis suite.  The curriculum integrates practical application with theoretical understanding, covering areas such as biomechanics, sports psychology, and physical performance.  Students benefit from unique placement opportunities with professional sports clubs, enhancing their employability and real-world skills.  The program is designed in collaboration with industry partners, ensuring its relevance and preparing graduates for successful careers in sports.
Course Structure: The course combines theoretical learning with practical application, utilizing state-of-the-art facilities and industry-standard software. Students gain skills in video analysis, data analysis, visualization, and the application of performance analysis and coaching methods in various sports.  The curriculum explores areas like biomechanics, sports psychology, physical performance, and injury prevention, providing a holistic understanding for a successful career. The hands-on training incorporates work placements within professional and non-professional sports clubs, allowing students to connect theory to practice.  Assessment involves coursework, practical exercises, exams, and presentations, preparing students for real-world performance analysis scenarios, and many opportunities to network and learn from leading professionals in the industry.
Year 1: The first year introduces foundational knowledge in performance analysis principles, sports science fundamentals (biomechanics, physiology, psychology), and basic coaching techniques. Students gain familiarity with industry-standard software like Hudl Sportscode and learn data collection and basic analysis methods.  Introduction to relevant research methodologies alongside the development of critical thinking skills. The year will likely include introductory modules on sports science concepts and introduction to performance analysis technologies.
Year 2: Year 2 builds on the foundation, delving into advanced performance analysis techniques, specializing in different sports contexts and employing more sophisticated data analysis techniques.  Students complete modules examining team tactics, individual athlete profiling, and coaching strategies across different sports.  Students may conduct practical projects, applying their knowledge to analyze real-world sporting events. The year will likely include modules on advanced analysis techniques, and the use of various software and technologies.
Year 3: The final year focuses on independent projects, specialist modules, advanced data analysis, and a significant placement or internship in the sports industry. This real-world experience allows students to apply their skills and knowledge within a professional setting.  The curriculum may include a research dissertation or capstone project, requiring students to conduct original research or solve a significant performance analysis problem. The placement will allow the student to work in a real professional environment, and gain valuable experience.

Course Title: Undergraduate Performance Analysis and Coaching Science with Foundation Year BSc (Hons)
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 72 UCAS points, A Levels (DDD), a T Level pass, BTEC (MMP), or a pass in an Access to HE Diploma. GCSE Maths and English are preferred but not mandatory; if lacking, Level 2 Maths and English can be undertaken during the course. International students need an IELTS score of 6.0 with at least 5.5 in each skill.  For Pakistani students, A-levels or IB from Pakistani international schools allow direct entry into Year 1.  Postgraduate entry from Pakistan requires a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2, potentially including a Master's degree if the Bachelor's is shorter than four years. A four-year Bachelor's with a minimum 2.4/4.0 GPA is also acceptable. PhD applicants need a Master's and Bachelor's degree in relevant subjects, along with a research proposal.
Overview: The University of Derby offers a four-year BSc (Hons) in Performance Analysis and Coaching Science, including a foundation year. This course blends theory and practical application, using cutting-edge technology and software like Hudl Sportscode, Dartfish, and Quintic. Students will develop skills in performance analysis, coaching science, and related areas like biomechanics and sports psychology. The program emphasizes real-world experience through work placements and internships with professional sports clubs, such as Derby County FC and Leicester Tigers.  Graduates will be well-prepared for careers in elite sport, performance analysis, talent identification, and sports coaching both domestically and internationally.
Course Structure: The course integrates theoretical learning with practical application.  Students engage in modules covering the theory and science behind performance analysis and coaching, exploring the interdisciplinary nature of the field. Modules cover aspects of various sport sciences such as biomechanics, psychology, and physical performance. The program also includes practical sessions utilizing state-of-the-art facilities, including a performance analysis suite equipped with advanced software. Work placements and internships offer real-world experience, enabling students to apply their theoretical understanding in practical settings. Assessments are diverse, including coursework, practicals, exams, and presentations; this ensures that the assessment methods prepare students for the work undertaken in professional sport.
Year 1: The foundation year provides a comprehensive introduction to sports science concepts.  Students build foundational knowledge in areas relevant to performance analysis and coaching science, including sports biomechanics, sports psychology and physical performance. The year is designed to prepare students for the rigors of the BSc (Hons) program and is structured to enhance students' skills, knowledge, and confidence for the coming years.
Year 2: NA

Required IELTS Score: 7.0 (or equivalent) in all areas
Entry Requirement: For Operating Department Practitioners (ODPs), entry requires a Diploma of Higher Education, City and Guilds 752, NVQ level 3, or Cert HE in Operating Department Practice or equivalent; at least one year of experience in a perioperative setting (evidenced by an employer reference); current and unrestricted registration with the Health and Care Professionals Council or an international equivalent; and an IELTS score of 7.0 if English is not the first language.  For Registered Nurses (RNs), a Diploma of Higher Education or Advanced Diploma of Higher Education in Nursing is needed, along with at least one year of perioperative experience, current and unrestricted registration with the Nursing and Midwifery Council or international equivalent; and an IELTS score of 7.0 if English is not the first language.  International students' qualifications must typically be mapped to the UK equivalent. Non-standard entrants might need to provide additional evidence or participate in an interview, and those whose English isn't their first language may need to submit evidence of equivalent English Language qualifications.  For those from Pakistan, if A-Levels or the IB are completed in Pakistan, the student would start from the first year of a Bachelor's degree.  Those pursuing postgraduate study must have completed a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognised Pakistani university, equivalent to at least a UK 'Upper Second Class (2:1)' or 'Lower Second Class (2:2)' degree. Students with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees must also have a pass in a Master's degree. A Bachelor's degree with honors (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani University may qualify for a Masters degree.
Overview: The University of Derby's online BSc (Hons) Perioperative Practice (Top-Up) degree is designed for healthcare professionals already working in perioperative settings, such as ODPs and RNs. This program focuses on specializing practice, leadership, education, and research. Students will gain a deep understanding of advanced perioperative theories and skills, developing critical thinking and the ability to transfer skills across various healthcare settings. The curriculum emphasizes leadership and evidence-based practice, preparing graduates to inspire and lead within their field. The course includes a virtual conference module that encourages interprofessional teamwork competencies. This focused program allows qualified professionals with a diploma to earn a bachelor's degree in 12 months, enhancing their confidence and employability for senior perioperative roles.
Course Structure: The course requires completing 120 credits across six 20-credit modules, plus a 0-credit virtual conference module ('Developing Competence and Capability'). The modules cover critical competence in clinical practice, care management, clinical practice leadership, and clinical practice development.  Students will develop subject-specific and transferable skills relevant to critical evaluation, independent study, professional development, and work-focused study, making recommendations to enhance service delivery and perioperative care provision.  Specific module details are subject to change. The course involves a range of assessment methods centered around coursework, including essays, reports, presentations, group work, and practical reports.
Year 1: The first year's structure depends on the student's chosen pace (standard or accelerated). Students will cover core modules focusing on clinical practice, care management, leadership, and development within the perioperative setting. The accelerated option involves completing two modules per trimester, requiring approximately 40 hours of weekly study. The standard pace allocates 20 hours of study per week for one module per trimester.  Each trimester consists of 10 weeks. Students will participate in virtual classrooms and have access to recordings.  Assessment will include coursework submissions, allowing for flexibility to manage professional commitments.
Year 2: NA

Overview: The Level 6 Personal and Professional Development course is designed for health and social care professionals and those working with families.  It focuses on personal and professional growth through formative and summative assessment methods. Students will create a position statement to define their learning goals, which will be discussed in group and individual tutorials. The course combines higher education teaching with practical experience from senior family therapists in children's and adult mental health, grounding learning in current evidenced-based models and research.  It aims to foster self-reflection and the application of systemic perspectives to personal and professional experiences. The course is suitable for  practitioners who want to enhance their skills and knowledge and develop their self- awareness.
Course Structure: The course structure revolves around self-reflection and the application of learned concepts in a professional practice setting.  Students will first produce a position statement that examines their personal approach to learning, followed by exploration of self-reflexivity in relation to professional, personal, family, and cultural contexts, using a systemic lens.  Throughout the course, students will receive formative and summative feedback, ensuring their growth and development.  The course team consists of experienced higher education educators and practicing senior family therapists, allowing for both practical and theoretical understanding. The course is practice-based, necessitating that participants have access to real-world applications for the ideas learned.
Year 1: The first year of this one-year course will focus on the theoretical underpinnings of self-reflection and its implications for professional practice.  Students will explore systemic perspectives for understanding experiences and reflecting upon these from a multi-faceted perspective.  A significant amount of time will be spent on creating and refining the position statement, followed by active engagement in small group and individual tutorials around this statement. The work is practice-based and requires ongoing integration of theory and practice.

Overview: The BA (Hons) Commercial Photography degree at the University of Derby offers a progressive and ethically responsible approach to commercial photography.  Students learn technical skills, develop professional portfolios, and gain experience working on commercial projects from the start.  The curriculum balances practical workshops with lectures, seminars, tutorials, and national/international visits.  Students receive mentorship on various aspects of professional practice, including client management and marketing.  The program leverages the legacy of Derby School of Photography and connects to industry professionals and the FORMAT International Photography Festival.
Course Structure: The course is delivered through a combination of practice-led workshops, lectures, seminars, tutorials, and national and international study visits. Students benefit from the support of both actively working and researching photographic lecturers and industry professionals. The program emphasizes developing autonomous practice, including building a professional identity and marketing strategies, which is incorporated into the portfolio development throughout the studies. The emphasis is on setting new standards of visual language that advocates for contemporary and future-visioning clients.
Year 1: Year 1 modules explore analogue and digital photography, alongside histories and theories of the medium. Students build foundational skills across both photographic mediums including film-based process, digital image capture and editing and digital workflows. These modules include underpinning theoretical knowledge that develops creative understanding.
Year 2: Year 2 focuses on developing a broader range of photographic skills, including expanded studio practice and innovation in image-making.  Modules like "Keeping Good Company" suggest projects involving collaborations or engagements with clients or groups. "Portfolio for the Future" begins to shape student work and professional ambitions.
Year 3: Year 3 builds on previous years, focusing on final portfolio development, persuasive photographic techniques and the presentation of final work to a professional or public audience. Students further specialise in their chosen area of photographic practice and fully commit  to completing a professional portfolio to industry standards.

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 72 UCAS points, A Levels (DDD), BTEC (MMP), or equivalent. GCSE Maths and English are preferred but not mandatory.  International students need an IELTS score of 6.0 with at least 5.5 in each skill. For Pakistani students completing A-levels or IB from International Schools in Pakistan, direct entry into the first year is possible.  Those with a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized Pakistani university (equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2) can apply. A Master's degree is also required for students with two  or three-year Bachelor's degrees. Students with a four-year Bachelor's degree with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university will be considered for entry.
Overview: The BA (Hons) Photography (Commercial) with Foundation Year is a four-year program offered by the University of Derby, building upon the legacy of the Derby School of Photography.  The course uniquely blends technical skills development with an ethically responsible approach to commercial photography. Students gain practical experience through commercial projects, developing their skills in areas such as client communication, pitch presentations, production management, and building a professional identity.  The program leverages strong industry links, including the FORMAT International Photography Festival and the Association of Photographers (AOP), allowing graduates to enter the field with a strong portfolio and well-honed skills.
Course Structure: The program is structured across four years.  The first year is a foundation year designed to build a strong base of skills and confidence before progressing onto the core degree. The subsequent years combine workshops, lectures, seminars, tutorials, and national and international visits, all under the guidance of working photographers and researchers.  The modules are subject to regular review and change to ensure relevance and student success. Students' professional development is enhanced through a LinkedIn Learning subscription.  Assessment is 100% coursework based, demanding high-quality photographic work supported by artist's statements.
Year 1: The foundation year focuses on developing core skills in creative practice, studies, digital skills, and technologies through a combination of practical workshops, lectures, and tutorials.  A negotiated project allows students to develop their individual interests and skills. This year prepares students for the more specialized modules in the following years.
Year 2: Year 2 introduces core photography concepts with modules such as Exploring Analogue and Digital Photography, Histories, and Theories of Photography, accompanied by practical workshops and studio-based work that will allow the students to build a strong portfolio.
Year 3: Year 3 delves into more advanced concepts in photography and commercial practice, focusing on developing a professional portfolio showcasing advanced photography skills, and exploring different commercial practices and photographic roles within the market.  Modules in this year will include building up the students' professional identity and enhancing their self-marketing skills.
Year 4: The final year concentrates on building a robust professional portfolio and refining persuasive image creation techniques,  through a variety of module work. Students engage in advanced projects, gaining valuable experience in the commercial photography industry.The degree show is an integral part of the final year, exhibiting students' work to the wider public and industry professionals.

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical requirements include 104 UCAS points, A Levels (BCC), T Level (Merit), BTEC (DMM), or an Access to HE Diploma.  GCSEs in Maths and English at grade 4/C or above are also needed.  A portfolio is recommended.
