For postgraduate study, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognised Pakistani university (equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2) is required; a Master's degree may also be necessary depending on the undergraduate degree.
Overview: The University of Derby offers a three-year BA (Hons) Photography program designed to cultivate highly creative and technically skilled professional photographers.  The curriculum emphasizes imaginative approaches, challenging conventions, and developing a unique identity. Students will learn a wide range of techniques, from traditional analogue methods to cutting-edge digital technologies, including CGI and 3D.  The program involves practical workshops, lectures, seminars, critiques, and individual and group tutorials, providing a balanced approach to learning. Students benefit from access to state-of-the-art facilities, industry partnerships, guest lectures, and opportunities to participate in competitions and festivals like the FORMAT International Photography Festival. The course culminates in a professional final exhibition, showcasing students' work to industry professionals and the public. The program also helps develop essential skills such as research, critical thinking, communication, and presentation.
Course Structure: The course blends creative, experimental and theoretical approaches with technical skills development.  Students explore a broad range of photographic media, including traditional analogue, digital, time-based media, moving image, installation, sculptural and performance art techniques, and the hybridisation and combination of media to create new forms of image making.  The curriculum incorporates technical workshops covering black and white, colour, digital photography, CGI, and 3D techniques.  Lectures, seminars, critiques, individual tutorials, group research activities, and presentations enhance learning and skill development.  Industry collaborations, guest lectures, gallery visits, and participation in competitions and festivals contribute to practical experience and networking opportunities. Assessments are 100% coursework, where photographic work is supported by artist statements, and students will develop skills in professional image presentation, research methods and dissemination and critical analysis of image and photography. The course is designed to equip students with the skills needed to carve out a successful career in the creative industries.  A final professional exhibition is showcased at the university's Degree Show.
Year 1: The first year provides a foundational understanding of photographic principles and techniques, covering both analogue and digital processes. Students will explore fundamental concepts of photography through practical exercises and theoretical studies. Basic darkroom skills are introduced with digital photography, and students practice core image making techniques. Introductory research and presentation skills form part of the year. Students acquire basic skills across all technical applications of photography and begin to work towards developing professional identities and practices.
Year 2: In the second year, students build upon their foundational skills, exploring more advanced theoretical approaches to photography. They undertake more complex projects, focusing on the development of a conceptual approach. They are expected to develop critical thinking skills and the ability to work independently or in collaborative productions. A wider range of media is explored. Students develop independent research skills, critically engaging with specific areas of photographic practice and history, building further skills in presentations and portfolio development.
Year 3: The final year focuses on the development of a substantial final project, requiring students to apply their accumulated knowledge, critical thinking ability, and research skills. Students focus on developing a body of professional output and gaining experience in disseminating and exhibiting their work. As such they are further supported in applying for exhibitions, writing press releases and in organising their own studio space.  Students will also develop networking skills, building up industry contacts in preparation for their careers after graduation.

Students will be introduced to the history of photography, various photographic styles and genres, and fundamental image-making principles. Course Title: BA (Hons) Physical Education, Physical Activity and Sport

Overview: This BA (Hons) in Physical Education, Physical Activity and Sport is designed for aspiring PE teachers and sports coaches.  The program develops theoretical knowledge and practical skills in designing, delivering, and reviewing physical education content for diverse settings and populations. Students gain practical experience through school placements, field trips (including potential international opportunities), and utilize the university's sports center facilities.  The curriculum emphasizes inclusion, understanding of special educational needs and disabilities (SEND), and the use of outdoor environments as educational tools which is supported by strong industry links and expert teaching staff. The course also includes embedded professional qualifications and encourages further studies like PGCE programs.
Course Structure: The course covers various aspects of physical education, physical activity, and sport (PEPAS). Students learn about curriculum design, delivery, and assessment; develop practical teaching skills in various settings, from schools and colleges to community organizations; and gain experience in working with diverse populations, including those with additional needs.  Assessment methods are varied, including practical assessments, presentations, essays, and a dissertation. Additional qualifications, such as coaching badges and the Association for Physical Education Level 3 diploma, are incorporated. Significant components include work placements, field trips, and networking opportunities that contribute to building a strong portfolio of skills and experiences.
Year 1: The first year likely lays the groundwork for the program by establishing a solid foundation in the theoretical underpinnings of physical education, exercise science, and sport pedagogy.  Students will likely engage in introductory modules covering the history and philosophy of physical education, motor skill development, and the basics of lesson planning and teaching methodologies.  The year might include a variety of assessment methods, including both written assignments and practical teaching sessions.  Early focus on developing their understanding of practical coaching techniques  and the educational principles underpinning the field is likely.
Year 2: The second year will likely build upon the first year's foundation while deepening the student's knowledge and skills.  It may include more specialized modules focused on teaching methodologies for various age groups and populations, coaching specific sports or activities, and addressing diversity and inclusion in physical education.  A focus on educational assessment techniques and evaluation methodologies may be part of the year's curriculum. Students might undertake further practical placements and continue to refine their abilities through increased direct teaching experience and feedback.
Year 3: The final year entails increased specialization through advanced modules, potentially including action research projects, dissertation work, and in-depth applied modules offering practical skill enhancement.  Modules may offer options catering to specialized interests, such as outdoor education, adapted physical activity, or specific coaching specialisations. The final year would also emphasize career preparation and professional development including internship and work placements in relevant sectors or settings.

Course Title: Certificate of Credit in Physical Ergonomics
Required IELTS Score: 6.5 (minimum of 6.5 in each module)
Entry Requirement: Applicants need a UK undergraduate degree or equivalent international qualification, or a relevant professional qualification.  Relevant key practical experience and work-based training will also be considered.  For non-native English speakers, IELTS 6.5 (minimum 6.5 in each module), TOEFL 550 (paper-based), 213 (computer-based), or 80 (internet-based), Cambridge Advanced Certificate, London Tests of English level 5, International GCE O Level English Language Grade C, International GCSE English/English as a Second Language Grade C, or ASE Proficiency are acceptable.  Pakistan entry requirements are not specifically detailed for this Certificate of Credit but generally for postgraduate studies at the University of Derby include a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognised Pakistani university equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree. A Master's degree may be required if the Bachelor's degree is only two or three years. A Bachelor's degree with honours (four-year) and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani university is also acceptable.
Overview: The Physical Ergonomics Certificate of Credit is a 10-week online course focusing on the physical aspects of ergonomics and human factors.  It provides a comprehensive understanding of human anatomy, physiology, biomechanics, and anthropometry as they relate to workplace design and safety. The course examines various physical environmental factors (noise, vibration, lighting, and thermal conditions) and their impact on worker health,  comfort, and performance.  Students will investigate work-related musculoskeletal disorders, workplace layout, safety, and health issues, including emerging concerns like an aging population, obesity, and sedentary lifestyles and critically analyze the evidence-based interventions in physical ergonomics examining the strengths and weaknesses of this approach. The program culminates in coursework assessments, including essays, research reports, presentations, group work, and practical reports. It is CIEHF accredited, offering 20 credits at Level 7.
Course Structure: The course is delivered entirely online over ten weeks and includes interactive learning materials and live classroom sessions.  Students engage with tutors and peers through virtual classrooms and online discussion forums. The curriculum explores physical ergonomics principles, applying theory to practical workplace scenarios. Core subjects include biomechanics, anthropometry, workplace design considerations regarding health safety concerning physical environment factors such as noise, vibration, lighting, and temperature.  Students also learn to apply evidence-based approaches to real-world problems while working alongside students in the online Ergonomics and Human Factors MSc program for a broader perspective.  Assessment is 100% coursework-based, encompassing a range of methods designed to build practical skills and critical analysis abilities.
Year 1: NA
Year 2: NA

Entry Requirement: For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 128 UCAS points.  A-Level applicants need ABB, with at least 40 points from Biology, Human Biology, Physics, Chemistry, Physical Education, or a Social Science.  T Level applicants require a Merit, while BTEC applicants need DDM in a relevant subject. GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or equivalent are also needed. An Access to HE Diploma with specific credit requirements is acceptable.  A satisfactory reference is required, demonstrating suitability for the profession. Applicants should have skills and experience showing commitment and enthusiasm; familiarity with at least two areas of physiotherapy (through reading, research, experience, or shadowing) is also necessary. Offers are subject to occupational health clearance.  International applicants must meet the HCPC's IELTS 7.0 requirement. For Pakistani students completing A-levels or the IB from International Schools in Pakistan, direct entry into the first year is possible.
Overview: The University of Derby's Physiotherapy BSc (Hons) is a three-year, HCPC and CSP-approved program designed to equip students with the knowledge and skills for a physiotherapy career. The curriculum blends theory and extensive practical experience, including five periods of full-time practice-based learning in diverse settings (NHS, private, voluntary sectors).  Students learn in a stimulating environment, collaborating with professionals from allied health, nursing, and social care. The program emphasizes a holistic approach to patient well-being, incorporating concepts of efficacy and modern physiotherapy practices.  The university boasts state-of-the-art facilities, including a simulated hospital ward and rehabilitation kitchen, complemented by technology-enhanced learning experiences.
Course Structure: The course integrates theoretical learning with extensive practical training.  Modules cover a wide range of subjects central to physiotherapy, such as human anatomy, physiology, pathology, and biomechanics.  Assessment methods vary, encompassing assignments, case studies, examinations (written and practical), presentations, and practice-based assessments. Interprofessional learning opportunities are integrated to ensure graduates are ready to work effectively within multidisciplinary healthcare teams.Throughout the course, students receive personalized support from a dedicated Personal Academic Tutor (PAT) and a team of registered and experienced physiotherapists who provide insights and guidance. The structured curriculum ensures students are well-prepared for professional registration and practice, and are equipped with the knowledge, skills, and confidence to navigate the latest healthcare practices and trends.
Year 1: Year 1 likely introduces foundational knowledge in anatomy, physiology, and the principles of physiotherapy. Students begin to develop fundamental assessment and treatment skills.  Early modules might focus on building a strong understanding of human movement, common health conditions, and basic therapeutic interventions. Basic patient interaction, communication, and professional conduct may be part of the curriculum, alongside an introduction to the clinical setting via observation or shadowing.
Year 2: Year 2 incorporates more advanced physiotherapy techniques, focusing on specific patient populations and conditions.  Students expand their assessment and treatment skills and are introduced to more complex rehabilitation programs.  Additional topics could include neurology, musculoskeletal conditions, cardiorespiratory systems, and specific approaches to pediatric or geriatric physiotherapy. This builds a further enhanced understanding and practical application of previously covered knowledge, paving a stronger foundation towards clinical practice.
Year 3: Year 3 culminates in extensive clinical placements and advanced studies in specialized physiotherapy areas, such as sports injuries, neurological rehabilitation, or geriatrics. Students consolidate their clinical skills and build professional experience. Advanced assessment, treatment planning, and patient management are a key focus, as they will apply their practical learnings in diverse contexts, enhancing critical thinking and problem-solving skills.  Ethical considerations and professional responsibility reinforce effective healthcare and collaborative practices.

Course Title: Bachelor of Science (BSc) in Professional Policing Practice
Required IELTS Score: NA
Entry Requirement: Applicants must be at least 18 years old and employed by a police force.  They must meet standard PC eligibility criteria.  A Level 3 qualification (or equivalent such as A-level or work experience) is typically required.  Level 2 qualifications in English and Mathematics are also necessary; support is offered if these are lacking.  The Police actively encourage applications from under-represented communities. For Pakistani students, if studying A-levels or the International Baccalaureate from an International School in Pakistan, entry to the first year of a Bachelor's degree is possible.
Overview: This three-year Police Constable Degree Apprenticeship combines on-the-job training (80%) with academic study (20%).  The program equips students with the skills and knowledge necessary for modern policing, covering areas such as evidence-based policing, supporting vulnerable individuals, and combating cybercrime.  The apprenticeship is delivered in partnership with Nottinghamshire Police and Derbyshire Constabulary, providing practical experience and preparing graduates for a career in law enforcement.  The curriculum focuses on developing expertise in effective policing strategies within a modern context. Students will learn and apply modern investigation techniques, building their confidence in upholding the law and protecting the community. The program is designed to lead to a BSc in Professional Policing Practice.
Course Structure: The apprenticeship is structured to blend on-the-job learning with academic study. 80% of the time is spent in practical policing roles within a designated force, gaining first hand experience in real-world scenarios. This on-the-job training is supported by uploading evidence to an e-portfolio. The other 20% entails academic study towards a Bachelor's Degree in Professional Policing Practice, delivered through a combination of online and face-to-face teaching, accommodating work schedules.  The second year involves rotations through key police departments, allowing students to explore areas of specialization. This allows graduates to gain a comprehensive understanding of police work and the skills needed in various contexts.  The third year offers the opportunity to apply for specialisms based on earlier experiences and interests. This allows specialization of skills and knowledge developed earlier in the training.  The assessment incorporates both practical application and academic coursework.
Year 1: Year one likely introduces foundational concepts in policing, including law, ethics, and investigation techniques.  Students will gain experience in basic policing duties under supervision, building a foundation of practical skills and knowledge. The first year focuses on building the basic knowledge of policing and procedures. Students begin with the fundamentals of the legal framework related to policing and the ethical considerations that guide law enforcement in practice. This foundational understanding is crucial in shaping their attitude and approach to legal work. Simultaneously they start to use and apply their theoretical knowledge to various practical policing duties under appropriate instruction and supervision.
Year 2: The second year involves rotations in various police departments, such as uniformed patrol, crime investigation, and community engagement. This allows for a diversified practical learning experience, exposing students to different aspects of policing.  Students will apply the fundamental knowledge gained earlier to broader practical scenarios and contexts within different departments. They will use the opportunities arising from the varied placement schemes to broaden their experience and exposure.
Year 3: The third year allows for specialization in a chosen policing area based on interests and experience built during years one and two. This specialization may involve dedicated training or advanced coursework in the chosen domain, allowing a focused development of skills and mastery of techniques. It also provides a greater opportunity to expand their professional network.

Course Title: MSc Police Leadership, Strategy and Organisation
Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with 5.5 in each skills area
Entry Requirement: Normally, a 2:2 or above undergraduate degree is required.  Significant work or voluntary experience in the justice sector, or professional qualification at a graduate level or above, is also accepted.  For international students whose first language is not English, an IELTS score of 6.5 with a minimum of 5.5 in each skill area is necessary.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognized university, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree is required.  Those with two or three-year Bachelor degrees must also have a Master's degree. A four-year Bachelor’s degree with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university is also acceptable.
Location/Campus: One Friar Gate Square, Derby Campus
Overview: The MSc in Police Leadership, Strategy and Organisation is a postgraduate program designed to develop the leadership skills of current and future police leaders. It combines business and management principles with criminology and social sciences to address contemporary policing challenges.  The curriculum emphasizes police accountability, independence, effectiveness, performance, and organizational transformation.  The program boasts a strong network of influential figures in policing, offering guest lectures and events. It also provides an international perspective, bridging UK policing with global practices.  The program aims to equip students with the knowledge and skills to lead effectively in a complex and scrutinized environment, ultimately shaping a better society.
Course Structure: The course consists of three stages: Postgraduate Certificate, Postgraduate Diploma, and MSc.  The Postgraduate Certificate includes core modules on Policing and Accountability, Police Leadership and Organisational Transformation, and Applied Research in Criminal Justice Systems. The Postgraduate Diploma builds upon this foundation with core modules on Partnerships and Policing, and What Works in Policing, along with a choice of several optional modules such as Digital Intelligence, various Criminal Investigation modules, Financial Investigation, Digital Investigation, Understanding Radicalisation, Personal Career Guidance and Coaching, and Concepts of Global Terrorism. The final MSc stage involves Independent Studies in Policing, a research-based dissertation project.  A practical placement may be an option, subject to availability and security clearance.
Year 1: Year 1 (Full-time) covers the Postgraduate Certificate modules: Policing and Accountability, focusing on the political, legal, and operational challenges faced by police; Police Leadership and Organisational Transformation, addressing organizational change and strategic leadership in policing; and Applied Research in Criminal Justice Systems, equipping students with research methodologies.
Year 2: Year 2 (Part-time or Full-time) involves the Postgraduate Diploma modules. This stage delves into Partnerships and Policing, emphasizing multi-agency collaboration and communication; and What Works in Policing, which analyses effective policing strategies  Students also select one of several optional modules based on their interests and career goals, offering a focus on areas such as digital intelligence, criminal investigation, financial investigation, or radicalization.

Overview: The BA (Hons) Policing and Investigations degree provides a comprehensive understanding of the investigative process, contemporary policing, criminology, and forensics. The program focuses on the theory, policy, and practice of policing and investigations, enabling critical evaluation of contemporary challenges. The University actively encourages students to volunteer with the police as Police Support Volunteers or join the Special Constabulary.

The program integrates theory, policy, and practice across policing and investigations, criminology, forensics, and criminal justice. Learning is enhanced through fieldwork, such as visits to police facilities and related organizations (such as victim support). Emphasis is placed on hands-on learning and developing skills relevant to graduate employment. Course Title: BA (Hons) Popular Music Production and Business Management
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For entry in 2025, typical requirements include 112 UCAS points, A Levels BBC, BTEC DMM, GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or equivalent, or an Access to HE Diploma.  International students will need an IELTS score of 6.0 with at least 5.5 in each skill area.  For students from Pakistan completing A-levels or the IB from international schools in Pakistan, entry into the first year is possible. Students with a relevant bachelor's degree from a recognized Pakistani university (equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2) are eligible for postgraduate study; a master's degree may be required if the bachelor's degree is two or three years. A four-year bachelor's degree with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 is considered.
Location/Campus: Kedleston Road and Markeaton Street, Derby Campus
Overview: The BA (Hons) Popular Music Production and Business Management is a joint honors degree offering a blend of creative and business skills. Students develop expertise in music production using state-of-the-art recording studios and learn practical business management skills, tackling real-world scenarios through projects and placements. The program emphasizes the development of both creative and professional skills, preparing graduates for diverse roles in the music industry and broader business world. Students benefit from industry partnerships, guest speakers, and opportunities to participate in the annual Music Production Show. The course is accredited by JAMES and CMI, ensuring industry-standard quality.
Course Structure: The course combines modules in popular music production and business management.  The first year focuses on equal study in both subjects. Students then choose their preferred pathway:  equal focus, Popular Music as major with Business Management as minor, or vice versa. Modules in music production cover recording techniques, studio technology, performance, and industry practices. Business modules cover responsible management, business ethics, analytics, digital media, innovation, and globalization. The course uses a mix of lectures, seminars, tutorials, projects, and self-directed study, assessing students through coursework, portfolios, presentations, and practical assignments.
Year 1: The first year provides a balanced introduction to both Popular Music Production and Business Management. Students will gain foundational skills in music technology, recording techniques, and performance.  Alongside this, they'll begin exploring key concepts in business such as financial accounting, organizational management, and marketing. The year is designed to establish a strong base and allow students to determine their preferred focus of study going forward. Practical assessments will include recordings, projects, and presentations.
Year 2: In the second year, students can choose to specialize or maintain an even split between Popular Music Production and Business Management.  Those focusing on music production might delve into advanced recording techniques, music business strategies, audio engineering, and potentially choose additional specializations such as sound design or digital audio workstation proficiency. In the business stream, students can deepen their understanding of topics such as finance, strategic management, project planning and human resources, with the opportunity to specialize in a particular area of interest. Collaborative projects and practical work will dominate the learning experience.
Year 3: The final year builds on the knowledge and skills acquired in the previous two years. Students undertaking the major in popular music might focus on independent project work, potentially involving the creation of a portfolio, developing a business plan for a music venture, or producing a full-length album. The business management specialism may involve a significant work placement, completing consultancy projects, creating substantial business reports, culminating in a detailed dissertation or final project demonstrating specialized skills and knowledge. Final year projects generally focus on culminating skills and knowledge into a single, comprehensive demonstration.

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical requirements include 96 UCAS points, A Levels (CCC), T Levels (Pass with C and above), BTECs (MMM), or an Access to HE Diploma.  GCSEs in Maths and English at Grade 4/C or above are also needed.  A portfolio is recommended. International students will have different entry requirements.  Contextual offers may be available for students from particular backgrounds, such as care leavers, estranged students, refugees, asylum seekers, or those with parents in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistani students, entry requirements depend on their existing qualifications. A-levels or IB from Pakistani international schools enable direct entry to year 1.  Postgraduate entry requires a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2. A Master's degree might be required for those with shorter Bachelor's degrees. A four-year Bachelor's degree with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani university is considered for Master's entry.  PhD applicants need a Master's and Bachelor's degree in a relevant subject, plus a research proposal.
Overview: The University of Derby's BA (Hons) Popular Music course is a three-year (full-time) or five-year (part-time) program designed for aspiring musicians seeking to understand the commercial music industry. Students will develop expertise in performance, composition, music technology, media production, and musicology, gaining a comprehensive understanding of the economic and professional aspects of popular music. This course emphasizes the development of creative and entrepreneurial skills, enabling students to navigate the dynamic landscape of the music industry. It includes hands-on experience in state-of-the-art recording studios, collaborations with industry professionals, and public performance opportunities. The curriculum is regularly reviewed to ensure alignment with industry standards and enhance graduate prospects.
Course Structure: The curriculum blends practical and theoretical learning, encompassing performance, composition, production, and the technological aspects of music. Students will build skills on their chosen instruments, refine song-writing techniques, and study the social and business contexts of commercial music.  The program incorporates work with music software, digital audio workstations, and recording studio technologies, all within top-tier facilities including sound technology labs, surround-sound testing rooms, and electronic labs. Students benefit from industry connections, including participation in the annual Music Production Show featuring guest speakers from established companies like Sound on Sound, Avid, Yamaha, Ableton, and Focusrite.  The course culminates in two major music projects in the final year, focused on professional practice in performance and composition to enhance employment prospects. Assessments include coursework, portfolios, assignments, presentations, and potentially examinations.
Year 1: The first year lays the foundation for understanding the core elements of popular music, beginning with foundational instrumental and vocal training, alongside basic music theory and composition principles. Early modules would introduce essential music production techniques using DAWs (Digital Audio Workstations) and explore the fundamentals of music technology and recording. Students also start to comprehend the social and cultural contexts of popular music history, relevant to their chosen specialism. This year helps to foster confidence in performing and working both individually and collaboratively.  Alongside learning core musical skills, students will begin to engage with studio technology and equipment.
Year 2: In the second year, students will delve deeper into the specialized areas of popular music composition, arranging and production. Modules enhance both technical and creative skills. Topics such as audio engineering, mixing, and mastering are explored in greater detail to build practical abilities and a strong understanding of production processes. Students begin to solidify their personal creative style through more advanced performance techniques, and will deepen their critical analysis of popular music.  Building upon the foundational year, year 2 sees development of musicianship, combined with increasing technical proficiency and an exploration of the business and marketing of music.
Year 3: The final year focuses on refining professional practices and preparing graduates for industry roles.  Students undertake significant independent projects showcasing artistic capabilities and technical expertise.  This may include producing their own EP or album, demonstrating a mastery of diverse musical forms, and understanding  commercial opportunities within the creative economy. Alongside this the final year includes modules such as advanced business techniques, legal awareness in the creative world, further strengthening graduate employability.   The final year will include an emphasis on professional development, including networking opportunities and building a professional portfolio.

Course Title: Undergraduate Popular Music with Foundation Year BA (Hons)
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical UCAS points are 72; A-Level requirements are DDD; T Level requires a pass; BTEC needs MMP; GCSE in Maths and English are preferred; Access to HE Diploma requires a pass with 60 credits, 45 at Level 3 (minimum Distinction: 0, Merit: 30, Pass: 15). A portfolio is recommended.  International students may need to meet different English Language requirements. For Pakistan, students completing A-levels or IB from Pakistani International Schools can enter Year 1. Postgraduate entry from a Pakistani university requires a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK Upper Second Class (2:1) or Lower Second Class (2:2) degree. A Master's degree is needed if the Bachelor's degree is two or three years; if it is four years with honors and a minimum 2.4/4.00 GPA from a recognized university, it may suffice.
Overview: The Popular Music with Foundation Year BA (Hons) program at the University of Derby is a four-year undergraduate course designed for aspiring musicians.  It focuses on equipping students with the technical and creative skills needed to thrive in the commercial music industry.  The curriculum blends practical experience with theoretical understanding, covering areas like performance, composition, music technology, media production, and musicology. Students have access to state-of-the-art recording studios and rehearsal facilities, with opportunities for public performances and collaboration with industry professionals. The course also explores the business and social context of commercial music, preparing graduates for diverse roles in the industry. The programme is accredited by JAMES, assuring it meets high industry standards.
Course Structure: The course combines practical and theoretical modules. Students will develop skills in popular music performance, composition, and production utilizing music technology and software such as Adobe Creative Suite. This includes learning about the technology of the recording studio, video production, and music software application on DAWs.  The curriculum encompasses  musicology, exploring the social and business spheres of the commercial music industry.  Students will also build entrepreneurial skills and will benefit from industry links, including opportunities to perform and network at industry events such as the annual Music Production Show.  Assessment methods are varied and include coursework, portfolios, assignments, case studies, and projects.
Year 1: The first year of the Popular Music with Foundation Year BA (Hons) program provides a foundational understanding of music theory, aural skills, and instrumental techniques. Students will be introduced to basic music production principles, working with music software and equipment. There will be focus on developing performance skills, both individually and collaboratively. The foundational year is likely to provide a supportive introduction to music technology and equip students for the more advanced modules to follow.
Year 2: In the second year, students continue to hone their musical skills, likely delving deeper into composition, arranging, and production techniques.  More advanced music technology is included, alongside exploration of different genres of popular music. Further development of performance skills takes place, possibly including workshops and collaborative projects. The programme continues to build on the foundations of year one, offering a more specialized knowledge and development of musical and technical competencies.
Year 3: The third year progresses to an intermediate stage, students explore music industry practices further, studying music business, marketing, and entrepreneurship. More specialized modules may be introduced, allowing students to focus their skills and interests within popular music. This could involve advanced music production techniques, concentration on specific instruments or genres, and development of advanced performance skills and presentation.
Year 4: The final year focuses on developing professional practice in both performance and composition, working towards a major project in music creation and production. Students will consolidate their knowledge and skills learned through the previous years and are likely involved in individual and group-based productions alongside professional projects. Industry networking and career management skills will also be emphasized, preparing students for professional employment upon graduation.

Course Title: PGCE Post-14 Further Education and Skills
Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with a minimum of 5.5 in all areas
Entry Requirement: Applicants need a minimum 2:2 honors degree in a subject relevant to the Further Education and Skills sector (e.g., psychology, law, media, sports, music technology).  Pending GCSEs are considered, and equivalency tests are accepted for English and Mathematics. Level 2 equivalency qualifications in English and Maths are also accepted if recognised by the Society for Education and Training's QTLS eligibility.  A DBS certificate is required upon accepting a place.  Those who have lived outside the UK in the past five years (excluding holidays) need a Certificate of Good Conduct from their country of residence. Two references from academic or professional sources are needed. All qualifications must be certified, and photographic ID is required. A personal statement explaining the reasons for applying is mandatory. An Occupational Health Assessment and Clearance by the University is also required. A Prohibition List Check will be conducted after accepting an offer. For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized university is required, equivalent to at least a UK 2:1 or 2:2.  Those with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees must also have a Master's degree. A four-year Bachelor's degree with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university is also considered.
Location/Campus: Buxton & Leek College (Leek Campus); Kedleston Road, Derby Campus
Overview: The PGCE Post-14 Further Education and Skills course prepares individuals for teaching roles in the Further Education and Skills sector.  It focuses on developing practical teaching skills and confidence to work with post-14 learners in diverse educational settings.  The program blends theoretical learning with extensive hands-on teaching experiences, including placements in various educational environments. Upon completion, graduates are eligible for Qualified Teacher Learning and Skills (QTLS) status and can fast-track to a master's degree, having already earned 60 credits towards it. The course is highly practical and includes mentorship from university teaching staff and subject-specific mentors during placements. Students gain expertise in curriculum development, learning theories, and various teaching methodologies.  The University is Ofsted rated 'Outstanding' for its Further Education and Skills provision.
Course Structure: The course includes core modules like Exploring the FE Teaching Role, Professional Practice 1 & 2, Learning Theories Applied, and The Curriculum Examined. Students can also choose specialist pathways focusing on subjects such as English, Maths, Science, Engineering, Sport, or SEND.  These pathways offer enhanced pedagogy within the chosen subject area. The program utilizes various teaching methods, including practical teaching, presentations, workshops, and blended learning. Assessments involve observation of practice, presentations, and academic writing.  Full-time students are based at the university for two days a week and on placement for two days, plus an eight-week block placement. Part-time students attend college one day a week and must have a relevant work placement.
Year 1: Full-time students cover core modules focusing on exploring the FE teaching role, professional practice, learning theories, the curriculum, and subject pedagogy (either core or specialist pathway).  They divide their time between university-based learning and two days a week on teaching placements, which includes an eight-week block placement.  They receive mentorship and support throughout the placement. Assessments involve observations, presentations, and academic writing demonstrating levels 6 and 7 academic skills. Part-time students will cover the same modules over two years, with one day of college study a week combined with a relevant work placement.
Year 2: NA

Course Title: Practice Certificate in Non-Medical Prescribing for Nurses and Midwives (V300)
Required IELTS Score: NA
Entry Requirement: For the undergraduate level (Level 6), nurses or midwives need a professional qualification.  For the postgraduate level (Level 7), a first degree is usually required.  Those without a first degree can study at Level 7 if they've completed at least one Level 7 module in the past 5 years.  The Nursing and Midwifery Council (NMC) requires applicants to be registered nurses, midwives, or SCPHNs for at least one year before applying.  Applicants must demonstrate competence in clinical/health assessment, diagnostics/care management, and planning and evaluation of care.  Employers must confirm the applicant's diagnostic skills in their specialty.  A pre-admission portfolio is available for additional evidence.  For applicants from Pakistan, undergraduate entry requires A-levels or the International Baccalaureate from an International School in Pakistan to start in the first year. Postgraduate entry requires a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2, or a Master's degree if the Bachelor's degree is only two or three years long. A four-year Bachelor's degree with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university is accepted. PhD applicants need both a Master's and Bachelor's degree in a relevant subject area and a research proposal.
Overview: This course equips nurses and midwives with the skills and knowledge to become independent prescribers, meeting NMC standards.  It covers pharmacology, clinical assessment, consultation, investigation, communication, professional ethics, legal and governance principles related to prescribing.  The program emphasizes safe, cost-effective prescribing and shared decision-making. Students gain practical experience and complete assessments including an OSCE, calculations test, pharmacology exam, evidence-based poster, and an essay. The course aims to develop autonomous clinical decision-making skills within the scope of professional competence.
Course Structure: The course consists of one core 40-credit module spread over two semesters.  The curriculum includes pharmacology, its application to practice, clinical assessment skills, consultation techniques, investigation methods, communication strategies, ethical considerations of prescribing, legal and governance frameworks, and practical clinical experience. Students learn to apply evidence-based practice within their prescribing roles.  Assessment methods are diverse:  a practical OSCE assessing prescribing skills, a written examination on pharmacology and its application, a coursework component including an evidence-based poster and an essay, and documentation of 12 days or 90 hours of clinical practice. Successful completion awards practitioners a Practice Certificate (Level 6) or Postgraduate Practice Certificate (Level 7).
Year 1: NA
Year 2: NA

Course Title: Practice Certificate in Non-Medical Prescribing for Paramedics
Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with a minimum of 5.5 in all areas
Entry Requirement: To be eligible for the Practice Certificate in Non-Medical Prescribing for Paramedics, applicants must meet several criteria.  They need to be registered with the HCPC (Health and Care Professions Council) as a paramedic in good standing, working at an advanced practice level with at least three years of relevant post-qualification experience.  Applicants must demonstrate support from their employer and show that they operate in an environment with a need for independent/supplementary prescribing.  The employer must confirm appropriate supervised practice, and suitable medicines and clinical governance arrangements must be in place.  Applicants must demonstrate their ability to reflect on performance and take responsibility for their Continuing Professional Development (CPD).  A Disclosure and Barring Service (DBS) DBS36 check within the last three years is also required.  An approved practice educator or medical practitioner must agree to supervise and assess the student during their clinical placement.  For Pakistani students, the requirements from Pakistan Entry Requirements for Postgraduate stated on the university website apply. This includes holding a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised University in Pakistan equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree, or a four-year Bachelor's degree with honours and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University.
Location/Campus: St Helena, Chesterfield; Kedleston Road, Derby Campus
Overview: The University of Derby offers a Practice Certificate in Non-Medical Prescribing for Paramedics. This postgraduate certificate program equips paramedics with the skills and knowledge to become independent prescribers, meeting HCPC standards.  The course is designed for registered paramedics with substantial post-registration experience who wish to enhance their advanced practice skills.  The curriculum focuses on pharmacology, clinical assessment, consultation, and ethical and legal aspects of prescribing.  Students develop practical prescribing skills through assessments such as OSCEs and case studies, working towards autonomous decision-making while maintaining awareness of professional limitations.  They will participate in supervised clinical practice, consolidating their learning in real-world settings.  The program emphasizes evidence-based practice and the development of strong communication and teamwork skills, vital for non-medical prescribing roles within the healthcare system.
Course Structure: The program consists of one core 40-credit module, delivered over two semesters and 6 months.  Assessment includes a practical OSCE (Objective Structured Clinical Examination) for prescribing, a pharmacology exam (requiring 80% pass mark), and a calculations test (100% pass mark).  Students also need to submit an evidence-based poster on specific drugs and a relevant essay evaluating clinical circumstances. Finally, they must complete 12 days/ 90 hours of supervised clinical practice, earning professional sign-off.  The course faculty includes senior lecturers, program leaders, and experienced pharmacist lecturers and independent prescribers.  The program aims to develop advanced clinical decision-making skills, building expertise in pharmacology and its application to patient care within the legal and ethical frameworks required for practicing paramedics.
Year 1: NA
Year 2: NA

Course Title: Postgraduate Practice Certificate in Independent Prescribing for Pharmacists
Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with a minimum of 5.5 in all areas
Entry Requirement: To be eligible for this course, applicants must be registered pharmacists with the General Pharmaceutical Council (GPhC) or the Pharmaceutical Society of Northern Ireland (PSNI), in good standing with their respective regulatory bodies.  A minimum of two years of post-registration, patient-oriented experience in a relevant UK practice setting is required, along with an identified area of clinical or therapeutic practice to serve as the basis for independent prescribing practice during training.  A designated prescribing practitioner (DPP) is needed for supervision throughout the course. This DPP can be a medically active practitioner or a non-medical prescriber with independent prescribing rights who meets the DPP Competency Framework (RPS, 2019).  If the DPP is a non-medical prescriber, assessment by a GMC-registered medical practitioner is also required.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised university in Pakistan, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree, is necessary.  A Master's degree may be needed if the Bachelor's degree was two or three years long.  A four-year Bachelor's degree with honours, a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University will also be considered.
Overview: The Postgraduate Practice Certificate in Independent Prescribing for Pharmacists is a 6-month program designed to equip pharmacists with skills and knowledge to become independent prescribers.  Meeting General Pharmaceutical Council (GPhC) standards, this course demands at least two years of post-registration, patient-focused experience in a UK setting with a defined clinical or therapeutic area of practice. The curriculum encompasses pharmacology, clinical assessment, consultation, ethical and legal aspects of prescribing, and professional development. Assessment includes practical examinations, coursework, reflective practice, and clinical practice sign-off.  The course aims to enhance healthcare effectiveness and efficiency by developing qualified Non-Medical Prescribers (NMPs) with the autonomy to make sound clinical decisions for patients.  Successful completion leads to a postgraduate certificate and enables practice as an independent prescriber.
Course Structure: The course involves a core 40-credit module spread over two semesters.  It covers a range of essential topics including, independent prescribing theory, pharmacology's role in informed decision-making and safe practices, clinical assessment and consultation skills, diagnostic reasoning, patient communication, development of shared treatment plans, ethical and legal aspects of prescribing, and professional governance.  Practical training and assessment include clinical skills examinations, clinical decision-making exercises, case-based discussions, evidence-based poster presentations, critical reflection on prescribing practice, and sign-off to ensure competence is met in practice.  An optional module on Diagnostic Reasoning in Clinical Practice can also be completed to enhance prescribing practice.
Year 1: NA
Year 2: NA

Course Title: Practice Certificate in Non-Medical Prescribing for Physiotherapists
Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with a minimum of 5.5 in all areas
Entry Requirement: Applicants must be registered with the HCPC in a relevant allied health profession and professionally practicing where independent/supplementary prescribing is needed.  They must demonstrate employer support, including supervised practice, and existing medicines/clinical governance arrangements. At least 3 years of relevant post-qualification experience at an advanced practitioner level is required.  Applicants need to show a reflective practice and commitment to CPD, and provide a DBS check within the last 3 years. An approved practice educator or medical practitioner is also necessary, with the employer confirming their training and experience in supervising, supporting, and assessing trainees.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognized Pakistani University (equivalent to a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree) is required.  Those with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees need a Master's degree pass. A four-year Bachelor's degree with honours and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized university may also qualify.
Overview: This postgraduate practice certificate equips physiotherapists with the skills and knowledge to become independent prescribers, meeting Health and Care Professions Council (HCPC) standards. The course focuses on developing safe, appropriate, and cost-effective prescribing practices.  It emphasizes clinical assessment, consultation, investigation, and communication skills crucial for diagnosis, shared decision-making, and treatment planning.  Students will explore professional, ethical, legal, and governance principles related to prescribing, team working, and continuing professional development. The program involves both practical assessments, including an OSCE, and theoretical examinations, covering pharmacology and calculations. Students also complete coursework such as evidence-based posters and essays, along with practical sign-off to verify clinical practice. The curriculum is designed to foster autonomous clinical decision-making while acknowledging limitations within professional scope.
Course Structure: The course consists of a single core 40-credit module delivered over two semesters. The curriculum covers pharmacology, clinical assessment skills, communication techniques, legal and ethical considerations of prescribing, and clinical governance.  Practical components include supervised clinical placements where students hone their prescribing skills under the guidance of experienced practitioners.   Assessment methods are diverse and include an objective structured clinical examination (OSCE), a pharmacology examination, a calculations test, an evidence-based poster presentation, and an essay.  Successful completion requires a 100% pass on the calculations test and an 80% pass on the pharmacology examination.  Finally, a significant amount of supervised practical experience in a clinical setting is necessary to demonstrate competency before qualification is granted.

Course Title: Practice Certificate in Non-Medical Prescribing for Podiatrists
Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with a minimum of 5.5 in all areas
Entry Requirement: To be eligible for the Practice Certificate in Non-Medical Prescribing for Podiatrists, applicants must meet several criteria: registration with the HCPC in a relevant allied health profession; current practice in an environment needing regular independent/supplementary prescribing; employer/sponsor support with supervised practice in the prescribing area; established medicines and clinical governance arrangements supporting safe prescribing; at least 3 years of relevant post-qualification experience in the prescribing area; working at an advanced practitioner level; demonstration of self-reflection on performance and commitment to CPD, including support networks; a recent Disclosure and Barring Service (DBS) check; and an approved practice educator or medical practitioner with relevant experience, training in supervision and assessment of trainees, and commitment to provide student support in developing prescribing competencies.  Specifically for Pakistan, students must have completed a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised University in Pakistan, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree. Those with two or three-year Bachelor degrees need a Master's degree pass. A four-year Bachelor's degree with honours and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University is also acceptable.
Overview: The Practice Certificate in Non-Medical Prescribing for Podiatrists is a postgraduate course designed to equip podiatrists with the skills and knowledge to independently prescribe medication.  The course covers pharmacology, clinical assessment, consultation, communication, ethical and legal considerations in prescribing, and clinical governance.  Students learn to make informed prescribing choices, considering cost-effectiveness and patient safety. The program includes practical assessments, such as an OSCE for prescribing, a pharmacology examination, and a coursework component, including an evidence-based poster and an essay. Successful completion of the course will allow podiatrists to register as Non-Medical Prescribers (NMPs). The program emphasizes both theoretical knowledge and practical application through a supervised clinical placement.
Course Structure: The course structure consists of one core module covering pharmacology, clinical assessment, consultation skills, communication strategies, and legal and ethical implications related to prescribing.  This involves practical training where students will gain experience in making clinical decisions, utilizing their newly acquired knowledge related to pharmacology, and understanding practical applications within the podiatry profession. This training also incorporates an emphasis on clinical governance, ensuring they can navigate ethical and professional contexts while implementing safe prescribing practices. This allows the students to hone their skills and knowledge through practical experiences in a guided and safe environment, culminating in them becoming competent and confident independent prescribers.

Entry Requirement: For this free online preparatory course, there are no formal entry requirements.  Access to the internet and a valid email address are needed for registration.  The course is open to anyone regardless of age, location, or educational background.  The provided text focuses on preparation for undergraduate study, particularly within health or social care, suggesting that successful completion could improve readiness for application to such programs.  Regarding Pakistan-specific entry requirements, the university's website mentions prerequisites for undergraduate, postgraduate, and PhD programs.  Undergraduate applicants from Pakistani international schools completing A-levels or the IB may enter directly into the first year. Postgraduate applicants need a relevant bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2, with a master's degree required if the bachelor's is only two or three years.  PhD applicants need a master's and bachelor's degree in a relevant subject, along with a research proposal.

Overview: This free online course, "Preparing for Undergraduate Study," is designed to equip prospective students with essential academic skills needed for undergraduate programs, particularly in health or social care.  The course's interactive units focus on developing independent study skills, effective resource utilization and referencing, critical thinking and presentation abilities, workplace success, and communication and teamwork.  The objective is to bridge the gap between prior education and higher education, boosting confidence and self-awareness in approaching university-level studies. This course is ideal for those considering, waiting to begin, or already undertaking undergraduate study in health or social care. Completion earns digital Open Badges for each unit and a final e-certificate.
Course Structure: The course comprises five units, each requiring roughly two hours of self-guided online study.  Unit 1 focuses on independent work and organization skills crucial for university success. Unit 2 covers locating, using, and referencing evidence, essential for academic research and practice. Unit 3 develops critical thinking and presentation abilities. Unit 4 concentrates on thriving in workplace and practice placements. Finally, Unit 5 emphasizes communication, teamwork, and long-term career planning.  Each unit includes interactive elements and culminates in a digital Open Badge upon completion. Upon completion of all five units, a final e-certificate is awarded.

Required IELTS Score: NA
Entry Requirement: There are no formal entry requirements for this course.  It is open to anyone regardless of age, location, or education status.  The course is free and available to anybody who wants to understand pressure ulcers, why they occur, and how to prevent them. This includes healthcare professionals, caregivers of at-risk individuals, and those with a general interest in pressure care.  Specific requirements for Pakistani students are not mentioned as it's a free online short course and not a formally accredited university program for a degree.
Overview: This free online course from the University of Derby provides comprehensive knowledge about pressure ulcers.  It covers the causes, management, and prevention of these sores, focusing on identifying at-risk individuals, early warning signs of skin breakdown, and the significance of healthy lifestyles (physical and psychological) in prevention. The course emphasizes actions to avoid pressure ulcers and strategies for managing existing ones to prevent further skin deterioration.  It also highlights the importance of multi-agency cooperation and professional support in comprehensive pressure ulcer care. The course is suitable for healthcare professionals, caregivers, and anyone interested in pressure ulcer prevention, offering a flexible, self-paced learning experience.
Course Structure: The course is divided into four units, each taking approximately 2 hours to complete.  Unit 1 introduces pressure ulcers, covering their causes, warning signs, and prevention strategies. Unit 2 focuses on positioning, lifestyle considerations, and maintaining a proactive approach to health. Unit 3 delves into health promotion interventions, including nutrition, continence management, and promoting overall well-being. Finally, Unit 4 addresses referrals and signposting, helping learners understand when and how to refer patients to appropriate professionals and agencies. Upon completion of each unit, learners earn a digital open badge, and a final e-certificate is awarded upon completion of the course.
Year 1: NA
Year 2: NA

Required IELTS Score: NA
Entry Requirement: For the Pre Access Level 2 course, students must be over 19 years old on August 31, 2025.  The course is designed for students who want to improve their basic academic skills before progressing to higher education or enhancing their employment prospects.  Students will study GCSEs or Functional Skills in English and Maths, depending on their prior qualifications.  There is no mention of specific standardized test scores such as IELTS, TOEFL or PTE for entry into this pre-access course.  For Pakistani students, the provided entry requirements for undergraduate, postgraduate, and PhD programs at the University of Derby are unrelated to this specific Pre-Access Level 2 course. These requirements mention A-Levels, IB diplomas (for undergraduates from Pakistani international schools), a relevant bachelor's degree (for postgraduates), and a master's degree plus bachelor's in a relevant area (for PhD applicants) from recognized Pakistani universities.  Minimum GPA requirements for postgraduate entry from Pakistani universities are also specified.
Overview: The University of Derby's Pre-Access Level 2 course is designed to help students aged 19 and over enhance their fundamental academic skills in preparation for higher education or career advancement.  The course focuses on bridging the gap between prior education and more advanced studies.  Students lacking the necessary entry qualifications for Access to HE Diplomas or Foundation Programmes will benefit greatly.  The curriculum includes English and Maths (either GCSEs or Functional Skills Level 2), alongside Social Sciences modules incorporating psychology-related topics. The course aims to boost academic skills, study techniques and self-confidence. Support is provided to ease students back into the academic environment.
Course Structure: The Pre-Access Level 2 course covers foundational academic skills, primarily focusing on English and Mathematics. Students choose between GCSEs or Functional Skills Level 2 depending on their prior qualifications. Course Title: PGCE Primary (Provider-Led, School-based) with Qualified Teacher Status
Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with a minimum of 5.5 in all areas
Entry Requirement: For entry to any Initial Teacher Education (ITE) program, a minimum of Grade C (Grade 4) or above in GCSE English Language, science, and mathematics is required.  Applicants must hold an undergraduate honors degree (or equivalent) with a minimum 2:2 classification.  A 3rd class degree may be considered with extenuating circumstances, requiring a panel discussion.  Equivalencies are accepted, and prospective students should contact the admissions team for clarification. A Disclosure and Barring Service (DBS) check is needed upon acceptance.  Immunization is also required before practice-based learning.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognized university (equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree) is necessary. Those with two or three-year Bachelor degrees also need a Master’s degree pass. A four-year Bachelor's degree with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university is also considered.
Overview: The University of Derby's PGCE Primary (Provider-Led, School-based) program is a one-year, full-time teacher training course leading to Qualified Teacher Status (QTS).  It combines university-led training sessions with extensive school-based practical experience.  Students are immersed in classroom teaching from the start, working mainly in one of the university's partner schools. The curriculum includes modules focused on understanding behavior and learning, curriculum and pedagogy, progression and assessment, and professional practice.  Graduates receive 60 credits towards a master's degree and benefit from a strong network of provider schools offering diverse placement opportunities. The program is designed to prepare students for the demands of primary teaching, including core and wider National Curriculum subjects. University support is provided through trained school mentors, subject specialists, and link tutors. The course is Ofsted-rated 'Outstanding', reflecting high-quality teaching and up-to-date content.
Course Structure: The PGCE Primary (Provider-Led, School-based) program integrates modules such as Understanding Behavior and Learning, Curriculum and Pedagogy, Progression and Assessment, and Professional Practice.  Assessment is primarily based on three teaching placements (two in the main school and one in a second school) along with enhanced school opportunities.  These placements, in a range of settings, provide diverse practical experience.  Students also engage in in-depth teacher enquiry on school-based issues and reflection on their subject knowledge development. The program includes professional development input and support from school and university-based mentors and specialists.The curriculum is regularly reviewed to ensure it meets Ofsted standards and remains relevant to the evolving educational landscape.
Year 1: The first year of the PGCE Primary program is a full-time, intensive experience blending theory and practice.  Students begin with foundational modules covering curriculum development, pedagogical approaches, behavioral management strategies, and assessment techniques.  Extensive time is devoted to school placements in diverse partner schools. The placements are structured, including regular feedback from mentors. Students also participate in university-led sessions focused on enhancing specific teaching skills and subject knowledge development, and also spend time at the university, engaging in workshops, seminars, and reflective practice sessions.  Assessment involves lesson planning, teaching observations and evaluation, and project-based work related to practical challenges encountered during the school placements.
Year 2: NA

Course Title: Undergraduate Primary Education with Qualified Teacher Status BEd (Hons)
Required IELTS Score: 7.0 (with at least 6.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For entry in 2025, typical requirements include 120 UCAS points, A Levels (BBB), a T Level (Merit), BTEC (DDM), or an Access to HE Diploma (Pass with 60 credits, 45 at Level 3, minimum Distinction: 21, Merit: 24, Pass: 0). GCSEs (or equivalents) in Maths, English Language, and a Science at Grade 4/C or above are also needed.  A reference from a professional email address (school/college/employer) is required, along with certified qualifications and photographic ID. A personal statement detailing reasons for applying is mandatory.  An Enhanced Disclosure & Barring Service certificate and Occupational Health Assessment are required.  Contextual offers may apply to care experienced students, those estranged from families, refugees, asylum seekers, or those whose parents/carers are in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistani students, completing A-levels or the IB from International schools in Pakistan allows entry into the first year.
Overview: The University of Derby's BEd (Hons) Primary Education with Qualified Teacher Status is a three-year, full-time undergraduate program designed to prepare students for careers as primary school teachers.  The course focuses on developing outstanding, resilient, critical, and reflective classroom practitioners.  Students learn advanced teaching and academic skills, focusing on inclusive practices to ensure positive outcomes for all children. The program includes extensive school placements with mentor support, allowing students to gain practical experience across different year groups. Students also engage in community projects and have opportunities for overseas school visits and exploring outdoor learning. The curriculum is personalized, enabling students to select pathways that align with their professional interests and career ambitions. The program culminates in Qualified Teacher Status (QTS) allowing graduates immediate entry into the teaching profession.
Course Structure: The course integrates university-based learning and school-based training, meeting Teacher Regulation Agency requirements.  Learning takes place through a variety of methods including lectures, workshops, seminars, and tutorials.  Assessment is diverse and includes essays, reflections, presentations, reports, and tests. Students complete multiple school placements, approximately 24 weeks total, across different primary school years (EYFS to Key Stage 2).  Placements are supported by mentors and specialists. Students also benefit from a Personal Academic Tutoring programme supporting their academic progress, career planning, and personal development.
Year 1: The first year likely introduces foundational teaching methodologies, curriculum development, child psychology, classroom management techniques, and initial school-based practicum experiences. Students build a foundation in educational theory, understand child development and educational psychology, and begin to develop practical skills in a classroom setting.  The focus would be on building confidence and establishing a strong understanding of the primary school environment and working with primary-aged children.
Year 2: In the second year, students build upon the foundational knowledge of year one, developing more specialized skills and understanding, such as subject-specific pedagogy and differentiated instruction. Students will continue to deepen their practical skills via extended school placements, focusing on specific year groups.  The focus is likely on developing lesson planning techniques, assessment for learning, and working with different learning styles within the classroom.  This year may also integrate special educational needs practicum placements, offering exposure to diverse learning environments and approaches.
Year 3: Year three focuses on consolidating practical skills and experience and applying theoretical knowledge to a range of primary school settings. This year incorporates more extended placements, possibly including leadership responsibilities.  Students refine their teaching practice through observation, feedback and focused mentorship, preparing for their roles as newly qualified teachers. Curriculum design and implementation, effective assessment strategies (summative and formative), and reflective practice would be key aspects of the final year.

Course Title: PGCE Primary with Qualified Teacher Status
Required IELTS Score: 7.0 overall, with 6.5 in each skills area
Entry Requirement:
A good UK Honours degree (preferably 2:2) or equivalent is required, along with grade 4 (C) or above in GCSE Mathematics, English, and a Science.  Pending GCSEs are considered, and equivalency tests are accepted for English, Mathematics, and Science.  Applicants must demonstrate clear written and spoken English communication skills and meet the Secretary of State's requirements for physical and mental fitness to teach, and all Department for Education entry requirements, including suitability and fitness to teach checks.  A Disclosure and Barring Service clearance is needed before the course starts.  Applicants must specialize in either Early Years (age 3-7) or Primary (age 5-11) and demonstrate engagement with the relevant Key Stages.  For international students, the above qualifications or equivalents with an IELTS score of 7.0 or above are needed, with 6.5 in each skills area.  They must also demonstrate clear and accurate communication in Standard English.  

Pakistan Specific Requirements:
Students must have completed a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised University in Pakistan. This should be equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree. Students who have a two or three-year Bachelor degree must also have a pass in a Master’s degree. If you hold a Bachelors degree with honours (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University you will be considered for entry to a Masters degree.
Overview: The University of Derby's PGCE Primary program is a one-year, full-time course designed to prepare students for a career as a primary school teacher.  The program focuses on developing both practical teaching skills and a deep understanding of child development and learning theories. Trainees gain extensive hands-on experience through 24 weeks of placements in partner schools across the East Midlands. The curriculum covers all National Curriculum subjects and allows for specialization in Early Years (ages 3-7) or Key Stages 1 and 2 (ages 5-11). Graduates receive Qualified Teacher Status (QTS) and 60 credits towards a Master's degree. The University boasts impressive facilities, including the Kirtley Building with its collaborative learning spaces and specialist rooms for science, English, and mathematics. The program is highly regarded, receiving an 'outstanding' Ofsted rating.
Course Structure: The PGCE Primary program blends university-based learning with extensive school placements.  University modules cover areas like understanding behavior and learning, curriculum pedagogies, progression and assessment, and professional practice.  Significant emphasis is placed on practical experience, with five school experiences totaling 24 weeks. These placements provide opportunities to observe experienced teachers, team-teach, and take increasing responsibility for classroom management and instruction. Students also develop essential professional skills, such as parent communication, involvement in after-school activities, and trip planning. The curriculum includes a focused curriculum enhancement module, chosen by the student, adding a specialization which is reflected on the degree certificate. Assessment methods include essays, subject knowledge audits, presentations, and practical classroom observations by trained mentors.
Year 1: The first year of the PGCE Primary program is intensive, combining theoretical study and practical teaching experience.  Students engage in modules covering child development, learning theories, curriculum design and implementation across all primary subjects, behavior management, assessment strategies (including formative and summative assessment), and effective classroom management techniques. A substantial portion of the year involves school placements, allowing for extensive practice under the guidance of experienced mentors.  Students will be assessed on their teaching skills, subject knowledge, and ability to manage a classroom effectively. The curriculum also integrates professional development, equipping students with essential skills for collaborating with parents, colleagues, and school leadership. The curriculum enhancement is also completed in year 1.
