Required IELTS Score: NA
Entry Requirement: To undertake this course, applicants must be a registered nurse with the Nursing & Midwifery Council (NMC), hold current registration, be Band 5 or above in a patient-facing clinical NHS role, provide evidence of prior level 6 study (Bachelor’s degree level), and evidence completion of the Professional Clinical Nursing Leadership e-learning modules on the PNA role and the A-EQUIP model.  Applicants must also discuss their participation with senior nurses in their organization.  For Pakistani students, specific entry requirements are not listed on the provided course page but general University requirements for postgraduate programs state that students must have completed a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised University in Pakistan. This should be equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree. Students with a two or three-year Bachelor's degree need a Master's degree pass. A Bachelors degree with honours (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University is considered for entry to a Masters degree.
Overview: This Level 7 Professional Nurse Advocate Certificate of Credit is a 10-week online course designed to equip registered nurses and nursing associates with the skills and knowledge to become effective Professional Nurse Advocates (PNAs).  The program focuses on the A-EQUIP model, which emphasizes supporting professional resilience, high-quality care, identifying areas for improvement, and advocating for nurses.  Students will learn facilitation of restorative supervision, leading quality improvement initiatives, and applying advocacy principles in practice.  The course blends self-paced online learning, weekly online lectures (recorded for flexibility), and weekly activities, fostering interaction with tutors and peers through online discussions. The course also addresses ethical concerns related to clinical supervision and the need for ongoing professional development within the field of nursing advocacy.
Course Structure: The course covers a wide range of topics crucial to effective nursing advocacy.  This includes the role of the supervisor and PNA within national and local governance policies, the importance of supervision in supporting nurses and professional revalidation, and the educational principles that facilitate efficient supervision. Students will also explore various supervision frameworks and models, including methods like coaching, motivational interviewing, reflection, debriefing, and managing challenging conversations. The course incorporates approaches to evidence-based practice and quality improvement to ensure the provision of safe, compassionate, and person-centered care, including advocacy.  The participants will engage with ethical issues in clinical supervision, learn techniques to evaluate the supervision process, and understand the importance of continuous skill development and knowledge updates. The curriculum also includes implementing the A-EQUIP model and its principles in practical settings.

Overview: The BA (Hons) Professional Policing degree at the University of Derby offers comprehensive preparation for a career in law enforcement.  The curriculum integrates theoretical knowledge with practical skills, providing students with a thorough understanding of criminal justice systems, police powers, and relevant legislation in England and Wales.  The program is developed in close partnership with local constabularies, offering real-world experience through opportunities such as becoming a special constable. Students benefit from a variety of learning methods, modern facilities such as a replica crown court and custody suite, visits to police stations and other criminal justice settings, and interaction with policing experts. Graduates will have a strong foundation for advancing in policing or several related fields and will benefit from the university's career support services for up to three years after graduation.While the degree doesn't guarantee employment, it significantly enhances career prospects.
Course Structure: The course blends theoretical and practical learning. Students will engage in lectures, tutorials, seminars, workshops, role-play exercises, and site visits to police stations, custody suites, courts, and other relevant organisations. Guest lectures from industry professionals and online learning resources are incorporated, fostering interaction with current professionals and experts. Moreover, the course integrates independent study, guided reading, and opportunities for self-reflection alongside peer support. Assessment methods are diverse and include role plays, coursework, exams, presentations, and case studies, enabling students to apply their knowledge in simulated real-world scenarios.
Year 1: The first year will likely introduce foundational concepts in policing, criminal law, and the criminal justice system. Students will probably begin developing practical skills through role-playing exercises and gain an overview of the legal framework guiding police procedures.  There will also be introductory modules on police ethics, human rights, and the history and evolution of policing.  The curriculum may also include an introduction to investigation techniques and crime scene management.
Year 2: The second year will build upon the first year's foundation, delving into more advanced topics. Students will likely explore various policing specialisms, perhaps covering areas like public order, criminal investigation, and community policing.  Advanced legal modules may include evidence law and criminal procedure, and students will further hone their practical competencies through more complex simulations and possibly a significant fieldwork component like an internship or placement.  Modules might also address contemporary issues in policing and the impact of technology on modern law enforcement.
Year 3: The final year focuses on specialization and developing comprehensive expertise. Students will likely undertake advanced research projects, potentially in areas such as police leadership, investigative strategies, or community relations programs.  There might be opportunities to focus on specific aspects of policing that align with students' future aspirations.  Advanced modules may challenge students to create solutions for complex scenarios and present their findings, fostering critical thinking and problem-solving abilities.

Overview: This online Level 5 Project Management course provides a comprehensive methodology for managing projects, covering definitions, principles, and the importance of project management across various sectors.  It emphasizes the "project management triangle" (scope, time, cost) and considers external factors (PESTLE analysis). The course explores project stages, risk management, stakeholder interests, and critical success factors. Students learn to assess the need for change and develop change management strategies, define and schedule projects, and evaluate organizational and management issues related to project management. The course is designed to provide a practical understanding of project management techniques applicable to a range of business contexts.
Course Structure: The course covers definitions and characteristics of projects, project management principles, the need for projects in different sectors, project types, implications of the project management triangle (scope, time, and cost), external business environmental factors (PESTLE), stages of project management and available tools, risk assessment and management, stakeholder interest mapping, critical success factors, and reasons for project failure.  Assessment is 100% coursework, including essays, research reports, presentations, group work, and practical reports. Approximately 20 hours of study per week are recommended for the 10-week trimester, with 1-2 virtual classrooms scheduled.

Overview: The Project Manager Degree Apprenticeship is a four-year, part-time blended learning program designed in collaboration with East Midlands employers.  It focuses on developing advanced project management skills and knowledge applicable to real-world settings across various sectors such as advanced manufacturing, healthcare, construction, and finance. The program emphasizes collaboration, ethical practices, leadership, decision-making, and communication, integrating on-the-job and off-the-job learning. Apprentices will gain practical experience and theoretical understanding, leading to professional proficiency and potential Chartered Project Manager status.  The program also explores broader business and digital technology concepts, preparing graduates for dynamic project management roles in an evolving business environment.
Course Structure: The degree apprenticeship integrates on-the-job and off-the-job learning.  After Year 2, students undertake the International Project Management Association (IPMA) Level D qualification. The curriculum covers various aspects of project management,  including introduction to project management, management in the business environment, applied analytical methods and business control, procurement and contract management, project quality and operations management, project planning, risk and value engineering, corporate responsibility and professional development, digital trends and business intelligence, project strategy and leadership, programme and portfolio management and a work-based project. The program also incorporates professional review components and credit-based modules.
Year 1: The first year introduces fundamental project management concepts.  Modules include "Introduction to Project Management," providing a foundational understanding of project management principles and methodologies; "Management in the Business Environment," exploring the broader business context of project management; and "Applied Analytical Methods and Business Control," equipping students with analytical and data-based decision-making skills relevant to project management.
Year 2: The second year delves into more specialized areas of project management. Key modules include "Procurement and Contract Management," covering the legal and practical aspects of managing contracts and procurement processes in projects; "Project Quality and Operations Management," focusing on ensuring high-quality project execution; and "Project Planning, Risk, and Value Engineering," emphasizing effective project planning, risk management techniques, and value engineering principles.
Year 3: The third year builds on previous knowledge by exploring corporate responsibility, digital trends and advanced leadership skills. Modules such as "Corporate Responsibility and Professional Development" integrate ethical considerations and professional development into project management practices; "Digital Trends and Business Intelligence," explores the impact of technological advancements on project management and strategic business data usage; and "Project Strategy and Leadership" focuses on developing strategic thinking and leadership capabilities in managing complex projects.
Year 4: The final year culminates in a comprehensive understanding of programme and portfolio management, in addition to a final work-based project to demonstrate practical application of the knowledge and skills acquired throughout the programme.  Modules include "Programme and Portfolio Management," which focuses on managing multiple projects simultaneously  and "Professional Review" provides an opportunity to reflect upon the knowledge and skills acquired during this programme and "Work Based Project" which allows the student to apply the knowledge gained in a practical, work-based project.

Course Title: Undergraduate Psychology and Business Management BA/BSc (Hons)
Required IELTS Score: 6.5 (with at least 6.0 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 104 UCAS points, A-Levels BBC, T Levels Merit-Distinction, BTEC DMM, GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or above, or equivalent.  Access to HE requires a Pass Access to HE Diploma with 60 credits (45 at Level 3, minimum Distinction: 15, Merit: 24, Pass: 6).  Contextual offers may apply to care experienced students, estranged students, refugees/asylum seekers, or students with parents/carers in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or IB from International Schools in Pakistan, entry to the first year is possible. For postgraduate study in Pakistan, a relevant Bachelor’s degree equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ is needed; a Master’s degree may be required for students with two or three-year Bachelor degrees.  A Bachelor’s degree with honors (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 is considered for Master's entry.
Overview: The University of Derby's Psychology and Business Management BA/BSc (Hons) is a three-year, full-time joint honors degree program. The course combines the study of psychology and business management, offering students a versatile skillset applicable to many fields. Students begin by studying both subjects equally before choosing to major or minor in one in their later years.  The program features practical assignments, real-world projects, and opportunities for placements or internships. This course includes a focus on research, with access to specialist facilities such as an observation suite, eye-tracker equipment, and a Babylab for psychological studies, while the business program utilizes a Financial Markets Lab.  The course features an emphasis on ethical business practices, analytics and digital media in a rapidly changing global marketplace.   Graduates are well-prepared for a wide range of careers in psychology, business management, and related fields and enhanced by accreditation from the British Psychological Society and the Chartered Management Institute.
Course Structure: The course structure allows for a flexible approach to specialization. Students initially study both Psychology and Business Management equally. Later, they can choose to either focus equally across both subjects, or concentrate more on one with additional specialized modules for either discipline.  The business modules emphasize responsible management, business ethics, business analytics, digital media, innovation, and globalization, preparing students for challenges in the modern global landscape. While the Psychology modules cover a range of areas, using a variety of teaching methods that include lectures, seminars, practical workshops, work experience, and project-based assessments. The program includes a strong emphasis on research with opportunities to contribute to ongoing university research in areas like mental health, compassion, mindfulness, and autism.
Year 1: The first year involves an equal division between psychology and business management modules. In psychology, foundational topics like research methods, biological psychology, and social psychology are introduced, building a basis for subsequent specializations.  In business management, students learn foundational concepts such as business ethics, accounting principles, and introductory economics, starting the process of gaining practical business skills through analysis of real-world cases.  Students also begin to prepare for specialized modules in the subsequent years by undertaking preparatory assessment projects.
Year 2: The second year allows for greater specialization based on the student's chosen path.  Psychology majors will delve deeper into specific areas of interest, perhaps focusing on cognitive psychology, developmental psychology, or abnormal psychology, taking a range of further, specialist modules. For those specializing in Business Management they will explore more advanced topics in finance, marketing, management, and organizational behavior, developing business plans and potentially engaging in internships. Students maintain engagement with the other subject, albeit at a reduced level, maintaining a solid understanding of the supplementary discipline.
Year 3: The final year provides opportunities for advanced study and independent projects in the chosen major. Psychology students could work on a dissertation, exploring an advanced topic in depth, or undertake a placement in a relevant professional environment. Business management students engage in an advanced capstone project that can showcase practical application of the skills gained over the previous years, building on lessons from case studies and project work.  Through this year, students continue to develop skills in critical thinking, research, and communication, applying and refining their practical business experience.

Required IELTS Score: 6.5 (with at least 6.0 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 120 UCAS points, A Levels (BBB), T Levels (Merit - Distinction), BTECs (DDM), and GCSEs in Maths and English (Grade 4/C or above).  An Access to HE Diploma with 60 credits (45 at Level 3) is also acceptable.  Contextual offers may be available for care experienced students, estranged students, refugees, asylum seekers, or students with parents/carers in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or the IB from International Schools in Pakistan, entry to the first year is possible.
Location/Campus: Kedleston Road and One Friar Gate Square, Derby Campus
Overview: The BSc (Hons) Psychology and Criminology is a joint honours degree at the University of Derby, offering students the chance to study psychology and criminology equally or with a major in one subject.  The course provides a blend of theoretical knowledge and practical experience, encompassing psychological research methods, various facets of psychology (mental health, wellbeing, etc.), and criminological concepts like hate crime, human trafficking, and organised crime.  Students benefit from specialist facilities such as an observation suite, eye-tracking equipment, and a Babylab.  The Psychology major pathway holds British Psychological Society accreditation, granting students access to professional networking opportunities, resources, and graduate  membership. The program is designed to foster critical thinking, creative problem-solving and equips graduates to handle real-world challenges in diverse professional settings.
Course Structure: The course covers a wide range of topics in both Psychology and Criminology, with a varied teaching style including lectures, seminars, tutorials, group work, and independent learning.  The first year involves equal study of both subjects, after which students choose a major (Psychology or Criminology), a minor, or continue with equal study. Psychology modules focus on research methods, mental health, wellbeing, compassion, mindfulness, emotional processing, and environmental psychology.  Criminology modules explore drug use, hate crime, human trafficking, psychopathy, organized crime, and witness reliability, with practical experience using facilities like a replica crown court and custody suite. Assessment methods include essays, posters, presentations, reports, portfolios, individual and group projects, and examinations.
Year 1: The first year provides an introduction to both psychology and criminology, covering foundational topics in each subject.  Students engage in introductory modules in both disciplines to gain understanding and develop the core knowledge related to research techniques, essential theories, and practical applications. By the end of the first year, students make a decision to either major and minor in one of the subjects or continue with equal study in both.
Year 2: In Year 2, students continue to develop their understanding of psychology and criminology in greater depth. Depending on the chosen pathway (major, minor or equal study), students gain more specialised knowledge related to their chosen subject. Students may explore more specialised topics within their chosen subject, such as advanced research methods, therapeutic techniques, or specific areas of criminal justice. This year introduces opportunities to apply knowledge through projects, case studies, or internships related to professional development.
Year 3: The final year involves advanced study and specialization within the chosen major.  In this year, students often undertake independent research projects, providing opportunities to explore specific interests and enhance research skills. Students may also engage in placement or study abroad opportunities which are available.  The focus varies depending on the specialization chosen and may include advanced topics such as forensic psychology, organizational psychology or criminal justice policy in more detail.

Course Title: Undergraduate Psychology and Early Childhood Studies BA (Hons)
Required IELTS Score: 6.5 (with at least 6.0 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 120 UCAS points, A Levels BBB, BTEC DDM, GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or equivalent, or Access to HE Distinction: 15 credits, Merit: 24 credits, Pass: 6 credits.  International students need an IELTS of 6.5 with at least 6.0 in each skill.  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or IB from International Schools in Pakistan, entry to Year 1 is possible. Postgraduate entry for Pakistani students requires a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK Upper or Lower Second Class degree.  A Master's degree is also needed if the Bachelor's was two or three years long.  A four-year Bachelor's degree with honours and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani University is also considered for Masters entry.
Annual Tuition Fee: UK: £9,535 per year; International: £16,900 per year
Overview: The Psychology and Early Childhood Studies BA (Hons) is a joint honours degree offered by the University of Derby. This three-year undergraduate program combines the study of psychology with early childhood education, providing students with a comprehensive understanding of child development, learning, behavior, and holistic needs. It is designed to equip students with the theoretical and practical knowledge needed for a career working with children in various settings. Courses include fundamental psychological theories, child development from multiple perspectives, and meeting the diverse challenges and opportunities faced by professionals in early childhood services.  The program focuses on developing critical thinking, research skills, and practical application of learned concepts through various teaching methods, assessments (including reports, presentations and essays), and access to specialized facilities  such as a 'babylab'. The program also offers BPS accreditation for students who choose a specific pathway.
Course Structure: The program allows students to study both psychology and early childhood studies equally in the first year after which students can choose to continue studying both equally or choose a major in one subject. The modules will vary depending on chosen pathways.Psychology modules may involve lectures, seminars, tutorials, and assessments such as essays, posters, presentations, and reports, and possibly exams. Early Childhood Studies modules are assessed through case studies, essays, research, tests, posters, presentations, and reports.  The university provides support through a personal academic tutoring (PAT) program. There are additional costs for supplementary materials, certain training(like Makaton), and optional field trips.
Year 1: The first year involves an equal study of both Psychology and Early Childhood Studies. Students are introduced to fundamental psychological theories and principles of human behavior and development. In Early Childhood Studies, students gain a foundational understanding of child development, learning, and thinking, considering various perspectives (e.g., cognitive, social, emotional). Practical activities and observations may also be included. This comprehensive introduction establishes a flexible base for future specialization.
Year 2: In the second year, students can choose to either continue with an equal balance of Psychology and Early Childhood Studies or opt to major in one subject. The choice of major will influence the range and depth of chosen modules and assessments. Those majoring in psychology will have more psychology-focused modules, including more advanced topics and research in their field of interest. Early Childhood Studies majors will expand their understanding of education and care practices with more in depth modules and practical training. Each pathway may increase specialization in a particular area of interest, allowing for individual career trajectory planning.
Year 3: The third year builds upon the foundation of the previous two, with an increasing emphasis on specialization, project work, and independent study. Depending on which stream the student has selected (equal or major stream), the final year focuses on more specialized modules and assessments. If they chose a psychology major, they'll delve into more advanced theoretical concepts, while those who continued on the balanced path will consolidate their understanding of both disciplines. The year could include a practicum or placement for students seeking practical experience, preparing them for entry into working roles after the graduation.

Course Title: Undergraduate Psychology and Education Studies BA/BSc (Hons)
Required IELTS Score: 6.5 (with at least 6.0 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical requirements include 128 UCAS points, A-Levels ABB, a BTEC DDM, or an Access to HE Diploma with specific credit and grade requirements.  GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/Grade C or above are also needed.  International students require an IELTS score of 6.5 with at least 6.0 in each skill area.  Contextual offers may be available for students from certain backgrounds, including those who are care experienced, estranged from their families, refugees, asylum seekers, or whose parents are in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or the IB from international schools in Pakistan, entry to the first year of the Bachelor's degree is possible.
Overview: The University of Derby's Psychology and Education Studies BA/BSc (Hons) is a three-year, full-time joint honours degree program. Students study both subjects equally in the first year before choosing to major or minor in one subject or continue studying both equally.  The course combines psychology and education, offering a versatile skillset.  Psychology modules cover various areas such as mental health, wellbeing, compassion, mindfulness, autism, and maths anxiety, using specialist facilities like observation suites and eye-tracker equipment.  Education Studies modules explore education's role in society, educational equality, current educational policy, and practice, using varied teaching methods and providing work placement opportunities. The course is accredited by the British Psychological Society (BPS) if students major in Psychology, with benefits including access to networking, events, and resources. The course emphasizes research and practical application, preparing graduates for various careers.
Course Structure: The course structure allows for flexibility.  Students begin by studying Psychology and Education Studies equally in the first year, then choose whether to major in one subject, minor in one, or continue studying both equally in years two and three.  Psychology modules might include topics like maternal health, mental wellbeing, compassion, mindfulness, pain, and emotional processing; while Education Studies modules could cover inclusion, diversity, social equality, online learning, and pastoral care. Assessment methods vary across modules, with essays, posters, presentations, reports, portfolios, and case study analyses; exams are only used for some Psychology modules.  There's a focus on technology-enhanced learning, work placements, and research opportunities.  The program also incorporates Personal Academic Tutoring to support students' academic and personal growth.
Year 1: The first year involves an equal balance of Psychology and Education Studies modules.  Psychology introduces foundational concepts, research methods, and ethical considerations while also providing an introduction to central themes and areas within the field.  Education Studies modules provide a broad overview of educational theories, policy, and practice, covering topics such as the history of education and current social and educational issues, introducing early childhood studies, and considering current educational theory. Students are introduced to the fundamental concepts of both disciplines, laying the groundwork for more specialized study in later years. Practical skills such as essay writing, research methods, and presentation skills are also emphasized in the first year.
Year 2: In the second year, students will have already chosen their major or minor subject, or chosen to study both subjects equally.  Those majoring in Psychology will focus on more advanced topics, including potentially specific research methods, experimental design, data analysis, and more in-depth study.  Those majoring in Education Studies might continue with advanced modules related to policy, specific educational methodologies, and possibly specialized areas like early childhood education or special educational needs.  Regardless of pathway chosen, specialized software such as SPSS and NVivo will be used. Students will develop their critical thinking and research skills further while specializing in their chosen area of expertise.
Year 3: The final year typically involves further specialization, potentially including advanced research projects or a dissertation. Psychology majors might engage in independent research projects, applying their knowledge to specific areas of interest based on their selected pathways and optional modules. Education Studies majors may focus on practical application through case studies, independent research projects related to the education sector, and perhaps, more in-depth pedagogical practices. All options culminate in work that displays specialization in the subject area. Students will also have the opportunity to apply for graduate membership of the BPS.

Overview: The University of Derby's BA (Hons) English and Psychology is a three-year, full-time joint honours degree program designed to cultivate both creative and analytical thinking. Students explore the intellectual and cultural history of various fields, including art, film, philosophy, linguistics, and sociology, alongside a rigorous study of fundamental psychological theories and their application to human behavior and development.  The course is accredited by the British Psychological Society, providing significant career advantages and opportunities for postgraduate study. Students benefit from specialist facilities, including computing labs, eye-tracking equipment, and a Babylab while fostering research and analytical skills through various assessment methods, such as essays, presentations, and research projects.   Derbyshire's strong literary heritage offers an enriching environment for study. Students also have options to study abroad at partner universities in the USA. The course allows for students to equally study both subjects in the first year or choose to major or minor in one subject by the end of the first year.
Course Structure: The course combines modules in English and Psychology.  In year one, students study both subjects equally.  Later, students can choose to major in Psychology (leading to BPS accreditation), major in English, or continue studying both subjects equally.  Psychology modules cover fundamental psychological theories explaining human behavior and development; specific research areas may include mental health, wellbeing, compassion, mindfulness, autism, and math anxiety.  English modules involve lectures, seminars, tutorials, essays, research projects, presentations and conference papers, fostering communication and research abilities. Work-based learning and placements may involve cultural institutions and organizations such as the 1623 Theatre Company and Writing East Midlands.
Year 1: The first year involves an equal balance of English and Psychology modules.  English modules introduce key literary and cultural theories, foundational texts, and analytical techniques. Psychology modules cover fundamental research methods, biological psychology, and introductory concepts in developmental, social, and cognitive psychology. Students engage in various learning activities, including lectures, seminars, tutorials, and coursework assignments to build a foundation in both subjects and determine their preferred focus in future years. By the end of the year, students choose their preferred pathway for years two and three based on whether they want to major or minor in one or the other or to maintain an equal spread of both subjects.
Year 2: In Year 2, students continue their studies in both disciplines but with a deeper exploration of specific areas according to their chosen pathway (majoring in psychology, English or an even spread of the two). Those focused on Psychology will undertake increasingly sophisticated research methods and delve into specialized subfields like cognitive psychology, personality psychology or developmental psychology. For English modules, there might be specialized courses on literary genres and theory.  Students present their work through seminars, presentations and larger essays.  Work-based or placement opportunities will be arranged for interested students.
Year 3: Year 3 involves advanced coursework depending on the students chosen pathway. Those majoring in Psychology will likely undertake a major research project, possibly culminating in a dissertation, and will delve deeper into the subject they chose to focus on. The assessment will reflect the choice of path and might include a final project in place of exams. Students specializing in English typically produce original research projects or substantial critical essays, and may prepare for a career through work-based learning or a relevant placement .

Overview: The University of Derby's Psychology and Law Joint Honours BA/BSc is a three-year undergraduate program combining the study of human psychology and the legal system. Students explore the interplay between psychological principles and legal practices, developing skills in both fields. The course balances theoretical study with practical application, such as mock court cases and legal advice center involvement.  This program offers flexibility; students can choose to major in Psychology (gaining British Psychological Society accreditation) or Law, or maintain an equal balance between both subjects.  Graduates will possess a blended skill set, enhancing career prospects in various sectors.
Course Structure: The course structure is flexible, allowing for specialization in psychology or law or an equal division of both subjects. The first year involves equal study in both disciplines before students choose their specializations at the end of the first year.  Psychology modules might include topics on mental health, compassion, mindfulness, autism, and pain processing. Law modules focus on developing legal skills such as case preparation, interviewing, negotiation, and mooting (mock court presentations).  Modules offered may vary, and students should contact the university for the precise curriculum of their chosen pathway. The university uses a variety of assessment methods, including essays, presentations, reports, group work, and examinations.
Year 1: The first year provides a foundation in both psychology and law, introducing core concepts and principles in each subject.  Students will typically undertake introductory modules in both fields, gaining a broad understanding of both areas before deciding on their focus for the following years. This helps them to develop a well-rounded understanding that informs their subject choice later.
Year 2: In the second year, students who chose to major in Psychology will focus on advanced psychology modules, while those majoring in Law delve deeper into legal subjects. Those continuing with an equal balance will study intermediate modules in both disciplines. Specific modules will vary based on the student's chosen pathway. Practical application and skill development remain central, with continued opportunities for mooting, research projects, and involvement in the Student Legal Advice Centre.
Year 3: The final year intensifies specialization. Psychology majors complete advanced modules and may undertake an independent study or research project. Law majors conduct more advanced legal studies and work on larger-scale projects.  Students maintaining the balanced approach will complete modules covering more specialized topics in both psychology and law.  All students will also engage in activities that help them develop their employability skills. This might involve final-year projects for their chosen pathway, and placement or internship opportunities.

Overview: The University of Derby offers a joint honours Bachelor of Arts or Science in Publishing and Psychology.  This three-year undergraduate program blends creative and commercial aspects of the publishing industry with the study of human behavior and the mind. Students gain expertise in publishing, learning skills to bring works to market, and develop their understanding of psychological theories.  The course is designed to provide a competitive advantage by applying psychological knowledge to commercial aspects, fostering critical thinking and problem-solving abilities.  Students use modern facilities, including computing labs, psychological recording equipment (eye-trackers), and the Babylab. The course boasts British Psychological Society accreditation, providing access to networking opportunities, discounts, and potential pathways to chartered membership after graduation. Students start by studying both subjects equally, later choosing to major or minor in one or continue with an equal balance.
Course Structure: The course structure is flexible.   Students study publishing and psychology equally in the first year. Following that, they can choose to major in one subject (Psychology for BPS accreditation; otherwise Psychological Studies), minor in one, or continue studying both equally. The curriculum includes modules covering various aspects of publishing such as writing, editing, and industry practices, integrated with psychological theories and research methods.  Modules utilize lectures, seminars, workshops, project-based learning and utilize advanced technologies and student-led research to enhance learning. The final year typically involves a mix of independent study and specialized modules that allows students to hone their skills and explore their chosen area of specialization.
Year 1: The first year provides a balanced introduction to both publishing and psychology. Students explore foundational concepts in publishing, such as the history of the industry and the roles of different professionals, while simultaneously learning core principles of psychology, such as research methods and major psychological perspectives.  This equal split allows students to gauge their interests and strengths before deciding on their specialization in subsequent years. The year includes lectures seminars, workshops, tutorials and projects that allow for collaboration and development of key skills in both areas.
Year 2: In the second year, students delve deeper into their chosen major, minor or continue studying both fields proportionately. Those majoring in psychology will take more advanced courses in areas such as cognitive psychology, social psychology or developmental psychology and meet the requirements for BPS accreditation. Publishing students deepen their skills in areas such as manuscript development, editing or marketing.  Students continue to refine both their practical and theoretical skills through coursework, projects and possibly a work placement related to their future career pathway.
Year 3: The final year involves specialisation, independent study, and potentially a dissertation or capstone project. Students complete major modules and advanced modules related to their chosen area of focus in publishing or psychology. Students can focus on their area of interest or develop interdisciplinary project that utilizes both skillsets. The final year also involves the development of advanced critical thinking and communication skills in preparation for career pathway. Modules may include market research,  publication design and production or more advanced psychological research methods and application.

Overview: The University of Derby's Psychology and Sociology Joint Honours BA/BSc (Hons) is a three-year undergraduate program exploring both disciplines. Students initially study both subjects equally, making a major/minor choice after the first year.  The course provides a solid foundation in psychological principles and research methods, examining areas like mental health, wellbeing, compassion, mindfulness, and the influence of environment, alongside sociological theories and trends.  Students analyze social issues, such as inequality, gender and sexuality, and digital culture. The program offers specialization options, BPS accreditation (with Psychology Major), and access to specialized facilities. Through practical applications and assessments, students develop critical thinking, research abilities,  and employability skills.
Course Structure: The course combines psychology and sociology modules.  Students initially study both subjects equally.  After the first year, they can major in one subject or maintain balanced study.  Psychology modules cover areas such as maternal health, mental health, compassion and mindfulness, pain, and emotional processing using specialized equipment and software while Sociology modules will cover topics such as social inequality, race and ethnicity, gender and sexuality, globalisation, the impact of the digital era, the sociology of childhood and youth, the cult of celebrity, social movements and political engagement, marginal beliefs and the influence of conspiracy theories. Assessment methods vary between subjects, encompassing essays, presentations, reports, and potentially exams.
Year 1: The first year introduces both psychology and sociology equally.  Psychology modules may cover introductory topics in research methods, biological psychology, and social psychology, alongside foundational sociological concepts, exploring societal structures, social theories, and research methodologies. Students get familiar with introductory theories and start to form a basic level of knowledge of both subjects before choosing which one they want to major in.
Year 2: In Year 2, students' modules will depend on their chosen pathway (major in Psychology, Sociology, or equal study).  Psychology majors will delve deeper into specialized areas like cognitive psychology, developmental psychology, or clinical psychology. Sociology majors might focus on areas like social inequality, criminology, or political sociology.  Students maintaining an equal balance continue with modules in both subjects, maintaining their broad knowledge base.
Year 3: The final year focuses on advanced studies in the chosen major subject and further development of both disciplinary topics. Psychology majors might undertake dissertation research, while sociology majors might engage in independent study or research projects. Students choosing to study both subjects equally in Year 1 will now make a decision toward which one they want to major in, and a third of the modules will be in this subject.
