Overview: The BSc (Hons) Psychology and Sport Studies is a joint honours degree at the University of Derby offering a blend of psychology and sports studies.  Students gain a strong foundation in psychological principles, including mental health, decision-making, and healthy lifestyles, alongside diverse sports topics.  The course features practical work in state-of-the-art facilities, including psychology labs with EEG and eye-tracking equipment, and sports facilities such as a physiology lab, sports hall, and 4G pitch.  Teaching is conducted by experts in their fields, and the course includes opportunities for internships and applied experiences to enhance employability. The program also emphasizes personal development and career planning with personalized academic tutoring.
Course Structure: The course begins with equal study in both Psychology and Sport Studies. Students then choose to major in one or minor in the other depending on their preference, either majoring or studying equally through the three years.  Psychology modules cover core areas, while Sport Studies modules allow for a range of optional topics like sports management, strength and conditioning, and sports psychology, among others.  The program combines theoretical knowledge with practical application, utilizing specialized facilities and involving applied case studies, role-playing, and coaching sessions. Assessment involves written reports, presentations, examinations, and practical demonstrations, tailored to the chosen major or minors.
Year 1: The first year involves equal study of both Psychology and Sport Studies. Psychology modules introduce core concepts and research methods, covering areas like the nature of mental illness and decision-making. Sport studies modules will cover an overview of topics such as sports management, nutrition, strength and conditioning, coaching and physical activity, health and sports psychology. Students will have practical experience in the psychology and sports science laboratories.
Year 2: In year two, students will continue their studies in the chosen pathway to their major or minor. Regardless of pathway, students will expand their knowledge in Psychology and their specified sports studies topic, with a focus on practical application and real-world projects. Specific modules and their weight will vary depending on the selected pathway.
Year 3: The final year is dedicated to advanced study within the chosen major or minor.  Psychology majors undertake advanced modules, potentially including independent research projects.  Sport studies majors broaden their knowledge in specific areas that align with their career goals.  Students refine their research skills and complete assignments and projects, applying their knowledge in practical settings.

Required IELTS Score: 6.5 (with at least 6.0 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 120 UCAS points, A Levels BBB, BTEC DDM, GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or equivalent, or Access to HE Distinction: 15 credits, Merit: 24 credits, Pass: 6 credits.  IELTS 6.5 with at least 6.0 in each skill is required. Contextual offers may apply to care experienced students, those estranged from their families, refugees or asylum seekers, or those whose parents/carers are in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or IB from International Schools in Pakistan, entry to Year 1 is possible.  Postgraduate entry from a recognised Pakistani university requires a degree equivalent to a UK Upper or Lower Second Class Honours, and a Master's degree if the Bachelor's is two or three years. A Bachelor's with Honours (four-year) and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 is also considered for Masters entry.
Location/Campus: University of Derby, Derby city centre
Overview: The BA (Hons) Psychology and Theatre Arts is a joint honours degree allowing students to explore both disciplines.  Students learn research methods, data analysis, and critical thinking within psychology, while in theatre arts they develop creative skills and practical performance experience. The course includes opportunities for professional work experience at Derby Theatre or partner organizations.  The Psychology curriculum is designed to be challenging and relevant, covering topics such as mental health, wellbeing, and decision-making. Theatre Arts focuses on practice, experimentation, and exploring various theatre making techniques, taught by practicing artists.  Graduates will obtain transferable skills valuable in various sectors.
Course Structure: The course structure involves equal study of both subjects in the first year, after which students can choose to major in Psychology (for BPS accreditation), minor in one subject, or continue with equal study.  Psychology modules are taught using cutting-edge technology and involve various assessment methods such as essays, presentations, and reports.  Theatre modules use a mix of practical exercises, workshops, and public performances for assessment. A Personal Academic Tutoring programme provides support and guidance throughout the degree.
Year 1: The first year provides an equal exploration of both Psychology and Theatre Arts.  Psychology introduces foundational concepts, research methods, and data analysis techniques. Theatre Arts provides an introduction to various theatre practices, including performance skills, devising, and applied theatre. Students begin to build their portfolios, and are introduced to the practical and theoretical demands of the course.
Year 2: In Year 2, students continue their studies with an opportunity to decide whether to specialize in one subject or continue with both equally. Psychology modules may delve into more specific areas such as cognitive psychology, social psychology and abnormal psychology. Theatre Arts modules may increase focus on specific skills areas, such as acting, directing, stage management, or playwriting, through practical workshop and production opportunities. Students begin to develop their independent research skills.
Year 3: The final year allows students to specialize in psychology or theatre arts or to continue to manage their time equally. Psychology modules may focus on advanced research methods, specialized psychological topics or the completion of a dissertation. Theatre Arts may include advanced production workshops, culminating in a major production. Students work towards completion of their studies and finalize their portfolios.

Required IELTS Score: 6.5 (with at least 6.0 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2024 entry, typical requirements include 120-128 UCAS points, A Levels ABB-BBB, T Level Merit, BTEC DDM, GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or above, or a Pass Access to HE Diploma.  For 2025 entry, requirements are 128 UCAS points, A Levels ABB, T Level Distinction, BTEC DDM, and GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or above.  Contextual offers may be available for care experienced students, estranged students, refugees, asylum seekers, or students whose parents/carers are in the UK armed forces.  For  Pakistani students completing A-levels or IB from International Schools in Pakistan, direct entry into Year 1 is possible. Students with a 4-year Bachelor's degree with a minimum 2.4/4.0 GPA from a recognised Pakistani university may be considered for entry.  Those with 2- or 3-year Bachelor's degrees require a Master's degree pass.
Overview: The University of Derby's Psychology BSc (Hons) program is a research-focused course designed to equip students with the skills and knowledge of a forward-thinking psychologist.  The curriculum covers a wide range of psychological topics, from mental health and wellbeing to compassion, mindfulness, autism, and the impacts of nature.  Students benefit from expert teaching staff who are actively involved in research and from access to specialist facilities, including observation suites, eye-tracking equipment, and a Babylab, allowing hands-on experience with psychological research methods. There's also the opportunity to participate in research projects, gain applied experience through work placements, and potentially have work published in academic journals. The course is accredited by the British Psychological Society (BPS), providing access to networking opportunities, resources, and potential pathways for chartered membership.
Course Structure: The course is delivered through interactive lectures, small group seminars, practical workshops, and innovative use of web-based learning.  Assessment is primarily through assignments, including essays, posters, presentations, and reports.   Modules cover a broad range of subjects within psychology, encompassing theoretical concepts and their practical applications. While specific modules are subject to change, students are taught by leading researchers and contribute to cutting-edge projects, developing a deep understanding of psychological principles, research methods, and ethical considerations. The course blends theory with practical skills development through opportunities like work placements. Students receive support from Personal Academic Tutors who facilitate academic and personal growth.  The program culminates in opportunities for advanced learning and career opportunities in various fields.
Year 1: First-year modules will provide a foundation in core psychological principles and research methods. Students will be introduced to various topics such as the biological basis of behavior, cognitive psychology, developmental psychology, and social psychology. Introductory research methods and statistical analysis techniques will also be covered. The year lays the groundwork for more specialized modules in subsequent years.
Year 2: The second year delves into more specialized areas of psychology. Students refine their research skills by engaging in more advanced research methods and statistical analysis.  The program expands on core areas explored in the first year while introducing students to advanced applied areas such as abnormal psychology, psychopathology, and potentially specialized options such as developmental psychopathology or cognitive neuroscience.
Year 3: The final year focuses on applied psychology, allowing students to apply the knowledge and skills acquired in previous years.  Students may undertake a placement year within the third year, gaining practical experience in a real-world setting.  Advanced research methods and a dissertation or major research project are key features of this year, providing in-depth exposure to the full research process.  There's opportunity to further specialize in areas of personal interest.

Entry Requirement: Entry requirements include A levels (104 UCAS points excluding General Studies) or equivalent qualifications like BTEC National Diploma or Scottish Highers.  GCSE Maths and English Language (minimum grade C) are also required. Access qualifications with a grade of 22 merits or a distinction are accepted. Relevant work experience may be considered. Students with an online University Certificate in Psychology with a final average grade of 50% and passing all core modules may be offered automatic progression. For other certificate holders, progression is at the Programme Leader's discretion.  Those with an undergraduate degree in another subject may be eligible for an MSc Psychology conversion course.  For non-native English speakers, IELTS 6.0, TOEFL 550 (paper based), 213 (computer based), or 80 (internet based), Pearson Test of Academic English 51, Cambridge Advanced Certificate pass, London Tests of English level 4, International GCE O-level English Language grade C, or International GCSE English/English as a Second Language grade C are acceptable.  Regarding Pakistan, students completing A-levels or IB from International Schools in Pakistan can start in the first year of a Bachelor's degree.
Overview: The University of Derby offers a British Psychological Society (BPS) accredited online BSc (Hons) Psychology degree.  This established program provides a comprehensive education in psychology, covering core curriculum topics and offering optional modules in areas like educational psychology, pain psychology, and gender and sexuality.  The course emphasizes research-led teaching and provides opportunities for students to tailor their studies to personal interests.  Students benefit from access to a supportive online learning environment, including online resources, a digital library, specialist software, and a strong academic community with opportunities to engage with faculty and peers. The program's design caters to online learners, offering flexible study options and support systems to help students balance their studies with other commitments.  Graduates gain Graduate Basis for Chartership (GBC), a crucial step toward becoming a qualified psychologist in the UK, or they can apply the gained skills to various career paths in health, social care, or education.
Course Structure: The program is structured into three stages. Stage 1 involves completing six core modules (120 credits). Stage 2 requires completion of six modules (120 credits), four core and two optional. Stage 3 involves four optional modules and an independent research project. In Stages 2 and 3 students have the opportunity to choose optional modules to align with their career goals and interests. The optional modules available may vary from year to year according to student demand. The program operates on a trimester system, with three 10-week terms each year.  Students can choose from a standard pace (20 hours per week per module) or an accelerated pace (40 hours per week per module) depending on their commitments.
Year 1: The first year focuses on foundational psychology concepts and core modules which prepare for further learning. The precise modules are not detailed, however the first year modules must be completed before progress to the second year of study.
Year 2: The second year build on the foundation established in Year 1. Students will complete four core modules, covering advanced topics in various psychology fields relevant to the BPS accreditation. In addition, two optional modules can be selected to match personal interests and career goals; examples include Psychology of Education, Psychology of Pain, Autism and ADHD, and Psychology of Gender and Sexuality.
Year 3: The final year consists of four optional modules giving further specialization, and an independent research project.  The optional modules allow students to further customize their studies, selecting areas of interest and developing research skills. The final year research project provides a chance to apply the knowledge and skills obtained throughout the program in an original research study.

Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with at least 6.0 in each skill area
Entry Requirement: For UK students, a 2:1 honours degree in psychology or a closely related subject with good coverage of undergraduate research methods is typically required.  International students must have qualifications equivalent to a UK 2:1, and if English isn't their first language, they need an IELTS score of at least 6.5 (with at least 6.0 in each skill area).  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised University in Pakistan equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree is required. Students with a two or three-year Bachelor's degree must also have a Master's degree.  A four-year Bachelor's degree with honours and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University will also be considered.
Annual Tuition Fee: £9,720 for the full course* (Full-time)£1,080 per 20 credits (Part-time)International: £16,900 for the full course
Overview: The MRes Psychology program at the University of Derby is designed to prepare students for original research in psychology.  It focuses on developing high-level research skills, including both quantitative and qualitative methods. Students design and conduct their own independent research projects under expert supervision, culminating in a presentation and viva voce examination.  The program offers flexibility with a blend of online learning and short on-campus study blocks, allowing students to balance their studies with other commitments.  The curriculum emphasizes real-world applications and includes access to state-of-the-art facilities.  Graduates are well-prepared for careers in research (academic, commercial, or public sector), further professional training, or progression to a PhD.
Course Structure: The MRes program involves modules in advanced qualitative and quantitative analysis for psychology, philosophy of science, and conducting psychological research in the 21st century.  It includes methodological strategies for reviewing contemporary research and a significant independent research project.  The independent research project incorporates developing a research question, planning the project, choosing methods, data analysis, and communicating findings. Students can tailor their research project to their interests.  A variety of research areas are supported such as Religious Belief, Paranormal Belief, Music Psychology, and many others.
Year 1: The first year of the full-time MRes program involves completing modules in advanced qualitative and quantitative analysis for psychology, philosophy of science in psychology, conducting psychological research in the 21st century, and methodological strategies for reviewing contemporary research.  The majority of the year is dedicated to an independent research project, under the supervision of a faculty member. This project involves all aspects of research from question development to dissemination of findings and usually includes a viva voce examination. Students have access to state-of-the-art research facilities at the university.
Year 2: NA

Entry Requirement: Applicants typically need an undergraduate degree with Honours (minimum 2:2) from a UK university or an equivalent overseas qualification.  A Master's degree or a psychology degree (minimum 2:2) that doesn't provide Graduate Basis for Chartered Membership (GBC) is also acceptable.  Overseas applicants must have an equivalent qualification and demonstrate a good standard of written and spoken English.  A GCSE/GCE O Level Maths grade C is required.  English language proficiency is demonstrated through IELTS 6.5, TOEFL 550 (paper), 213 (computer), or 80 (internet), Pearson Test of Academic English 51, Cambridge Advanced Certificate pass, London Tests of English level 5, or equivalent.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized university, equivalent to at least a UK Upper Second Class (2:1) or Lower Second Class (2:2), is required. Those with two- or three-year Bachelor's degrees also need a Master's degree.  A four-year Bachelor's degree with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university is also acceptable.
Overview: The University of Derby's online MSc Psychology is a BPS-accredited program designed for those seeking careers in psychology or further professional training. It offers a comprehensive understanding of core psychological areas (biological, cognitive, lifespan, individual differences, social psychology), research methodology, and project design.  Graduates gain Graduate Basis for Chartered Membership (GBC), a crucial step toward chartered psychologist status. The program is flexible, allowing part-time study over 2-3 years, and includes optional modules to specialize in areas like Applied Psychology of Human Performance or Autism Spectrum Disorder. The curriculum blends interactive learning, online resources, and support from academic staff and online learner advisors.  This program is geared toward non-psychology graduates or those from non-BPS accredited programs, allowing them to meet entry requirements for further specialized psychological professional training.
Course Structure: The MSc comprises 180 credits, structured in three stages: Postgraduate Certificate (60 credits), Postgraduate Diploma (60 credits), and Masters (60 credits). The Postgraduate Certificate involves three core 20-credit modules and one 0-credit Skills and Careers module.  The Postgraduate Diploma includes two core 20-credit modules and one optional 20-credit module (subject to availability). The final Masters stage culminates in a 60-credit independent empirical research project. Group work is mandatory in some modules to meet BPS standards. This program also includes various support services such as access to online library, student webinars, individual support, and career guidance.
Year 1: NA
Year 2: NA

Entry Requirement: Applicants need 60 credits in psychology at level 4 or above.  If lacking these credits, the University's online University Certificate in Psychology is a prerequisite.  Additionally, an undergraduate degree with Honours (at least a 2:2) from a UK university or equivalent overseas qualification; a Masters degree from a UK university or equivalent; a psychology degree (at least a 2:2) not granting Graduate Basis for Chartership; or an equivalent undergraduate degree from an overseas institution is required.  Proficiency in written and spoken English is essential.  Students from Pakistan must have completed a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognized university, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree.  Those with two or three-year Bachelor degrees need a Master's degree pass as well. A four-year Bachelor's degree with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university might suffice.
Overview: The University of Derby's online Postgraduate Diploma in Psychology is a part-time program designed for individuals aiming for a career in psychology, particularly those seeking Graduate Basis for Chartered Membership (GBC).  The course provides a thorough understanding of core psychology areas, including biological, cognitive, lifespan, individual differences, and social psychology. It incorporates practical experience through an independent research project. While this diploma alone doesn't qualify one to practice as a psychologist, attaining GBC opens doors to various psychology specializations, such as clinical, forensic, health, sports, educational, and occupational psychology. The program emphasizes flexible learning, blending interactive online sessions, discussions, and individual support.
Course Structure: The Psychology Postgraduate Diploma consists of six core 20-credit modules and one zero-credit module, totaling 120 credits.  The curriculum covers fundamental areas of psychology, encompassing biological, cognitive, lifespan development, individual differences, and social psychology, integrating these with contextual and historical issues.  A significant component is designing, conducting and disseminating an independent research project.  The course features a structured learning experience with a supportive environment, providing detailed learning materials and regular interaction with tutors and peers through online platforms. The assessment is 100% coursework-based, incorporating various methods such as essays, research reports, presentations, group work, and practical reports.
Year 1: NA
Year 2: NA

Entry Requirement: For the University Certificate in Psychology, students must be at least 18 years old and have a minimum of GCSE Maths and GCSE English Language (grade C or equivalent).  Relevant work experience can be considered for those who don't meet the standard entry requirements.  To progress to the BSc (Hons) Psychology, a final average grade of 50% in the certificate course is needed.  For the Postgraduate Diploma in Psychology, an undergraduate degree with at least a 2:2 is required.  For Pakistan, the entry requirements depend upon the level of the program; however, at the undergraduate level, students completing A-levels or the IB from Pakistani International Schools are eligible. At the postgraduate level, a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to at least a UK 2:1 or 2:2 is needed, and those with shorter Bachelor's degrees require a Master's degree. For a PhD, a Master's and Bachelor's degree are required along with a research proposal.
Overview: The University Certificate in Psychology is an introductory course designed for those interested in learning about the foundations of psychology, regardless of their career aspirations.  The course equips students with a breadth of knowledge and transferable skills applicable to various career fields such as human resources, management, and social services. The program is flexible, offering part-time study options. Successful completion requires passing three 20-credit modules and allows progression to a BSc (Hons) or Postgraduate Diploma in Psychology at the University of Derby. The curriculum covers fundamental theoretical issues and offers choices in cognitive, developmental, social, biological psychology and historical issues in psychology.  Research methods are also introduced, benefiting those seeking further education or enhancing work skills. The program offers a supportive online learning environment that includes online sessions, discussions, and access to a comprehensive library and experienced academic staff.
Course Structure: The University Certificate in Psychology requires completion of 60 credits earned through three 20-credit modules from optional areas including cognitive, developmental, social, biological psychology and historical issues in psychology, and in addition to Introduction to Research Methods. The modules are delivered through a trimester system, with each 20-credit module lasting 10 weeks. Students can study at a standard pace (20 hours per week) or an accelerated pace (40 hours per week) as per their comfort. Assessment is 100% coursework based and involves various methods such as essays and research reports. Module choices follow a study pattern determined by the start date, with guidance available throughout. The course content is regularly reviewed and updated to enhance the learning experience.
Year 1: NA
Year 2: NA

Course Title: Undergraduate Psychology with Foundation Year BSc (Hons)
Required IELTS Score: 6.5 (with at least 6.0 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2024 entry, typical requirements include 80 UCAS points.  A-levels (CDD), T-levels (pass with C or above in core), BTECs (MMP), or an Access to HE Diploma are acceptable. GCSEs in Maths and English are preferred but not mandatory; if lacking, they can be studied at Level 2 as part of the course.  International students should meet the IELTS requirement.  For Pakistani students, A-levels or IB from Pakistani international schools allow direct entry to Year 1.  For postgraduate study in Pakistan, it is normally necessary to have a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2, and those with 2-3 year Bachelor's degrees should also have a Master's degree. A four-year Bachelor's degree with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.0 from a recognised Pakistani university is considered for Master's entry.
Overview: The University of Derby's Psychology with Foundation Year BSc (Hons) is a four-year undergraduate program designed to provide a strong foundation in psychology.  The foundation year is beneficial for career changers or those who don't meet the standard entry requirements for a three-year degree. Students learn from leading researchers, engaging with cutting-edge research projects and utilizing specialist facilities like observation suites and eye-tracking equipment. The broad curriculum covers social, developmental, cognitive, and biological dimensions of behavior, preparing graduates for diverse career paths or postgraduate study.  The course incorporates various teaching methods such as lectures, seminars, group activities, and practical work, along with ample support from faculty and online resources. Optional modules allow for specialization in areas of interest.
Course Structure: The course combines core psychology modules with a range of optional modules covering applied and theoretical aspects such as cyberpsychology, sport and exercise psychology, addictive behaviors, family health, psychology in education, the psychology of pain, and the psychology of nature and wellbeing.  The foundation year focuses on strengthening skills and knowledge required for university-level study.  Students are assessed through diverse methods, including essays, exams, posters, presentations, and reports.  An optional work placement offers valuable experience, enhancing employability.  The program emphasizes research engagement, and students may get involved in ongoing projects.
Year 1: The foundation year focuses on building a strong base with modules to prepare for core psychology coursework. This may include introductory modules in psychology, research methods, and essential academic skills, such as essay writing and critical thinking. Students gain confidence and strengthen their skills before progressing to the main degree.  This year also allows students to develop proficiency in key areas relevant to psychology, like mathematics and English language skills, if necessary.
Year 2: Year 2 introduces fundamental areas of psychology, such as biological psychology, cognitive psychology, developmental psychology, and social psychology. Students will engage in research methods, and start to develop specialised skills in data analysis and report writing, such as SPSS and NVivo software programs. This year lays the groundwork for more specialized study in later years.
Year 3: Year 3 allows for greater specialization. Students will likely have the opportunity to choose optional modules to align with their interests and career goals.  The course covers advanced topics within their chosen area of focus and builds upon the foundational knowledge gained in previous years. Advanced research skills are also emphasized through a range of assessment and engagement methods.
Year 4: The final year, year 4, involves an optional work placement opportunity combined with a capstone project.  Students will use the skills gained in previous years in a professional environment.  They complete a major research project, further developing their research, analytical abilities, and specialized knowledge. The project helps students to develop their professional writing and communications skills as well as developing their independence and self-management skills.

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 overall, with a minimum of 5.5 in each test category
Entry Requirement: A 2:1 undergraduate degree in a relevant subject or relevant professional experience in the heritage sector is required.  Applicants with a 2:2 honours degree and significant relevant experience may also be considered.  An interview may be required. For non-native English speakers, an IELTS score of 6.0 overall with at least 5.5 in each section is mandatory.  The test must be less than two years old at the start date.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognized university equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree is needed.  Those with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees must have a Master's degree. A four-year Bachelor's degree with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university is also considered.
Overview: The MA Public History and Heritage program at the University of Derby provides a comprehensive education in public history and heritage, combining academic study with practical experience within the heritage sector.  Students develop both intellectual and professional skills for leadership roles within museums, archives, education, and related fields. The program emphasizes the role of history in the public sphere, preparing students for various careers through a dynamic curriculum.  Students will engage in real-world projects, consultancies, and field trips, working alongside renowned historians and heritage professionals. The program also builds networks through partnerships with local, national, and international heritage organizations.  The course culminates in a research-based dissertation, enhancing students' advanced research abilities.
Course Structure: The course involves a dissertation and work placement, supplemented by modules such as 'The Politics of History,' 'Current Debates in Global Heritage,' 'Curation and Conservation in the Digital Age,' 'Understanding Audiences and Audience Development,' and 'Funding, Marketing, and Heritage Management.'  The curriculum blends theoretical understanding with practical skills acquisition via workshops, seminars, tutorials, field trips, and work-based experiences.  Assessments include policy papers, audience research evaluations, and a dissertation, fostering critical thinking, research, and presentation capabilities.
Year 1: The first year of the full-time MA program includes a blend of core modules focusing on the theoretical underpinnings of public history and heritage, alongside practical modules that build essential professional skills.  Students engage with 'The Politics of History,' exploring the use and contestation of history in society; 'Current Debates in Global Heritage,' examining the growth and challenges of the heritage industry;  'Curation and Conservation in the Digital Age,' exploring practical and digital curation; and 'Understanding Audiences and Audience Development,' focusing on audience research and engagement strategies.  The year concludes with a work placement in a heritage organization.
Year 2: NA

Required IELTS Score: 7.0 (with at least 6.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 112 UCAS points, A-Levels BBC, T Level Merit, BTEC DMM, GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or equivalent, or a Pass Access to HE Diploma.  A portfolio is recommended.  Contextual offers may be available for care experienced students, estranged students, refugees or asylum seekers, and students whose parents/carers are in the UK armed forces. For Pakistani students completing A-levels or IB from International Schools in Pakistan, entry into Year 1 is possible.  Postgraduate entry from a Pakistani university requires a relevant Bachelor’s degree equivalent to a UK Upper or Lower Second Class Honours, and a Master’s degree if the Bachelor’s was two or three years. A four-year Bachelor’s with a minimum 2.4/4.00 GPA is also considered.
Overview: The BA (Hons) Public Relations and Journalism is a three-year undergraduate program designed to equip students with skills in both journalism and public relations.  It combines practical training with theoretical knowledge, focusing on multimedia skills, PR strategies, marketing expertise and digital media. The curriculum covers a wide array of topics from news writing and audio/video production to brand management, social media campaigns and campaign planning. Students gain practical experience through the in-house PR and communications agency, UniComms Derby, working on real-world projects for clients. They also benefit from potential work experience opportunities with media outlets such as Reach plc and the BBC.  The program is designed to prepare students for a diverse range of careers in these fields or related areas.
Course Structure: The course is structured across three years, with a mix of core and optional modules allowing students to specialize. Year one establishes a foundation in core PR, marketing, and journalism skills including newswriting, audio-visual techniques,  PR theory, brand management, and media law. Year two builds upon this foundation, introducing modules like PR content creation, convergent media, and PR and media management, while adding optional modules according to student interest.  Year three allows for specialization through elective modules that cover advanced skills in areas such as social media, video production, podcasting, brand marketing, and online community management. Students also complete either a PR Campaigning module (developing and implementing a full-scale campaign) or a Journalism Project module (producing a dissertation or practice-based journalistic work).
Year 1: The first year provides a broad foundation in PR, marketing, and journalism. Core modules include PR skills, newswriting, discovering audio and video, introduction to PR and communication theory, managing the brand, and media law.  The integrated approach combines specialized PR and marketing modules with modules taken alongside BA (Hons) Marketing and Journalism students to offer a well-rounded understanding of each discipline.
Year 2: Year two builds on the first year's foundation. Students take four core modules that further develop PR, marketing, and journalism skills. These include PR content creation, convergent media, celebrity media and culture, PR and media management, and future trends in journalism. Students also select optional modules reflecting their interests (e.g., fashion journalism, consumer behaviour), and may choose study abroad.
Year 3: The final year allows for specialization. Students select one core 40-credit module: either PR Campaigning (developing a full-scale PR campaign via UniComms) or Journalism Project (producing a dissertation or practice-based journalistic work). They also select two other 20-credit modules tailored to their specialism, potentially including subjects such as social media management, video news days, podcasting, and brand marketing. The Start-Up Journalism module prepares them for self-employment options.

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 112 UCAS points, A Levels BBC, BTEC DMM, GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or above, or an Access to HE Diploma.  International students need an IELTS of 6.0 with at least 5.5 in each skill.  Contextual offers may be available for care experienced students, those estranged from their families, refugees or asylum seekers, or students whose parents/carers are in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or the IB from international schools in Pakistan, entry into the first year is possible.
Annual Tuition Fee: UK: £9,535 per year; International: £16,900 per year
Overview: The University of Derby's BA (Hons) English and Publishing is a three-year, full-time joint honors degree program designed to equip students with a comprehensive understanding of both literature and the publishing industry.  The course blends creative writing workshops and literary analysis with practical, industry-focused modules. Students explore various forms of cultural expression and develop essential skills in writing, editing, research, and presentation. The curriculum allows for specialization in English or Publishing, or a balanced approach to both subjects.  The program emphasizes critical engagement with literature and cultural politics, preparing graduates for diverse career paths in the publishing world or other communication-intensive fields.
Course Structure: The course structure is designed to provide students with solid foundations in both English and Publishing. Year one focuses on fundamental literary theory, writing techniques, and introductory publishing concepts. Year two allows students to choose between major or minor in English or Publishing, and explores specialized subjects and advanced literary criticism. Year three consists of independent research projects that allow students to demonstrate their skills and apply knowledge. This approach aims at producing graduates who are capable of navigating both the academic and professional aspects of English and Publishing.
Year 1: The first year introduces core concepts of literary analysis, creative writing, and the fundamental aspects of the publishing industry. Students engage with a range of literary texts, learn different writing styles, and explore different roles within publishing. An equal balance of English and Publishing modules enables students to develop a foundational understanding of both disciplines.  This introductory phase helps formulate the basis for further specialization in the following years.
Year 2: In the second year, students can decide to major or minor either in Publishing or English. Major students take additional modules in their chosen subjects, while minor students concentrate on balancing both disciplines. The course offers specialized tracks for students interested in various subjects, such as editing, literary theory, journalisms, and publishing for different literary markets.  Students further develop their skills in critical analysis and creative writing within the chosen specializations.
Year 3: The final year is centered around independent project work and advanced discussions. Students have the opportunity to develop and specialize their research skills via independent research projects. This involves developing and completing an extended dissertation, which is marked according to the specific regulations set for the chosen pathway. Students also have the opportunity to expand their skill development through guest speakers and additional workshops.

Required IELTS Score: Overall: 6.5, minimum 5.5 in each test category
Entry Requirement: A good honours degree (1st or 2:1) in any subject, or its international equivalent, is required.  Applicants with a 2:2 honours degree may be considered if they demonstrate significant publishing or related industry experience or aptitude, such as work experience in publishing or a related field, or a portfolio of relevant work. An informal interview may be required.  For international students whose first language is not English, an IELTS score of 6.5 with a minimum of 5.5 in each category is needed.  The test must be taken within two years of the course start date.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised University in Pakistan equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree is required. Students with a two or three-year Bachelor's degree must also have a Master’s degree. Overview: The University of Derby's MA Publishing program offers a comprehensive education in all aspects of the publishing industry.  Students gain practical skills and theoretical knowledge across diverse areas, including editorial and content development, design and production, marketing and sales, and business operations. The curriculum incorporates both traditional and digital publishing approaches, preparing graduates for the dynamic challenges and opportunities of the modern industry. The program emphasizes real-world learning with guest lecturers, networking events, and potential industry placements, fostering professional connections and preparing students for successful careers.  The program stresses the evolving landscape of publishing, encompassing print, ebook, audio, and the influences of social media and AI.
Course Structure: The course is structured in three stages: Postgraduate Certificate, Postgraduate Diploma, and Masters.  Core modules cover essential aspects of publishing such as The Publishing Profession, Editorial and Editing, Print and Digital Production, and Marketing and Sales in Modern Publishing. Optional modules allow for specialized study in areas such as legal frameworks, specific publishing sectors (academic, educational, professional, magazines), and skill development.  Assessment methods are diverse, featuring written assignments, presentations, and portfolios demonstrating practical skills.
Year 1: The first year of the full-time MA Publishing program covers core modules focusing on the publishing profession's current issues and trends, editorial and editing ethics and practices, print and digital production processes, and effective marketing and sales strategies in the modern publishing environment. Throughout, the program emphasizes practical application and real-world scenarios.
Year 2: The second year, applicable to part-time students, may include a mix of core modules from the first year and optional modules allowing for specialization and greater in-depth study of chosen domains within publishing, along with practical project work or research.

Course Title: BSc (Hons) Quantity Surveying and Commercial Management
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical entry requirements include 104 UCAS points, A Levels (BCC), T Level (Merit), BTEC (DMM), or an Access to HE Diploma.  GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or above are also needed.  International students need an IELTS score of 6.0 with at least 5.5 in each skill.  Contextual offers may be available for students from specific backgrounds, such as care-experienced students, estranged students, refugees, asylum seekers, or those whose parents are in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistani students, entry depends on their qualifications.  A-levels or IB from Pakistani international schools allow direct entry into Year 1. Postgraduate entry requires a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2, potentially with a Master's degree if the Bachelor's was shorter than four years.  A four-year Bachelor's with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani university is also accepted.  PhD applicants require a Master's and Bachelor's degree in a relevant subject area plus a research proposal.
Overview: The BSc (Hons) Quantity Surveying and Commercial Management degree at the University of Derby provides a comprehensive education in the financial and business aspects of construction.  Students develop strong technical skills alongside financial acumen, preparing them for senior roles within the industry. The course is accredited by the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS), the Chartered Institute of Building (CIOB), and the Chartered Institution of Civil Engineering Surveyors (CICES), ensuring alignment with industry standards and enhancing career prospects. Students benefit from industry partnerships, work placement opportunities, and expert teaching from staff conducting influential research. The curriculum integrates practical learning through site visits, fieldwork, and engagement with real-world projects, such as Down to Earth Derby's 'New Commons' initiative.  Graduates are well-prepared for diverse career paths in quantity surveying and related fields.
Course Structure: The course combines theoretical learning with extensive practical application.  Modules cover a breadth of topics including contract preparation, cost analysis, feasibility studies, payment arrangements to contractors, site assessments, and sustainable building design.  Students engage in group work, individual assignments, lectures, seminars, site visits, and field studies to gain a well-rounded understanding of the industry.  Assessment involves computer workshops, surveying fieldwork, group projects, individual assignments, and exams.  A personal academic tutoring program ensures individual support and guidance throughout the degree.
Year 1: The first year lays the foundation in quantity surveying principles. Students study fundamental concepts of construction technology, building regulations, and basic surveying techniques.  Early modules focus on developing core skills in communication, teamwork, and problem-solving, essential for success in the construction industry. An introduction to cost planning, contractual agreements, and the legal framework within construction will also be covered. A compulsory residential field trip is included, providing valuable practical hands-on experience.
Year 2: Year two builds upon the foundational knowledge gained in the first year.  Students delve deeper into cost estimation, risk management, and project planning, applying these concepts to more complex scenarios.  Advanced surveying techniques, including digital modeling and software proficiency (like AutoCAD), are explored. The curriculum includes topics like contract administration, payment mechanisms, and dispute resolution. Students might also start considering an optional work placement for Year 3.
Year 3: The final year enhances specialization, allowing students to tailor their studies to their career aspirations.  Modules might include advanced topics in commercial management, construction law, sustainable practices, and professional development.  There's a strong emphasis on project management and the completion of a significant individual or group project, applying knowledge gained throughout the course.  Students also benefit from strong industry connections and support in their job search.

Overview: The BSc (Hons) Quantity Surveying and Commercial Management with Foundation Year is a four-year undergraduate program designed to equip students with the financial, business, and technical skills needed for senior roles in the construction industry.  The integrated foundation year strengthens skills and knowledge before progressing to the degree.  The course is accredited by RICS, CIOB, and CICES. It emphasizes practical learning through lectures, seminars, site visits, and project work, including involvement in real-world projects. Students gain valuable experience through optional work placements and develop strong industry connections.
Course Structure: The course combines theoretical knowledge with practical application. It covers a range of modules encompassing quantity surveying principles, commercial management, construction technology, legal and contractual aspects of construction, and project management techniques.  The curriculum is regularly reviewed to maintain relevance to the industry's evolving practice and technological advancements. Assessment involves continuous project work, individual and group assignments, examinations and computer workshops.  A personal academic tutor (PAT) supports students throughout their academic journey.
Year 1: The foundation year focuses on developing foundational academic and professional skills.  Subjects are likely to include introductory mathematics, English for academic purposes, study skills, an introduction to quantity surveying and construction principles and basic construction technology. The aim is to build a solid base of knowledge ready for progressing to the main degree program.
Year 2: Year 2 delves deeper into core quantity surveying principles and commercial management.  Key topics include cost planning and control, measurement, procurement, and contract administration.  Students will also likely receive  introduction to construction technology and software relevant to quantity surveying and begin to develop skills in report writing and presentations. The year 2 modules build upon the foundation year and lay the groundwork for more specialized studies in later years.
Year 3: The third year builds upon the foundations laid in the previous years, introducing students to more advanced concepts in quantity surveying and commercial management. This could include specialist aspects such as advanced cost planning, risk management and dispute resolution, construction law, and advanced construction technology modules. Students may also undertake an optional work placement, gaining valuable real-world experience.
Year 4: The final year focuses on integrating knowledge and skills developed throughout the program.  Students will likely have more specialized module choices based on personal career aspirations. Projects, dissertations, and final exams provide opportunities to demonstrate a comprehensive understanding of quantity surveying and commercial management. The aim is to prepare students for professional practice and chartered status.

Overview: This Level 7 short course focuses on radiographic image analysis of the chest. The course covers normal and abnormal radiographic appearances, clinical indications, referral protocols, basic techniques, interpretation of normal variants, and common pitfalls.  It employs a multi-professional approach with online lectures, case study discussions, and image viewing, along with an assessment day involving a portfolio, OSCE, and VIVA.  The goal is to equip participants with a systemic approach to analyzing chest radiographic images relevant to their professional needs.  Students who successfully complete the course will enhance their skillset in interpreting chest X-rays and the principles of image quality, benefiting both themselves and their employers.

The course culminates in an assessment day which includes a portfolio, OSCE (Objective Structured Clinical Examination), and VIVA (verbal examination). Required IELTS Score: Overall: 6.5 with no less than 6 in any category
Entry Requirement: Applicants must be employed as Assistant Practitioners in a UK radiography department, secure 240 hours for projection radiography, and have a workplace mentor (HCPC-registered Diagnostic Radiographer with minimum two years post-qualification experience).  A manager's approval form is needed, confirming support and learning opportunities.  If applying for the BSc (Hons) Diagnostic Radiography apprenticeship, a Foundation degree (FdSc) in an Assistant Practitioner radiographic imaging pathway (within the last 5 years) is required. A workplace audit form demonstrating experience in projection radiography examinations is also necessary.  For those whose first language isn't English, IELTS with an overall score of 6.5 with no less than 6 in any category, or an equivalent, is required.  The Healthcare Assistant Practitioner Apprenticeship Standard Reference: ST0215 is satisfactory if modules in skeletal imaging (including appendicular imaging), radiographic anatomy, and radiation physics have been completed.
Overview: This online Certificate of Credit in Radiographic Imaging (Projectional) is designed for Assistant Practitioners in imaging departments.  The course aims to equip participants with the projectional (plain film) radiography competency needed to apply for the BSc (Hons) Diagnostic Radiography Apprenticeship.  It focuses on foundational radiographic practice for the appendicular skeleton, thorax, and abdomen, encompassing skeletal and soft tissue anatomy, image assessment, and quality measures.  Students will integrate radiographic techniques with evaluations of normal radiographic appearances, applying their knowledge in clinical practice.  The program includes workplace learning involving supervised projectional radiography, various appendicular techniques (static and mobile chest imaging), and assisting with theatre imaging. This is a standalone 10-week course, awarding 20 credits at Level 4.
Course Structure: The course is structured into ten units. These will build upon existing knowledge, skills, and behaviors in projection radiography, both academically and within the imaging department's on-the-job learning.  Learning methods include reflections in a journal, online discussions with peers, knowledge check quizzes, self-directed learning, and revision. It involves studying the relevant skeletal anatomy (bones and joints of the appendicular and thorax), and understanding the relevant musculature, ligaments, and tendons.  The course integrates radiographic techniques with the evaluation of normal radiographic appearances, applying these to clinical practice. The curriculum further emphasizes practical experience by encouraging practical application of knowledge in real-world imaging department settings.

Overview: The University of Derby offers a free online course titled "Recovery Pathways." This course provides a comprehensive overview of addiction recovery science, its history, and research, drawing primarily from US and European studies.  It delves into the REC-PATH study, a European research project investigating recovery pathways by gender in the UK, Belgium, and the Netherlands. The course examines the study's rationale, methods, and key findings, analyzing their implications for research, policy, and practice.  It's designed for professionals in the addiction field, those supporting people in recovery, and those working in peer recovery organizations.  No prior knowledge of research or science is assumed. The course aims to enhance understanding of recovery concepts, the history of recovery research, gender differences in recovery, and the details and findings of the REC-PATH study.  Learners receive digital open badges for completing each unit, culminating in an e-certificate upon course completion. The course leverages professionally recognized theory and evidence for its curriculum and is also an accredited provider of the CPD Standards Office.
Course Structure: The course comprises six units, each requiring approximately two hours of study. Unit 1 introduces recovery definitions and patterns. Unit 2 focuses on existing evidence and knowledge regarding recovery patterns. Unit 3 explores recovery-oriented drug policies in the UK and Europe. Unit 4 examines gender differences in addiction and recovery. Unit 5 details the REC-PATH project's origins and methods. Finally, Unit 6 presents the study's key findings and their implications for research, policy, and practice.  Each unit concludes with the award of a digital open badge, recognized by many employers and institutions. Upon course completion, participants receive an e-certificate detailing their achievement.

Entry Requirement: Applicants require a Level 2 English and Maths qualification (GCSE Grade 4-9, GCSE Grade A-C, Level 2 Functional Skills English/Maths, Key Skills Level 2 Communication/Application of Number or equivalent).  112-128 UCAS points are needed, achievable through various Level 3 qualifications such as Access to Higher Education or Access to Nursing (60 credits: 45 at level 3 with a minimum of Dist: 15 Merit: 24 Pass: 6), A Levels, T Levels, or BTEC (DDM-DMM). Health or care experience is desirable.  Those whose first language isn't English must provide IELTS 6.5 overall with no less than 6.0 in each section or an equivalent OET score.  The employer must confirm they can provide necessary placements for NMC registration.  Applicants must be in paid employment (at least 37.5 hours/week), and the employer covers apprenticeship costs.  For Pakistani students, entry is dependent on the specific qualifications held, usually requiring a relevant Bachelor’s degree equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2 degree.  Additional requirements for postgraduate level may include a relevant Master’s degree and a minimum GPA depending on the years of their Bachelor's Degree.
Overview: The University of Derby's Registered Nurse Degree Apprenticeship is a 3-year, full-time program leading to NMC registration.  It blends theoretical study with extensive practical experience, with 50% of the program dedicated to placements in various clinical settings.  The curriculum covers fundamental nursing knowledge, skills, and professional values, emphasizing person-centered care and emotional resilience.  Students benefit from state-of-the-art facilities, experienced faculty (including NMC-registered professionals), and a supportive learning environment with personal academic tutors and regular tripartite reviews.  The course aligns with NMC standards and includes a wide range of assessments designed to ensure graduates are prepared for autonomous practice.  The apprenticeship model allows students to earn a salary while studying, with employer-sponsored fees and government funding support. This program is designed to build emotional resilience and help students become effective registered nurses.
Course Structure: The program is structured across three stages, each consisting of core modules. Stage one introduces fundamental nursing concepts, including legal and ethical frameworks, human physiology, pharmacology, and person-centered care. Stage two builds upon this foundation by exploring research methodologies, pharmacological and psychosocial interventions, and further develops person-centered care skills. Stage three focuses on leadership, improving nursing practices via an extended innovation project, and finally, transitioning to autonomous practice. Assessments are diverse (aligned to learning outcomes and NMC standards) and are designed to bridge theory and practice, helping students improve their professional development and make them suitable for various roles upon completion.
Year 1: Year one introduces the foundational aspects of nursing practice; it includes modules like “Introduction to Nursing”, “Health Sciences for Nursing Practice”, and “Person-centered nursing care for health & wellbeing”.  Students will learn the role of nurses in contemporary practice, explore legal and ethical contexts, and develop skills in communication and reflection, alongside basic human physiology and pharmacology related to health and well-being for all ages.  Focus on person-centered care equips students with skills in assessing and planning interventions.  The completion of MYEPAD, crucial for meeting Part 1 Future nurse standards, is also done this year.
Year 2: The second year deepens understanding of nursing practice. Key modules such as "Research for health & wellbeing" teach students evidence-based practice and its application in patient care, considering wider life contexts.  A strong focus on applying knowledge and developing person-centered skills is evident in modules like "Pharmacological and psychosocial interventions", exploring disease pathophysiology and interventions. Furthermore, "Developing nursing practice" allows for practical application of the previous year's learning, and MYEPAD completion is needed to meet the requirements of Part 2 Future nurse standards.
Year 3: The final year focuses on leadership and advanced nursing practice.  Here, the curriculum encompasses "Leadership for nursing practice" to build skills in leading and managing care delivery within interprofessional healthcare teams.  Students learn from near misses, critical incidents, and major events.  In addition to this, skills related to innovation and improvements are developed with "Innovation and improvement in nursing practice", which involves an extended project and research skills to make recommendations for practice. Lastly, "Transition to autonomous practice" ensures preparedness for entry onto a professional register, demonstrating the ability to critically evaluate and intervene in complex care situations while meeting the requirements of Part 3 Future nurse standards.

Required IELTS Score: 6.5 overall with no less 6.0 in any element

Applicants whose first language is not English require IELTS 6.5 overall with at least 6.0 in each section. Apprentices must be in paid employment (at least 37.5 hours/week), with the employer covering apprenticeship costs.  For Pakistani students,  the university will consider applicants from International Schools within Pakistan if they are completing their A-levels or IB. Those with a four-year Bachelor's degree with honours (minimum GPA 2.4/4.00) from a recognised university may be considered.
Location/Campus: Online; Annual residential week at University of Derby campus
Overview: The University of Derby's Registered Nurse Degree Apprenticeship BSc (Hons) is a 3-year, full-time online program designed for UK-based healthcare professionals supported by their employers.  It's an apprenticeship, meaning students are employed full-time while studying.  The program combines online learning with annual residential weeks on campus, utilizing state-of-the-art clinical simulation facilities. The curriculum emphasizes evidence-based practice, person-centered care, and professional values, preparing graduates for registration with the Nursing and Midwifery Council (NMC).  The program aims to develop emotionally resilient and transformational registered nurses through a mix of theoretical and practical learning, including substantial clinical placements. The course is designed to equip students with the skills and knowledge to deliver high-quality, patient-centered care and to adapt to the ever changing landscape of modern nursing practice.
Course Structure: The BSc (Hons) Nursing comprises nine 40-credit modules, totaling 360 credits.  Modules are structured across three stages.  Stage one introduces fundamental nursing concepts, including legal, ethical, and professional frameworks, human physiology, and person-centered care, requiring completion of MYEPAD to meet NMC standards. Stage two builds upon this foundation with modules on research methods, pharmacological and psychosocial interventions, and developing nursing practice, again integrating MYEPAD for assessment. Stage three focuses on leadership, innovation and improvement in nursing practice, and transition to autonomous practice, culminating in the achievement of NMC standards for registration.  Throughout the program assessments are diverse and directly relevant to professional nursing practice, ensuring graduate readiness.
Year 1: Year one introduces students to the core role of a registered nurse in contemporary practice, within its legal, ethical, and professional frameworks.  Students build foundational knowledge in health sciences, including human physiology, pharmacology, and psychological and sociological aspects of health and well-being.  The curriculum will also introduce the essential principles of person-centered nursing care, integrating practical skills using the MYEPAD framework to demonstrate competency in the first part of the NMC standards.
Year 2: The second year deepens students’ understanding of research methodologies in health and well-being.  It examines the etiology and pathophysiology of diseases, exploring pharmacological and psychosocial interventions through an evidence-based approach. For Registered Nursing Associates entering at the 18-month point, there is a transition module to bridge the gap.  The year also includes practical application and development of person-centered care skills, completing the second part of the MYEPAD requirements aligned with the NMC’s Future Nurse standards.
Year 3: Year three focuses on leadership and management within inter-professional teams, including analyzing critical incidents and near misses to influence practice.  Students undertake an extended project focusing on innovation in nursing, critically applying theoretical and investigative principles to their area of interest.  Finally, assessment on the transition to independent practice allows students to showcase their ability to assess, intervene, and evaluate complex patient care, ensuring they meet all NMC requirements for registration.

Required IELTS Score: 6.5 overall with no less 6.0 in any element
Entry Requirement: Applicants require GCSE grade C or above (Grade 4-9) in Maths and English, an Honours degree (2:2 or above), and 800 hours of work experience in a service user context within the last five years.  An interview is also required.  International students whose first language is not English must provide IELTS 6.5 with a minimum of 6.0 in each section or an equivalent. For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised University in Pakistan equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree is required. Those with a two or three-year Bachelor's degree need a Master's degree pass as well, while a four-year Bachelor's degree with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 is also acceptable.  Applicants must submit an enhanced CV demonstrating the relevance of past experiences and work experience hours.
Overview: The Registered Nurse Degree Apprenticeship MSc is a two-year, full-time program designed for individuals with a prior degree (2:2 or above) and relevant work experience. It leads to registration with the Nursing and Midwifery Council (NMC). The program blends theoretical learning with extensive practical experience through clinical placements, encompassing various healthcare settings and specialties such as adult, children's, and mental health nursing.  Students develop comprehensive knowledge in their chosen field, focusing on compassionate professionalism and patient-centered care. The curriculum is aligned with NMC standards, incorporating diverse assessment methods to ensure students meet the requirements for registration. The program is taught by experienced NMC-registered professionals, supported by outstanding university facilities, including state-of-the-art clinical skills suites.
Course Structure: The course is divided into two academic years and three equal parts for practice assessment. It involves a range of modules designed to build fundamental knowledge and skills for safe and effective nursing practice. During each year, students complete modules focusing on professional nursing practice, evidence-based practice, complex care, leadership, innovation and improvement, and transition to autonomous practice.  The curriculum is mapped against NMC standards and incorporates a variety of learning methods including classroom-based activities, skills laboratories, and online learning. A significant component of the program is practice learning which takes up 50% of the total program duration and involves placements in various clinical settings.  Students are assessed through a diverse range of methods aligned with module learning outcomes and NMC standards.  These assessments are designed to be relevant to professional nursing practice, support the application of theory to practice, and provide opportunities for professional development.
Year 1: Year one focuses on building the foundation for safe and effective nursing practice. Core modules include 'Professional nursing practice', covering human anatomy, physiology, psychological and sociological aspects of health, and reflective practice skills.  'Evidence-based nursing practice' delves into applying evidence for patient-centered care, while ‘Complex care in nursing practice’ focuses on assessing, planning, and implementing nursing interventions for individuals with complex needs. This year also includes the completion of Part 1 of the MYEPAD to demonstrate the achievement of skills outlined in the NMC’s Standards of Proficiency.
Year 2: The second year builds upon the foundation laid in the first year and focuses more on leadership, innovation, and the transition to autonomous practice.  Core modules include ‘Leadership for nursing practice’, a field-specific module that explores managing care within inter-professional teams and uses problem-based learning to analyze incidents.  'Innovation and improvement in nursing practice', another field-specific module, involves an extended project leading to recommendations for nursing practice.  'Transition to autonomous practice' covers the assessment, intervention, and evaluation of complex care, preparing students for independent practice.   Part 2 and 3 of the MYEPAD need to be completed to demonstrate the achievement of skills relating to the NMC’s Standards of Proficiency.

Course Title: Level 7 Research Methodologies - Application to Advanced Practice
Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with a minimum of 5.5 in all areas
Entry Requirement: For this course, an undergraduate degree in a relevant subject or equivalent is required.  Specific requirements for Pakistani students include: for postgraduate study, a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised Pakistani University equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree is needed.  Those with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees must also have a Master's degree. A Bachelor's degree with honours (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University is also acceptable for Master's entry.
Overview: This Level 7 postgraduate module focuses on research methodologies and their application to advanced practice in health and social care.  It's designed for healthcare professionals wanting to improve their research skills for practical application, clinical decision-making, and those preparing for independent scholarship. The module uses problem-based learning to cover various aspects, such as different research approaches (mixed methods, qualitative, and quantitative), using research effectively in practice, critically evaluating evidence, and understanding the evidential underpinnings of practice. The course aims to develop critical thinking skills related to research methodologies within the scope of advanced practice and assess the overall significance of research for the advancement of professional knowledge and practice.
Course Structure: The course utilizes a problem-based learning approach.  Topics covered include the nature of current research approaches, encompassing mixed methods, qualitative, and quantitative research designs.  Significant emphasis is placed on applying research effectively within practical healthcare settings.  Students will develop crucial skills in conducting critical evaluations of research evidence and comprehending the evidential foundation of evidence-based practice (EBP). The curriculum is structured to provide a thorough understanding of the essential components of research methodologies, equipping students with the necessary skill set for independent scholarly work.
Year 1: NA
Year 2: NA

Course Title: Level 7 Research Methods - Health, Psychology and Social Care
Required IELTS Score: NA
Entry Requirement: For this short course, professional registration in a health and social care role is required.  The provided text does not specify requirements for other qualifications like GCE A Levels, International Baccalaureate, GRE, or GMAT.  For Pakistani students, the information is not specific to this course but mentions that for postgraduate study, a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised Pakistani University equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree is needed. Those with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees require a Master's degree pass.  A four-year Bachelor's degree with honours (minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00) from a recognised university is acceptable for Masters entry.
Overview: This Level 7 Postgraduate Certificate in Research Methods is designed for health and social care professionals. It is a 20-credit module focusing on research design, encompassing quantitative and qualitative methods, data analysis techniques, ethical considerations, practical research challenges, and appropriate dissemination of research findings.  The course emphasizes critical analysis of existing research literature to identify viable research topics and evaluate suitable research methods for those topics.  It's delivered entirely online, with student support provided through various means like phone, Skype, and email from a dedicated module tutor.  The program is suitable for a wide range of health professionals, including nurses, paramedics, occupational therapists, pharmacists, and ultrasonographers. It involves around 200 hours of study over three months.
Course Structure: The Research Methods module covers a comprehensive range of topics crucial to conducting impactful research within the health and social care sector.  The curriculum begins with the ability to critically evaluate existing literature, identify areas needing further investigation and to formulate a suitable research question for investigation.  Students will learn about various research designs, including quantitative and qualitative approaches and how data may be analyzed using appropriate techniques.  A strong emphasis is placed on ethical considerations, ensuring that research is conducted with integrity and respect for participants.  The course will also cover the practical challenges researchers often encounter, such as limitations in access to data or resources which may impact on outcomes and appropriate data analysis methods.  Finally, the module emphasizes the importance of effectively communicating research findings to relevant stakeholders, ensuring maximum impact and facilitating informed decision-making within healthcare settings.

Required IELTS Score: NA
Entry Requirement: The provided text does not specify entry requirements beyond the course being available to athletes of all levels.  There is information regarding entry requirements for undergraduate, postgraduate, and PhD programs at the University of Derby in general, but not specifically for this short course.  For undergraduate programs, an IELTS score between 6.0 and 7.0 or a TOEFL score of 79-100 is required and for postgraduate programs an IELTS score of 6.5 with a minimum of 5.5 in all areas or a PTE score of 60 is required. For PhD programs, an IELTS 7.0 overall with 7.0 in writing and 6.5 minimum in other areas, a TOEFL score of 100 with a minimum of 27 in writing, 20 in speaking, and at least 19 in other sections, or a PTE score of 76 overall with 71 minimum in other skill areas are required.  Pakistan specific requirements include for undergraduate programs: completion of A-levels or IB from Pakistani International Schools allows direct entry to the first year of a Bachelor's degree. For postgraduate, a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2 is needed. A Master's degree is also required for those with a 2- or 3-year Bachelor's degree. A 4-year Bachelor's degree with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.0 from a recognized university is considered for Master's entry. For PhD programs, a Master's and Bachelor's degree are needed, along with a research proposal.
Overview: The University of Derby's Running Performance short course offers a comprehensive analysis of running technique and physiological capabilities for athletes of all levels.  Participants choose from three packages (Experience, Advanced, and Complete) providing detailed assessments tailored to individual needs.  Each package incorporates testing for body composition, blood lactate levels, and running economy, providing valuable insights into training zones and areas for improvement.  The Complete Package adds a comprehensive gait analysis, offering a holistic evaluation for optimizing running technique and performance. The ultimate goal is to personalise your training to improve performance. The course is suitable for anyone who is serious about running, and aims to provide detailed data and feedback to improve performance.
Course Structure: The course is structured around three distinct packages, each building upon the previous one.  The Experience Package focuses on basic physiological assessments, including body composition analysis and lactate threshold determination. The Advanced Package builds on this by adding VO2 max testing and running economy analysis, offering greater depth of understanding.  The Complete Package integrates the assessments of the Advanced Package with a detailed gait analysis using high-speed video and the OPTOJUMP analysis system.  All packages culminate in a comprehensive report providing results, interpretations, and personalized training recommendations.
