Course Title: PGCE Secondary (Provider-Led, School-based) with Qualified Teacher Status
Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with a minimum of 5.5 in all areas
Entry Requirement: To be eligible for this course, applicants need an undergraduate honors degree (preferably a 2:2) or equivalent.  A GCSE grade 4 or above in English Language and Maths is also required.  Applicants must demonstrate sufficient subject knowledge in their chosen curriculum specialism.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognized university in Pakistan, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree, is necessary. Those with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees also need a Master's degree. A Bachelor's degree with honors (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university is acceptable for Master's degree entry. A Disclosure and Barring Service (DBS) check is mandatory upon acceptance.
Overview: The University of Derby's PGCE Secondary (Provider-Led, School-based) program is a one-year, full-time master's level teacher training course leading to Qualified Teacher Status (QTS).  The program emphasizes school-based learning, with trainees spending most of their time in partner schools gaining practical experience and working as part of a school team.  The course blends hands-on teaching experience with university-based modules covering effective learning, lesson planning, and educational policy. Students receive intensive classroom support from mentors and university tutors and undertake two assessed teaching placements.  The curriculum is designed to equip graduates with the skills and knowledge to excel as secondary school teachers, incorporating current educational practices and research.  The program is known for employing teaching staff who are also published authors and researchers, ensuring cutting edge pedagogy is embedded in curriculum and delivery.
Course Structure: The course combines school-based placements with university-based modules.  The majority of the program is dedicated to practical teaching experience in partner schools across the East Midlands.  University components provide a theoretical grounding in key areas such as effective learning, teaching methodologies, educational policy, and subject-specific pedagogy.  The program includes modules such as "What is effective learning?", "How do we all learn, what is our role?", and "How do we plan for and evidence learning?"  Assessment includes two assessed teaching placements, providing practical experience and opportunities for feedback and reflection.  Academic assessment involves three level 7 assignments that connect theory and practice. The program also integrates visits to other schools and opportunities to work with diverse student populations. This fosters insights into various teaching environments and approaches.
Year 1: The first year involves intensive school-based teaching placements in various partnered secondary schools. Students will receive regular feedback on their teaching practice from both experienced school-based mentors and university tutors. The University component integrates theoretical and practical aspects by employing master's level assignments that allow students to critically analyze their classroom experiences. Alongside the practical teaching experience, students will also undertake modules such as 'What is effective learning', 'How do we plan and evidence learning', and engage with current educational policy and research.
Year 2: NA

Course Title: Level 7 Senior Leader Apprenticeship with PG Diploma
Required IELTS Score: NA
Entry Requirement: For the Senior Leader Apprenticeship, employers typically require a recognised bachelor's degree (BA, BSc, or BEng) or equivalent, plus management experience.  The University of Derby works with employers on their specific selection criteria.  For Pakistani applicants, a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised University in Pakistan, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree, is typically required.  Those with two or three-year Bachelor degrees may need a Master's degree pass.  A four-year Bachelor's degree with honours (minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00) from a recognised Pakistani University may also be sufficient for Master's entry.  The apprenticeship also requires current employment of at least 30 hours per week, with the employer covering apprenticeship costs.  The employer must agree that the apprentice is performing at or above the required level;  the apprentice also must achieve English and Maths at Level 2 or higher, and  develop and have the EPAO sign off their strategic business proposal. The apprentice must also hold a portfolio to evidence achievement of KSB’s.
Annual Tuition Fee: £14,000 (employer-funded, with potential government subsidies for SMEs reducing costs to under £800)
Overview: The Senior Leader Apprenticeship is a Level 7 program designed to develop confident and informed business leaders.  It offers in-depth personal and professional development, encompassing a broad range of business management topics such as organizational strategy, financial performance, operations management, and customer value delivery.  The program blends on-campus learning with real-world workplace application. Apprentices gain contemporary knowledge in strategic management and leadership, contribute to their businesses while learning, and develop crucial leadership capabilities including critical analysis, innovation, corporate social responsibility, and employee engagement,  Apprentices may be eligible for both an apprenticeship certificate and a Postgraduate Diploma in Management, which forms the first two stages of a University of Derby MBA.  The program is designed to transform apprentices into effective and well-rounded business leaders.
Course Structure: The apprenticeship curriculum integrates on-campus and workplace learning.  It starts with an initial assessment (including a skills scan) to inform individual learning plans.  An induction program prepares apprentices for Level 7 study, covering relevant processes and procedures. The Postgraduate Certificate includes modules on HRM, information systems, business research methods, the sustainable global business environment, marketing, and governance and risk. The Postgraduate Diploma (optional) builds on this with modules on improving supply chain operations, strategic and financial performance management, and critical perspectives in strategic leadership.  Successful completion requires passing the End-Point Assessment (EPA) after meeting the EPA Gateway requirements.
Year 1: The first year of the Senior Leader Apprenticeship focuses on foundational business management principles and practices.  Modules such as Understanding HRM, Information Systems for Sustaining Competitive Advantage, Introduction to Business Research Methods and Data Analysis, The Sustainable Global Business Environment, Marketing in Organisations, and Governance and Risk are covered, providing a solid base in core business functions and strategic thinking. There is a strong emphasis on applying learned knowledge to real-world workplace situations through real work activities.  The year culminates in the successful completion of the Postgraduate Certificate.
Year 2: The second year of the program deepens the learning with a focus on strategic leadership and operational efficiency.  Modules such as Improving Supply Chain and Logistics Operations, Strategic and Financial Performance Management, and Critical Perspectives in Strategic Leadership and Management are undertaken. These subjects cover a broader range of business-related subjects with a focus on the practical application of leadership principles within real-world business contexts.  This year culminates in the completion of the Postgraduate Diploma (optional) and the End-Point Assessment (EPA).

Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with 5.5 in each skills area
Entry Requirement: For this MRes program, applicants must submit a 1000-word research proposal outlining their research topic, questions, rationale, methodology, and ethical considerations.  If English is not their first language, they need an IELTS score of 6.5 with at least 5.5 in each band.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized university is required, equivalent to at least a UK Upper Second Class (2:1) or Lower Second Class (2:2) Honours degree. Those with a two or three-year Bachelor's degree need a Master's degree pass. A four-year Bachelor's degree with honours (minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00) from a recognized Pakistani university is also sufficient.
Location/Campus: One Friar Gate Square, Derby Campus
Annual Tuition Fee: £9,720 (Full-time) / £1,080 per 20 credits (Part-time) UK Students; £16,900 (Full-time) International Students
Overview: The University of Derby's MRes in Social Sciences and Humanities is a postgraduate research degree offering a flexible approach to developing advanced research and analytical skills. Students can specialize in Social Research, Criminal Psychology, Humanities, or Journalism. The program emphasizes interdisciplinary learning, drawing on best practices from across the social sciences and humanities.  It combines taught modules on research philosophy, methodology, and subject-specific areas with an independent research project culminating in a 20,000-word thesis. The course is designed to equip students with a strong foundation in research methods, critical thinking, data analysis, and communication for career advancement in academia or various professional sectors. Students benefit from a supportive community, expert supervision, and opportunities for collaboration with University staff and external stakeholders.
Course Structure: The MRes program is structured around a series of modules and a substantial independent research project.  It begins with modules covering research philosophy and methodology, introducing key theoretical approaches to social sciences and humanities and the construction of research from diverse conceptual foundations. Students then select a subject pathway (Social Research, Criminal Psychology, Humanities, or Journalism) and undertake relevant modules and masterclasses, developing expertise in various research methods (qualitative, quantitative, archival).  A 'Personal Development for Researchers' module addresses essential professional skills like research communication, project planning, funding acquisition, and impact assessment. This culminates in an independent research project, involving a literature review and original research leading to a 20,000-word thesis and conference presentation.
Year 1: The first year of the full-time MRes program involves modules in Research Philosophy and Methodology, subject-specific introductions (Social Research, Criminal Psychology, Humanities, or Journalism), Introduction to Research Methods, and Advanced Research Methods (with specialized masterclasses).  The Personal Development for Researchers module equips them with valuable professional skills. The year culminates with the commencement of the substantial independent research project, involving a literature review and the beginning of original research.
Year 2: NA

Required IELTS Score: Overall: 7.0, minimum 6.5 in each skills area
Entry Requirement: Applicants require a minimum 2:1 honours degree (or international equivalent) and GCSE grade C or above in English and Maths.  A written test is also mandatory. Non-UK applicants need an IELTS score of 7.0 overall with at least 6.5 in each skill.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognised university, equivalent to a UK Upper Second Class (2:1) or Lower Second Class (2:2), is required.  Those with a two or three-year Bachelor's degree also need a Master's degree. A four-year Bachelor's degree with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani university is acceptable. The application must demonstrate understanding of UK social worker roles, relevant social care experience (paid or unpaid), relevant experience in the Professional Capabilities Framework domains, and the ability to utilize basic IT facilities. A health check and DBS check are also required.
Overview: The University of Derby's MA Social Work program is a two-year, full-time course designed to equip students with the necessary skills and knowledge to become qualified social workers.  The curriculum integrates theory and practice, with a significant emphasis on practical experience through 170 days of placements across two stages. The program covers a wide range of social work topics, including social work law, contemporary issues, safeguarding adults and children, and independent study. Students will develop essential skills in assessment, problem-solving, partnership building, working with diverse populations, and ethical practice within the social care sector. Upon completion, graduates will be prepared for diverse careers within the field, such as providing support to vulnerable populations including children and adults, or specializing in areas such as youth justice or mental health.
Course Structure: The MA Social Work program is structured across two years. Year one focuses on building the foundation of social work theories, knowledge, and skills.  Students will learn about preparation for practice learning, contemporary issues in social work, and relevant social work law.  A substantial portion of the year is dedicated to practical experience in a placement setting. Year two builds upon these foundations, further refining practical and reflective skills in a second, extended placement. This year also involves modules on safeguarding, and culminates in an independent research project.  The curriculum is regularly reviewed and updated to align with the evolving needs of the health and social care sector and national policy changes.
Year 1: The first year of the MA Social Work program lays the groundwork for future practice.  Key modules include 'Preparation for Practice Learning', focusing on essential skills and knowledge needed for the profession; 'Contemporary Issues in Social Work,' examining current issues and challenges; and 'Social Work Law,' providing a thorough understanding of relevant legal frameworks. Finally, 'Practice Learning One' provides 80 days of hands-on work placement experience.
Year 2: Building on the foundation established in the first year, the second year of the MA Social Work program emphasizes deepening practical skills and applying theoretical knowledge.  The curriculum covers 'Safeguarding Adults' and 'Protecting and Safeguarding Children and Young People', modules addressing critical aspects of social work practice. The program also includes 'Independent Study,' which encourages scholarly research and practice application. This year includes a 90-day placement period, 'Practice Learning Two', providing extensive firsthand work experience, making students job-ready upon graduation.

Course Title: Undergraduate Sociology and Early Childhood Studies BA (Hons)
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 112 UCAS points, A-levels BBC, T-level Merit, BTEC DMM, GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or equivalent.  Access to HE Diploma with 60 credits (45 at Level 3) is also accepted.  Contextual offers may be available for care experienced students, those estranged from their families, refugees, asylum seekers, or those whose parents/carers are in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or IB from International Schools in Pakistan, entry to Year 1 is possible. For postgraduate study, a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2 is required; students with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees need a Master's degree as well. A four-year Bachelor's degree with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university is acceptable for Masters programs. PhD applicants need a Master's and Bachelor's degree in a relevant subject area. A research proposal is necessary for PhD admission.
Annual Tuition Fee: UK: £9,535 per year; International: £16,900 per year
Overview: The Sociology and Early Childhood Studies BA (Hons) Joint Honours degree at the University of Derby offers a combined study of social structures and the development of young children.  Students explore how societal factors influence early childhood and learn about advocacy, sustainability, and agency within this context.  The program blends theoretical knowledge with practical application, offering placement opportunities within various settings. It prepares graduates for roles in diverse professional services touching upon health, education, and social care, fostering critical thinking, analytical skills, and impactful intervention skills needed to address societal issues and promote social justice. Students can choose to major or minor in one subject or maintain an equal study split across both.
Course Structure: The course structure allows students to study both Sociology and Early Childhood Studies equally in the first year, followed by a choice to major or minor in one subject or continue studying both equally in the second and third years. Modules vary depending on each specialization, and students should utilize the provided email address for the most up-to-date subject options. Teaching methods involve lectures, seminars, multimedia presentations, online collaborations, guest lectures, debates, and tutorials, including placement experience options for Early Childhood Studies.  Assessment methods differ for each subject but may include essays, case studies, project work, presentations, online discussions, independent research, online tests, and reports. Exams are not included.
Year 1: The first year involves an equal study of both Sociology and Early Childhood Studies.  Students are introduced to core concepts in sociology, such as social theory, research methods, and social justice issues. In Early Childhood Studies, they will develop a foundation in child development, educational practices and the holistic care provided to children under the age of eight within different settings.
Year 2: In the second year, students either continue studying both Sociology and Early Childhood Studies equally, or choose to have one as a major and the other as a minor.  Sociology modules might delve deeper into specific areas such as social inequality, social deviance, or political sociology, while Early Childhood Studies will branch out into specialized areas such as curriculum development, inclusive education, or child psychology. Students may also start their placement during this year.
Year 3: In their final year, students continue with their chosen major and minor, or continue studying both subjects equally, building on the knowledge from previous years. Students further develop their research and analytical skills, for example, learning to conduct their own research project.  The emphasis on applying theoretical knowledge to real-world scenarios is carried forward. Early Years students will gain extensive practical experience and build their final project, likely placing them in an early-years related professional setting.

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 112 UCAS points, A Levels BBC, T Level Merit, BTEC DMM, GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or above, or a Pass Access to HE Diploma with 60 credits (45 at Level 3). Contextual offers may apply to care experienced students, those estranged from their families, refugees, asylum seekers, or those whose parents are in the UK armed forces.  International students may need to meet additional English language requirements.  For Pakistani students, A-levels or IB from Pakistani International Schools allow entry into year one. For postgraduate studies, a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK Upper or Lower Second Class degree is needed.  A Master's degree may be required if the Bachelor's degree was two or three years long. A four-year Bachelor's degree with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university is considered for Master's entry. PhD applicants need a Master's and Bachelor's degree in relevant subjects and must submit a research proposal.
Overview: The University of Derby offers a three-year Bachelor of Arts (Hons) in Sociology and Economics, a joint honors program allowing students to explore sociological themes through the lens of economic theory.  The course develops quantitative and qualitative analytical skills applicable to various sectors.  Students can choose to major in Sociology or Economics or study both equally, providing flexibility and tailoring to individual career aspirations. The program features a range of teaching methods, including guest lectures, projects, and the option of a placement year to gain valuable work experience.  Graduates will be prepared for roles in business, public, and voluntary sectors, possessing strong analytical, critical thinking, and problem-solving skills.
Course Structure: The course combines modules in both Sociology and Economics.  In year one, students study both subjects equally.  Subsequently, they can choose to major in one subject or continue with an equal balance.  Sociology modules cover social interaction, societal dynamics, and developing skills for positive social change.  Economics modules focus on applying economic theory, using software like Bloomberg and SPSS for real-world business problem-solving. Assessment methods vary and include essays, case studies, projects, presentations, and computer-based assessments, reflecting various skills.
Year 1: The first year involves an equal balance between Sociology and Economics.  Students are introduced to core concepts in both fields, building a foundation in sociological theory and economic principles.  Introductory modules cover topics such as social structures, economic systems, microeconomics, and macroeconomics.  Students start developing their analytical and research skills through assignments and group work.
Year 2: In the second year, students can choose to major in either Sociology or Economics or maintain equal study in both.  Specialized modules become available and students delve further into their chosen subjects. This year has the optional placement year. For Sociology this could include modules on social inequality, research methodologies, and social policy, while Economics modules may focus on econometrics, financial markets, and international trade.
Year 3: The third year provides further specialization and builds on the knowledge acquired during previous years. This might involve more advanced research methods, specialized topics in sociology or economics, a dissertation or capstone project, depending on your pathway. You may have modules on topics such as globalization, sustainability, behavioral economics, or social change.

Course Title: BA (Hons) Sociology and English Joint Honours
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical requirements include 112 UCAS points.  A-Level students need BBC grades (including at least a C in English or a related subject), while those with BTECs need DMM.  T-Level applicants require a Merit grade. GCSE Maths and English grades of 4/C or higher are also needed.  Access to HE Diploma applicants must pass with 60 credits (45 at Level 3, including at least Distinction 15, Merit 24, and Pass 6).  Contextual offers may be available for care experienced students, those estranged from their families, refugees, asylum seekers, and students whose parents/carers are in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or the IB from international schools in Pakistan, direct entry into Year 1 is possible. Postgraduate entry requirements for Pakistani students vary depending on the type of degree held, focusing on GPA requirements as well as the level of the degree and the associated requirements for entry into higher degrees.
Annual Tuition Fee: UK: £9,535 per year (2025/26); International: £16,900 per year (2025/26)
Overview: The BA (Hons) Sociology and English Joint Honours program at the University of Derby offers a comprehensive exploration of the human experience through sociological and literary lenses. Students examine how social and linguistic structures shape lives, exploring themes like social justice, power dynamics, globalization, and self-expression.  The English component delves into critical and cultural theory, fostering sophisticated analysis of literature, language, and culture. Students choose to either major in one subject or study both equally after the first year. Experienced researchers with expertise in fields such as Romanticism, social policy, and extremism teach the course. The program aims to cultivate confident, articulate graduates equipped for diverse professional paths.
Course Structure: The course structure involves modules in Sociology and English, with the specific modules varying depending on whether a student chooses to study both subjects equally or major in one.   In the first year, both subjects are studied equally before students make their decision. Students are assessed through various methods, including coursework, presentations, seminar participation, online tasks, projects, and assignments. Formative assessments like essay plans and online tests help prepare students for main assessments.  The curriculum incorporates  the study of art, film, philosophy, linguistics, and sociology within contemporary politics, providing a holistic understanding of the human experience through literature and social sciences.
Year 1: The first year provides an equal introduction to both Sociology and English. In Sociology, students will likely cover foundational concepts, theories, and research methods, exploring aspects of social structure, inequality, and social change. The English component will introduce key literary movements and theoretical frameworks, analyzing different genres and literary techniques. Students will engage with fundamental concepts of literary criticism and cultural theory, exploring a range of texts from varied historical periods and geographical locations.  This year serves as a foundation, allowing students to explore both subjects further as they progress.
Year 2: In the second year, students will delve deeper into their chosen area of focus, whether equally specializing in both subjects or majoring in one subject. This year will involve specialized modules, allowing them to build on the foundation from year one.  For those majoring in Sociology, there will be advanced courses in research methods, relevant social theories, and specialized aspects of sociology that the student has already shown interest in. Students majoring in English will engage in advanced literary analysis and in-depth study of specific authors or genres. Modules could include critical theory, post-colonial studies, and the history of language. Those studying both equally will be able to continue to work at these topics in more depth moving forward into their final year, as well as to add in other topics of study from both of their chosen fields.
Year 3: The final year builds on the knowledge and skills acquired across the previous two.  For students specializing in Sociology, this year may involve a dissertation or extended research project, applying the research methods and theories to a chosen topic. They may also take modules of advanced sociological study or take elective courses. Similarly, English majors may conclude with a dissertation or advanced project, delving into a specialized area of literary study. They will often engage with practical skills such as conference and paper presentation, giving them insight into the world of work and academic research. Students who are studying both equally will have further flexibility in the modules they choose, allowing them to fully develop the skillset in relation to their chosen field.

Course Title: BA (Hons) Sociology and Human Resource Management
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 112 UCAS points, A-Levels BBC, T Level Merit, BTEC DMM, GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or above, or an Access to HE Diploma with 60 credits (45 at Level 3).  International students should check specific requirements.  Contextual offers may be available for students who meet specified criteria, such as those who are care experienced, estranged from their families, refugees, asylum seekers, or whose parents/carers  are in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistani students, A-levels or IB from International Schools allow entry to the first year. Postgraduate entry requires a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2, or with honors and GPA of 2.4/4.0 from a recognised University. A Master's degree may be required for two- or three-year Bachelor degrees.  PhD applicants need a Master's and Bachelor's in relevant subjects, and a research proposal.
Location/Campus: Kedleston Road and One Friar Gate Square, Derby Campus
Overview: The Sociology and Human Resource Management BA (Hons) is a joint honors degree that offers students a combined approach to understanding social structures and organizational behavior.  The program allows students to explore how societal forces impact businesses and the management of people. Students will study both sociology and human resource management equally in their first year, before choosing whether to major or minor in one subject or continue with equal study in subsequent years. The course includes a wide array of teaching methods, including lectures, seminars, group work, case studies, and practical projects, with an emphasis on real-world application. It also provides opportunities for work placements or study abroad.  The program aims to develop critical thinking, analytical, and problem-solving skills and equip graduates for careers across several fields.
Course Structure: The course comprises modules in both sociology and human resource management.  In year one, students study both subjects equivalently. Then, they choose to specialize by majoring or minoring in one subject or continuing an equal split for years two and three. Teaching methods are diverse and include lectures, seminars, multimedia presentations, online collaboration, guest lectures, class debates, tutorials, and work experience projects. Assessment methods are equally varied and include essays, case studies, project work, group presentations, and computer-based assessments. The program emphasizes real-world learning and interaction with real businesses.
Year 1: The first year involves an equal split between sociology and human resource management modules. Students will be introduced to core concepts in both subjects for a broader understanding.  The program will incorporate foundational knowledge of sociological theory, research method, and practical aspects of human resource management including recruitment and selection, reward management, and employee relations. The year will emphasize developing key skills such as critical analysis and teamwork to prepare for advanced modules in later years.
Year 2: The second year allows students to specialize. If they chose to major in sociology, they focus more deeply on advanced sociological concepts and may engage in research projects aligned with their chosen interests. If focusing on human resource management, the emphasis will be on more advanced techniques, strategies and professional development. Regardless of their choice, they will continue to incorporate elements of the complementary subject, depending on their selected major or minor focus (or continued equal study).

The curriculum balances theoretical learning with practical experiences through field trips, work placements, and a potential semester abroad at Charles University in Prague. Year 1: The first year introduces foundational sociological concepts, theories, and research methods. Overview: The Sociology with Foundation Year BA (Hons) is a four-year undergraduate program at the University of Derby.  The course is designed to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of sociological theories and their application to real-world issues. Students explore key themes such as crime and justice, youth cultures, politics and social justice, and security and terrorism, with the option to specialize in a combination of these areas. The curriculum emphasizes critical thinking, ethical considerations, and international perspectives, offering opportunities for study abroad in Prague and field trips. The program focuses on developing research skills through hands-on projects and fieldwork, preparing students for diverse career paths.
Course Structure:
The course is structured around four years. The foundation year strengthens skills and builds confidence before progressing to the main degree.  The subsequent years cover core and optional subjects delving into sociological theories and their application to topics like social inequality, race and ethnicity, gender and sexuality, globalization, the digital era, childhood and youth, celebrity culture, social movements, and conspiracy theories. Students engage in lectures, seminars, multimedia presentations, online collaboration, guest lectures, and class debates. Assessment includes essays, case studies, project work, presentations, and online discussions. A year-long placement opportunity is available after the second year.
The program emphasizes hands-on and real-world learning complemented by expert teaching from experienced researchers. Regular guest lectures and departmental seminars are also part of the curriculum.  A study trip to Prague is offered and fieldtrips enhance learning.  A personal academic tutor provides guidance throughout.
Year 1: The first year, for students taking the Foundation Year, focuses on building core skills and knowledge necessary for undergraduate study in sociology. This includes an introduction to key sociological concepts, theories and research methods.  The curriculum will cover fundamental aspects of social science, with modules designed to prepare students for the challenges of university-level work.  Students enhance their academic writing, research skills, study techniques and gain confidence in their abilities to manage academic study.
Year 2: Year 2 delves deeper into core sociological theories and concepts. It allows students to begin specializing in areas that interest them, such as crime and deviance, social inequalities, or media and culture. Students will develop advanced research skills, including data analysis and qualitative research techniques, perhaps through the study of an important current social issue or sociological theme. Students who perform well on coursework may gain opportunities for internships or work placements for the following year.
Year 3: Year 3 provides advanced coursework in chosen specializations within sociology.  Students undertake a substantial research project, possibly incorporating fieldwork or data analysis, demonstrating their understanding of sociological research methods and their ability to analyze and interpret complex data.  This year might include a study-abroad semester of exchange in Prague and/or a work placement module, offering practical experience in a relevant field, and enhancing the curriculum with international experience.
Year 4: The final year builds on previous learning,  culminating in a significant independent research project. This allows students to apply their acquired knowledge and skills to a specialized area of sociological interest.  Other modules might focus on contemporary sociological debates, advanced research methods or career development skills. The year brings together a wide range of skills and knowledge, demonstrating their understanding of the subject and preparing them for career opportunities.

Overview: The BSc (Hons) Sound, Light and Live Event Engineering degree at the University of Derby is a highly practical course designed to prepare students for technical careers in the live events industry.  The program focuses on the technical aspects of electronics, computer and software systems, acoustics, and sound technology, combined with practical experience in planning and executing live events. Students will gain hands-on experience using industry-standard equipment in state-of-the-art facilities, including a hemi-anechoic chamber, auditorium, and various specialized labs. The curriculum emphasizes real-world application, with opportunities for work placements, guest lectures from industry professionals, and collaborations on live events ranging from festivals to corporate functions.  Graduates will possess multi-disciplinary skills including technology, design, project management, and health and safety knowledge.

Students will learn both the theoretical underpinnings and practical applications of these technologies through hands-on projects and the planning and delivery of actual live events.  The curriculum integrates industry links through guest speakers, site visits, and collaborations with companies like Solotech, d&b audiotechnik, Disney, and Meyer Sound.  An optional industrial year is also available.  Assessment is varied, including laboratory exercises, written reports, exams, group projects, and evaluations of managed events.

Year 3: The final year focuses on advanced topics and specialized areas within sound, light, and live event engineering.  Students will undertake a major project, often involving the planning and execution of a large-scale event, showcasing their skills and knowledge. They'll also likely develop specialized expertise in a chosen area of interest, refine their technical skills, and engage in extensive practical work.

Course Title: MSc Specialist Community Public Health Nursing (Health Visiting or School Nursing)
Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with a minimum of 5.5 in all areas
Entry Requirement: This course is for NMC registered nurses who want to gain a professional qualification in health visiting, occupational health nursing, or school nursing.  A Diploma or Advanced Diploma in nursing studies allows degree-level study to top up qualifications.  Applicants must hold a current nurse or midwife qualification with NMC registration, a 1:1 or 2:1 degree (120 credits or equivalent), a student Health Visitor/Occupational Health Nurse/School Nurse position from a seconding/sponsoring organization, and at least one year's post-registration experience (two years for V300 non-medical prescribing).  Employers are responsible for DBS and health checks.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized university (equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2) is required.  A Master's degree is needed for two or three-year Bachelor's degrees. A four-year Bachelor's degree with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 would be considered.

Annual Tuition Fee: £712 per 20 credits (Part-time); £6,408 for the full course (Full-time)
Overview: The University of Derby's MSc in Specialist Community Public Health Nursing is a postgraduate program designed for registered nurses seeking to specialize in health visiting, school nursing, or occupational health nursing.  The curriculum focuses on developing advanced clinical skills, leadership capabilities, and public health knowledge. Students will learn to assess and address the health needs of diverse communities. The program integrates theoretical learning with significant practical placement experiences. It equips graduates with the competencies required by the Nursing and Midwifery Council (NMC) for registration as specialist community public health nurses. Course Structure: The program involves modules covering specialism introduction and clinical practice, public health community education, innovation, leadership and team development, research-based practice, mental health across the lifespan, and condition management fundamentals in adults (relevant for the Occupational Health Nursing pathway).  There's a focus on specialist skills for vulnerable people within family contexts (School Nursing or Health Visiting) pathway.  To achieve the full MSc, students complete an additional research-based 'Independent Scholarship' module.  Teaching methods include role modeling, exposure to evidence-based practice, group discussions, presentations, lectures, and action learning sets.  Assessment includes exams, observations, assignments, presentations, a practice portfolio, and placement assessment.
Year 1: The first year focuses on building a foundation in community public health nursing specialism. Key modules include an introduction to the chosen specialism (Health Visiting, Occupational Health Nursing, or School Nursing), public health principles and strategies, innovative leadership and team building, and research methodologies. Students also gain substantial hands-on experience through a significant clinical placement alongside their studies.  The year culminates in the consolidation of specialized knowledge and skills in preparation for the final year of study and future practice.

Overview: The FdA Special Educational Needs and Disabilities course is a part-time program designed for professionals working with children and young people with special educational needs and disabilities (SEND). Developed with employers, it aims to enhance practitioners' skills and knowledge to improve outcomes for students. The course blends theoretical learning with practical application, and assessments are based on work-based activities, presentations, essays, and portfolios, with no exams.  The curriculum focuses on developing the skills and competencies needed for inclusive and effective work with SEND children and their families. Students will specialize in areas relevant to their work and interests, progressing to become confident, knowledgeable practitioners.
Course Structure: The curriculum is designed to provide a comprehensive understanding of SEND while allowing for specialization based on individual professional contexts and interests.  Although specific module details are subject to change and can be reviewed regularly to improve the student experience and graduate prospects, students can expect modules related to inclusive teaching strategies, special educational needs legislation, assessment methods, effective communication and collaboration with families. The program emphasizes reflective practice, encouraging students to critically evaluate their work and identify areas for improvement. Individualized support is provided through a Personal Academic Tutoring (PAT) program. There are no traditional exams but a variety of assessment methods focusing on practical application within the students area of focus.
Year 1: NA
Year 2: NA

Course Title: BA (Hons) Special Educational Needs and Disability (Top-Up)
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: To be eligible for this top-up BA (Hons) in Special Educational Needs and Disability, applicants must have a foundation degree with grades above 50% and 240 credits.  Additionally, they need at least five GCSEs (or equivalent) including Maths and English at grade 4/C or above.  For Pakistani students, entry requirements vary:  If completing A-levels or the International Baccalaureate from an international school in Pakistan, entry to the first year is possible. If holding a four-year Bachelor's degree with honours (BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University, entry may be granted. Students with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees require a Master's degree pass for admission.
Overview: The University of Derby's BA (Hons) Special Educational Needs and Disability (Top-Up) is a one-year (full-time) or two-year (part-time) program designed to equip students with the knowledge and skills to support individuals with special educational needs and disabilities (SEND). The course covers various aspects of SEND, including theories, factors, and contexts.  Students learn about the psychological, sociological, philosophical, and biological causes of SEND and the importance of multi-agency support.  The program emphasizes collaboration among professionals and features a range of teaching methods, including small group work, presentations, and coursework. It also includes optional modules to cater to individual interests.  Upon completion, graduates are prepared for various roles within the SEND sector. The University guarantees an interview for its PGCE Primary program to graduates who meet the necessary requirements.
Course Structure: The course involves a combination of lectures, seminars, group work, and individual study.  Assessment is entirely coursework-based, with no exams.  Modules cover in-depth understanding of SEND, exploring its various aspects, including psychological, sociological, philosophical, and biological causes. Students learn about multi-agency support and collaboration, understanding the roles of different professionals involved in SEND support. Optional modules allow students to focus on specific areas of interest, such as autism, attention disorders, or communication and language development. The program aims to provide applied knowledge and practical skills for a rewarding career in SEND.
Year 1: The first year of the Special Education Needs and Disability (Top-Up) BA (Hons) program focuses on building a comprehensive understanding of special educational needs and disabilities (SEND).  Students explore theoretical frameworks, factors influencing SEND, and relevant contexts. Key areas include different types of disabilities, including specific learning difficulties, physical disabilities, and sensory impairments. Students learn about effective support strategies and the collaboration required among professionals, such as teachers, therapists, and social workers. They also delve into the psychological, sociological, philosophical, and biological perspectives of SEND. There will be a focus on applying theory to practical scenarios through case studies and group discussions.  The year concludes with an assessment of students understanding which may include case study analysis or essays.
Year 2: NA

Course Title: BA (Hons) Special Educational Needs and Disability (Top-Up)
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with 5.5 in each skills test)
Entry Requirement: This top-up program requires an HND or Foundation Degree in a relevant subject (equivalent of 240 credits).  Alternatively, significant work and life experience may be considered, requiring at least 60 credits at both level 4 and 5 in a relevant subject.  If English is not your first language, you need an IELTS score of 6.0 (with 5.5 in each skill) or equivalent qualifications like Cambridge English Scale: B2,  International GCE O-Level English Language: Grade C, etc.  For Pakistani students, entry requirements depend on their prior qualifications.  Those with A-levels or IB from Pakistani international schools can enter directly. Students with a relevant bachelor's degree from a recognized Pakistani university equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2 can apply.  A master's degree might be required alongside a two or three-year bachelor's degree. Four-year bachelor's degree holders with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized university may also be eligible.
Overview: The University of Derby's Special Educational Needs and Disability (SEND) Top-Up BA (Hons) is an online program designed for individuals already working or intending to work in SEND settings who possess a level 5 qualification.  The course aims to deepen critical knowledge, skills, and application in understanding the diverse and inclusive aspects of SEND. It's structured to provide a cohesive focus on key issues and debates relating to SEND from a multidisciplinary perspective.  The curriculum explores how SEND impacts children, young people, and adults, equipping professionals with the skills and knowledge to meet diverse needs. The program emphasizes practical application, including modules focusing on profound and multiple learning difficulties, autism, and the importance of identity and lived experience.  Students develop skills for working with individuals with diverse needs in education, social care, and health settings. The program integrates personal development planning (PDP) and includes opportunities for collaborative learning.
Course Structure: The program consists of five modules totaling 120 credits. Four modules are 20 credits each, and one is 40 credits. The specific module order will be provided upon enrollment, subject to change to improve student experience and graduate prospects.  Modules are taught by expert academics working as SEND professionals, ensuring up-to-date and relevant content.  Teaching is entirely online, utilizing a student portal, digital learning environment, virtual classrooms, tutorials, guest lectures, forums, and collaborative tools.  Digital resources are available through the university library. Assessment is 100% coursework-based, incorporating methods such as essays, case studies, micro-teaching evaluation, oral presentations, and multimedia product creation, reflecting complexities surrounding SEND and fostering authentic learning.
Year 1: Year 1 (if studying at the standard pace) will cover core modules focusing on the theoretical and practical aspects of SEND, including an introduction to key legislation, policies, and practices related to supporting individuals with diverse needs.  Students will explore various perspectives on SEND and gain experience in applying relevant theories to practice through a range of assessment methods.  The curriculum may include modules focusing on specific needs, such as learning difficulties, autism, and communication disorders. Students also begin their personal development planning.
Year 2: Year 2 (if studying at the standard pace) builds upon Year 1 by delving deeper into specialized areas within SEND.  Students will undertake more in-depth study of chosen areas based on their individual interests and professional goals.  This could involve specializing in a particular age group or disability type, gaining advanced knowledge in specific areas of practice.   Emphasis will continue to be placed on practical application and the synthesis of theory and practice.  Assessment tasks will be designed to reflect real-world scenarios within the SEND field.  PDP continues, with students creating a comprehensive plan for their career development.

Course Title: BA (Hons) Special Educational Needs and Disability
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2024 entry, typical requirements include 112-120 UCAS points, A Levels (BBB-BBC), T Level (Merit), BTEC (DMM), GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or above, or a Pass Access to HE Diploma.  For 2025 entry, requirements are 104 UCAS points, A Levels (BCC), T Level (Merit), BTEC (DMM), GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or above, or a Pass Access to HE Diploma.  An Enhanced Disclosure & Barring Service certificate is also needed.  Contextual offers may be available for students who are care experienced, estranged from their families, refugees, asylum seekers, or whose parents/carers are in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistani students,  A-levels or IB from Pakistani international schools allow direct entry into year one. Postgraduate entry requires a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2, or a four-year Bachelor's degree with a minimum 2.4/4.00 GPA.  A Master's degree may be needed for students with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees. PhD applicants need a Master's and Bachelor's degree in a relevant subject with a research proposal.
Overview: The BA (Hons) Special Educational Needs and Disability course at the University of Derby provides a comprehensive education in supporting individuals with diverse learning needs.  It focuses on developing practical skills and in-depth theoretical knowledge of SEND (Special Educational Needs and Disability), encompassing various aspects like learning difficulties, physical disabilities, behavioral problems, and sensory impairments. Students will engage with current research, explore contributing factors to SEND, and learn collaborative approaches involving professionals like social workers, SENCOs, and therapists. The program emphasizes real-world learning through placements in diverse settings including schools, hospitals, and social services, offering invaluable practical experience.  Graduates will be prepared for rewarding careers within the SEND sector.
Course Structure: The course is structured across three years (full-time) or up to six years (part-time) and incorporates various teaching and assessment methods.  There are no exams; assessment is through group work, presentations, directed tasks, tutorial discussions, and coursework. A focus on collaborative learning and real-world applications is integrated throughout. The program incorporates two placements, offering students the opportunity to gain experience in different settings. A strong emphasis is placed upon developing a critical understanding of SEND, exploring various theoretical perspectives, and engaging with experts in related fields like education, health, psychology, and social work.  Optional modules allow students to tailor their studies according to their interests and career goals.
Year 1: The first year will lay the foundation for understanding SEND, covering fundamental theories, concepts, and legislation related to special educational needs.  Students will begin to develop practical skills for working with diverse learners, exploring different support strategies and assessment techniques. An introduction to the different types of special needs will be covered early-on, allowing the student to begin learning how to identify the needs of individuals within these categories. Introductory modules on collaborative practice and professional ethics are also likely to be included.
Year 2: The second year builds upon the foundational knowledge gained in Year 1. Students will delve deeper into specific areas of SEND, perhaps specializing in particular learning difficulties or disabilities.  This year will likely incorporate the first placement opportunity, providing invaluable real-world experience in a relevant setting such as a school or support service. The module content may also evolve to include advanced assessment techniques, intervention strategies, and the effective management of challenging behaviors.
Year 3: The final year focuses on developing advanced expertise and preparing students for professional roles.  Students will engage in advanced research methods and critically evaluate different approaches to supporting individuals with SEND. A second placement will afford further opportunity to implement acquired skills and knowledge, furthering their understanding of SEND and allowing them a further opportunity to network and build relevant professional contacts. This year will also feature advanced modules and likely include the opportunity to focus on a specific aspect of special needs based on the student's career interests.

Overview: The University of Derby's Special Educational Needs and Disability (SEND) with Foundation Year BA (Hons) is a four-year undergraduate program designed to prepare students for careers supporting individuals with special learning needs.  The course combines theoretical knowledge with practical experience, providing a comprehensive understanding of SEND across various settings. Students will explore theories, factors, and contexts of SEND, examining psychological, sociological, philosophical, and biological causes.  The curriculum includes two placements in diverse settings such as schools, hospitals, social services, and charitable organizations.  The program emphasizes multi-agency collaboration and the importance of inclusive practices.  Students will develop practical skills useful in roles such as family liaison, inclusion support, teaching assistance, or mentoring.  The foundation year provides additional support for students who wish to strengthen their knowledge before commencing with the primary degree course.
Course Structure: The course structure comprises a foundation year followed by three years of the BA (Hons) program. The foundation year likely focuses on building fundamental skills and knowledge pertinent to SEND.  The subsequent years include in-depth studies of SEND theories, factors, and contexts; practical training via placements in various settings such as schools, hospitals, and social services; coursework assessments; independent study; and presentations. There is a selection of optional modules. Students will also study professional development to include training in areas such as autism, and also have the opportunity to undertake visits to other educational facilities.  The course culminates in graduation with suitable career opportunities.
Year 1: The foundation year focuses on strengthening students’ academic skills, building knowledge, and enhancing confidence, with support from expert staff.  It may include introductory modules covering essential concepts related to special educational needs and disability, educational psychology, and effective teaching strategies.  The aim is to thoroughly prepare students for the rigors of the subsequent BA (Hons) program.
Year 2: This stage delves into a range of SEND topics. Students engage in discussions and debates centered around recent SEND research, exploring the psychological, sociological, philosophical, and biological underpinnings of SEND. Modules may cover different categories of need such as autism, other learning difficulties and communication disorders. Placements in relevant settings will likely begin in this year alongside academic study. Assessments are primarily coursework-based.
Year 3: Year 3 will build on the previous year with more specialist topics. This may include modules on professional practice, child development and inclusive education. Students will further develop their practical skills  through continued placement experiences, gaining valuable hands-on expertise in supporting individuals with diverse needs in various settings.  The emphasis will be on  refining professional skills and preparing for graduation.
Year 4: The final year of study incorporates advanced topics in special educational needs and disability, offering specialized knowledge to prepare graduates for a range of SEND sector roles.  This might include modules focused on professional ethics, leadership, and further practical application of skills. Students undertake a significant final project, which is usually a dissertation.  The overall focus is on career readiness; linking academic attainment with practical experience.

Overview: The University of Derby's BSc (Hons) Sports Nutrition and Health is a three-year undergraduate program designed to equip students with the knowledge and skills necessary for careers in sports nutrition, public health nutrition, and related fields.  The multidisciplinary curriculum integrates psychology, physiology, and biochemistry, providing a comprehensive understanding of nutrition's role in athletic performance and overall health. Students will develop practical skills through hands-on experience, including work placements, laboratory assessments, and the completion of industry-recognized qualifications such as a Level 2 Gym Instructor and Level 3 Personal Trainer Award. The program emphasizes both theoretical learning and the development of essential transferable skills, including communication, problem-solving, and data analysis.  Graduates will be prepared for a variety of roles within the health and fitness sector, impacting the lives of both elite athletes and members of the general public. The course content is aligned with the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals.
Course Structure: The course structure integrates theoretical and practical elements.  Students engage in lectures, seminars, practical sessions using specialist equipment (nutritional and physiology testing, cardiometabolic health assessments), and technology-enhanced learning. Work-based learning is a core component, with placements offered at organizations such as local sports clubs and community health initiatives.  The curriculum covers human responses to sport and exercise, performance enhancement, health-related aspects of exercise, the social impact of sport, and sport policy.  Students have the opportunity to gain additional qualifications such as a Level 2 Food Hygiene Certificate and the UK Anti-Doping Introduction to Clean Sport course.  The program culminates in an independent dissertation.
Year 1: The first year lays the foundation in sports nutrition, human physiology, and relevant psychological principles. Students begin building practical skills in areas such as nutritional assessment and exercise prescription.  Introduction to research methods and data analysis is likely also a key element. Students might also start exploring the social and ethical implications of sport and exercise. Initial work placement opportunities might be introduced towards the end of the year.
Year 2: Year two deepens the understanding of the theoretical frameworks established in Year 1. Students will engage in modules exploring topics such as advanced nutrition for athletic performance, exercise physiology in specific populations, and nutrition and diseases. Practical experience increases through more extensive work placements and potential involvement in research projects. Continued development of data analysis and research writing skills is expected. The second year frequently includes further professional qualification development.
Year 3: The final year focuses on advanced topics and specialized areas within sports and exercise nutrition.  A major component is the independent dissertation, requiring students to conduct and present original research within their field.  Specialized modules may offer a focus on areas like clinical nutrition, community health, or specific sport-related nutritional interventions. The final year typically includes a significant work placement, providing valuable real-world experience in a chosen field and giving students portfolio-building opportunities.

Overview: The University of Derby's BSc (Hons) Sports Nutrition and Health with Foundation Year is a four-year undergraduate program designed to equip students with the knowledge and skills necessary for careers in sports nutrition, health promotion, and related fields. The course integrates theoretical learning with practical experience, including work placements and industry-relevant qualifications such as a Level 2 gym instructor qualification and a Level 3 personal training qualification. Students will explore the psychology, physiology, and biochemistry of nutrition, and gain expertise in performance analysis, biomechanics, strength and conditioning, and injury prevention.  The curriculum is aligned with the UN Sustainable Development Goals and is developed in collaboration with Derby City Council. Graduates will be proficient in various areas such as human responses to exercise, performance enhancement, health-related exercise, and the sociological aspects of sport.
Course Structure: The course covers a multidisciplinary approach to sports nutrition and health, integrating several aspects. Students will gain a comprehensive understanding of human physiology, athletic performance, sports nutrition, and related health topics.  The program includes a foundation year, followed by three years of academic coursework.   The curriculum includes theoretical modules in sports nutrition, human physiology, and exercise science with practical modules encompassing laboratory-based assessments, practical sessions, and work placements. Students gain practical expertise through various assessments like presentations, case studies, and dissertations, alongside obtaining additional qualifications like gym instructor and personal training certifications. The coursework is designed to develop both technical and transferable skills including research, analysis, communication, and problem-solving capacity, as well as personal and professional development. The programme also involves guest lectures from industry experts to give industry insights, increase networking opportunities and help students make informed career choices.
Year 1: The foundation year focuses on building a strong academic base across key areas relevant to sports nutrition and health. It strengthens students' skills, knowledge, and confidence, preparing them for the more advanced modules of the degree. This year may comprise fundamental introductions to biology, chemistry, sociology, psychology, and introductory aspects of nutrition and exercise physiology.
Year 2: Year two introduces core concepts in sports nutrition. Students start learning the principles of exercise physiology, the science of nutrition, and their applications in sports performance. It likely delves into macronutrients, micronutrients, dietary plans for athletes, hydration, and supplementation; alongside practical sessions covering nutritional assessment and performance monitoring techniques.
Year 3: This year deepens the student's understanding of health-related issues and disease, emphasizing the impact of sports and exercise in disease management. Students may study specialist topics such as weight management, disordered eating, and exercise referral.  Practical skills develop further with hands-on experience in laboratory settings and likely involve modules on research methodology and statistical analysis.
Year 4: The final year is dedicated to advanced study, individual research, and practical placements.  Students often undertake a dissertation project, potentially focusing on areas such as performance nutrition, injury rehabilitation, or public health initiatives. As well as further developing essential skills including critical analysis, presentations, and report writing.  A significant amount of this year involves professional placements, exposing them to real-world application in various settings.

Overview:
The University of Derby's BSc (Hons) Sport and Exercise Science degree provides a comprehensive education in the scientific principles underpinning sport and exercise.  Students gain a strong foundation in biomechanics, physiology, and psychology, applying this knowledge to enhance athletic performance and health. The curriculum allows for specialization in areas such as nutrition, injury rehabilitation, and strength and conditioning. The program integrates practical experience through work placements with organizations like Derby County FC and Derbyshire County Cricket Club, internships, and opportunities to gain additional qualifications like coaching awards.

The course emphasizes professional development, preparing graduates for diverse career paths.  Students benefit from expert teaching from accredited professionals, access to state-of-the-art facilities including a biomechanics laboratory and a strength and conditioning suite, research opportunities within the Human Performance Unit, and support through a Personal Academic Tutoring program.   The degree is accredited by the British Association of Sport and Exercise Sciences (BASES), guaranteeing high teaching standards and providing access to numerous benefits and networking opportunities.
Course Structure: The program's structure combines theoretical and practical learning. It begins with building a foundation in core areas like biomechanics, physiology, and psychology that pertain to athletic performance and health improvement. As students progress, they apply this fundamental understanding.  Students select a preferred career path, creating individualized educational plans within specialist subject-matter sectors.  Students engage in activities like internships alongside academic studies.  In year two, a mandatory work placement helps to establish professional networks and develop employable skills.  Assessment methods include a mixture of practical assessments in specialized facilities, written work, presentations, and examinations.
Year 1: Year one focuses on establishing a firm foundation in the core subjects of sport and exercise science.  This includes modules covering the anatomy, physiology, and mechanics of human movement, the psychological aspects of athletic performance, and the introduction of research methods and statistical analysis within the field.  Students also undertake introductory practical sessions, utilizing the university's state-of-the-art facilities to apply the theoretical knowledge learned within classes.
Year 2: The second year builds upon the foundational knowledge acquired in the first year.  Students delve deeper into specialized areas within sport and exercise science, such as nutrition, strength and conditioning, or injury rehabilitation.  A significant component of the second year involves a mandatory work placement, offering practical, hands-on experience within a real-world sporting environment.   Students use this placement to establish professional contacts and further enhance their practical abilities.  This practical work is complemented by furthering the academic and research skills via specialist modules.
Year 3: The final year allows for further specialization and in-depth exploration of chosen areas of interest, developing advanced skills which are relevant to student-chosen specializations. Students undertake an independent research project that allows them to demonstrate their skills and knowledge within the subject. The research may culminate in a presentation at a major conference and students present their research findings to their peers.   In addition to applying previously gained knowledge to enhance the understanding of particular areas within the fields of sport and exercise science, students continue to develop their professional skills and abilities.

The course helps learners understand marketing's role in achieving organizational objectives and attaining a sustainable competitive advantage through industry and competition analysis. The program is assessed through 100% coursework, including essays, research reports, presentations, group work, and practical reports.
Course Structure: The course covers strategic marketing as a management process, marketing ethics dilemmas, auditing internal and external environments, stakeholder roles, marketing data analysis, identifying consumer and target markets, formulating marketing goals and objectives, developing marketing plans for commercial or social organizations, and understanding control and performance indicators.  Significant time is devoted to learning how to measure marketing outcomes. The course is delivered online through 10 weeks of structured learning, requiring approximately 20 hours of study per week.

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (minimum of 5.5 in each module)
Entry Requirement: Normally, a UK undergraduate degree (at least a 2:2) with honours in any business-related subject or an equivalent international qualification is required.  Equivalent professional qualifications are also considered. Applicants without the required academic or professional qualifications but with significant management experience and a substantial record of achievement will also be considered.  For those whose first language isn't English or who didn't complete their undergraduate degree at a UK university, an English language qualification is necessary (IELTS 6.0, TOEFL 550/213/80, Pearson 51, Cambridge Advanced Certificate Pass, London Tests of English Level 4, International GCE O Level/IGCSE English Grade C, ASE Proficiency Pass).  Pakistan-specific entry requirements for postgraduate studies include a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized Pakistani university, equivalent to at least a UK 2:1 or 2:2.  A Master's degree is also required if the Bachelor's degree is only two or three years long.  A Bachelor's degree with honors (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani University is also acceptable.
Overview: The University of Derby's online MSc in Strategic Sustainability Management equips students with the strategic leadership and management skills necessary to integrate sustainability into organizational decision-making. The program focuses on corporate sustainability, environmental impact, and strategic management, crucial elements for any forward-thinking organization.  The curriculum blends theoretical knowledge with practical application through a virtual business simulation, allowing students to test strategies in a risk-free environment.  The program also emphasizes entrepreneurship and intrapreneurship, encouraging innovation within established companies.  Internationalization is another key theme, addressing the challenges and opportunities of a globalized economy.  Graduates will be equipped for various strategic management roles in diverse sectors and organizations, capable of effectively formulating, managing, and executing sustainable business strategies.
Course Structure: The MSc comprises six core 20-credit modules, two optional 0-credit modules, and a final 60-credit independent research project. The program is structured in stages: a Postgraduate Certificate mirroring the online MSc Strategic Management, focusing on strategic thinking and leadership skills; a Postgraduate Diploma adding specialist knowledge in environmental policy, management tools, and sustainable business practices; and finally, the Masters level, where students undertake an in-depth research project based on professional interests.  The program also includes modules focused on personal development, skills transformation, and career coaching, enhancing employability further.  The curriculum is reviewed regularly to ensure its relevance and effectiveness.

Course Title: Level 6 Strategy in the Global Marketplace
Entry Requirement: Applicants need a HND, foundation degree, or equivalent in a business-related field; or 240 credits from a business-related qualification.  Other professional business qualifications like BTEC level 5, CMI level 5, Edexcel level 5, or CIMA may be considered. If English isn't your first language, you'll need an IELTS 6.0, TOEFL 550 (paper), 213 (computer), 80 (internet), Pearson Test of Academic English 51, Cambridge Advanced Certificate (Pass), London Tests of English (Level 4), International GCE O-level English Language (Grade C), or International GCSE English/English as a Second Language (Grade C).  For Pakistani students,  the entry requirements will depend on their undergraduate or postgraduate level and may require a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised University in Pakistan, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree.  A two or three-year Bachelor's degree would necessitate a Master's degree pass. A four-year Bachelor's degree with honours and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University is also acceptable for a Master's.
Overview: The Level 6 Strategy in the Global Marketplace is a short online course designed to equip students with a comprehensive understanding of strategic management within a global context.  The course focuses on strategies used by businesses to find opportunities, competitive advantages, and growth within a rapidly changing global environment.  Students will explore the impact of globalization, adaptation strategies, and response to emerging challenges and competition from both theoretical and practical standpoints.  The curriculum also covers key decision-making areas like production strategy, sustainability, innovation, change, and risk management. This course is assessed through 100% coursework including essays, research reports, presentations, group work and practical reports. In addition, virtual classrooms are held throughout the course.
Course Structure: The course examines contemporary issues affecting strategic management. The curriculum covers various aspects of strategic management and strategy formulation to enhance competitiveness in the global marketplace.  Topics include analyzing internal and external environments; understanding globalization; strategy formulation and strategic choices; employing strategic tools; mastering change and risk management; implementing strategies; production and supply chain management; integrating sustainability considerations; and leveraging innovation. The course concludes with assessment tasks such as essays, research reports, presentations, group work and more.
