Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 112 UCAS points.  A-Level students need BBC grades (including a C in a science subject like Biology, Chemistry, Physics, Physical Education, or Psychology).  BTEC students need DMM.  GCSEs require grade 4/C or above in Maths and English.  An Access to HE Diploma is acceptable with 60 credits (45 at Level 3, including distinctions and merits). International students need an IELTS score of 6.0 with at least 5.5 in each skill.  Contextual offers may adjust requirements for students who are care experienced, estranged, refugees, asylum seekers, or whose parents are in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistani students completing A-levels or IB from international schools in Pakistan, direct entry into the first year is possible.
Overview: The BSc (Hons) Strength, Conditioning and Rehabilitation degree at the University of Derby is designed to prepare students for careers in strength and conditioning, rehabilitation, and injury risk reduction within the sports industry.  The course emphasizes practical, hands-on experience using state-of-the-art facilities, including a high-tech strength and conditioning suite with VICON 3D motion capture and Kistler Force Plates. Students will learn the latest training methods, performance analysis techniques and injury prevention strategies.  The program integrates theoretical knowledge with applied experience through work placements with organizations like Derby County FC and Derbyshire County Cricket Club.  The curriculum is aligned with UKSCA accreditation guidelines, providing students with the necessary skills for professional recognition.  The program also incorporates masterclasses from established sports practitioners, enhancing employability skills. The course aims to bridge the gap between sports science and medical/injury management, equipping graduates with a comprehensive skillset for a rapidly evolving industry.
Course Structure: The course structure integrates theoretical learning with significant practical application.  Students will engage in modules covering strength and conditioning principles, exercise physiology, biomechanics, rehabilitation techniques, injury prevention strategies, and sports coaching methodologies. Practical components involve extensive hands-on training in the university's modern sports facilities, allowing students to apply their theoretical knowledge to real-world scenarios.   A mandatory professional placement is integrated into the curriculum, providing valuable practical experience in industry settings like Derby County FC and other sports clubs.  Assessment methods are varied and include case studies, presentations, field-based assessments, written assignments, and professional discussions, all reflective of industry practices. The course also incorporates regular masterclasses given by professionals in the field.
Year 1: The first year lays a strong foundation in the theoretical underpinnings of strength and conditioning, rehabilitation, and injury prevention.  Students develop an understanding of exercise physiology, biomechanics, and anatomy, providing a basis for understanding how the body responds to training and injury.  The course also introduces essential coaching principles and practical techniques, supplemented by early professional development activities such as internships and research participation.  Students will gain basic first-aid qualifications and further professional development may commence. Alongside the basic knowledge, communication skills, critical thinking skills and problem-solving skills will also be fostered.
Year 2: Year two builds upon the foundational knowledge gained in the first year, delving deeper into specialized topics.  Modules may focus on advanced strength and conditioning programming, advanced rehabilitation techniques, detailed injury assessment and management, and evidence-based practice in sports therapy and rehabilitation. Students undertake a mandatory work placement in the second year, gaining hands-on experience in professional settings and applying their academic knowledge to real-world scenarios. This placement could involve working closely with athletes, providing rehabilitation exercises, or assisting in strength training programs in settings such as elite sports teams or clinical environments.
Year 3: The final year focuses on consolidating knowledge into specialized areas and preparing students for professional practice. It may include modules on advanced research methods, practical applications of training or rehabilitation principles and career development preparation. Students are expected to integrate their knowledge into a capstone project, providing them with an opportunity to demonstrate their understanding of advanced concepts and their readiness to engage in the professional workforce.  The focus is on practical application of skills and readiness for professional employment while continuing professional development and optional placements remain available.

Course Title: BSc (Hons) Strength, Conditioning and Rehabilitation with Foundation Year
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For entry in September 2025, typical requirements include 72 UCAS points, A-Levels (DDD), T-Levels (Pass), BTECs (MMP), or an Access to HE Diploma. GCSEs in Maths and English are preferred but not mandatory. International students require an IELTS score of 6.0 with at least 5.5 in each skill area.  Students from Pakistan who have completed A-levels or the IB from international schools in Pakistan can begin from Year 1. For postgraduate study, Pakistani students need a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to at least a UK Upper Second Class (2:1) or Lower Second Class (2:2) degree.  Those with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees also need a Master's degree. A four-year Bachelor's degree with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university is considered for Masters entry. For PhD programs in Pakistan,  a Master's and Bachelor's degree in relevant subjects are needed, along with a research proposal.
Overview: The BSc (Hons) Strength, Conditioning and Rehabilitation with Foundation Year is a four-year undergraduate program designed to equip students with the knowledge and skills needed for careers in strength and conditioning, rehabilitation, and sports coaching. The curriculum emphasizes practical application, with students learning the latest training methods, techniques, and technologies in a state-of-the-art facility equipped with VICON 3D motion capture system. Students benefit from partnerships with professional sports organizations, offering work placement opportunities and exposure to real-world settings. The course focuses on maximizing athlete performance, injury prevention, and rehabilitation techniques.  The foundation year provides support for students transitioning into higher education or changing career paths. Graduates will be prepared for careers in elite and participation sport and will gain valuable transferable skills through professional development packages.
Course Structure: The course integrates theoretical learning with practical experience. Students engage in various assessments, including case study presentations, field-based assessments, written coursework, and professional discussions.  The curriculum covers a range of topics related to strength and conditioning, rehabilitation, performance analysis, biomechanics, injury prevention, and sport science. The use of state-of-the-art equipment and software ensures students stay abreast of technological advancements in the field. The program includes collaborations with professional sports teams and organizations, creating opportunities for work placements and real-world application of knowledge. Throughout their education, students are supported through a Personal Academic Tutoring program designed to enhance their academic and professional growth.  The program also incorporates masterclasses delivered by established sports professionals in the field.
Year 1: The first year of the course will lay a strong foundation in the fundamentals of sport science. This may include introductory modules in exercise physiology, anatomy, biomechanics, and sports psychology.  Students might also develop essential practical skills in movement analysis and basic exercise prescription. Basic First Aid will also be covered as part of the course. The foundation year provides extensive support to help students hone their academic and personal skills.
Year 2: The second year builds upon the first-year foundation. Students will delve deeper into the specifics of strength and conditioning, including advanced training methodologies, program design, and exercise techniques.  They may also explore injury rehabilitation principles and begin to apply their knowledge through practical assignments and case studies. It's likely that they will perform movement analysis and advanced training methods and techniques. This year would further build up on the foundations of First Aid.
Year 3: The third year involves increasingly specialized knowledge in areas like performance analysis, injury prevention strategies, and advanced rehabilitation techniques. Students will likely conduct more in-depth research projects and participate in professional development activities. The focus will likely shift more towards practical application, perhaps with a work placement or internship.  Students may also hone their skills in working individually and as part of a team.
Year 4: The final year culminates in a significant project or dissertation, showcasing the students' ability to apply previously acquired knowledge independently.  The year also may involve advanced modules relating to strength and conditioning and injury management. This final year is often tailored to the individual’s interests. There may be opportunities to explore a more specialized area of interest through specialized modules.  Throughout the program, students are encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities, strengthening their networks and career prospects.

Course Title: Level 7 Supervisory Practice and Evaluation within an Organisational Context
Entry Requirement: Applicants must be a professionally qualified, experienced (minimum 12 months post-qualification) and accredited or accreditable counsellor and/or psychotherapist.  They must demonstrate the ability to work at level 7, through previous postgraduate study.  Photographic ID is required (driving license or passport). Evidence of Higher Education level study in English Language or GCSE English Grade C is also needed.  Credit for prior learning may be possible. If English is not your first language, IELTS 7.0 or equivalent is required.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised University in Pakistan is needed, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree. Those with two or three-year Bachelor degrees must also have a Master’s degree. A Bachelor's degree with honours (four-year) and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University may also suffice.
Overview: This Level 7 postgraduate module focuses on supervisory practice and evaluation within organizational contexts in health and social care.  It equips professionals with the skills to critically evaluate their supervisory performance at individual, group, and organizational levels. The curriculum emphasizes the impact of legal, professional, and ethical considerations, and includes the practice of supervisors receiving their own supervision to enhance their expertise.  The course aims to develop the competencies needed for senior organizational supervisors and creates an understanding of the relationship between organizational culture and effective supervision. The program is beneficial to a wide range of health professionals and social workers.
Course Structure: The module covers several key areas, including performance evaluation at individual, group, and organizational levels; critical examination of legal, professional, ethical, and organizational influences on supervision; and the processes involved in supervisors receiving supervision themselves. It examines various methods for establishing supervisors’ supervisory networks, helping build strong support systems within organizations.  Additionally, the course delves into the structure and culture of organisations and their effects on supervision.  The module uses a blend of theoretical frameworks, practical exercises, case studies, and reflective practice to support learning.

Course Title: Certificate of Credit in Surgical First Assistant
Entry Requirement: Applicants must be registered practitioners with current, unrestricted registration with a relevant professional regulatory body (e.g., HCPC or NMC).  They must be employed in a UK-based perioperative environment, have experience in the scrub role, hold a degree or Diploma in Higher Education (or equivalent), and provide evidence of recent study or ability to study at a degree level. A current DBS is required, along with a completed Managers Approval Form confirming support and suitability for the extended duties.  The manager must confirm that local policy supports the SFA role, a risk assessment is complete, indemnity insurance covers the extended duties, and 100 hours of SFA practice will be provided, along with an appropriate clinical supervisor (consultant surgeon or Surgical Care Practitioner) and additional assessors. Access to diverse surgical specialties, including laparoscopic surgery, is also needed. Completion of an in-house catheterisation course is recommended.  For those whose first language is not English, an IELTS score of 7.0 (or equivalent) is required.  Under the 'Pakistan Entry Requirements', there is no specific information for this course.
Overview: The University of Derby's online Surgical First Assistant Certificate of Credit is a part-time course designed for registered healthcare practitioners (ODPs or RNs) working in UK perioperative settings.  The program equips participants with the knowledge and skills to function as Surgical First Assistants (SFAs) within the NHS or private healthcare, aligning with professional guidance (PCC 2018).  The curriculum covers a range of topics from legal and ethical considerations to crucial surgical skills such as handling instruments, tissues, and organ manipulation.  Successful completion necessitates a 3,000-word coursework submission and a clinical portfolio evidencing 100 hours of supervised practical experience.  Students will be mentored by experienced professionals and assessed by both academic assessors and clinical supervisors within their workplace.
Course Structure: The 10-week course blends online learning with supervised clinical practice.  Online modules cover legal, professional, and ethical issues; role boundaries; communication; infection control; asepsis and wound care; principles of pathology; tissue handling; patient preparation and positioning; instrument handling; tissue and organ manipulation; surgical haemostasis and suction; catheterization; and minimal access surgery skills.  The clinical practice component involves 100 hours of supervised practice, documenting competency in enhanced surgical skills, and culminates in a clinical portfolio alongside a 3000-word written assignment.

Overview: The MSc Sustainability and Environmental Management is an online program designed for professionals seeking to advance their careers in environmental management and sustainability.  The program covers a wide range of topics, including environmental policy, sustainable business practices, and the tools and techniques needed to address environmental challenges.  Students will develop critical skills in areas such as corporate governance, environmental business cases, communication and reporting, and sustainable value chain management.  The curriculum is accredited by IEMA and CIWEM, providing access to valuable resources and potentially fast-tracking professional membership. The program emphasizes a blend of theoretical knowledge and practical application, preparing graduates for leadership roles in various sectors.
Course Structure: The MSc program comprises a Postgraduate Certificate stage (three core modules), a Postgraduate Diploma stage (three core modules + three optional modules), and a Masters stage (Postgraduate Certificate and Diploma plus an Independent Scholarly Activity, a 60-credit module). Core modules cover fundamental aspects of environmental management and sustainability. Optional modules allow for specialization based on individual interests and career goals.  The Independent Scholarly Activity involves a substantial research project or dissertation. The program is highly flexible, with students studying approximately 20 hours per week. Course Title: MSc Sustainable and Ethical Business Management (Block Delivery)
Entry Requirement: A good honours degree (minimum 2:2) or equivalent qualification is normally required, along with at least three years of work experience in a mid-level or senior management role relevant to the program's outcomes.  Applicants with three years of relevant mid-level or senior management experience and effective communication and learning skills will also be considered.  For those whose first language is not English, IELTS 6.5 or equivalent is required.  The program leader and staff panel will review applications, considering qualifications, work experience, job role, career development opportunities, and learning opportunities within the applicant's organization. A virtual interview and employer endorsement letter may also be required. For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognized Pakistani University (equivalent to a UK Upper Second Class (2:1) or Lower Second Class (2:2) degree) is needed; those with two- or three-year Bachelor's degrees must also have a Master’s degree pass. A Bachelor’s degree with honors (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university is considered for Master's entry.
Overview: The MSc Sustainable and Ethical Business Management is a postgraduate program designed for mid-level to senior business professionals seeking to integrate sustainability and ethical considerations into their organizations.  The curriculum focuses on aligning business strategy, leadership, operations, marketing, finance, and human resources with environmental, social, and economic sustainability goals.  The program uses a seminar-led approach, incorporating real-world case studies, work-based learning, and insights from industry experts and researchers across various disciplines. The program's unique aspect is its holistic approach to integrating sustainability throughout the business functions, addressing social,environmental, and economical aspects simultaneously. Students will develop leadership skills and a sustainability mindset, learning to balance economic success with global sustainability challenges and ethically driven decision-making.
Course Structure: The program is structured in three stages: Postgraduate Certificate, Postgraduate Diploma, and MSc. The Postgraduate Certificate involves modules covering the case for sustainable and ethical business practices, sustainable and ethical business strategies, and leading sustainable and ethical change. The Postgraduate Diploma adds modules on sustainable operations and marketing, sustainable workforce and wellbeing, and sustainable finance and accounting. The MSc stage culminates in an independent study project focusing on a sustainable leadership or responsible management problem or a journal article on ethical or sustainable business.  The program also includes work-based learning components, empowering students to implement learned concepts in their own workplaces. The content is delivered through seminar-based block sessions while leveraging online resources and collaboration.
Year 1: Year 1 (Postgraduate Certificate Stage) focuses on building a foundation in sustainable and ethical business practices. Students delve into the justification for these practices, exploring frameworks for value-driven organizations and responsible strategies. Key modules include 'The Case for Sustainable and Ethical Business,' 'Sustainable and Ethical Business Strategy,' and 'Leading Sustainable and Ethical Change,' which cover leadership development within a sustainable context.
Year 2: Year 2 (Postgraduate Diploma and MSc Stage) deepens the understanding of integrating sustainability across functional areas of business. 'Sustainable and Ethical Business Operations and Marketing' explores environmentally and socially conscious operational and marketing strategies.  'Sustainable Workforce and Wellbeing' addresses employee wellness within a sustainability framework. 'Sustainable and Ethical Finance and Accounting' examines financial management from an ethical and sustainable standpoint. The final independent study project allows for specialization and application of knowledge to a real-world context.

Overview: The MSc Sustainable and Ethical Business Management equips students with the skills and mindset to lead the transition towards responsible business practices. Students will learn to develop resilient, purpose-driven organizations that prioritize people, planet, and profit.  The curriculum blends theoretical knowledge with practical application, providing students with real-world experience through projects, case studies, and industry collaborations.  The program also includes Carbon Literacy certification, fostering a responsible and impactful business leadership approach. Graduates will be prepared to drive positive change and contribute to a sustainable global economy. The program is designed to cater to the needs of a rapidly evolving business landscape.

The teaching methodology is diverse, utilizing techniques like tutor-facilitated learning, industry case studies, business improvement projects, guest lectures, simulations, and generative AI. Students engage in critical reviews of academic and industry literature, and conduct relevant research.  Carbon Literacy certification is also part of the program's structure. The curriculum is developed with extensive involvement from various University research centres and industry networks to ensure relevance and workplace preparation.

Students develop their independent research skills through dedicated modules.  Throughout the year, real-world applications are emphasized through case studies, industry projects, and simulation exercises designed to enhance practical skill application.

Overview: The MSc Sustainable Architecture and Healthy Buildings program integrates scientific theories and design principles for healthy buildings and environments. It covers sustainable design analysis within building information modeling, critical analysis of low-energy design, government legislation, and professional standards.  Students explore the broader context of sustainability, including socio-cultural, economic, and governance factors.  The program features live projects, field trips, and workshops, offering practical experience and providing opportunities for research collaboration with industry professionals. Overview: The University of Derby's Systems Ergonomics Certificate of Credit is a 10-week online course designed for professionals such as nurses, occupational therapists, physiotherapists, engineers, and designers who want to expand their knowledge of ergonomics. This course focuses on macro-ergonomics and the organizational context, exploring how individual performance and competence are ensured through staff selection and development.  It examines crowd behavior and how systems affect performance, health, and well-being. Completing this course allows students to deeply understand ergonomic approaches to problem analysis and system design, critically analyze systems to identify ergonomic benefits, and apply human factors perspectives to event analysis and prevention. The course is CIEHF accredited and taught by experienced academics with over 20 years of online course delivery expertise.  The program emphasizes comprehensive learning and practical application.
Course Structure: The course is delivered 100% online across ten weeks through interactive learning materials and live classroom sessions.  Students engage with tutors and peers in live virtual classroom sessions and online discussion forums.  The curriculum encompasses macro-ergonomics, organizational context, individual performance, staff selection, and development. Crowd behavior and the impact of systems on performance, health, and well-being are also key elements. The instruction blends theoretical concepts with practical applications, fostering collaborative learning and individual understanding. The learning materials and activities are intended to facilitate a direct application of the knowledge and theories learned to the student's work context.  Evaluation involves various assessment methods, such as essays, research reports, presentations, group work, and practical reports.

Entry Requirement: For 2025 entry, typical requirements include 112 UCAS points, A Levels BBC, BTEC DMM, GCSE Maths and English Grade 4/C or above, or a Pass Access to HE Diploma with 60 credits (45 at Level 3). Contextual offers may apply to care experienced students, estranged students, refugees/asylum seekers, or students whose parents are in the UK armed forces.  For Pakistani students, A-levels or IB from Pakistani international schools allow entry into Year 1. Postgraduate entry requires a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK Upper or Lower Second Class, and a Master's degree for two- or three-year Bachelor's degrees.  A four-year Bachelor's degree with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university will also be considered for a Master's degree.
Location/Campus: Derby Theatre, Markeaton Street, Derby Campus
Annual Tuition Fee: UK: £9,535 per year (2025/26); International: £16,900 per year (2025/26)
Overview: The BA (Hons) Technical Theatre and Performance Design is a three-year undergraduate program based at Derby Theatre, a professional working theatre.  The course provides hands-on experience in technical theatre and performance design, integrating traditional techniques with emerging digital technologies such as AI, XR, and VR. Students collaborate on live productions, work with industry professionals, and develop skills in stage management, production management, lighting, sound, video, CAD, and costume and set design.  The curriculum emphasizes sustainability, accessibility, inclusivity, and community engagement, fostering creative and critical thinking alongside technical expertise.  Graduates will be equipped for freelance work, employment, or postgraduate study.
Course Structure: The course integrates practical, studio-based learning with lectures and seminars. Students work on live and speculative briefs, ranging from micro-projects to full-length productions.  Modules cover contemporary theatre and performance, stage technology, production and project management, design-led theatre, performance design, interactive storytelling, lighting, sound and projection design, the ethical application of AI and XR technologies, sustainable theatre, stage and production management, costume and set design, site-specific design, immersive narrative, practice-research, and creative coding.  Collaboration and professional skills development are central to the curriculum.
Year 1: The first year would likely involve foundational modules in theatre practices, introductory design principles (lighting, sound, set, costume), and basic technical theatre skills. Students would begin to develop collaborative skills and an understanding of the technical and creative processes involved. There's an emphasis on building fundamental knowledge and familiarity with the tools and machinery within a professional theatre environment. Students also participate in workshops and smaller-scale projects alongside learning about the industry and theatre design practices.
Year 2: Year two could involve more specialized modules, focusing deeper into chosen areas like lighting design, sound design, stage management, or costume design.  Students would work on more complex projects, potentially involving collaborations with external partners.  This year often includes a group project with a real-world brief, testing teamwork, critical thinking, and project management capabilities. More practical workshops, masterclasses, and field trips expand industry insight and skills.
Year 3: The final year would focus on independent projects, allowing students to specialize further and demonstrate their accumulated expertise.  This might include a major design project, a production management role for a large-scale production, or independent research.  The curriculum includes reflective practice assessments and preparation for professional practice.  Students would likely develop their portfolio, refine their creative vision, and build their professional networks.

Overview: The BA (Hons) Theatre Arts program at the University of Derby is a three-year, full-time course based at Derby Theatre, a professional theatre venue.  The program focuses on developing practical theatre skills in acting, directing, and devising, preparing students for professional careers in the theatre industry. Students work alongside industry professionals, gaining valuable experience and networking opportunities through workshops, performances, and potential professional work experience within Derby Theatre or partner organizations. The course emphasizes practical learning through studio-based exercises, major performance projects, and the study of contemporary performance practices.  Students participate in public performances in various settings, contributing to their professional portfolios.
Course Structure: The curriculum integrates practical, studio-based work with lectures and seminars. Key areas of study include acting techniques, directing methods, devising strategies, analysis of theatrical movements, and new writing processes, with an emphasis on workshop-based learning and practical, assessed rehearsals.  Students may participate in student-led theatre companies and have access to masterclasses.  Assessment involves a mix of written coursework, presentations, creative portfolios, and public performances. The course is underpinned by the professional production programme of Derby Theatre, providing students with real-world experience in a professional theater environment.
Year 1: The first year likely introduces foundational acting techniques, basic directing principles, an overview of theatrical history and theory, and early experience with devising work and collaborative theatre-making. Students will begin building their performance skills and receive introductions to key aspects of stagecraft and technical aspects of theatre production. This might involve smaller-scale performances or workshops to refine skills.
Year 2: The second year likely progresses to more advanced acting styles and directing techniques. Students may focus on developing specific skills and interests within theatre, such as stage management or design. More complex performance projects and research-based work are likely part of the curriculum.  Students will be expected to handle greater responsibility in productions and potentially undertake leadership roles within their collaborative projects.
Year 3: The final year will typically see a focus on major performance projects, allowing for advanced practical application of skills and specialization in areas of interest. Students may undertake in-depth research projects, leading to a thesis or extended portfolio.  There's likely an emphasis on final-year productions, which might include community engagement or more extensive touring experiences.  Placement opportunities and portfolio development are vital aspects of this final year.

Overview: The BA (Hons) Theatre Arts with Foundation Year at the University of Derby is a four-year program based at the Derby Theatre, a fully equipped professional theatre.  Taught by practicing professional artists, the course emphasizes practical, hands-on learning alongside theoretical study. Students develop skills in acting, directing, devising, and technical theatre, through workshops, performances, and collaborative projects. The program provides opportunities for professional work experience within Derby Theatre or partner organizations and involves public performances in a variety of venues.  The program aims to equip students with the skills and experience needed for a successful career in the theatre industry.
Course Structure: The course combines practical, studio-based exercises, workshops, performances, and lecture-based learning.  Students undertake major performance projects, studying devising strategies, case studies, and analyzing theatre movements and practices.  The curriculum covers various aspects of theatre-making, including rehearsal strategies, directing, dramaturgy, new writing, and contemporary performance practices. Students also complete coursework subject to academic criticism.  The course is underpinned by the professional production program at Derby Theatre providing real-world experience within a working theatre environment.
Year 1: The first year of the course lays the foundation for theatre studies. It may include introductory modules in acting techniques, movement, voice training, stagecraft, and foundational theatre theory.  Students are introduced to collaborative theatre-making processes, learning basic elements of directing and design. This will be a combination of practice based work and lectures.
Year 2: Year two builds upon the foundational skills developed in the first year. Students likely explore more advanced acting techniques, delve deeper into devising and directing practices, investigate different theatrical styles and genres, and engage in collaborative projects, including smaller-scale productions. There will be a combination of practical and theoretical sessions.
Year 3: The third year allows for specialized study and further skill development.  Students may choose modules to focus on areas of greater interest, potentially including playwriting, stage management, costume design, or other technical aspects.  There will likely be more significant collaborative projects and the opportunity to work with professional theatre practitioners. This will be a combination of practical and theoretical sessions.
Year 4: The final year is focused on developing a professional portfolio and preparing for post graduation employment.  This likely includes a major project, internship or placement and further develop skills acquired in previous years.  The experience will help students gain confidence, develop a professional network and prepare for future career opportunities. This will be a combination of practical and theoretical sessions.

Course Title: Level 7 Theoretical Considerations in the Diagnosis and Management of Osteoporosis
Required IELTS Score: NA
Entry Requirement: Students must hold a professional healthcare qualification and be eligible to register with the relevant professional board.  Those without a BA/BSc should be a healthcare professional with at least two years of clinical experience in Osteoporosis, DXA, or Falls.  For Pakistani students, requirements vary depending on their previous qualifications.  Undergraduate applicants from Pakistani International schools completing A-levels or the IB can enter directly into the first year.  Postgraduate applicants need a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK Upper or Lower Second Class degree.  Those with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees also need a Master's degree.  A four-year Bachelor's degree with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University is acceptable for Master's entry.  PhD applicants need both a Master's and Bachelor's degree in a relevant subject area and must submit a research proposal.
Overview: This Level 7 postgraduate certificate module provides healthcare professionals with a comprehensive theoretical understanding of osteoporosis.  The course delves into the pathophysiological processes, diagnostic procedures, and treatment options for this increasingly prevalent condition.  Students will critically evaluate current practices and develop their ability to identify and manage patients at risk of osteoporosis and fragility fractures.  The module also examines the impact of osteoporosis on individuals and society, preparing healthcare professionals to effectively diagnose and manage this disorder and to contribute to improvements in care delivery. The program is ideal for health and social care professionals seeking to enhance their skills in managing osteoporosis, regardless of whether they work in general or specialized settings.
Course Structure: The course covers the epidemiology of osteoporosis and fragility fractures, emphasizing their societal impact.  It delves into the diagnostic process, linking it to the identification of high-risk patients. Treatment and management options available to healthcare professionals are analyzed. Finally, students critically evaluate the quality and delivery of care within clinical practice. This module provides a strong theoretical foundation for preventing and managing fractures, equipping students to become agents of change in their respective healthcare settings.

Course Title: Level 7 Theory and Practice of Appendicular Reporting
Entry Requirement: Applicants typically need a 2:1 or higher science or health-related degree.  They must also demonstrate English language proficiency equivalent to IELTS 7.  Two years of post-registration experience is required, along with current registration with the HCPC or NMC.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized university equivalent to at least a UK Upper Second Class (2:1) or Lower Second Class (2:2) is needed.  Those with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees require a Master's degree pass. A Bachelor's degree with honors (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university is considered for Master's entry.
Overview: This Level 7 short course focuses on the theory and practical application of appendicular skeletal reporting in the healthcare field. Students learn the anatomy, physiology, and pathophysiology of the appendicular skeleton (including the pelvis), correlating clinical manifestations with radiological findings.  The course emphasizes diagnostic reasoning and the generation of structured, accurate clinical reports.  It includes reflective practice, knowledge gap identification, and peer learning through a problem-based approach.  Successful completion aids in applying for advanced practice status.  The majority of the study is work-based, requiring a portfolio including a logbook and reflective practice evidence. The course is for health professionals with at least two years of postgraduate experience and regular access to radiographic images and radiology support.
Course Structure: The course utilizes a structured approach to learning about appendicular skeletal anatomy, physiology and pathophysiological processes.  Students engage in self-audit and reflective practice, addressing identified knowledge gaps individually and collaboratively.  A significant portion of the learning takes place in the workplace, leading to a portfolio that includes a logbook and evidence of reflective practice. Problem-based learning within group settings contributes to the portfolio and promotes independent learning after course completion. The advanced practice framework underpins the module content and assessment, supporting applications for advanced practice status.

Entry Requirement: A good first degree in a related subject is required.  Applicants with professional qualifications or relevant experience may also apply.  If English is not your first language, you will need an IELTS score of 6.0, a TOEFL score of 550 (paper-based), 213 (computer-based), or 80 (internet-based); a Pearson Test of Academic English score of 51; a Cambridge Advanced Certificate pass; a London Test of English level 4; an International GCE O-level English Language grade C; or an International GCSE English/English as a Second Language grade C.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized university is equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree. Overview: This postgraduate Certificate of Credit focuses on equipping environmental professionals and organizations with the tools and techniques to address environmental challenges sustainably.  The course covers various environmental management systems (EMS), conducting environmental audits, pollution linkages and impacts, and team-based application of these skills.  It is designed to enhance professional portfolios and provide a critical understanding of environmental problems and sustainable solutions. Students will develop proficiency in environmental management tools while learning from experienced academics and collaborating with other students in a global community.
Course Structure: The course consists of one 20-credit module that covers environmental policy, environmental law, and the practical application of environmental management systems and audits. The teaching methodology incorporates online learning materials, live virtual classroom sessions, and online discussion forums that allows for interaction and feedback from instructors and fellow students.  Assessment is 100% coursework-based, including essays, reports, presentations, group work, and practical reports. The course duration is ten weeks and requires around twenty hours of study per week.  Half of the virtual classrooms are held live within the ten weeks, with recordings available for those who can't attend. This course is accredited by CIWEM, providing free student membership with access to resources, networking opportunities, and career development advantages.

Overview: This online short course in Transfusion Medicine is designed for individuals with a background in biomedical science or healthcare.  It provides a comprehensive understanding of the transfusion process, covering blood group systems, donor screening, blood donation and component preparation, and immunohaematological aspects. The course explores transfusion science, including basic scientific laboratory immunohaematology, blood processing, transfusion, and governmental policies on managing adverse reactions. The course aims to equip learners with knowledge of blood collection, donor requirements and screening, blood component preparation and storage, and relevant legislation and guidelines.
Course Structure: The course comprises three units, each requiring approximately 2-3 hours of study.  Unit 1 focuses on basic transfusion science, including major blood group systems, antibodies, transfusion hazards, and haemovigilance. Unit 2 covers laboratory testing of blood and components, donor requirements, blood donation, screening, component preparation, and storage. Unit 3 details British Committee for Standards in Haematology (BCSH) guidelines for blood and component use and the role of information technology in blood transfusion practice. Learning involves reading, quizzes, short videos, and reflective written tasks.  There is no graded assessment; instead, learners receive a badge for each completed unit and an e-certificate upon course completion.

The curriculum covers investigation and critical evaluation of different treatment modalities in hand therapy, justification of modality choices based on individual patient needs and biopsychosocial factors, and critical evaluation of the benefits and limitations of each modality.  Students also critically reflect on their own professional practice.  The program aims to improve collaborative practices among occupational therapists and physiotherapists by providing them with a thorough understanding of each other’s roles and methodologies within the multidisciplinary hand therapy team. The course is particularly beneficial for healthcare professionals seeking to improve collaborative practices, streamline patient care, and enhance their individual professional skill sets.
Course Structure: The course consists primarily of online learning modules, incorporating work-based practical application.  Students will explore a variety of treatment modalities employed by occupational therapists and physiotherapists, undertaking detailed assessments of their effectiveness and limitations.  Significant emphasis is placed on the critical analysis of individual patient cases, incorporating biopsychosocial factors into the decision-making process for treatment modality selection. Finally, there is a reflective component encouraging students to critically evaluate their current professional practice and identify areas for improvement. The course culminates in an assignment that demonstrates a comprehensive understanding of the subject matter and the student's ability to apply learned principles to practical scenarios. Overview: The University of Derby's Triathlon Assessment Package is a short course designed for athletes of all levels, from beginners to elite performers.  The program offers a comprehensive assessment battery focusing on cycling and running performance.  It provides detailed physiological testing, including body composition analysis, cycling efficiency measures (gross efficiency and FatMax), critical power and anaerobic work capacity assessments, running economy analysis, and lactate threshold determination through blood lactate and gas analysis. The goal is to deliver personalized training insights, such as specific training zones, performance predictors, and identification of strengths and weaknesses to maximize athletic performance.
Course Structure: The course involves a battery of tests designed to provide a comprehensive assessment of an athlete's triathlon performance.  These include body composition assessment; cycling assessment, focusing on efficiency and power metrics using advanced gas analysis; resting blood analysis for hematocrit and hemoglobin levels; running assessment, including running economy evaluation and lactate threshold determination via a 3-minute step test and ramp protocol involving blood lactate and gas analysis.  The results are used to develop a personalized training plan.

Course Title: Level 7 Ultrasound in Early Pregnancy Assessment
Required IELTS Score: NA
Entry Requirement: For this module, applicants must be studying or have completed the Principles of Medical Ultrasound module (or an equivalent qualification).  They must also have access to a minimum of two days per week of supervised scanning practice with a named ultrasound mentor. Entry is subject to discussion with the module leader and completion of a practice-based agreement.  Specific entry requirements for Pakistani students are not explicitly detailed on the provided webpage, but generally, postgraduate applicants from Pakistan must hold a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognized university, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree.  Those with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees need a Master's degree pass. A four-year Bachelor's degree with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university is also considered for entry.
Overview: This postgraduate-level module, accredited by CASE, is designed for sonographers, nurses, midwives, obstetricians, and gynecologists who provide early pregnancy assessment services.  The course aims to develop competent, reflective, and autonomous practitioners capable of safely and effectively using ultrasound in early pregnancy assessment.  The curriculum focuses on building skills in interpreting ultrasound images from both trans-abdominal and trans-vaginal scans, identifying normal and high-risk pregnancies, and assessing early pregnancy complications.  The module includes approximately 200 learning hours, with five days of on-campus teaching/tutorials and directed study, supplemented by a minimum of 14 hours per week of supervised clinical placement for practical scanning experience.
Course Structure: The course structure includes structured on-campus sessions, directed study time, and extensive supervised clinical placement.  The on-campus component covers theoretical knowledge and practical skills training related to ultrasound techniques and interpretation in early pregnancy.  The main focus is on developing competence in the safe and effective use of ultrasound to assess various situations in early pregnancy including detecting complications and managing high-risk pregnancies.  The clinical placement provides an essential opportunity to apply the skills learned in a real-world environment under the guidance of an experienced mentor. The curriculum emphasizes practical skills development, critical analysis of ultrasound findings, and the capacity to contribute effectively to a multi-disciplinary healthcare team.  Participants will learn to assess patients' needs, analyze and report ultrasound findings, and propose service improvements. The course strongly incorporates skill development in communication and patient care.

Course Title: Professional Certificate in Ultrasound of the Hips, Lumps and Bumps
Required IELTS Score: NA
Entry Requirement: To attend this course, applicants must be experienced ultrasound users or relevant point of care specialists.  There is no mention of specific entry requirements such as IELTS, TOEFL, or PTE scores. For Pakistani students, the provided text mentions undergraduate and postgraduate entry requirements for different programs at the university generally, but does not provide specific entry requirements for this particular short course.  The general postgraduate requirements for Pakistani students include a relevant Bachelor’s degree equivalent to a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree, or a four-year Bachelor's degree with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university.  Students with a two or three-year Bachelor's degree need a Master's degree pass.  PhD applicants must have a master's and bachelor's degree in relevant subject areas along with a research proposal.
Overview: This one-day professional certificate course in ultrasound focuses on the practical application of ultrasound scanning techniques for hips, lumps, and bumps.  The course combines presentations, live demonstrations, and hands-on practical sessions guided by experienced musculoskeletal (MSK) sonographers.  Participants will learn about anatomy, physiology, clinical assessment, the interpretation of normal and pathological ultrasound findings, and report generation. The course is designed for experienced ultrasound users or point of care specialists who wish to enhance their skills in this area. The program aims to provide practical, hands-on training, enabling participants to confidently apply ultrasound technology in a clinical setting. The educational outcome is improved competence and confidence in using ultrasound for accurate diagnosis and assessment.
Course Structure: The course follows an intensive one-day format. The curriculum is structured around a blend of theoretical and practical components. The day will consist of presentations that cover the foundational knowledge needed for interpreting ultrasound scans. This is followed by live demonstrations by expert practitioners, showcasing best practices in using ultrasound technology for diverse clinical situations. The major focus is on hands-on practical sessions, where participants work under direct supervision to gain experience applying ultrasound to real-world scenarios, strengthening their skills in diagnosis and assessment.  The course provides structured opportunities for feedback and learning from experienced sonographers, leading to refined clinical skills applicable to patient care. Finally, the participants will learn techniques for accurate and effective reporting of their ultrasound findings after interpreting the images.

For undergraduate programs, an IELTS score between 6.0 and 7.0 or a TOEFL score of 79-100 is required. Postgraduate programs require an IELTS score of 6.5 with at least 5.5 in each section, or a PTE score of 60. PhD programs need an IELTS 7.0 (with 7.0 in writing and 6.5 minimum in other sections), a TOEFL score of 100 (with a minimum score of 27 in writing, 20 in speaking, and 19 in other skills), or a PTE score of 76 (with at least 71 in other skill areas).  Pakistan-specific entry requirements include A-Levels or IB for undergraduates from Pakistani international schools, while postgraduates need a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK 2:1 or 2:2.  A Master's degree is also required for those with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees.  Four-year Bachelor's degree holders with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.0 are considered. PhD applicants need a Master's and Bachelor's degree in a relevant subject, along with a research proposal.

Participants will gain knowledge of shoulder anatomy and physiology, clinical assessment techniques, and the identification of normal and pathological ultrasound findings, alongside accurate reporting methodologies. The course aims to enhance participants' skills and knowledge in performing and interpreting shoulder ultrasounds and improve patient care.  The curriculum focuses on practical application and expert guidance to ensure participants develop proficiency in this crucial diagnostic imaging technique.

Presentations provide foundational knowledge and theoretical understanding of relevant anatomy, physiology, and clinical assessment methods. Live demonstrations by MSK sonographers showcase the techniques and interpretations.  Hands-on practical scanning sessions allow participants to practice their skills under expert supervision, receiving real-time feedback and refining their techniques. The curriculum culminates in an understanding of reporting techniques for accurate diagnosis. The course emphasizes practical experience to translate knowledge into clinical proficiency.

Course Title: Certificate in Understanding Autism, Asperger's and ADHD
Required IELTS Score: NA
Entry Requirement: There are no formal entry requirements for this free online short course.  The course is open to anyone regardless of age, location, or educational background. Access to the internet and a valid email address are required for registration and participation.  Specific entry requirements under the Pakistan Requirements heading are not applicable to this course because this is a free short course, not a degree program. The course materials are designed to be accessible; the learning platform is compatible with screen reader technology to assist those with visual impairments.
Duration: 18 CPD hours (6 units, 3 hours of study per unit)
Overview: This free online short course provides an introduction to autism, Asperger's Syndrome, and ADHD.  It explores the differences between these conditions, their diagnostic criteria, and the nuances of assessment and classification. The course challenges common assumptions, examining the sometimes-blurred lines between these conditions and encouraging critical thinking about diagnosis and treatment methods in the UK and internationally.  Participants will improve their understanding of autism and ADHD, which is helpful for anyone working with or around these neurodevelopmental disorders.  The course is flexible, self-paced, and suitable for those in health and social care settings, education sectors, as well as families impacted by autism and ADHD.
Course Structure: The course comprises six units, each taking approximately three hours to complete. Unit 1 focuses on ADHD and hyperkinetic disorder, covering symptoms, subtypes, and diagnostic criteria. Unit 2 explores autism spectrum disorder, including its symptoms, prevalence, assessment, and diagnosis, differentiating it from Asperger's.  Unit 3 delves into classification, assessment, and diagnostic processes in the UK. Unit 4 examines aetiology, theories, and causes of ADHD and autism. Unit 5 addresses comorbidity, investigating overlapping symptoms and considering the differences between ADHD and autism. Finally, Unit 6 focuses on treatment approaches for both conditions, encompassing medication, behavioural interventions, treatment challenges, and support groups.

Required IELTS Score: NA
Entry Requirement: There are no formal entry requirements for this free online course.  Access to the internet and a valid email address are needed to enroll.  The course is open to anyone regardless of age, location, or educational status.  For those interested in further study in journalism at the University of Derby, prospective students from Pakistan who have completed A-levels or the International Baccalaureate from Pakistani international schools may enter a Bachelor's degree program.  Postgraduate applicants from Pakistan must hold a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK  'Upper Second Class (2:1)' or 'Lower Second Class (2:2)' degree, or a four-year Bachelor's degree with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University. Those with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees additionally require a Master's degree pass. PhD applicants need both a Master's and Bachelor's degree in a relevant subject plus a research proposal.
Overview: This free online course from the University of Derby provides an introduction to the key debates and principles of journalism ethics.  It explores the history and evolution of journalism, examining its foundational principles and controversies.  The course delves into press standards, regulation, and the challenges faced by journalists.  It incorporates insights from various stakeholders such as the Ethical Journalism Network, the National Union of Journalists, and press regulators. The course aims to enhance media literacy and critical thinking skills related to the news media, but it doesn't aim to train students to become journalists. The course is suitable for anyone wanting to learn more about the news media, journalistic practices, ethical standards, the regulation of journalism in the UK, and the history of journalism from varied perspectives.
Course Structure: The course consists of three units, each requiring approximately four hours of study for a total of 12 hours. Unit 1: Journalism and its Promise introduces basic principles and concepts along with its historical development. Unit 2: Broken Promises? examines instances where journalism has failed to adhere to its principles and addresses controversies that have affected the field. It delves into press standards, regulation, accuracy, and threats to journalists. Unit 3: How can journalism be improved? explores ways to improve journalism by analyzing current problems and public trust. It uses recent research and proposes solutions to these issues.

Required IELTS Score: NA
Entry Requirement: The University Certificate in Concrete Technology is designed for a wide range of applicants, including those working in the cement, ready-mixed concrete, and concrete products industries with significant experience but limited qualifications.  It also suits construction employees with higher education qualifications in related subjects who need more technical knowledge of concrete, employees in testing laboratories, and those in related supply and equipment manufacturing industries.  Certain learners may receive exemptions from Module 1 if their qualifications reflect best practices; examples include the University of Derby's Diploma/Foundation Degree in relevant areas, City and Guilds Parts 2/3 qualifications, or higher qualifications in civil engineering encompassing concrete technology.  Applicants must demonstrate English language proficiency equivalent to GCSE English Language. Learners should be employed or affiliated with an employer, nominated by their line manager, and deemed capable of succeeding on the program.  The University adheres to equal opportunities policies.  For those applying from Pakistan, the requirements mirror those of other applicants, though the specific degree qualifications needed from Pakistani Universities to qualify for exemption from Module 1 should be discussed with program staff.
Overview: The University Certificate in Concrete Technology is a part-time, blended learning program designed to meet the needs of professionals in the concrete industry.  The flexible program incorporates online learning materials combined with face-to-face sessions at a corporate environment. Course content focuses on the practical application of knowledge and aims to bridge the gap between theoretical understanding and real-world application. The program aims to equip learners with a comprehensive understanding of concrete technology, its global and environmental context, and best practices related to health, safety, and sustainability. Graduates will be equipped to improve efficiency and sustainability in their organization and the concrete industry overall.
Course Structure: The program is structured into three modules. The first module, "Introduction to Concrete," covers fundamentals such as aggregates, cement, concrete standards, specifications, testing methods, mix design, and product quality management. The second module, "Properties of Concrete," delves into detailed concrete technology, including specifications for durable concrete in challenging conditions and various test methods for fresh and hardened concrete. Health, safety, and environmental aspects during design and management are also addressed.  The final module, "Production, Use and Control of Concrete," explores concrete use and control as a construction material, examining the requirements of various uses like precast and prestressed concrete. Assessment of and repairs to concrete structures and an introduction to sustainable practices are also covered.  Learning is achieved through a blend of face-to-face teaching with structured discussion and reflection, workplace-based learning, group activities, and online learning via a virtual learning environment.
Year 1: The University Certificate in Concrete Technology is a one-year part-time program.  The first and only year covers three modules: Introduction to Concrete, Properties of Concrete, and Production, Use and Control of Concrete. These modules provide a comprehensive understanding of concrete technology, from the basic properties of aggregates and cement to the advanced aspects of mix design, testing, and construction practices. The curriculum is heavily focused on practical application, encouraging students to connect their learning with real-world situations through projects and assignments.
Year 2: NA

Course Title: University Diploma in Asphalt and Pavement Studies
Entry Requirement: The program is designed for operational managers, assistant managers, supervisors, graduate employees in related fields (like mining engineering or geology), industry suppliers/manufacturers, and consultants.  Key entry criteria include employment or affiliation with an employer, nomination by a line manager or recruitment manager, organizational identification of potential for success, adherence to the University's equal opportunities policies, demonstration of English language capability equivalent to GCSE English Language or IELTS 6.0, completion of a University of Derby application form, and being 18 or older upon commencement.  For Pakistani students, specific requirements are not explicitly detailed on the provided webpage but general University guidelines may apply.  For postgraduate programs generally, a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised University in Pakistan equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree is needed. Students with a two or three-year Bachelor's degree must also have a Master's degree. A Bachelors degree with honours (four-year) with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani university may be sufficient for Masters consideration.
Overview: The University Diploma in Asphalt and Pavement Studies is a flexible, part-time program designed to meet the needs of professionals in the mineral products industry. It uses a blended learning approach, combining online materials with face-to-face sessions at the University of Derby's Enterprise Centre. The curriculum focuses on asphalt technology, pavement solutions and innovation, and contracts management.  Optional modules in business and operational management, and a work-based project, provide opportunities for specialization and practical application.  The program aims to develop learners' knowledge and understanding of the industry, equip them with managerial and technical skills, and enhance their ability to respond to change and adopt sustainable practices.  It is suitable for individuals seeking to improve their competence, specialize in the sector, or gain a broader understanding of the mineral products environment.
Course Structure: The program's structure includes core modules in Asphalt Technology, Pavement Solutions and Innovation, and Contracts Management.  Asphalt Technology covers the basics of asphalt pavements, including design, testing, production, transport, and placing mixtures, as well as health, safety, and environmental considerations. Pavement Solutions and Innovation deals with specialized applications, binders, and sustainability concepts such as circular economy and lifecycle assessments. Contracts Management explores the legal and commercial aspects of the construction industry and related contracts.  Optional modules in Business and Operational Management (which includes concepts like asset management, sustainable business building, and cybersecurity) and a Mineral Products Work-based Project allow students to tailor their learning to their interests and career goals. Assessment methods vary, including practical projects, reports, presentations, and e-assessments.
Year 1: The first and only year of this part-time diploma program covers the core modules: Asphalt Technology, focusing on asphalt pavement technology, mixture design, testing, production, and environmental aspects; Pavement Solutions and Innovation, which explores specialized asphalt mixtures, sustainable practices, and innovations in the field; Contracts Management, covering construction contracts, estimation, organization, and relevant legal aspects.  Students also have the opportunity to take an optional module in Business and Operational Management or the Mineral Products Work-based Project, depending on individual needs and career goals.

Overview: The University Diploma in Cement Studies is a part-time, one-year program designed to equip learners with comprehensive knowledge and skills in the cement industry.  The flexible, blended learning model combines online resources with face-to-face sessions at the University of Derby's Enterprise Centre, catering to the diverse and geographically dispersed nature of the industry and its workforce. The curriculum focuses on cement raw materials processing, cement process engineering, and cement clinker processing, providing a strong theoretical base and practical application through assessments directly related to workplace challenges and activities.  The program emphasizes agile delivery, advanced learning technology, and work-based learning principles, fostering independent learning, critical thinking, and reflective practice. Optional modules in business and operational management and a work-based project further enhance the learning experience.
Course Structure: The program incorporates modules on Cement Raw Materials Processing, focusing on raw material extraction and preparation for kiln feed. Cement Process Engineering emphasizes efficient fuel use and energy management in cement production, including waste stream utilization.  Cement Clinker Processing focuses on grinding and blending cement types, including composite cements with additions. Optional modules include Business and Operational Management, which further develops business and financial skills plus human resources matters, asset management and sustainability aspects and finally the Mineral Product Work-based Project, which requires a detailed analysis of a problematic area within the student's workplace using academic and professional literature. The program uses a variety of teaching and assessment methods, including face-to-face sessions, online learning, action learning sets, individual reflection, and a range of assessments including projects, reports, presentations, portfolios, and e-assessments.
Year 1: The first year of the University Diploma in Cement Studies covers core modules in Cement Raw Materials Processing, Cement Process Engineering, and Cement Clinker Processing.  These modules provide a comprehensive understanding of the entire cement production process, from raw material extraction and preparation to the final product. Students also have the option to take additional modules in business and operational management, and a work-based project that tackles a real-world challenge within their respective workplaces.  The assessment methods are varied and include projects, technical reports, and presentations, enabling students to demonstrate their knowledge and skills in practical settings.

Overview: The University Diploma in Clay Studies is a flexible, part-time program designed for professionals in the mineral products industry. It addresses the geographically dispersed nature of the industry, utilizing blended learning (online and face-to-face) to cater to diverse learners. The curriculum focuses on practical skills and theoretical knowledge relevant to clay extraction, processing, and product manufacturing.  It emphasizes workplace application through assessment methods such as practical projects and reports and aims to equip learners with management and technical skills, fostering critical thinking and professional development. The program welcomes individuals with varying backgrounds and experience levels, seeking to enhance their skill sets and operational effectiveness within the mineral products sector. The program is also designed to promote continuous learning and leadership skills, equipping students to address modern day challenges and build sustainable businesses.
Course Structure: The Diploma in Clay Studies is composed of several modules, focusing on different aspects of the clay production process.  These include "Clay Evaluation and Investigation," covering the identification and evaluation of clay sources; "Clay, Winning, Preparation, and Forming," detailing extraction, processing and molding techniques; and "Clay, Drying, and Firing," covering the methods and principles involved in drying and firing clay products to create finished goods.  Optional modules available include "Business and Operational Management" providing a necessary business background to operations, and "Mineral Products Work-based Project."  The program utilizes various teaching methods, combining face-to-face sessions, workplace-based learning, and online resources. Assessment methods encompass a range of approaches including practical projects, reports, presentations, portfolios, and e-assessments.
Year 1: The first year of the University Diploma in Clay Studies covers three core modules: Clay Evaluation and Investigation, Clay, Winning, Preparation and Forming, and Clay, Drying and Firing. Clay Evaluation and Investigation focuses on techniques to identify potential clay sources and considerations for site development, including geological and environmental factors. Clay, Winning, Preparation and Forming covers extraction, processing, and molding methods. Clay, Drying and Firing explores drying and firing methods, addressing the chemistry, economics, safety, and quality control aspects of these processes. Students can also choose to study optional modules including Business and Operational Management and the Mineral Products Work-based Project.

Overview: This Level 7 module in Vascular Ultrasound is designed for healthcare professionals aiming to provide comprehensive routine and emergency vascular ultrasound services. The curriculum covers vascular screening and surveillance.  The intensive program combines seven full days of on-campus teaching and tutorials with significant directed study.  Successful completion requires a minimum of 14 hours (two days) per week of supervised clinical placement for practical scanning experience.

Course Title: Level 7 Working in a Differing Field of Practice
Required IELTS Score: 6.5 with a minimum of 5.5 in all areas
Entry Requirement: To be eligible for this course, you must be a qualified nurse registered with the NMC on the third part of the register as a School Nurse or Health Visitor.  The University of Derby's general entry requirements state that for postgraduate programs, an IELTS score of 6.5 with a minimum of 5.5 in all areas is needed.  For Pakistani students, a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised University in Pakistan equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree is required. Those with a two or three-year Bachelor's degree need a Master's degree pass. A four-year Bachelor's degree with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University also qualifies.
Overview: This postgraduate module, "Working in a Differing Field of Practice," is designed for nursing practitioners who already hold the Specialist Community Public Health Nursing (Health Visitor / School Nurse) Award. The course focuses on providing students with a broad understanding of specialist public health service nursing provision.  Through reflective practice and portfolio development, students will deepen their knowledge base and demonstrate proficiency in meeting the Nursing and Midwifery Council Standards of Proficiency.  A critical assessment of skills and knowledge acquired, along with an action plan, forms a foundation for meeting current and future Continued Professional Development (CPD) requirements. The program aims to build a strong understanding of the wider implications of specialist public health practice and allow students to work across a wider range of public health nursing practice.
Course Structure: The course involves a 26-week program focused on reflective learning and portfolio development.  Students will complete a personal skills analysis to benchmark their competencies. The core component is the creation of a portfolio showcasing evidence of practical work, meeting the NMC standards. This is substantiated by a mentor's report.  Self-assessment and feedback from practice teachers, mentors, and academic staff guide the student in developing an action plan for successful module completion.  The development of critical thinking skills for future practice is a key learning objective.
Year 1: NA
Year 2: NA

Entry Requirement: Applicants need to demonstrate prior study at Level 5 or above in a related field (health and social care, social work, health promotion, or youth work).  They must also be healthcare professionals or have access to an environment to apply learned skills (voluntary work is acceptable).  English language proficiency is required.  Acceptable qualifications include GCE O level English Language C, GCSE English C, IELTS 7.0, TOEFL (various scores), Pearson Test of Academic English 66, Cambridge Advanced Certificate (Pass), London Tests of English (Level 4), International GCE O Level English Language Grade C, or International GCSE English/English as a Second Language Grade C; other equivalents with supporting evidence may also be considered.  Pakistan-specific entry requirements are not detailed on the provided webpage, but general requirements for postgraduate study in the UK may apply.  These typically require a relevant bachelor's degree from a recognised university, equivalent to at least a UK Upper Second Class (2:1) or Lower Second Class (2:2) degree.  Students with two or three-year bachelor's degrees may need a master's degree as well.
Overview: The online Level 6 short course "Working with Vulnerable People" equips students with the knowledge and skills necessary to identify, assess, and manage risk and vulnerability in health and social care settings.  The course covers a wide range of concepts, including safeguarding, disability, inequality, poverty, mental health, substance abuse, and different forms of abuse and violence (familial, child, adult, partner). It examines the policy, legal, and ethical perspectives surrounding vulnerability, providing students with practical tools and frameworks for assessment and risk management. The curriculum emphasizes collaborative analysis, inter-professional perspectives, and the development of effective communication and intervention strategies.  The course aims to foster critical thinking, ethical decision-making, and the ability to work effectively with vulnerable populations in complex situations.  Successful completion allows for the transfer of credits towards a BSc (Hons) Top-Up degree.
Course Structure: The course content spans various critical areas in working with vulnerable people. Students will learn about the political and social dimensions of abuse, neglect, and violence.  The curriculum delves into hidden and underreported forms of harm, including familial violence, violence toward children and vulnerable adults, and partner violence. The impact of ethnicity and cultural relativism will also be examined. Students will analyze serious case reviews to learn from past failures in this field. Additionally, risk assessments and vulnerability modeling will also be included in the overall curriculum. Students learn to analyze the effectiveness of interventions. The course also includes information about different populations with special vulnerabilities, including migrant and asylum-seeking children, sexually exploited and trafficked children,  individuals with disabilities, and people experiencing poverty or fabricated illnesses. Effective communication and building relationships across age groups will be taught. The modules address legal and policy frameworks pertinent to vulnerability and safeguarding, including topics like oppression, stigma, and stereotyping.  The program emphasizes best practices and ethical considerations to tackle vulnerabilities from a multi-faceted perspective.
