Course Title: Level 7 Work Based Learning - Negotiated Module
Required IELTS Score: NA
Entry Requirement: For this postgraduate module, students must be health professionals.  The University of Derby's general postgraduate entry requirements for international students include an IELTS score of 6.5 with a minimum of 5.5 in all areas or a PTE score of 60.  Specific entry requirements for Pakistani students include a relevant Bachelor’s degree from a recognised University in Pakistan, equivalent to at least a UK ‘Upper Second Class (2:1)’ or ‘Lower Second Class (2:2)’ degree. Students with a two or three-year Bachelor's degree also need a Master's degree pass. A Bachelor's degree with honours (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) with a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognised Pakistani University is considered for entry.  This module is work-based, requiring participants to identify an area of theoretical study relevant to their practice.
Overview: The Level 7 Work Based Learning - Negotiated Module is a postgraduate module designed for healthcare professionals seeking to enhance their specialist knowledge.  Participants undertake in-depth theoretical research on an individually negotiated topic relevant to their practice and service needs. The module emphasizes applying theoretical understanding to improve services.  The coursework involves evaluating existing service needs, developing an investigative strategy, critically analyzing theoretical perspectives, and disseminating findings to colleagues or service users through a chosen method (poster, report, presentation, etc.).  The flexible, online module utilizes a learning contract and offers support through email and telephone tutorials but with specified mandatory contact points.
Course Structure: This module is highly individualized. Students work with the university to develop a learning contract which specifies their area of study and assessment methods. The curriculum is not predefined. The module consists of 200 total learning hours, mainly independent study utilizing online learning materials, and the primary course structure is guided by the learning contract.  Students are expected to conduct in-depth research concerning their chosen topic, evaluating the needs of their workplace and critically evaluating relevant theoretical perspectives which will then inform and improve their service provision within their organisation.  A significant portion of the module involves dissemination of findings to a target audience (multi-professional team, managers, service users etc) through various methods such as writing a report or presentation.

Course Title: Level 7 Work Based Project - Health, Psychology and Social Care
Required IELTS Score: NA
Entry Requirement: Applicants usually require 5 years of post-professional qualification experience.  For Pakistani students seeking postgraduate study, a relevant Bachelor's degree from a recognized university is needed, equivalent to at least a UK Upper Second Class (2:1) or Lower Second Class (2:2) degree. Those with two or three-year Bachelor's degrees must also have a Master's degree. A Bachelor's degree with honors (four-year BA, BBA, BSc, BEng) and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 from a recognized Pakistani university may also qualify for entry to a Master's degree.  PhD applicants need both a Master's and Bachelor's degree in a relevant subject, along with a research proposal.
Overview: This Level 7 Work Based Project module allows health professionals to link their workplace project achievements to academic credit.  It focuses on developing project leadership and management skills transferable between professional and academic settings. Students will negotiate how their project meets module outcomes, providing evidence of meeting practical and academic criteria. The module is designed to enhance critical thinking, applying learned knowledge to improve multidisciplinary practice, and generating practice recommendations.  The course emphasizes originality, planning, implementation, and project evaluation, all guided by practice and academic facilitators.
Course Structure: The course primarily revolves around a work-based project undertaken by the student.  Students will identify a project aligned with their professional role and demonstrate how it fulfills the module's learning outcomes through evidence-based work.  Guidance is provided by both a professional practice facilitator and an academic facilitator. The project's management aspect must meet both workplace and academic standards, demanding a critical evaluation of knowledge application within professional and multidisciplinary contexts.  The final component is generating practical recommendations based on findings.

Course Title: Writing and Researching the Political Economy of Inequality
Required IELTS Score: NA
Entry Requirement: This free online course is open to anyone interested in the topic, but it's designed for postgraduate students and early career researchers focused on the political economy of inequality.  There are no formal entry requirements, such as specific degrees or IELTS/TOEFL scores.  However, some grounding in (International) Political Economy or related disciplines is recommended.  For those in Pakistan, the course description does not provide specific entry requirements.  The only requirements are that you have access to the internet and a valid email address to register for the course.
Overview: This course provides a comprehensive introduction to researching and writing about the political economy of inequality.  It's designed to equip postgraduate students and early career researchers with the conceptual and practical skills needed to conduct research in this complex field.  The course covers defining and measuring inequality, establishing research questions, conducting literature reviews, employing various data collection methods (both qualitative and quantitative) and effectively disseminating research findings.  Participants will develop their research skills and gain confidence in their abilities. The focus is on building a solid understanding of the subject matter and advancing research skills throughout the process.
Course Structure: The course is structured into seven units. Unit 1 focuses on defining and measuring inequality, establishing a foundational understanding of the subject and diverse ways to measure it. Unit 2 analyzes inequality across different time periods, geographical locations, and social scales. Units 3 and 4 guide participants in forming effective research questions and conducting thorough literature reviews using resources such as Google Scholar. Units 5 and 6 focus on practical research methods, covering both qualitative (interviews, observation) and quantitative (secondary data, questionnaires) approaches.  Finally, Unit 7 addresses research dissemination and impact, explaining how to tailor research findings for various audiences and maximizing the research's impact.

Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For September 2025 entry, typical requirements include 128 UCAS points.  A-Level students need ABB (with at least a C in Biology), while BTEC students need DDM.  T Level students require a Merit.  A GCSE grade 4/C or higher in Maths and English is also necessary.  An Access to HE Diploma with 60 credits (45 at Level 3) is acceptable, with a minimum of 15 distinctions, 24 merits, and 6 passes.  Specific Level 3 subjects must be passed.  International students will have different requirements. For Pakistani students, A-levels or IB from Pakistani international schools allow direct entry into Year 1. Postgraduate entry requires a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to a UK Upper or Lower Second Class degree, plus a Master's degree if the Bachelor's is two or three years.  A four-year Bachelor's with honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4/4.00 is also considered. PhD applicants need a Master's and Bachelor's degree in a relevant field, along with a research proposal.
Overview: The University of Derby's BSc (Hons) Zoology program is designed to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of the animal kingdom. The course is deeply rooted in practical application, incorporating fieldwork, laboratory work, and research projects that allow students to explore various aspects of zoology.  Special emphasis is given to conservation, animal behavior, ecology, and genetics. Students will develop strong intellectual, technical, and personal skills, aligning with the UN's Sustainable Development Goals. The program features fieldwork opportunities across the UK and internationally, and includes access to specialized facilities, providing real-world experience and research capabilities that prepare students for a variety of careers in the biological sciences.  The program's strong industry ties provide great work experience opportunities, including potential placements or internships. As one of the first of its kind accredited by the Royal Society of Biology and accredited degree pathway status from the Chartered Institute of Ecology and Environmental Management, this program offers graduates a strong professional foundation.
Course Structure: The Zoology BSc (Hons) curriculum is a three-year (full-time) course, covering foundational and advanced topics in animal biology.  It integrates theoretical learning with hands-on practical work, fieldwork opportunities, and research projects. Students will learn about subjects such as animal behavior, ecology, genetics, conservation, and related fields.  The specific course modules are regularly reviewed and updated to improve the learning and career prospects of the graduates, so refer to University's website for exact module list. Throughout their studies, students will benefit from the expertise and supervision of research-active lecturers, enabling them to take part in ongoing experiments and projects.  The course culminates in an independent research project.
Year 1: The first year introduces fundamental concepts in zoology and related biological sciences. Students will build a solid foundation in subjects such as animal physiology, ecology, genetics, and cell biology.  Introductory laboratory sessions will help develop experimental and observational skills, and the year may include preliminary fieldwork opportunities. Lectures and tutorials are used, supported by structured practical classes.
Year 2: Year two builds upon the foundation from the first year. More advanced modules will cover topics such as animal behavior, conservation biology, and evolutionary biology. Students will gain advanced laboratory techniques and likely participate in an extended fieldwork project, possibly abroad depending on module selection. The curriculum also includes introductory modules covering research design and statistical analysis.
Year 3: The final year provides advanced specialized study, allowing students to tailor modules to their career interests. A major component is an independent research project that allows for in-depth exploration of a subject in an area of personal interest; students may also participate in work placements during year three.  Students could also develop skills in scientific writing and communication through essay writing, poster presentations, and professional reports. The year might include further fieldwork opportunities.

Course Title: Undergraduate Zoology with Foundation Year BSc (Hons)
Required IELTS Score: 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skills area)
Entry Requirement: For entry in September 2025, typical requirements include 72 UCAS points, A Levels (DDD), T Level (Pass), BTEC (MMP), or an Access to HE Diploma. GCSE Maths and English are preferred, but Level 2 courses can be taken if needed.  International students need an IELTS of 6.0 (with at least 5.5 in each skill).  For Pakistani students with A-Levels or IB from international schools in Pakistan, direct entry to Year 1 is possible. For postgraduate study, a relevant Bachelor's degree equivalent to at least a UK 2:1 or 2:2 is needed; a Master's degree is required for two- or three-year Bachelor's degree holders. A four-year Bachelor's with Honors and a minimum GPA of 2.4 from a recognized Pakistani university qualifies for Masters programs. PhD applicants require a Master's and Bachelor's degree in a relevant field, along with a research proposal.
Annual Tuition Fee: UK: £9,250 per year; International: £16,900 per year
Overview: The University of Derby offers a four-year BSc (Hons) Zoology with Foundation Year. This program is designed to equip students with a strong understanding of animal biology, covering various topics such as wildlife conservation, ecology, animal behavior, genetics, biochemistry, and statistics.  The curriculum blends theoretical learning with extensive hands-on experience through laboratory work, fieldwork, and optional placements or internships. Students develop essential practical and intellectual skills, preparing them for careers in diverse fields or further studies. The program distinguishes itself with its accreditation from the Royal Society of Biology and its focus on global initiatives like the UN Sustainable Development Goals, promoting sustainable practices in zoology.
Course Structure: The course is structured to provide a comprehensive understanding of zoology. Students will begin with fundamental principles of biology progressing into specialized modules that include wildlife conservation, animal behaviour, ecology and genetics, as well as laboratory and fieldwork.The curriculum includes a foundation year designed to strengthen skills and knowledge before entering the core modules of the degree.  Optional modules allow students to tailor their studies to specific career ambitions. A significant component of the program involves practical experiences, ranging from fieldwork trips (costs included in tuition) to placements at partner organizations like Sea Life and the Derbyshire Wildlife Trust.
Year 1: The foundation year strengthens fundamental scientific knowledge and skills relevant to zoology, covering introductory biology, chemistry, and mathematics.  Students develop essential lab techniques, scientific writing, and data analysis skills. The year also includes workshops designed to enhance study skills and confidence for university-level work.
Year 2: Year two builds upon the foundation, introducing core zoological concepts such as animal physiology, ecology, evolution and behaviour.  Students engage in fieldwork, applying learned techniques to real-world scenarios. This year includes laboratory-based practical modules and individual projects to provide a deeper insight into studying zoology.
Year 3: Third year allows for the optional application for a placement year with partner organisations, applying classroom learnings to practical situations. Modules focus on specialized areas of zoology, allowing students to tailor their studies to suit their career aspirations.  Advanced fieldwork techniques are also introduced.
Year 4: The final year combines advanced zoology modules with an independent research project. Students have the opportunity to specialize in one area, conducting research under the guidance of academics.  The year also incorporates training in professional skills like writing scientific reports and giving presentations.
